webTitle: Tony's still winning the ratings war

fields.headline: Tony's still winning the ratings war
fields.standfirst:
He complains about soap-opera politics, but the Prime Minister did much to create it and continues to profit from it
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Inside politics: He complains about soap-opera politics, but the Prime Minister did much to create it and continues to profit from it
fields.body:
My initial reaction was to think that the producers of Downing Street, an everyday story of power folk, had gone too far this time.

When audiences began to droop last autumn, they threw at us an accidental pregnancy. Fresh life was injected into this ancient device of soap opera by giving it a cruel twist. As Cherie radiantly swelled with child, her husband's career went pear-shaped. His Hamletesque indecision about taking paternity leave was accompanied by the fiasco of the Dome's opening night, the triumph of Ken Livingstone and the winter emergency in the health service.

By yet more wicked irony, the birth of little Leo coincided with even more curses on his father. From the moment of Dad's cooing appearance outside Number 10, clutching that coffee mug just too tweely emblazoned with a picture of his three elder children, things have gone from bad to worse. Ever since the handbagging by the WI, I've been wondering how they would rescue the show's flagging ratings and respond to the critics vituperative attacks on the credibility of the central character.

I didn't think even Alastair Campbell, whom everyone assumes to be the chief scriptwriter, would have the nerve to come up with a denouement like this. The Prime Minister makes a dreadful hash of Question Time, at which he is mercilessly mocked for his fatuous idea of on-the-spot fines for drunken nuisances. That very night, the police bring his eldest son back to Number 10 in the early hours of the morning having found Euan legless. It would have to be - of all clichéd locations - the vomitorium of Leicester Square. You couldn't make it up.

When the Prime Minister complains that the media is obsessed with 'soap-opera politics', as opposed to 'real politics', he has a point. The country is enjoying the magic combination of sustained growth, low inflation and high employment. Inward investment is at record levels. The real disposable incomes of the great majority are rising. Most people, as Harold Macmillan almost said, have never had it so good.

That gets far less column inches and airtime than the misadventures of one 16-year-old.

Paradoxically, the absence of anything that would genuinely answer to the overworked label of crisis is part of the Government's problem. When real politics lacks life-and-death drama, the punters search for alternative entertainment.

The soap-sudding of politics may be something to deplore, but Tony Blair is particularly ill-placed to complain because he and those who advise him have long exploited the celebritisation of public life. In an ideologically bland age, questions of character become bigger than clashes of ideas. Combine that with a media which have the attention span of a goldfish and you get the ravenous appetite for the politics of the personal. When he was running for the leadership of his party, Tony Blair made a little note to himself of his selling propositions as a personality, the prominent bullet points being that he was young, a Christian and had a strong family. Much as he complains about it, he has always had a lively appreciation of how to use soap operatics.

'The kids' have been regularly invoked in his rhetoric. The Millennium Dome was famously set a 'Euan test'. Was he delivering his verdict when he puked up? The Prime Minister appeared on the soft sofa of Richard and Judy to face a toe-curling interrogation about the cellulite on his wife's legs. The wholesome, Bisto ad togetherness of the Blair family has been used to market the Prime Minister as a regular kind of guy, a bloke like you or yours, who just happens also to be the leader of his country.

Whenever he says, as he has said a lot, that his family keep him 'normal', Tony Blair implicitly suggests a superiority to all those unbalanced bachelors in politics like - to pluck a name at random - Gordon Brown.

The entire Government has become something of a soap opera. Compared with previous administrations, this Cabinet is one of the most ideologically united. In place of serious intellectual strife, there is personal bitchiness and backbiting, the crockery smashing and kiss-and-make-ups which are the staple of soap. It is entirely typical that the divisions between Ministers over the single currency are not so much to do with principle and strategy as about tactics entwined with personality. Spiky Uncle Robin loathes brooding Uncle Gordon who hates serpentine Uncle Peter. There's a sub-plot entirely devoted to the decline of lovable but difficult Auntie Mo.

When there is no great clash of ideas, then the politics of gossip, about which Ken Follett complained in these pages last week, becomes dominant.

The Prime Minister is hoping that the forthcoming result of the comprehensive spending review will reassert the primacy of real politics. Unprecedented levels of investment in education and transport, on top of that already announced for health, will be a testimony to baseline strength. At a point in the cycle where previous Labour governments were slashing and burning, this government will be building as it approaches the next election.

I fear, however, that Tony Blair will be a disappointed man if he thinks he can end the soap-opera politics which he has helped to create. The modern audience wants bread from its leaders. But it demands circuses, too. His winning talent has been to provide both.

The latest episode of Downing Street has actually played rather attractively for the Prime Minister. As a father, there's no question it was a pretty horrible night, waiting for Euan to be brought home, looking after him as he chundered up his guts, and then sheepish father and son explaining to Cherie how it had been allowed to happened.

As a politician, it has turned out so well for the Prime Minister that the cynics even jokingly wonder whether Alastair Campbell didn't have a hand in tanking up young Euan. The gentle mockery - will David Blunkett order the Blairs to attend remedial classes in effective parenting? - is good for Tony Blair. Just at the moment when the air is thick with accusations that he is a sanctimonious, manipulative autocrat, the Prime Minister is seen to be vulnerable. He looks humbled - and he does humility well. This is what the audience wants of the soap-operatic leader. He has to be both extraordinary and ordinary; a superman who bleeds.

For the man playing the role, there is a large personal cost. It is hard enough work being a father and a Prime Minister. He must combine those parts with being a 24-hour-a-day actor as well. Soaps are an intensified, exaggerated and accelerated pastiche of real life. Tony Blair sounds used up by the strain. 'I know it's only been three years,' he told that sympathetic audience of evangelical Christians. 'Sometimes it seems like 30.'

That suggestion of exhaustion, with its hint of early retirement, may have played music for Gordon Brown. But I don't think the audience are ready to give up Tony Blair. There is a lot of life left in this drama. And what is the alternative viewing? Among the Tories, only Michael Portillo, with his revelations of a gay past and his attempts to reinvent his character, grasps the soap-operatic dimension of politics. The childless William Hague and Ann Widdecombe are minority tastes; cable TV, not mainstream terrestrial viewing. The rest of the Conservative front bench is famous only for its anonymity.

Will the mass audience flip channels to Deadenders ? No, I don't think so. The majority of viewers will want to know what happens next in Tony's soap.

fields.headline: The hidden target
fields.standfirst:
The scalp the Orangemen really want to collect is Trimble's, writes Henry McDonald
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Comment: The scalp the Orangemen really want to collect is Trimble's, writes Henry McDonald
fields.body:
Drumcree is Ulster's Hebron. The fields around the nineteenth century Anglican church on the edge of Portadown are as important to Protestant loyalists in Northern Ireland as the West Bank town in the occupied territories is to Jewish extremists.

For those extreme loyalists opposed to the Good Friday Agreement Drumcree is a cultural and religious citadel where the final battle with the republicans and a British government will take place later today. Losing the siege of Drumcree would be as disastrous for Protestant extremists as the loss of Hebron would be for Jewish settlers opposed to the Middle East peace process.

The issue appears to be the Orange Order's call to return from Drumcree parish church along their traditional route back to Portadown town centre - the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road. For five years Catholic residents have campaigned against the march traversing their area.

As the dispute reached its annual climax this weekend, there seemed to be little chance of resolving these two conflicting positions.

Behind the dispute, however, lies another issue at the very heart of the Northern Ireland peace process. For the man who represents Drumcree at Westminster is the Province's First Minister and Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble. And pro-Agreement loyalists and unionists are in no doubt that the real target of the Orange Order's standoff at Drumcree is Trimble.

David Ervine, the leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, which is linked to the Ulster Volunteer Force terror group, accused the Order on Friday of attempting to undermine Trimble.

'I think the head of Trimble is the big issue. Anti-Agreement forces are at work,' Ervine said. The former UVF prisoner was in no doubt where the strategy to topple Trimble came from - the Orange Order's ruling body, the Grand Lodge of Ireland.

'The last thing Grand Lodge want is a parade down Garvaghy Road. I mean, they want this to be the Alamo, they want this to be their hunger strike, they want this - almost in a ludicrous sense, to give them the opportunity for the phoenix to rise from the ashes,' he said.

Brian Kennaway, a Presbyterian Minister and former member of the Order's Education Committee, agrees.

'This is not about the right to march on a road. I am convinced that elements in Grand Lodge want to use this to destabilise the power-sharing executive and endanger Trimble's leadership,' said Kennaway.

At the core of the controversy at Drumcree is the Order's stubborn refusal to talk directly to Catholic residents hemmed in behind a massive ring of steel and barbed wire around the Garvaghy Road.

In particular the Orangemen refuse to engage in direct dialogue with the residents' spokesman, the former IRA prisoner Brendan MacCionnaith.

Their opposition to dialogue is the main reason why the Parades Commission, the quango set up by Tony Blair to mediate in parades disputes, has banned today's march along the road.

The Order claims that it does not talk to terrorists, past or present. However, when it comes to loyalist terrorists, it takes a rather different view. Last Monday night Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair was given a hero's welcome at Drumcree.

Among those cheering the former commander of the Ulster Freedom Fighters from Belfast's Shankill Road were Orangemen and women protesting on the hill.

No one from the Order asked Adair and his cohorts to stay away. As with extremist settlers on the West Bank, terrorists are terrorists only when they come from the other side.

Among those Orangemen calling for militant action against the ban last week was Mark Harbinson from Stoneyford in County Antrim.

While a church service was taking place last Sunday in Drumcree, Harbinson shouted about the siege being 'Ulster's Alamo' and the time for war being now.

Last November Stoneyford Orange Hall, of which Harbinson was a keyholder, was raided by the RUC. Detectives found British military intelligence files stolen from Army headquarters in Lisburn, which included information on republican suspects.

The find was a major embarrassment to the Orange Order in County Antrim. Harbinson was arrested and questioned over the incident and was later released without charge.

The standoff at Drumcree has produced the annual round of hijackings, riots and gun attacks on the security forces. Last Tuesday gunmen fired shots at RUC cars in Belfast's Lower Shankill area. According to well informed loyalist sources the snipers belonged to the UFF.

'There were three incidents during which they opened fire on the police. I know for a fact that on the third occasion a very senior UFF actually fired the shots,' said one loyalist source.

A detective who has led the fight against loyalist and republican terrorism over the 20 years painted a nightmare scenario following Drumcree Sunday.

'All our informants on the loyalist side, all our intelligence, points to a new strategy after Sunday. They will kill a Catholic a day until the Orangemen get down the Garvaghy Road. Kill a Catholic a day in any part of Northern Ireland - it's as simple as that,' the senior RUC officer told The Observer .

'They' are a loose alliance of the UFF from west and north Belfast alongside its South East Antrim brigade in a new coalition with the Loyalist Volunteer Force, the terror group founded during the 1996 Drumcree standoff by the late Billy Wright.

The security forces are convinced that UFF and LVF units will resume sectarian assassinations, using a cover-name to avoid blame.

There is a lot at stake for UFF and LVF leaders. Their remaining prisoners in the Maze could stay there if Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, decides their organisations are in breach of their ceasefires. But there is also a lot to gain for both organisations including supremacy over the more pro-Agreement UVF and the control of the drugs trade in Protestant areas.

There are others willing to use the standoff to de-stabilise Northern Ireland and create a crisis that could eventually destroy the power-sharing coalition involving Sinn Fein Ministers. A senior UVF figure told The Observer that he thought there were elements inside and on the fringes of Orangeism goading the UFF and LVF into returning to violence.

He said he feared that if other loyalists were killing Catholics then this would inevitably draw in the IRA, which could lead to pressure on Trimble's UUP to resign from the Government.

Trimble pointedly refused yesterday to comment on claims that his leadership and strategy are the real targets at Drumcree.

The Upper Bann MP supports the Orangemen's right to walk along the Garvaghy Road.

The ambiguity within Orangeism regarding loyalist terror and violence was highlighted again on Friday evening when Harold Gracey, the district Master of Portadown spoke to reporters at Drumcree. Gracey declined to condemn loyalist street violence throughout last week.

His remarks gave the British Government some comfort as they would alienate many law-abiding Orangemen who were wavering over whether or not to come to Drumcree this weekend. But in Northern Ireland as in the Middle East it only takes a dedicated, violent minority to de-stabilise peace. Loyalists may go on the rampage later today both at Drumcree and in other parts of the Province. They may even start killing again in a bid to provoke the IRA back to war.

The sixth Drumcree standoff is the final test for No Unionism in its strategic aim of destroying the Good Friday peace agreement.

Ulster's Hebron could become David Trimble's hubris.

webTitle: The poison at the heart of the Orange Order

fields.headline: The poison at the heart of the Orange Order
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Comment: One of the most enduring myths of the Troubles is that the conflict was never about religion. The present battle over Drumcree is a conflict about territory and identity, of loss of status and rights.
fields.body:
One of the most enduring myths of the Troubles is that the conflict was never about religion. The present battle over Drumcree is a conflict about territory and identity, of loss of status and rights. Yet it is no coincidence that this dispute takes place in a rural Protestant redoubt like Portadown,where images of Bible, faith and Crown are as commonplace as the balaclava and Kalashnikov.

For a significant minority both inside and on the fringes of the Orange Order, the struggle at Drumcree is another battle in the age-old war between the forces of light (reformed Protestantism) and the forces of darkness (Popery).

It is no coincidence that the LVF, the one terrorist faction which insists on its members attending religious services and reading the Good Book, was spawned at Drumcree. The LVF, for all its involvement in sectarian criminality and extortion, represents what can be called 'evangelical loyalist terrorism'. It believes that it is not only fighting to defend the Union but also the Protestant faith.

In rural areas of Ulster, there is a sizeable faction of Protestants and loyalists who regard Catholics and nationalists as an ever-present danger to both their temporal and spiritual well-being. One of the most truculent Protestant preachers is Pastor Alan Campbell, a former member of Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterian Church, who has since set up his own religious grouping which regurgitates the fantasy that the people of Ulster are the lost tribe of Israel.

Campbell has penned a raft of anti-Catholic pamphlets with titles such as 'The Beast Has a Banner'. In his taped sermons, he refers to Catholics as 'people of the wafer God'.

Some might dismiss the likes of Campbell as sectarian cranks but as John D. Brewer points out in his chilling book, Anti-Catholicism in Northern Ireland: 1600-1998, anti-Catholic ideology is a robust virus, which replicates in times of crisis for the Ulster Protestant community.

Brewer's thesis is that anti-Catholicism has survived in Northern Ireland because it helps define territories and excuses Catholic inequality and Protestant privilege.

The durability of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, with its connections to the Free Presbyterian Church, is evidence that the ideology of anti-Catholicism still plays a leading role in unionism. Those who have tried to sever the link between religion and the union, such as the Progressive Unionist Party, have paid a heavy price. Their opponents in the DUP, Orange Order and LVF have, with some success, attempted to portray the PUP as 'godless atheists' .

None of the above is to suggest that the majority of evangelical Christians are hate-filled anti-Catholics. There are thousands of genuine, peace loving Christians. One of the most sincere evangelicals is Billy Mitchell, the former UVF life-sentence prisoner who practises his Christianity on the streets of North Belfast, where he works with nationalists to cool sectarian tempers. Nor should this exposé of anti-Catholicism excuse the sectarian defender strain within northern republicanism, in particular the Provisional IRA. When it has politically suited them, the Provos have exploited sectarian divisions.

None the less, anti-Catholicism lies at the root of Orange thought and not unionism; it remains a potent force. Worst of all, its final logical terminus is eliminationist, just as anti-Semitism was in Germany.

After all, if you believe that Catholic men, women and children will burn in the fires of Hell if they do not convert to the true faith, what's wrong with petrol-bombing their homes and burning them out of your streets?

It believes that it is not only fighting to defend the Union but also the Protestant faith. In rural areas of Ulster, there is a sizeable faction of Protestants and loyalists who regard Catholics and nationalists as an ever-present danger to both their temporal and spiritual well-being. One of the most truculent Protestant preachers is Pastor Alan Campbell, a former member of Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterian Church, who has since set up his own religious grouping which regurgitates the fantasy that the people of Ulster are the lost tribe of Israel. Campbell has penned a raft of anti-Catholic pamphlets with titles such as 'The Beast Has a Banner'. In his taped sermons, he refers to Catholics as 'people of the wafer God'. Some might dismiss the likes of Campbell as sectarian cranks but as John D. Brewer points out in his chilling book, Anti-Catholicism in Northern Ireland: 1600-1998, anti-Catholic ideology is a robust virus, which replicates in times of crisis for the Ulster Protestant community. Brewer's thesis is that anti-Catholicism has survived in Northern Ireland because it helps define territories and excuses Catholic inequality and Protestant privilege. The durability of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, with its connections to the Free Presbyterian Church, is evidence that the ideology of anti-Catholicism still plays a leading role in unionism. Those who have tried to sever the link between religion and the union, such as the Progressive Unionist Party, have paid a heavy price. Their opponents in the DUP, Orange Order and LVF have, with some success, attempted to portray the PUP as 'godless atheists' . None of the above is to suggest that the majority of evangelical Christians are hate-filled anti-Catholics. There are thousands of genuine, peace loving Christians. One of the most sincere evangelicals is Billy Mitchell, the former UVF life-sentence prisoner who practises his Christianity on the streets of North Belfast, where he works with nationalists to cool sectarian tempers. Nor should this exposé of anti-Catholicism excuse the sectarian defender strain within northern republicanism, in particular the Provisional IRA. When it has politically suited them, the Provos have exploited sectarian divisions. None the less, anti-Catholicism lies at the root of Orange thought and not unionism; it remains a potent force. Worst of all, its final logical terminus is eliminationist, just as anti-Semitism was in Germany. After all, if you believe that Catholic men, women and children will burn in the fires of Hell if they do not convert to the true faith, what's wrong with petrol-bombing their homes and burning them out of your streets?

fields.headline: Hooligan ban Bill alarms police
fields.standfirst:
Officers fear fans will sue if Straw's 'unworkable' plan is passed by MPs

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Police expressed alarm last night about 'knee jerk' plans to ban football fans from going abroad merely because they have offensive tattoos or are 'being unpleasant'.
fields.body:
Police expressed alarm last night about 'knee jerk' plans to ban football fans from going abroad merely because they have offensive tattoos or are 'being unpleasant'.

Senior sources at the Police Federation, which represents 125,000 rank-and-file officers told The Observer that many provisions of the emergency legislation announced on Friday by Home Secretary Jack Straw are unworkable. Members were particularly concerned at planned powers to ban unconvicted fans they 'suspect' of violence.

The proposals have been attacked by civil liberties groups, which say that giving police draconian powers to stop people travelling abroad could contravene human rights legislation. The federation now agrees with some of the groups' criticisms.

Straw hopes to rush the Football (Disorder) Bill through Parliament before the summer break at the end of the month. The new powers would then be in place before England's friendly match against France in Paris in October.

'Timescale is the key issue,' a federation source said. 'We do not want to get into dangerous dogs syndrome' - a reference to legislation rushed through Parliament in the Nineties to curb animal attacks. Police are still smarting about this law which embroiled them in a bureaucratic nightmare.

'The problem is that you legislate in haste and repent at leisure,' the source said. 'What we need is proper consultation on this so that we do not give ourselves a complete legal headache.'

The frosty police response risks scuppering an important plank of the Government's attempt to seize the initiative on crime.

Last week the Prime Minister was left embarrassed after chief constables told him they did not support his plans for police to impose on-the-spot fines for drunken behaviour.

Officers fear that if Straw's Bill is passed they could be sued by banned fans who win court appeals against the restriction, and claim that the police acted maliciously.

The federation will tell Ministers that making the police judge and jury in decisions made on the spot risks bringing them into conflict with the courts and the Crown Prosecution Service.

Its members are most concerned about clause 14c in the Bill. It says that people can be banned from travel for 'displaying any writing, sign or other visible representation which is threatening, abusive or insulting'.

Announcing the new legislation, Lord Bassam of Brighton, a Home Office minister, said people making V-signs and acting aggressively would be enough evidence for a police constable to stop someone travelling.

Aggressive tattoos, even those 20 years old, could provoke a ban. An officer would have only to suspect someone of 'causing or contributing' to any violence in Britain or elsewhere to take action.

'The question is how much extra work this will mean for the police,' the federation source said. 'We are already overstretched and have lost 2,600 officers since the last election.'

Fred Broughton, the head of the Police Federation, called for a period of sober reflection on the new laws.

'What the Government can't do is give police additional responsibilities without extra resources,' he said.

Bassam admits the Government may have difficulty getting it through Parliament and has said he will listen to arguments against it. The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have reservations about its potential impact on civil liberties.

fields.headline: Can Brown trump 'dump the pump'?
fields.standfirst:
The argument should not about cutting petrol duty but why the Government has failed to give us a proper transport system
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Comment: The argument should not about cutting petrol duty but why the Government has failed to give us a proper transport system
fields.body:
The day is approaching - 1 August is designated 'dump the pump' day, when the nation's motorists can collectively signal their anger at high petrol prices by boycotting petrol stations. I doubt there'll be less traffic - we will fill up the day before - but the sight of deserted filling stations and the prospect of more boycotts thereafter is meant to show the country, media and the Government the degree to which motorists have had enough. You will have to make your mind up. Are you going to use a petrol station on 1 August - and earn the wrath of the Sun and Mail, now in full, awesome campaigning mode - or not?

My guess is that 1 August will be a moderate success. It's not been much reported, but the world is experiencing a fourth, mini oil shock. Prices have trebled over the last 18 months in response to production cuts by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, driving up petrol by 20 pence a litre, but unlike the last three oil shocks petrol duty is very much higher - twice as high in real terms as it was in 1974 and 1979, and two- thirds higher than it was in 1990. The result is that pump prices are approaching the dreaded £1 a litre, although if the oil price can be prevented from rising above $30 a barrel, which the Saudi Arabians are ardently attempting by unilaterally signalling further production increases, then the danger could be averted for the moment. That's too fine a point for most British motorists - they're mad enough already.

For on top of that 20p increase in the underlying petrol price has come another 20p rise in petrol duty since 1993 (6p of it since Labour took power in 1997). The policy of ratcheting up duties faster than inflation was started by the Tories and, until the last Budget, had been continued by Gordon Brown. To Ken Clarke, it seemed a politically risk-free way of closing the budget deficit under the guise of meeting internationally agreed targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. As an expedient when oil was cheap, it worked, but Opec has put an end to that, and New Labour is paying the political price for motorists having to pay £50 to fill their tank.

The accusation from the Sun, Mail and the motoring organisations that the Government is chiefly responsible for the motorists' plight is largely disingenuous; even if New Labour had frozen petrol duties when it reached office, petrol would only be 6p a litre cheaper. Opec and the Tories have done for the motorist. But what the 'dump the pump' campaign is highlighting is the long-standing failure of British policy makers to get to grips with the transport question, the disgraceful refusal to accept that modern life depends on mobility and that there are unacceptable and undesirable consequences of high petrol prices. We are reaching the limits of what ordinary people can pay for transport relative to their other spending. Rail fares have risen by more than 70 per cent in real terms over the last 25 years; bus fares by more than 50 per cent. Using a car now is becoming seriously expensive. Small wonder transport is becoming a hot political issue.

You may, as an Observer reader, be wary of the Mail, but when it writes, as it did last week, that Brown would have some excuse for high petrol duties if he had been investing in a first-class public transport system, you can only agree. Indeed, the signs are that he agrees; under pressure, the Government is saying that the Comprehensive Spending Review is set to announce a major increase in transport investment.

In the meantime, we are grappling with the here-and-now impact of a trebling of the oil price overlaid on the steep increase in duties over the 1990s. It is no accident that the last three oil shocks were all accompanied by recessions; it is very hard, indeed almost impossible, for businesses and individuals to change their demand for energy and fuel in the short run. Company profits are hit as companies absorb the increased fuel costs and consumer demand falls away as more disposable income is diverted to meeting fuel and petrol bills. Unless there is a compensating increase in demand through interest rate cuts, tax reductions or increased public spending, the first-round impact of high oil prices is deflationary.

Thus some of the arguments deployed by the 'dump the pump' campaigners are rooted in real economic concerns. Intriguingly, after both the 1970's oil shocks, Old Labour's reaction was to cushion the impact by allowing petrol duty to fall about a quarter in real terms by not lifting it in line with the very high inflation rates of the time - equivalent today to around a 12p cut in duty. Today's oil price increase is nothing like so recessionary, but the case for some reduction - or at least no further increase in duty - is pretty persuasive. There are telling signs of economic distress - not least the reaction to the campaign - and it was important last week that the Bank of England did not lift interest rates.

But the notion of cutting duty seems silly both environmentally and in transport terms; after all, we want to deter car use, don't we? But some brutal realities need to be recognised. The rise in duties over the 1990s has done little or nothing to deter car use. A superb paper by the Institute for Fiscal Studies, forbiddingly entitled 'The Distributional Effects of Taxes on Private Motoring', shows how we are using the car more, notwithstanding higher petrol prices. We regard car use as a necessity, and there is only a tiny measurable deterrent-effect from higher petrol prices. However, the rich and poor pay the same duty, so that for any given duty increase the poorest 10 per cent of car owners suffer more than twice the impact on their living standards as the richest 10 per cent.

So it has not been high petrol prices that have brought about the fall in emissions of pollutants over the last few years as car use has intensified; that has been almost entirely due to better engines and compulsory use of catalytic converters in new cars. If we want to tackle congestion, we have to find ways of persuading people to think of their car as less of a necessity - and that means much better and efficient public transport together with a more effective system of deterring car use at peak times, such as congestion charges or tolls. As matters stand, we have a regressive and ineffective tax on essential car use, a poor road system and second-rate public transport - the worst of all worlds.

So a lot hangs on the Comprehensive Spending Review in a fortnight's time. If there really is a decisive increase in public transport investment and a convincing transport policy, then the 'dump the pump' campaign will have been trumped by events. If not, we should all join in.

webTitle: 'It was a drinking game. We'd been arguing politics...

fields.headline: 'It was a drinking game. We'd been arguing politics...
fields.trailText: MONDAY: I knew no good would come of that terrible night at the Folletts' all those years ago... but I suppose we should be grateful the press hasn't got the full story on why they fell out.
fields.body:
MONDAY: I knew no good would come of that terrible night at the Folletts' all those years ago... but I suppose we should be grateful the press hasn't got the full story on why they fell out. I know, now, it might seem impossibly childish for two grown men to come to blows over who could best play the guitar riff from 'More Than A Feeling', by Boston. Actually, it seemed impossibly childish even then, especially when Ken started doing the tremolo bit Tony can't do, all bobbing head and wet lips. Silly man. Silly times. But it feels like the last cowpat in our recent meadow of bad luck, and I hardly care anyway: off to Portugal tomorrow, and a lovely quiet week ahead.

TUESDAY: I suppose I should feel guilty out here, with my other children busy with their own problems, and dear Tony struggling a little after having shafted Alastair, but... ah, well. Yes, another custard tart would be lovely.

WEDNESDAY: I suppose I should feel slightly guilty, with my... things... doing whatever, and old whatsit at home trying to run the... thingie.

Damn. Call from whatsit. I'll just get mum to pour us some more port. Won't be a second.

THURSDAY: 'How is he now?' I ask Alastair, eventually, at the end of a long, horrible day.

'Oh, you know,' he says, quietly. 'Still a bit tearful. Shaky. Stopped throwing up, at last. He's had a bit of dry toast now. He's half-asleep in front of a Wallace and Gromitt video.'

'No, I mean how's Euan? I spoke to Tony earlier.'

'Oh, Christ, him? Dunno. Dead, for all I care.'

'Thanks, Al.' A pause. 'Is it awful back there?'

'No, it's okay. In fact, everyone's being pretty nice about it all.' He sounds almost human for once; compassionate, forgiving. It's times like these, I reflect, when old enmities are forgotten, and bitchiness recedes.

'Yeah,' he continues. 'Nice call from the Tories. Kind email from Gordon. We even got a note from Prescott.'

'Really? What did it say?'

'Um... hard to tell, to be honest. The crayon was just all over the place...'

FRIDAY: Euan comes up the moment I walk in the door. Poor lamb. Big hug. 'It's OK,' I tell him, gently, 'it's all OK. And I know just what you need now'... he looks up angelically... 'you need to settle down with a nice steaming cup of hot pork fat.' He disappears, violently. Well. Silly little bugger.

Later, of course, it all comes out, as we do the grim parental sitting-down thing. Slightly surprised, in the midst of my annoyance, to find stirring of sympathy as the tale progressed.

'It was a drinking game,' he confessed. 'We'd been arguing politics, and they kept saying Dad always went to the right of the Tories just to please the Mail, and I said rubbish, so they bet me I had to down a Snorthammer for each one, and I said fine, no problem. But then they started remembering the tax, and the prison ship, and the asylum-seekers, and the bogus beggars, and trial by jury, and drink, and hooligans, and cannabis, and teachers, and single parents, and...'

'Fine, son, fine,' interrupted Tony. 'Look... no need to explain it all now. Let's just be a family again, for a minute. Let's just ... I'd like, if I may, to read you some words from a wonderful poet, a personal favourite of mine, a very special lady by the name of Patience Strong...'

Euan disappears, violently. I follow.

webTitle: Holyrood 'father' may now set English on road to home rule

fields.headline: Holyrood 'father' may now set English on road to home rule
fields.standfirst:
Kenyon Wright, who led the campaign for a Scottish Parliament, has new tasks in hand. Arnold Kemp profiles an odd - and influential - character
Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Kenyon Wright, who led the campaign for a Scottish Parliament, has new tasks in hand.  Arnold Kemp profiles an odd - and influential - character
fields.body:
The man who is often called the 'father of the Scottish Parliament' may soon have a new and tricky assignment - to set the English regions on the road to home rule.

Until now they have been largely uninterested in the next stage of the Blair administration's constitutional reforms. But both Labour and Liberal Democratic leaderships believe the picture must change if devolution - so far confined to Scotland, Wales and London - is not to falter because of its imbalances.

The task of preaching to the unconverted is a familiar one to Canon Kenyon Wright, 67, who was once a missionary in India. He is also dogged, and over more than a dozen years helped to build the consensus that ended Scotland's long and hesitant flirtation with home rule. With the Scottish Parliament a year old, he decided it was time to abandon his political neutrality and last month joined the Liberal Democrats.

It was no sudden conversion. He has long been comfortable with the party's policies on devolution, Europe and electoral reform. And, he says, he has no immediate ambitions, either for a seat at Holyrood or a job in the party - although, he said last week, 'no one can ever say never'.

In the first election last year he stood as an independent. He is a pensioner, and friends helped pay the campaign bill of £10,000. He says: 'Frankly I never expected to be elected, but I think it was probably worth it to get certain messages across'.

Wright joined the party after meeting leader Charles Kennedy in London and no job was sought or offered.

But when Kennedy paraded his new recruit before the Scottish press last month, Wright says that 'to my surprise' Kennedy indicated 'I could have a role in working with the English regions. It's a role I'd find interesting.'

Labour's plan that the English regions should follow Scotland, Wales and London into devolution has been adrift on a sea of indifference. But that may be changing. The London mayoral contest has shown the new politics can be glamorous, with a high media profile. English regional jealousies have been sharpened by Scotland's over-representation and favoured share of public spending.

Kennedy says regional assemblies in England will answer the infamous West Lothian question. Long a matter for speculative debate it is now assuming reality - on the unlikely issue of fox hunting. Votes of Scottish Labour MPs will carry a ban that applies only to England. Tam Dalyell, who formulated the question in the first place, has said he will abstain.

Until the English themselves embrace devolution, Wright believes, the problem will remain. The West Lothian question, he concedes, is an anomaly. 'But it's less than the anomaly with which we [in Scotland] had to live for so long.' During the Eighties, Scottish legislation was pushed through Westminster with English MPs as lobby fodder. The most notorious example was Margaret Thatcher's poll tax.

Wright believes the regions are now 'girding up their loins' and are turning for guidance to the Scottish model in general and to Wright, executive chairman of the Scottish Constitutional Convention from its beginning in 1989, in particular.

He said: 'I've been closely associated with the North-West Constitutional Convention, chaired by the Bishop of Liverpool, and powerfully funded by local authorities, and the North-East convention, chaired by the Bishop of Durham.'

The Scottish convention's work will not translate easily across the border. Devolution in Scotland has been driven by Labour's fear of the Scottish Nationalists. The Claim of Right adopted by the con vention in 1989 asserted the sovereign right of the Scottish people to decide their own form of government. This was an explicit rejection of the Westminster doctrine of the Crown sovereign in Parliament, which justifies an 'elective dictatorship'.

In the English regions there is not yet a comparable sense of distinctiveness or alienation. The English give their loyalty to their villages and communities and, perhaps, to the old Anglo-Saxon counties. There is no SNP knocking hungrily on the door, left of centre and committed to legality. English nationalism merges into the extreme Right.

But there is now a feeling in the English regions that they have been left behind, both economically and politically, a feeling that is particularly acute in the North-East. Resentment focuses on Scotland's favourable share of public spending and over-representation at Westminster.

Wright accepts that the Barnett Formula, which shares out new public spending programmes, will have to be renegotiated from time to time as needs change and populations shift. But he insists that Scotland must be involved in the process and that any new settlement must not be imposed by Whitehall.

Yet, despite the rhetoric it uses to soothe regional angst, he also senses the Blair Government is drawing back from its reform programme and attempting to reassert the traditions of Whitehall centralism.

He acknowledges Labour kept its promises on devolution, but adds: 'I have always seen this as possibly the first act of one of the great reforming Governments of our time. But there could be a loss of nerve, an absence of any deep understanding of what's actually happened.'

The Scottish Parliament is a creature of statute, but Wright believes the process is irreversible and that it is entrenched as an autonomous part of the constitution.

The Executive - Wright prefers to call it the Scottish government - was knocked off course on the reform of Section 28 by millionaire Brian Souter and a ground-swell of popular reaction, largely, he believes, because it failed to follow the principle of prior consultation.

The first year, he says, has been a 'curate's egg'. 'But it's light-years better than anything that went before. Look at the amount of legislation that has been going through, compared with what Westminster could handle, or the way in which politics have been repatriated.

'The media in Scotland are interested in what's happening in this Parliament. The difficulty seems to be the lack of interest in what's happening at Westminster. A lot of the Westminster MPs complain to me that they're simply not getting the press coverage that they should.'

The new Parliament, he believes, has established itself 'in the minds of the people. Some of the committees are flexing their muscles and trying to bring the Executive to account.' Indeed, Wright would have preferred a minority Labour administration, rather than a coalition with the Lib Dems, because he believes it would have produced an Executive having greater respect for accountability and consultation.

Eventually the number of Scottish MPs at Westminster will be cut after a review by the Boundaries Commission. He is against the Labour view that there should be a corresponding reduction of MSPs in Edinburgh, from 129 to about 100. At its present strength, he believes Parliament is having difficulty in coping with its workload. He wants a separate Scottish Boundaries Commission.

For a man who has held no public office, the canon has enjoyed extraordinary influence. Describing himself as 'an odd character', he is both a Methodist and an Anglican. Because he worked as a missionary for the unified Church of North India the Anglican Bishop of Coventry could appoint him director of his international ministry.

He came back to his native Scotland in 1981 to be general secretary of the Scottish Council of Churches.He retired from pastoral work last year but continues to chair an inter-church group on his other great passion, sustainable development.

The true father of the Scottish Parliament, he believes, was Donald Dewar, or perhaps John Smith. He says he has 'immense respect and affection' for the First Minister, who hopes to be back in harness in September after heart surgery. He brought Labour into the convention alongside the Lib Dems. It was Dewar, discharging Smith's 'unfinished business', 'who really got Labour tied into the devolutionary programme'.

His reluctance to claim paternity of Holyrood also springs from his feelings about Thatcher, whose attitudes to Scotland in the Eighties did more to forge the consensus than the convention. He says: 'When I am rather flatteringly but inaccurately called the father of the Scottish Parliament, I sometimes bridle slightly because I once called her the mother of the Parliament. Perhaps it would be more accurate to call her the midwife.

'What she did - because of the way she centralised power, because of the way she used the constitutional arrangements - was to bring home to people forcibly that the problem was not who governed us but how we were governed, that it was not political but constitutional.'

fields.headline: Provos' holiday cash pinched
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA's Belfast Brigade will have to decommission its suntan lotion and forget about a summer holiday, thanks to a light-fingered comrade.
fields.body:
The IRA's Belfast Brigade will have to decommission its suntan lotion and forget about a summer holiday, thanks to a light-fingered comrade.

For a former IRA activist from East Belfast, in charge of the Provos' punishment beatings, has made off with almost £100,000 from the terror group's war chest.

The ex-prisoner from the Catholic enclave, the Short Strand, pinched the Provo loot which had been set aside to pay for holidays and short breaks for IRA volunteers in the city.

The Provos only found out that their long-standing comrade had stolen the cash when they interrogated his sister, also from the Short Strand.

According to republican sources, she was given £10,000 by her brother to keep quiet about the theft. But when she started spending large amounts of cash the IRA became suspicious and hauled her in.

The £100,000, mostly earned from selling cigarettes illegally smuggled from Spain, was hidden under floorboards in her house. The IRA threatened to shoot her unless she told them where her brother and his family had fled. She revealed that he was in the United States. 'They tried to contact him but he's not coming home,' said an RUC source. 'And who would blame him?'

The ex-IRA man is known as 'Big A'. For several years he has been involved in so-called punishment beatings and shootings in the Short Strand and Markets areas close to Belfast city centre.

Big A has carried out many beatings and mutilations of young men accused by IRA kangaroo courts of joyriding, drug dealing and burglary. A number of his victims threw parties last weekend to celebrate Big A's fall from grace.

fields.headline: An Orangeman speaks
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Comment: The Orange Institution's often proclaimed Christian principles are being brought into question by the events surrounding the protest at Drumcree.
fields.body:
The Orange Institution's often proclaimed Christian principles are being brought into question by the events surrounding the protest at Drumcree.

While all Orangemen would support the right of Portadown District to complete their traditional walk home from Morning Prayer at Drumcree Parish Church, multitudes are distressed by the violence accompanying the protest. These shameful events raise questions over the fundamental direction of the Orange Institution. Has the institution lost its historical connection with the past so definitively that it is destroying the principles it once upheld?

The comments of the Rev F. Rupert Gibson, a former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, made many years ago, are equally true today: 'Probably there is no human institution claiming to be based on the Bible and professing to maintain the principles of the Reformed Faith, which has been more bitterly maligned by its avowed foes and more falsely represented by those who profess to be its friends than the Orange Order.'

Though its origins can be traced to the disputes of the 17th century, the institution established itself on the sure foundation of Scripture, as understood by Reformed theology. It may appear strange to the onlooking world that an Orangeman is pledged, 'as far as in him lies, to assist the magistrates and civil authorities'.

Strange, only because of the more recent images of Orangemen involving themselves in civil disorder in the current dispute over parades. The biblical principle expounded by the Apostle Paul in Romans 13 is clear:

'Everyone must submit himself to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God. Consequently, he who rebels against the authority is rebelling against what God has instituted, and those who do so will bring judgement on themselves. For rulers hold no terror for those who do right, but for those who do wrong.'

That is not to say that there is no place for a tradition of dissent. There certainly is. But it is a clear breach of one of the core values of Orangeism to be involved in civil disorder. Orangemen are not to be merely passive in relation to the civil authorities but actively to assist law and order. To refuse to condemn violence is to encourage violence. This is not merely anti-social, it is anti-Orange.

Having public protests which result in the injury or death of members of Her Majesty's Security Forces must bring shame on any organisation which professes to be both Christian and Loyal. Those who call people on to the streets today, particularly in this present volatile situation, must accept responsibility for the consequences.

Human responsibility is a fundamental principle of the Gospel. Accepting personal responsibility for our actions is also a sign of maturity. But the Scriptures also teach us that we are 'our brother's keeper'.

In accepting responsibility for our actions we must also recognise that we must accept some responsibility for the results of our actions.

If the Orange Institution is ever to regain its lost credibility it must pledge by word and perform by deed the principles of Scripture. All those concerned with the future of the Institution must be obedient to the Word of God. As James instructs the early disciples - 'Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says.'

The Rev Brian Kennaway is former convener of the education committee of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland

fields.headline: Menace of 'clean-skin' drug dealers
fields.standfirst:
'Respectable' crooks replace gangsters

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: They use public transport, not Ferraris, pay their rent and council tax on time, hold down a boring job and never get in trouble with the law.
fields.body:
They use public transport, not Ferraris, pay their rent and council tax on time, hold down a boring job and never get in trouble with the law.

These are the 'clean skins' or 'lilywhites' - the new drugs traffickers who dwarf the activities of the old English crime 'families', led by well-known villains such as Kenneth Noye and Curtis Warren.

Controlled by the Turkish gangs importing huge amounts of heroin and the South American gangs running cocaine, the 'clean skins' live a life of virtue. 'Imagine John Major and you've got the picture,' said a law enforcement source. 'Dull, law-abiding, boring and completely off our radar. No previous convictions, no trouble, nothing. Only now are we beginning to realise the "clean skin" gangs are behind the huge amounts of heroin and cocaine coming into the country.'

Terry Byrne, director of intelligence for HM Customs, told The Observer: 'We have a major concern with "clean skins". This is a term of art first used in connection with the Provisional IRA, meaning people with no previous criminal convictions. The "clean skins" pose the major threat to our strategy.'

The decline of the traditional crime 'family', as English as roast beef, has been going on for some time. The Krays are now the stuff of legend, with Ronnie and Charlie dead, and Reggie in prison. The Adams family, who used to run north London's gangland, have fled to Spain and in Liverpool, the reign of Curtis 'Cocky' Warren ended when he was jailed in Holland for 12 years.

But these victories are red herrings, against the invisible importers. Customs fear the 'clean skin' gangs are using respectable banks and solicitors to launder their money.

Byrne said: 'We are concerned at the rise and rise of money-laundering, through banks in tax havens, shell companies and the like. One particular concern is solicitors and their escrow accounts. There are 76,000 solicitors and, for the last available year, we had only 407 reports of suspicious transactions. The banks must know their customer, but what if a solicitor - known to the bank for 30 years - pays in cash? That presents no suspicious cash problem.'

The new Customs strategy targets cash as much as hard drugs. 'In our experience, the money is always nearer the Mr Big than the drugs,' said Byrne. 'We want to have the powers to seize large amounts of cash. All we need is an audit trail, showing us the source of the money, and notice that tax has been paid. No audit trail, then the cash goes to help the victims of drugs crimes and their families. We are deploying Customs officers to watch outgoing flights, looking for the big money leaving the country.'

The strategy, involving Customs working with the police, the security and intelligence services, GCHQ at Cheltenham, and the Inland Revenue, is targeted at the drugs trade as a business.

'What we want to do is to impact in the most effective way on this wretched trade,' said Byrne. 'We will increasingly use the civil courts to go after the wealth of drug traffickers. Forfeiture of goods and wealth gained through the drugs trade will be a powerful part of our armoury.

'Criminals won't like it, but it worked in Ireland after the murder of Veronica Guerin. Civil forfeiture works, and the standard of proof is less than in a criminal case.

'One of the problems we face when fighting organised crime is that wealthy core criminals will employ all their resources in avoiding conviction.

'But if they cannot explain the source of their wealth and show tax records, then that money will go to help victims of drugs.'

fields.headline: Dyke axes 1,000 BBC managers
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Up to 1,000 jobs will be axed at the BBC this week when Greg Dyke reveals his long-awaited blueprint for the future of the corporation.
fields.body:
Up to 1,000 jobs will be axed at the BBC this week when Greg Dyke reveals his long-awaited blueprint for the future of the corporation.

The new director-general will strip out layers of bureaucracy and middle management in a move that will release millions of pounds to be spent on programmes. Three new senior editors will be appointed to make programmes that can be aired across all BBC media, including the internet and on new interactive channels.

The head of each of the BBC's main departments in radio, television and new media will reveal the findings of a six-month review ordered by Dyke when he arrived. His decision to dismantle the 'internal market', which split programme commissioners from programme makers, will see more than 500 jobs go in finance, human resources, marketing and production.

By ploughing the savings made back into programme making, Dyke will achieve his goal of channelling 85 per cent of the BBC's £2.6 billion annual revenue into programmes, rather than the current 76 per cent. The 1,000 jobs - 5 per cent of the BBC's 20,000 staff - will be shed over three years.

This week's announcement will be followed by a crucial governors' meeting next week when Dyke's plan to transform BBC1 into a popular entertainment channel and move more serious programmes such as Panorama on to BBC2 will be approved. His vision will be unveiled at the Edinburgh Television Festival next month.

Television, radio, drama, entertainment, children's programmes, factual programmes and learning will be reorganised under the review. BBC1 and BBC2 will cooperate more closely as part of Dyke's plan to create 'one BBC'.

Mark Thompson, the BBC's new director of television, will announce the appointment of the three new 'genre commissioners' for drama, entertainment and factual programmes. The new posts are designed to ensure that all programmes are developed for television and the internet.

'We want to make sure that when we develop, say, a factual programme we think about how it will translate to other programmes or channels including the internet and interactive sites. We don't want people thinking in isolation. We want them thinking across genres and across media.'

webTitle: Witch-hunt punishes those who defy Haider

fields.headline: Witch-hunt punishes those who defy Haider
fields.standfirst:
Denis Staunton reports from Vienna on a cutback in funding for liberal activists
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Denis Staunton reports from Vienna on a cutback in funding for liberal activists
fields.body:
In a few sparsely furnished rooms in Vienna's former imperial stables, a handful of artists and political activists are taking the opposition to Austria's right-wing government into cyberspace. But not for long. Public Netbase, which provides Internet facilities for more than 1,200 cultural and political projects, has had its public funding stopped and been told to get out of the building by April next year.

Konrad Becker, one of the founders of Public Netbase, says his organisation is only one of many cultural institutions to face closure because they are judged by the government, which includes Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom Party, to be on the wrong side of the political tracks.

'As soon as the new government came into place, all project money was immediately withdrawn. They don't even talk to us now,' Becker said.

Austrian artists, journalists and intellectuals describe a climate of fear and intimidation that they believe is part of a government attempt to silence opposition to the coalition government that has become the pariah of European politics.

Journalists on the public service television channel ÖRF have been threatened with dismissal for being too critical of the government and some coalition politicians have called for weekly demonstrations in the centre of Vienna to be banned.

Later this week the president of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg will nominate three 'wise men' to monitor Austria's treatment of minorities, immigrants and asylum-seekers and assess the evolution of the 'political nature' of the Freedom Party.

If the report is favourable, Austria's 14 EU partners will lift the sanctions imposed in protest against the presence in government of Haider's party.

Among the cases the wise men may care to examine is that of Anton Pelinka, Austria's most distinguished political scientist, who was convicted in a Vienna court in April of defaming Haider by accusing him of trivialising National Socialism. Pelinka, who is appealing against the verdict, claims that Haider is using the libel laws to silence his critics.

'Less privileged people than me will consider very carefully what they say in future. Because they don't want to spend five years in the courts until Strasbourg proves them right,' Pelinka said.

Austria's Foreign Minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, last week dismissed the furore over Pelinka as a political interpretation of a private, legal matter. 'We have independent courts and maybe this was not a very fantastic judgement. But who are we to judge that?' she said.

But other Austrian intellectuals claim that there is a pattern in the government's behaviour, and Walter Famler, who edits the literary magazine Wespennest (Wasps' Nest) says that the Pelinka case ought to ring alarm bells about the coalition's intentions.

'They really want to destroy the public standing of people like Pelinka with every means they can find. The hardcore Nazis in Germany threaten people with violence. Here they want to corrupt people,' Famler said.

Ferrero-Waldner argues that, as the new government prunes back its public spending, everyone's budget is being cut and that most of the complaints by disgruntled artists and intellectuals are nothing more than the predictable gripes of disappointed people.

But many of the casualties of the cuts, from community radio stations to independent theatre groups, have one thing in common - their opposition to the government. And while Ferrero-Waldner claims that her government's attempts to effect changes in political programming on television are aimed at creating more objectivity and efficiency, all the journalists who are being targeted are critical of the coalition.

Although the Foreign Minister does not favour a ban on the demonstrations against her government that attract thousands each Thursday evening, she suggested that groups taking part in the protests could see their state subsidies disappear.

'The demonstrations can go on forever, but on the other hand I think it's also a question sometimes of subsidies. Because these people have their stands here and so on. Maybe they get the money from somewhere. I don't know,' Ferrero-Waldner said.

In the past, many independent cultural groups topped up their budgets and broadened their intellectual horizons by touring abroad, but Austria's current status as an international pariah has meant that many invitations have been cancelled and most groups are staying at home this summer.

Combined with the budget cuts, the international boycott of Austria's independent voices represents a double blow. 'Nobody's called us from Western Europe at all this year. But maybe we'll go to Skopje in October - that will be our international tour,' said Baertl Gstetner, who runs Tanzhotel, a pioneering modern dance group in Vienna.

Becker has given up hope of receiving any more public funding for Public Netbase, and as he watches the progress of Austria's new government he believes that he underestimated the threat to free speech.

'At the beginning, we were all quite happy to see a mobilisation of the public and it was very impressive to see so many people on the streets,' Becker said.

'But I'm very much afraid if this goes on for a long time. Austria doesn't have a very big tradition of dissenting democratic structures, and I'm very worried about the consequences,' he said.

Public Netbase is at www.t0.or.at and Wespennest is at www.wespennest.at.
Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times .

webTitle: Why Tony must slay prince of dark arts

fields.headline: Why Tony must slay prince of dark arts
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: One conversation from this past hectic week will stay with me. I was talking to a Labour peer - let's call him Lord X. 'I'm terrified,' he said. 'I'm afraid of doing anything that will offend Alastair or Peter, because of the awful, horrible things that will appear in the press about me and be so hurtful to my family.'
fields.body:
One conversation from this past hectic week will stay with me. I was talking to a Labour peer - let's call him Lord X. 'I'm terrified,' he said. 'I'm afraid of doing anything that will offend Alastair or Peter, because of the awful, horrible things that will appear in the press about me and be so hurtful to my family.'

Lord X is an irreproachable Blairite who was on popping-round-for-coffee terms with Tony and Cherie until they moved into Number 10. His fear, expressed quietly and sincerely, made me think I had, if anything, understated the scale of the briefing problem in my article for last Sunday's Observer .

That's probably why I had to be the one to write it. I'm not scared of Peter Mandelson or Alastair Campbell. I don't have a political career for them to ruin. I told Tony Blair years ago that I don't want a peerage. Alastair thinks I'm in politics for social advancement, which always amuses me. I became friendly with the Kinnocks when Margaret Thatcher was at the height of her popularity and a Labour leader was about as socially useful as a pet python.

Alastair's intemperate response gave credibility to my article. It was easy to believe that someone so splenetic could rubbish his colleagues. By contrast, Mo Mowlam, who might have preferred me not to meddle, was characteristically gracious. In the middle of my granddaughter's birthday party, I got a message from Mo to say that she was putting out a statement but it was nothing personal.

Margaret Beckett was the third person publicly to contradict me. Interestingly, she had been the target of vicious briefings in the weeks before Mandelson got her job at the Department of Trade and Industry. Why would Beckett go on television and say that it doesn't happen?

She said that Ministers do not brief against one another; it is all made up by journalists. This has a superficial plausibility - but an invented briefing only has credibility in the context of real ones. Every week people who are believed to speak with Tony Blair's authority pass on to journalists malicious gossip about Ministers. A Government that uses off-the-record briefing invites journalistic dishonesty.

Take Thursday's front-page splash in the Express, in which Anthony Bevins claimed a 'government colleague' described Gordon Brown as 'bonkers'. Is it true? We will never know. I imagine that the editor, Rosie Boycott, called in Bevins and asked him who the source was. Whatever he said, Rosie trusted him. Why? Because she knows that this kind of thing goes on. Were it not so, she probably would not have run the piece.

Blair says briefing is done by people who couldn't possibly be speaking with his authority. Last week he told a colleague the following anecdote to prove his point. He had confronted a journalist about an inaccurate report which was said to have come from 'a source close to the Prime Minister'. Tony pressed the journalist to name this source. 'And do you know who it was?' Tony said with incredulity. 'Derek Draper!'

This story is telling, though not in the way Tony intended. Poor, young 'Dolly' Draper had only one role in the world of politics and that was to be a messenger for Mandelson. The journalist in the anecdote obviously thought the story came from Peter and it probably did. Peter is a source close to the PM.

Doesn't Tony understand that? Can he be so innocent that he does not know what is done in his name? It's hard to believe. But the person to whom he related the above anecdote tells me he was utterly sincere.

The unofficial government line is that Tony may know about it but he can't do anything. I was cornered in the Pugin Room bar by a PPS, a junior Minister and a former Secretary of State, all trusted friends. Don't blame Tony, they urged me; Peter Mandelson and Gordon Brown are at one another's throats and Tony can't stop them.

Last week's papers have recalled two fascinating instances of briefings from the distant past. Harold Wilson personally leaked to the Telegraph his intention of sacking Tony Benn from the Department of Industry in 1975. His purpose, according to Donald MacIntyre in Monday's Independent, was to discredit Benn in order to make it easier to sack him. And, more shockingly, that old Edwardian gentleman, Harold Macmillan, did the same to Selwyn Lloyd in 1960.

What both those incidents have in common is that the leak had the authority of the Prime Minister. And that's why I think my Pugin Room pals are wrong. True, politicians are a quarrelsome lot and they gossip to journalists. Little harm is done, so long as it is perceived as gossip. But when the gossip is thought - rightly or wrongly - to have the authority of Number 10, it ceases to be gossip and becomes news. Then it is damaging. That's why Lord X is terrified.

Tony Blair has the right to make or break people's political careers - that's what being the boss means - but they should not be crucified first. It's brutal and cowardly and it damages Labour.

Regardless of whether Tony is the evil genius behind briefings or a helpless observer, he most certainly can stop it. He would have to fire Campbell, return Mandelson to the back benches and banish them both from Number 10. That would be a convincing signal that the briefing is going to stop and take away the authority of the culprits.

A lot of people seem to think Alastair is likely to be fired soon. But it would do Tony no good to sack him and keep Mandelson. Lord X will not sleep easy until the papers are fully convinced that the Prince of Darkness no longer speaks with the voice of the Prime Minister.

webTitle: Tony's Cabinet: Just like the rest of us

fields.headline: Tony's Cabinet: Just like the rest of us
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What kind of cabinet is this? Their children are found 'drunk and incapable' and dealing in drugs; their parents were single mothers; they are divorcees, adulterers and three of them are openly gay. In other words, they are just like us
fields.body:
What kind of cabinet is this? Their children are found 'drunk and incapable' and dealing in drugs; their parents were single mothers; they are divorcees, adulterers and three of them are openly gay. In other words, they are just like us.

UNDERAGE DRINKING

TONY BLAIR'S 16-year-old son Euan found drunk and incapable in Leicester Square.

REST OF US: 58 per cent of children between 11 and 15 have tried alcohol.

AVERAGE CONSUMPTION in this age group has more than doubled in the 90s, from 5.4 units a week in 1990 to 8.4 units in 1996.

IN ENGLAND, the HEA (Health Education Authority) reports that 96 per cent of 15-year-olds have tasted alcohol; 900,000 11- to 15-year-olds had had an alcoholic drink in the last week.

ONE IN TEN 11- TO 15-YEAR-OLDS drink regularly with their parents.

130,000 CHILDREN UNDER 16 drink alcohol in pubs in an average week in England.

THREE QUARTERS OF 16- to 24-year-olds admit being drunk regularly and may 'do something they regret'.

VIOLENCE

MO MOWLAM'S father an alcoholic and she has spoken out about the destructive effect this can have on young people growing up with it.

REST OF US: The Home Office's 'Addressing Domestic Violence' says 1 woman in 4 reports experiencing domestic violence at some point in their lifetime. Each year in England and Wales 63,000 women and children spend at least one night in a refuge and, of 224 female victims of homicide in 1997, 47 per cent were killed by a current or former partner. This amounts to one woman dying as a result of domestic violence every 3 days.

DRUGS

JACK STRAW'S son William, then 17, was exposed by Dawn Alford of News of the World in December 1997 for selling cannabis.

REST OF US: Drugscope reports that 40 per cent of 16- to 19-year-olds have used cannabis, half regularly, compared with 25 per cent of adult population.

HALF OF ALL 16-year-olds have tried a non-sanctioned drug.

SINGLE PARENTS

JACK STRAW'S MOTHER was a single parent and brought up Jack and four siblings in a council maisonette in Brentwood.

ALAN MILBURN'S MOTHER raised him single-handedly in a Durham mining village.

REST OF US: 1.5 million children under 16 now live with only one natural parent (NOP poll).

IN 2000, ONE in seven mothers will be leaving the space under 'father' blank on birth certificates - 50,000 were left blank in 1998 whereas 28,000 in 1978

LIVING IN SIN

ALASTAIR CAMPBELL and Fiona Millar (press advisers to Tony and Cherie) are unmarried.

REST OF US: 14 per cent of adults aged 16-59 report at least one completed period of cohabitation which had not led to marriage. Civil marriages fell by 1.5 per cent between 1997 and 1998 to a figure of163, 000. (Office for National Statistics).

GAY

CHRIS SMITH and PETER MANDELSON and NICK BROWN are three cabinet members who are openly out of the closet.

REST OF US: Up to 6.1 per cent of the male population encounter homosexual experiences in their lifetimes, according to the National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles (Penguin).

AFFAIRS

ROBIN COOK had a series of affairs when married to Margaret and has since remarried his mistress and secretary, Gaynor Regan.

REST OF US: 1 out of 4 respondents to a survey conducted by counselling service Relate and Candis admitted to having had at least one affair; 32 per cent of men responding to the survey admitted to cheating; 28 per cent of men marrying in 1998 had been married previously.

DIVORCE

DAVID BLUNKETT and ALAN MILBURN are both divorced.

REST OF US: The Office of National Statistics predicts that 4 out of 10 UK marriages will end in divorce (projected in 1994). Fifty years ago the figure was 1 in 80.

fields.headline: Refugees slam 'hostel from hell'
fields.standfirst:
Victims of tyranny talk of violence between ethnic groups, bullying and theft at the sanctuary that costs council £3m a year

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: It looks like any other anonymous, run-down inner city building. Its name, the London Park Hotel, suggests a rural oasis amid urban squalor. But, say residents, it is closer to a prison.
fields.body:
It looks like any other anonymous, run-down inner city building. Its name, the London Park Hotel, suggests a rural oasis amid urban squalor. But, say residents, it is closer to a prison.

The multi-storey hotel is one of Britain's biggest holding centres for young male refugees. Here 530 asylum seekers wait out the months while their applications for leave to remain in Britain are processed. Many have risked their lives to flee violence, deprivation and fear in their home countries.

But instead of sanctuary, they have arrived in Britain to find more of the same.

Last week a group of London Park residents spoke for the first time about life in what has been dubbed 'the hostel from hell' - and described an atmosphere of gang violence, intimidation, frustration and petty theft. They told of a world where the strong bully the weak, and the weak bully the weaker. 'There is much trouble, much fighting. I never feel safe. You cannot even take out a cigarette because someone will take it from you,' said Mohammed, 31, a student who escaped from one of Saddam Hussein's jails.

'My room has been burgled three times but I have nothing. The only thing they could find was my travel card, so they took that.'

Most of the asylum seekers at the hotel, in the centre of the Elephant and Castle, south London's busiest traffic roundabout, have been placed there by Southwark council. It pays £130 a week for each resident's board and lodging. Most are white, Christian and from Albania, Kosovo or elsewhere in the Balkans. Around 50 are Kurds from Turkey, Iran or Iraq. All tell stories of their escape from their homelands; at first on foot, then hidden in lorries or boats. Many saw friends die on the way, drowned when their flimsy craft overturned or blown up by landmines as they crossed unmarked borders at night. But nothing prepared them for the life that they now lead.

'It is terrible,' said Ali, who survived a grenade attack by Saddam's henchmen. Crying, he said he regretted leaving his family 'for this'. 'Sometimes I think I was better off where I was. This is like an old Soviet prison camp. I am living in fear every day.'

The Kurds - who are Muslims - claim they are preyed on by other, larger ethnic factions in the hotel.

They describe a 'prison culture' where brute force prevails among residents. In one incident last March, a violent argument broke out when Kurds wanted to turn the hotel's television set to a Kurdish satellite channel showed the traditional new year celebrations in their homeland.

'We wanted a link with home, perhaps to see friends or relations in the crowds. Many of us don't even know if our families are alive,' said Hussein. He described how the dispute turned to violence with the more numerous Albanians 'attacking' his countrymen.

'One man had his head cut open very badly,' said Hussein.

The fight was one of many, the refugees said. Racial and religious insults from other residents are commonplace, they said.

But the biggest problem is sheer tedium. Most of the men, who are mainly aged between 18 and 30, have nothing to do but hang around in groups around the building or watch TV. It is illegal for them to work, and none receives any state handouts other than food and board.

'I cannot even get a haircut or a pair of shoes,' said one.

'Even in prison you would have a library or maybe a workshop. Here - nothing.'

Although the residents are free to come and go at will, strict security keep out the unwanted.

In the confined atmosphere a prison-style gang culture has emerged. Several groups have formed around the strongest individuals.

The young men who loiter around the hotel also initimidate locals. 'Residents have been seeing the hotel residents as a threat just because they are a large group,' said Sergeant Andrew Cameron of Southwark police. 'But we are having to explain to them that this is only a perceived threat, not a real one.'

He admitted there were two serious incidents involving residents which were going through the courts.
