webTitle: Seven days that spun out of Blair's control

fields.headline: Seven days that spun out of Blair's control
fields.standfirst:
Kamal Ahmed traces the week from Follett to Euan, and suggests the PM is ready to rise from his rock bottom
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Don Brind was at home watching the tennis when the phone rang. It was Saturday evening and the Labour Party official was on duty to field calls from journalists following up stories appearing in the next day's newspapers.
fields.body:
Don Brind was at home watching the tennis when the phone rang. It was Saturday evening and the Labour Party official was on duty to field calls from journalists following up stories appearing in the next day's newspapers.

On the other end of the phone was Bob Roberts, deputy political editor of the Press Association. Was Brind aware, Roberts asked, of a story appearing in the next day's Observer based on an article written by Ken Follett, the author who had helped to raise millions for New Labour?

Brind wasn't. Roberts had received a press release from the Observer detailing Follett's allegation that Blair was guilty of making 'malicious gossip an everyday tool of modern British government'. Alastair Campbell, Blair's official spokesman, was also at home that night. Brind faxed him the release. Campbell read it and decided attack was the best form of defence. They put together a statement saying Follett was a man 'better known for his fiction than his judgment'. It was the start of a week that many have described as the worst seven days Blair has faced in government.

Leaked memos revealed splits at the heart of government over the euro; police criticised plans over spot-fines for drunken yobs; Blair's performance at Prime Minister's Questions was described as lamentable; his son was found drunk in a gutter.

So was this the beginning of the end of the Blair soap opera? Will the events of the past week finally force the real Blair to stand up, free of the spin doctors and advisers who have created such cynicism among traditional voters? Or will he be left so irreparably damaged that his image as a man in control will never be regained?

Blair has no doubts. In private, he argues that in the real world voters are starting to see results: unemployment down, better schools, slow changes in the health service. In an interview for Michael Cockerell's programme on Alastair Campbell, to be screened on Saturday, Blair will criticise what he says is the press's obsession with splits. He says all he is doing is concentrating on the fundamentals.

In part he has own spin machine to blame. 'Of course some can criticise how we have handled the message,' one Labour official said yesterday. 'I think we've learnt some lessons.'

This is how the week spun out of control. Last Sunday, Roger Mosey, the head of BBC television, had just finished watching the Euro 2000 final when he first became involved in the 'Follett affair'. The match had gone to extra time and the television news summary was delayed.

Mosey watched the efforts of his news team with interest. The Follett story led the bulletin. The report called it the bitterest row that had faced New Labour.

Mosey wasn't happy. He called his news executives and pointed out that maybe 'bitterest row' was a bit strong, given the fallout over the euro, the Bernie Ecclestone affair and the Peter Mandelson home loan scandal. The report was toned down but it still led the 11pm bulletin. The rumour did the rounds that Campbell had been on to Mosey and ordered the BBC to act. It wasn't true. 'The Government gave this story legs,' a senior TV executive said. 'If they hadn't put Margaret Beckett up to attack Follett on Sunday maybe it would not have taken off like it did.'

No chance. Andrew Grice, political editor of the Independent, knew that Frank Field, the sacked Welfare Minister, might have a few things to say about spin. He called him.

Field did not disappoint, revealing that he had kept a detailed account of efforts to discredit him. Government aides had said Field was 'a complete joke' who was 'wrapped up in his own ego'. Field said he would go public if the Government didn't clean up its act. 'They had better behave themselves or they will have a nice publication on their hands.' Asked who was responsible for the negative briefing, he said: 'The manuscript is pretty clear on that.'

There were more worries in Monday's papers. A leaked memo from Andrew Fraser, head of the Department of Trade and Industry's Invest in Britain bureau warned that the strength of sterling meant the policy of gradual convergence with the euroland economies was 'no longer working' and the Government should expect 'high profile closures'.

That morning in Downing Street, Blair was trying to keep his crime agenda going. Around the Cabinet Office table sat Home Secretary Jack Straw, Home Office Minister Charles Clarke, five chief constables and Professor Jonathan Shepherd, a crime expert. They had been invited to discuss cracking down on loutish behaviour.

As they poured tea and water in readiness for the two-hour meeting, Blair spoke about his time living in Islington, an ordinary London borough, he said, which suffered its fair share of loutish behaviour. As a father and family man, he was determined to act.

But his genuine effort to get 'joined-up' thinking going on crime was about to be hung out to dry because of a few lines spun from a speech the Thursday before. In Blair's speech to a religious audience in Germany a few paragraphs had been awkwardly inserted saying that police should be given powers to fine drunken yobs £100 on the spot. Blair even suggested that police should march transgressors to a cash machine and order them to take out the money. Advisers thought it showed that Blair was doing something.

But at the Monday morning meeting the chief constables made it clear this would not work. 'The collection of cash is not a practical idea,' said Sir John Evans, the head of the Association of Chief Police Officers. Fingers have been pointed at Jonathan Powell, Blair's chief of staff and the man charged, along with Campbell, with protecting the Prime Minister from stupidity. Critics say Powell should have picked up on the appoaching elephant trap.

Clarke had to think quickly. He explained after the meeting that Blair's talk of £100 fines and cash points 'was a figure of speech'. He was forced to add a coda. 'I am not trying to get off the hook.'

Blair's week was to get worse. Last Tuesday morning it was reported that four senior party figures - Doug Henderson, Rhodri Morgan, Tony Benn and Barbara Castle - backed Follet's plea for an end to the 'briefing culture'. The wheels were wobbling.

Another leak brought the damaging European debate to the fore again. The British ambassador to Japan, Stephen Gomersall, was warning that Japanese investment might be put at risk if Britain did not make significant moves towards joining the euro.

Blair knew he had to make an impact at Wednesday's Prime Minister's Questions. He met his key advisers, including Campbell and private secretary Bruce Grocott, and it was agreed that they would push the line, 'substance not spin', at everything William Hague could throw at them.

It was a disaster. With the Commons packed and four former leaders of Australia looking on in bemused wonder from the public gallery, Blair was given a very public roasting. Tired after a series of nights kept awake by his two-month-old son, Leo, and grappling with the increasingly tense state in Northern Ireland, the Prime Minister said he had agreed to a memorial to US servicemen killed in the Second World War. Good idea, accept that it was Australian servicemen. He then said he was only interested in 'spin not substance'. Grocott's heart must have sunk.

'Tony has a real problem with Question Time,' one senior Labour backbencher and former Minister said. 'He is too crammed with statistics and Hague beats him with quips and soundbites. He's got to relax, he's got to forget his barrister training.'

Last Wednesday evening Blair was working alone on his speech to black evangelical leaders when the call came. He was already a little concerned about his son Euan, who was out with friends celebrating the end of his GCSEs. Cherie Blair was in Portugal for a few days with Leo and the Prime Minister was wondering how long he should wait before parental concern turned to action.

As midnight approached, Special Branch officers rang and said that Blair's 16-year-old son had been found, drunk and incapable, in Leicester Square. He had given a false name, age and address. Police only realised who he was when they asked him to turn out his pockets and discovered Euan's Downing Street security pass.

An hour later and Campbell was already getting calls. Someone had tipped off the tabloids. But it was very late, and the newspapers, aware of the dangers of reporting on the Blair's children, agreed to hold off.

The next morning Campbell and Blair met to discuss how to handle the issue. Lord Wakeham, chairman of the Press Complaints Commission, had put out a statement saying that because Euan was 16 and because it was not an incident linked to school he did not come under the press code of conduct which protected children. The London Evening Standard had already decided to run the story. Campbell knew they would have to put a brave face on it and give out the details of what was, at its simplest, a criminal offence. That morning's lobby briefing, in the hot and sweaty downstairs room next to No 10, was packed. Journalists were left queueing outside as the 11.30am start time came and went.

Twenty minutes later Campbell arrived, clutching a mug of tea in one hand and a hastily typed-up statement in the other. He smiled as he fielded questions. Any drugs involved, Alastair? No. What do his parents think? Well, obviously, they're not very happy. All a bit embarrassing given the Prime Minister's pledge to clean hooligans and drunks off the streets? Well, put it this way, given that Euan was lying on the floor and couldn't move, there wasn't an awful lot of damage he could do. There was laughter.

At 12.45pm the official cars pulled up outside Downing Street and Blair and Campbell were whisked to Victoria station for the 1.08pm train to Brighton where Blair was to address a conference organised by the African and Caribbean Evangelical Alliance.

In the first-class carriage, the two men sat opposite each other and trawled through Blair's speech line by line. Some of the dryer passages were dropped and Blair decided it would be ridiculous if he didn't mention his son.

In the ugly Seventies conference centre next door to the Brighton Pavilion, Blair went to the podium. 'The values you represent are the values we all share,' he said. 'Respect, tolerance, trying to bring up children properly.' He paused as a ripple of laughter went round the hall. 'That part was written a short time ago.'

Then came the killer blow. 'Being a Prime Minister can be a tough job, but I always think that being a parent is probably tougher.' He was on the verge of tears. And then he revealed how tired he was. 'I know it's only been three years, sometimes it feels like 30.' The audience gave him a standing ovation.

The day's finale, and the most testing engagement of all, was a recording of BBC's Question Time with David Dimbleby. It was filmed at Brighton and Hove Sixth Form College and from 4pm until his car swept up to the redbrick building around four hours later, Blair was doing his homework, closeted with advisers while a bus load of pro-hunting campaigners prepared for him, laughing and joking at a nearby pub.

Blair was on form. He gave a robust response to those who heckled his positive stance on the euro. 'Even though it's unpopular with certain people sometimes it's up to the Prime Minister to tell people what they don't want to hear.'

Blair has insisted to colleagues that after a week of froth, he wants to concentrate on the fundamentals - jobs, education, the economy.

More than 20,000 documents entitled '300 Gains from a Labour Government', have been sent to MPs and party members. Achievement number one says 929,000 more jobs have been created since 1997 and that unemployment is at its lowest for 20 years. Number 300 details achievements in providing 'sport for all'. Members will be expected to stick to the '300 achievements' script as the election campaign approaches.

This week sees the publication of the Government's annual report, which will show the party has achieved most of its election manifesto pledges. This is where Blair wants to focus the debate.

There was a brief glimmer of sunshine from the right-wing press. Max Hastings, old-style Tory and editor of the Evening Standard, said: 'New Labour is going to be re-elected next year because the party looks like it belongs to the 21st century, while the Tories are mired in the twentieth.'

But it was only a glimmer. By yesterday everyone was again asking the question: is Blair beginning to show the strain? 'The question is not, "Has Tony Blair taken punishment?" Like all his predecessors, he clearly has,' the Labour peer and former deputy leader of the party, Roy Hattersley, wrote in the Daily Mail yesterday. 'We need to know if he can survive. From time to time all politicians are knocked down. Will Blair get up?'

Campbell dismisses all talk of Blair failing to take the strain. It's a difficult job, for God's sake, he says, and the Prime Minister is quite capable of handling it.

As he got up to address the National Policy Forum in Exeter yesterday, Blair tried again to focus on on the Government's record, believing this is where he will beat Hague. The modern sports hall among the traditional spires of Exeter University seemed the perfect backdrop.

fields.headline: Indonesia on the brink of meltdown
fields.standfirst:
Rulers dither and army awaits its chance as thousands die in sectarian conflict
Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Bomb plots, ethnic and regional violence, a sinking currency, a feeble government and a restless military are compounding the sense that Indonesia is approaching meltdown.
fields.body:
Bomb plots, ethnic and regional violence, a sinking currency, a feeble government and a restless military are compounding the sense that Indonesia is approaching meltdown.

Amid mounting international alarm, Foreign Minister Alwi Shihab last week warned diplomats against 'meddling' in Indonesia's internal affairs. UN peacekeepers have been in East Timor since it voted for autonomy and rebels in other regions have called for international intervention.

In the Moluccas, the islands famous for their spices, Christians and Muslims have been locked in a sectarian conflict for the past 18 months that has left more than 3,000 people dead and almost 500,000 refugees.

Militant Muslim fighters from Java and Sumatra have descended on the islands and launched a major offensive. Hundreds of people have been killed, including 500 drowned when a ferry they were fleeing on sank.

Most of the fighting has been around the region's main city, Ambon. Last Wednesday, the principal university in the Moluccas, Universitas Pattimura, was looted and razed to the ground by Muslims.

On Thursday, the European Parliament called for international intervention, in the form of observers and increased aid. But most aid workers believe brutal tactics are necessary. 'The army is going to have to go in and shoot a couple of dozen people on both sides to show they mean business,' one European logistics expert said.

The armed forces are criticised for not only failing to curb the fighting, but for actively participating in it.

In Poso, central Sulawesi, Christians and Muslims fought for weeks in May and June. Rivers ran with blood and bodies. Mass graves turn up every day and the authorities believe the death toll of 211 could more than double.

Last Thursday, deadly clashes broke out in central Kalimantan, on Borneo island, between the indigenous Dayaks and migrants from Madura, an island off the north-east coast of Java.

Conflict is also continuing in Aceh in north Sumatra, while pro-independence groups in Papua, the Indonesian half of New Guinea, report escalating activity by pro-Jakarta militias trying to disrupt their peaceful campaign.

At a crucial parliamentary session next month, President Abdurrahman Wahid will account for his first 10 months in office. A week ago, legislators were convinced the almost blind Muslim cleric would survive the test, but now they are not so sure.

'People are getting very jittery in the parliament,' said legislator Tosari Widjaja. 'The situation is getting out of control and the President does not seem to be able to stop the collapse.' The military is content to remain in the barracks, but there are signs that what was once the country's most powerful socio-political force is starting to get restless again.

What might prompt Wahid's opponents to act would be if the economy continues its downward spiral. Ministers and central bank officials say the economy is much stronger than the value of the rupiah indicates and that the current downturn - it has fallen more than 10 per cent in less than a month - is only a hiatus.

But with prices starting to rise and foreign investors staying away, Ministers admit the outlook is bleak. 'If the rupiah remains weak, our economic indicators will soon be affected,' senior Economics Minister Kwik Kian Gie said on Thursday.

The other area where Indonesians expect government action is in the prosecution of the former dictator, President Suharto, his family and cronies. He is under investigation for allegedly stealing tens of billions of dollars. One bomb exploded and two others were found at the attorney-general's office last week in an apparent terror tactic by parties wanting to disrupt the investigation.

On Friday, the chief of police said the bombs were of the kind used in military operations and that the explosion happened soon after Suharto's son, Hutomo 'Tommy' Mandala Putra, had been questioned at the office.

Political analyst Tommy Legowo is pessimistic. 'Unless the political elites sort out their differences and start running the country, we will head towards anarchy and away from democratisation,' he said. 'And national disintegration is only a short step beyond that.'

fields.headline: Fiji rebels seize 30 more hostages
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: A second hostage crisis erupted in Fiji yesterday as armed rebels supporting coup leader George Speight seized 30 soldiers, police and government officials in a police station 40 miles from the capital.
fields.body:
A second hostage crisis erupted in Fiji yesterday as armed rebels supporting coup leader George Speight seized 30 soldiers, police and government officials in a police station 40 miles from the capital.

Speight said there would be more unrest until the military gave in to his demands. But he also offered hope of an end to the crisis that has gripped Fiji since he and six gunmen stormed the parliament on 19 May and took the democratically elected government hostage.

'It will be resolved very soon, I am confident of it,' he told reporters. 'The army will see the folly of its ways. They have completely misread a political situation.'

Earlier yesterday a spokesman for the second gang of hostage-takers, Iferemi Tiko, told reporters he was a cousin of Speight and that the latest action was in support of Speight's aims to disenfranchise ethnic Indians.

Tiko led about 100 rebels with makeshift weapons who took over a military checkpoint in Korovou before confiscating six M-16 rifles and storming the town's small police station.

fields.headline: Police probe Customs drugs sting
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A special team of elite detectives has been set up to probe allegations that Customs and Excise officers set up a series of bogus drug deals to entrap men they suspected of trafficking heroin.
fields.body:
A special team of elite detectives has been set up to probe allegations that Customs and Excise officers set up a series of bogus drug deals to entrap men they suspected of trafficking heroin.

A number of officers have been suspended and dozens questioned in the probe, which lawyers say could result in at least 13 convictions being overturned. Several convicted drugs dealers have been interviewed by the police in prison. Customs sources admit that the investigation is unprecedented.

'It is by far the biggest ever. Nothing like this has ever happened before,' a senior officer said last week.

The investigation is based in south Birmingham and is staffed by officers from West Midlands police force and the National Crime Squad - a nationwide pool of top detectives who investigate serious crimes. Unusually, the inquiry is being run by an assistant chief constable.

The investigation centres on a series of Customs operations between 1994 and 1998 which led to the convictions of more than a dozen alleged drug traffickers. The inquiry was originally run by Customs officers themselves but was handed over to the police last year when its complexity and seriousness became obvious. The allegations against Customs officers include perversion of the course of justice - a police matter.

The operations under investigation all involve 'controlled deliveries' of heroin to Britain from Pakistan. Informants were recruited by Customs to pose as couriers to arrange the smuggling of large quantities of heroin - refined in the lawless Pakistani border areas from locally grown opium - into the UK. They were monitored all the way by officers based at the British High Commission in Islamabad, the Pakistan capital, and in Britain.

There have also been allegations that Customs officers 'recycled' seized drugs as bait for potential traffickers in fresh deals.

The inquiry was launched after two court cases involving 55 kilos of heroin with a street value of around £7 million collapsed when the alleged 'dealer' - a 45-year-old Bradford businessman - said he was prepared to give evidence on behalf of the five defendants. Solicitors in Birmingham, Bradford and Glasgow are all watching the inquiry with interest. The result of the police probe could launch a wave of appeals against recent convictions, lawyers say.

Marsha Singh, Labour MP for Bradford West, has a number of his constituents among those convicted in trials now under examination by the West Midlands team.

'A number of very serious charges have been made about controlled deliveries and it is important that the matter is cleared up as soon as possible,' he said.

Corruption inquiries are rare among Customs and Excise officers. While the police have suffered a series of very public scandals resulting in scores of detectives being sacked, moved or disciplined, there are few recorded instances of Customs officers being found guilty of similar misdemeanours. Critics of the service say this is because Customs officers have managed to ward off public scrutiny more successfully than the police; their defenders say they are genuinely less prone to corruption.

The number of police and Customs seizures involving heroin, still the most frequently seized Class A drug, rose to nearly 15,000 in 1998 - the most recent figures available - but the amount confiscated dropped.

Last week Customs and Excise chiefs heard that they were to be quizzed by MPs to explain why the House of Commons had not been made aware of a legal loophole that may have cost the Exchequer up to £2 billion.

A Customs and Excise spokesman refused to go into details about the West Midlands inquiry.

'This is a matter being quite properly dealt with by the police. We cannot comment on any ongoing investigation,' he said.

jason.burke@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Loyalists in murder ultimatum
fields.standfirst:
'We'll kill a Catholic every day'

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The spectre of sectarian murder haunts Northern Ireland again after a warning that loyalist terrorists plan to kill a Catholic a day if today's planned Orange Order march at Drumcree is blocked.
fields.body:
The spectre of sectarian murder haunts Northern Ireland again after a warning that loyalist terrorists plan to kill a Catholic a day if today's planned Orange Order march at Drumcree is blocked.

With security forces on high alert, senior RUC officers said the plan had been devised by a loose alliance of the Loyalist Volunteer Force and elements of the Ulster Freedom Fighters.

One police officer involved in the security operation at Drumcree told The Observer that loyalist informants had claimed a coalition between the LVF in Portadown and UFF units in north and west Belfast, along with its South-east Antrim brigade, will carry out sectarian assassinations if there is a stand-off at Drumcree today.

The two groups will not admit responsibility for the murders, adopting a 'no claim, no blame' policy. The officer said the campaign would begin in the mid-Ulster area, where the LVF is strongest, but spread out as the Drumcree stand-off continued to other parts of Northern Ireland. 'All our informants on the loyalist side, all our intelligence, points to a new strategy after Sunday. They will kill a Catholic a day until the Orangemen get down the Garvaghy Road. Kill a Catholic a day in any part of Northern Ireland - it's as simple as that,' he said.

The officer added that there had been a debate in the highest echelons of the RUC over their response to the loyalist violence of the past seven days. It centred on whether the force would recommend to Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, that loyalist prisoners recently released from the Maze should be re-arrested. So far the Chief Constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, has resisted advising Mandelson to re-arrest loyalist leaders.

Johnny Adair, the former UFF commander who has become a loyalist cult hero at Drumcree, has denied that the organisation was planning sectarian attacks. Asked if the UFF was linking up with the LVF to kill a Catholic a day and pressurise the Government to reverse the Drumcree ban, Adair said: 'Absolutely not.' The Shankill Road loyalist said he 'fully supported' the Orangemen's protest at Drumcree and their right to walk along the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown. He also criticised rival loyalist Billy Hutchinson of the UVF-aligned Progressive Unionist Party who claimed the UFF was behind a series of gun attacks on the RUC in the Lower Shankill area last Tuesday. 'Billy Hutchinson is a liar,' Adair said.

Orangemen in Portadown called for the entire order to organise four hours of protest across Northern Ireland tomorrow in support of the Drumcree protest. They confirmed that the protest would continue until their civil and religious liberties were restored.

The RUC's concern about renewed loyalist violence has been compounded by the force's inability to use plastic bullets. Under new legislation introduced to coincide with the Patten report, RUC personnel cannot fire plastic bullets without the permission of senior officers. The restriction was the main reason why a water cannon was used at Drumcree last week - the first time the device has been used in Ulster since 1970.

An RUC spokesman said 37 police officers and two soldiers had been injured in last week's street protests. There were 145 attacks on the security forces including 12 gun attacks over five nights of trouble. Forty-three homes have been damaged and 54 people have been arrested for public order offences.

Although Protestant areas were quiet overnight, there were more sectarian attacks on Catholic-owned schools yesterday. Petrol bombs damaged two primary schools in Newtonabbey in the northern outskirts of Belfast. Loyalists also attacked a religiously integrated secondary school in Carrickfergus.

David Trimble, Northern Ireland's First Minister, appealed for 'cool heads' yesterday but said he had no intention of resigning from the Orange Order, adding that he supported their right to march down the Garvaghy Road. Drumcree itself resembles a battlefield with rolls of barbed wire across fields beside a huge steel and concrete barrier erected on the road from Drumcree to the Garvaghy Road.

Mandelson paid a visit yesterday to Mahon Road army barracks in Portadown, the centre of the massive security operation at Drumcree. The Northern Ireland Secretary said there was a 'rabble hijacking this process' who had exploited the Drumcree protests. Mandelson added that he was sorry that local Orange leaders in Portadown were not more outspoken about the street violence.

Meanwhile the opening of a community garden in Derry featuring the BBC presenter Charlie Dimmock has been cancelled following loyalist threats. The building of the garden was filmed for the BBC's Charlie's Garden Army as a project involving people from both sides of the community.

fields.headline: Yeltsin blamed for Russia's ills
fields.standfirst:
Putin finds a scapegoat for Chechen violence, rampant corruption and reliance on the West
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian state needs to be strengthened radically if it is to reverse the sharp decline of the past decade, President Vladimir Putin said yesterday, coupling his solution for Russia's ills with an undercurrent of savage criticism aimed at his patron - former President Boris Yeltsin.
fields.body:
The Russian state needs to be strengthened radically if it is to reverse the sharp decline of the past decade, President Vladimir Putin said yesterday, coupling his solution for Russia's ills with an undercurrent of savage criticism aimed at his patron - former President Boris Yeltsin.

Making his first state of the nation address since his election in March, Putin warned that Russia was on the verge of becoming a Third World nation if its economic problems were not urgently addressed. He said the cure lay in reasserting the state's authority and implementing liberal economic reforms. He devoted the first half of the 50-minute speech to a harsh assessment of the key threats and difficulties facing Russia. At the root of all these problems was the weakness at the state's core which had developed under his predecessor.

The conflict in Chechnya, the dire problems wracking Russia's economy, proliferating corruption, the crippling lack of co-operation between Moscow and the nation's many regions - all were the direct result of weak rule. Yeltsin, who was expected to make a rare public appearance to listen to the speech in the ornate Marble Hall of the Kremlin, chose not to attend.

'We have to recognise that the state itself was largely responsible for the growing strength of the unofficial, shadow economy, the spread of corruption and the flow of great quantities of money abroad,' Putin said at the start of the speech, before promising that under his rule there would be no more empty promises and hollow declarations.

'An inefficient state is the main reason for our long and deep crisis - I am absolutely convinced of this.'

Yeltsin named Putin as his heir when he appointed him prime minister last August. He went on to boost his protégé's presidential chances with his premature retirement on New Year's Eve, at a time when Putin's popularity was soaring, crucially curtailing the time opposition candidates had to put up a fight. Until now Putin has stayed loyal to his benefactor; the extent to which he remains beholden to the powerful backroom figures who worked with Yeltsin in his final years remains unclear, but yesterday's address was a bold attempt by the new president to distance himself from his predecessor.

In a text which confirmed Putin's fondness for using an iron fist, the president repeatedly stressed that the only way out of the current morass, was to reassert state authority and gather power back from the regions to the centre.

Putin's authoritarian tendencies have caused some unease at home and more in the West. Clearly aware of these sensitivities, he accompanied his demands for a strong state with assertions of his commitment to democracy within Russia.

'The battle between strong power and freedom is an old one, and at the moment this debate is giving rise almost daily to speculation on the themes of dictatorship and authoritarianism,' he said. 'But our position is clear. Only a strong and democratic state can defend the civil, political and economic freedoms of the population.'

Putin also grappled with two other issues which have caused international consternation during his months in power: free speech and the war in Chechnya. Growing visibly angry and raising his voice as he focused on the continuing row over press freedoms, he asserted that freedom of speech remained an 'unshakeable value in Russian democracy'. However, he went on to undermine his own comments by declaring that political and business interests were manipulating the media and using it to attack the state. 'We must guarantee journalists' freedom that is real and not just for show,' he said.

He defended the Russian army's brutal campaign in Chechnya, arguing that if firm measures had not been taken, the unrest in the region would have led to the further disintegration of Russia, and stressing that 'international terrorism' needed to be fought.

In another apparent condemnation of Yeltsin - who once told regional leaders to 'take as much autonomy as they could swallow' - he described the situation he inherited in Chechnya as 'an extreme example of the government's failure to assert its authority over the regions'.

Looking pinched and slightly nervous, Putin began the most important speech in his career so far by listing what he saw as the most acute problems faced by the nation. In the first place he highlighted the alarming consequences of Russia's demographic crisis. He said that with the population shrinking at a rate of 750,000 people a year, the size of the nation could decrease by up to 22 million over the next 15 years - losing one seventh of the total population. 'If the current tendency prevails, the survival of the nation will be under threat,' he warned, adding that Russia could end up a 'senile state'.

The country's standing in the world would be jeopardised as a result of the dwindling birthrate in conjunction with the still feeble economy - with Russia dropping further and further behind the West, he said.

'The matter is not only a question of national pride. The question is far more acute and more dramatic: will we be able to survive as a nation, as a civilisation, if our well-being continues to depend on the goodwill of the world economy?'

He went on to devote the bulk of his speech to laying out in detail how his government could remedy the economic crisis, noting six fundamental principles - guaranteeing property rights; stopping the preferential treatment of some businesses over others, and ending unnecessary state intervention in business; lowering the tax burden; simplifying the customs system; developing banks and other economic infrastructure; and reorganising the welfare system by reducing the number of benefits handed out.

In a text which confirmed Putin's fondness for using an iron fist, the president repeatedly stressed that the only way out of the current morass, was to reassert state authority and gather power back from the regions to the centre. Putin's authoritarian tendencies have caused some unease at home and more in the West. Clearly aware of these sensitivities, he accompanied his demands for a strong state with assertions of his commitment to democracy within Russia. 'The battle between strong power and freedom is an old one, and at the moment this debate is giving rise almost daily to speculation on the themes of dictatorship and authoritarianism,' he said. 'But our position is clear. Only a strong and democratic state can defend the civil, political and economic freedoms of the population.' Putin also grappled with two other issues which have caused international consternation during his months in power: free speech and the war in Chechnya. Growing visibly angry and raising his voice as he focused on the continuing row over press freedoms, he asserted that freedom of speech remained an 'unshakeable value in Russian democracy'. However, he went on to undermine his own comments by declaring that political and business interests were manipulating the media and using it to attack the state. 'We must guarantee journalists' freedom that is real and not just for show,' he said. He defended the Russian army's brutal campaign in Chechnya, arguing that if firm measures had not been taken, the unrest in the region would have led to the further disintegration of Russia, and stressing that 'international terrorism' needed to be fought. In another apparent condemnation of Yeltsin - who once told regional leaders to 'take as much autonomy as they could swallow' - he described the situation he inherited in Chechnya as 'an extreme example of the government's failure to assert its authority over the regions'. Looking pinched and slightly nervous, Putin began the most important speech in his career so far by listing what he saw as the most acute problems faced by the nation. In the first place he highlighted the alarming consequences of Russia's demographic crisis. He said that with the population shrinking at a rate of 750,000 people a year, the size of the nation could decrease by up to 22 million over the next 15 years - losing one seventh of the total population. 'If the current tendency prevails, the survival of the nation will be under threat,' he warned, adding that Russia could end up a 'senile state'. The country's standing in the world would be jeopardised as a result of the dwindling birthrate in conjunction with the still feeble economy - with Russia dropping further and further behind the West, he said. 'The matter is not only a question of national pride. The question is far more acute and more dramatic: will we be able to survive as a nation, as a civilisation, if our well-being continues to depend on the goodwill of the world economy?' He went on to devote the bulk of his speech to laying out in detail how his government could remedy the economic crisis, noting six fundamental principles - guaranteeing property rights; stopping the preferential treatment of some businesses over others, and ending unnecessary state intervention in business; lowering the tax burden; simplifying the customs system; developing banks and other economic infrastructure; and reorganising the welfare system by reducing the number of benefits handed out.

webTitle: Tempted by Europe? It's different there

fields.headline: Tempted by Europe? It's different there
fields.trailText: Fidelity's new European Index fund sounds like a great idea. Europe has been one of the best-performing areas, and most expect this to continue. The fund is also a tracker, and statistics show that even the best active fund managers are lucky to outperform indexed funds by enough to compensate for their higher fees.
fields.body:
Fidelity's new European Index fund sounds like a great idea. Europe has been one of the best-performing areas, and most expect this to continue. The fund is also a tracker, and statistics show that even the best active fund managers are lucky to outperform indexed funds by enough to compensate for their higher fees.

But Europe is different. Statistics from HSBC show that, over the past five years, more than 80 per cent of actively managed European unit trusts beat the index, compared with just 27 per cent of UK specialists. HSBC's Alan Gadd suggests this is because European markets are influenced more by medium and small businesses. Active managers can reflect that in their portfolio; trackers cannot. Similarly, active managers can choose their countries; trackers have to invest across the whole of Europe.

The difference in active and tracking portfolios is striking. Baillie Gifford European has just 42 stocks in its portfolio, while M & G European has 57. In contrast M&G's European tracker, launched in February, will have 500 when it is fully invested. Fidelity's fund will have just 50 - like the Dow Jones Eurostoxx index it tracks - but the choice will be based on market value.

Baillie Gifford European's manager, Andrew Strathdee, has pursued a growth strategy, buying good small companies - an early success was Nokia, which now accounts for 9 per cent of the fund - and avoiding industries he expects to be dull. This has paid off. In the five years to 28 April, the fund is up 220 per cent, compared with 130 per cent for its FTSE index benchmark.

So should investors shun European trackers? Not necessarily. You need to know what you're buying. Michael Hayden of Legal & General points out that some funds sold as European are quite specialised - as Baillie Gifford's concentrated portfolio suggests. That can be disastrous - remember Peter Young and Morgan Grenfell's European funds.

However, John Hatherly M&G says Europe lags behind the UK and the US in restructuring and focus on shareholder value, so it is easier to pick companies which are likely to do well.

Fidelity also offers a range of managed funds and sees its trackers as a good way for novice investors to build a balanced portfolio. More adventurous investors should look for managed funds - but be sure that they know what they are buying.

fields.headline: Medics jump NHS queues
fields.trailText: Up to a million NHS workers are routinely jumping official waiting lists for their own treatment at the cost of ordinary patients who have to wait up to 18 months.
fields.body:
Up to a million NHS workers are routinely jumping official waiting lists for their own treatment at the cost of ordinary patients who have to wait up to 18 months. The scandal, uncovered by an Observer investigation, has caused fury among NHS patients who have had their lives threatened by delayed or cancelled operations.

Doctors insist that avoiding lengthy delays and getting first class treatment is the last perk of working for the NHS. They admit they are not prepared to wait as long as their patients, but justify what they say is a 'gentleman's agreement' because it keeps them working.

However, the Department of Health condemned it as 'totally unacceptable'. And Roger Gough of the pressure group Patient Concern said: 'The one million of them shouldn't get priority over the other 57 million of us. It's unethical, even if the doctors want it that way.'

The investigation revealed that hospital staff get both initial consultation and then surgery far quicker than ordinary patients. They are also far more likely to be treated by a senior consultant, while ordinary patients are treated by more junior colleagues.

Techniques used to jump waiting lists include cancelling operations for other patients; opening operating theatres out of hours; or simply claiming that their clinical condition is far more urgent than it really is.

Peter Fisher, president of the NHS Consultants Association, said: 'So long as it is for all staff, not just consultants, there is an argument for it, as it keeps the system working. It's one of those gentleman's agreements, it's not formally talked about. It's a bit like British Rail, where staff get travel concessions, or people who work at banks getting cheaper mortgages.'

John Yates, professor of health policy at Birmingham University, said: 'It's human nature... almost impossible to stop. But it is a moral issue.'

Justin Keen, a fellow of the King's Fund, and one of the top health policy analysts in the UK - but not a medical worker - said he was a victim. 'I had a hernia and it was unbelievably painful. I had been waiting months already, but... I was bumped off the waiting list by a junior doctor. He just rolled up and was treated in a couple of hours.'

A DoH spokeswoman said: 'This is totally unacceptable. The NHS should provide treatment solely on the basis of clinical need, no matter where you live or what you happen to do.'

webTitle: Shopping? Can't you see I'm on the phone?

fields.headline: Shopping? Can't you see I'm on the phone?
fields.trailText: John Naughton: The Networker
fields.body:
Now that over half the population owns a mobile phone, stand by for an outbreak of Electric Wok Syndrome. This is the condition, often terminal, which induces industries to believe that because something can be made, consumers will want it. The latest manifestation of this is a sudden upsurge in corporate belief that the Next Big Thing (now that e-commerce has bombed) will be m-commerce - selling stuff to consumers over their mobile phones.

One can see why the disease has taken hold. The great British public has finally tumbled to the absurdity of having telephones tethered, like goats, to the wall, and so mobiles are becoming ubiquitous. Then there is the fact that it is possible (via Wap technology) for current mobiles to access the net (well, sort of) and the promise that the next generation of phones will have permanent, high-bandwidth internet connections.

Add the fact that the phone networks, unlike the internet, can do 'microbilling - charging for inexpensive transactions - and the realisation that the phone always knows where it is, and you have a marketing opportunity to end all marketing opportunities.

This is the reasoning that has led men in suits to gamble unconscionable amounts of money on buying licences for the third-generation (3G) mobile networks. Wiser heads than mine have already pointed out that there is no conceivable way in which the operators can get a return on these outlays from telephony alone.

But the networks are unmoved. Telephony is old hat, they say; m-commerce is the thing. All kinds of lucrative services will be available over the new phones, yea even live video.

It will be like the net, they say, only bigger. In the brave new fantasy world of 3G, we will all be able to buy things all the time. Most of what we buy will be services - news, football results, share prices, horoscopes, weather forecasts and, er, lots more really cool stuff they haven't thought of yet.

Because the phone knows where it is, you can always ask it for a map, or the location of the nearest taxi-rank, or indeed the nearest pub. When you're walking down a street you'll get a call from a local hostelry. Up flashes live video of the pub's interior - complete with vomiting yobs, underdressed tarts and other attractions - overlaid with the message: 'It's all happening down at LagerLand three doors down on the right. What'll you have, mate?'

There are so many absurdities in the m-commerce scenario that one scarcely knows where to begin. The most glaring is the assumption that everyone is a compulsive shopper - that the 3G phone is really the Home Shopping Network on legs. Another is the assumption that most people will be happy for their precise location to be tracked by their phone and signalled to strangers (or indeed even their employers or families).

The idea of a walk down an urban street metamorphosing into running a gauntlet of e-hucksters will be enough to make many people turn off their phones. And who really wants to watch Desmond Lynam on a postage-stamp screen, even if he is 'live', or at any rate not actually dead?

I could go on; but you get the point. What we are seeing in m-commerce hype is wishful thinking elevated to a business strategy. Much the same has been true of the stampede into e-commerce on the net. Both are undermined by their denial of the simple fact that human beings are social animals first and passive consumers second.

Give them a technology for communicating and they will use it for that. They use the net primarily for email, and phones primarily for talk. They are unlikely to change their spots, not even to save Vodafone from bankruptcy.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: The waiting game
fields.trailText: 'OK, I'd be the first to admit that I'm not the most assiduous follower of lawn tennis, but surely every Englishman owes it to himself and to his country to take himself off to Wimbledon at least once in his life to support one of Britain's more civilised institutions and in the process perhaps cheer Tim Henman to victory over Boris or Bjorn'.
fields.body:
OK, I'd be the first to admit that I'm not the most assiduous follower of lawn tennis, but surely every Englishman owes it to himself and to his country to take himself off to Wimbledon at least once in his life to support one of Britain's more civilised institutions and in the process perhaps cheer Tim Henman to victory over Boris or Bjorn and drink champagne and not mind that it's chucking it down with rain because isn't that part of the national sense of humour and legendary plucky spirit under the bombardment of enemy weather? Perhaps Dame Cliff will be there to give us a song!

And there's nothing snooty about Wimbledon. If you're not Princess Michael of Kent or one of the players' fiancées or don't know anyone who owns a large dotcom enterprise with their own liveried box or designer hotel in the stands, it doesn't matter - all you have to do is turn up, hire some binoculars and take a bit of an interest. So I wait until my wife is safely off to her supply teaching job in up-and-coming Hackney (only two people shot outside the school this month) and head for the less grievous bodily harmful part of London, which as it happens is where I have to be in any case at six o'clock to attend a union meeting to decide whether we are going to accept the management's morally reprehensible and derisory bribe of jam today or prepare to take firm action to get organically sustainable and slightly less derisory jam in the long run, so why not kill two birds with one Travelcard?

At last I'm waiting at the Earl's Court tube, where already there's the hubbub of excited chatter conducted in the amplified vernacular of our American visitors, who despite a tendency to unfold their maps in confined spaces you can't help but forgive for coming over here and buying up our centre court tickets for all the world as though they don't have tennis in their own country because you have to agree they are always so unfailingly effervescent and willing to share their thoughts with everyone on the platform. I for one am sorry when I see a large group of them get on the train to Richmond, which is very much the wrong direction, though the perfect spot for boating, I understand.

But then by the time we get to the ground, there somehow seems to be millions of us. Who would have guessed tennis was so popular? I join the queue and read my official guide to why Wimbledon is much better organised than, say, The Lion King , which is still using the stuffy old-fashioned method of selling tickets to any Tom, Dick or Harry who rings up with a credit card, whereas here they have a brilliant system whereby everyone is guaranteed to get in with a cheery nod from someone in a blazer and panama hat, though understandably not always on the same day they arrive. Which is a slight worry because I neglected to build time in my busy schedule to buy a pack of M&S mini kievs or one of those little rucksacks designed to be positioned in front of other people's noses on the tube.

But the stewards are fantastically helpful to the point of annoyance and a woman with pineapples on her head comes down the line giving away bottles of fruity Volvic, presumably in the forlorn hope of garnering some kind of media interest. Still, fruity Volvic is wholesome and delicious and to my mind much better than the Ribena, which only the stewards get free. So I wait and do the crossword in the Standard and muse over the ad for penile enlargement and testicular implants until at last someone comes round to announce that, alas, the ground is full, though there is every chance we might get in by six o'clock, in time to see Anatole Dharjeeling (Swe) play Ronald D'Gruyère (Arg) when everyone else has gone home. Oh well. I start the walk back to the station, resolving to write a polite but exhortative note to the manager urging him to please consider staying open for the whole year. I'm sure it would be a big hit. Obviously the staff would have to do a bit more than hand out stickers saying 'I've queued at Wimbledon!', but when all is said and done, you wouldn't catch London Zoo just opening for a fortnight.

On the upside, I do have plenty of time to get to the union meeting. I wonder what the queue's like.

phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: War on corruption? Not quite, Minister

fields.headline: War on corruption? Not quite, Minister
fields.trailText: Gregory Palast: Inside corporate America
fields.body:
There's still one bargain left in Rip-Off Britain: the price of a Minister remains way below the cost of purchasing officials in the United States, and even below the cost in the developing world.

Case in point: last week, it was disclosed that the US Justice Department had sought Swiss help in tracking $60 million (£40m) from British Virgin Islands bank accounts that it alleges was paid to the current president and former prime ministers of Kazakhstan. The account was funded by US giant Exxon-Mobil, British Petroleum and Phillips Petroleum. (There is currently no accusation of criminal intent by the oil firms who, we can assume, had legitimate reasons to send their millions on holiday to the Caribbean.)

By contrast, in 1989, prior to its merger with Exxon, Mobil paid a mere £10,000 to Neil Hamilton following the MP's attempt to scupper a tax on North Sea oil.

During Hamilton's libel suit against Mohamed al-Fayed and the Guardian, a Mobil executive testified that Hamilton, then on the Commons Finance Committee, demanded cash for defending the oil company's positions. The executive was 'horrified', as Mobil had legitimately approached Hamilton without thought of payment. Nevertheless, the firm suggested the payment be invoiced as a consulting fee, though 'The reality was that we were buying off Mr Hamilton for what he had done, in connection with this tax issue.'

In what must be the most stunning - and unreported - statement of the trial, Mobil's barrister informed its executive that 'This was the normal course of things for some MPs who did ask for payment.'

Really? Which other MPs? And how much? And which other companies received bills from 'Parliamentarians-R-Us'? Most important, is this still business as usual?

At first blush, it would appear the game is over. Tough-guy Jack Straw last week published his law reform white paper, Raising Standards and Upholding Integrity: the Prevention of Corruption. Extortionists and bribers beware. No more Hamiltonian fees for favours.

Well, not exactly, explained a Home Office spokesperson. The Home Office would not deem as bribes payments that were for 'remuneration' - consultancy fees. Furthermore, the proposals state that 'offering a bribe' will not constitute an offence unless the pay-off is 'primarily' the reason for a public servant's actions. If a future Hamilton simply has a heartfelt hatred of taxes on oil companies, and oil company payola merely stiffens his resolve, the cash is his to keep.

Then bribery is legal? Don't be cynical. A £10 pay-off, says the Home Office, would be a 'gratuity', but a million pound pay-off is corrupt. It depends on the amount that the fixer believes would influence the politician's decision.

How about £10,000? The functionary told me, either as a warning or an advertisement: 'Ten thousand would influence me, but maybe not some of our wealthier MPs.' (The Home Office declines, however, to publish the price list for each member of the Government.)

I was assured that the normal course of things remains undisturbed. 'We are not trying to change the law, just clarify it.' New Labour, promised the Home Office, had simply repackaged current common law and three old codes into one statute.

So why had Straw bothered at all with this legal shuffling? Because there was a need for one change: for the first time, the anti-corruption rules, such as they are, will now apply to British corporations bribing foreign officials. This was not a courageous advance towards an ethical foreign policy. Rather, Tony Blair has been dragged kicking and screaming into action by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which declared that Britain was not complying with its Anti-bribery Convention.

Thus, as a result of the Government's belated and grudging move to adhere to international regulations, UK companies that obligingly meet requests for gratuities will now be subject to the same diligent lack of prosecution.

The real test of Blair's commitment to shutting down the worldwide casbah for favours is not whether the Home Office puts UK executives into leg-irons but an action far less dramatic: cutting off public subsidies to companies found guilty of corruption. The World Bank has already adopted this simple rule - if you pay off a potentate (and get caught), you lose your loan guarantees and your government contracts.

For the Prime Minister, this test has arrived now. The government of Lesotho has charged the British construction giant Balfour Beatty - along with several European and American operators - with paying at least 22 million rand (£2.2m) to government agents to grease through approval of lucrative contract amendments in the building of the Highlands dam.

While Balfour Beatty is in the dock in Lesotho, it is drawing down funds backed by the British taxpayer through the Export Credit Guarantee Department, for the company's work on the Ilisu Dam project in Turkey.

The ECGD says it is looking into the Lesotho case.

I called Lesotho's chief prosecutor about any evidence he had passed to Straw. He told me no one from the British Government had contacted him. That does not mean there has been no UK investigation. The Department of Trade and Industry told one watchdog organisation that officials asked Balfour Beatty if the charges had merit and the company said, 'No'. Well then, case closed.

'Government is so hypocritical,' barrister Jeremy Carver told me. Carver, a partner in the big corporate firm Clifford Chance and adviser to anti-corruption campaign Transparency International, fumes at Straw's predilection for strong press releases and weak enforcement.

'I went to a DTI reception,' Carver said. 'I was introduced to someone who identified himself as the chairman of a company and we were talking about corruption. The corporate honcho, the chairman of Balfour Beatty, was not confessing, but boasting about the payment which he may have considered not a bribe but just the cost of doing business Malaysian-style. Carver noted that the then Tory Trade Minister, learning of the pay-off, publicly congratulated Balfour Beatty on its patriotic competitiveness.

This did not surprise Johnny Chung, who pleaded guilty to funnelling money from the Red Chinese military industries to Clinton's campaign. Chung, who earned several meetings with the President, explained: 'I see the White House like a subway - you have to put in coins to open the gates.'

These and hoarier tales suggest that US politicians' zeal to prevent payments of bribes abroad is motivated primarily by a jealous desire to keep all the baksheesh at home.

webTitle: Can Dixons convey more to life than Freeserve?

fields.headline: Can Dixons convey more to life than Freeserve?
fields.trailText: Heather Connon:Throg Street
fields.body:
Why is the City so obsessed with the value of Dixons' stake in Freeserve? The retailer has invested less than £2 million in the business and has already recouped almost £250m through the sale of a 20 per cent stake. If it realises the same price for the remaining 80 per cent - and, unlike practically every other internet flotation, Freeserve's shares are still more than 50 per cent above their issue price - Dixons could pocket another £1 billion. If only it could make that kind of return from selling toasters and computers.

The problem is, of course, that it is unlikely to be able to sell the remainder - at least for the foreseeable future. It may have been able to persuade punters to part with hard cash last July, but floating another large tranche would be unlikely to be so easy. The rather-too-public attempt to auction off Freeserve merely confirmed that no serious bidder would be prepared to offer cash. For Dixons' shareholders, a smaller stake in a larger internet stock would be little better than the large stake in a small ISP.

In the meantime, the market is at a loss as to how to value Freeserve. Is it worth the current value of £3.3bn, or is £9.4bn (the peak reached in March) or £1.2bn (which it sunk to in October) more appropriate?

Analysts are fond of doing sums to prove that Dixons' core business is undervalued, based on stripping out the value of Freeserve. In fact, the only thing such calculations prove is that retail investors have been far more realistic about the ISP's worth than technology punters are.

When Freeserve shares were at their peak, Dixons looked extremely undervalued - indeed, the analysts proclaimed you were getting the retail chain for free. But that was simply because retail investors, sensibly enough as it turned out, did not believe the toppy valuation.

The Freeserve conundrum is, however, diverting attention from the performance of Dixons' core business. At the moment, that may be no bad thing. On the face of it, the results are not bad, particularly given the poor retailing climate. Profits, excluding the Freeserve disposal and Dixons' share of the ongoing losses of the business, rose by 11 per cent.

The trouble is, sales from continuing businesses were 16 per cent ahead. The difference between the two rates of increase was a squeeze on margins, which fell by 1 per cent.

Dixons makes much of the fact that it managed to claw back three-quarters of that lost margin through improved efficiency in the buying process, streamlining its customer service centre and tinkering with its store design. The trouble is, the City expects at least as much margin pressure this year - and if Dixons carries on recouping only some of that through cost control, the result will be lower returns.

Group finance director Ian Livingston is confident that the company can offset 'most, if not all' the margin pressure by continued attention to costs. Investors are sceptical - and that scepticism was increased by the group's reluctance to be specific about current trading. The rather woolly 'the year has started with further sales growth against tough comparatives' was taken as meaning that the rate of increase in the UK stores has slowed markedly from last year's 7 per cent like for like.

There were pockets of disappointment. The 3 per cent like-for-like increase in sales at Currys is less than half that enjoyed by rival Comet, although Livingston believes improvements in store design and stock levels will help. Overall, however, Dixons seems like a business that will struggle for headway.

That is confirmed by analysts' forecasts that profits in the year to next April, excluding Freeserve, will be about £267m - similar to last year. Stripping out Freeserve, that leaves the retail business on a price-earnings ratio of about 13 times. Whether that is realistic depends far less on the future of Dixons' business than on your assumptions about the value of Freeserve. Until that is resolved - and Dixons shows it can cope with margin pressure - there is no reason to buy the shares.

Mixed brew

Brian Stewart, chief executive of Scottish & Newcastle, talks about a 'strategic reshaping' of the group, following the acquisition of Kronenbourg beer, Greenalls pubs and restaurants and the, hopefully, imminent sale of Center Parcs and Pontin's. So far, however, little of that strategic reshaping has been evident in the shares, which still stand on a rating of about 10 times earnings.

There was enough in the results for the year to March to suggest that that could be a bit unfair. The shares dipped initially on disappointment that the £415m profit was a bit below the City's expectations, but they subsequently bounced as investors got to grips with the prospects for the new-look group.

Little of that new look was evident in the figures. Greenalls was included for just five months, and the Kronenbourg deal has still to be completed. But the potential is already clear. The £25m cost savings promised at Greenalls is on target. The 6 per cent drop in food sales at its outlets, compared with an impressive 14 per cent growth in S&N's own brands, underlines the potential for improving its performance.

There is still much to do. The 'tail' of unbranded pubs is still holding back performance, accounting for much of the squeeze in margins suffered by the managed-pub divisions. Only 40 per cent of the estate is currently branded, under names such as Chef & Brewer. S&N's target is 65 per cent.

Analysts say that will mean selling a further 500 pubs, although the company suggests the figure could be closer to 300. In brewing, Interbrew's acquisition of the beer business of Whitbread and Bass may have knocked S&N off the top slot, but it could still be good for prospects. Interbrew will be left with significant debt, not to mention the need to demonstrate that it can handle two such sizable deals.

It is more likely to want to keep the market stable - and margins healthy - than to do anything to upset it. That should help keep profits at S&N's brewing division, up 4.8 per cent last year, on an upward trend.

The delayed sale of Center Parcs is likely to continue to weigh on the shares. Analysts are now expecting it to raise as little as £700m, compared with talk a few months ago of £800m - and investment of more than £1.2bn since it was acquired. The shares are unlikely to move much until that deal is completed, but they do currently look cheap.

fields.headline: The willing captives of Whitehall
fields.trailText: William Keegan: In my view
fields.body:
The Government may be spinning out of control, but this merely means that normal service has been resumed. Since the disastrous New Year's Eve opening of the Dome, there has been a healthy realisation that the Blair regime is mortal.

The curse of the Government's failure to provide even a drink for some of the Dome's backers on New Year's Eve lives on: some prominent City figures invited to dine with the Chancellor and the American Ambassador to celebrate British entrepreneurship at the Dome last Wednesday could not quite face it.

If the myth of New Labour's magical powers has been laid to rest, one other myth, associated with the nation's obsession with 'spin', has endured.

This is that Tony Blair, Alastair Campbell and the rest walked into Whitehall and 'took over' the civil service. That wise observer of Whitehall, Professor Colin Campbell of Georgetown University, Washington DC, has recently been over on one of his regular check-ups of British governance, and reached a conclusion that explains quite a lot. According to Campbell (Colin, not Alastair), far from taking over Whitehall, 'Blair and his Party have been captured by Whitehall'.

This helps explain many things. Much of the offence caused to Labour voters over civil liberties appears to have been the result of incoming Labour Ministers picking up Whitehall ideas for intervening in people's lives that even the Tories turned down.

Indeed, it is not uncommon to meet former Conservative Cabinet ministers who freely admit that they recognise a lot of the controversial policies that have swept through the Commons and are now being seriously challenged in the Lords - because Whitehall raised them as options during 1990-97, but they were turned down. Some of those former Ministers can now challenge such policies in the Lords.

The Foreign Secretary's increasingly open championship of the euro constitutes a magnificent example of 'capture' by Whitehall. Robin Cook was cautious about the euro in his early days, but has happily espoused the Foreign Office view. Indeed, the general view in Whitehall - and this extends to the official Treasury, the department still considered the most 'euro-sceptical' - is that, in the words of one senior mandarin, 'there is a sense of inevitability about it all'.

But 'inevitability' does not mean 'tomorrow'. Much of the infighting is about timing and conditions. The strategy is to go in, but we can thank our lucky stars that we have a Chancellor who listens to the crucial Treasury and Bank of England concerns about the appropriate exchange rate that Britain would be adopting forever against other European economies.

Which brings us to where the (Colin) Campbell thesis links up with the general perception that this government is dominated by Gordon Brown. For one of the interesting things about this government is the way the fiscally frugal Son of the Manse and Her Majesty's Treasury were made for each other.

At which point it is pertinent to quote the reply given by Nigel Lawson when asked what had most surprised him, after studying the Treasury from afar, about actually running it. 'The degree to which it is an institution for controlling public spending.'

Or, as a former permanent secretary noted: 'Some commentators do not seem to appreciate that I spend only about a tenth of my time on macro-economic policy.' And that was in an era before Brown hived off month-to-month demand management to the Bank of England.

Before the First World War the state of the real economy - levels of output, employment or prices - was considered to be the result of acts of God or of the Gold Standard. During the twenties, macro-economic policy was left largely to the whims of the Bank of England. It was only after the Keynesian revolution that, in postwar years, attempting to control the business cycle became central to Treasury aims.

The Thatcher governments tried to dispense with demand management, but eventually learnt the error of their ways. Brown handed it back to the Bank of England: although the Treasury retains control of fiscal policy, it eschews short-term management of demand.

The Treasury is back to being an expenditure-control machine par excellence . How Treasury officials loved it when Brown told them: 'I'm serious about freezing public spending for two years.' One cannot quite imagine them replying, 'Oh dear, Chancellor, we have all sorts of spending plans we'd like to offer you.'

No, the Treasury knew Brown was a man they could do business with. They could be as harsh as possible, dust off all their plans for (often mean-minded) spending cuts, and know they would be approved. Even when, this year, the freeze was relaxed and the strategic spending began, officials knew they could attach strings to it.

Lord Desai, the Labour peer, describes the Treasury as an institution for 'pinching the penny and clipping the pound'. Even under the Chancellor's plans for increases in certain areas of public spending from now on, money is dispensed, in the words of one observer, 'neither generously nor with an open heart'.

The Treasury is a reluctant spender. That is one reason why New Labour's efforts are not being greeted with the respect it thinks it deserves. I like the Campbell Thesis.

webTitle: Hope for banks crying all the way to the high street

fields.headline: Hope for banks crying all the way to the high street
fields.trailText: Emily Bell: Comment
fields.body:
Feeling sorry for banks is a bit like feeling sorry for Gerhard Schröder. One moment you are reflecting sadly on how the mighty are fallen, the next you are wondering how you managed to lose the right to stage the World Cup to the pack of sly foxes.

Banks, we hear, are in for a bath - their tenuous hold on a profit mountain so steep that it resembles the north face of the Eiger is about to be broken, with the inevitable consequence of death and mayhem, we are told. Their capitulation on robbing customers every time they choose to visit a hole in the wall - or indeed are forced to do so by an irate Tony Blair who has been woken up by drunken hooligans - has made it a grand slam for the consumer versus the high street bank. Even the high street nomenclature grows increasingly inappropriate as the banks' portfolio of real estate is flogged off to the ghastly All Bar One and Rat and Handbag chains.

Watching the strategies for survival against this brush with adversity is as compelling as a particularly good heat of Gladiators, and about as phoney. The fascinating idea that Abbey National has for franchising out its branches is certainly a step to cut its overheads. Letting space to coffee shop chains, crèches, perhaps even car valeting or free parking ... Who knows what exciting blandishments lie round the corner for tempting our custom. But will clients really buy the idea of handing over their life savings or taking a mortgage out with the financial equivalent of the local manager of McDonald's? Online banks continues to offer more attractive rates, and this is forcing the established players to launch their own groovy brands to compete with the newcomers, though these are often little more than an ad campaign backed by a couple of desks in a call centre.

If we accept however, that the £4 billion or so in excess profits which Don Cruickshank identified are going to dwindle, the question is whether this has happened as a result of the efforts of banking review uberführers, masses of dreadfully negative publicity - or simply a confluence of these with market conditions.

One suspects the latter: the deregulated market was always going have an impact in such a fecund environment for change. The prognosis is that, inevitably, there will be a fallout in the short term, with further mergers and consolidation on the cards.

My colleague Heather Connon (see page 2) rightly points out that declining profit is merely a reality faced up to by the rest of British industry some time ago. But, again like the Germans and their pitiful currency and even more pitiful football team, one suspects that the fat-trimming exercise is a precursor to the British financial services sector rising, phoenix-like, from the ashes. Perhaps it will form the core of an example of where Britain leads the world - that and our Wap phone content.

Or a worse case still: the sector could follow the example of the insurance industry, where a sudden dose of competition led to such aggressively marketed products that consumers basked for a while in the downward spiral of premiums, only to be shocked and dismayed when they inevitably headed back up as companies genuinely struggled to meet their overheads.

But then I'm afraid it will be largely a case of customers having only themselves to blame. Our own inertia in refusing to drop a relationship with a bank which consistently overcharges us is ultimately the biggest hope most lenders have for hanging onto inflated profits.

With more information readily available to the consumer than ever before on the comparable rates for competing financial products, it is amazing that such a high proportion of people stick doggedly with their bank - often even with the branch where they paid in their first pay cheque at the age of 16.

Add to this the number of educated people who until very recently would routinely take out endowment mortgages 'because the building society financial adviser told them to', and there maybe hope in the high street yet.

And there's nothing like a coffee shop to attract a mug punter.

 emily.bell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Branson helps hunt for missing tourist

fields.headline: Branson helps hunt for missing tourist
fields.trailText: Richard Branson has put the resources of the Virgin group behind the search for a young British woman who has been missing in Tokyo for more than a week.
fields.body:
Richard Branson has put the resources of the Virgin group behind the search for a young British woman who has been missing in Tokyo for more than a week.

The tycoon, who has a chain of record shops and cinemas in Japan, has offered to assist the family of Lucy Blackman with a poster campaign in Tokyo and the neighbouring area of China.

The 21-year-old has not been seen since she failed to meet a friend on 1 July.

Japanese police have issued a nationwide alert and asked for a check of hospitals. An appeal for information on Lucy's whereabouts will be printed in the Tokyo Shimbun newspaper.

'We feel that Lucy's life may be at risk,' said her sister Sophie, who has flown from Britain to help coordinate the search. 'All we know is that she left the house and failed to return. It is not like her.'

The Blackman family, from Sevenoaks, Kent, contacted Richard Branson through a friend who works for Virgin.

The millionaire businessman has asked his Japanese staff to display posters of Lucy, requesting that she return home because a relative is unwell.

Lucy, a former British Airways cabinet crew attendant, arrived in Japan reportedly for a holiday with her friend, Louise Phillips, on 4 May. Neither speaks Japanese.

According to Phillips, the two girls arranged to meet at Shibuya, a well-known Tokyo nightspot, last Saturday.

'She rang up and said I'll be there in an hour so get ready to go out,' said Phillips. 'I haven't heard from her since.'

The British consulate have been helping to liaise with Japanese authorities, but there has been no progress.

Police have hacked into Lucy's email in a bid to identify a man that she is believed to have met for lunch on the day she disappeared.

They have also conducted inquiries in the area where Lucy was staying and been to nightspots she was known to frequent, but her whereabouts remain unknown.

'At the moment all we have is conjecture,' said Tim Blackman, Lucy's father. 'All that we know for sure is that she failed to turn up having said that she would.'

webTitle: Cool to wear a cagoule at Scotland's hottest festival

fields.headline: Cool to wear a cagoule at Scotland's hottest festival
fields.trailText: After an uncharacteristically sunny event last year, it was business as usual yesterday for 47,500 revellers who braved driving rain for the huge T in the Park music festival.
fields.body:
After an uncharacteristically sunny event last year, it was business as usual yesterday for 47,500 revellers who braved driving rain for the huge T in the Park music festival.

Suntans may have been out of the question, but the vast site near Kinross was soon transformed into a soggy-but-throbbing tented village.

By mid-afternoon even the Ceilidh tent was packed out, although that may have had more to do with the shelter than the music. 'I didn't come here to do the Dashing White Sergeant,' said Paul Burns, 22, from Bathgate. 'But at least it's a better laugh than standing out there getting soaked.'

As the weather steadily worsened, distinctly unfashionable cagoules and garish plastic rain macs became the fashion must-haves of the day. The trend received celebrity endorsement when All Saints, making their first festival appearance north of the border, swapped glamour for practicality by sporting orange-and-blue Adidas anoraks on the main stage.

The line-up for this year's event, the sixth since it was launched, underlines its growing status on the summer festival circuit. As well as All Saints, the list of major acts on the bill includes Moby, Fun Lovin' Criminals and Macy Gray. Proceedings will be brought to a close tonight by the Scottish chart-toppers Travis.
