fields.headline: A better tax
fields.body:
Amid discussions about the rights or wrongs of this or that tax, there is one tax that is rarely mentioned. Being properly discriminatory, it is the only fair tax, and it is a principal reason why the social and public services of other nations are superior to ours. It is a tax which scarcely dares speak its name. It is income tax.
Jack Seddon
Chesham
Bucks

fields.headline: A gay prejudice
fields.body:
Peter Tatchell (Comment, last week) is right to stress that for all that there has been a major advance in social attitudes there remains a significant inequality at law between heterosexual and homosexual people. The critical, and unacceptable, difference is quite simply this: straight sex, except under certain prescribed circumstances, is legal; gay sex, except under certain permitted circumstances, is criminal.
David N Taylor
Halifax

fields.headline: A good Deal
fields.body:
I am glad to see your article (Cash, last week) recognises the achievements of this Government. But your claims for the New Deal are not borne out by the facts. The New Deal is proving a great success, with figures showing that almost three quarters of those who have found work are still in their job after 13 weeks. The New Deal has the most comprehensive ethnic monitoring of any employment programme - and figures show that people from minority ethnic backgrounds do better through the New Deal than in the labour market as a whole. Of course we want to do more and we will.
Tessa Jowell
Minister for Employment, Welfare to Work and Equal Opportunities
Department for Education and Employment
London SW1

fields.headline: Distorted art
fields.trailText:
Describing Turner's paintings on show at the Tate Liverpool (Review, last week), Laura Cumming says that the paintings are shown in natural light. She notes that, at last, it is possible to see them in their true colours. In London, at the Tate's Clore Gallery, their impact is blurred by artificial lighting. In many major museums and galleries, artificial lighting grossly distorts and diminish the paintings of European Masters.
Herbert Lank
Marlborough
Wilts

Kate Allen

fields.headline: Not just happy
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr's column on the Genome project (Comment, last week) was thought-provoking. However, I was disappointed   that in his one sentence concerning Down's syndrome he repeats that sad old cliché regarding 'abnormally happy'. This is a caricature of people with a learning disability.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr's column on the Genome project (Comment, last week) was thought-provoking. However, I was disappointed that in his one sentence concerning Down's syndrome he repeats that sad old cliché regarding 'abnormally happy'. This is a caricature of people with a learning disability.

I have worked with people with Down's and they are able to express many more emotions than to be 'abnormally happy' - anxious, depressed, elated, frustrated, sad or upset. Is it Society's disability that such emotions are expressed less readily by most people leading to all sorts of other problems.
Kevin Byrne
Southampton

fields.headline: Staying honest
fields.body:
Will Hutton's perceptive piece on US world dominance (Comment, last week) is inaccurate in two major respects. First, he ought to have the grace to concede that so-called Left paranoia was pretty accurate during the Cold War. Second, US influence has been anything but benevolent. Honesty on these matters is an essential starting point for effective opposition. Then we can turn to the real enemy - trans-national corporate power.
Gerard Watson
Cardiff

fields.headline: Just shut up!
fields.body:
Kathryn Flett's eulogistic fawning over John McEnroe (Review, last week) nearly induced - well, a stomach upset. While not questioning his tennis ability, he was once the most uncouth jackanapes ever to step on to court. Now we have to listen to a McEnroe dialogue and thousands are, I suspect, reduced to shouting 'For heaven's sake, shut up'.
Max Bowen
Stourbridge
West Midlands

webTitle: Follett at the eye of the storm

fields.headline: Follett at the eye of the storm
fields.trailText: They still don't get it, do they? What on Earth possessed the Blair boys to label Ken Follett's criticisms (Comment, last week) as echoing the Right? The Right don't worry about honesty or dictatorial leadership. Their star was Thatcher, who came to power quoting St Francis on harmony, and solved the problem of Cabinet government by sacking members who didn't agree with her.
fields.body:
They still don't get it, do they? What on Earth possessed the Blair boys to label Ken Follett's criticisms (Comment, last week) as echoing the Right? The Right don't worry about honesty or dictatorial leadership. Their star was Thatcher, who came to power quoting St Francis on harmony, and solved the problem of Cabinet government by sacking members who didn't agree with her.

What Follett has done is scratch the ancient democratic wound, which matters to the Left. How you treat the people on your side, how you come to collective decisions, how you tell the leaders when they've got it wrong - those are the tough questions, the ones Number 10 dare not pose, let alone answer. I never thought I'd be praising Ken Follett as a necessary prophet but that's the excitement of democracy - the one thing that's certain is surprise.
Paul Francis
Much Wenlock
Shropshire

For heaven's sake Ken, we're only three years into a Labour government, the first for 18 years. Whatever the rights and wrongs of the new government, what staggers me is the ferociousness, bitterness and bile from our own supporters' mouths, particularly sacked Ministers and London-based wealthy supporters. Do we really need the Labour Party slaughtered in every national newspaper by our own supporters.
Tony Cross
Hulme
Manchester

I have lived through every Labour administration since 1945, and in each case there had been a consolidated press campaign to discredit the leader. Sooner or later, some former supporter - through personal spite or an inability to stand the pressure - has decided to distance himself from the leader. Nauseatingly, they've always managed to think of the most noble motives for doing so.
S.R. Roan
West Harrow
Middx

No doubt, if William Hague and his new, improved, ultra-right-wing, xenophobic, little Englander Tory Party win the next election, or seriously dent Labour's majority, commentators from Nick Cohen to Roy Hattersley to Ken Follett will be queuing up to explain the reasons for this disaster, and will point to New Labour's timidity, and Tony Blair's control-freakery, and the machinations of spin doctors - everything in fact other than their constant, tiresome sniping, complaining and backbiting. New Labour is not perfect, but take a good look at the alternative.
David Gent
Totnes
Devon

Perhaps the word Ken Follett and other critics of the Court of King Tony are edging towards is 'eunuch'. Gibbon describes the emperor Constantius as surrounded by them, supinely permitting them 'to intercept the complaints of the injured provinces; to accumulate immense treasures by the sale of justice and honours; and to gratify their resentment against the few independent spirits who dared criticise them.'
John Fletcher
Shepton Mallet
Somerset

fields.headline: Union power: good or bad?
fields.trailText: Nick Cohen (Comment, last week) is right to be concerned about prison privatisation, and the lack of effective unions in private prisons. However, insofar as he links the welfare of prisoners to a strong presence of the Prison Officers' Association he is misguided.
fields.body:
Nick Cohen (Comment, last week) is right to be concerned about prison privatisation, and the lack of effective unions in private prisons. However, insofar as he links the welfare of prisoners to a strong presence of the Prison Officers' Association he is misguided.

The POA, which represents most officers in the publicly-run prisons, has often been criticised by the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham. In recent reports into Wormwood Scrubs and Wandsworth he points out the POA's role in creating a culture that can encourage unacceptable attitudes towards prisoners and neglect of their basic needs.

While Cohen rightly recognises the need for an adequate staff response to bullying by prisoners, he omits to mention that some of the prisons where the POA is strongest have generated the most complaints from prisoners about assaults by prison officers.
Hamish Arnott and Nicki Rensten
Prisoners' Advice Service
London EC1

So unions object to the fact that the Labour Party 'can no longer be regarded as a progressive force' and considers union principles 'laughable'. May I suggest that they should donate some of their cash to the Lib Dems who are more sympathetic to their needs and certainly more progressive in their views than New Labour, rather than subscribing them all to maintain the 'inch' separating Tony Blair's policies from those of William Hague?

After all, it is by no means impossible that with union support Charles Kennedy's party should hold the balance of power after the next general election.
Bob Heys
Halifax

fields.headline: US has to stop
fields.standfirst: Missile defence plan is dangerous
fields.trailText: If all had gone to plan yesterday, the United States would be celebrating its technological wizardry. A Minutemen rocket with a mock warhead was to be destroyed in mid-flight by another rocket.
fields.body:
If all had gone to plan yesterday, the United States would be celebrating its technological wizardry. A Minutemen rocket with a mock warhead was to be destroyed in mid-flight by another rocket. It was the third, decisive test to demonstrate that the idea of the US constructing its own national missile defence system was not science fiction. The experiment, to the embarrassment of Boeing and the Pentagon, failed.

On Tuesday the CIA convenes a meeting of key US security players and intelligence agencies to decide what to recommend, but it looks as if the test's failure means full development is unlikely. Good. The whole idea, as Germany's Chancellor Schröder insists, is flawed. If the US were to go ahead unilaterally with the system then it would have broken the terms of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty in which both the Russians and Americans agreed not to upset mutually assured destruction by building anti-missile defence systems.

Yet all that is in prospect is deferral. The Republican right is wedded to a unilateralist, America-first agenda, as is their Presidential candidate, George W. Bush. Democrat Gore equally does not want to be seen as soft on defending the US from rogue state missile attacks.

The US already has refused to sign the renegotiated nuclear test ban treaty. Now it is preparing to tear up the ABM treaties. The issue is whether in military and security terms we want a world governed by a web of international treaties, or whether we want to retreat into unilateralism. Britain must oppose this development. We must make it clear before Tuesday's meeting that we are not prepared to allow Fylingdales to be part of the NMD: it would be one more reason for the US not to proceed with this dangerous project. Sitting on the fence and hoping it will go away is neither dignified nor right.

Now it is preparing to tear up the ABM treaties. The issue is whether in military and security terms we want a world governed by a web of international treaties, or whether we want to retreat into unilateralism. Britain must oppose this development. We must make it clear before Tuesday's meeting that we are not prepared to allow Fylingdales to be part of the NMD: it would be one more reason for the US not to proceed with this dangerous project. Sitting on the fence and hoping it will go away is neither dignified nor right.

fields.headline: Perfidious Albion
fields.standfirst:
A red card for our World Cup bid

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Enough! Let us now take determined action against the self-styled England football patriots who sully our name abroad.
fields.body:
Enough! Let us now take determined action against the self-styled England football patriots who sully our name abroad. We refer, of course, not to the St George-draped asses who display their love of what we arrogantly call the national sport by getting as slammed as a post-exams 16-year-old, but to that more shaming bunch of nationalists who formed the official campaign team to secure World Cup 2006 for England.

This is the team which first promised to support Germany, broke that promise by entering the race, made a virtue of junketing its way 'to the Moon and back' to secure votes (while condemning deals in 'smoke-filled rooms in Zurich'), publicly sneered at the country it had pledged to support ('Germany could never beat South Africa'), then, when Germany's cool, well-managed campaign won the day, shed crocodile tears for South Africa, a nation we should have supported from the outset.

This murky episode has tarnished the reputation of two fine footballers and deprived Africa - a continent which, from dry-mud village pitch to city stadium, has shown utter commitment to and joy in the sport - of a chance that would have transformed the lives of millions of the world's poorest citizens.

It is bad enough that Ing-er-land fans shout, bash and puke their way through Europe, but do we have to act up to the national stereotypes of hypocrisy and perfidy (plus whingeing, special pleading, unjustified arrogance and xenophobia) in every international forum?

fields.headline: Our university challenge
fields.standfirst:
We must pay to be world class

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: About one thing Blair and Hague can always agree. To be at the cutting edge of the knowledge economy, British education must be world class.
fields.body:
About one thing Blair and Hague can always agree. To be at the cutting edge of the knowledge economy, British education must be world class. One half of the story about our universities is encouraging. The numbers going into higher education have doubled in 20 years, which is life-enhancing for those benefiting from a university education and good for the economy. The other half is dismal. Funding per student has fallen by nearly a half.

This is typically British. We demand universities with the horsepower of a Jaguar, but run them as cheaply as a moped. Average class sizes have doubled. Salaries have diminished. University lecturers, who have not had a real increase in earnings for two decades, will eventually be on the minimum wage. You do not need a degree to see that this leads to the degradation of the quality of the learning in our universities.

Ideally, the funding crisis might be resolved with a largess financed from general taxation. The merit of the just-published report by the Russell Group is that it inhabits the real world. The public will not permit - certainly politicians don't think they will allow - large additional tax pounds to go to higher education when there are so many other clamours on the public purse.

The realistic solution is for the universities to become more self-funded by introducing tuition fees. These need not be a barrier to entry to the less well-off if some of the extra income is used to assist students from financially disadvantaged families. Harvard, which Gordon Brown recently contrasted so favourably with Oxford, manages to be both élite and socially inclusive by giving more than half of its students financial aid.

The current system is the reverse of fair. Students, most of whom will make above average earnings, are subsidised through university by those who never enjoyed higher education. This is redistribution from the worse-off to the better-off. The fair system is for high-earners with degrees to pay their fees through a graduate tax. Ministers are turning a cold-shoulder to this, vice-chancellors are wary, and the National Union of Students is negative. But if any of them has a more socially just solution, we are waiting to hear it. Britain will not have world-class research, world-class teachers and world-class graduates on sweat-shop wages.

webTitle: Whizzkids of sport risk an early exit

fields.headline: Whizzkids of sport risk an early exit
fields.trailText: Child sporting 'prodigies' - such as tennis players Venus and Serena Williams - risk serious psychological and physical damage, an influential group of American doctors has warned.
fields.body:
Child sporting 'prodigies' - such as tennis players Venus and Serena Williams - risk serious psychological and physical damage, an influential group of American doctors has warned.

The American Academy of Paediatrics has said that specialising in one sport before children reach puberty can lead not only to emotional burn-out, but damage to joints and bones, heart problems, malnutrition, stunted growth, delayed onset of menstruation in girls, and eating disorders. The academy published its view in a policy statement, warning pushy parents to think twice before forcing their children into relentless training.

The statement - written by a panel of doctors led by Steven Anderson, professor in paediatrics at the University of Washington in Seattle - said that child athletes who are forced to specialise early end up with short careers. 'Those who participate in a variety of sports and specialise only after reaching the age of puberty tend to be more consistent performers, have fewer injuries, and adhere to sports play longer than those who specialise early,' they said.

The academy also said the risk of emotional burn-out was very real and could permanently damage the child. 'Unrealistic parental expectations and/or exploitation of young athletes for extrinsic gain can contribute to negative psychological consequences for elite young athletes.'

Tennis is notorious for producing prodigies who burn brightly before burning out. American players Andrea Jaeger and Tracy Austin reached the top in their teenage years and then disappeared. Michael Chang, who won the French open at 17, has achieved little since. Other sports also produce child prodigies. Justin Rose stunned the golf world in 1997 by coming fourth in the British Open at 17, but now the only question about him is 'where did he go?'

Another area of concern was whether child athletes received proper nutrition, particularly those who specialised in sports where slenderness was important, such as gymnastics or ballet. The doctors said such children risked stunted growth and anorexia or bulimia.

Girl athletes could also be vulnerable to delayed onset of menstruation, the doctors said. The age at which girls start menstruating in the US is on average 12-and-a-half, while that of athletes is typically one to two years later.

The authors concluded: 'Most Olympic sports have selection processes that attempt to identify future champions and initiate specialised training, often before the prospect finishes [primary] school. The lure of a professional career can also motivate athletes (and their parents) to commit to specialised training regimens at an early age.'

webTitle: Generation of wimps shuns playing fields

fields.headline: Generation of wimps shuns playing fields
fields.trailText: Despite humiliation at Euro 2000, countless defeats at cricket and Henman and Rusedski's early exits from Wimbledon, England's sporting decline is not yet complete. New research reveals that many of the nation's schoolchildren are wimps who hate playing games because it means getting wet, dirty and sweaty, falling over and ruining your hair.
fields.body:
Despite humiliation at Euro 2000, countless defeats at cricket and Henman and Rusedski's early exits from Wimbledon, England's sporting decline is not yet complete. New research reveals that many of the nation's schoolchildren are wimps who hate playing games because it means getting wet, dirty and sweaty, falling over and ruining your hair.

Up to two-thirds of pupils resent sport's time-honoured rituals such as having to get changed, putting up with bad weather, taking a shower afterwards or learning a new skill. One in six is 'too embarrassed' to get involved, even more dislike playing sport if it's competitive, and one in four plans to give it up on leaving school.

The biggest ever survey of young people's attitudes to sport shows that, in spite of stars such as David Beckham's huge popularity, many of them see it as something to be endured rather than enjoyed. Computer games, television and teenagers' increasing obsession with looking good are all to blame. For many, sport is no longer cool.

The study, in which pollsters Mori questioned 3,300 pupils aged between five and 16 for Sport England, will make grim reading for coaches and managers worried about the glaring lack of homegrown talent. Trevor Brooking, the ex-England footballer who is Sport England's chairman, said he was 'worried, but not surprised' by the findings and feared what the implications would be for the quest for a new generation of world-class performers.

'There's an apathy towards sport among many young people these days. There has been an extremely significant decline in the traditional "British fighting spirit" in sport, which is famous around the world. It is a major drawback.

'That spirit has been diluted by too many people saying "don't worry, at least you tried", and too many years of non-competitive sport in schools, where everyone was congratulated simply for turning up and taking part and exceptional performance was not rewarded with prizes because some teachers felt that was unhealthy and would put some kids off from playing. That created an environment of average output in sport.'

When asked what they disliked about doing sport, 64 per cent of the girls and 41 per cent of the boys mentioned 'being hit, kicked or falling over during sport'. Almost as many, 56 per cent of girls and 33 per cent of boys, cited 'going outside for bad weather'.

Many do not want to either get 'cold and wet' (48/29 per cent) or 'hot, sweaty or dirty' (51/25 per cent), while over a fifth of both sexes list 'having to wash or shower after sports' as a deterrent.

A quarter of girls confessed that 'getting wet hair' puts them off doing sport, but only 9 per cent of boys agreed. 'Having to change in and out of sports clothes' is disliked by 36 per cent of females and 26 per cent of boys; a third of all teenagers dislike having to exchange their school uniforms for shorts, vests, gym knickers and tennis skirts.

John Matthews, chief executive of the Physical Education Association of the UK, which represents 4,000 PE teachers, said: 'This research confirms what we have suspected for some time, that society's perception is that sport isn't as much fun as it used to be and that children are less up for sport than before.

'Young people are less hardy these days than they used to be. They will look out of the window before a PE lesson, see that it's drizzling and ask if they can do it inside in the sports hall rather than outside on the grass.'

Matthews, a PE teacher himself, believes the increased importance to youngsters of their 'body image' was responsible for much of the change in attitudes. Girls, especially, are more reluctant than before to put their bodies on show by getting changed or washed. 'Schools are now very aware of that issue and very few insist any more that every pupil has a shower after a games or PE lesson.'

Perhaps the most alarming conclusion in the research is that two in five children are put off doing sport at school 'if it takes you a long time to learn something new'.

Brooking said: 'These days when the going gets tough in the key moments of a competitive tennis match or football game, too many youngsters shrug their shoulders and don't have the determination and will to compete and really hang in there that you need to succeed in sport. Too many want to have success without first putting in hard work.'

Sport England's survey also shows that large numbers of young people start to dislike sport, and give up doing it if they can, as soon as they head towards their teenage years. This phenomenon of 'dropout' begins among girls at 10 or 11 but does not strike boys until they are 12 or 13. Interest in pop music, magazines, going out with their friends and, especially, the opposite sex become preferable to any physical activity.

Brooking said that urgent Government action was needed to improve run-down sports facilities and overhaul the 'often poor' quality of PE teaching in schools.

Ministers, he said, could enhance participation in sport at a stroke by insisting that all pupils had to do a minimum of two hours of PE a week in school time. At the moment that was merely an 'aspiration'.

webTitle: Child genius ran away to be rebel in a scarf

fields.headline: Child genius ran away to be rebel in a scarf
fields.standfirst:
Sufiah Yusof's father insists she was brainwashed

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: It was in March that Sufiah Yusof's parents noticed a dramatic change in her. It began with her decision to start wearing Islamic dress, including the  hijab - the traditional headscarf worn as a mark of an Islamic woman's modesty. Looking back, Farooq and Halimahton Yusof now realise this was the first sign of a new life she was planning for herself - away from her family and the intense pressure of being Britain's best-known child prodigy.
fields.body:
It was in March that Sufiah Yusof's parents noticed a dramatic change in her. It began with her decision to start wearing Islamic dress, including the hijab - the traditional headscarf worn as a mark of an Islamic woman's modesty. Looking back, Farooq and Halimahton Yusof now realise this was the first sign of a new life she was planning for herself - away from her family and the intense pressure of being Britain's best-known child prodigy.

When she disappeared from St Hilda's College Oxford after her third year exams on 22 June, everyone feared the worst, including her father. Now that she has reappeared, to be taken into care by Bournemouth social services, what has emerged is a picture of a politically committed student struggling to be taken seriously as a young woman, rather than the clever little girl who had previously sprung to the media's attentions.

A family photograph taken just weeks before her disappearance shows Sufiah confident with her new look - scarf, long-sleeved blouse and shawl, in contrast to the sportswear she wore until then.

'It was part of a new identity,' her father told The Observer, in the first full interview given by the family since Sufiah's disappearance. 'She began taking an active interest in politics and the Muslim world: good causes that we would probably have encouraged her to support. Unfortunately, whoever was acting as her mentor could not have known that.'

Yusof has led a chequered career. In 1992 he was jailed for three years for a £1.5 million mortgage fraud, for which his wife Halimahton received a suspended sentence. Since then he has devoted his life to developing a top-secret programme of 'accelerated learning', believing that bright children are let down by conventional education.

He has now set up his own firm to market his educational products, but everything is on hold until his best advertisement returns home.

So far, his methods have seen three of his children winning places at university to read maths at an age when most of their peers are adding the values of Pokémon cards. But clearly, his plan made no allowance for his student's growing political awareness. The discovery of her Muslim roots was part of a political awakening that saw her embrace green issues, the anti-capitalist movement, the campaign against the detention of asylum seekers and international Muslim solidarity.

During her end-of-year exams last month, her parents took it in turns to spend time with her in Oxford and cook her meals. 'She had become very particular about what she ate,' said Halimahton Yusof. 'Everything had to be organic and GM-free. Always wholemeal bread and freshly-squeezed oranges. She refused to eat McDonald's and Nestlé products.'

'I would describe her attitude as anti-corporate,' said Sufiah's father.

She had started to subscribe to the weekly paper of the Socialist Worker's Party and during the holidays had it delivered to the family's previous address in Coventry so that she could collect it without her parents finding out.

Her parents are convinced that Sufiah was abducted and that her emails, sent from an internet cafe in the seaside town, were sent under duress.

In the front room of their Coventry home, the mantlepiece is crammed with two dozen trophies won for tennis, another area in which the children were expected to excel. As the Yusofs shuffle through snaps of the family together during happier times - in Sufiah's Oxford flat or walking in the University parks - talk turns to mysterious 'third parties'. Alternatively, these are commercial rivals attempting to debrief Sufiah about his teaching methods, or socialist extremists who brainwashed her with revolutionary politics.

'Our children's lives have been very well balanced,' insisted Yusof. 'We have no problem with Sufiah exercising her independence. But I am convinced there are sinister elements behind this and I know I will be proved right.'

According to the Yusofs, police interception of calls made by their daughter prior to her disappearance show that she was arranging secret meetings with someone calling from a phone box outside St Hilda's. 'She would return from the meetings very moody and would go straight to her room,' said her father. Police subsequently discovered she attended a meeting of the Socialist Workers' Party during her exams. 'I find it difficult to believe she would have done this without someone else's influence,' Yusof told The Observer.

Thames Valley Police have refused to confirm whether anyone is under suspicion of abducting Sufiah Yusof or whether they are looking into claims contained in an email, apparently from Sufiah, that she suffered physical abuse at home.

So far, Farooq Yusof's attempts to identify the 'third parties' who turned his daughter's head have failed. The police have checked her email logs and found she was in regular contact with Alice Wright, a prominent member of Oxford University's Amnesty International group, elected president of St Hilda's Junior Common Room for next year. Since Sufiah disappeared, Wright has manned phones at the college and is highly regarded by lecturers and students.

Anna Chen, spokeswoman for the Socialist Worker's Party, who herself ran away from home at 15, has talked to Farooq Yusof about the case. She has also made inquiries about the involvement of members of her organisation and discovered none. 'I identify with her very much. I think she sounds wonderful. I'd like to recruit her to the party myself, but we are not a cult, which brainwashes people. It sounds to me like a classic case of someone getting politicised at university.'

The case has also raised serious doubts about the wisdom of hot-housing young talent. The Government is already planning a series of Advanced Maths Centres across the country to cater for primary pupils to take their GCSEs at age 11 instead of 16. Many experts believe that even this is too much too soon. Valsa Koshy, Director of Brunel University's Able Children Centre, said there was no research to back up the Government's plans and that Australia and the United States were abandoning similar schemes because they led to the isolation of children from their peers.

'I find it difficult to believe she would have done this without someone else's influence,' Yusof told The Observer. Thames Valley Police have refused to confirm whether anyone is under suspicion of abducting Sufiah Yusof or whether they are looking into claims contained in an email, apparently from Sufiah, that she suffered physical abuse at home. So far, Farooq Yusof's attempts to identify the 'third parties' who turned his daughter's head have failed. The police have checked her email logs and found she was in regular contact with Alice Wright, a prominent member of Oxford University's Amnesty International group, elected president of St Hilda's Junior Common Room for next year. Since Sufiah disappeared, Wright has manned phones at the college and is highly regarded by lecturers and students. Anna Chen, spokeswoman for the Socialist Worker's Party, who herself ran away from home at 15, has talked to Farooq Yusof about the case. She has also made inquiries about the involvement of members of her organisation and discovered none. 'I identify with her very much. I think she sounds wonderful. I'd like to recruit her to the party myself, but we are not a cult, which brainwashes people. It sounds to me like a classic case of someone getting politicised at university.' The case has also raised serious doubts about the wisdom of hot-housing young talent. The Government is already planning a series of Advanced Maths Centres across the country to cater for primary pupils to take their GCSEs at age 11 instead of 16. Many experts believe that even this is too much too soon. Valsa Koshy, Director of Brunel University's Able Children Centre, said there was no research to back up the Government's plans and that Australia and the United States were abandoning similar schemes because they led to the isolation of children from their peers.

webTitle: 'In Botswana, the old bury the young'

fields.headline: 'In Botswana, the old bury the young'
fields.standfirst: Lindsey Hilsum reports from a nation where millions will die, and those who are left will be condemned to poverty
fields.trailText: Aids will kill one-third of working age people in Botswana. Read that again. In Botswana, one third of people aged 15 to 49 are HIV positive, and they will die.
fields.body:
Aids will kill one-third of working age people in Botswana. Read that again. In Botswana, one third of people aged 15 to 49 are HIV positive, and they will die.

Sometimes it's too much for those who deal with the disease every day. Nurse Olebogeng Tsedi has watched the Aids epidemic seep through her country like poison, felling patients and colleagues alike.

'When you get home you're so tired,' she said, smart in her white uniform with old-fashioned navy cape, lined in scarlet silk. 'You think of friends who have passed away, you think of friends who are HIV positive... you think, it means my friend will be like that patient. So you sit and start crying.'

The hospitals are full, so Tsedi organises volunteers to care for Aids patients in their own homes in Molepolole, a sprawling village 50 miles from the capital, Gaborone. Her aim is to prolong the lives of those already infected, and educate those who are not how to avoid the virus. It's not easy in a country where many believe Aids is a curse that can be lifted only by witchcraft.

Dirang Rapula lies in a rumpled bed, complaining that her legs will no longer carry her. The one-room house contains the possessions she bought with wages earned in the South African mining town of Rustenburg where she worked as a maid. She has a mirror, several chairs and a wardrobe. That, she believes, was her downfall. Other women were jealous of her furniture and laid a curse. 'I've been bewitched because I was able to take care of my children,' she explains, her face gaunt as she lies back on the pillow. 'The traditional doctor said it was witchcraft. Straightaway he gave me medicine, and immediately I felt better.'

She is far too sick to look after her children today, but that has not shaken her faith in traditional beliefs. Her eldest daughter, Kearoma, aged 23, sits on the end of the bed watching her mother. Her light brown jacket is torn and she is too weak to work so earns a few pennies braiding the neighbours' hair. She miscarried a baby a few months ago, and was then diagnosed HIV positive, but she too doubts the doctors.

'I know Aids exists, but I go to a spiritual healing church, and there they say it's witchcraft,' she said.

Nurse Tsedi tries to help them understand. But her scientific explanation, however simply put, has a flaw. Scientists and doctors admit they cannot cure Aids, but the witchdoctor says he can. No wonder Tsedi cries at home in the evenings.

The cheapest funeral costs about £130, and these days families are devoting more and more of their income and time to dealing with death. Calvin Ngwape, the manager of Pule Funeral Parlour in Gaborone, said that two decades ago they processed three or four funerals per week, now it was 20 or more. 'In Botswana, the old are burying the young,' he said.

On Saturday night in Gaborone, those most at risk are out in the shebeens and bars. Reseachers say this is a promiscuous society and the government's message has not yet got through.

'It is very difficult for us young people to abstain,' said Inyaneng Dipatane, an actress. 'We have already tasted the delights of honey so it's very difficult to stop.' In the latest production from the Reetsanang Drama Group, Inyaneng plays a woman whose sister is forced into sex without a condom by her HIV-positive husband. She dies a horrific, painful death. The play is based on the cast's own experience.

'I'm afraid of death and every time I look at my family, I sit alone and think: who is next?' reflects Inyaneng. Despite government exhortations that everyone should know their HIV status, even those giving out the health education messages are too frightened to get tested.

'I'm married now, but I don't remember what I did 15 years back and I don't even know what my wife did before we got married,' said Reesanang's director, James Chitukuta, who has lost 15 friends to Aids. 'We haven't been tested and I don't know my status, but looking at my friends, I'm scared. Very, very scared.'

President Festus Mogae is scared too. 'Aids permeates all our society and everything we do, and therefore it has to be and is our preoccupation,' he said. 'We must subordinate puritanical considerations to the superior value of national survival,' he said in a recent address. He mentions the disease in every speech and wears an Aids ribbon at all times.

Botswana produces nearly one-third of the world's diamonds, and has Africa's fastest growing economy. Diamond mining provides little employment, so people remain poor and there is high unemployment, but over 30 years of independence the government has built up a welfare state and paid for hundreds of young people to be trained abroad.

'Aids cuts across our efforts in fighting poverty,' said President Mogae. 'The other day we had to charter a plane from the United States to bring home two ill students whose ailment had progressed so far the airlines would not take them. We could have built a country primary school with the cost of that charter,' he said.

The government is considering compulsory Aids tests for anyone applying for a government scholarship to study overseas. Human rights activists, who point out that Botswana is one of Africa's few democracies, say this would violate medical confidentiality. 'We may have to change the law,' responds the President.

At this week's Aids conference in Durban, economist Robert Greener will present the first paper analysing the likely impact of Aids on Botswana's economy. The people will get poorer, he will say. Already, the able-bodied are giving up work to look after dying family members and orphans.

Nurse Tsedi walks home through the murmuring evening streets of Molepolole. She listens to children chattering, goats bleating, the sound of people coming back from work and preparing the evening meal. 'You cry for someone out there who's suffering. You try to help.' She shrugs. 'But in the end, what can you do?

Lindsey Hilsum is Diplomatic correspondent for Channel 4. She will report from Durban this evening at 7.30pm

webTitle: Explicit French sex film set to reach British screens

fields.headline: Explicit French sex film set to reach British screens
fields.trailText: An explicit French film featuring graphic scenes of sex and violence is set to go on show at cinemas in Britain. The film, called  Baise-moi ( Screw Me ), caused huge controversy when it was screened in France because of its close-up sex shots.
fields.body:
An explicit French film featuring graphic scenes of sex and violence is set to go on show at cinemas in Britain. The film, called Baise-moi ( Screw Me ), caused huge controversy when it was screened in France because of its close-up sex shots.

British distributors are in talks with the French producers of the film and hope to bring it to cinemas here soon. The English version is entitled Rape Me, but is no different from the one that drew more than 30,000 filmgoers in its first week after release - with a '16' certificate - in France in June. It offers 90 minutes of almost non-stop hardcore sex and violence.

The film was shot in northern France and follows the fortunes of two bored young suburban women who set out on a spree of sex and murder after one of them is brutally raped and then shoots dead her brother in a row.

A passer-by is shot for her cashpoint card, a tramp who leers at the two women is gunned down and two gendarmes who stop them for a check on papers are summarily executed. A man is picked up for sex and then stamped to death with high-heels, another dies during a shoot-out in a sex club when he is forced to strip and pretend to be a pig before being shot in the anus. There are graphic sequences of fellatio and intercourse.

In France last week a campaign group linked to the far Right forced cinemas to withdraw the film temporarily, but it is to be re-released with an '18' certificate.

Optimum Releasing, a London-based independent distributor, last week said it had been speaking to Canal Plus - the French entertainment giant that is marketing the film - and hoped to show it in British cinemas.

'Films like this can perform an important function,' said Will Clarke, Optimum's managing director. 'We are interested in quality movies. The controversial angle is of interest but it has to be decent artistically.' Two other film companies have confirmed their interest to The Observer .

The production team of Baise-moi, which was made for under £1 million, claims the film is not deliberately controversial or titillating but makes important points about sexual violence, prostitution and friendship.

'Anyone who goes to see it for a thrill will be disappointed,' said Coralie Trinh Thi, co-director and ex-porn star. Many critics have praised the film's examination of the 'moral nihilism' of modern life. The liberal establishment is behind Trinh Thi and her co-director and writer Virginie Despentes, with politicians calling the pornography laws 'obsolete'.

British companies hope shifts in the UK in attitudes to screen sex may help get Baise-moi shown in cinemas. Last year Romance, a French production, was passed almost uncut but for a one-second excision of an ejaculating penis, and three years ago David Cronenberg's Crash, about people aroused by road accidents, was given an '18' certificate.

A High Court judgment, which this year allowed seven 'hardcore' sex films, with titles such as Horny Catbabe and Nympho Nurse Nancy, to be sold on video in licensed sex shops, will be incorporated into new guidelines for the British Board of Film Classification.

Baise-moi will face resistance in Britain. 'You cannot possibly allow a film like this,' said John Beyer of the National Viewers and Listeners Association. 'We have a rising number of sexual crimes and if you constantly put up lifestyles and roles glamourising what is harming our society then it is just going to make things worse.'

Vincent Maraval, in charge of marketing the film for Canal Plus, said it had been sold to 30 countries, including Spain, Italy, Japan and South Korea. Judges at the Locarno Film Festival have selected the film for the competition next month.

webTitle: 'My son was lying there, throwing up on the carpet'

fields.headline: 'My son was lying there, throwing up on the carpet'
fields.standfirst: Support is growing for a national scheme to curb underage drinking, report Sarah Ryle and Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: Karen Marshall was content to allow her 14-year-old son David some privacy when he had his friends round. And, since it was the end of term, she thought he deserved a late night. The boys disappeared upstairs with crisps and bottles of Coke.
fields.body:
Karen Marshall was content to allow her 14-year-old son David some privacy when he had his friends round. And, since it was the end of term, she thought he deserved a late night. The boys disappeared upstairs with crisps and bottles of Coke.

But behind his closed bedroom door David and his two mates were celebrating with more than Coke.

'One had a two-litre bottle that he'd filled with bits and pieces of all the alcohol in his dad's house,' Karen said.

The disgusting brew included vodka, whisky and red wine. The other boy had brought four bottles of alcopops. Between the three, they drank the lot.

'It was the sound of retching that made me go in and there they were,' Karen Marshall said. 'David was lying on the carpet just vomiting continually and his best friend was unconscious under the window.'

Karen was able to sort out the situation in the safety of her own home. The wider concern among health groups, politicians and the drinks industry is that young people see binge drinking as the best way of celebrating.

Organised attempts to educate children and teenagers about the pitfalls are thin on the ground. The Portman Group, the industry's self-regulator, has recently issued postcards to schools to highlight why binge drinking is a bad idea 'in language that children as young as eight can understand'.

But what chance has a postcard of a cartoon face looking sick against this growing craze?

The group announced a teacher-training programme last month and grants worth £100,000, funded by companies, have been taken up by 18 local education authorities.

'There is a lot done in schools about smoking and drugs, but alcohol education has not had the same support,' said Graham Goodwin, a spokesman for the group. 'There are millions of pounds available for drugs education but nothing for alcohol.'

Alcohol Concern says it is worried that so much regulation is left up to the Portman Group. 'Their primary aim is to promote drinking and sales of alcohol. That is their job as an industry body,' said Sue Boon, assistant director of Age Concern. 'We are concerned that Ministers are becoming complacent. The industry is as powerful as the tobacco companies and it brings in a lot of tax revenue.'

She added that the Government has been promising a White Paper for months. 'We were supposed to see the proposals for a national strategy on alcohol this month, but everything has gone quiet again.'

The Portman Group insists it is doing everything it can to curb underage drinking. Last month, it published a Mori poll which said that 17 per cent of under-25s say they regularly drink to get drunk, compared with 5 per cent of the rest of the population.

The second part of the survey will show widespread public support for a government-run proof-of-age identity card as the most important weapon in the battle to curb underage drinking.

'We have done research and we know that teenagers will not carry passports or driving licences when they go out but many of them will carry proof-of-age cards,' Goodwin said.

However, the drinks industry has been blamed for encouraging underage drinking. In 1995, it was accused of packaging potent alcohol as if it were fizzy pop when it promoted alcopops.

A ministerial group was set up to investigate and the bad publicity forced the Portman Group to introduce a tougher code of practice for labelling drinks.

Retailers claim to have made efforts to curb sales to underage customers but say that the only practical solution is an ID card.

Unruly drunken behaviour among schoolchildren cuts right across the social spectrum. Headteachers warn that alcohol has replaced drugs as their greatest concern.

webTitle: Why did this man kick off football chaos?

fields.headline: Why did this man kick off football chaos?
fields.standfirst:
Personal feuds and one man's petulant refusal to cast his vote have wrecked an African sports dream

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Personal feuds and one man's petulant refusal to cast his vote have wrecked an African sports dream.
fields.body:
Charles Dempsey cut a fairly pathetic figure around Zurich's elegant Dolder Grand Hotel last Wednesday night. Shuffling along with a slight stoop and troubled by poor eyesight, the frail 78-year-old did not look like one of the most powerful men in world football.

His shambling appearance disguised the fact that Dempsey is one of the 24 members of the executive committee of Fifa, the game's global governing body. It had gathered amid customary five-star luxury near its Swiss headquarters to decide on the next day which of the four bidding countries would be awarded the money-spinning honour of hosting the 2006 World Cup.

Unknown to Fifa, the previously marginal Dempsey was about to emerge as the key figure in 24 hours of extraordinary drama, intrigue and farce which ended with outsiders Germany unexpectedly wrecking South Africa's dream of becoming the first African nation to stage the biggest sporting event in the world.

By yesterday, Dempsey had become football's most wanted man. He was in hiding at his plush home in Auckland, New Zealand, and still refusing to answer why, by abstaining at a crucial stage of the voting, he handed Germany the tournament. He is due to explain himself today to the Oceania football congress, of which he is president, and answer questions tomorrow about one of the most mysterious and shameful chapters in recent football history.

The man with the crucial vote is an ageing expatriate Scot who is New Zealand's member of the executive. Dempsey was born in Glasgow in 1922, served as a petty officer in the Second World War and moved to Auckland after the war, where he set up a construction business that would make him a millionaire. He owes his place at football's top table to his 40 years spent developing soccer down under. Even his friends in British football say he is 'prickly and suspicious and doesn't make friends easily'. One of them described Dempsey as 'a confused geriatric who is out of his depth in Fifa politics and cracked under the pressure.'

Dempsey was already in turmoil last Wednesday night about how he should use his vote the next morning. His personal preference was to back England, although they had no chance, and then switch to Germany once the bid championed by his friends from the Football Association had been rejected. Despite England spending more and travelling further than any of their rivals in their high-profile quest for votes, they actually persuaded almost nobody.

But the Oceania football congress had ordered him to support South Africa after England's widely anticipated early elimination. Should Dempsey follow his instincts or bow to the wishes of his colleagues? After hours of agonising, he resolved his dilemma in an idiosyncratic and histrionic way. He backed England in the first two rounds of the ballot, but then, with Germany and South Africa tied at 11-11, refused to vote again - a fateful decision which ensured Europe was handed its tenth World Cup while Africa was left still waiting for its first. Dempsey's bizarre behaviour means he is now an object of unique loathing for many people in football who believe 'fair play' - Fifa's motto - has been sacrificed on the altar of one man's selfishness and antipathy towards the developing world.

'He has betrayed the South African people,' fumed Irvin Khoza, chairman of the country's bid, which most observers of the four-year 2006 race had expected would succeed.

Trevor Mallard, New Zealand's Sports Minister, was just as blunt. 'Dempsey is an international embarrassment.' Dempsey's plea that he was under 'unsustainable pressure', including death threats, did nothing to stop the deluge of criticism. Helen Clark, New Zealand's Prime Minister, said she was upset by the result and telephoned South African President Thabo Mbeki to apologise for Dempsey's action.

'This old fool has denied Africa its destiny, its turn and its place in history', said an angry member of the South African team. 'He voted for England, even though they never had a chance, and then he refused to do what was democratically decided he should do, which was to back South Africa once England were out. I don't know why he abstained.

'Was he bribed? Is his attachment to the mother country, and Europe in general, so great that he couldn't see the merits of letting someone else have a go at staging the World Cup? Does he really think South Africa couldn't do that? Does he think so little of us?'

He always claimed he was too busy, yet managed to find the time for regular trips back to Britain and Europe, often to watch big football matches such as the FA Cup Final and the final of the European Champions League. 'As a Fifa executive member you're meant to at least pretend that you're objective in the bidding for the World Cup, and show some interest in what the rival countries have to offer, but he didn't even bother doing that with us,' said the South African.

Across South Africa last Thursday, tens of thousands of people gathered from early morning in Soweto, Johannesburg and Cape Town for what they expected would be confirmation that, at last, South Africa had been deemed worthy of hosting the World Cup. Events that were planned as street parties instead became a series of public wakes as the news filtered through at lunchtime from Zurich that Germany, hosts as recently as 1974, had got it again.

'We have lost a great opportunity to focus the world's attention on our country which has its problems, admittedly, but is working harder to get things right,' said one campaigner. 'Being in the spotlight would have made us work harder and strive harder.'

While the tournament will make little difference to Germany's already strong economy, it would have really boosted South Africa's economic base and reputation. Danny Jordaan, its bid chief, estimated that 2006 would have created 300,000 jobs in the country's hotels, construction industry and transport infrastructure. 'Manchester United's turnover is greater than the combined turnover of all the football played in Africa, Asia and Oceania, and that cannot be right,' said Jordaan. All those grievances will have to wait at least another four years.

He rang several heads of state, including the Emir of Qatar and the Kings of Thailand and Belgium, and pleaded with them to persuade their voters to back South Africa. Mandela also rang Dempsey, who implied that he would make South Africa his second preference.

England disappeared in the second round after Dempsey and Fifa vice-president David Will, another Fifa vice-president, were their only supporters. The two main contenders each got 11. At that point New Zealand's man left the room and headed to Zurich airport, where he caught a flight for Auckland via Singapore.

Shuffling along with a slight stoop and troubled by poor eyesight, the frail 78-year-old did not look like one of the most powerful men in world football. His shambling appearance disguised the fact that Dempsey is one of the 24 members of the executive committee of Fifa, the game's global governing body. fields.headline: Star Wars falls to Earth
fields.standfirst: Ed Vulliamy in Washington examines why there may be relief in the White House after the latest failure
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy in Washington examines why there may be relief in the White House after the latest failure
fields.body:
The action was to be relayed live from the Pacific to a big screen at Boeing's East Coast headquarters in Virginia. The atmosphere was relaxed and confident. A senior Pentagon official, Ed Hudak, ran a simulation of what was intended to be a seamless operation - a third and decisive test of a missile defence system that would push the United States into a new generation of nuclear weaponry.

After a two-hour delay while technicians fixed a last-minute glitch, a 37-year-old remodelled Minuteman rocket containing a mock warhead and a decoy balloon thundered aloft from a tightly guarded launch pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base, 125 miles north of Los Angeles. Twenty-one minutes later, an interceptor missile carrying the 'kill' vehicle ripped into the daytime sky from Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific.

The kill vehicle was supposed to separate from the second-stage rocket booster exactly 2 minutes and 37 seconds into flight, then manoeuvre itself into the path of the mock warhead. Hudak alerted the watchers as interception neared. 'It'll be eight minutes after the launch,' he said.

The clock ticked on past nine minutes. 'We should have had confirmation by now,' said Hudak, as the screen remained a sickly green colour, with no sign of the flash that would signify success. Nearly half an hour passed before officials who monitored the test from a basement office in the Pentagon reported that the interceptor missile had missed.

Without making an announcement, Boeing and Defence Department officials transported the entire gathering through dead of night to the Pentagon. There, at a dramatic briefing lasting until 2.30am, we heard that one of the most technologically adventurous experiments ever mounted by the Defence Department had floundered for a banal low-tech reason. The booster had failed to separate and launch the 'Exoatmospheric Kill Vehicle'.

General Ronald Kadish looked like a melting waxwork. 'What this tells me is that we have a lot of engineering work left to do. This is a challenge; this is rocket science.' The thought that the booster would not release the kill vehicle 'wasn't even on my list of potential problems', he said. It had not received the necessary signal.

The Pentagon's head of weapons procurement, Under-Secretary Dr Chuck Gansler, emphasised that the problem was a basic one. 'We still want to see the end game, the interception of the missile. Would we like to have more data? Of course we would. But we are where we are.'

The test was intended to be the gateway to the most important policy decision of President Clinton's eight years in office: whether to proceed with the embryonic National Missile Defence system - a revival of the Star Wars programme. This was supposed to be the missile defence shield that would take the US into the next phase of the military world order, and - say its critics - run the risk of detonating another arms race.

The test was the decisive one of three: last October a 'kill vehicle' pulverised a dummy missile, but in January missed another by 141ft.

This is not quite Star Wars as pioneered by the Reagan Administration, since the 'kill vehicle' is terrestrially (not space) based, but it is a version of the same vision - hitting a bullet with a bullet. But yesterday the project seemed doomed. The technical problems make it almost impossible for the Pentagon to recommend pursuit of the high-speed timetable set down for the missile shield. They also reinforce a host of political and strategic objections.

Indeed, there were reports of secret relief inside the White House, which has been ambivalent about the missile shield since a bipartisan vote in Congress last year mandated the President and the Pentagon to develop an heir to Star Wars. The vote leaves Clinton legally obliged to decide whether to go ahead this summer.

The scope of the project is awesome: proceeding in four stages from an initial 20 missile interceptors in 2005 to a fleet, by 2011, of 250 'exoatmospheric kill vehicles' in underground silos across Alaska and North Dakota, to be unleashed and guided by a global network of three command centres and five communications relay stations using 29 satellites and 15 space-based radar stations.

On Tuesday morning, in a conference room on the seventh floor of CIA headquarters, the agency's director, George Tenet, will convene probably the most important meeting of his career: a multi-agency cabal tasked to confront a cacophony of objections and give its 'National Intelligence Estimate'. The meeting will be attended by the Pentagon, the Defence Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency, the State Department Bureau of Intelligence and various mapping and satellite bureaux.

On the agenda will be non-technical objections from both within and without the US, and indeed within the intelligence services themselves. Principal among these will be the fears of Russia and China. Russia has made its opposition clear, with President Putin working to win over sympathy and support in both western and eastern Europe for his view that the defence screen is an abrogation of three decades of arms control treaties and constitutes a bellicose return to the arms race.

What the intelligence community has to gauge is whether deployment would cause the Russians to abandon arms control and prompt China to enlarge its own nuclear arsenal. The bedrock decision to be made on the basis of the intelligence report will be Clinton's this summer, but if the shield were to go ahead the deployment and targeting orders would follow in 2003, thereby becoming the single most momentous task of the next president.

There is no debate between Vice-President Al Gore and Republican challenger George Bush on the need for a screen, but there is a world of difference between how far - in terms of cost, geography, technology and bellicosity - each wants to go. And on how far each is prepared to go in overturning decades of doctrine that kept the peace throughout the Cold War.

The United States and Russia are still bound by the anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty of 1972, which banned the deployment of missile defence systems, under the notion that the best way of preserving peace is the doctrine of MAD (mutual assured destruction), whereby no one would risk a nuclear attack for fear of the finality of retribution.

During the Reagan years, both the US and USSR experimented with Star Wars projects (the Americans were way ahead) on the premise that defence is the best form of attack. The idea was that the ability to take out incoming missiles would lead - as Paul Warnke, President Carter's negotiator, put it to The Observer - 'to the terrifying notion that you might just catch it right, and actually be able to fight and win a nuclear war'.

Gore has said he is ready to negotiate with Putin's post-Communist Russia on changes to the ABM treaty which allow for defensive systems. But he has refused to rule out the possibility of unilaterally breaching the treaty if he thought such a step was 'necessary to US security'.

Bush advances Gore's position by leaps and bounds. He has pledged to rip the ABM treaty to shreds, if necessary, in pursuit of an unequivocal return to Reagan's Star Wars, deploying a comprehensive shield system of space, ground and sea-based missiles.

The Bush programme would not be limited to the Alaska 'front' or indeed to the US. 'Our missile defence,' said Bush, 'must be designed to protect all 50 states, and our friends and allies and forces deployed overseas.'

In terms of cost, the Clinton-Gore version has been estimated at $60 billion, while experts calculate the Bush plan would come in at three times that amount.

China has warned that it will escalate its own missile-building and modernisation programme, which has come under particular scrutiny by US intelligence since the leak of core secrets from the nuclear laboratory in Los Alamos.

The problems proliferate in the post-Cold War disorder, since a revived and accelerated arms race would no longer involve two opposing blocks, around the US and USSR as of old, but a miasma of 'sideshow' nuclear powers with their own priorities and concerns.

Officials at the State Department tell The Observer that they will want to discuss the possible 'card deck effect' of a build-up by Beijing. They fear that China's nemesis in Asia, India, will then feel obliged to accelerate its missile programme, which in turn would lead to a retaliatory programme by India's bitter rival in the sub-continent: Pakistan.

Even without Putin's recent burst of shuttle diplomacy across Europe to argue against a US missile shield, there were deep concerns among America's allies.

The US intelligence agencies will examine in detail the threats to America posed by missile programmes in North Korea, Iraq and Iran - upon which the need for the defence screen is publicly justified by the administration, the Pentagon and the Bush camp. But German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder leads a view that even taking the 'rogue' states into consideration there remains no threat to Western security sufficient to warrant what is in effect a continuation of a Cold War programme.

Another concern in European Nato-member capitals is that the new screen will mean the US departing from the alliance and going its own way in defence policy, without taking a Nato consensus with it. The Pentagon's proposed network of interceptor missiles, high-speed computers and advanced radar systems includes installations in the UK and in Greenland.

webTitle: Lottery projects paint ugly picture of London bias

fields.headline: Lottery projects paint ugly picture of London bias
fields.standfirst: Millennium projects all over the country are fed up. They struggle harder and receive less recognition than their cousins in the capital
fields.trailText: The rest of England is biting back. As London glories in the launch of a series of galleries and museums, the curators behind a group of rival Cinderella projects in regional cities think they should be allowed to go to the   ball. London is not the only centre of cultural excellence, they say.
fields.body:
The rest of England is biting back. As London glories in the launch of a series of galleries and museums, the curators behind a group of rival Cinderella projects in regional cities think they should be allowed to go to the ball. London is not the only centre of cultural excellence, they say.

Millennium openings of arts centres in Sheffield, Salford, Walsall, Gateshead and Bradford have all faced much more difficult struggles for survival and for publicity. They have also been burdened with the added expectation that they will help to regenerate their areas.

While both of the Tate Gallery's openings and the fanfared refurbishments of the Wallace Collection, Somerset House and the National Portrait Gallery have won critical attention, schemes in the North, which are worth just as much money, and in some cases more, have been largely ignored.

The only one to hit the headlines was Sheffield's National Centre for Popular Music, which has been declared bankrupt. Costing £15 million, the centre may be bought by Sheffield Hallam University. Martin King, the second manager brought in to try to revive the fortunes of the centre, left after a few months to run a venue in north London.

The York MP and Social Security Minister Hugh Bayley has noticed the bias too. In the mid-Nineties he complained about the glut of lottery cash being spent in London. 'These days there is a disdain for things that go on outside London,' he said.

The £105m Lowry Centre in Salford opened in April with the odds similarly stacked against it. Like the Sheffield centre, the bold modern architecture won early fans and it was also expected to revive the rundown Salford Quays area.

The opening was dogged with problems, including a car park that left motorists unable to get out, staff with offices but no desks and, most embarrassingly, a museum housing valuable works of art with doors that could not be locked. 'It took weeks to get keys to doors,' said chief executive Stephen Heddingly. But the Lowry has welcomed many more visitors than expected.

Karsten Schubert, author of The Curator's Egg, a new book about the history of the museum, was not surprised by the failure of the Pop centre in Sheffield, but he sees other regional museums facing a real prejudice.

'When I first came here from France I could not believe how London-centred this country had become.' he said. 'So Sheffield failed. If there is nothing of great worth in there, then people will stay away. The quality of the idea and of the content will always prevail.'

Schubert bemoans the way British cultural institutions have had to justify their right to a grant by coming up with secondary reasons for existing, usually turning around the fortunes of an area. 'The danger with finding these secondary motives is that the whole argument is lost. Museums have to know that they are museums for their own sake.'

Learning the lessons is another flagship millennium project set in the middle of an urban renewal project. Baltic is a £45m gallery and performance space funded by the Arts Council from lottery cash and based in the old Baltic Flour Mill in Gateshead.

It launches in September and hopes to attract 350,000 people a year. One staff member said: 'It looks good, but that may not be enough. It all depends on the publicity.'

The biggest victim of the London cultural bias may be the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television in Bradford, reopened last year after a millennium-funded refit. While visitor numbers are good, there has been no critical coverage of the content, and Amanda Nevill, head of the museum, is cross: 'We have galleries with permanent displays and special exhibitions of international standard, but we still don't get talked or written about nationally.

Peter Jenkinson, director of the one new regional project that has won more attention and plaudits than any other, the Walsall Gallery for modern art in the Midlands, is convinced the North of England has to fight back. 'There is actually much more experimenting going on outside London in the arts and cultural world,' he said.

'When we got help from the capital, it used to be seen as London dispensing a few crumbs from its table to the regions. That is not the case at all any more. We are equal partners really.'

As London glories in the launch of a series of galleries and museums, the curators behind a group of rival Cinderella projects in regional cities think they should be allowed to go to the ball. London is not the only centre of cultural excellence, they say. Millennium openings of arts centres in Sheffield, Salford, Walsall, Gateshead and Bradford have all faced much more difficult struggles for survival and for publicity. They have also been burdened with the added expectation that they will help to regenerate their areas. While both of the Tate Gallery's openings and the fanfared refurbishments of the Wallace Collection, Somerset House and the National Portrait Gallery have won critical attention, schemes in the North, which are worth just as much money, and in some cases more, have been largely ignored. Martin King, the second manager brought in to try to revive the fortunes of the centre, left after a few months to run a venue in north London.
