fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Benn attacks Labour Party line on the euro
fields.body:
Benn attacks Labour Party line on the euro

The Labour MP Tony Benn addressed the 116th Durham Miners' Gala yesterday and attacked the Government's stance on the euro. Benn said he was in favour of a closer relationship with Britain's neighbours, but said we should not 'allow our laws to be made and our taxes imposed by those who do not represent us... The trade union movement has always been internationalist in its outlook and rightly so.'

Cat found good home

A cat was reunited with its owner after being found in an RSPCA inspector's back garden more than 100 miles from her home. Emma, a seven-year-old tortoiseshell disappeared from her home in Rushden, Northamptonshire, three months ago.

Centre of attention

12-year-old Raju Tital yesterday became the first non-umpire to toss the coin to decide which player should serve first on Centre Court at Wimbledon. Raju, from Calcutta, was chosen to toss the coin before the Ladies Singles final after being found on the verge of death at Calcutta railway station. Today 17-year-old Anthony Mills, from Egham in Surrey, who was diagnosed with leukaemia in January 1999, will toss the coin before the men's final between Pete Sampras and Pat Rafter.

Arson attack on flats

Families were evacuated from a burning block of flats in Luton, Bedforshire, yesterday, after a man set fire to the building. One man was injured as he jumped from the fourth floor, after waking when he heard strange noises. He saw the arsonist pouring petrol through a letterbox and about to strike a match. Thirty people including children were evacuated as smoke began to fill the flats. Detectives were hunting the man who was believed to have been targetting a specific family in the flats.

Pokémon boy found

Missing nine-year-old Adam Messenger was found safe yesterday after sleeping rough on Friday night after a row with his parents over Pokémon cards. Coastguards searched the shore near his home in Westgate, Kent, but he was found by police after sleeping on a golf course.

Degree for Quant

Mary Quant, the designer credited with inventing the miniskirt, has been awarded an honorary degree for achievements in the fashion industry. Quant, 66,was given an honorary degree by Winchester School of Art.

fields.headline: 'Dracula' sex fiend hits sixth victim
fields.trailText: A masked sex fiend dubbed Dracula, believed to have attacked five times in eight months, has struck again, police said yesterday. The attacker - known to wear gloves, a balaclava or a Dracula mask - has been preying on women and girls as young as 11 in the Hayling Island and Portsmouth areas of Hampshire since December last year.
fields.body:
A masked sex fiend dubbed Dracula, believed to have attacked five times in eight months, has struck again, police said yesterday. The attacker - known to wear gloves, a balaclava or a Dracula mask - has been preying on women and girls as young as 11 in the Hayling Island and Portsmouth areas of Hampshire since December last year.

DNA tests have linked two attacks and police say all descriptions of the man show striking similarities.

In the latest offence on Friday night, a 15-year-old girl was grabbed as she cycled along a disused railway on Hayling Island. The man wore a black woollen hat, grabbed her from behind, threatened to kill her, and tried to drag her into the bushes but she managed to struggle free.

On 20 May, a 13-year-old girl suffered a horrific sex attack in the churchyard of St Mary's in Hayling Island. A man in a black balaclava threatened to kill her and tied her hands behind her back, using women's underwear.

On 10 March, a woman was approached by a man at her front door on Hayling Island but shut the door on him. On 14 February, a 44-year-old woman fought off a man wearing a Halloween mask in Denvilles, Havant, and four days later a 51-year-old woman was attacked in a subway in Emsworth. Her attacker left behind his Dracula mask.

The first attack was on 1 December last year when an 11-year-old girl was grabbed as she cycled along the same railway line as Friday night's victim, but she managed to struggle free.

Police linked the attacks on the 13 and the 51-year-old and say all the attacks have similarities.

The latest victim gave police the best description of him yet, saying he is aged 35-55, white, clean-shaven, 5ft 7in tall with short, greying hair and was physically slim and weak.

A Hampshire police spokeswoman said: 'We must catch this man.'

webTitle: Exiled dissident defies Saddam's regime of rape

fields.headline: Exiled dissident defies Saddam's regime of rape
fields.trailText: When former Iraqi General Najib al Salihy picked up the video wrapped in paper from the bakery in Amman, he suspected nothing.
fields.body:
When former Iraqi General Najib al Salihy picked up the video wrapped in paper from the bakery in Amman, he suspected nothing.

On the 7 June, a man with a Jordanian accent had told al-Salihy the 48-year-old dissident that he had a gift for him from his family in Baghdad. As he was in a hurry, said the caller, he would leave it at a convenient pick-up point.

Seconds into the tape, Salihy had no doubt what was to come. He sat and watched the clinical video, a 'gift' from Saddam Hussein's evil regime - film of the brutal rape of a young member of his family.

Salihy, his hands crossed across his lap, could not bring himself to say more about the identity of the victim. He has not told his wife and three children who she is. When he finished watching the rape, fuming, determined to retaliate and go public, he sealed the video in an envelope and hid it to use as evidence against Saddam Hussein, if he is ever indicted.

The humiliation of such family dishonour in the Middle East is powerful enough to make most men do anything. Rape has been effectively used by the Iraqi regime for the last 30 years to blackmail, intimidate and coerce loyalty from those inside and outside its borders.

What will happen to the female victim is unclear, but she is probably still in prison, facing death, or perhaps she will be released as a pariah into a community where the implications of rape are fatal.

For decades this has proved a devastatingly successful tactic. Men fearing for their lives, families and honour buckle silently and play along in an endless revenge game that further entangles and incriminates them.

Salihy decided to speak out and to make public, both here and in the Arab world, the extent to which men like Saddam brutalise his countrymen. He wants to tell the world what the Iraqis already know. 'I wanted to do something different,' said Salihy.

A former Iraqi army chief of staff, he fought the Iraqi Opposition during the rebellion in Kurdistan in 1995. But he had secretly been involved in opposition activities since 1979 and, fearing discovery, escaped to Jordan with his immediate family in 1996.

The tape was not his first run-in with the Mukhabarat, the Iraqi intelligence service. Twice they tortured and beat Salihy's brother into going to Jordan with a message from Baghdad from them. To ensure his return, they held his family. But still the exiled ex-general remained defiant.

Ten days after the video, Salihy received the call. The man aimed to bully him into working for the regime, to halt opposition activities that so threaten Saddam.

The Mukhabarat officer was banking on the threat of exposure being enough to cow Salihy. He was wrong.

The ex-general was told the tape was only a taste of what was to come for his family in Baghdad.

'My response was that the issue of honour was a barrier but is no longer,' Salihy said. 'My family is being held hostage, as is the rest of the population. I told him you are just criminals, and you can broadcast it on satellite if you want. I worry about reprisals on my family, but I won't let this demoralise me and I won't let it stop me, otherwise Saddam has won.'

webTitle: New York's No 1 deli loses its cool flavour

fields.headline: New York's No 1 deli loses its cool flavour
fields.standfirst: Family intrigue may prove the downfall of the stars' favourite Italian haunt, reports Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: Family intrigue may prove the downfall of the stars' favourite Italian haunt, reports Ed Vulliamy
fields.body:
Uma Thurman was in the other day buying pesto and cold cuts. It's where Lou Reed stocks up on linguini, where Anna Wintour pops in for pecorino and prosciutto.

It would be silly to call Balducci's of Greenwich Village the Fortnum's of New York. Sure, it's where the rich and famous shop for gourmet groceries, but it is also hip, sensual - and authentic; it smells like an alleyway in Bologna, even though the trucks are roaring past up Sixth Avenue.

Another Balducci's delicatessen opened last week on the Upper West Side. Except that is an oxymoron: you can't have a Balducci's on the Upper West Side. A Balducci's on the Upper West Side is as authentic as a Fortnum and Mason's in Hackney. What it means is that Balducci's isn't Balducci's any more.

The distinctive 'B' on the green awning is the same as the original in Greenwich Village, but the sanitised decor is entirely different, as is the stroller-pushing clientele, which has as much razzmatazz appeal as the traffic jam outside.

The attempt at cloning New York's most beloved food store is the first sign of the fall of the famous delicatessen opened by Louis and Maria Balducci in 1945. It is also the first sign of the bitter war within the Balducci family itself.

No member of the clan can agree on what went wrong, on who betrayed whom. It is a grand opera of sibling rivalry, jealousy, alleged swindling and lawsuits more piquant than the spiciest olives on the deli counter. All that is certain is the result: no member of the Balducci clan now works at either store.

Louis and Maria came to America in 1914 and had three children - Charles, Andy and Grace. According to Andy, Charles was the favourite, even before he astonished his proud father by becoming a doctor.

Andy spent his life trying to prove to Louis he was a better man than Dr Charles. It was Andy who went into business with his father, setting up a fruit and vegetable stall on Greenwich Avenue. 'I always thought it should be a little more sophisticated,' he says, 'so I put up a sign "Balducci Produce".'

After marrying Nina d'Amelio in 1952, however, Andy went to work for his father-in-law in the marble and granite trade. Nina's father, it is said, did not want a son-in-law 'with dirt under his fingernails'. But in 1968, Andy came back to the fold. Four years later, Balducci's moved to its new, prestigious location on the Avenue of the Americas.

'When I came back,' Andy says, 'I found what I had left, no progress at all'. To the usual fare of the stall, he began to add truffles, gourmet cheeses and Italian specialities.

No sooner was the new shop bought than the intrigue began. For some reason, Louis - who died in 1988 - did not sign the lease for the property, nor did he appear to own any part of the business. The store belonged to Andy and Nina, sister Grace and her husband Joe Doria. Andy and Nina had 51 per cent; Grace and Joe 49.

Andy's cousin, Charlie Balducci, says Louis had no idea he had been written out until the early Eighties, when - says Charlie - he once shouted: 'My son is a thief! Do you hear me? My son is a thief.' Andy, a genial man with a floral tie, says: 'That was Pop's opinion. I don't believe my father said that.' In 1985, Louis filed a suit for his share - the family will not discuss it, nor do the court papers tell what was settled.

Andy Balducci, now 74, says his brother, Dr Charles, put the old man up to the lawsuit. Dr Charles retorts that the dividing up of the lease and company in 1972 was a ploy to cut him out.

Grace and Joe festered with their 49 per cent, insisting - says Grace - that 'Andy did everything, we were just puppets', and that 'Andy pulled the wool over our eyes'.

Grace and Joe filed their own writ and left the company for a reported $2.5 million. They tried to establish an Uptown store called Grace Balducci's, but were counter-sued by Andy, who said they had no right to use the name.

The Grace Balducci's store became Grace Doria's none the less. The real Balducci's was now owned by Andy and Nina alone. Andy last year sold up - to a chain of food emporia called Sutton Place Gourmet of Bethesda, Maryland. Andy stayed on as a consultant.

Tim Zagat, publisher of guides to foodie New York, had rated Balducci's number one food store in the city, but warned: 'The quirky charms will be lost in an acquisition of this kind.' His prophecy came true. Sutton Place had 12 stores before it bought Balducci's. Now it has 14 - two are called Balducci's, but not one is Balducci's.

The week before last Uma Thurman was buying her gourmet Italian groceries at a rival delicatessen called the Jefferson Market, two blocks from Balducci's.

webTitle: Greek courts get tough over Nazi massacre

fields.headline: Greek courts get tough over Nazi massacre
fields.standfirst: German property in Athens could be seized
fields.trailText: German property in Athens could be seized
fields.body:
The people of Distomo would like to honour their dead, but they have never quite had the means to do so.

Like the incomplete mausoleum on the grassy knoll above the village, paying tribute to the 218 men, women and children who were killed by the Nazis in one of the worst massacres of the Second World War is still unfinished business.

The Waffen-SS unit drove into the village near Delphi one hot June day 56 years ago. By the time it left, when night fell, the priest had been decapitated, bodies were dangling from trees and the foetuses of butchered, pregnant women were splattered on the ground. The atrocity, in reprisal for a partisan ambush in which seven soldiers died, remains one of occupied Greece's darkest events.

'You cannot erase such things, they stay with you for life,' says Loukas Papachristos, the village mayor, who lost four relatives that day. 'What we want is to show that no matter how long afterwards there will be a point when you have to pay for your crimes.' That point, he hopes, will come this week.

On Tuesday, Greek court officials are expected to begin proceedings for the forcible seizure of three German government properties in Athens - the Goethe Institute, the German Archaeological School and the German high school. Staff will be turfed out of the buildings when the prime real-estate is put up for auction, possibly as early as September. Last April, the Greek Supreme Court, upholding a 1997 ruling by a lower tribunal, decreed that Germany should part with $30 million (£20m) in reparations to the village. Money raised from the sale of the properties will go towards paying the damages more than 50 years after the end of Hitler's Third Reich.

Yannis Stamoulis, a former local governor who launched the campaign said: 'If the German government had chosen not to ignore the court rulings we would not now be seeing this as the only way of settling the matter.

'This is Berlin's problem. Legally, ethically, whichever way you look at it, the German state has every reason to find a solution. The verdicts of the Greek courts are valid because the crimes occurred here.' The extraordinary step could have profound repercussions for others seeking wartime reparations, says Stamoulis, a septuagenarian lawyer who initiated the campaign in 1995.

'There are thousands of people in Greece who have never been properly compensated. Our court action paves the way for others to follow suit,' adds the former Socialist MEP who only narrowly escaped a Nazi firing squad himself.

Greece suffered appalling deprivations during the three years that the swastika flew over the Acropolis. An estimated 130,000 people were executed while some 300,000 more starved to death. The ruins of villages that were pillaged and burnt by Nazi troops still scar the landscape. Among the older generation, memories of those traumatic years are still vivid.

But unlike other occupied nations, Greeks say they were never adequately compensated for the loss of lives and damages to their homes. In March 1960 West Germany handed the Greek state 115 million deutschmarks, but campaigners say under the treaty the final settlement of war reparations was put off until Germany reunited.

Papachristos, Distomo's mayor, said: 'Almost all of those funds went to Greece's Jewish community which was only right because it suffered so terribly. Each of us received 16,500 drachmas (£31 at today's rate), a laughable amount which wasn't even enough to buy a car.

'I remember very well that we were told we could file individual claims later ... we all suffered under Nazi rule. The German parliament can't agree to compensate some and not others.'

Not that Berlin sees it that way. Last week, foreign ministry officials flatly dismissed the claim as 'moribund', saying no court had jurisdiction over another country. The issue of forced labourers - who had never received a penny of the £50 billion damages Germany has handed to Israel and other countries since the end of the war - was, they argued, an entirely different matter.

A spokesman at the German Foreign Ministry told The Observer: 'The Greek Supreme Court's decision violates international public law ... for Germany the 1960 treaty of damages was a final settlement of all claims ... how it was handed out was up to the Greek government.'

Was Berlin concerned by the prospect of having its property in Athens seized? 'No, under Greek law such a move would require the prior consent of the country's Justice Minister.'

But, on this matter at least, Greek justice has moved at a speed that has only brought embarrassment for the Athens government.

Berlin may, as German diplomats also point out, have contributed some Dm30 billion worth of EU infrastructure funds to Greece, the 15-nation bloc's poorest partner. And Prime Minister Costas Simitis, for years a university professor in Hamburg, may equally have sought to play down the issue - even if his predecessor, the late Andreas Papandreou, also demanded that Germany reimburse Greece with up to £13bn for funds looted by Nazi troops. But there is a very clear sense that Simitis's position is being overtaken by events. Once derided, Yannis Stamoulis's campaign has so far met with unforeseeable success. He said: 'The Justice and Foreign Ministers have told me quite openly that the seizure is a court issue, one in which the government cannot intervene. It's really just a matter of time before the confiscations go ahead.'

In Distomo, money for those who survived the massacre no longer means much. Papachristos said: 'What can you do with it when you're 80 except honour the dead?'

Which is exactly what the village plans to do, putting the final touches to the marble mausoleum on the grassy knoll where German tourists often stop to lay a wreath.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Sweden has granted temporary visas to two doctors who defected from Cuba while on a medical mission to Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
Swedish sanctuary

Sweden has granted temporary visas to two doctors who defected from Cuba while on a medical mission to Zimbabwe. Leonel Córdova Rodríguez, 31, and Noris Pena Martínez, 25, are expected to seek permanent asylum.

Spy Sonya dies at 93

Ruth Werner, a communist spy codenamed 'Sonya' who helped Klaus Fuchs smuggle atom bomb secrets from Britain to the Soviet Union in the Forties, has died in her native Berlin, aged 93. She had a successful career as a novelist in East Germany.

Mafia suspects held

Police arrested 10 suspected Mafia men and accused them of plotting the murder of a fishmonger in the Sicilian capital, Palermo, for refusing to pay extortion money.

Sharif wife arrested

Pakistani police detained the wife of deposed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif after stopping a rally she was expected to lead in Lahore. He has been jailed for life on charges of hijacking and terrorism.

Mt Oyama erupts

A volcano erupted on the summit of Mount Oyama on Miyakejima, 124 miles south of Tokyo, spewing ash and rocks high into the air.

Poisoned peacocks

More than a dozen peacocks, the national bird, have died at Maharagpur, a central Indian village whose name means 'place with plenty of peacocks'. They had eaten seeds treated with chemicals.

42 killed by typhoons

Floods ravaged the northern Philippines, bringing the death toll from two typhoons to 42. About 800,000 people, crowded into a mere 80 shelters, were made homeless after the severe wet season disasters.

Iranian rally gassed

Iranian police used tear gas to break up a pro-democracy student rally in Tehran staged to mark the anniversary of a violent police raid on a student hostel.

Church hit by bomb

An explosion damaged a Lutheran church in Hubli, southern India. Furious Christians set fire to a bus and hurled rocks at vehicles in response.

webTitle: Detectives quiz dangerous paedophiles as hunt for missing Sarah is stepped up

fields.headline: Detectives quiz dangerous paedophiles as hunt for missing Sarah is stepped up
fields.trailText: Police forces across the country are urgently interviewing high-risk paedophiles and other sex offenders in a desperate bid to track down missing Sarah Payne. The interviews with registered offenders will attempt to establish their whereabouts at the time the eight-year-old disappeared. DNA samples may be taken from them.
fields.body:
Police forces across the country are urgently interviewing high-risk paedophiles and other sex offenders in a desperate bid to track down missing Sarah Payne. The interviews with registered offenders will attempt to establish their whereabouts at the time the eight-year-old disappeared. DNA samples may be taken from them.

The hunt in West Sussex is being intensified, with more than 1,000 officers now assigned to it.

Sarah's grandfather made an emotional appeal yesterday for her return. Terry Payne broke down in tears as he read letters written by Sarah's brother and sister: 'Please let her go because I love her, I love her, I love her,' wrote her younger sister Charlotte. 'And please give her a rose and I will give her loads of kisses because I love her so much.

'When we bring her back I will give her something special. I love, I love you so much, Sarah.'

Payne, who was joined at a press conference by his wife Lesley and Sarah's uncle, Paul Williams, shook uncontrollably as he read the letters and collapsed as the event finished. He said: 'It's tearing our family apart. Somebody's got Sarah and we want her back.'

Sarah's parents, Mike and Sara, were under unimaginable strain. 'They've been through a hell of a situation, the grandfather said. 'If there's anybody out there who knows anything, please ring us.'

Sarah's brothers, Lee and Luke, had not stopped crying since she disappeared, and Charlotte kept asking her mother when Sarah will be coming home, he said.

'We are a strong family. We're sticking together, and we're going to get through this,' he vowed.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Sandra Horley, head of the domestic violence charity Refuge, first met Helena Kennedy QC when the barrister asked her to   be an expert witness. Now it's Helena who lends her expertise to help battered women
fields.trailText: Sandra Horley, head of the domestic violence charity Refuge, first met Helena Kennedy QC when the barrister asked her to be an expert witness. Now it's Helena who lends her expertise to help battered women
fields.body:
Helena Kennedy QC
I'd just become a senior counsel in 1991 when I was briefed on a case involving the killing of a baby for which a young man, Brian Hedman, and woman, Sally Emery, were standing trial. I had a strong feeling that there was much more to this case than we were getting at. I was representing Emery, who was very careful not to say anything incriminating about her husband. They both denied the charges. But as she began to trust me, she began to unravel that she had been battered.

I wanted someone who had a psychiatric background to see her, but at that time battered women's syndrome was still a year away from being a recognised psychiatric diagnosis. I remembered an article about the dynamics of women survivors and how often the men who were abusers were not the stereotype of the aggressor and the woman wasn't necessarily timid or passive. The author was Sandra Horley, director of the then Chiswick Women's Aid.

The trial had already started when I phoned her. I knew it would be difficult to persuade the court to acknowledge her as an expert - it's easier if you have someone medically or scientifically qualified - yet there was probably no one more experienced than someone who'd worked in refuges for 20 years. I arranged to see her in chambers after court that day, to see whether she would make a good witness.

Sandra arrived wearing a red cape and looked glamorous, which is a plus, because if someone looks interesting and likeable that's half the battle. I was thrilled because she defied the idea of a feminist adviser to battered women, she obviously liked men, she was highly informed and could clearly describe the dynamics operating in battering relationships. I was trying to show that people like the chap in the dock, who in fact came across as a gentle soul and quite likeable, can also, behind closed doors, sometimes be violent. And a woman can sometimes be psychologically frozen and believe that the man who was once charming, who has turned into her persecutor, can be won back by her adjusting her behaviour. In the end, Hedman was given eight years in prison for cruelty, and Emery the lesser charge of failing to get medical attention.

Sandra has been at the heart of the shift in the legal understanding of domestic violence and she has been the key person who's helped me do cases in the courtroom with the degree of understanding that I otherwise would never have had. She is able to empathise very well with the people she works with because she's had it tough, too. Everyone probably imagines that life has been plain sailing for this incredibly confident woman who now heads up Refuge, the domestic violence charity which employs 100 people. She left her home in Canada at 14 with 15 cents in her pocket after her parents divorced, and supported herself through school by working.

Sandra Horley
I couldn't believe it when the phone rang and it was Helena Kennedy. She's a household name. I knew she was a very famous barrister for human rights - I'd heard her speak at conferences - but I wouldn't have imagined that she knew about me. I had been working for years with a handful of staff at Chiswick, dealing with emergencies all day long, such as a woman whose husband had taken a hammer and chisel to her face, which then needed 250 stitches to repair.

I walked into her very formal chambers feeling very nervous. I had never testified before, and the prospect of that was the most terrifying experience of my life. She turned out to be very down to earth.

We talked about the case. Helena was very patient with me, because I didn't know anything about criminal legislation. But we got through it. Since then we've worked together on a number of cases, including June Scotland - a famous one which became the basis of Brookside - where she had buried her intimidating husband in the garden, after killing him with a rolling pin. June was charged with murder, but it was reduced to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. She was released and immediately she and her daughter, who had been sexually abused by her father, stayed in one of our refuges.

Another case was Marie Shahir, whose partner, in the midst of an argument about their newborn baby's photographs, hit her head with a beer can. She grabbed a knife in self-defence and killed him, but she was given a probation order because she was diagnosed with battered women's syndrome.

These cases have helped create a much better understanding about domestic violence in the courts and psychiatric circles. Meeting Helena has changed my life completely. She's taught me a lot about people, to persevere against the odds, to never give up. If I phone Helena with a problem, she'll drop what she's doing to fire off a letter on behalf of the women we're serving. It's been tough getting the government to recognise domestic violence and it's Helena who's been my cl0sest ally.

 Sandra Horley OBE is the author of The Charm Syndrome, Why Charming Men Can Make Dangerous Lovers, Waterstone's, £9.99 (£3.40 of each book goes to Refuge)

fields.headline: Missed! $100m foul-up for Star Wars
fields.standfirst: Antony Barnett on board the Arctic Sunrise in the Pacific sees a US test failure
fields.trailText: Two hundred miles off the coast of California, a red flash exploded on the Pacific horizon. Within seconds the fireball grew, blasting through the heavens at up to 15,000mph.
fields.body:
Two hundred miles off the coast of California, a red flash exploded on the Pacific horizon. Within seconds the fireball grew, blasting through the heavens at up to 15,000mph.

As it blazed past the constellation of Aquilla, the $100 million (£68m) comet left a trail of weapons-grade graffiti on the night sky. America's most ambitious Star Wars military exercise had begun.

Yesterday's Pentagon experiment marked a new chapter in the arms race. China and Russia expressed fury at Bill Clinton's decision to test the technology and pledged to step up their efforts to build their own missile shields.

America insists the new technology - which will allow it to attack any target on the surface of the earth with impunity - is vital to its defence. But there is one snag: it does not work.

Embarrassed Pentagon officials were forced to admit yesterday that they had failed to destroy a target warhead in space in the third test of its proposed National Missile Defence system.

'We did not intercept the warhead tonight. We are disappointed,' Air Force Lieutenant General Ronald Kadish, director of the missile defence effort, said after the weapon failed to separate from its booster rocket and intercept the dummy warhead over the Pacific Ocean.

'It tells me we have more engineering work to do,' Kadish said. 'We had good confidence in this. This is rocket science - things do happen.'

On board the Arctic Sunrise, where eight campaigners had been sailing around the exclusion zone in inflatable dinghies watching anxiously as the missile roared overhead, no one could quite believe the news at first. Could the nation that had just demonstrated to us its awesome power have simply missed?

The radio cracked again. The answer was a clear 'Yes'. As the last faint traces of the missile's afterglow disappeared from the night sky, bottles of beer were opened in celebration in the ship's mess.

Maria, a Greenpeace activist from Moscow aboard the Arctic Sunrise, said: 'I don't know why, but seeing this missile come over our heads like that, I still feel scared. How can man make something so evil and so beautiful at the same time?'

As he clambered out on to the deck of the Arctic Sunrise, wearing an orange survival suit, one said: 'It serves them right. Fantastic.'

It was the second failure in three tries for the system. The miss could weigh heavily in a decision by Bill Clinton later this year on whether to begin building a new radar system in Alaska for a limited missile defence network in the face of bitter objections from Russia and China.

Kadish told a Pentagon press conference that the 'hit- to-kill' weapon fired from Kwajalein Atoll in the central Pacific at 12:40 a.m. Washington time (04.40 GMT) did not separate from the second stage of its lift-off rocket. The weapon had no chance of intercepting a warhead launched about 20 minutes earlier from Vandenberg Air Force Base, California, 4,000 miles away.

Under-secretary of Defence Jacques Gansler said he felt the design of the planned NMD system 'is pretty solid', but declined to say what recommendation Defence Secretary William Cohen might make to Clinton in coming weeks as to whether the system can be deployed by 2005.

Clinton is caught between opposition from Moscow and Beijing, who fear that a mature and successful US anti-missile system could neutralise their nuclear arsenals, and pressure from conservatives in the US Congress for quick deployment and limited protection against threats from such states as North Korea, Iran and Iraq.

Prominent scientists and former US government officials have also warned the president that the technology is so immature that it would be folly to begin building a system that could cost anywhere from $30 billion to $60bn.

After detailed technical data from Saturday's test is analysed by the Pentagon, Boeing and Raytheon, William Cohen is scheduled to relay a recommendation to Clinton in coming weeks on NMD's immediate future. Clinton says his decision will also consider a pending detailed intelligence analysis of the threat from emerging potential enemies such as North Korea as well as US ties with its European allies, China and Russia.

Europe fears a new arms race begin if the United States breaks the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty by building even a limited system.

fields.headline: Brown cuddles up to Europe
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown cast off a lot more than his eurosceptic mantle yesterday as he shared a plane and two bunk beds with his counterparts from Germany, France and Italy on their nine-hour journey to a G7 meeting in Japan.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown cast off a lot more than his eurosceptic mantle yesterday as he shared a plane and two bunk beds with his counterparts from Germany, France and Italy on their nine-hour journey to a G7 meeting in Japan.

The unprecedented show of solidarity and parsimony was made at the suggestion of the Chancellor, usually considered to be one of the most reluctant members of the Cabinet to pursue closer European union.

'It was very economical and very European,' said a Treasury official. 'It gave the Ministers a good opportunity to talk on the way.'

Germany, which provided a Luftwaffe Airbus A310, charged its distinguished hitch-hikers just Dm4,500 (£1,500) for the flight, which they joined at Helsinki. This is less than a third of the price they are used to paying.

'You cannot underestimate the symbolic value of this flight,' French Finance Minister Laurent Fabius said after landing. But in keeping with the political intrigues of the EU, there were sharply contrasting versions about who slept with whom.

The Airbus has only two cabins, each with a bunk bed. According to British sources, Brown spent the night with his French counterpart. This entente cordiale would have left the former Axis powers in the other room. However, German officials insist that Finance Minister Hans Eichel paired up with Fabius. This would be a closer reflection of modern Europe with Brown and Italian Treasury Minister Vincenzo Visco left outside of a Franco-German alliance.

The only agreement was that nobody snored.

As the flight banked towards the North Sea after take-off, Brown is reported to have asked in mock concern whether the Luftwaffe was heading towards a new Battle of Britain.

webTitle: Harry Potter and the Small Snubbed Fans

fields.headline: Harry Potter and the Small Snubbed Fans
fields.standfirst:
The long-awaited launch of J.K. Rowling's new book finally begins - but there are some tears before bedtime

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Parents fought, children wept and the author proclaimed herself amazed. 'Think of a stronger word and double it,' J.K. Rowling said, shaking her head in disbelief at the mayhem.
fields.body:
Parents fought, children wept and the author proclaimed herself amazed. 'Think of a stronger word and double it,' J.K. Rowling said, shaking her head in disbelief at the mayhem.

London's King's Cross station had never seen anything quite like it. Two fathers, with weeping children clinging to their shoulders, bayed blue murder as they wrestled for a place near the crash barrier. Police rushing in to subdue the squall upbraided them: 'If you don't cut this out, you'll have to leave before she arrives.'

An immediate, snarling peace was established as police restrained a mother determined to get her child a better view by dangling him precariously from the bridge, 30ft above the railway.

Welcome to 'Platform 9 and 3/4'. As Potterites know, this is where their young hero boards the Hogswart Express at the start of each school term, heading for adventure armed with nothing but half-baked spells and an insipid group of friends that drive some critics to distraction.

But what should have been the happiest day in a month of book-publishing Saturdays descended into farce yesterday as more than 300 children watched in dismay when the press formed a scrum and trampled both them and their bemused parents underfoot.

'It's a shame,' said Linda Mullen, who had come with her 7-year-old son, Daniel. 'This should be an event for the kids, but it's full of people rushing around with their mobile phones. Where's the fantasy and magic in this?' 'I thought there would be flying owls,' whispered her son.

The waiting is over and Harry Potter is back. The frenzied speculation of the past few weeks has woven its witchcraft: many of the initial 1.5 million prints have already been sold and every child in Britain and beyond with a taste for magic and three-headed dogs called Fluffy is agog with excitement to learn which of Harry's friends dies, which girl he has a crush on, and whether the new Defence Against the Dark Arts professor lasts longer than the last.

Rowling dismounted from the trademark light blue Ford Anglia of Harry's cruel uncle with engine oil on her calves, and set off instinctively towards the bank of keening children. But she was jostled instead towards the baying scribes and snappers.

Thomas Martin, seven, proudly sporting his father's black velvet smoking jacket and a witch's hat half as tall as himself, was too excited to sleep the night before but now sat on his father's shoulders and stared glumly from the back of the crowd. 'I suppose she's just a normal person anyway, just like anyone else,' he sadly concluded.

Rowling had the look of someone who had been outfoxed by her press office. Each time she tried to move towards her small fans, she was pulled back by the press pack, surrounded by flashing cameras and gesturing sadly towards her young readers with frustrated goodwill.

'I'm sorry,' she called to a group of children who had left their home in Durham at 5.45 that morning to visit the Dome but had managed to persuade their parents to change course en route. 'I'm not allowed: the policeman told me.' The policemen surrounding her looked ashamed, and the one who had his book signed moments before tried to hide it behind his back. Ariadne, 10, was frantic. 'It's ruined,' she sobbed. 'The book won't seem nearly as magic now.' 'She'll get over it,' reasoned her mother, 'it's all been a bit too much. She knew she probably wouldn't get her book signed, but she did hope to get a smile.'

Luke Gate, nine, avoided the madness and retreated behind the ticket office to read his new book in peace. 'She's just a normal person. Harry's my hero, not her,' he said gloomily.

As the train chugged away, headed off to the next press call in Didcot, Rowling leaned out of the carriage and waved for all she was worth. 'Oh God, I'm sorry, I'm sorry,' she called unhappily. 'It was nice meeting you all.'

'And you,' called one polite little voice from the front.

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

The frenzied speculation of the past few weeks has woven its witchcraft: many of the initial 1.5 million prints have already been sold and every child in Britain and beyond with a taste for magic and three-headed dogs called Fluffy is agog with excitement to learn which of Harry's friends dies, which girl he has a crush on, and whether the new Defence Against the Dark Arts professor lasts longer than the last. Rowling dismounted from the trademark light blue Ford Anglia of Harry's cruel uncle with engine oil on her calves, and set off instinctively towards the bank of keening children. But she was jostled instead towards the baying scribes and snappers. Thomas Martin, seven, proudly sporting his father's black velvet smoking jacket and a witch's hat half as tall as himself, was too excited to sleep the night before but now sat on his father's shoulders and stared glumly from the back of the crowd. 'I suppose she's just a normal person anyway, just like anyone else,' he sadly concluded. Rowling had the look of someone who had been outfoxed by her press office. Each time she tried to move towards her small fans, she was pulled back by the press pack, surrounded by flashing cameras and gesturing sadly towards her young readers with frustrated goodwill. 'I'm sorry,' she called to a group of children who had left their home in Durham at 5.45 that morning to visit the Dome but had managed to persuade their parents to change course en route. 'I'm not allowed: the policeman told me.' The policemen surrounding her looked ashamed, and the one who had his book signed moments before tried to hide it behind his back. Ariadne, 10, was frantic. 'It's ruined,' she sobbed. 'The book won't seem nearly as magic now.' 'She'll get over it,' reasoned her mother, 'it's all been a bit too much. She knew she probably wouldn't get her book signed, but she did hope to get a smile.' Luke Gate, nine, avoided the madness and retreated behind the ticket office to read his new book in peace. 'She's just a normal person. Harry's my hero, not her,' he said gloomily. As the train chugged away, headed off to the next press call in Didcot, Rowling leaned out of the carriage and waved for all she was worth. 'Oh God, I'm sorry, I'm sorry,' she called unhappily. 'It was nice meeting you all.' 'And you,' called one polite little voice from the front. amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Five of the best...
fields.standfirst: ... places to find fresh and dried pasta, and vegetables for the sauce. By Sue Webster
fields.trailText: ... places to find fresh and dried pasta, and vegetables for the sauce. By Sue Webster
fields.body:
There are no prizes for guessing why pasta is fast replacing potatoes as our national carbohydrate: it's quick to cook, requires no preparation and seems infinitely versatile. The best news is that it's good for you, helping to lower blood-cholesterol levels - as long as you don't wolf it down with too many cream or cheese sauces. In summer, tomato- and vegetable-based sauces are often the most appealing option.

Cardiff residents are lucky to have Pastacara (12 Clare Road, Grangetown, Cardiff; 02920 222 988), where Gill DeVita makes a dazzling range of fresh pasta every day in all shapes and sizes, including 20 types of ravioli. She also makes sauces, of which the most summery, she thinks, is 'picanti' - sautéed courgettes, peppers, chillies, garlic and onion, which she adds to a basic Napoletana (tomato) sauce.

The Treehouse (14 Baker Street, Aberystwyth; 01970 615 791) is well placed to concoct vegetable-based pasta dishes: this organic food store and restaurant has a market garden nearby. Right now, its green and yellow courgettes are mere babies which come with or without the flower at no extra cost, if you feel like frying them à l'italienne .

But what of the pasta itself? There is some disagreement even among pasta experts about how to make the best products. Much depends on the quality of the semolina, and some makers insist on using spring or filter water, too. Sandra Cavaciuti of Delicatessen (23 South End Road, London NW3; 020 7435 7315) makes her fresh pasta every day with eggs 'because it gives a nicer flavour' and says one of the most popular shapes locally is the classic paglia e fieno (straw and hay). But her husband, John Cavaciuti, who goes all over the country selling pasta-making machines to commercial producers, says his favourite dish is spaghetti vongole (clam sauce), for which dried pasta is essential, 'otherwise you just don't get the bite in the spaghetti'.

This only confirms my belief that, if you can't get to your local Italian deli for fresh pasta, then it's better to buy the superior dried varieties (Voiello or the more readily available De Cecco), because the so-called 'fresh' pasta sold pre-packaged by supermarkets tastes bland and soggy. I now know why: the extended shelf-life means pasteurisation is required, which amounts to pre-cooking the pasta. Then it is gelatinised on the outside to inhibit mould growth, and often packed in a container flushed with gas.

It's true that dried pasta takes longer to cook, but often you need that time to prepare the sauce. The De Cecco website has an amusing quiz for would-be master chefs, inviting them to test their pasta-cooking knowledge. It fails to supply any answers beyond your score, so in case you are left wondering what the fail-safe method of cooking pasta is, this is the consensus of all the Italians interviewed: Boil it in lots and lots of water ('You can't drown pasta'). Don't add the salt until the water is boiling, otherwise you lower the temperature at which the water boils. Don't just tip the pasta in and walk away - stir it for the first minute. Cook it for the time specified on the packet - not a minute more or less. Serve immediately with the sauce, and to hell with any guest who is late.

Phillip Britten, sometime Michelin-starred chef at The Capital, agrees with these methods. He runs an organic vegetable company, Solstice, from London's New Covent Garden Market (Units 51 and 52; 020 7498 7700). Most of his clientele are posh restaurants, but a visit to Solstice is fun for anyone who loves vegetables and doesn't mind getting up early. You can find juicy Italian peppers, pale aubergine and branches of bright-red cherry tomatoes. Make the £3 parking fee worthwhile by filling up with heaps of summer roses from the adjacent flower market.

fields.headline: Sea greens
fields.standfirst: Succulent, saline and tasting of the sea, marsh samphire is worth  trudging through mud and to the fishmonger for. By Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: Succulent, saline and tasting of the sea, marsh samphire is worth  trudging through mud and to the fishmonger for. By Sybil Kapoor
fields.body:
The temptation to forage in the green shade of the countryside can seem irresistible on a sultry July day. Wild raspberries can seem alluring, rustling in cool, dappled woods. Few, however, consider collecting the succulent green stems of marsh samphire, otherwise known as glasswort ( Salicornia europaea ), which grows on much of Britain's coastal mud flats. With your back bent low to snip the juicy saline shoots, sunk in tidal mud and with no respite from the sun, it is not for the faint-hearted. But resilient locals gather it, confident we will pay good money for such a delicacy.

It is easy to understand why samphire can cost up to £4.20 for 500g. Its lush, dark green, jointed stems taste of the sea - salty and fresh. Chefs buy it by the boxload, so they can serve it raw in chic summer salads or lightly blanched as a refreshing contrast to sweet-fleshed shellfish, fish and lamb.

Simon Newnes, a specialist fish wholesaler in Billingsgate Market in London, buys his direct from Norfolk during the English season, which starts mid-June, but pickers believe the best samphire is gathered after Midsummer's Day. 'We sell it until the end of August, when it starts to turn woody,' he says, 'then we revert to the French stuff until the end of September.' According to Newnes, the latter is plumper and larger than its British cousin, but tastes the same. 'You can also buy cultivated samphire from Saudi Arabia,' he adds. 'It usually appears from mid-January until March. The Saudis have irrigated sections of land and harvest it by machine, but it has a far stronger, saltier flavour and can be a bit limp, having travelled so far.'

Fishmongers are the traditional outlet for samphire, although you can find it in some health-food shops. Allow about 115g per person as an accompaniment. Once home, you will need to sort through it to remove any slimy or woody segments. It should be chilled and covered with a damp cloth until needed. Then, and only then, wash it thoroughly in cold water and, if you are serving it hot, drop it in a pan of boiling unsalted water for one minute. If you are using it cooked but cold, refresh it under the cold tap and dry it in kitchen paper. Then settle in a shady spot and contemplate nature while savouring the taste of the wild without any undue exertion.

 C J Newnes & Partners (Shop 10, Billingsgate Market, Trafalgar Way, London E14; 020 7515 0793) sells samphire alongside char, pike and sturgeon, as well as fresh anchovies and paku (South American piranhas). It is open from 5am to 8am.

fields.headline: Mover and shaker
fields.standfirst: Whether it's a Raspberry Martini or a Russian Spring Punch, Dick Bradsell is the man to mix it. Michael Jackson meets the bar supremo and introduces his specially commissioned Observer cocktail
fields.trailText: Whether it's a Raspberry Martini or a Russian Spring Punch, Dick Bradsell is the man to mix it. Michael Jackson meets the bar supremo and introduces his specially commissioned Observer cocktail.
fields.body:
'It's as important as good food.' That's cocktail king Dick Bradsell's view on 'decent drink'. After a moment's reflection, he decides the imperatives are not equal. 'If someone said I had to eat the same thing every day for the rest of my life, I could survive on organic brown rice. If I were limited to one choice of drink, I would hate it. What would I choose? Perhaps Campari and soda.' Another time, he thought he'd prefer mint juleps.

Even if your repertoire of summery drinks extends no further than gin and tonic, you can learn from Dick Bradsell. He may let slip an acid jest as sharp as a twist of lemon peel, but it is largely thanks to his influence that Britain now has a scattering of proper bars with well-made drinks.

As a shy boy in an 'inbred weirdo' corner of the Isle of Wight, with a 'mad professor' father, Bradsell was bullied for being a bookworm. 'I liked Harper Lee_ don't say anything about Tequila Mockingbird.' Now, he favours Charles Bukowski. The change began when he became a punk rocker. 'There was a party at which our house got trashed. I was sent away and put in the care of my Wicked Uncle, a former naval man, in London. He ran the Naval & Military Club in Piccadilly. He knew everybody: the police, the criminals, the ladies. The complete training he gave me would have been hard to find elsewhere. At the club they made pink gins. Where else could you still get pink gins in the mid-70s? I had to buckle down, learn to make Pimm's, martinis, gin and tonics_'

The gin and tonic is still the acid test for Bradsell. 'I can tell you if a person will ever make a bartender by watching them make a gin-and-tonic over and over again. Some people could try for three months and still not make a decent one.'

Not 'three cubes of ice' but a glassful. Not 'equal parts' but two shots of gin. Not 'a horrible, thin little piece of lemon' but a fresh, healthy slice; not inserted by 'digging about with a spoon, spilling half the drink', but popped in by hand. And always a fresh bottle of tonic.

Another boss drew diagrams to illustrate the interplay of flavours in a mixed drink. Bradsell does the same for me on a napkin. 'Classic cocktails are the starting point for most new recipes. The flavours of the principal elements must be in balance. Between them are gaps in flavour. These gaps must be filled. We are trying to create one long flavour on the palate. I want my customers to enjoy it so much they order another.' The diagram now looks like a geological section, but it is actually a Brandy Alexander. 'The Cognac is here, the cream there, the dark cacao, and the white... '

Such classics are more than a cover for the flavour of alcohol, but they were a visual disguise during Prohibition, and the notion of innocently pretty but potent drinks is surely the basis of their 'dangerous' glamour. They recall their heyday in grand hotels like New York's Waldorf and London's Savoy - where 'the line of knowledge' (to use one of Bradsell's favourite phrases) is continued today by Peter Dorelli.

Names such as Dorelli, Gilberto Preti (at Duke's Hotel) and Salvatore Calabrese (the Lanesborough) are a reminder that the British are traditionally uncomfortable with jobs that involve service. Bradsell reckons his unexotic Englishness helped him be noticed. A more important distinction is that he has never worked in a hotel. The base of his influence is the contemporary bar. He has worked in the best, and his trainees are everywhere.

In the late 70s, Bradsell worked at the Zanzibar, spending two years learning all the drinks on the list. This was the era of piña coladas, Blue Hawaiians, Scorpions. In some places the Scorpions did not bite, and the era of rip-off drinks has left Bradsell a campaigner for proper measures, good quality spirits and fresh juices, fruits and garnishes. 'I remember when there was no decent vodka or tequila, no fresh lemon or lime, no raspberries, no garden mint in any bar in London.'

As the mood has swung between glamour and grunge, Bradsell has ridden on every cocktail revival. At the Soho Brasserie, he created the Vodka Espresso. At the Groucho, media types favoured Moscow Mules. In what he dubs the era of Ecstasy and flavoured vodkas (notably Mars bar), he joyfully dispensed classic cocktails at Fred's. At the Atlantic, Dick's bar was noted for Raspberry Martinis and Russian Spring Punches.

People who once came to London to dance all weekend now come to tour cocktail bars instead. There is a bar culture. There are also new bar neighbourhoods. The latest seems set to be SoSho (South Shoreditch), where the new Match opens next Tuesday. The drinks are by Dick Bradsell... as are these two recipes.

The Observer Summer Cocktail

30ml Stoli Razbri

25ml cranberry juice

10ml Cointreau

10ml framboise liqueur

dash of lime cordial

juice of lime wedge

dash of orange bitters

lemon twist, to garnish

Shake all ingredients (except lemon twist) with ice. Strain into a pre-chilled cocktail glass. Spray lemon twist over drink and drop in.

The Bramble

50ml good gin

30ml fresh lemon juice

3 tsps sugar syrup

25ml crème de mre

slice of lemon and a blackberry, to garnish

Fill a whisky glass with crushed ice. Pour in the gin, lemon juice and sugar syrup, and stir. Add more crushed ice, then the crème de mre. Garnish with two straws, a slice of lemon and a blackberry.

fields.headline: Birthday boys
fields.standfirst: Men are starting to make their mark in the women's world of midwifery. Wendy Moore meets the new labourers
fields.trailText: Men are starting to make their mark in the women's world of midwifery. Wendy Moore meets the new labourers.
fields.body:
There is quite enough that is unexpected about expecting a baby - heartburn, piles and perpetual floods of tears come to mind - without any unnecessary extra surprises. So when the man in the antenatal clinic claimed he was my midwife, it was a shock too far.

True, John appeared outwardly every bit as competent and sympathetic as the next woman. But, without the same anatomical make-up, how could he possibly understand the vagaries of pregnancy, agonies of childbirth and mysteries of breast-feeding? Admittedly, I might have ended up with a male doctor supervising events in the delivery suite. But I had opted for a community midwifery team - to provide antenatal care, deliver my baby in hospital and look after me afterwards at home- precisely because I wanted to keep doctors - and, yes, men - out of my delivery as much as possible. What I wanted was the empathetic, low-key approach I suspected only another woman could provide.

Worried I might be oversensitive, I asked friends how they would react. Responses ranged from mild discomfort to downright outrage that - once again - men were muscling in on childbirth. But rejecting John would mean being delivered by a hospital midwife I had never even met. I decided to take a gamble: as he was one of six midwives on the team, I had a one in six chance - a kind of childbirth Russian roulette - of avoiding him.

In the event, John was not on duty when my daughter was born three years ago - but, by then, I wished he had been. Two days earlier, I had gone into hospital with what turned out to be 'false labour' - trial contractions before the real thing - and spent a lonely and painful night on the labour ward with barely a perfunctory check from a midwife. In the morning, when John appeared at the foot of my bed to check how I was, reassure me all was well and say I could go home, I was so relieved to see a friendly and familiar face I could have hugged him. It struck me then that knowing and trusting a midwife might be more important than their gender, and I genuinely regretted he had not been on hand when Susannah was born.

Most pregnant women never face the same dilemma, since male midwives are still very much in a minority. Only 94 out of more than 33,000 midwives currently practising in the UK are male. Men first entered the profession in 1983, after a long legal battle and in the face of fierce opposition from female midwives and women generally. Seventeen years later, they have confounded their critics. Male midwives have not only been accepted by the vast majority of pregnant women but - in some cases - are now being positively preferred and actively recommended by women to their friends.

John - Willie John Dolan - is a typical example. After only four years as a midwife (he qualified in 1996), he has a firm following in the Shepherd's Bush area of London, where he works. Renowned for his non-interventionist, natural approach to childbirth, he is heavily in demand. Women who have had first babies delivered by him request him for the next time and pass his name on to their pregnant friends. 'His reputation goes before him,' says student midwife Joan Foy, who specifically asked to train alongside him.

Dolan, 31, knew he wanted to become a midwife when he was 16. He was inspired by his midwife aunt. But being brought up on a farm in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, it was not the simplest career choice. He moved to London to train as a nurse, spent six years on the wards, then began the 18-month course to become a midwife. 'Midwifery was always what I wanted to do,' he says.

Although based at Queen Charlotte's Hospital, west London, he works on a community one-to-one scheme - one of only two in the UK - which aims to allow women to be cared for by the same midwife throughout pregnancy. The midwives work in pairs - covering for each other when off duty - yet Dolan still delivers around 90 per cent of the women on his caseload by being available on days off. He boasts one of the highest home-birth rates in the area - 11 out of 30 deliveries since November, while the national rate is 2 per cent - and strives to keep Caesarean sections and other medical interventions to a minimum.

'Women are very vulnerable in labour,' Dolan says. 'It is the most painful time in one's life and you need someone you can trust. The idea is to have a positive attitude and keep things as positive as possible.'

Initially, he was rejected by women who felt uncomfortable with the idea of a man delivering their baby, some on religious grounds. Dolan still allows his patients up to 20 weeks to opt out. But since his reputation has grown, few do. After seven months, when he sees patients every two weeks, a strong relationship has usually built up, he says. 'The woman gets to trust you, and you get to know what she wants.'

Lucy Boyd's third baby, Mia, was delivered at home by Dolan just two weeks ago with her family - her mother Rose Gray owns The River Cafe - downstairs. Boyd, 34, herself a cook, chose Dolan after he delivered her second daughter, Alex, now 14 months. She had no qualms about a male midwife. 'The main thing is that you are able to trust the person looking after you,' she says. Her labour was so quick that when Dolan arrived at her house on his Friday night off, she did not want to leave for hospital. 'Willie John was absolutely fantastic,' she says. 'He made me feel secure and reassured that everything was fine.'

Melanie Yudolph, 36, whose second baby is due imminently, requested Dolan as her midwife on the recommendation of a friend. She had her first child by elective Caesarean because she was so afraid of a natural delivery, but this time hopes for a natural birth despite her fears. She has no apprehensions about Dolan: 'I just know he knows more about it than I do.'

Her friend Louise Hart recommended Dolan after he delivered her second baby, Remy, last October. The birth of her first child, Ethan, now nearly six, had been so traumatic she waited five years before getting pregnant again. This time, although labour took 15 hours, the birth was 'absolutely brilliant', says Hart, 37, who works for a record company.

Dolan supported Louise's wish to avoid a Caesarean and kept epidural doses to a minimum. 'The great thing for me was he really stood up to these male and female doctors. He was not bolshie or aggressive, he just stood his ground.'

Being male is irrelevant to his approach, Dolan believes. Anyone going into midwifery needs a particular personality, he argues, whether they are male or female. 'Childbirth is one of the most natural things women do, and you need to support that. You are the woman's advocate,' he says. He is certainly not motivated by money, since top pay for clinical midwives runs to £24,000. 'Job satisfaction is more important than pay for me,' he says.

Money was a major obstacle for James Tudge when he gave up his job as a lorry driver 11 years ago to become a midwife. He was inspired by the birth of his own son, Daniel. 'It was just seeing my son born. It was very emotional,' he recalls. But embarking on nurse training followed by a midwifery course meant bringing home in a month the same pay he earned driving lorries in a week. Still, having now worked for four years at Bolton General Hospital, where his son was born, he has no regrets. Although some women do reject him, he encounters few problems. 'I have been told I am always very compassionate with women and usually spend more time with them than female midwives do,' says Tudge, 40.

Unlike in nursing, where men generally scale the management ladder faster than women, most male midwives have stayed in clinical practice. One exception is Paul Lewis, one of the first men ever to become a midwife and now professor of midwifery at Bournemouth University. As a nurse, he enrolled on the first experimental midwifery training scheme for men in 1979 at the Whittington Hospital, London, largely because he wanted obstetrics experience to work abroad. Once qualified, he was unable to practice until 1983, when the Government lifted the legal barriers, and then took his first job at King's College Hospital, London.

He, too, believes a midwife's gender is unimportant. 'If they are good midwives they are good midwives whether they are men or not,' he says. But as a minority group, he believes men who become midwives often try harder not to take over or cause offence.

They appear to have been so successful that they have not only won over many pregnant women but also transformed erstwhile enemies into firm friends. Independent midwife Caroline Flint was totally opposed to men in midwifery when the idea was first mooted in the 70s. 'We'd had such problems with male obstetricians taking over that I had suspicions male midwives would be the same,' she says. 'But they are not, they are not at all.' She describes Lewis as 'visionary' while all male midwives she has met have been 'lovely, gentle' men.

Beverly Beech, who chairs the lobby group the Association for Improvements in Maternity Services (AIMS), was another vehement opponent. Now she says: 'I have yet to meet a male midwife who has not been absolutely super.'

Misgivings remain. Some pregnant women are still diffident when they encounter male midwives, according to the president of the National Childbirth Trust, Gillian Fletcher, who teaches antenatal classes in an area where a male midwife practises. Some remain totally opposed to the idea, while others decide that gender is unimportant, she says. Women should always be able to opt out if they are uncomfortable with a midwife, she stresses. But she adds: 'At the end of the day, it is not so much about what gender they are but how they treat people.'

Delivering babies was an exclusively female experience - men were taboo in the birthing room - until the first 'man-midwives' emerged in the 16th century. They were the forerunners of today's obstetricians, who generally still control childbirth. In 1952, the Midwives Act prohibited men from midwifery, but in the 70s, male nurses fought for the right to become midwives.

This was fiercely opposed by the Royal College of Midwives, as well as by women's groups. When the 1976 Sex Discrimination Act was passed, midwifery was made exempt, but the government later sanctioned two experimental training schemes - one in England in 1977 and the second in Scotland in 1978. A study of the schemes concluded that male midwives were acceptable to women - although this finding was disputed. In 1983, the government lifted the legal barriers on men practising as midwives. Initially it was thought they would need chaperones, but this never became normal practice. According to the UK Central Council, 161 men have trained as midwives, but only 94 currently practice out of more than 33,000 practising midwives.

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ...tennis player
fields.trailText: ...tennis player
fields.body:
For volleys I'd have to go for Stefan Edburg or myself... because we're the best! He's just a great athlete and very hard to get past around the net. His volleying, and serving for that matter, is just fantastic. For serving, though, I'd pick a left-hander like Ivanisevich. Technically, his action is just about perfect, he's the best. He's tall, with good reach - height makes a lot of difference. He's also got that left-handed angle, which is very unusual - a left-hand serve gives you extra difficulty because it's not something you're used to. For forehand, I'd probably have to say Andre Agassi, maybe even Agassi for backhand as well... although Becker and Sampras have great backhands, too. But Agassi just has fantastic ground strokes, the best of all time. He's got a great eye, hits the ball very hard and he's quick on his feet.

Conners and McEnroe have the best mental attitude - they're tough, really tough, good fighters. They are both relentless competitors, who make it very, very hard for you. I definitely think there was an element to McEnroe's behaviour that was about deliberately unsettling his opponent. I don't know that for sure, but I'd say it was borderline cheating, and he did go too far sometimes. I'm good friends with John nowadays - we both do commentary for the BBC.

For pure speed, I'd go for Michael Chang. I think he's probably the quickest player there ever was. But you need a combination of speed, agility and height. The most powerful player is probably Mark Philippoussis - but again, power's not much if you don't have something else with it. For overall athleticism, Yannick Noah is fantastic, and then there's Bjorn Borg, who had such endurance - he's just so fast.

I think Wimbledon was very open this year. But if I'd had to put my money on someone, it would have been Sampras.

fields.headline: Go buy...
fields.standfirst: ... the impossible image
fields.trailText: ... the impossible image
fields.body:
The camera always lies. Especially when the camera happens to be in the hands of a 21st-century fashion photographer. The new breed of modish snappers, including the British agent provocateur Nick Knight, and the Dutch artist Inez van Lamsweerde, use digital technology as a creative tool. Their work is celebrated in The Impossible Image , published this week by Phaidon (priced £24.95). The cover alone is intriguing - a jigsaw puzzle dreamt up by Knight, featuring the profiles of the six most flavourful models of the season, Erin, Gisele, Karen, Maggie, Kate and Alec, hidden between a technicolour explosion of flowers.

With an introduction by Robin Derrick, the art director of British Vogue , this is an indispensable aid for getting up to speed on the hottest names in fashion photography. They're all here, from Vincent Peters - who makes his model pose for hours to look as though she has just fallen out of her partner's arms, or as though he has just caught her in the middle of a riot - to van Lamsweerde, whose pictures take on a hyperreal quality with their pin-sharp focus and graphic lines. And all are, of course, helped by the gentle tickling of the digital paintbrush. With the help of digital technology, anything is possible. This is not just about retouching a few wrinkles or the odd stray hair. This is a world where flames spurt from a girl's nether regions (perhaps the British photographer Phil Poynter got a bit carried away with all his new boys' toys).

But it is Knight's work that makes The Impossible Image something worth buying rather than flicking through at the bookshop. His dreamy 'Sister Honey' sequence of sweetie-coloured erotic images blurring into one another like an oil painting is in stark contrast to his 'War' series, which is gratuitous in its violence and energy, but, like all the best fantasies, makes use of nothing more gory than a few litres of red gloss paint.

 Robin Derrick and Phil Poynter will be talking about digital fashion photography at the Photographer's Gallery, 5 and 8 Great Newport Street, London WC2 (020 7831 1772) on 12 July at 7pm

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ...a swimming pool
fields.trailText: ...a swimming pool
fields.body:
Public swimming pools are a form of ritual humiliation for many people. Their first experience of a pool may have been swimming lessons at the local sports centre, which are invariably places where the water is throat-searingly over-chlorinated and the strip lighting is unforgivingly bright.

It is these people whot fantasise about having their own swimming pool; a pool that doesn't offer a range of fungal infections as souvenirs. A reasonably basic pool will cost about £20,000 in total. It will be outdoors, rectangular (about 15ft by 30ft), tiled, and heated. Any other outline, such as a kidney shape, will be 10 per cent extra, although precise costs vary according to supplier. However, the best construction method is to have a seamless gunite shell installed, rather than building the pool block by block.

You will be spending about £1,000 on the three-horsepower pump and filter, and another £1,000 on the gas boiler, while the excavation of your lawn will cost £2,000 of the total. Australians rave about solar-heated pools, but with an average of 270 sunny days a year, they would.

The only sensible way to combat the British climate is to have the pool built indoors. As a rough guide, indoor pools cost about as much as a house, and the expense of maintaining it will be about the same as that of maintaining a car. The minimum you should expect to pay is about £130,000 and any extras will add to the price: a diving board is a further couple of thousand, and a jacuzzi at least another £10,000.

For the full rap-video effect, real gold mosaic tiles are essential (£1,500 per sq m), but the ultimate status symbol is a 50m-long Olympic-sized infinity edge pool (the pool is filled to deck level).

To avoid your new purchase turning into a bacterial broth, you will need to keep it clean and chlorinated. A dedicated pool cleaner will make weekly visits for £2,500 per year, or you could do it yourself, with about £300 worth of chlorine, acid and testing kits.

Excavation £2,000
Pump and filter £1,000
Boiler £1,000
Indoor pool from £130,000
Jacuzzi £10,000
Diving board £2,000
Gold mosaic tiles £1,500 per sq m
Cleaner £2,500 per year
Total from £20,000

webTitle: Plot, plot, plot that's worth the weight

fields.headline: Plot, plot, plot that's worth the weight
fields.standfirst:
The kids love it. But what about The Observer's Literary Editor?

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: I confess that my first thought, when I picked up  HP IV (as  Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is known), was that this was not a book to be put down lightly but, as Dorothy Parker once put it, to be hurled with some force to the corner of the room.
fields.body:
I confess that my first thought, when I picked up HP IV (as Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is known), was that this was not a book to be put down lightly but, as Dorothy Parker once put it, to be hurled with some force to the corner of the room.

It is HUGE: 636 pages, to be precise. Think of the reported 5 million-copies first printing here and in America, and spare a thought for those trees. At 10 words to the line and 35 lines to the page, Harry Potter fans are looking at a novel of some 222,600 words. If that sort of length would not disgrace a Booker Prize contender, it does not look like a book for children either, and its awkward size will swiftly exclude it from several hundred thousand pockets and satchels.

It invites weighing as well as reading. Here, strangely, it is bulky but light. Puffed and promoted in a frenzy of international publicity, the inflated physical appearance of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Bloomsbury £14.99) represents the marriage of hype and expectation. The public wanted something big. The publishers wanted something commercial. J.K. Rowling, who has already triumphantly demonstrated that no one ever went broke spinning a series of unputdownable yarns, has supplied just that. HP IV is a commercial blockbuster with knobs on.

But I agree with the judges of this year's Carnegie Medal who have just awarded the coveted children's book prize to Aidan Chambers's novel Postcards from No Man's Land. Rowling's fourth in a projected series of seven Harry Potter adventures may introduce a breathless hush to the nation's evening hours, but it is not to be spoken of in the same breath as previous Carnegie winners Arthur Ransome or C.S. Lewis, although it owes a freely acknowledged debt to both.

Having said that, this is storytelling of a high order indeed. It draws the reader in with a riddle and a letter. It proceeds through a series of trials to a great confrontation. And it concludes with a death and a climactic resolution. E.M. Forster famously observed that, 'Yes - oh dear, yes - the novel tells a story'. HP IV is the apotheosis of 'story'.

The novel opens with Harry menaced by his old arch-enemy Lord Voldemort in a terrifying dream. Harry knows this is a dream he must take seriously because that scar on his forehead is giving him terrible pain once more. So he contacts his mysterious godfather Sirius Black... Meanwhile, his friends the Weasleys have taken Harry and their son Ron (his best friend) to watch the Quidditch World Cup Final between Ireland and Bulgaria, whose crack team features that star Seeker Viktor Krum.

This entertaining setpiece turns out to be merely the curtain-raiser to Harry's return to another term at Hogwarts, the school for wizards that's been at the centre of all previous instalments. Now we discover that there's to be a Triwizard Tournament between Hogwarts and its rivals Durmstrang and Beauxbatons. When dark references to previous tournaments establish that this is a contest in which the participants can lose their lives, we realise that the stakes are getting dangerously high.

Harry Potter! But who has manipulated the Goblet of Fire to choose the under-age Harry? Who indeed? The finger of suspicion points at the evil forces surrounding terrible Lord Voldemort.

Naturally, young Harry emerges from the Triwizard Tournament almost unscathed. Almost, but not quite. Mini muggles say: It's wicked
The young fans' verdict:

Anna Berrill, 13
The thing about Harry Potter's magical world is that the minute you start to read, you can imagine yourself being there. They're just like real life, but with wizardy bits added on. Harry's first three adventures have been so exciting that I couldn't imagine how The Goblet of Fire could match up to them. It starts off in a village called Little Hangleton and I couldn't see how it followed on from the previous stories. But suddenly there is Voldemort up to his old tricks with the dark arts. From then on you're back with all those characters you really like reading about because you care what happens to them.

The summer holidays are dragging on a bit for Harry in the ordinary old muggle world until his best friend Ron Weasley invites him to the Quidditch world cup. Quidditch is one of the best things about the Harry books. It's a game I'd really like to have a go at - I wish we played it at my school, because it sounds a lot more fun than muggle hockey.

I've got two favourite characters, Fred and George. They are very funny and get into some good scrapes. They remind me a lot of my friends, not that my friends are wizards - at least, I don't think they are.

Sam Sweeney, 11
I feel privileged to be one of the first to dive into this wicked adventure! Millions and millions of kids are desperate to get their hands it. I think this novel is very descriptive and really tense and spooky. This book is very chunky for young readers. It costs £14.99 so you Harry Potter fans better start saving. If you were spooked by the last three books, this one is meant to be more scary. J.K. Rowling has a brill way of luring you into the story. If you have read the others, don't worry; you don't get bored when she's explaining about Harry's life so far. The good descriptions can turn a flat character three-dimensional. She writes about Harry watching his mean uncle's face: 'He watched the purple recede blotchily from Uncle Vernon's face, making it look like badly mixed blackcurrant ice-cream.' And so far, the plot is superb.

Sian Pearson, 11
The most surprising thing about the new Harry Potter is how BIG it is - with 636 pages it is the longest book I have read. The size of it didn't put me off reading it though. After the first couple of pages the magical world of Harry, Hermione, Ron and friends comes zooming back to you as you remember all the adventures they have had in the previous books. Harry meets many exciting and strange characters and Fred and George Weasley are, as usual, getting up to all sorts of mischief. The amazing, funny and sometimes scary plot keeps you hooked and your fingers will itch to keep turning the pages. This book is just as brilliant and gripping as the other Harry Potter books and I am still unable to choose a favourite. I hope J.K. Rowling will carry on writing, and I know I will read every one of them.

At 10 words to the line and 35 lines to the page, Harry Potter fans are looking at a novel of some 222,600 words.
