webTitle: Detroit: where the wheels came off...

fields.headline: Detroit: where the wheels came off...
fields.standfirst: It was Motor Town - the engine room of America. Then the car industry stalled and riots, racial tension and the flight of whites to the suburbs reduced Detroit to ruins. But, as Geoff Dyer discovers, hope can come from the unlikeliest source...
fields.trailText: It was Motor Town - the engine room of America. Then the car industry stalled and riots, racial tension and the flight of whites to the suburbs reduced Detroit to ruins. But, as Geoff Dyer discovers, hope can come from the unlikeliest source...
fields.body:
In the Detroit Institute of Art there is a painting by Frederick Edwin Church called Syria by the Sea (1873). Ruined columns of antiquity are bathed in the elegiac light of the declining sun. A helpful caption explains that the painting depicts 'a civilisation in ruins, succumbing to the forces of nature. The crumbling buildings, overgrown with vegetation, symbolise nature's power over humanity and its structures.'

If the picture was acquired with some Dorian Gray-ish motive in mind - the ruination of the painted city guaranteeing the Motor City's eternal prosperity - it was a bad investment; it has turned out, instead, to offer an allegory of Detroit's decline and fall. The nature and extent of that decline are well known: riots in 1967; white flight to the suburbs; collapse of the automobile industry; unemployment; crack; gangs; murder; violence_ As the spokesman for a former mayor puts it in Devil's Night , Ze'ev Chafets' excellent book about the city: 'This is the place where the wheels came off the wagon of Western civilisation.'

Human and social costs aside, the devastation has left an architecture of abandoned and burnt-out buildings whose derelict beauty recalls the ruins of antiquity. Most obviously at the Michigan Central Railroad Station, near where the old Tigers stadium used to be (directions in Detroit have their own special tense: everything is where something used to be ). It was built in 1913, a huge neo-classical edifice, 15 or 16 storeys high, a terminus whose function has since been terminated. Now it stands surrounded by its own silence. The entrance is framed by Corinthian columns. Every window is broken, suggesting, somehow, that all the building's remaining energy - and it still has a lot - is spent surveying its own abandonment.

I arrived there to find a couple of people taking photographs. Having parked in front of the station, I walked over to talk to ask what had drawn them here.

'Imagine what this was like during World War Two,' said the man. 'The amount of men and equipment coming through here. The scale of the operation. The people, the cars and trucks pulling up. The trains_'

I tried to imagine all this commotion, but could not. Ruins do not encourage the viewer to dwell on what they were like in their heyday. The Colosseum in Rome or the amphitheatre at Leptis Magna have never been anything but ruins. They are eternal ruins. And it's the same here. This building could never have looked more magnificent than it did now. Rather than make you think of the past, ruins direct you towards the future. The effect is almost prophetic. This is what the future will end up like. This is what the future has always ended up looking like.

The station was framed and - because of the broken windows - penetrated by the sky: a specific Midwestern sky, a prairie sky, a sky at ease with hugeness. All around the building was a litter-strewn acreage of parking lots and railroad tracks. A rusted sign creaked in the wind, as old signs should. At its base, a thicket of tough grass had taken hold. In almost every crack in the concrete there was a sprouting of grey-green grass: the prairie making a slow comeback. Eventually, perhaps, the entire city will return to the prairie.

I asked the photographers if they knew the work of Camilo José Vergara. No, they did not. This surprised me. I'd assumed they were on the Vergara trail. Like me. He was the reason - one of two reasons - I was here in Detroit.

Vergara has spent years photographing the ruins of American cities. Detroit, naturally, looms huge in his work. And so, just as people are lured to Greece by a few shots of a beach, so I came here to see his photographs in the flesh (in the stone), to look at the places he'd looked at.

My itinerary was determined, largely, by the route mapped out by his pictures. Buildings like the Book-Cadillac Hotel and the Statler Hilton took on the landmark importance of the Empire State or the Statue of Liberty for a first-time visitor to New York. In one particular spot in downtown Detroit, you can see half a dozen architecturally outstanding buildings in various stages of dilapidation: Kales, United Artists, Fine Arts, Park Avenue, the Statler Hilton, the Wurlitzer, the David Broderick Tower_

Monday-Friday the area is sparsely populated. On a typical weekend, you could be the last person on the planet. The best views, though, are from the People Mover, a driver-less elevated train that takes a 15-minute loop through the heart of downtown. One moment you're gliding past immaculate, new, sky-reflecting office blocks, the next you're passing within a few feet of the Ionic columns and weather-squatted interior of the abandoned Statler Hilton. It's like Belgrade and Manhattan rolled into one.

Vergara would like to preserve parts of the ruined downtown 'as an American Acropolis - that is, to allow the present skyscraper graveyard to become a park of ripe ruins'. As he himself concedes, however, this plan is 'seen by most as at best misguided and at worst a cruel joke'. This lends an urgency to the task of preserving them on film. Several of the places photographed by Vergara have already been demolished, making way for new projects more appropriate to the city's future-oriented mood.

Tyree Guyton's 'guerrilla' art - which radically transformed buildings in Heidelberg Street in the 90s, embellishing them with baroque flourishes and surreal accretions of discarded junk - has been stamped out by the city. Less alarming than demolition per se is the swiftness of the amnesia that settles in its wake. It is as if people's memories are housed in the buildings that surround them. Demolish the building and you destroy the memory of its ever having existed.

Following Vergara's visual itinerary, I visited Brush Park, an area of derelict Victorian mansions which, in the late-19th century, was the wealthiest part of the city. A few days later I passed by again, in a taxi, on the way to the DIA. In response to a question, the driver indicated 'the ghetto' off to the right.

'Brush Park,' I said. He didn't know what I was talking about. He'd never heard it called that. To him it was just the ghetto. Whatever it was called, I had been there. I would like to have walked but, unsure about how safe it was, I visited American-style, in the car, with the doors locked and the windows sealed.

It's located off Woodward Avenue, a few blocks north of the new Tigers stadium. Houses and the burnt-out, plundered remains of houses are so thin on the ground that the area has an airy, rural quality. Vegetation has clambered up many of the walls - exactly as painted by Church - camouflaging them. Parked on the grass, a zebra-striped van added to the impression of a slum safari park. A few vagrants stood around fires. Smoke drifted. An old man sat in a doorway reading the paper with the concentration of a scholar deciphering hieroglyphics. It was a peaceful scene.

Feeling conspicuous as an investment banker, I locked my car and walked over to the corner store - George's Market - which, incredibly, was still functioning. Half an hour earlier I had stopped off at the old Ford plant at Highland Park, home of the Model T. By 1925, a plaque explained, 9,000 Model Ts were being made in a single day, 'setting the pattern of abundance for 20th-century living'. Now, in the 21st century, I was sitting on the curb in the Brush Park ghetto, strawing Coke from a bottle, feeling quite content.

People came by, pushing shopping trolleys as if the world were an enormously depleted supermarket in which there was nothing left to buy. I looked at the guy straining hard over his newspaper, at another toasting his hands over a fire (it wasn't a cold day but, after a certain point of dereliction, you never miss a chance to get warm) and thought that I wouldn't at all mind ending up like either of them.

Buildings do not just fall into ruin; something in them aspires to ruination. It's the same with people. All we can do is keep applying the creosote, propping ourselves up with health and success, trying to keep the rot at bay for a little longer, trying to postpone the moment of complete collapse and abandonment for the same reason that one waits as long as possible for the first alcoholic drink of the day: because the longer you leave it, the better it will feel.

In the vacant aftermath of this thought, a young mother came by with her two kids, lovely in their freshly laundered clothes, and I was struck by the power of an equal and opposite urge: to improve, to make your life better, to pick yourself up off the floor, to get on your feet. We smiled, said 'Hi' and I stood up.

There were a number of places photographed by Vergara that I couldn't find. One of them was the Packard Automobile Plant where, he writes, 'illegal parties known as "raves" are held... Techno, which originated in Detroit, is the music of choice.'

That's the second reason I was here.

Not only did techno originate in Detroit, it's also been the city's most important musical export since Motown. The innovators - Kevin Saunderson, Derrick May and Juan Atkins - are all from the area, and the city's industrial past and desolate present audibly animate their music. In 1988 Atkins explained that 'Berry Gordy built the Motown sound on the same principles as the conveyor belt system at Ford's. Today their plants don't work that way - they use robots and computers to make the cars. I'm probably more interested in Ford's robots than Berry Gordy's music.' If people are put off by exactly this inhuman, robotic quality, for Atkins the fact that Detroit was 'such a desolate place' meant that he saw techno as an alternative reality, 'like as dreaming'. I liked the aboriginal suggestion of that phrase, its hint that the music somehow accessed the urban songlines of the place, the hidden geography of the city.

Detroit may have provided the soundtrack but it was only when the music was exported that it became part of the larger social phenomenon of dance culture. This year, though, it was decided to bring it all back home in the form of the free three-day Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

It was quite a gamble. For a start, dance music has become indelibly associated with drugs and Detroit is a city that has suffered from drugs every bit as much as London has benefited from them. And the venue for this festival was not some abandoned industrial wasteland but the riverside Hart Plaza, overlooked by plush expense-account hotels and spanking new corporate developments, such as the Renaissance Center (headquarters of General Motors, 74 storeys high, topped off with a revolving restaurant).

Part of the reason for using this civic amenity was to attract Detroiters who had either never been exposed to their local brand of post-industrial folk music or who'd been put off by the druggy warehouse scene. But would they come?

They did. By close of the first day's play, 300,000 people had turned up. According to the festival's creative director Carl Craig, 750,000 were there for the festival's climax on Memorial Day, among them the mother and her two kids I had seen amid the ruins of Brush Park a few days earlier. In other ways, too, the success of the festival extended way beyond the epic schedule of 36 hours of music and dance. Something else was happening here, too. Seventy per cent of the artists performing - including May and Saunderson - were from the Detroit area. It was a site-specific triumph and, as the festival developed, people began to get a palpable sense that they were not simply witnessing but were part of a turning point in the history of their city.

Techno - which was pioneered by black men - emerged from the ruins of a city nearly destroyed by racial tension. In some respects the city after the riots was like a miniature urban version of a post-colonial nation in Africa. An affluent white city turned into a poor black one almost overnight; the whites left, the blacks had to sort things out.

In Devil's Night , Chafets quotes a police spokesman as saying that 'Detroit was the first city to get a lot of these problems, and it's going to be the first city to find solutions to them.' The festival celebrated one aspect of this ongoing search. No one would claim that a three-day feast of electronic music was going to solve all the city's problems, but, equally, no one who was there could deny the capacity of music and dance to bring people together. That has become a commercially exploitable cliché in London and elsewhere, but here it was felt as a self-evident truth. After the final set by localish hero Richie Hawtin, Carl Craig made a brief speech that was intermittently drowned out by the crowd chanting 'Detroit! Detroit!' Substitute 'San Francisco' and it sounds - how shall I put it? - implausible , but this, remember, is a city that has been on its knees for almost a third of a century. Now it was getting back on its feet. Also, crucially, the festival had been organised with the co-operation of the city council. The DEMF cannot bring about economic resurrection, but it heralds a possible future of regeneration and liberation.

This was made explicit on Saturday night when Stacey Pullen sampled Martin Luther King's 'I have a dream' speech, culminating with the famous declaration 'Free at last! Free at last! Thank God almighty we are free at last.' We associate this address - which has since been rapaciously sampled by DJs - with the march on Washington in 1963, but King actually delivered a version of the speech in Detroit two months earlier. With this historic resonance in mind, it would be difficult to exaggerate its relevance to - or the rapture with which it was received in - Detroit this time around.

King's speech was the climactic moment of the 1963 March on Washington; DEMF, the new context for King's oratory, takes its cue from an event like Love Parade in Berlin which, in the words of German writer Ulf Poschardt, 'drops the demanding, critical character of the demonstration and simply demonstrates itself. What you see is what we want.' Like Love Parade, the DEMF 'doesn't promise anything - unusual in political discourse - but it demonstrates, in the true sense of the word: it presents, it shows.' It shows an alternative to the vision of ruination depicted by Church and Vergara. It shows a way out, a way up, a way ahead.

Following Vergara's visual itinerary, I visited Brush Park, an area of derelict Victorian mansions which, in the late-19th century, was the wealthiest part of the city. A few days later I passed by again, in a taxi, on the way to the DIA. In response to a question, the driver indicated 'the ghetto' off to the right. 'Brush Park,' I said. He didn't know what I was talking about. He'd never heard it called that. To him it was just the ghetto. Whatever it was called, I had been there. I would like to have walked but, unsure about how safe it was, I visited American-style, in the car, with the doors locked and the windows sealed. It's located off Woodward Avenue, a few blocks north of the new Tigers stadium. Houses and the burnt-out, plundered remains of houses are so thin on the ground that the area has an airy, rural quality. Vegetation has clambered up many of the walls - exactly as painted by Church - camouflaging them. Parked on the grass, a zebra-striped van added to the impression of a slum safari park. A few vagrants stood around fires. Smoke drifted. An old man sat in a doorway reading the paper with the concentration of a scholar deciphering hieroglyphics. It was a peaceful scene. Feeling conspicuous as an investment banker, I locked my car and walked over to the corner store - George's Market - which, incredibly, was still functioning. Half an hour earlier I had stopped off at the old Ford plant at Highland Park, home of the Model T. By 1925, a plaque explained, 9,000 Model Ts were being made in a single day, 'setting the pattern of abundance for 20th-century living'. Now, in the 21st century, I was sitting on the curb in the Brush Park ghetto, strawing Coke from a bottle, feeling quite content. People came by, pushing shopping trolleys as if the world were an enormously depleted supermarket in which there was nothing left to buy. I looked at the guy straining hard over his newspaper, at another toasting his hands over a fire (it wasn't a cold day but, after a certain point of dereliction, you never miss a chance to get warm) and thought that I wouldn't at all mind ending up like either of them. Buildings do not just fall into ruin; something in them aspires to ruination. It's the same with people. All we can do is keep applying the creosote, propping ourselves up with health and success, trying to keep the rot at bay for a little longer, trying to postpone the moment of complete collapse and abandonment for the same reason that one waits as long as possible for the first alcoholic drink of the day: because the longer you leave it, the better it will feel. In the vacant aftermath of this thought, a young mother came by with her two kids, lovely in their freshly laundered clothes, and I was struck by the power of an equal and opposite urge: to improve, to make your life better, to pick yourself up off the floor, to get on your feet. We smiled, said 'Hi' and I stood up. There were a number of places photographed by Vergara that I couldn't find. One of them was the Packard Automobile Plant where, he writes, 'illegal parties known as "raves" are held... Techno, which originated in Detroit, is the music of choice.' That's the second reason I was here. Not only did techno originate in Detroit, it's also been the city's most important musical export since Motown. The innovators - Kevin Saunderson, Derrick May and Juan Atkins - are all from the area, and the city's industrial past and desolate present audibly animate their music. In 1988 Atkins explained that 'Berry Gordy built the Motown sound on the same principles as the conveyor belt system at Ford's. Today their plants don't work that way - they use robots and computers to make the cars. I'm probably more interested in Ford's robots than Berry Gordy's music.' If people are put off by exactly this inhuman, robotic quality, for Atkins the fact that Detroit was 'such a desolate place' meant that he saw techno as an alternative reality, 'like as dreaming'. I liked the aboriginal suggestion of that phrase, its hint that the music somehow accessed the urban songlines of the place, the hidden geography of the city. Detroit may have provided the soundtrack but it was only when the music was exported that it became part of the larger social phenomenon of dance culture. This year, though, it was decided to bring it all back home in the form of the free three-day Detroit Electronic Music Festival. It was quite a gamble. For a start, dance music has become indelibly associated with drugs and Detroit is a city that has suffered from drugs every bit as much as London has benefited from them. And the venue for this festival was not some abandoned industrial wasteland but the riverside Hart Plaza, overlooked by plush expense-account hotels and spanking new corporate developments, such as the Renaissance Center (headquarters of General Motors, 74 storeys high, topped off with a revolving restaurant). Part of the reason for using this civic amenity was to attract Detroiters who had either never been exposed to their local brand of post-industrial folk music or who'd been put off by the druggy warehouse scene. But would they come? They did. By close of the first day's play, 300,000 people had turned up. According to the festival's creative director Carl Craig, 750,000 were there for the festival's climax on Memorial Day, among them the mother and her two kids I had seen amid the ruins of Brush Park a few days earlier. In other ways, too, the success of the festival extended way beyond the epic schedule of 36 hours of music and dance. Something else was happening here, too. Seventy per cent of the artists performing - including May and Saunderson - were from the Detroit area. It was a site-specific triumph and, as the festival developed, people began to get a palpable sense that they were not simply witnessing but were part of a turning point in the history of their city. Techno - which was pioneered by black men - emerged from the ruins of a city nearly destroyed by racial tension. In some respects the city after the riots was like a miniature urban version of a post-colonial nation in Africa. An affluent white city turned into a poor black one almost overnight; the whites left, the blacks had to sort things out. In Devil's Night , Chafets quotes a police spokesman as saying that 'Detroit was the first city to get a lot of these problems, and it's going to be the first city to find solutions to them.' The festival celebrated one aspect of this ongoing search. No one would claim that a three-day feast of electronic music was going to solve all the city's problems, but, equally, no one who was there could deny the capacity of music and dance to bring people together. That has become a commercially exploitable cliché in London and elsewhere, but here it was felt as a self-evident truth. After the final set by localish hero Richie Hawtin, Carl Craig made a brief speech that was intermittently drowned out by the crowd chanting 'Detroit! Detroit!' Substitute 'San Francisco' and it sounds - how shall I put it? - implausible , but this, remember, is a city that has been on its knees for almost a third of a century. Now it was getting back on its feet. Also, crucially, the festival had been organised with the co-operation of the city council. The DEMF cannot bring about economic resurrection, but it heralds a possible future of regeneration and liberation. This was made explicit on Saturday night when Stacey Pullen sampled Martin Luther King's 'I have a dream' speech, culminating with the famous declaration 'Free at last! Free at last! Thank God almighty we are free at last.' We associate this address - which has since been rapaciously sampled by DJs - with the march on Washington in 1963, but King actually delivered a version of the speech in Detroit two months earlier. With this historic resonance in mind, it would be difficult to exaggerate its relevance to - or the rapture with which it was received in - Detroit this time around. King's speech was the climactic moment of the 1963 March on Washington; DEMF, the new context for King's oratory, takes its cue from an event like Love Parade in Berlin which, in the words of German writer Ulf Poschardt, 'drops the demanding, critical character of the demonstration and simply demonstrates itself. What you see is what we want.' Like Love Parade, the DEMF 'doesn't promise anything - unusual in political discourse - but it demonstrates, in the true sense of the word: it presents, it shows.' It shows an alternative to the vision of ruination depicted by Church and Vergara. It shows a way out, a way up, a way ahead.

webTitle: Fast forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: Fast forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: This week: The proms
fields.trailText: This week: The proms
fields.body:
What's that all about, then? The BBC Promenade Concerts were founded in 1895 by conductor Henry Wood to present classical music to the public in an informal atmosphere. This year, the Proms kicks off on 14 July and works its way through some 72 concerts - symphonies, concertos, operas, chamber music, etc - before the glorious finale of Last Night of the Proms, on 9 September, which as everyone knows is the night that matters most, when the audience gets to sing Land of Hope and Glory and Jerusalem and generally feel good and patriotic about themselves. The organisers would be advised not to include the music of Frank Zappa, Bob Marley and The Beatles, as they did in 1995, though - traditional Promenaders jammed the BBC switchboard with complaints.

Tickets from all the usual outlets? Not for the Last Night, no. Owing to huge demand, there is a fairly complex ticket system based on rewarding loyal punters who forked out for a minimum of six other concerts during the Proms season. If all else fails, you could hang out for a standing ticket near the front, but your chances are slim.

A case of first come first served? Absolutely. There is a long tradition of 'Prommers' sleeping out overnight to get the best standing places, as well as cheeky punters turning up five minutes before the start, just on the off-chance. But if you don't want to wait, head for Hyde Park. The BBC 's Proms in the Park allows you a taste of the action in the open air; you can munch on picnics while huge video screens broadcast pictures of tearful patriots wrapped in Union Jacks belting out Rule Britannia . And if you don't fancy travelling down to London, there will be Proms in parks in Birmingham and Liverpool as well. Word of warning, though: the compere is Terry Wogan.

And if it rains? You either get wet, or plan ahead by forking out for the BBC's 'hospitality facility'. For a mere £369 + VAT, you not only get a three-course meal, champagne and complimentary bar, but as you make your way to your private toilets, you can show off your luxury souvenir programme and Proms gift bag. However, this year's festivities will also include the first 'virtual proms', which means that anyone with a computer can watch the whole thing on the net.

webTitle: Bank let someone else take my cash

fields.headline: Bank let someone else take my cash
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I opened an account with Barclays in my name for my five-year-old niece. About a year ago, when there should have been £2,000 in the account, I tried to withdraw £1,500, but the bank said there was only £1,000. It transpired that another customer had withdrawn £1,000 from the account six months earlier. After much hassle, the bank rectified the fault, apologised and gave me £20. Imagine my horror when last month I discovered a further £1,550 was missing from the account, taken by the same customer. Barclays has offered £25 this time, but I think this is an insult.
DB, Liverpool

 Your experience reveals that some bank customers have the same account number but different sort codes. Barclays says there is a limit to the numbers available and, when an account is closed, some time later the number is reused. The numbers are generated by computer, which sometimes throws up a number still being used.

Barclays monitored your account daily for six months after you first complained, but the second mistake happened after that. The bank is giving you a new account number, and I think the compensation is reasonable.

Credit blunders: Trouble in stores

Four years ago, I was refused a store card as a credit risk. I obtained my credit reference agency file from Equifax, and it said the problem was that I had lived at my address for less than two years. In fact I had been there for eight: I sent proof, and got my card.

Now I have been refused a Debenhams store card. I do not want to go through this rigmarole again. Is there somewhere central that can clear my credit rating once and for all?
RK, Cranleigh

 There is one other credit reference agency, Experian. GE Capital Bank, which runs the Debenhams card, uses Experian, so this agency may also have the wrong information, perhaps because of an electoral roll error by your local authority. The agencies do not update each other's files, except when you ask for your credit history to be dissociated from someone else's.

Phone GE Capital's helpline on 0870 1242475; ask them to reassess your application, pointing out the error. You may have been rejected on credit scoring grounds, so emphasise your good record.

Meanwhile, check your Experian file (send £2 to Consumer Help Service, PO Box 8000, Nottingham NG1 5GX). Equifax is sending a free copy of your current file.

Teacher pension: Part-time help?

During some of my career as a teacher, I worked part-time. Can I claw back those years when I was not allowed to contribute to a pension?
RP, Newcastle upon Tyne

 The European Court of Justice ruled last May that those who worked part-time between 1976 and 1995, when part-timers gained legal access to employers' pensions schemes, can now backdate their membership. But you must claim within six months of leaving a job. The National Union of Teachers hopes to get the period extended when the issue goes t0 the House of Lords, starting in a few weeks' time. Contact your union for help with your case and advice on whether to lodge a claim now to be dealt with later.

Crash payout: Pain from Spain

In May 1998, while on holiday in Spain, someone drove into the back of our car, damaging the lights and the bumper. The police were there when it happened, the driver admitted it was her fault and we exchanged insurance details. We sent an accident form to our insurance company, Frizzell.

We have had repeated contact with the company, which did warn us that it might take two years for the Spanish firm to pay out. In June 1999, the Spanish finally agreed to pay out 111,000 pesetas (£235), and we agreed to settle. As we have a non-resident Spanish bank account, we thought the easiest way was for them to pay it into this. However, they said they had problems doing this, so we agreed to accept a cheque, but we still have not had any payment.
LM, Brighton

 Frizzell says it has been chasing the Spanish insurer every month, even though it has no obligation to retrieve the money for you. The problem is that you did not tell Frizzell you were taking your car abroad, so your cover was reduced to third party only.

Had Frizzell known beforehand, you would have paid extra to extend your UK policy for driving abroad and Frizzell would have paid your claim direct, as you were the innocent victim. Each insurer makes its own rules about driving abroad: not all require advance notice; some make no extra charge. Some provide a green card; others do not, as there is no legal need for one. The only safe way is to check with your insurer before travelling and note the name of the person you speak to.

Frizzell, which is owned by Liverpool Victoria Friendly Society, now accepts that its frequent chasing costs more than the amount you are claiming, so will pay the full amount itself straight away.

Isa cash hold-up: Low Fidelity?

On 7 April, I took out a Fidelity monthly income Isa. The first income I received was on 28 May. I asked why I had not received money sooner, and was told that the investment was not made before the first of the month and that I would not get any payment for that month. Nowhere in the firm's brochure does it say anything of the sort. Is there anything I can do?
AP, Lanhydrock

 Fidelity is writing to reassure you that you have not missed a payment by investing part-way through the month and to explain how the distribution is calculated. Payments for this Isa are calculated on the last day of the month. This is the money you received on 28 May, unlike bank interest which is credited on the due day. The next payment, at the end of June, should be for the full month to 30 May. This will be £36.42, against the first payment of £33.10.

Tax relief comes about three months later after an Inland Revenue refund.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: June winners share £1,000
fields.standfirst: Investor of the year
fields.trailText: Investor of the year
fields.body:
We have now calculated the winners for June in our Investor of the Year 2000 competition, sponsored by Fleming Asset Management and run in conjunction with our sister publication, Money Observer .

The ideal result in full was Tate & Lyle (number 27 on your original coupon) +31.74 per cent; WPP Group (30) +18.7 per cent; Reuters Group (23) +13.15 per cent; Granada Group (15) +11.4 per cent; and Invensys (17) +7.83 per cent.

This made an average gain of 16.54 per cent, with 17 shares in total managing to register a gain during the month.

No one managed to select that ideal combination, but two people picked the top four and 10th best-performing shares to produce an average gain of 16.068 per cent; that 10th best-performer was EMI Group, with a gain of 5.45 per cent.

Both winners had to be separated by their tie-breaker predictions. Thus it is Mrs MP Kenny from Leicester who scoops the top prize with a tie-breaker of 15 shares, to record a gain in June. She wins a cheque for £500.

Second place goes to Susan Chaddell from Ellon in Aberdeenshire, with a tie-breaker of 9. A cheque for £200 is winging its way to her.

Our third-prize winner for June is Mrs S Moore from Cambridge, who selected the top three, fifth and ninth best-performing shares to produce an average gain of 15.416 per cent. She wins £100 in premium bonds.

Fourth prize goes to Mr ML Passey from Leeds, who picked the top three, sixth and ninth best-performers to make an average gain of 15.408 per cent. He also scoops £100 of premium bonds.

Our fifth-prize winner, Robert Oldfield from Harlech in Gwynedd, wins the final £100 worth of premium bonds on offer in June. He picked the top two, fourth, sixth and 10th best shares to produce an average gain of 14.996 per cent.

Details of the shares' July performances will appear in Cash on 6 August, with winners announced the following Sunday.

fields.headline: Friendly banks (no, honestly)
fields.standfirst: When the going gets tough, these guys get... nice, reports  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: When the going gets tough, these guys get... nice, reports Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
It seems bankers have decided to become nice. After years of being the most unpopular people on the high street, they are pushing up interest rates on current accounts, slashing overdraft charges, deciding not to levy surcharges if you use another bank's cashpoint, letting their own staff call the shots and voluntarily chopping their mortgage rates. At this rate, it is just a matter of time before they are doing the shopping for old ladies and throwing picnics for socially excluded children... or perhaps not.

These remarkable developments are not altruism. 'There are far too many banks chasing far too little business,' says Phil Middleton, banking strategy head at consultant KPMG. 'The world is changing quite horribly for them. In future they will have to offer a much more personalised service.'

Now that we can all compare their rates at the click of a mouse, banks can very quickly lose business if they offer uncompetitive products. 'The biggest driver is the internet,' says John Hitchins, of PricewaterhouseCoopers.

In the past, a giant such as Halifax needed only to open its doors to attract business. But that mighty organisation is preparing to launch some of the keenest rates available, to maintain market share, when it unveils its internet arm, Intelligent Finance (IF), on Friday. IF is to offer an extremely competitive 5 per cent on its current account. Among its many fine deals is a flexible service, netting off loans against savings and paying or extracting interest on the balance. Since, as a rule, loan rates are pegged above savings rates, IF is doing itself out of profits by this move.

Halifax has been forced into this by the very attractive deals offered by the other internet banks: Egg, Abbey National's Cahoot and the Woolwich's Open Plan. Patrick Bunton of London & Country Mortgages thinks there will be rush to copy IF - to make products far more friendly and flexible.

One reason for the increased competition this year is that last year financial institutions had to concentrate their IT resources on the Millennium Bug and are now making up for commercially unproductive time. Until now, few had the resources to set savings against their loan accounts. They might have run those products through different computer systems.

Several factors are squeezing the banks - new players, from Egg to Virgin, can now cherry-pick the most attractive (that is wealthiest) customers and leave the poorer customers to the traditional banks.

Supermarkets also pose a threat. They don't cherry-pick, but they do have a cheap distribution mechanism - the checkout - which can attract huge numbers of customers. Tesco already has 1.5 million customers for its accounts. Last week, it became the first supermarket to announce banking at its checkouts. Customers will be able to pay into their accounts as they settle up for their groceries.

UK banks are under pressure to offer free banking - pressure reinforced by the Government when it urged them to drop plans to charge for cashpoint withdrawals at rival banks. Most banks have now decided not to charge.

But banks will have to find money somewhere. Middleton believes they will continue to close unprofitable branches. Banks are experi menting with management techniques. Abbey National is even piloting a scheme to let local managers work under franchise, setting their own terms with customers and - if they succeed - dramatically increasing their own pay. Middleton says that even the shape and location of banks will change. 'You could even have banks operating in the workplace - with a bank manager ready to come to advise you at your desk.

'Branches will be far more like retail stores. Those in shopping malls could start running crèches. When mothers have done their shopping, they might come back to the branch, have a coffee and talk about their pension.'

After years of being the most unpopular people on the high street, they are pushing up interest rates on current accounts, slashing overdraft charges, deciding not to levy surcharges if you use another bank's cashpoint, letting their own staff call the shots and voluntarily chopping their mortgage rates. At this rate, it is just a matter of time before they are doing the shopping for old ladies and throwing picnics for socially excluded children... or perhaps not. These remarkable developments are not altruism. 'There are far too many banks chasing far too little business,' says Phil Middleton, banking strategy head at consultant KPMG. 'The world is changing quite horribly for them. In future they will have to offer a much more personalised service.' Now that we can all compare their rates at the click of a mouse, banks can very quickly lose business if they offer uncompetitive products. 'The biggest driver is the internet,' says John Hitchins, of PricewaterhouseCoopers. In the past, a giant such as Halifax needed only to open its doors to attract business. But that mighty organisation is preparing to launch some of the keenest rates available, to maintain market share, when it unveils its internet arm, Intelligent Finance (IF), on Friday. IF is to offer an extremely competitive 5 per cent on its current account. Among its many fine deals is a flexible service, netting off loans against savings and paying or extracting interest on the balance. Since, as a rule, loan rates are pegged above savings rates, IF is doing itself out of profits by this move. Halifax has been forced into this by the very attractive deals offered by the other internet banks: Egg, Abbey National's Cahoot and the Woolwich's Open Plan. Patrick Bunton of London & Country Mortgages thinks there will be rush to copy IF - to make products far more friendly and flexible. One reason for the increased competition this year is that last year financial institutions had to concentrate their IT resources on the Millennium Bug and are now making up for commercially unproductive time. Until now, few had the resources to set savings against their loan accounts. They might have run those products through different computer systems. Several factors are squeezing the banks - new players, from Egg to Virgin, can now cherry-pick the most attractive (that is wealthiest) customers and leave the poorer customers to the traditional banks. Supermarkets also pose a threat. They don't cherry-pick, but they do have a cheap distribution mechanism - the checkout - which can attract huge numbers of customers. Tesco already has 1.5 million customers for its accounts. Last week, it became the first supermarket to announce banking at its checkouts. Customers will be able to pay into their accounts as they settle up for their groceries. UK banks are under pressure to offer free banking - pressure reinforced by the Government when it urged them to drop plans to charge for cashpoint withdrawals at rival banks. Most banks have now decided not to charge. But banks will have to find money somewhere. Middleton believes they will continue to close unprofitable branches. Banks are experi menting with management techniques. Abbey National is even piloting a scheme to let local managers work under franchise, setting their own terms with customers and - if they succeed - dramatically increasing their own pay. Middleton says that even the shape and location of banks will change. 'You could even have banks operating in the workplace - with a bank manager ready to come to advise you at your desk. 'Branches will be far more like retail stores. Those in shopping malls could start running crèches. When mothers have done their shopping, they might come back to the branch, have a coffee and talk about their pension.'

fields.headline: Building chateaux in the air
fields.standfirst: Low French prices can be deceptive, warns  Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: Low French prices can be deceptive, warns Alexander Garrett.
fields.body:
The woes of the euro have created an unexpected bonus for people in the UK: the opportunity to buy property on the Continent at knockdown prices. Sterling's strength has enabled Britons to snap up homes on a scale not seen since the boom of the late Eighties.

For most buyers, the automatic first stop is France. While pretty village houses in England increasingly command a king's ransom, their equivalent in France seem to be in limitless supply at a fraction of the cost. But while the prices may be seductive, don't expect to make a killing.

Property in most parts of France has always been a poor capital investment. As Dick Schrader, publisher of French Property News explains: 'There simply aren't the wild swings in property prices you see in the UK. There is a much more relaxed policy in terms of building. That means land prices are much lower.'

Hard data on the French housing market is elusive. But there is a general consensus that, with the exception of one or two areas, prices tend to move at about the same rate as inflation. When you consider that the costs of purchasing - including notary's fees and stamp duty - typically add 7 per cent to the purchase price, and that estate agent's fees on selling average at 5 per cent, it is easy to see that the value needs to go up by at least 12 per cent before you will break even.

Moreover, before you can sell, you need a buyer - which is by no means guaranteed. For all that the Brits, the Dutch and the Irish are now vying to buy up rural France, there is an awful lot of it, and if you're in a neglected area, your property may be overlooked.

David King, a London-based agent who specialises in the upper end of the French market, says there is a risk in depending on another overseas buyer want ing your property, since demand can be fickle. 'Buy where the French buy and you should be fairly safe,' he suggests. Few French would think of buying in Normandy unless they had family connections there.

By the same token, the way you decorate your property can restrict the market when you come to sell. 'French people are looking for something that is still French, not an Englishman's castle abroad,' says Schrader.

Don't overspend on improving your property. Stick to the basics such as the electrics and a roof over your head, says King. If you ship in Carrara marble or renovate to London standards, you risk losing out.

The two areas of France where property prices tend to be most volatile are Paris and the Cte d'Azur. In Paris, prices fell by 40 per cent in the early Nineties. The capital is now coming back strongly, with typical yields on residential property about 5 per cent, with the prospect of capital gains on top.

The most up-and-coming areas from a UK buyer's point of view are those the low-cost no-frill airlines fly to, such as the South West. Ryanair flies to Carcassonne and Biarritz; Buzz has a Bordeaux service; and Easyjet will take you to Nice. Prices in Gascony have risen by about 20 per cent in three years.

However, as long as the French remain uninterested in property prices, you are unlikely to make a fortune by splashing out on a gte or a chteau. And while many of the best places may already be taken, the supply of holiday homes in France is unlikely to dry up.

fields.headline: Friends, removals and countrymen
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of her French diary,  Natalie Sutton  gets by with a lot of help from 'les amis' in the village
fields.trailText: In the latest instalment of her French diary, Natalie Sutton gets by with a lot of help from 'les amis' in the village.
fields.body:
Our latest trip down to the South of France was an exercise in making friends and influencing people.

Faced with the dilemma of what to do with bits of furniture that don't fit into our London home, an obvious move seemed to be to transport them to France where we have no furniture at all.

I contacted a British firm that specialises in transporting antiques from France back to the UK. Rather than go down to France empty, the firm delivers furniture at a reduced cost to various places on the way. I carefully explained to the man at British HQ that the route to our hamlet included tiny, winding mountain roads, ending with 7km of pot-holed dirt track. He chuckled: they were used to far worse, and I should 'expect the lads' at 10am on Tuesday.

The cargo was duly collected by a small van. We took the train across the Channel, looking forward to the arrival of a table and some chairs. Ten o'clock on Tuesday morning came. We hung around, amused that such an exact arrival time had been predicted and not surprised when it came and went without the appearance of the removal van. An hour later, Marius the hunter roared up in his jeep saying that the mayor had called him (we have no telephone), rather annoyed that a very large English lorry was parked across the main square in the village.

So much for good first impressions. He drove me back to the village, and I cringed when I saw a truck the size of a barn sprawled across the entire square.

The truck driver was happy to follow Marius out of the village again along little dirt tracks, through various sheep-filled fields in the direction of the hamlet.

A moment later he hit a dip in the road and came to a grinding halt. Marius disappeared in a cloud of dust ahead and I was left with a beached juggernaut, two embarrassed removal men and a field full of sheep. The back wheels spun hopelessly in the waterlogged dip.

After an hour or so of poking ineffectively at the back of the lorry with a stick and a penknife (they had no jack, no tools), I headed off to get help. I arrived red-faced, sweaty and panting at Chez Francine, the auberge where most of the villagers were having lunch.

I was handed a glass of water, made to sit down and, once I had introduced myself and explained my predicament, everybody put down their knives and forks and gathered together vehicles, chains, various tools and copious amounts of advice to come and help. Two jeeps, including our rusty old Land Cruiser, were hooked up to the lorry and managed to drag it out.

The truck driver decided not to venture any further off road, so my tatty, self assembled furniture was handed out for people to store until we find a way of transporting it the last few kilometres.

We were invited to a party in the Mairie and given endless advice by our new-found friends as to how we should restore the hamlet. It has all the creature comforts - but it's the lack of human ones that I'm worried about. Extensive work needs to be done, and organising everything while based in London has proved difficult.

The electrician we met on our last visit took two months to deliver a quote, and said that as there was no sign of any of the promised electric cables and telegraph poles going up near our property, there was little point in him wiring up the house. We begged him to start the work regardless. The mayor has forgiven us for the removal lorry fiasco, and it seems that he will fight our corner on the electricity issue.

Every problem we voiced to the villagers was met with 'I've got a friend who's in that business. I'll give him a call.' We were put in touch with local plumbers and masons, who looked over the hamlet tutting with sharp intakes of breath. Back in England, waiting for their quotes, we take equally sharp intakes of breath and give the go-ahead for work in the hope that one day it will actually be done.

On one of our last days, no fewer than 10 people, including the mayor, dropped in for a drink, a few olives and a chat. Although the locals regard us as 'les rosbifs fous', we found it much harder to leave this time. Although that could have had something to do with the Land Cruiser's clutch cable making a bid for freedom and leaving us stranded in the middle of nowhere.

It was fine though, because we've got a friend in the local village who's got a friend who can fix it.

webTitle: The way we live now:  Ibiza covered

fields.headline: The way we live now:  Ibiza covered
fields.standfirst: How Manumission cleaned up
fields.trailText: How Manumission cleaned up
fields.body:
If holiday hotspot Ibiza is one big soap opera - and TV docu-soaps like Ibiza Uncovered suggest it is - then its notorious Manumission club is the leading lady. Since 1993 the club has pulled in 8,000 clubbers a week to Privilege, the island's biggest venue, with a saucy mix of gay imagery, club theatre, party games and, since 1996, a live sex show performed at dawn by the swimming pool in the middle of the club. Two couples are in charge, brothers Andy (balding, sensible) and Mike (shaved-head, bearded, wild) and their respective girlfriends Dawn and Claire, and all use Manumission as a surname. Their success has meant that keeping up with the Manumissions is a game every club on the island is forced to play. Andy and Dawn do the boring stuff; Mike and Claire the shagging - although sometimes Mike did generously allow another woman (or two) with a strap-on dildo to take over.

Clubbers often found themselves performing party tricks - sitting on a toilet on the dancefloor reading a paper, maybe. Visitors lucky, or unlucky, enough to get into Mike and Claire's party hangout - a former brothel renamed the Manumission Motel - could find themselves sucked in and spat out weeks later. The DJ Derek Dahlarge came for a weekend and stayed all summer. Music journalists sent to cover Manumission ended up running around in costume - a knight in shining armour, say, or an abbot. Radio 1 bravely staged a fraught live broadcast from the club and famously lost DJ Lisa I'Anson into the chaos. She failed to turn up for her show the next morning and was publicly disciplined.

As the rest of clubland has slowly embraced a kind of reluctant respectability - sponsorship deals, dress codes, 'brand identities' - Manumission alone seemed untouchable. 'Some of the things we did made us virtually unsponsorable,' says Andy. 'That was cool.' But that was then.

The people who run clubland are getting older and the age gap between DJs and teenage clubbers gets bigger every year (two of Radio 1's 'dance team', DJs Pete Tong and Danny Rampling, are pushing 40). The talk at dance-industry get-togethers this year is more about mortgages and children than sex and drugs. For Ibiza's wildest, respectability is knocking on the door in the shape of the Orange mobile-phone network. Even the sex show has gone, replaced by an energetic display by performers from the De La Guarda aerobatic dance spectacular.

Alongside the Motel and beachside boozer Bar M, Manumission has opened a fancy dress shop. (Hiring a club-supplied Lawrence of Arabia outfit does seem to miss the point - institutionalised raving for the kind of people who say, 'I'm mad, me.')

On the day before the club opens its summer 2000 season, the Manumissions sit around a table on the sundeck of their new Pulp Fiction -style diner, in the portside of Ibiza's old town, making polite chitchat with the Men From Orange. This is a press launch to announce the sponsorship deal. The notorious sex show is in the past - it finished last year, having run its natural course, everyone says. Handily, Claire is eight months pregnant, which gives them a good excuse (and no, they say, baby Stan was not conceived on stage). 'They were doing it for hype,' says a pragmatic Man From Orange of the sex show later. 'They don't need to do it any more.'

There are two Men From Orange on the Manumission table, gung ho and yet clearly worried about the marathon night planned for them: the club's 8am finish, followed by an after-party at another club, Space, that goes on well into the next day. 'Sleep deprivation is really good fun,' Mike Manumission tells them. They look worried. Peter Raymond, Orange's pallid sponsorship consultant, pales next to the Manumissions's funky beachwear and tans. 'It'll be like going back to primary school,' Mike tells him. 'Is that right_' Peter mutters, unconvinced. It's like one of those bizarre Christmas conversations when staid relative and feisty teenager are tipsy enough to get on for a few seconds.

But the deal makes sense. Everyone in the mobile-phone business has been taken by surprise by the explosion in text messaging (SMS), especially among the young, who find it cheap, discreet, flirtatious. The youth market, for whom mobiles are a social tool, is crucial. Manumission has an agenda too. It was the first club on the island to employ flyer-people -PRs - to carpet-bomb clubbers with flyers, but now everyone is at it, the island is buried in paper, and within two years, Manumission reckons, the practice will become illegal. 'We need to find a new way to promote activities in a way the authorities are happy with,' says Andy. Delivering text messages or email to thousands of clubbers on the beach is it, he believes. This must have sounded like (dance) music to Orange's ears.

At the opening party that night, there are male and female strippers from New York, but they keep their thongs on. The only Orange presence is a few logos flashing up on the big screens - plus an information phone line that Mike and Claire voice.

So respectability has arrived for Manumission. Andy talks in terms of 'brand values'. It had to happen; clubbing is big business, and there always was something dreadfully suburban about that sex show anyway. Especially in Ibiza, which has a long history of hedonism; when one of the island's grandees, Pepe, opened the first club in the 60s, he called it Playboy. 'Because it stood for pornography and corrrrrruption!' he tells me. Manumission has a company motto: its name means 'freedom from slavery'.

So does the man from Orange believe in freedom from slavery? Peter Raymond's answer is a masterpiece of corporate spin. 'I wouldn't go so far as to say we believe in freedom from slavery. We certainly believe in freedom - that's what the wire-free future is all about.'

fields.headline: The intelligent consumer
fields.standfirst: What to eat for lunch to stop you feeling drowsy in the afternoon, how to get off to sleep better at night, and do you really need a proper breakfast? The answers to these questions and more can be found in our two-part serialisation of Life columnist Jane Clarke's new Bodyfoods Cookbook. This week, she whips up delicious energising treats for breakfast and lunch, as well as suggesting what to eat when you're feeling down or suffering from swinging energy levels. Here, she explains how her love for food and cooking became her life
fields.trailText: What to eat for lunch to stop you feeling drowsy in the afternoon, how to get off to sleep better at night, and do you really need a proper breakfast? The answers to these questions and more can be found in our two-part serialisation of Life columnist Jane Clarke's new Bodyfoods Cookbook. This week, she whips up delicious energising treats for breakfast and lunch, as well as suggesting what to eat when you're feeling down or suffering from swinging energy levels. Here, she explains how her love for food and cooking became her life.
fields.body:
When I was little, we used to go and stay with my great-auntie May and her husband Tom and I was struck by how much they enjoyed food. Breakfast toast was cooked on the fire in winter, and there would always be napkins, but not in a pretentious way. My mother was a good cook, too, but Auntie May gave me my burning desire to make food an enjoyable and loving thing. We always ate together as a family, and even if there's just the two of you, it's good to take even 10 minutes to eat together, rather than grabbing something from the fridge and eating it in front of the TV.

One of the very first things I remember making was cheesecake at primary school - the gelatine went all into strands. But I was always in the kitchen with Mum, and I'd just cook instinctively, make things up. Even then I cared about food - laying a tray, not just plonking fruit and cheese on a board but adding grapes and walnuts - because that's what Auntie May used to do. The way food looks is very important - when I first went into private practice, I used to keep recipe books in my rooms to stimulate patients. I still don't really use them myself, although I love Claudia Roden - it's all so simple and her love of food shines through in her writing.

As a teenager, I was interested in studying medicine, but I wanted to use food instead of drugs. I see a lot of people with cancer, some of whom have tried every other avenue and think I can make everything all right, but I can't. My mission is to encourage you to make the connection between what you put into your stomach and the way in which your life unfolds as a result. Having previously written two books - Bodyfoods for Women and Bodyfoods for Life - I thought it was time to explore eating habits more widely, to see how simple dishes and the way we put them together can help us tune into what our body needs. I hope that the following extracts from my new Bodyfoods Cookbook will inspire you to adopt delicious and nutritious eating habits that are both easy and achievable. I've kept things simple because you shouldn't have to hunt hard to find ingredients - you can hopefully find the ingredients to make everything from simple snacks to more exotic dinner party 'hits' in your local supermarket or delicatessen. The ingredients contained in every recipe have been included with the sole purpose of combining flavour with health-giving properties, but each recipe also features a 'magic ingredient', an ingredient that has a specific health-giving quality.

Breakfast-time boosts

Despite the saying 'Breakfast like a king, lunch like a knave and dine like a pauper', there is no hard-and-fast rule about when, or how much, you should eat. Instead, it's a question of understanding how your body responds to food and how you can maximise your wellbeing through eating. Breakfast provides an invaluable opportunity to enable you to do the latter. A bowl of fresh fruit salad eaten shortly after getting up, for example, will provide a slow release of energy to help you to get through the morning, as well as a good dose of vitamins and minerals. Scrambled eggs on toast, on the other hand, supply a dose of protein that goes towards building up your muscles, which is particularly necessary if you expend a lot of physical energy throughout the day.

Everyone responds differently to food in the morning: some people feel sleepy and unable to function after eating a large breakfast, whereas others need a hearty breakfast before they embark upon the day's activities. Although there is a lot of confusion about the necessity of having breakfast as a result of these differing reactions, it is important to consider the scientific evidence. It has been proven that the body performs and feels better if you eat something (however little) between waking up and having lunch. Because you have had to rely on your body's nutrient reserves to keep you going overnight, the morning is the best time to start topping them up again. Scientific studies have furthermore shown that children who either skip breakfast or eat very little at the start of the day are at a disadvantage when compared with those who eat a healthy breakfast. This is because the brains of children who have empty stomachs tend to receive less than the ideal level of blood sugar. Although this doesn't mean that they're likely to keel over at any moment, certain parts of their memories may not work as well as they should, which may cause problems at school. Children who've breakfasted properly generally have better reaction times and are also more proficient at such problem-solving exercises as mental arithmetic (this is most apparent in children with lower IQs).

A well-nourished brain can improve adults' ability to recall information, too, because it has received sufficient fuel (that is, sugar) to enable it to perform effectively. Before you start reaching for a sugar lump, however, you should understand that the sugar = brain-fuel formula is not that simple. For example, if you eat a sugar lump or gulp down a can of sweetened 'sports drink' first thing in the morning when you have an empty stomach, your blood-sugar level will shoot up, consequently stimulating your body to secrete a large amount of insulin (the hormone that transfers sugar from the blood to the body's cells). This insulin reaction will in turn cause your blood-sugar level to plummet, thus leaving your brain with very little sugar to work with.

Instead, the best way in which to deliver sugar to your brain is to package it within a high-fibre, carbohydrate-rich food, such as wholemeal bread, wholegrain cereal, oats or fresh fruit. The fibre in such foods helps to slow down the rate at which sugar is released into the blood and carried to the brain, thereby enabling you to remain focused.

The wide range of high-fibre, carbohydrate-rich foods offers you flexibility and choice at breakfast time. If time is short in the morning, how about a puréed fruit drink, such as a banana and pineapple smoothie? Smoothies (puréed fruit drinks) are ideal breakfasts, being both quick to make and containing energising properties. They are also a good way in which to give children a vitamin boost at the beginning of the day. Refreshing and revitalising drinks, they can be made with various combinations of fruits, such as oranges, grapefruits, apricots, peaches and other seasonal fruits, with or without added yogurt. Try adding a few baked fruits or a spoonful of puréed fruit to smoothies, as these give a slightly different texture. This breakfast can be eaten at home, as well as at the gym after a work-out, or after you've arrived at the office.

If your early mornings are not so rushed, relaxing over a wild-mushroom omelette with fresh herbs is a highly effective way in which to prepare yourself for some productive hours. However, pregnant women and people who have compromised immune systems should avoid eating undercooked and soft-boiled eggs. Although children under the age of eight or nine months can eat cooked egg yolks, egg whites are more challenging to a young gut, so you should wait until your children are a year old before feeding them eggs. Remember that breakfast doesn't have to be eaten at a set time each day, although you should try to have something within a couple of hours of getting up. Another good reason why you should eat a little something in the morning is because your digestive system performs much more efficiently if it is allowed to work on a small amount of food every few hours.

Long and short lunches

Lunches have changed over the past 50 years. Gone are the days when we stopped work for a couple of hours and went home to tuck into the substantial main meal of the day. By contrast, today it's more often a question of making a quick dash to the sandwich shop and then hastily consuming our purchase while working, or perhaps worse still, having a couple of mouthfuls of the children's left-overs, followed by a quick cup of coffee and a chocolate biscuit. For many of us, taking the time to have lunch seems like too much of an indulgence, one that we save for the weekend, when we can afford the time and can also cope better with the sleepy feelings that we frequently experience when our stomachs are full.

If we choose the foods that suit our bodies, lunch should provide the perfect opportunity to supply ourselves with nutritional, energising fuel. Yet many people don't like to take a food break in the middle of the day because they end up feeling far from energised, wanting instead to crawl into bed for a catnap. Because we lead demanding, highly stressed lives, we want and need to feel alert, not sleepy, during the afternoon.

What many of us don't realise, however, is that the type of food that we eat, as well as the manner in which we eat it, influences how we feel. For instance, pasta, bread and other starchy foods encourage the brain to produce sleep-inducing hormones. This happens because these foods need to be digested slowly, which means that the stomach and digestive system (which is, after all, a muscle) require oxygen to perform their duties efficiently. The brain therefore secretes hormones that encourage us to sleep in order to diminish both our desire and physiological ability to divert oxygen from our stomach to our limbs to enable us to rush around. If we ignore the effect of these hormones, however, and instead command our limbs to move energetically, oxygen is diverted from the stomach, which frequently leads to indigestion, stomach cramps and bloating.

In short, the brain's response to these starchy foods is one that is conditioned by physiological efficiency. If you have time to take a siesta after lunch, perhaps at the weekend, then by all means go ahead and make a dish like my pasta with courgettes and lemon or baby potatoes topped with guacamole and roasted peppers; eating these foods and then having a little snooze is the best way to allow your body to enjoy and digest them. If you don't have the time, however, choose a protein, fruit and vegetable-based lunch in which the proportion of vegetables, fruits and/or protein is high, such as my asparagus and lemon salad, a bowl of courgette and pea soup or a chunk of cheese with some figs, grapes and crisp, green celery. By opting for such foods, your body's hormonal response will encourage, not hinder, your desire to be energetic in the afternoon.

There is a further benefit of having a protein-rich lunch, too. Proteins are made up of amino acids, two of which, L-phenylalanine and tryptophan, encourage the body to produce endorphins (mood-enhancing hormones). Eating a protein-rich lunch, like my sea bass with crab, chicken Caesar salad or some lean charcuterie with cherry tomatoes, therefore not only helps to prevent the mood swings that may occur mid-afternoon, but also enables your body's blood-sugar levels to remain more constant (which means that you shouldn't experience 'sugar dips' at 4pm). If eating protein-rich foods doesn't appeal to you, having a fruit- or vegetable-based lunch, like a bowl of soup followed by some fruit, can similarly energise your body.

If you are organised and a little eclectic in your thinking, you can turn lunch into an interesting affair, rather than settling for the which-sandwich-bores-me-least? option. Practicality is usually a big issue, which is why sandwich bars may initially appear to be your only resort as a convenient source of lunch, but why not make a large cauldron of soup or a tray of grilled vegetables at home at the weekend to take to work in small plastic containers and then heat them up in the microwave at work (if your office has one)? Alternatively, if for reasons of practicality or preference, bread is your staple food for lunch, remember that you don't have to stick to the traditional sandwich made up of two slices of sliced bread with something in the middle.

Many different, mouth-watering types of breads are readily available today, such as ciabatta, focaccia or flat bread, which you can either make into wraps or warm up and eat with dips and crudités; muffins, too, can be topped or filled with lean, protein-rich foods and salads. In order to vary its texture and taste, you could also toast some bread to serve with a bowl of hearty soup, while an open focaccia sandwich like my focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham will show off its topping in a gloriously sensory-stimulating manner.

Turn lunch into a delightful, energising interlude in the middle of what would otherwise be a hectic, draining day. Half an hour or so is plenty of time in which to eat something nutritious and delicious, and taking a break will also allow you to step back from your busy routine for a while and refresh both your body and mind.

The brain therefore secretes hormones that encourage us to sleep in order to diminish both our desire and physiological ability to divert oxygen from our stomach to our limbs to enable us to rush around. If we ignore the effect of these hormones, however, and instead command our limbs to move energetically, oxygen is diverted from the stomach, which frequently leads to indigestion, stomach cramps and bloating. In short, the brain's response to these starchy foods is one that is conditioned by physiological efficiency. If you have time to take a siesta after lunch, perhaps at the weekend, then by all means go ahead and make a dish like my pasta with courgettes and lemon or baby potatoes topped with guacamole and roasted peppers; eating these foods and then having a little snooze is the best way to allow your body to enjoy and digest them. If you don't have the time, however, choose a protein, fruit and vegetable-based lunch in which the proportion of vegetables, fruits and/or protein is high, such as my asparagus and lemon salad, a bowl of courgette and pea soup or a chunk of cheese with some figs, grapes and crisp, green celery. By opting for such foods, your body's hormonal response will encourage, not hinder, your desire to be energetic in the afternoon. There is a further benefit of having a protein-rich lunch, too. Proteins are made up of amino acids, two of which, L-phenylalanine and tryptophan, encourage the body to produce endorphins (mood-enhancing hormones). Eating a protein-rich lunch, like my sea bass with crab, chicken Caesar salad or some lean charcuterie with cherry tomatoes, therefore not only helps to prevent the mood swings that may occur mid-afternoon, but also enables your body's blood-sugar levels to remain more constant (which means that you shouldn't experience 'sugar dips' at 4pm). If eating protein-rich foods doesn't appeal to you, having a fruit- or vegetable-based lunch, like a bowl of soup followed by some fruit, can similarly energise your body. If you are organised and a little eclectic in your thinking, you can turn lunch into an interesting affair, rather than settling for the which-sandwich-bores-me-least? option. Practicality is usually a big issue, which is why sandwich bars may initially appear to be your only resort as a convenient source of lunch, but why not make a large cauldron of soup or a tray of grilled vegetables at home at the weekend to take to work in small plastic containers and then heat them up in the microwave at work (if your office has one)? Alternatively, if for reasons of practicality or preference, bread is your staple food for lunch, remember that you don't have to stick to the traditional sandwich made up of two slices of sliced bread with something in the middle. Many different, mouth-watering types of breads are readily available today, such as ciabatta, focaccia or flat bread, which you can either make into wraps or warm up and eat with dips and crudités; muffins, too, can be topped or filled with lean, protein-rich foods and salads. In order to vary its texture and taste, you could also toast some bread to serve with a bowl of hearty soup, while an open focaccia sandwich like my focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham will show off its topping in a gloriously sensory-stimulating manner. Turn lunch into a delightful, energising interlude in the middle of what would otherwise be a hectic, draining day. Half an hour or so is plenty of time in which to eat something nutritious and delicious, and taking a break will also allow you to step back from your busy routine for a while and refresh both your body and mind.
