webTitle: Charlie Watts: ‘All the musicians I love look beautiful’

fields.headline: Charlie Watts: ‘All the musicians I love look beautiful’
fields.standfirst: Charlie Watts has always marched to a different drum than the rest of the Rolling Stones. He has been happily married for 36 years, he had a drug habit when the others had quit, and a pathological fear of screaming girls. Now he has returned to his other first love, the drummers of the bebop era
fields.trailText: Charlie Watts has always marched to a different drum than the rest of the Rolling Stones. He has been happily married for 36 years, he had a drug habit when the others had quit, and a pathological fear of screaming girls. Now he has returned to his other first love, the drummers of the bebop era.
fields.body:
You'd be hard pressed to find anybody with a bad word to say about Charlie Watts. He's a Rolling Stone, of course - and so, by definition, a legend - but there's more to it than that. After all, Mick Jagger is a Rolling Stone and people queue up to say bad things about him. Certainly, for a lot of drummers, Charlie Watts is the stick-wielding colossus by whom all others should be judged. I should know, I lived with a former drummer for years and had to sit through many a misty-eyed eulogy in the small hours. It was like a crash course in Charlie studies. Why Charlie was so talented. Why Charlie was such a class act. Why Charlie was so unassuming. Why Charlie was the undisputed God of backbeat. Hey, I wanted to scream (and sometimes did), screw Charlie, what about me?

The 'Charlie effect' seems to carry through to people who have only the most glancing interest in the Stones. We might have a grudging soft spot for the ludicrous Mr Jagger. We might warm to charming, riff-crunching Keith Richards and his craz-eee sidekick Ronnie Wood. Some might even mourn the departure of Bill Wyman, who resigned in 1993, or, more pertinently, the death of Brian Jones, who drowned in his swimming pool in 1969, mere days after the official announcement that the Stones had sacked him. Charlie's the one, though. Charlie's the Stone who is so universally well liked that he commands instant respect without even trying.

I remember the Manic Street Preachers once telling me how they'd bumped into Charlie Watts briefly at a recording studio, and what a 'gentleman' he'd seemed. To put this small compliment into perspective, it should be noted that the Manic Street Preachers is a band so hard to impress, if Elvis Presley rose from the dead and wanted to jam with them, they'd tell him to bring his own beer.

It all seems to boil down to a certain quality which is as rare as hen's teeth in the music business, but which Charlie Watts is perceived to have in abundance. In a word, decency. You've got to hand it to a 59-year-old man who's played with the world's most infamous rock'n'roll band for 38 years, and stayed happily married to his wife, Shirley, for 36 of them. A man who, moreover, remains resolutely determined not to take his elevated position too seriously. 'There's a lot more interesting people around than rock'n'roll bands,' Charlie Watts tells me in no uncertain terms, over a lazy pub lunch. 'There's this huge cult grown up around rock'n'roll, but I never saw it myself. I don't mean I never saw it going on, I mean I just didn't "get" it.'

And then, the drummer whose own rock'n'roll band inarguably rates among the most significant musical forces in global pan- cultural history, shifting literally hundreds of millions of records along the way, stares into his espresso, and ponders apparently without irony: 'What have we got to be so egotistical about?'

Charlie and I meet first at The Observer photographer's studio in a small street in Islington which my A-Z hasn't heard of. I have to bang on a couple of graffiti-strewn doors before I finally find it, and by then I'm 15 minutes late. This isn't good, I think, as I barge my way into the studio. Charlie Watts has always seemed so organised and precise. The other Stones might have spent the best part of their careers resembling dishevelled tarts in a rock-themed brothel, but not Charlie Watts. He could be the type to take offence at the late arrival of a journalist. I needn't have worried. 'I didn't even know you were late,' says Charlie, when we're introduced. And with that, he gives one of his mellow grins, and trudges back to his stool for more photographs.

Later, during the course of our conversation, Charlie Watts is to demonstrate again and again how important appearances are to him. Marvin Gaye: 'The coolest-looking man - the epitome of a black American.' Elvin Jones: 'Beautiful!' Duke Ellington: 'Stylish.' Kenny Clarke: 'Chic, like Fred Astaire.' Zoe Ball: 'She's really ugly, isn't she?' That last one, muttered as a casual aside during our drive to the pub-restaurant, was clearly an aberration for Charlie. He's definitely one for praising rather than denigrating, especially where his musical heroes are concerned. 'All the musicians I love look beautiful,' he says. 'The way a man looks as he plays, his style , is very important to me.'

Charlie himself makes a point of being nicely turned out. The day I meet him, his sharp blue suit speaks of timeless chic and East End betting shops. The eyes are gentle, the swept-back silver hair is thinning but hanging in there. Then there's those Slavic cheekbones, and the delicate, surprising body. All the Stones are renowned for being shorter than you'd expect, but Charlie's slightness makes him seem shorter still. Right now, though, his body is rather less noteworthy than his body language. Staring into the camera lens, Charlie manages to look both serene and agonised - like a small boy having a tooth pulled at the dentist, who's determined not to cry in front of his mother.

'I hate doing things like this,' he admits later. 'Interviews, videos, pictures, all of it. I'd prefer Keith to do it for me, but he can't really, can he?'

Seeing as Charlie is promoting his latest solo project a tribute album - honouring jazz drummers, put together with fellow aficionado Jim Keltner - Keith Richards' sudden appearance in the publicity schedule might indeed be surprising. It's Charlie who's had the lifelong love for jazz, and who's done various acclaimed tours and albums with his own Charlie Watts Quintet. All these years on, the drummer still seems totally besotted by the genre that bit him first, long before he'd even heard the name Rolling Stones. Nor could anyone dismiss this latest outing as a simple case of 'vanity publishing'. A second CD features diverse contemporary ambient-techno-drum'n'bass mixes by artists such as Coldcut and The Propellorheads. However, the main record is a muso bath of purist excellence put together with obvious taste and passion.

'I'd like it to sell,' says Charlie. 'Nobody ever brings a record out not wanting people to buy it. My wife doesn't like it, though,' he smiles. 'She prefers the Stones.' And which does Charlie prefer? 'I love both,' he says instantly. 'With the jazz, it's great being onstage with such wonderful players, and with the Stones, it's great being up there with your friends. I stand firmly with my rock'n'roll band - though I have to say,' his eyes narrow thoughtfully, 'I have always considered the Stones to be a great blues band - rock'n'roll to me is Little Richard.'

We're sitting in the restaurant in the back of the pub. By now, Charlie has relaxed considerably. When we first came in, he'd sat, fidgeting, eyes averted, unable to make up his mind whether he wanted the interview to start or not. Usually, when you hear that a world-famous celebrity is 'shy', you take it with a pinch of salt, but Charlie's reserve seems genuine. When he finally thaws, he is friendly and courteous to a fault, but initially, his paralysing shyness hangs between us like an exclamation mark. You wouldn't believe any other Stone, but you trust Charlie Watts when he tells you that he never enjoyed the female attention the band got in the early days.

'Girls chasing you down the street, screaming... horrible!' he says. But Charlie, I say, isn't that supposed to be every man's dream? 'Maybe it is,' he shrugs. 'But I hated it. It was quite flattering, I suppose. And it's fantastic to play to audiences like that. For me, that was the whole point of being chased down the street... Playing the drums was all I was ever interested in. The rest of it made me cringe. The girls only really loved Mick, Brian and Keith anyway,' he continues sagely. 'Bill and I were older, and Bill looked it then. He looks much younger now.' Charlie cackles. 'Bill used to have this terrible Tony Curtis haircut - Keith does this great impression of it.'

The Stones themselves didn't seem to make much impression on Charlie in the very early days: 'I used to play with loads of bands, and the Stones were just another one. I thought they'd last three months, then a year, then three years, then I stopped counting.' He remembers them travelling together in a small van: 'Me and Keith were in the back, on a ledge, under a blanket. Brian conned his way into the front on account of his asthma.' Does he have any nostalgia for those years?

'No,' says Charlie. 'We tour very well now - first class and Rolls-Royces, and that's the only way to do it. Those were valuable times, though, because that's how you became a working band. And we still are. There's bigger gaps between work, but we're still a working band.' Even when the Stones started to become a serious proposition, Charlie continued to consider them a blues band, and remained stubbornly resistant to the allure of rock'n'roll: 'To me, it was about as interesting as something like flower power,' he says. His eyes twinkle wickedly: 'That's just me, though.'

Charlie Watts was born in 1941, the son of a British Rail lorry driver. He studied graphic design at Harrow Art College, then took a job in a West End advertising agency. Around this time, he started playing the drums for local acts, including Alexis Korner, and the Rolling Stones. He also met his future wife, Shirley - an art student and sculptress. They married, and had one daughter, Seraphina, born in 1968.

Still very much together, Charlie and Shirley now live on their 16th-century stud farm in Devon, along with numerous horses and rescued greyhounds. Seraphina adjusted very badly when the Watts first returned from tax exile in France and, by all accounts, became a bit of a wild child. She got expelled from Millfield public school for smoking pot, but has since calmed down, and become a mother. 'It's difficult to be a good father when you're away from home so much,' says Charlie sadly.

Recently, the Watts had to prosecute the husband-and-wife managers of their stud farm for fraudulent accounting. Apart from that, life Chez Charlie seems almost surreally idyllic. If the drummer reads at all, it's detective novels, or books on Hollywood in the 40s. His favourite music is jazz, or anything from Stevie Wonder to Stravinsky. The mood most likely to inspire him to put a record on is 'loneliness'. 'Not in a negative way,' says Charlie quickly. 'Just that feeling of being alone.' Solitude? 'Yes.'

When I ask Charlie if he would prefer to live in London to be more 'in the centre of things', he points out: 'It isn't the centre of things for me, and hasn't been for 30 years.' Later, Charlie adds that London, along with America, is the place he feels least safe. Not that anywhere is totally safe these days for a rock star. The stabbing of Beatle George Harrison, last year, on his country estate in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, left Charlie very shaken.

For those unfamiliar with the case, it was reported that Michael Abram broke into the house and stabbed Harrison, who fought him off with the help of his wife Olivia. 'But what George really went through was not in the papers,' says Charlie. 'I spoke to Ringo about a month after it happened and he told me exactly what went on, and it was horrific. George was stabbed about 40 times. It happened outside his bedroom on the landing. He would have been dead if he'd been lying in bed, he wouldn't have been able to fight. The papers did say that one wound punctured his lung, but a lot of the others were just as horrific. The man was slashing him everywhere. George's wife hit him again and again on the head with this brass lamp, but he just wouldn't stop. There was blood everywhere.'

Charlie shakes his head ruefully: 'I think George is still going through trauma,' he says. 'He's bound to - he's lived in that house for 30 years. It's just so shocking that it should happen to a guy who's so...' he gropes for the right word - 'inoffensive. George has never been nasty to anyone, he's only ever preached love and peace. He's not like John Lennon: he's never made statements or anything.' Charlie sighs, bemused. 'He's just a very nice guitar player.'

He doesn't say it but, going by the look on his face, Charlie obviously believes that anything that could happen to the bass player of the Beatles could also happen to the drummer of the Stones. Not that he's about to let it blight married bliss with Shirley. The Watts have long been considered to be among rock's most loving couples. While other Stones were busy going mad in the carnal and pharmaceutical sweetie shops of the 60s and 70s, Charlie was famous for retiring to his room to pine for his wife. Around this time, he developed a habit of drawing each bed he sleeps in on tour. 'It's a way of marking time,' he says. 'It's become such a fetish, I couldn't bear to miss one.'

Charlie's devotion to Mrs Watts doesn't show any sign of abating. Shirley told an interviewer not so long ago how Charlie still tells her he loves her every single day and never, ever criticises her. This is precisely the sort of story that makes even the most music-illiterate of people worship Charlie Watts. Was it love at first sight?

Charlie considers for a moment, pushing back his silver hair. 'Well, it was obviously very sexual, and I suppose that's love as well. I just_' he hesitates, ' wanted her, I suppose. She was so funny and clever, and she had the most infectious laugh you'd ever heard. And I loved the world she was in, the world of art and sculpting. I just admired Shirley very, very much.' He smiles. 'I still do.'

Shirley was the main reason Charlie cites for coming back from the brink in the mid-80s when, inexplicably, he decided to go off the rails just as the other Stones were starting to calm down. Today, Charlie has a coffee, while I have a red wine. He hasn't drunk, smoked, or taken drugs for 15 years, and dismisses the period when he suddenly started overindulging as 'a mid-life thing, it must have been'. One thing's for sure, Charlie wasn't short of bad influences. Many of his jazz heroes, including Charlie Parker, succumbed to drugs, and the Rolling Stones entourage was famously packed solid with 24/7 party people.

Charlie's personal slide started with drinking too much. 'Probably a normal day's quota for most people, but too much for me. Then it became regular.' From there, Charlie went on to booze, amphetamines and heroin. His daughter would look at him most mornings and declare he reminded her of Dracula. Shirley was in despair and on the verge of leaving. It lasted for about two years.

That's quite a long time to be_ I hesitate, wondering how to politely finish the sentence.

'That out of it?' says Charlie helpfully.

I tell him I could imagine him boozing, but I couldn't imagine him getting involved with heroin.

'Well, I did,' says Charlie. 'Very easily. And drugs are very hard to give up. For me, anyway. I didn't even take that many. I wasn't that badly affected, I wasn't a junkie, but giving up drugs was very, very hard. Much, much harder than the rest of it.'

The turning point came when he broke his ankle. 'I was drunk,' says Charlie. 'I slipped down the steps when I was in the cellar getting a bottle of wine. I happened to be booked for a jazz show at Ronnie Scott's in six weeks' time, and it really brought it home to me how far down I'd gone. I just stopped everything - drinking, smoking, taking drugs, everything, all at once. I just thought, enough is enough .'

The Stones have had other troubles in recent times. In 1998, they were universally castigated as 'greedy' for axeing the British leg of their last 'Bridges To Babylon' tour, to avoid an unexpected £10m tax bill brought about by a new budget. The Stones played the dates the following year, but the damage was done. 'We didn't cancel that tour,' says Charlie, exasperated. 'They moved the goalposts, and we moved them again.' He's drily cynical about why people persist in wanting to see the Stones play live after all these years. 'Maybe they're hoping we'll fall over at long last. It would be an occasion, wouldn't it?'

There's also the fact that, offstage as well as on, the Stones continue to put on a good show. There was Mick Jagger's divorce from Jerry Hall, and his much-publicised love child with Brazilian model Luciana Morad. 'Mick's a very strict, very good father,' reveals Charlie. 'Very much "Do As I Say, Not As I Do".'

Then, a week or so after I talk with Charlie, Ron Wood is in the papers, having checked into the Priory for the usual 'tired and emotional' problems. However, when Charlie and I speak, all is calm in the Stones' camp, and the drummer talks warmly of his bandmates, commending Jagger's 'zest for life' and Wood's 'lovely, fun-loving' nature.

'Keith is the most interesting, the most different of us all, though,' says Charlie. 'He's a man of vision, and one of the few people who hasn't really changed over the years. Wherever he goes, whatever he does, he's always Keith. He'll be in his room and all the stuff that makes him Keith will be there. The music's going, the wine's there, his guitar's there, and he'll be sitting in the middle of it all like some wonderful sultan. ' Charlie beams. 'It's fantastic. It's not a new thing, it's the way he's always been.'

And what about Brian Jones, I ask, do you ever think of him?

'No,' says Charlie quite sharply, and his face clouds over.

'Well, actually, yeah,' he says, after a second's pause. 'Of course I think about Brian. Now and again, I'll see something which reminds me of him and I'll remember the laughs we used to have. He was a bit fey, though,' says Charlie pointedly. 'And he could be very cruel, contrary to his angelic looks. He was a terror with girls. People could be dropped in the most awful way. I always used to wonder how he coped with the worry of it all, the babies and whatever. He obviously didn't even think of it.

'Brian had this horrible streak,' says Charlie. 'John Lennon had it, too. John could be one of the nicest, most hilarious people you'd ever meet, but he could also be a cruel bugger. He used this terrible rapier-like wit to kick people down. Obviously, a very talented man, but, to me, John was just like everybody I went to art school with - funny, flippant, but he'd walk over anybody who got in his way.' Charlie sighs. 'Not the nicest person in the world, and Brian was the same.'

What about the conspiracy theories that Brian was murdered?

Charlie says: 'All that about Brian being knocked off is rubbish. I know a lot of people would have willingly knocked him off, but it didn't happen. Brian was just very weak. He was asthmatic, unhealthy. The stuff he took - uppers, downers, leapers, bleepers, whatever they were too strong for his body. He couldn't take it. And his swimming pool was about 70 degrees or something - it used to shimmer with heat. You'd drive down there on a spring morning and the heat would be rising off the top. And he got in there, and I suppose it was like getting into a warm bath, and he fell asleep. And_ that's how he died.' Charlie's voice trails away. He suddenly looks very tired.

Are you surprised, I ask, by the number of casualties there have been in and around the Stones' camp over the years?

'Surprised?' says Charlie wryly, looking me straight in the eye. 'I'm amazed there haven't been more.'

It's time for Charlie to leave. He has to go and record a Radio 2 interview with his old friend, jazz maestro George Melly. 'Good!' cries Charlie, with blatant relief, when I click the tape recorder off. I slip it quickly into my bag to save him the displeasure of looking at what is so obviously an instrument of torture. 'Are you coming along?' asks Charlie, smiling. 'George is hilarious. Very jazz !'

Charlie is right. Melly is hilarious and probably 'very jazz' too, whatever that means. Charlie certainly seems to relax beautifully when he's with Melly - the pressure is off, and all he has to think about are his favourite jazz records. When we all go to the bar after the radio show, I initially sit slightly apart from Melly and Charlie, thinking they'll appreciate some privacy. Charlie will have none of it. 'Come and sit here!' he orders, thumping the table, all kind bossiness. I switch the tape recorder on a couple more times, when the conversation turns interesting, but Charlie looks so pained, it's soon banished to my bag for good.

Then the change in Charlie Watts is quite amazing. He loses his haunted, wary look, and becomes playful, fun, delighted when Melly teases me, pretending to be entranced by my 'ideal' colouring: 'A raven bleeding to death in snow,' booms Melly. 'What do you think, Charlie?' He just chuckles merrily, and gives me and the rest of the room a dazzling smile that is a wink, a grin, and a leap for joy combined. I'm Charlie Watts, the smile seems to be saying - I'm perfectly relaxed, totally 'jazz'.

You wouldn't believe any other Stone, but you trust Charlie Watts when he tells you that he never enjoyed the female attention the band got in the early days. 'Girls chasing you down the street, screaming... horrible!' he says. But Charlie, I say, isn't that supposed to be every man's dream? 'Maybe it is,' he shrugs. 'But I hated it. It was quite flattering, I suppose. And it's fantastic to play to audiences like that. For me, that was the whole point of being chased down the street... Playing the drums was all I was ever interested in. The rest of it made me cringe. The girls only really loved Mick, Brian and Keith anyway,' he continues sagely. 'Bill and I were older, and Bill looked it then. He looks much younger now.' Charlie cackles. 'Bill used to have this terrible Tony Curtis haircut - Keith does this great impression of it.' The Stones themselves didn't seem to make much impression on Charlie in the very early days: 'I used to play with loads of bands, and the Stones were just another one. I thought they'd last three months, then a year, then three years, then I stopped counting.' He remembers them travelling together in a small van: 'Me and Keith were in the back, on a ledge, under a blanket. Brian conned his way into the front on account of his asthma.' Does he have any nostalgia for those years? 'No,' says Charlie. 'We tour very well now - first class and Rolls-Royces, and that's the only way to do it. Those were valuable times, though, because that's how you became a working band. And we still are. There's bigger gaps between work, but we're still a working band.' Even when the Stones started to become a serious proposition, Charlie continued to consider them a blues band, and remained stubbornly resistant to the allure of rock'n'roll: 'To me, it was about as interesting as something like flower power,' he says. His eyes twinkle wickedly: 'That's just me, though.' Charlie Watts was born in 1941, the son of a British Rail lorry driver. He studied graphic design at Harrow Art College, then took a job in a West End advertising agency. Around this time, he started playing the drums for local acts, including Alexis Korner, and the Rolling Stones. He also met his future wife, Shirley - an art student and sculptress. They married, and had one daughter, Seraphina, born in 1968. Still very much together, Charlie and Shirley now live on their 16th-century stud farm in Devon, along with numerous horses and rescued greyhounds. Seraphina adjusted very badly when the Watts first returned from tax exile in France and, by all accounts, became a bit of a wild child. She got expelled from Millfield public school for smoking pot, but has since calmed down, and become a mother. 'It's difficult to be a good father when you're away from home so much,' says Charlie sadly. Recently, the Watts had to prosecute the husband-and-wife managers of their stud farm for fraudulent accounting. Apart from that, life Chez Charlie seems almost surreally idyllic. If the drummer reads at all, it's detective novels, or books on Hollywood in the 40s. His favourite music is jazz, or anything from Stevie Wonder to Stravinsky. The mood most likely to inspire him to put a record on is 'loneliness'. 'Not in a negative way,' says Charlie quickly. 'Just that feeling of being alone.' Solitude? 'Yes.' When I ask Charlie if he would prefer to live in London to be more 'in the centre of things', he points out: 'It isn't the centre of things for me, and hasn't been for 30 years.' Later, Charlie adds that London, along with America, is the place he feels least safe. Not that anywhere is totally safe these days for a rock star. The stabbing of Beatle George Harrison, last year, on his country estate in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, left Charlie very shaken. For those unfamiliar with the case, it was reported that Michael Abram broke into the house and stabbed Harrison, who fought him off with the help of his wife Olivia. 'But what George really went through was not in the papers,' says Charlie. 'I spoke to Ringo about a month after it happened and he told me exactly what went on, and it was horrific. George was stabbed about 40 times. It happened outside his bedroom on the landing. He would have been dead if he'd been lying in bed, he wouldn't have been able to fight. The papers did say that one wound punctured his lung, but a lot of the others were just as horrific. The man was slashing him everywhere. George's wife hit him again and again on the head with this brass lamp, but he just wouldn't stop. There was blood everywhere.' Charlie shakes his head ruefully: 'I think George is still going through trauma,' he says. 'He's bound to - he's lived in that house for 30 years. It's just so shocking that it should happen to a guy who's so...' he gropes for the right word - 'inoffensive. George has never been nasty to anyone, he's only ever preached love and peace. He's not like John Lennon: he's never made statements or anything.' Charlie sighs, bemused. 'He's just a very nice guitar player.' He doesn't say it but, going by the look on his face, Charlie obviously believes that anything that could happen to the bass player of the Beatles could also happen to the drummer of the Stones. Not that he's about to let it blight married bliss with Shirley. The Watts have long been considered to be among rock's most loving couples. While other Stones were busy going mad in the carnal and pharmaceutical sweetie shops of the 60s and 70s, Charlie was famous for retiring to his room to pine for his wife. Around this time, he developed a habit of drawing each bed he sleeps in on tour. 'It's a way of marking time,' he says. 'It's become such a fetish, I couldn't bear to miss one.' Charlie's devotion to Mrs Watts doesn't show any sign of abating. Shirley told an interviewer not so long ago how Charlie still tells her he loves her every single day and never, ever criticises her. This is precisely the sort of story that makes even the most music-illiterate of people worship Charlie Watts. Was it love at first sight? Charlie considers for a moment, pushing back his silver hair. 'Well, it was obviously very sexual, and I suppose that's love as well. I just_' he hesitates, ' wanted her, I suppose. She was so funny and clever, and she had the most infectious laugh you'd ever heard. And I loved the world she was in, the world of art and sculpting. I just admired Shirley very, very much.' He smiles. 'I still do.' Shirley was the main reason Charlie cites for coming back from the brink in the mid-80s when, inexplicably, he decided to go off the rails just as the other Stones were starting to calm down. Today, Charlie has a coffee, while I have a red wine. He hasn't drunk, smoked, or taken drugs for 15 years, and dismisses the period when he suddenly started overindulging as 'a mid-life thing, it must have been'. One thing's for sure, Charlie wasn't short of bad influences. Many of his jazz heroes, including Charlie Parker, succumbed to drugs, and the Rolling Stones entourage was famously packed solid with 24/7 party people. Charlie's personal slide started with drinking too much. 'Probably a normal day's quota for most people, but too much for me. Then it became regular.' From there, Charlie went on to booze, amphetamines and heroin. His daughter would look at him most mornings and declare he reminded her of Dracula. Shirley was in despair and on the verge of leaving. It lasted for about two years. That's quite a long time to be_ I hesitate, wondering how to politely finish the sentence. 'That out of it?' says Charlie helpfully. I tell him I could imagine him boozing, but I couldn't imagine him getting involved with heroin. 'Well, I did,' says Charlie. 'Very easily. And drugs are very hard to give up. For me, anyway. I didn't even take that many. I wasn't that badly affected, I wasn't a junkie, but giving up drugs was very, very hard. Much, much harder than the rest of it.' The turning point came when he broke his ankle. 'I was drunk,' says Charlie. 'I slipped down the steps when I was in the cellar getting a bottle of wine. I happened to be booked for a jazz show at Ronnie Scott's in six weeks' time, and it really brought it home to me how far down I'd gone. I just stopped everything - drinking, smoking, taking drugs, everything, all at once. I just thought, enough is enough .' The Stones have had other troubles in recent times. In 1998, they were universally castigated as 'greedy' for axeing the British leg of their last 'Bridges To Babylon' tour, to avoid an unexpected £10m tax bill brought about by a new budget. The Stones played the dates the following year, but the damage was done. 'We didn't cancel that tour,' says Charlie, exasperated. 'They moved the goalposts, and we moved them again.' He's drily cynical about why people persist in wanting to see the Stones play live after all these years. 'Maybe they're hoping we'll fall over at long last. It would be an occasion, wouldn't it?' There's also the fact that, offstage as well as on, the Stones continue to put on a good show. There was Mick Jagger's divorce from Jerry Hall, and his much-publicised love child with Brazilian model Luciana Morad. 'Mick's a very strict, very good father,' reveals Charlie. 'Very much "Do As I Say, Not As I Do".' Then, a week or so after I talk with Charlie, Ron Wood is in the papers, having checked into the Priory for the usual 'tired and emotional' problems. However, when Charlie and I speak, all is calm in the Stones' camp, and the drummer talks warmly of his bandmates, commending Jagger's 'zest for life' and Wood's 'lovely, fun-loving' nature. 'Keith is the most interesting, the most different of us all, though,' says Charlie. 'He's a man of vision, and one of the few people who hasn't really changed over the years. Wherever he goes, whatever he does, he's always Keith. He'll be in his room and all the stuff that makes him Keith will be there. The music's going, the wine's there, his guitar's there, and he'll be sitting in the middle of it all like some wonderful sultan. ' Charlie beams. 'It's fantastic. It's not a new thing, it's the way he's always been.' And what about Brian Jones, I ask, do you ever think of him? 'No,' says Charlie quite sharply, and his face clouds over. 'Well, actually, yeah,' he says, after a second's pause. 'Of course I think about Brian. Now and again, I'll see something which reminds me of him and I'll remember the laughs we used to have. He was a bit fey, though,' says Charlie pointedly. 'And he could be very cruel, contrary to his angelic looks. He was a terror with girls. People could be dropped in the most awful way. I always used to wonder how he coped with the worry of it all, the babies and whatever. He obviously didn't even think of it. 'Brian had this horrible streak,' says Charlie. 'John Lennon had it, too. John could be one of the nicest, most hilarious people you'd ever meet, but he could also be a cruel bugger. He used this terrible rapier-like wit to kick people down. Obviously, a very talented man, but, to me, John was just like everybody I went to art school with - funny, flippant, but he'd walk over anybody who got in his way.' Charlie sighs. 'Not the nicest person in the world, and Brian was the same.' What about the conspiracy theories that Brian was murdered? Charlie says: 'All that about Brian being knocked off is rubbish. I know a lot of people would have willingly knocked him off, but it didn't happen. Brian was just very weak. He was asthmatic, unhealthy. The stuff he took - uppers, downers, leapers, bleepers, whatever they were too strong for his body. He couldn't take it. And his swimming pool was about 70 degrees or something - it used to shimmer with heat. You'd drive down there on a spring morning and the heat would be rising off the top. And he got in there, and I suppose it was like getting into a warm bath, and he fell asleep. And_ that's how he died.' Charlie's voice trails away. He suddenly looks very tired. Are you surprised, I ask, by the number of casualties there have been in and around the Stones' camp over the years? 'Surprised?' says Charlie wryly, looking me straight in the eye. 'I'm amazed there haven't been more.' It's time for Charlie to leave. He has to go and record a Radio 2 interview with his old friend, jazz maestro George Melly. 'Good!' cries Charlie, with blatant relief, when I click the tape recorder off. I slip it quickly into my bag to save him the displeasure of looking at what is so obviously an instrument of torture. 'Are you coming along?' asks Charlie, smiling. 'George is hilarious. Very jazz !' Charlie is right. Melly is hilarious and probably 'very jazz' too, whatever that means. Charlie certainly seems to relax beautifully when he's with Melly - the pressure is off, and all he has to think about are his favourite jazz records. When we all go to the bar after the radio show, I initially sit slightly apart from Melly and Charlie, thinking they'll appreciate some privacy. Charlie will have none of it. 'Come and sit here!' he orders, thumping the table, all kind bossiness. I switch the tape recorder on a couple more times, when the conversation turns interesting, but Charlie looks so pained, it's soon banished to my bag for good. Then the change in Charlie Watts is quite amazing. He loses his haunted, wary look, and becomes playful, fun, delighted when Melly teases me, pretending to be entranced by my 'ideal' colouring: 'A raven bleeding to death in snow,' booms Melly. 'What do you think, Charlie?' He just chuckles merrily, and gives me and the rest of the room a dazzling smile that is a wink, a grin, and a leap for joy combined. I'm Charlie Watts, the smile seems to be saying - I'm perfectly relaxed, totally 'jazz'. • Charlie Watts's album, Charlie Watts/Jim Keltner Project, is released on Monday by Virgin

fields.standfirst: Olivia Robinson asks  Margaret Dibben how to spend her payout
fields.trailText: Olivia Robinson asks Margaret Dibben how to spend her payout.

OLIVIA ROBINSON

AGE 25

AIMS To best use insurance compensation

Olivia Robinson was injured in a boating accident two years ago. At a summer party on the Thames, the engine exploded and she lost her hair, eyebrows and almost her sight. She has now made a complete recovery with no long-term effects, and six weeks ago received an insurance payout of £3,500.

She based her case on American lawsuits and won this amount not as a reflection of the mental stress, or for the risk to her sight but, oddly, for the vanity of losing her hair. She now wants to know what she should do with the money: 'Do I pay off my debts or invest it for the future?' Before returning to university, she had spent five years working in web design, office management and IT training. Part of the time she was self-employed, running a business doing research to help companies expand. More recently she was TEFL trained and has taught in the UK and abroad.

She has toured Europe and spent a year travelling across Russia, China and South East Asia. She spent last summer teaching in Thailand.

The TEFL training renewed her interest in linguistics, which she is now studying at the University of Reading. She graduates next year and says her job prospects are good.

Last October she bought a house for £95,000. As she was a student, her father guaranteed the interest-only fixed-rate mortgage. She has lodgers paying £5,280 a year in rent, which supplements her £1,800 grant and £2,350 from working in the holidays.

The mortgage costs her £4,400 a year; she has a £1,000 bank loan, a £1,000 credit card balance and a £3,600 student loan which is due next June. Her investments are £4,000 in Peps: Invesco European Growth, Baring European Growth, Credit Suisse Fellowship Fund.

She hopes to work for the teaching publications arm of a publishing house and eventually set up her own business: 'I was happy with the process of running a business. I know I have a strong head for business, but I want to see if I can combine my personal interests with business rather than running a business for its own sake.'

She wants to work from home and will also build her own house abroad, probably in France, using the internet to communicate with customers: 'I have been researching it for a few years and done some preliminary costings and I have definite ideas about what I want. I still want to travel but as long as I can have a room full of computers I will be happy.'

Adviser 1: Neil Bailey

Olivia should repay the bank loan and credit card bill, as the interest rates are higher than she is likely to get from investments. She should keep the balance as cash for expenses between now and when she graduates. She could open a mini-cash Isa for tax-free interest. An instant access or short notice account will give her flexibility. Nationwide is a good 'high street' provider, although better rates are available. Smile's Cat-standard Isa pays 7.25 per cent with instant access.

Olivia should ensure she is claiming all her tax reliefs: under rent-a-room, she can make £4,250 a year from a lodger before paying tax.

Although she has £4,000 in a Pep, Olivia does not appear to be making ongoing contributions to her mortgage - perhaps to reduce monthly commitments while studying. Her mortgage comes up for review around the time she graduates. She should review the repayments then. Her bank will probably offer a range of options, but other lenders will only consider an application after she has been employed for three to six months. She should wait until she can shop around before locking herself into another mortgage deal.

Olivia does not mention mortgage protection arrangements. I assume she has no dependents, but she should consider a critical illness policy, that will repay the mortgage if she suffers a a serious illness.

 Neil Bailey works for Winslow-based Sensible Financial Planning.

Adviser 2: Carolyn Corless

Olivia should pay off most of her debts as she is paying far more interest than she could receive from deposit accounts. Investing in the stock market could provide a higher rate of return, but it is in no way guaranteed and she could lose money in the short term. She should check if there are any onerous penalties for repaying the bank loan early. She should retain her student loan, though, as this is a cheap form of borrowing.

After paying her mortgage there is only a modest amount left for living expenses and she currently has no emergency fund for unplanned expenditure. To avoid building up debt again, I recommend she invests the £1,500 left in a bank or building society account paying the highest rate of interest. Accounts operated via the internet offer some of the highest rates (for example Nationwide e-savings pays 7 per cent gross on a minimum balance of £1); postal or telephone accounts are competitive traditional accounts (C&G Tracker account pays 6.5 per cent gross on a minimum balance of £100).

There is little benefit investing in a notice account and Olivia is likely to need regular access to the capital to meet occasional shortfalls.

With careful budgeting, this modest nest egg should enable Olivia to complete her degree, without incurring any additional debts.

 Carolyn Corless works for Bideford-based chartered accountant Sully & Co.

 Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Alternatives
fields.standfirst: Why water is the great body cleanser, building up your self-esteem, and tackling itchy scalps
fields.trailText: Why water is the great body cleanser, building up your self-esteem, and tackling itchy scalps
fields.body:
Your Body

During the summer months, it is more important than ever to drink large quantities of water. The healing properties of water are expounded by, among others, Dr Fereydoon Batmangeheilidj, a GP who is widely regarded as an authority in this field. The body is composed of 75 per cent water, and most experts recommend a minimum intake of two litres a day in order to cleanse the body properly. Alcohol and coffee in particular can lead to dehydration, which in turn can lead to a reduction in energy levels. Among Batmangeheilidj's radical solutions is the prescription that everyone should drink half their pound body weight of water in ounces daily - so, if you weigh 180 pounds, you should drink 90 ounces of water every day. He cites this as the key to a long and healthy life. The general consensus, however, is that two and half litres should do it for most of us.

Your Mind

The state of one's self-esteem is something of a hot topic on chat shows both here and in the US at the moment, and Bryan Craig, a life counsellor who runs workshops on self-esteem in this country, tells me that people can transform their lives by raising their self-esteem levels. Self-esteem is made up of two main components: the self-ideal, our definition of how we ought to be, and the self-image, our definition of how we actually are. The disparity between these two produces our individual level of self-esteem, which is often too low. One of the ways of increasing self-esteem, he says, is to re-evaluate these two elements by reducing any unrealistic demands in the self-ideal and valuing our qualities and achievements in the self-image more accurately. To help achieve this, he recommends a building self-esteem programme by Dr Glen Schiraldi, an author and psychotherapist at the University of Maryland. It includes a self-esteem check-up, in which you rate yourself out of 10 on a range of personal issues, with the idea of helping you to make more realistic assessments.

Your Questions

For several years, I have been suffering from an itchy scalp. I have tried various shampoos to control the irritation, but none have had any effect whatsoever. If I am out in the sun for long periods, my scalp becomes itchy. Please could you recommend what I should do to control this, it's making my life a misery.
Mickey Doyle, Gravesend, Kent

An itchy scalp is often an indication of an underlying health problem which could be diet-related. Sufferers should ensure they have a well-balanced diet - maybe by keeping a food diary - and might also try upping their intake of the Omega 3 fatty acids that occur in oily fish. These have been found to have a calming effect on irritated skin. The best shampoos for your condition contain extracts of marigold and nettle - an infusion of the two in the final rinse would be ideal. To improve the condition of the scalp, herbalists recommend kelp or nettle, which are available from any good health food store.

webTitle: Want a top stylist to fit you in quickly? That's £500, please

fields.headline: Want a top stylist to fit you in quickly? That's £500, please
fields.trailText: Beauty salons and hairdressers have traditionally been viewed as the territory of the woman with time on her hands, the lady who lunches. But over the past few years, increasing numbers of women have started regarding professional hair and beauty care as an essential part of their working and social lives.
fields.body:
Beauty salons and hairdressers have traditionally been viewed as the territory of the woman with time on her hands, the lady who lunches. But over the past few years, increasing numbers of women have started regarding professional hair and beauty care as an essential part of their working and social lives.

Andrew Clark, creative director of Nicky Clarke's hair salon in Mayfair, says it is not unusual to find executive women coming into the salon for a blow-dry every morning as part of their daily routine.

'They've usually got their mobile telephones plugged into their ears, and it's just a part of their job to look good,' he says.

A quick look at the Nicky Clarke price list shows that their salaries or business expense accounts must be impressive. An appointment with one of the salon's lesser-known stylists can costs from £45, depending on their experience at the salon. But an initial appointment with the man himself - and you may have to wait up to three weeks for a time of his choice - will cost you £300. A fast-track appointment (which limits the wait to two or three days) is £500. The average client spends around £180 a visit.

Most women teach themselves to apply makeup, but many now have a 'makeover' from a professional makeup artist. Ariane Poole, an independent consultant and makeup adviser for Boots No 7, has clients who book in twice a year for a complete assessment. A lesson with her normally lasts between two and three hours, and costs £250.

Poole goes through your makeup bag, discusses the look you want, and sorts out makeup for days and evenings. Her clients range from housewives to high-flying professionals.

Beauty salons are cheaper, about £20 for a 45-minute 'cleanse and makeup' session, or £35 for a complete makeup 'lesson' lasting an hour.

Bridal makeup costs slightly more, at £45, but includes a practice session as well as application for the big day itself.

Manicures are also becoming more mainstream. The concept of the nail bar- a manicure salon which you can walk into without an appointment and get your nails done at a reasonably low price - has finally crossed the Atlantic to the UK high street. A basic salon manicure costs about £15 and takes up to 45 minutes; a nail bar will turn you round in 15 minutes for £10. Branches of the New York Nail Company and Nails Inc are sprouting up in London. Boots is set to start a walk-in manicure service in major stores this month.

Hair today, gone tomorrow - for £1,000

Hair removal - one of the cheapest beauty processes if you use a razor and soap - becomes the most expensive if you have laser treatment. At the Laser Clinic in London's Harley Street, denuding an upper lip costs about £100 a session. A bikini line will cost between £250 and £400, while a full leg costs from £600 to £900. Success depends on zapping the hair follicles while they are growing, so you may need up to six sessions to remove all your unwanted fuzz.

One women recently spent £1,000 having her upper lip, armpits, bikini line and lower legs lasered - and she faces five more treatments.The effects are meant to be permanent, but hormonal changes such as the menopause may bring new hair.

The process is very quick and relatively painless. Your skin is chilled before being exposed to a laser beam, which is as uncomfortable as someone pinging elastic bands against your skin. A session normally takes between half an hour and an hour. Afterwards the skin becomes quite tender and blotchy - side-effects that can last from half an hour to two weeks.

In contrast, waxing hurts - don't let any beautician tell you otherwise - but it is much cheaper: about £14 for lower legs, and £8 for a bikini line and underarms. It has to be repeated every six weeks if you want to remain hair-free. Having your lower legs professionally waxed from the age of 30 to 60 would cost more than £3,600.

Likewise, electrolysis can be uncomfortable, leaving little red burn marks if the current is not applied properly. It costs about £10 per 10- or 15- minute session. These have to be repeated many times, and even then the hair may not be killed.

Beauty on a budget

If you are prepared to compromise, there are many ways of achieving good results at little cost:

 Get your hair done cheaply by letting a trainee practise on you. Some independent salons advertise for 'models' (often by notices in the shop window). Sessions are often in the evening. At the Toni & Guy Academies, these appointments cost £5. Others charge nothing.

 When you need a pick-me-up, there's nothing more satisfying than a makeover. Try a visit to a department store where most brands have beauty consultants on hand happy to give a free demonstration. There is occasionally a small charge for their time, but this is often redeemable against the sale of the cosmetics used.

 Beauty schools offer cut-price or free treatments to people willing to have the work carried out by students. But it is important to make sure the school is affiliated to one of the the following examining boards: Abtac, City & Guilds, Itec or Cidesco.

 If you are determined to have cosmetic surgery, but can't afford the prices in this country, you could have treatment abroad. Eastern European medical groups offer operations for up to a third less than their UK equivalents. For example, Europol Cosmetic Surgery, which operates in Poland, charges £2,300 for breast enlargement, £2,600 for a facelift and £2,200 for a nose job. Prices include travel and accommodation.

Play your cards right

Maintaining your body may make you feel good, but it won't improve your bank balance.

Unless you have the wealth to match Joyce Wildenstein (below), it's cheapest to pay by credit card. Capital One (0800 952 5355) charges an annual percentage rate (APR) of 3.9 per cent, rising to 12.9 per cent after six months. The Nationwide (0500 302011) charges 3.5 per cent, rising to 14.6 per cent after six months. If you prefer to repay debt over a longer period and don't mind paying more in interest, the Egg Visa (www.egg.com) charges 10.9 per cent indefinitely.

Do not accept any invitations to take out a store credit card unless you are prepared either to pay off the bill in full each month or pay through the nose for your credit. Harvey Nichols charges 26.5 per cent APR, Selfridges 27.6 per cent and Harrods 28.9 per cent.

If you want to borrow a large amount for major cosmetic surgery, you may have to consider a personal loan. For amounts between £3,000 and £5,000, the cheapest lenders are Smile (www.smile.co.uk) and Chartered Trust (0800 068 2286), which charge 12.9 per cent APR. For between £5,000 and £7,499, the Tesco bank (0845 6006016) is cheapest, at 10.2 per cent.

webTitle: All eyes on a new private Hamleys

fields.headline: All eyes on a new private Hamleys
fields.trailText: World famous toy retailer Hamleys will go private in the autumn, according to top company insiders.
fields.body:
World famous toy retailer Hamleys will go private in the autumn, according to top company insiders.

After a week in which takeover talks between Hamleys and venture capital group Charterhouse collapsed, it is believed Hamleys will seek ways out of the stock market within months.

Senior managers within the oldest toy shop in the world are known to be unhappy at the way Howard Dyer, Hamley's chairman, handled negotiations with Charterhouse.

They say he was unrealistic in sticking to 200p a share for the firm. Charterhouse were offering around 170p, valuing Hamleys at £35.8 million.

'It's not right that a company like this is public,' said a senior Hamleys source.

The source hinted that once Dyer leaves Hamleys this October, the way would be clear to take Hamleys private.

Hamleys, based in London's Regent Street, has issued four profit warnings since 1998. But City analysts believe that under new managing director, Simon Burke - former Virgin Entertainment Group chief - the firm is improving.

This is not the first troubled time for Hamleys. In 1931 it went into liquidation, but was rescued. It nearly went under again in 1971. Recent attempts to trade on its name with satellite stores failed.

webTitle: When perfume causes a stink in the office

fields.headline: When perfume causes a stink in the office
fields.standfirst: UK employers may be forced to follow a US lead in banning scents, writes Caroline Palmer
fields.trailText: UK employers may be forced to follow a US lead in banning scents, writes Caroline Palmer
fields.body:
Recent reports of an 84-year-old woman being escorted from a council meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia for dabbing perfume behind her ears may seem bizarre, but the decision by the Canadian province to ban perfume in public places is just one instance of a growing pressure to make public places and workplaces fragrance-free zones.

Most of this pressure is being exerted in North America, but as with issues such as banning smoking at work, there is no doubt that it is just a matter of time before the 'fragrance' debate begins on this side of the Atlantic.

At the heart of the move to ban perfume, with environmental activists threatening to file a personal injury class action against the perfume industry and the US government, there lies a medical controversy - whether multiple chemical sensitivity, or MCS, exists as a medical condition or, as some doctors suggest, is just all in the mind.

There is nothing imaginary about Donna Armstrong's symptoms, however. A building facilitator at the University of Minnesota School of Social Work in Minneapolis, she has such a severe reaction to fragrances that her employer agreed in 1993 to introduce a ban to prevent the 250 social work students and 35 faculty members from using scented products, including even certain shampoos. This ban has since been taken up by other parts of the university.

'I am highly allergic to perfume,' says Armstrong, 'particularly strong musk-based fragrances. My airways swell shut and I have to carry a Medic Alert card with me.' She has encountered no problems from colleagues or students objecting to the ban.

'Although I have the most serious allergy, there are other members of staff who are also somewhat sensitive to perfume, so there has been a lot of support.' And the University of Minnesota is not alone. Workplaces and public places in California are also starting to ban fragrances. Members of the public and officials are forbidden to wear fragrance when attending county park board meetings in Marin County, for instance.

Claudia Miller, associate professor of environmental and occupational medicine at the University of Texas Health Sciences Centre in San Antonio, says: 'Several studies indicate that between 15 and 30 per cent of the [US] population report a sensitivity to chemicals, including fragrances.'

Yet because the symptoms are so wide-ranging - headaches, mental confusion, memory loss, nausea, breathing difficulties and dizziness are just some - and because there are no tests which can detect the condition, critics say that MSC is not a real illness.

Despite this, many American government agencies, as well as companies, recognise it as a 'medical disability' that should be accommodated. The Americans with Disabilities Act, in particular, is an important piece of legislation strengthening the position of sufferers.

The American Job Accommodation Network, a service of the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, says: 'More employers are seeing the fragrance sensitivity issue as a real problem and are taking steps to create "fragrance-free workplace" policies.'

And data collected by the net work provides evidence which shows that employers 'that have instituted accommodations for people with fragrance sensitivities' have actually benefited financially. More than half of the employers surveyed report benefits in excess of $5,000.

People with fragrance sensitivity in Britain may find a voice through similar legislation, the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA).

Betty Bridges, who runs the US-based Fragranced Products Information Network, says that though more than 5,000 different chemicals are used in the fragrance industry, chemical sensitivity is not the only cause of adverse reactions. For instance, perfume is a recognised trigger for some asthma.

But whatever the cause, if a reaction causes health problems, the DDA could be used to force employers to make reasonable adjustments to workplaces.

This can go only so far, however, as employment lawyer James Davies, of Lewis Silkin, points out. 'If someone with a perfume problem worked in a shop, it wouldn't be practical to stop customers wearing perfume. But in a small office it wouldn't put people to too much inconvenience.'

Dr Alan Redman, a consultant for the British Fragrance Association, says that although there are moves in the US to promote fragrance-free zones, 'one doesn't want to run away with the idea that it is a big problem'. He adds: 'For the 99 per cent of people who find fragrance pleasant to have around, it could be argued that they were having their rights infringed. It's a balance.'

Meanwhile, on the other side of the Atlantic in Nova Scotia, a growing number of workplaces are observing the ban, even sending employees home if they arrive too strongly perfumed.

'If it's happening in the States, it will be happening here in 10 years' time,' says Tim Brown of the National Society for Clean Air and Environmental Protection.

Scent to try us: What US firms say about how fragrant you are

Excerpts from actual policies/statements from US employers that have implemented fragrance-free environments in their workplaces

Sample 1 Policy
'To reasonably accommodate bureau employees who have written memoranda documenting chemical sensitivity to perfume, employees will wear no perfum or cologne during business hours when they are scheduled to be within the bureau during their shift.'

Sample 2 Memo
'[Name of employer] strives to ensure the comfort and safety of staff and visitors by encouraging a smoke-free and fragrance-free environment.'

Sample 3 Policy
'Given that chemically sensitive individuals may react to different products with widely varying degrees of severity, it is very difficult to ensure a consistently comfortable and accommodating work environment under every conceivable set of circumstances.

Even so, it is the general consensus of the Labour/Management Committee and the desire of the [company name] to minimise to the extent possible the barriers and difficulties experienced in the workplace by both employees and clients subject to chemical/ fragrance sensitivities...

The [company name] requests that all offices and work spaces used by staff and their visitors remain free of chemical-based scented products.'

Sample 4 Memo
'I ask that we refrain from applying spray colognes, hairsprays and/or air fresheners in the office, as the use of such products may trigger allergic reactions and create health problems.'

Sample 5 Policy
'Employees working in patient care areas and in non-patient care areas shall not wear cologne, perfume, aftershave lotions, scented lotions or body washes in the medical centre.'

 Source: Job Accommodation Network

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Fleet Street is all just a board game | Bad tip from the top
fields.body:
Fleet Street is all just a board game
We cannot believe that David Yelland is really going to 'personally endorse' his own board game, Editor!, as this would move merchandising beyond parody, with only a handful of media hacks actually knowing who the Sun's current editor is. However, it has opened up a marvellous avenue of opportunity for the Media Diary in terms of others among Fleet Street's finest who may consider going down the same route. With the heated rivalry between the Mirror and the Sun, obviously there would be a Mirror editor's game - Piers Morgan's Monopoly, featuring the 'go to jail do not pass go and do not collect your share dividends' card, drawn from Tina Weaver's Community Chest. The Sunday Times Dream Date game - whereby contestants use a toy phone to be connected to their 'dream date' - or rather find themselves put through to the local tax office where details of a Labour Peer's tax returns are disseminated. And of course the highly popular Charles Moore's Consequences, where contestants fill page three of the Telegraph with unlikely and lurid scenarios involving vicars, labradors, scouts, acts of marital revenge and cross-dressing.

Bad tip from the top
You may remember, may even have bought, the heavily advertised Sunday Times last week with its promise to 'guide you through the investment jungle of the internet'. The newspaper went where many of the rest of us would fear to tread by printing a list of what it assessed to be the best internet and 'new economy' companies to invest in. But before you raid the piggy bank and follow their advice, pay heed to a small item in the excellent The Week digest of news and features. On its City pages, this features its shares 'worst tip': Freecom.net in, yes you've guessed, the Sunday Times, which over a three-month period plummeted 76.59 per cent from the point the paper had tipped it.

From the republican stable
Many congratulations to Simon Walker, director of communications at British Airways, who has been installed as the next communications secretary at Buck House, doing her maj's press releases and spinning all those damning stories about corgis and picture curators.

In keeping with the tradition, Walker's salary will be paid by BA for the duration of his post - which will be interesting given that BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, is from the land of Oz and, indeed, the House of Murdoch, both of which err on the side of republicanism.

As for HM the Q, we expect her air miles to reach the 'two return tickets to Alicante' level pronto.

webTitle: How to recover from a failure

fields.headline: How to recover from a failure
fields.trailText: 1 Recognise that having a blind spot about your own weaknesses is the worst mistake you can make. Remember the airline pilot whose staff were so scared of criticising him he crashed the plane, taking everybody with him.
fields.body:
1 Recognise that having a blind spot about your own weaknesses is the worst mistake you can make. Remember the airline pilot whose staff were so scared of criticising him he crashed the plane, taking everybody with him. Start accepting that all human beings have faults - including you - and begin learning from them. Ask yourself how you respond to criticism and when was the last time someone mentioned you might have a flaw. If it was in 1967, you may not - dare one say it? - be open to honest comments. Being able to discuss failures is a sign of strength and courage; crushing honesty is an indicator of fear.

2 Interpret your failures as a comment on your performance rather than as an indication of your value as a person. 'That way you remain mentally intact,' says personal skills trainer Terry Gillen. 'If you also regard it as a temporary state you get a more positive mindset. A lot of very successful business people have been bankrupt several times.'

3 Watch the reactions of great performers to setbacks. Tim Henman's response to his early Wimbledon defeat went along textbook lines. He faced up to reality, graciously accepted that Mark Philippoussis outplayed him on the day, said he would learn from the experience, restated his belief that he cold win the championship another year and went off for a break. Not only does he maintain his goals and self-esteem, he also wins friends.

4 Work out how you can avoid falling into that trap again. If you gave the wrong advice to a client or lost a customer, analyse how that failure occurred and what steps you could have taken to prevent it. You can rapidly become a great success story if you follow this road each time you trip up.

5 Avoid any temptation to indulge in a public guilt fest. Public breast-beatings are embarrassing to watch. Your colleagues are also more likely to take you at your word if you tell them you are an idiot. Unless you brought the company down with you, you should at the very least be able to say: 'Onward and upward: we'll do much better next time.' People are often willing to believe you if you deliver a positive message. And when you do have a success, they are often prepared, if you play your cards right, to say you were a genius all along. After years of gnashing of teeth, the England cricket team were treated as heroes this month when they beat the West Indies.

fields.headline: Games explosion hits small players
fields.standfirst: New platforms herald a $30bn market where winners could take all, writes Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: New platforms herald a $30bn market where winners could take all, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Blessed are the geeks, for they shall inherit the earth. Once, video-game designers were lampooned as unsociable anoraks who liked nothing better than sitting in crepuscular lofts writing lines of code. But now they are being feted as the Spielbergs of tomorrow, purveyors of electronically induced emotions to a discerning public desperate to spend billions of pounds on their gaming fix.

Worth nearly £1.8 billion a year, the video-games software market in the UK is already 1.8 times the size of the video rental industry, according to the European Leisure Software Publishers Association.

Analysts predict that the market is set to grow exponentially as the arrival of new technology starts to blur the barriers between films and video games, broadening the medium's appeal beyond the teenage market.

'You'll start to see episodic games, which change from week to week,' said Nick Gibson, games analyst with investment bank Durlacher. 'I'm sure the games manufacturers will start to borrow from the world of television.' Gibson predicts that the industry is about to enter a golden age, thanks largely to the introduction of new platforms such as Sony's PlayStation II and Microsoft's Xbox.

'These machines provide a fantastic new level of audiovisual experience, similar to TV,' says David Gardner, managing director of Electronic Arts Europe, the largest games manufacturer. 'This is the Holy Grail. We'll now be able to deliver what we have been promising.'

Analysts at Datamonitor predict that the global games-software market will be worth $11 billion (£7bn) this year. By 2003 it will be worth more than $17bn. Factor in the potential size of the interactive TV, internet and mobile-phone markets and it is easy to start predicting an industry worth $30bn in less than five years.

Gardner believes that the new technologies will combine to make the market grow exponentially. 'You may be playing online, then you'll go out with your mobile phone. You might get a message telling you that one of your characters is under attack. So you could type a couple of instructions and then when you get home start playing through your set-top box.'

He argues that the internet will provide a huge boost to the games industry, not just by offering a new method of distribution - some years off in his view - but in the way games can be promoted online. 'Record companies have the radio to promote their products; we'll have the internet,' Gardner says.

The internet will, Gardner believes, be a crucial driver in giving video games mass market appeal. But a lot of the groundwork for this has already been laid. Analysts point out that Sony's PlayStation opened up games to an older, more affluent market.

'Sony is a company that has huge marketing experience,' says Frederic Diot, senior analyst with Datamon itor. 'It was able to sell the idea of playing games. It used to have a geeky image but now it's cool to play. The industry has come out of the niche it was in five years ago. If you can create the right type of games, you can now appeal to anyone.'

But the costs of producing and marketing games are soaring, too. A couple of years ago a game would typically cost between £200,000 and £400,000 to develop. But these days, it is not unusual for a game to cost more than £1 million to bring to market. Some games - such as Sega's martial-arts epic Shenmue, due for launch this November - cost a staggering $20m to develop and market. In addition, many games are based on films - such as Infogrames' Mission Impossible - or are branded around sports stars, which means huge licensing fees.

As a result of this inflation the video-games industry is rapidly consolidating, as companies look to cut marketing and distribution costs. 'The biggest publishers are going to Hoover up the smaller publishers. The industry is very acquisitive,' Gibson says.

Currently Eidos, the UK firm behind the Tomb Raider series of games and valued at more than £500m, is the target of bid speculation. Infogrames, Electronic Arts and Vivendi subsidiary Havas have all been linked with the company. Eidos itself expanded by buying up small software houses and rebadging them.

But even if a bidder does not emerge for Eidos now, it is unlikely the company will retain its independence for long. It was forced into issuing two profit warnings in March when it became apparent that it was unable to shift as many games as it believed it could. Eidos's share price slumped by 40 per cent as a result.

Other companies are also finding the going tough. Infogrames picked up GT Interactive, which had been struggling for survival, while former software giant Acclaim is also in the doldrums.

'There are too many games coming out for the number of machines,' says Gardner. 'As a result there's some natural consolidation going on.'

One of the factors driving the current round of consolidation is consumer anticipation. As gamers wait for the launches of the new PlayStation and Xbox, they stop buying games made for the current consoles. This has allowed Sega to carve out market share for its Dreamcast model, although most analysts believe PlayStation II will prove the real winner in the long term.

'The games publishers are susceptible to the rhythms of the market. They are experiencing far more difficult trading conditions than they were when the market was at its apex a couple of years ago,' says Gibson.

Diot predicts more consolidation to come among the industry's 20 largest firms. 'In two or three years' time we will probably be only talking about five companies, who will control 60 per cent of the industry.'

Only the biggest companies can now afford to take the hit that comes when a game fails to sell. 'It's as expensive as video production,' says Gardner. 'And so the industry has the same dynamic as the film industry. Our top 10 games pay for our bottom 10 games.'

The implication is clear. Smaller companies can be wiped out if one of their games is a turkey. UK firm Gremlin, for example, which was eventually acquired by Infogrames, saw its share price collapse when a couple of its games failed to take off.

Roy Campbell, managing director of Infogrames UK, argues that further consolidation is vital if the industry is to have a wider appeal. 'We've got to drive the prices down,' he says. 'We have to get our products into the mass market, into places like grocery outlets, so that games can become impulse purchases.'

Games aficionados may blanch at this view, but Campbell says the games market can no longer be treated as a collection of cottage industries. 'The industry is not a charity case any more. Ten years ago it used to be run by hobbyists. But now it's Hollywood. Everyone is accountable. There are no hiding places.' As battered Eidos has found to its cost.

Beware geeks bearing new games consoles

When Sony launched its PlayStation II in Japan earlier this year, there was near rioting as shoppers scrambled to buy it. When the console is launched in Britain in the autumn, consumers will have to order in advance, because the company does not expect to be able to cope with demand.

The short history of the video games market is littered with examples of how the introduction of new technology creates seismic shifts in the industry.

In the Seventies the market was dominated by two US companies, Atari and Mattel, which both started out by making arcade games. But as Nick Gibson, analyst with Durlacher, noted in a recent report: 'The status quo changed in 1985 when Nintendo released its 8-bit Famicom console, and Sega released its Sega Master System in 1987.'

The two Japanese firms managed to see off the threat from their US rivals with the subsequent launch of 16-bit consoles, which were technically far superior, cheaper, and were able to offer consumers a wide choice of games.

But by 1994 the market was depressed as consumers waited for the launch of 32- and 64-bit games. Sony subsequently stole a lead with the launch of the original PlayStation, which has sold 75 million consoles worldwide.

Frederic Diot, senior analyst with Datamonitor, said: 'Nintendo has become complacent. And they've annoyed a lot of people in the industry. The Nintendo 64 has a high royalty charge, which has stopped a lot of people writing games for it. Sony's charge is much lower.'

Nintendo is hitting back with the launch of a new console, Dolphin, to be launched next year. But only around four games will be available at first, which worries analysts.

Sega, meanwhile, has launched the 128-bit Dreamcast console, which also gives internet access. Around 6 million consoles have been sold worldwide.

All eyes are now on Microsoft, which launches its X-box next year. The firm wants to price the device, which doubles as a DVD player, at around £200, a huge threat to Sony's dominance of the console market. While UK consumers wait before deciding what to buy, the market is expected to flatten out.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: A minor part of the Blair project has been to encourage taxpayers to file annual returns over the internet - proof that, even in our tax affairs, we are a modern nation. As an added incentive, those of us who complete a return and file by internet this year can get £10 off our tax bill.
fields.body:
A minor part of the Blair project has been to encourage taxpayers to file annual returns over the internet - proof that, even in our tax affairs, we are a modern nation. As an added incentive, those of us who complete a return and file by internet this year can get £10 off our tax bill.

But the politicians seem to have been flying faster than the software team at the Inland Revenue. The new filing system - unveiled last week - leaves a great deal to be desired. After you have navigated yourself out of the cul-de-sacs that seem to characterise the site, you will need to register (in the 'Filing on the internet' section) but, as Cash has already reported, the registration process has been suffering from glitches that you have to telephone the Revenue hotline to conquer. Once you have done this, you are theoretically in a position to file.

Now after months of fruitless work, the Revenue has had to ditch its own software and use a Microsoft system, TaxSaver iFile, instead. You are encouraged on the website to download the TaxSaver iFile programme - only to be told when you have that you need to get a CD-Rom from the Revenue before you can use it. This takes about a week by post.

The narrative in the website is badly written, clumsy, unclear and assumes that the reader is experienced on the net.

One useful part of the Inland Revenue site is its list of other sites which can help you file by the internet. It currently lists three - although it adds a disclaimer: 'The Inland Revenue has only tested the ability of a product to send a valid return and has not tested other features of the product.' Other names are likely to be added to this shortlist over the summer.

Top of the list now is the Consumers' Association service, taxcalc, which as well as giving you the basic software free, will also let you work out your tax liability so you can check it against the figure the Revenue comes up with. Since one in four Inland Revenue calculations is wrong, according to the Consumers' Association, this service could be well worth using - even if you do not file over the net.

The Inland Revenue procedures for calculating your own tax have got even more complicated over the past year. The IR calculation book has expanded from 5 to 29 pages. Another site aimed at accountants and other professionals is www.forbes-computers.co.uk. But you have to pay to download the software on this site - up to £290 plus VAT.

By contrast, The Tax Service - operating through www.tax.co.uk - is letting people download their software for free this year.

If, on the other hand, your tax affairs are in a difficult state and you are too poor to pay for professional advice, there is always TaxAid, the charity which helps the impoverished deal with the Inland Revenue. Its new site is a model of clarity in comparison with the Inland Revenue. Not only is it clear - it is also interesting. As well as explaining the way Working Families Tax Credit works, it also looks as such unexpected issues as 'Do taxpayers have human rights?'

www.taxaid.org.uk

www.taxaid.org.uk
