fields.headline: Another £10m? I shouldn't really...
fields.standfirst: But they do, says Bob Heller. UK chief executives trouser massive wealth with little opposition - and their merger games serve only to perpetuate the practice
fields.trailText: But they do, says Bob Heller. UK chief executives trouser massive wealth with little opposition - and their merger games serve only to perpetuate the practice.
fields.body:
Two sets of numbers have swollen gigantically over recent years: the king's ransoms paid in mergers and acquisitions, and the golden fortunes in 'compensation' thrust into the palms of top managers, above all chief executives.

The two phenomena are closely related - as Vodafone AirTouch's £10 million bonus for Chris Gent makes abundantly clear. This whopping sum is reward for masterminding Vodafone's £100 billion battle to take over Mannesmann, thus consolidating the British company's loftiness in the world telecoms league. A naive observer may think that Gent, with a mean million in salary, is already handsomely paid for his strategic mastery. Why does he deserve £10m extra for actually doing his job?

A less naive observer may note that relatively few mergers and acquisitions truly enrich shareholders, as many studies have established. Why is Gent receiving half his magnificent prize in cash before the Mannesmann merger has demonstrated whether it is the exception or the rule? There is one answer to both questions: top managers, aided and abetted by non-executive directors, can accumulate wealth, earned or unearned, with little let or hindrance.

By the same token, they can plunge into mega-mergers with fervour, backed by banks that are awash with capital. By a happy coincidence, the mega-mergers tend to boost the managerial moolah.

A giant worth £200bn should plainly pay its boss more than a mere £100bn midget would, shouldn't it? You can even justify this arithmetically. Willy-nilly, the chief executive must submit to massive pay to leave enough room to reward and retain lower executive ranks. The more the ranks, naturally, the higher the ceiling.

If that's hard to swallow, consider the distressing case of Marconi. The remuneration committee is 'aware that the company's current approach to share option grants is not sufficiently competitive to that provided by its US competitors which currently dominate the industries where the company operates'.

So Marconi is revising its scheme - which presumably means more goodies for chief executive Lord Simpson. His four-year take has already passed £14m. 'Onward and upward' is the top-pay motto as company after company, with no visible reluctance, engages in this lucrative game of leapfrog.

The rationale hinges on two unlikely propositions; first, that Gent, Simpson et al will scarper to other employment unless paid more; second, that their best efforts are forthcoming only because they get top whack.

The second proposition is insulting as well as absurd, since it implies that the recipient is a mercenary with no vision beyond his pay-packet.

Yet Jack Welch, super-manager of General Electric, and a stock option billionaire, was awarded an extra $42m, conditional on his meeting corporate targets in this, his final year. The idea of Welch, a far from extinct volcano, cooling off is laughable. Such payments have no rhyme and only one reason - to enrich the executive out of shareholders' pockets. So long as those pockets are enormously deep, nobody much cares.

There is specious logic in the notion that, if you 'create' billions in shareholder value, you should share in the loot. But chief executives do not create stock market wealth. Investors do that, by buying the shares. The chief executive's actions may or may not have triggered the enthusiasm by helping generate superior results. But note the 'helping'. Superior corporate performance, even GE's, is never a one-man bang.

Moreover, the traffic is almost entirely one way. Scores of billions have been wiped off the value of household names such as Procter & Gamble or Marks & Spencer and gee-whiz super-stars Amazon or Microsoft. Yet nobody would dream of suggesting that the bonuses and stock options of the boom years be offset. Will Vodafone demand a refund from Gent if his mega-merger disappoints?

Upsets can happen: Bernie Ebbers created WorldCom by multi-merging, but his empire looks vulnerable. Prices for voice and data transmis sion, the bread and butter (and jam) of telecoms, have been heading rapidly south, while the price of buying telecoms subscribers has been zooming north. If transmission becomes a dirt-cheap commodity, the merger-makers will have trouble covering the Himalayan cost of the debt and equity capital they have expended to rapturous applause.

Their financiers should, in theory, have been advising caution, while simultaneously acting as brakes on executive greed - shouldn't they? But bankers who live in billion-dollar glass houses daren't throw any stones. Their own fabulous rewards remove any right to criticise the pay of their clients. Naturally, their advice on M&A is entirely dispassionate - with no hint of self-seeking, of course. Yet their mega-fees, being linked to the value of deals, don't exactly offer a disincentive to mega-mergers.

It is true that after years of stock market underperformance financiers will demand chief executive heads here and there. They will also rise in righteous anger at really outrageous executive rewards. Yet several schemes have obnoxious, unopposed features such as linking pay to performance against competitors in the same industry. You cannot justify paying bonuses to people whose absolute performance may be awful, simply because they are the prettiest pigs in the sty.

As for lesser shareholders, they mostly applaud major mergers, on both sides of the deal. Even if they stay for the ride, investors rarely count the cost of failed amalgamations - and grotesque executive pay does less apparent damage to profits than grotty acquisitions. In the absence of genuine countervailing power, these great and worsening scandals will roll on regardless.

Governments could intervene - even outlaw stock options. But no American president or legislature will alienate their financial backers so needlessly; which means that Europeans can continue to plead the need to catch up with American rapacity. It's truly said that if you pay peanuts, you get monkeys. But if you let pussies pour the cream, all you get is very fat cats.

 Robert Heller's 'Riding the Revolution', written with Paul Spenley, is published by Harper Collins.

The two phenomena are closely related - as Vodafone AirTouch's £10 million bonus for Chris Gent makes abundantly clear. This whopping sum is reward for masterminding Vodafone's £100 billion battle to take over Mannesmann, thus consolidating the British company's loftiness in the world telecoms league. A naive observer may think that Gent, with a mean million in salary, is already handsomely paid for his strategic mastery. Why does he deserve £10m extra for actually doing his job? A less naive observer may note that relatively few mergers and acquisitions truly enrich shareholders, as many studies have established. Why is Gent receiving half his magnificent prize in cash before the Mannesmann merger has demonstrated whether it is the exception or the rule? There is one answer to both questions: top managers, aided and abetted by non-executive directors, can accumulate wealth, earned or unearned, with little let or hindrance. By the same token, they can plunge into mega-mergers with fervour, backed by banks that are awash with capital. By a happy coincidence, the mega-mergers tend to boost the managerial moolah. A giant worth £200bn should plainly pay its boss more than a mere £100bn midget would, shouldn't it? You can even justify this arithmetically. Willy-nilly, the chief executive must submit to massive pay to leave enough room to reward and retain lower executive ranks. The more the ranks, naturally, the higher the ceiling. If that's hard to swallow, consider the distressing case of Marconi. The remuneration committee is 'aware that the company's current approach to share option grants is not sufficiently competitive to that provided by its US competitors which currently dominate the industries where the company operates'. So Marconi is revising its scheme - which presumably means more goodies for chief executive Lord Simpson. His four-year take has already passed £14m. 'Onward and upward' is the top-pay motto as company after company, with no visible reluctance, engages in this lucrative game of leapfrog. The rationale hinges on two unlikely propositions; first, that Gent, Simpson et al will scarper to other employment unless paid more; second, that their best efforts are forthcoming only because they get top whack. The second proposition is insulting as well as absurd, since it implies that the recipient is a mercenary with no vision beyond his pay-packet. Yet Jack Welch, super-manager of General Electric, and a stock option billionaire, was awarded an extra $42m, conditional on his meeting corporate targets in this, his final year. The idea of Welch, a far from extinct volcano, cooling off is laughable. Such payments have no rhyme and only one reason - to enrich the executive out of shareholders' pockets. So long as those pockets are enormously deep, nobody much cares. There is specious logic in the notion that, if you 'create' billions in shareholder value, you should share in the loot. But chief executives do not create stock market wealth. Investors do that, by buying the shares. The chief executive's actions may or may not have triggered the enthusiasm by helping generate superior results. But note the 'helping'. Superior corporate performance, even GE's, is never a one-man bang. Moreover, the traffic is almost entirely one way. Scores of billions have been wiped off the value of household names such as Procter & Gamble or Marks & Spencer and gee-whiz super-stars Amazon or Microsoft. Yet nobody would dream of suggesting that the bonuses and stock options of the boom years be offset. Will Vodafone demand a refund from Gent if his mega-merger disappoints? Upsets can happen: Bernie Ebbers created WorldCom by multi-merging, but his empire looks vulnerable. Prices for voice and data transmis sion, the bread and butter (and jam) of telecoms, have been heading rapidly south, while the price of buying telecoms subscribers has been zooming north. If transmission becomes a dirt-cheap commodity, the merger-makers will have trouble covering the Himalayan cost of the debt and equity capital they have expended to rapturous applause. Their financiers should, in theory, have been advising caution, while simultaneously acting as brakes on executive greed - shouldn't they? But bankers who live in billion-dollar glass houses daren't throw any stones. Their own fabulous rewards remove any right to criticise the pay of their clients. Naturally, their advice on M&A is entirely dispassionate - with no hint of self-seeking, of course. Yet their mega-fees, being linked to the value of deals, don't exactly offer a disincentive to mega-mergers. It is true that after years of stock market underperformance financiers will demand chief executive heads here and there. They will also rise in righteous anger at really outrageous executive rewards. Yet several schemes have obnoxious, unopposed features such as linking pay to performance against competitors in the same industry. You cannot justify paying bonuses to people whose absolute performance may be awful, simply because they are the prettiest pigs in the sty. As for lesser shareholders, they mostly applaud major mergers, on both sides of the deal. Even if they stay for the ride, investors rarely count the cost of failed amalgamations - and grotesque executive pay does less apparent damage to profits than grotty acquisitions. In the absence of genuine countervailing power, these great and worsening scandals will roll on regardless. Governments could intervene - even outlaw stock options. But no American president or legislature will alienate their financial backers so needlessly; which means that Europeans can continue to plead the need to catch up with American rapacity. It's truly said that if you pay peanuts, you get monkeys. But if you let pussies pour the cream, all you get is very fat cats.  Robert Heller's 'Riding the Revolution', written with Paul Spenley, is published by Harper Collins.

fields.headline: Nation under the knife ...
fields.standfirst: Hate your neck, nose or tummy? Many Britons do - and more and more are choosing to do something surgical about it.  Jill Insley  and  Natalie Sutton  report
fields.trailText: Hate your neck, nose or tummy? Many Britons do - and more and more are choosing to do something surgical about it. Jill Insley and Natalie Sutton report.
fields.body:
How much are you prepared to spend on looking good? A fiver on a new mascara or lipstick? Twenty pounds on a moisturiser that will smooth out your wrinkles? Or £4,000 on a face lift to look a decade younger?

Sandra, a 55-year-old who works as a personal assistant in London, spent £3,500 on having the bridge of her nose shaved last autumn. 'I was staying in the US with friends who were crazy about cosmetic surgery. They'd all had something done, and encouraged me to see a surgeon about my nose. I was self-conscious about it - it was really big - and I've felt like that for most of my life.'

Delighted with her new, slim nose, Sandra now says she would consider further surgery. And she's not alone: demand for beauty treatments, both surgical and non-surgical, is soaring. According to market research company Verdict, Britons spent £634 million on cosmetics in 1999, a rise of 29.2 per cent since 1995, and £1,035m on skincare products, up 30.6 per cent over the same period. Fellow researcher Mintel, which has also delved into the facial skincare market, believes this is partly due to an increase in women over 40 who are prepared to spend more on expensive anti-ageing products, and partly because women now represent half the working population, have more disposable income and feel justified in spending it on skincare products and makeup so as to look good at work.

Cosmetic surgery specialists are reporting even bigger increases in business. The Harley Medical Group, one of the UK's biggest providers of cosmetic surgery, has seen a 32 per cent increase in operations year on year since last May.

Peter Coles, medical director at the Harley Medical Group, attributes the dramatic increase to the positive economy leading to greater affluence among potential patients, and the Millennium effect. 'Patients fall into two groups - those born with a genetic defect, and those who want surgery because of ageing . The latter group, who are older and have more disposable income, regarded the Millennium as a good time to have a face lift or a tummy tuck.'

But perhaps the biggest influence is a changed attitude to cosmetic surgery. Ten years ago, it was considered a luxury that only the rich and famous could afford. Now, says Coles, everyone goes in for it, and the ultimate goal is different. In many cases the problem is as much psychological as physical. 'Cosmetic surgery is not about looking mega-glamorous or having oodles of money to spend on yourself. The main emphasis is on looking normal, trying to remedy the problem that a patient perceives makes him or her look abnormal.'

Despite recent research indicating that men suffer from delusions that their physiques are better than they really are, increasing numbers of men are opting for cosmetic surgery. At the Pountney Clinic in West London, 25 per cent of the patients are men, while at the Harley Medical Group 40 per cent are men (compared with 5 per cent a decade ago).

And a quarter of these men are opting for penis extension operations, even though such operations have no effect on the performance or size of the erect penis.

'It's not usually the partner that's demand ing an increase in size,' says Coles. 'It's often young men in their twenties feeling inhibited about undressing in front of friends because they fear being ridiculed for the size of their penis. Such concerns take over patients' whole lives, even if they realise it is absurd. If you can break the psychological circle, you often have very happy patients.'

Cary Cooper, professor of occupational psychology and health at the University of Manchester Institute of Sci ence and Technology, says some people focus a desire to change their lives on their bodies. If only they could change their ears, nose, face or bottom, they would find it easier to make friends, get the job they want or find a lover.

'It can be a self-fulfilling prophecy,' says Cooper. 'If they have a treatment and it gives them confidence, they may be able to achieve the things they want. But in some cases it may prove a short-term solution, and ultimately they will have to tackle the deeper problem.'

Although the cost runs into thousands of pounds per operation (see table, page 5), patients are not just settling for one treatment.

In the US the average patient returns for seven procedures, and Coles says UK patients are showing similar tendencies. 'They may start off with a breast augmentation in their twenties, then when they start getting wrinkles they might consider laser treatment or collagen injections. Then, in their fifties, they may go for a facelift.'

Bill for beauty: £8,000 a year

Like many women, Suzannah argues that spending money on beauty treatments and haircare is necessary to maintain her confidence.

Her husband, James, is a successful businessman who is increasingly involved in local politics. Corporate entertainment plays an important part in his career. As his hostess, Suzannah, who is 33, insists that looking good is absolutely vital and is seen as 'part of the job'.

Being a full-time mother to two small children in the country doesn't afford her the time to be as well groomed as she would like but, ideally, she would visit the hairdresser for a cut and colour once a month, at £70, and would pay £12 for a blow-dry and styling before any important function, up to three times a week. She also likes weekly trips to the beauty salon for a manicure (£16), a facial (£40) and a relaxing massage (£27).

Fortnightly appointments are needed for pedicures (£20 a time), a fake-tanning session (£32) and eyebrow shaping (£5.50), with leg, bikini line and underarm waxing (£20). Her average annual expenditure on professional hair and beauty care is a staggering £8,196.

'It's all about being part of a team,' she says. 'If I look and feel good, I have the confidence to talk to people. It's a case of presenting a good image, which gives my husband extra credibility.'

Implant of confidence

Gill Walker decided cosmetic surgery would boost her confidence enough for her to look for a new job after the death of her husband three years ago.

Gill, 49, started by having collagen injections to fill out a few lines around her mouth and eyes. These worked well, recovery was instant and there was no need for an anaesthetic. But the effect only lasted for about three months, so she started having repeat treatments.

After a while, her nurse offered Gill Cooltouch laser treatment for her wrinkles free of charge, in return for having the process filmed for a television programme. This worked differently, gradually filling out the lines during the month following the treatment. Again the effects wore off.

Now she has opted for a permanent solution - soft implants looking like tiny tubes are pushed in along the line of the wrinkle. 'I had stitches, but there was no real puffiness. And you can have the implants taken out if you decide you don't like them. It probably means I don't have to go back for collagen, but I do anyway,' she says.

Gill acknowledges that other people probably think the treatments have made little perceptible difference to the way she looks. 'It does make a fractional difference to my face, but it makes a tremendous difference to the way I feel about myself. The thing is not to expect to look entirely different. It's not like a facelift where you lose 10 years, and you do have to have top-ups. But once you've seen what it can do for you, you become hooked.'

And has it helped her to find a job? 'Not yet,' she says.

Smile - you're worth it

When it comes to first impressions, your mouth can be a huge asset or your greatest liability. Recent research in the US shows that the first thing 63 per cent of people notice when meeting someone is their teeth and their smile.

Dr Phil Stemmer, dentist to celebrities such as Patsy Kensit, Liam Gallagher and All Saints, has seen a 60 per cent increase in the number of people wanting private cosmetic dentistry to improve their smiles during the past two years.

Treatments range from bleaching to whiten the teeth, closing gaps and replacing old amalgam fillings with the modern white versions, to crowns, porcelain veneers and titanium implants to form the root for a crown to replace a missing tooth.

Although some of the treatments do cost thousands of pounds - one recent patient, a market trader, spent £17,000 correcting his teeth - many cost a few hundred.

The results can be priceless. 'We've had people who've phoned us up after treatment to say they've found themselves new boy- or girlfriends and new jobs,' says Stemmer. It can be a tremendous confidence booster.'

However, the basis for all dentistry has to be a healthy mouth. He refuses to treat patients until they have cured any gum disease that could result in complications: 'There's no point in putting a diamond in a sea of disease. We recommend that affected patients visit a dental hygienist, floss, brush their teeth and use an alcohol-free mouthwash.'

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Grampian Holdings | BAE | Lasmo | TR Property Investment Trust
fields.body:
Check out Grampian Holdings, the Edinburgh Woollen Mill and Malcolm transport and warehousing group.

Over the past fortnight, Grampian's shares have lost all the gains made since mid-April, when the firm announced plans to break itself up. The reason is clear: poor trading has made the task much tougher. Also, an impatient market has been expecting miracles to happen as of yesterday.

The likelihood, still, is that Grampian won't be around in its present form to announce this year's results next April.

The Edinburgh Woollen Mill chain is suffering from a weak high street, but broker Seymour Pierce believes new formats for the stores are doing well.

Malcolm's warehousing, transport and logistics operation, meanwhile, are healthy and look attractive to buyers.

At 71p, the shares stand way below broker Charterhouse's 120p break-up value. City adviser Deutsche Bank is not going to pull rabbits out of hats overnight, but the shares look attractive on a one-year view.

BAE flies low

This newspaper's report of possible bid interest in BAE Systems, the old British Aerospace, from the ubiquitous Nomura was a talking point in the City a couple of weeks ago. And it produced no small amount of sneers and giggles from the BAE camp, too.

The shares have gained nearly 50 per cent since March, as the market reversed its pessimistic view of the price BAE paid for Marconi last year. Of late, the formation at last of the new Airbus Industrie Company (AIC) has given BAE a welcome fillip.

The AIC deal is worth an extra £1.1 billion to BAE in terms of synergies, dividends and reduced liabilities, according to latest research from broker Salomon Smith Barney. Yet the shares, at 415p, are still nowhere near even last year's 480p high.

On the basis of a 12-month target price of 585p, Salomon's Nick Cunningham rates the shares as a buy.

Oil going cheap

With Saudi Arabia moving to boost oil production, you would expect shares in independents such as Lasmo and Enterprise to take a tumble along with the oil price. And so last week, they did - to a small extent.

The question now is whether the UK twins have further to fall. Or, with the oil price still hovering around $30 a barrel, whether this year's recovery in the shares of both went far enough in the first place.

Broker Old Mutual comes out categorically in favour of the latter view. At 519p, Enterprise is trading at 70 per cent of the broker's 738p estimate of net present value (NPV) using a long-term crude price of just $18. A limited recovery in the shares may yet see Enterprise restored to the FTSE-100 index in September.

As for Lasmo, at 135p, the shares are trading on an underlying earnings multiple of less than eight times - against 20-30 for its US peers - and a huge discount to estimated NPV of 226p per share.

Enterprise, of course, failed in its bid, but there are lots of highly rated rivals which may be attracted by Lasmo's 1.2bn barrels of reserves at a knockdown price.

Land a catch

This column has been rather overweight in the property market of late. What better time, then, to highlight TR Property Investment Trust, which has an attractive £370 million portfolio of holdings in the sector.

At 52.5p, TRPIT's shares trade at an 18 per cent discount to its latest net asset value: 63.9p last month. But according to broker Merrill Lynch, after taking into account revaluations in the pipeline and the healthy balance sheet, TRPIT's 'enterprise value' (equity plus debt) stands at a huge 48 per cent discount to assets. So buy.

webTitle: Robin Reliant rescuer in Jersey legal battle

fields.headline: Robin Reliant rescuer in Jersey legal battle
fields.standfirst: Billionaire Kevin Leech is embroiled  in a bitter feud over loans, writes Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Billionaire Kevin Leech is embroiled in a bitter feud over loans, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
It is a tale of Dynasty meets Only Fools and Horses, set in the land of Bergerac. On Thursday, the latest twist in an increasingly bitter legal spat between one of the UK's most colourful self-made billionaires (who has more than a passing interest in the Robin Reliant) and the family of his former business partner will be played out in a Channel Islands court room.

Jersey financier Kevin Leech, who made his first millions in biotechnology before building up an estimated £1.3bn fortune through a series of internet investments, is being sued for alleged mismanagement of the assets of a private company in which he has a majority stake. As a result of the legal action brought by the Milner family against Leech, assets in Milner Laboratories have been frozen.

The Milner family claims Leech was loaned nearly £60m of Milner's funds on uncommercial terms. They argue that the money was loaned at only 1 per cent above the bank rate, had no date set for repayment and had no security. It is understood that Leech will dispute all of these claims.

The case is bound to attract interest because Leech has also shot to prominence in recent years as an arch campaigner in favour of keeping the UK's heritage out of foreign hands. Four years ago Leech, who quit accountancy training to build up one of the UK's biggest chain of funeral parlours, bought both Land's End and John o'Groat's in the same week. He followed this with the £1.3m acquisition of the Snowdon Mountain Railway two years later. More recently he ploughed money into reviving Reliant Cars, his investment helping the company develop a new range of vehicles.

Leech's ability to fund these new projects owes much to a chance meeting with Jeremiah Milner, an inventor who patented a new form of dialysis technique. Leech helped Milner out with a £50,000 loan and subsequently ploughed a further £700,000 into their company, ML Laboratories, which floated in 1987. By the middle of 1996, ML Laboratories was valued at more than £600m. Today the company, in which Leech has a 53 per cent stake, is worth a fraction over £250m.

Milner Laboratories, a private company separate from ML Laboratories, was set up by Leech in conjunction with Milner, to look after their business interests. Some of the pair's windfall from the flotation was subsequently channelled into Milner Laboratories and used for investment purposes, chiefly in property.

But following his death, Milner's 32 per cent stake in Milner Laboratories passed to his family. The remaining 68 per cent share is owned by Leech. But lawyers acting for Jeremiah's widow, 73-year-old Ellen Milner, who has three children all thought to be in their thirties, alleged last Monday that the accounts of Milner Laboratories revealed 'mismanagement of assets within the company'. In addition to suing Leech, she is also suing Milner Laboratories and its two other directors.

Jersey financier Kevin Leech, who made his first millions in biotechnology before building up an estimated £1.3bn fortune through a series of internet investments, is being sued for alleged mismanagement of the assets of a private company in which he has a majority stake. fields.headline: Lyons faces MSF showdown
fields.trailText: Embattled union boss Roger Lyons faces a bitter showdown this week with members who want to see him sacked from the Manufacturing Science and Finance Union.
fields.body:
Embattled union boss Roger Lyons faces a bitter showdown this week with members who want to see him sacked from the Manufacturing Science and Finance Union.

Members of the Kingston and District branch of the MSF will meet on Wednesday to demand the dismissal of general secretary Lyons and head of finance Nelson Mendes.

The motion follows an industrial tribunal hearing at which Lyons was accused of adding £14,000 to his annual salary by fiddling expenses and receiving cheques from fake union branches.

Last Friday the MSF agreed to pay £50,000 to secretary Marcia Solomon - who claimed she was unfairly dismissed for blowing the whistle on Lyons - after the proceedings were unexpectedly halted on Thursday before the tribunal ruled on the case.

But members of the Kingston and district MSF branch are expected to support a motion this Wednesday calling for Lyons to go. The motion will then be taken to the union's London Regional Council next Saturday. After that it will go to the MSF's national executive committee, where Lyons could be forced to leave.

When informed of the members' intentions by The Observer, Lyons said he would go to the meeting to answer questions. He added: 'There is no truth whatsoever in these allegations '.

Bob Shankey, member of the Kingston branch and treasurer of the London Regional Council, said: 'I am not impressed by the outcome of the tribunal. Lyons should do the honourable thing and resign from the MSF immediately.'

fields.headline: Asprey joins the street-smart set
fields.standfirst: The jeweller is set for the Hilfiger treatment, says Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: The jeweller is set for the Hilfiger treatment, says Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Ali G will be beside himself. The cult comedy icon, known for his love of Tommy Hilfiger designer hats and chunky, gold rings, has a brand new haunt - and, boy, is it classy.

The two financiers behind Tommy Hilfiger, one of the world's most successful designer labels, stunned the rarefied Bond Street retailing scene last week by paying £100 million for the former Royal jeweller, Asprey & Garrard.

A favourite of the late Diana, Princess of Wales, not to mention Posh Spice, the jeweller could soon be opening its doors to a wave of 'gangsta' rappers who have associated themselves with the 'designer street' style that Hilfiger has cultivated.

Asprey & Garrard was sold to Lawrence Stroll and Silas Chou, co-chairmen of Tommy Hilfiger, because its former owner, the Sultan of Brunei's oil-rich investment vehicle, was in trouble after huge losses were run up by the Sultan's younger brother, the spectacularly decadent Prince Jefri Bolkiah.

The London business world has for the past two years been buzzing with the news that the Sultan was listening to offers for some or all of his business empire in a bid to recoup some of the £12 billion the Sultan, once the world's richest man, is said to have lost thanks to the Asian economic crisis and his spendthrift brother.

The Sultan's interests in London include the Dorchester and Adelphi Hotels, a string of Grade I-listed office blocks including Terry Farrell's Embankment Place building above Charing Cross station and Asprey & Garrard, which Prince Jefri bought in 1995 for £243m.

But with the jewellery business haemorrhaging cash - its last accounts, for the year to March 1999, reveal losses of £100m - Asprey & Garrard was first to go.

The Hilfiger pair earlier this year nearly bought a substantial stake in Bernie Ecclestone's Formula One business. But following the failure of the Hilfiger consortium - which included the Benetton family and Morgan Grenfell - to reach agreement with Ecclestone, Stroll and Chou were on the lookout for a prestigious investment.

Stroll and Chou helped plot the dynamic growth of the Tommy label, having discovered Hilfiger in New York in the Eighties. The designer started selling jeans in upstate New York in the early Seventies. His first solo collection came in 1984, and in 1992 the company went public.

Lucrative profits have followed, thanks to astute marketing that made sure Hilfiger clothes would appeal to all races and classes - and the use of cheap overseas labour to make the threads.

Five years ago, net revenue was £213m and gross profits were £97m. Tommy's latest results, published this year, show revenue up to £1.1bn with gross profits at £506m.

Stroll, son of a Montreal childrenswear manufacturer, cashed in on his connection with Hilfiger when, in 1998, he sold his licences to make Tommy Hilfiger clothes back to the designer for close to £200m. Although still a Canadian citizen, Stroll now lives in Britain and collects Italian sports cars.

With other Tommy directors, Stroll and Chou, whose background is in the Hong Kong textile trade, have simultaneously built up the Pepe jeans label.

Asprey & Garrard's new owners were quick to form a board which mixed upmarket retail experience with blue-blooded establishment figures. On board are: Nicholas Soames, the rotund Tory MP and former equerry of Prince Charles; Sir Jocelyn Stevens, former chairman of English Heritage; and David Tang, the Hong Kong developer.

Together they will plot how to 'return lustre' to the Asprey & Garrard name. First on the list will be restoring the 'Crown Jeweller' cachet which the store lost when Prince Jefri merged Asprey and Garrard two years ago.

The shop has satellite stores in New York's Trump Tower and in Beverly Hills. Other stores are sure to follow. One Asprey insider says the new owners want to open in Paris and Milan, as well as two more in Britain - possibly Manchester and Edinburgh.

Such expansion is risky. Part of the cachet of historic, stores such as Harrods, Hamley's and Asprey is their uniqueness. A visit means traipsing to just one destination. If the brand is expanded, there is a chance that its unique appeal could be diluted. But others think that the pizzazz that the Hilfiger marketeers can bring to Asprey will see it triumph.

Former managers say the shop has slumped because there are fewer people prepared to spend more than £10,000 on a single item than in previous decades.

But it is hard to ignore the conspicuous consumption on display in several parts of London these days. Earlier this year, when bonuses for the City financiers were unveiled, stories abounded of cash payments made for flash cars, luxurious holidays and jewellery. Asprey made great play of the City boss who paid £30,000 for 10 solid-silver computer mice as a thank-you to his underlings.

With the perception that prosperity will continue, Asprey & Garrard should be in a position to pounce. The only thing to worry the store's new owners is the idea of Ali G and his gangsta crew scaring off the aristocracy.

webTitle: 'Clear the jams - or it's no new buses'

fields.headline: 'Clear the jams - or it's no new buses'
fields.trailText: Britain's bus giants are threatening to freeze billions of pounds of investment in new vehicles unless the Government increases spending and does more about road congestion.
fields.body:
Britain's bus giants are threatening to freeze billions of pounds of investment in new vehicles unless the Government increases spending and does more about road congestion.

Three of the UK's four leading bus companies, Stagecoach, Arriva and Go-Ahead, said there was 'no point' investing in state-of-the-art £145,000 buses if they were just going to sit in traffic.

The Government will publish its 10-year transport spending plans later this month.

The bus companies are demanding increased spending on measures such as bus lanes, and better strategies for keeping traffic moving. The bus and coach industry spends £500 million a year on new vehicles, mostly buses for public transport services.

Veronica Palmer, director-general of the Confederation of Passenger Transport, which represents private-sector operators, said: 'If the Government does not come up with matching investment for infrastructure, each company is likely to review its own investment.'

The CPT wants a 10-year total of £7.8 billion of Government funding, a 70 per cent increase over the last decade.

webTitle: You can fill in the blanks

fields.headline: You can fill in the blanks
fields.standfirst: Tate Britain goes overboard for new art with its biggest ever show. Though half of it is white space...
fields.trailText: Intelligence: New British Art 2000
fields.body:
Intelligence: New British Art 2000 Tate Britain, London SW1, 24 September

It's the largest show ever put on by the Tate. Intelligence is bigger than Cézanne, bigger than Jackson Pollock, even bigger than the show that precedes it, which united Turner, Ruskin and the full pre-Raphaelite team in a gridlock of crowded galleries. It is also the first in a series of triennial shows at Tate Britain, surveys of the newest and best that might put the event on a par with the much-attended Whitney Biennial in New York.

If all this makes you rub your hands in anticipation, like a cineaste at the start of a festival, bear in mind that there are only 22 artists on show: the rest is pristine white space.

Not that this is just any old space. Intelligence has been designed by Adam Caruso of St John Caruso, architects of the stunning New Art Gallery in Walsall. Caruso has transformed several acres of the Tate into a minimalist variation on the old beaux-arts museum, where all the rooms emerge from a lofty central hall so that nobody ever gets lost.

There are no dark mazes, no bottlenecks, no confusion of sound bleeding from one video-room to the next. Gillian Wearing's film is shown in a comfortable arthouse cinema; the stench of Sarah Lucas's scorched cars is dispersed in a gallery as big as a ballpark. From the cushy sofas to the flowers in the foyer, arranged by the WI, everything is calculated to put the visitor at ease, to soften the ordeal of contemporary art.

This turns out to be entirely consistent with the mission of the show itself. The curators of Intelligence are eager to include each and every visitor in the business of art. They believe in mutual dialogues, equal partnerships and so forth between the artists and their public. Although this doesn't extend to a halfway literate essay in the catalogue, it is a more than honourable aim. The curators don't want us to stand about passively absorbing the shock of the new, they want to encourage active viewers.

Julian Opie makes a feature of your very presence by turning the first room into a full-scale pastiche of a gallery. The walls are hung with generic pictures - a portrait, a still life, a reclining nude - generated by computer and reproduced in vinyl on metal billboards. Toy spectators are posted about the room, making the didactic point that no show is complete without its audience, an idea more subtly reprised in Mark Lewis's video eulogy to the 'silent proletariat' of overlooked bystanders who complete the cast in so many movies.

Alan Johnston invites you to project your own images into the ghostly frames he has sketched on the walls, a gambit rather less witty than the original Seventies text piece, 'Is it possible for me to do nothing as my contribution to this show?' Bob and Roberta Smith - aka Patrick Brill - hand the pencil directly to you. Every week, Brill will choose from among your slogans, painting his favourites on Caruso's white walls. As an incentive, he has supplied a few of his own - 'Eat British Meat', 'Peas are the New Beans' - presumably on the basis that every passing child could do better.

This is the snag with Intelligence: the title is such a hostage to fortune that you can't help wondering whether some of the art amounts to a facetious response. Hilary Lloyd's video, for example, shows a grown woman struggling like Sisyphus to erect a house of cards. Douglas Gordon lists the names of everyone he can remember meeting so far, an essay, he alleges, on the nature of memory. But is Gordon's memory good or bad? He's the only one who knows or cares.

All group shows have their bald patches, generally when the art has been tailored to fit the curatorial values or vice versa. The best work here has nothing to with equal partnerships, information gathering or the artist as secret agent, one of the more ludicrous notions in the catalogue. It is simply intelligent in its own right.

Graham Gussin has bought some dry ice, released it in a disused warehouse and filmed its gradual dispersal on shadowy black-and-white stock. The vapour steals through the building like the fog in Dickens's Bleak House , ebbing through the abandoned rooms, unfurling down the staircase. Sometimes it looks as still as the white mists in Romantic painting; then it continues to haunt the place with its presence. The transition between art and fiction, between framed image and fluid narrative, has been beautifully choreographed.

If you missed Susan Hiller's Witness, installed in a derelict London chapel last month, you have another chance to experience this mysterious event at Tate Britain. Based on first-hand accounts of inexplicable sightings that Hiller has recorded over the years, relayed through a hanging garden of tiny speakers, the piece gradually comes to feel like a phenomenal visitation in itself.

Gillian Wearing's film is also based on an eyewitness account, in this case her own encounter with a street drunk in south London. Wearing filmed this handsome woman talking with all the theatrical dignity of a stage star. You see this footage in grainy slo-mo, out of sequence with the sound of her voice describing the recent death of her twin sister from alcohol. It only becomes apparent at the end of the film that sound and vision are more profoundly divided. The voice belongs to the surviving twin: the woman you were watching is no longer alive.

Wearing has never made a better or more affecting film. Indeed, Intelligence includes some of the best work yet from several of these artists. There is a larger quota of duds and duffers, of course, but it doesn't begin to reach the sensational proportions you get at the Whitney Biennial. The Tate's first triennial is not a bit controversial in this or any other respect and it is all the better for it.

webTitle: Eyre we go, Eyre we go...

fields.headline: Eyre we go, Eyre we go...
fields.standfirst: Genteel Cheltenham sees dark passions run riot in Michael Berkeley's brooding new opera
fields.trailText: Jane Eyre |  Piotr Anderszewski | BBC Philharmonic
fields.body:
Jane Eyre Music Theatre Wales, Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham

Piotr Anderszewski Pittville Pump Room, Cheltenham, Radio 3

BBC Philharmonic Town Hall, Cheltenham

To dare to compress an epic Victorian novel into a short, taut opera with only five characters requires a touch of madness. When the book in question is Jane Eyre, that might prove an asset. Mrs Rochester up in the attic may be the one who is certified insane, but Mr Rochester and Jane herself are not averse to morbid imaginings and distinctly odd behaviour.

Pooling fantasies and talents, the composer Michael Berkeley and the Australian novelist David Malouf have reduced Charlotte Brontë's masterpiece to a two-act chamber opera, stripping away most of the action and leaving only the tell-tale heart of the matter.

Jane and Rochester's love is the fire which kills the unwanted, but in truth almost harmless and pathetic, Creole wife who stands in their way. The admirably sparse libretto covers a handful of pages. The music, insistent in its dark turbulence, lasts under two hours. Yet in the process of reduction, aspects of the story, mere shadows in the original, have been exposed anew.

We all assume we know Jane Eyre. How refreshing to be reminded that Brontë's moral world is far more tangled and uncertain than most of us, reading it first as adolescents, ever imagined.

The opera received its world premiere on the opening night of the 56th Cheltenham International Festival of Music in a strong staging by Michael McCarthy and conducted by Michael Rafferty at the intimate Everyman Theatre.

Having promoted the performance of more than 100 new works in his six years as the festival's director, Berkeley has surely earned the right to launch the current season with a work of his own. (This was sponsored by private funding raised with Music Theatre Wales, which takes the work on tour in the autumn, and kept separate from the rest of the festival, before anyone quibbles.)

Doors, mirrors, windows, reflections and screens in Richard Alwin's set reveal and disclose, double and distort, the chilling secrets of Thornfield.

That this version of Jane Eyre exists at all is a feat. This was the piece, you may recall, which in its unfin ished manuscript state was stolen from outside Berkeley's house. The ensuing mental crisis, the thought that harsh fate might have intervened, the sense of a second chance while reworking, all may yet fuel a future opera.

None the less, the reconstructed work was finished on schedule. Written for 13 instruments, the score has numerous echoes of Britten, the composer's godfather, whom he has always openly cited as an inspiration. In scale and atmosphere, The Turn of the Screw is never far away. Nor, in the relationship between vocal line and ensemble and in erotic mood, is Debussy's Pelléas et Mélisande.

Berkeley makes the music, full of alluring glissandi, work hard to carry the drama. Silences are used to dramatic effect. Rochester's music, like the wavering man himself, is caught between two women, at times echoing or repeating Jane's phrasing, at others, Mrs Rochester's. On occasion, he is pincered neatly and suggestively between the two as the music replicates the shape-changing mirrors of the set.

A saucy Parisian waltz and a snatch of Donizetti offset the terse chromaticism of Berkeley's score, in which he moves impressively beyond the brighter lyricism of his music to date.

In the title role, Natasha Marsh headed a well-chosen cast, with excellent playing by the Music Theatre Wales ensemble.

Cheltenham's first weekend was also enlivened by the festival's artist in residence, the mesmerising Polish-born pianist, Piotr Anderszewski, whose account of Mozart's Piano Concerto No 20 in D minor K466 shone with revelation. To describe a performance as dramatic can imply hectic overactivity. In Anderszewski's case, it meant a subtle but intense exchange between soloist and orchestra, between statement of theme and development, woodwind and strings, major and minor.

The operatic Mozart was ever present, each instrument a character, each key change a twist in the plot. At first, this seemed mannered. Most pianists strive for surface sheen rather than this kind of fascinating, some times knobbly texture. But it soon became clear that his playing was impelled by integrity rather than show.

The BBC Philharmonic, conducted by Jaap van Zweden, gave sympathetic and restrained support in a programme which allowed them full rein elsewhere. Few works come much noisier, especially in Cheltenham Town Hall's lively acoustic, than Tchaikovsky's Romeo and Juliet overture and Prokofiev's Suite No 2 on the same subject.

With brass and percussion also going full blast in the premiere of a new version of James MacMillan's Exsultet , a stirring, rhythmically peppy ascent through the register from low to high, this was an energetic evening all round.

Anderszewski was the pianist who, in the 1990 Leeds Piano Competition, left the stage in the middle of a performance of Webern's Variations Opus 27 because he was dissatisfied with his own playing. Fortunately, he must have felt more cheerful about his astonishing account of Beethoven's Diabelli Versions Opus 120 which he played at Cheltenham's other main venue, the Pittville Pump Room, in a recital last Thursday.

Despite exhalations and grunts in the manner of Glenn Gould, whom in some respects he resembles, his performance had one message which sets him apart from other pianists. Comparable performers in control and technique (and they are few) often seem to say: 'Listen to me.' Anderszewski's whole demeanour, however, gives one simple command: 'Listen to the music.' This vital distinction is all too rarely made real.
fields.bodyText: Jane Eyre Music Theatre Wales, Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham Piotr Anderszewski Pittville Pump Room, Cheltenham, Radio 3 BBC Philharmonic Town Hall, Cheltenham To dare to compress an epic Victorian novel into a short, taut opera with only five characters requires a touch of madness. When the book in question is Jane Eyre, that might prove an asset. Mrs Rochester up in the attic may be the one who is certified insane, but Mr Rochester and Jane herself are not averse to morbid imaginings and distinctly odd behaviour. Pooling fantasies and talents, the composer Michael Berkeley and the Australian novelist David Malouf have reduced Charlotte Brontë's masterpiece to a two-act chamber opera, stripping away most of the action and leaving only the tell-tale heart of the matter. Jane and Rochester's love is the fire which kills the unwanted, but in truth almost harmless and pathetic, Creole wife who stands in their way. The admirably sparse libretto covers a handful of pages. The music, insistent in its dark turbulence, lasts under two hours. Yet in the process of reduction, aspects of the story, mere shadows in the original, have been exposed anew. We all assume we know Jane Eyre. How refreshing to be reminded that Brontë's moral world is far more tangled and uncertain than most of us, reading it first as adolescents, ever imagined. fields.headline: Flavor of the month
fields.standfirst: Flavor Flav's new album has no cussin' on it. Have the hands of his clock finally moved on?
fields.trailText: Flavor Flav
fields.body:
With his oversized clock swinging around his neck, gold teeth blinking malevolently, Flavor Flav was the clown prince of rap music. He and Chuck D were the Muhammad Ali and Malcolm X of Eighties America, the lovable joker and the prophet of doom joined together in the single greatest rap group of all time - Public Enemy.

'C'mon, Chuck, show 'em what time it is,' Flav would yell, pointing to his clock. In Reagan's ultra-conservative America, with a black generation suddenly held under the sway of the Nation of Islam, Flavor Flav's flexed forefinger seemed to point to impending revolution.

Twelve years on from Public Enemy's heyday - the release of their second album, It Takes a Nation of Millions To Hold Us Back - Chuck D is still fighting a war, this time on the internet against the record conglomerates of America. But whatever happened to his sidekick, Flavor Flav? Well, he's back - and this time he's serious... sort of.

A few days before interviewing him, I contacted an old Flav acquaintance, Cecil Brown. The 54-year-old author and tutor at the University of Oakland has known Flav (real name, William Drayton) for almost 20 years.

I asked him whether the rapper's famous madcap eccentricity is real or just a marketable persona. Brown chortled softly down the phone line, and narrated an early Drayton misadventure.

Just prior to joining Public Enemy in 1985, Drayton was given a job on a local FM station in New York, doing the breakfast show. The untried DJ arrived fresh with excitement on his first day, locking himself into the sound-room. His debut performance stunned the station's already meagre audience; for three hours, New York area listeners were subjected to the grinding sounds of trains passing through Penn Street station. He'd edited the sounds together the night before. Drayton was dismissed, but not before station bosses broke down the studio door to confiscate his equipment.

In Public Enemy, Drayton's job description was, essentially, jester. A seven-album career with the group has often seen his contribution deprecated by critics - few recall more than his chorus chants: 'Yo, Chuck! Give it to 'em one more time' and 'Hurt 'em, Chuck, hurt 'em' are now widely regarded as Drayton's artistic zeniths.

But a glance over the group's back catalogue indicates moments of depth. 'Cold Lampin' With Flavor', from It Takes a Nation of Millions To Hold Us Back , '911 Is A Joke', from 1989's Fear of a Black Planet and 'What Kinda Power We Got' from 1994's Muse Sick-N-Hour Mess Age all hint at a lyrical dexterity that goes beyond buffoonery. Current rap stars such as Busta Rhymes and Ol' Dirty Bastard have described Flav as a formative influence.

Drayton's solo debut, the double A-side single, 'Git On Down/The Hot 1', will be released in the United States next week and followed by an album, It's About Time? , which will finally bring Flav the acclaim he deserves (the discriminating New York rap press have already lauded it). And controversy. Despite contractual threats from his record company, Drayton has refused to punctuate the record with expletives. The album is being released without the near-mandatory 'Parental Advisory' sticker. 'Cussin' is bad,' he pronounces, fingering his clock. 'Other rappers be talking all kinds of garbage - denigrating women and children and even their moms. Flav is chic - he knows how to respect a lady. Use a bad word once and people take notice. Use it a hundred times and your feelings lose all their energy. Flav ain't about to do that.'

Interviewing Drayton is no easy task. Sitting at the Royal Kensington Hotel in London, he is agitated, rarely dwelling upon one strand of thought for more than a few seconds. Periods of crack abuse in the late Eighties have been blamed for his lack of concentration. At 34, Drayton, a weekend father to three children, still wears a baseball cap and sunglasses and flashes those famous gold teeth, cackling at the reaction they provoke. Drayton always refers to himself as Flav. I'm re-minded of comedian Jerry Lewis, who often separates himself from his Hollywood persona, the Kid.

'Right now, you're interviewing Flavor Flav,' he says. 'William Drayton is nowhere to be seen. I tried to strangle that part of my character. He saw some awful shit growing up - Flav was his escape.'

I'm not entirely sure if he's serious. Half an hour earlier, while having his portrait taken in an underground car-park, Flav the joker was in full flow. 'Yo! Brrhan,' he yelled. 'What kind of name is that? Is you an Aye-Rab?'

I politely informed him the name is, in fact, Arabic in origin, but that my parents are Pakistani. Flav pondered my nationality for no more than a second.

'How many wives can I get in Arabia?' he asked. 'Five? Shee-it! I'm gonna change my nationality.'

Back upstairs, he rolls a cigarette between his fingers, and offers a rare moment of insight. 'I was a loner at school,' he mumbles. 'Never had too many friends; always on my own. Got into trouble a lot - only 'cos I wanted to make an impression. So Flavor was born - he's larger than life. Too big for this room even to contain.' And with that, he's off, racing down the hallway.

As I leave the hotel, he catches my arm. 'Wha's a good book to read?' I recommend Ralph Ellison's Juneteenth , an unfinished novel resurrected by his publisher last summer.

'I'll git that,' says Drayton. He probably won't. I imagine his mind is chaotic enough without the added clutter of books.

 Flavor Flav plays the Brighton Essential Festival on16 July

webTitle: Alistair Cooke - he's just so decadent

fields.headline: Alistair Cooke - he's just so decadent
fields.trailText: How Jazz Came To Britain | Modern Jazz Classics | Guesses At Most | Slow Train To Woking
fields.body:
How Jazz Came To Britain R4

Modern Jazz Classics R2

Guesses At Most R3

Slow Train To Woking R4

He has been the grand old man of radio for so long - he'll be 92 in November, but whenever there's a Radio 4 personality poll he still comes top - that it's difficult to imagine Alistair Cooke having a mother, let alone one who bursts into tears.

So what, back in the summer of 1931, when her lad was still a Cambridge undergraduate, made Mrs Cooke sob? Well, I think it was Louis Armstrong, but since Charles Chilton presenting How Jazz Came To Britain failed, irritatingly, to give us the name of the tune that had such a devastating effect on her, I'm only guessing.

Here's the story. Cooke ordered a record from his local gramophone shop. It took ages to arrive so when it did he raced home, hustled it on to the turntable and the moment that trumpet took off like a supersonic plane Cooke was hooked, as he still is, on jazz.

Not so his mum who like the majority of her generation viewed the new black music craze from the American South with deep suspicion. Jazz was equated with two adjectives: negroid and decadent. Magistrates often ascribed the rise of petty theft and illegitimate births to the influence of the saxophone and when, the following year, Louis Armstrong made his debut at the London Palladium, half the audience walked out in disgust.

It was as if today, recalls Cooke, a mother had seen her son nonchalantly take out a needle and give himself a shot of heroin. It scared the wits out of her. That trumpet intro has the same effect on me as on Alistair so if anyone knows what it's called, please advise soonest. The only clues are the saxophonist sounds like Paul Desmond in The Dave Brubeck Quartet, the vocalist singing 'Wah Dabble Doodah Wah Da Dooday' sounds like an Inkspot and someone is playing the spoons.

Talking of Brubeck, over on Radio 2 Branford Marsalis has got as far as 'Take Five 'in his Modern Jazz Classics series. I'm so used to listening to Julian Joseph's slightly professorial way of presenting jazz on Radio 3 - his tribute to Gil Evans last Friday was a case in point - that Marsalis and Chilton's shirt-sleeved approach struck a new chord.

Brubeck sounds as gruff, folksy and lovable as Uncle Remus. It wasn't easy, he says, trying to get Columbia Records to enthuse about his odd five-four time signatures to which no one could dance. The tempo for 'Blue Rondo a la Turk', the b-side of 'Take Five', he first heard from a street musician in Istanbul. 'I've just heard this great rhythm - tye tye tye ta ta ta,' he said and immediately the band started to improvise.

I am so used to actor Bill Nighy reading Martin Amis books on Radio 4 with the casual arrogance that exactly suits the Amis persona that for one panicky moment, hearing that familiar weary voice in the Radio 3 drama slot, I thought we were in for a heavy dose of male menopause counselling. No such luck as it turned out.

Nighy played Stan the anti-hero of Doug Lucie's first radio play Guesses At Most. Stan is the failed husband and a sworn enemy of two middle-class sisters whose disappointed lives made me want to top myself. Is life really as hopeless as Lucie makes out? No wonder Stan has hit the bottle. Nighy was a convincing drunk, all the more so because pissed he was still lovable.

Unlike the mummy's boy hero of Radio 4's afternoon play Slow Train To Woking, written and played by Michael Mears who was clearly taken Greg Dyke's budget-cutting dictum to heart because he plays all the other 27 characters too.

Interview of the week was on the World Service when A.S. Byatt told Harriet Gilbert that she knew George Eliot better than her own daughters. I always thought she was a cold fish.

fields.headline: This movie will self-destruct...
fields.standfirst: John Woo's M:i-2 borrows a plot from Hitchcock and action scenes from his own Hong Kong films. Neither device can alleviate two hours of tedium, and as for Tom Cruise - well, he's no James Bond
fields.body:
M:i-2 (124 mins, 15) Directed by John Woo; starring Tom Cruise, Thandie Newton, Dougray Scott

How about this for a plot? A handsome secret agent is dispatched by the boss of a major intelligence agency to secure the services of a beautiful, compromised woman. He seduces her after a wild car ride and she's transported from the northern to the southern hemisphere to renew an amorous association with a member of a sinister conspiracy and discover his world-threatening secret.

The agent, who has fallen in love with the woman, has a clandestine meeting with her at a racetrack, and when her undercover mission is rumbled she's near-fatally poisoned, though inevitably the heroic agent seeks to rescue her at the last moment.

You have, I'm sure, already recognised this as the plot of Notorious, which many discerning critics, including his daughter, regard as Alfred Hitchcock's finest cinematic achievement. It is also, in all of the details listed, the plot of John Woo's M:i-2, which is not some mysterious formula but a cute way of saying Mission Impossible 2.

The changes are few and unimaginative. First, the hero, Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise), picks up the heroine Nyah Nordoff Hall (Thandie Newton) in Seville and she's transported to seduce her former lover, the master criminal Sean Ambrose (Dougray Scott) in Sydney.

Second, the MacGuffin the good guys are after is not uranium but a deadly virus called Chimera that the villains have stolen; they're also competing for the anti-virus called Bellerophon that is still in the possession of an Australian pharmaceutical company.

Why then is Notorious one of the greatest movies ever made and M:i-2 as tedious a way of spending two hours as you'll come across this summer?

There are several answers to this question, the first being the matter of casting, but the more important being that Hitchcock knew how to pace a movie, how to create suspense, how to involve us with his characters, how to dramatise moral questions.

The screenwriter of M:i-2, Robert Towne, as he demonstrated so well in Chinatown , once knew about such Hitchcockian things. But he has been compelled to abandon them here in the cause of a succession of spectacular set-pieces - explosions, chases, fights - that go on forever and contributed to a budget said to be around $200 million, which is far more than Alfred Hitchcock spent in half a century of moviemaking.

The film is not even as good as the first feature-length Mission: Impossible that Brian De Palma directed four years ago, and it has little of the wit and ingenuity of Bruce Geller's TV series that ran from 1966 to 1973.

There are no moral issues raised, no unforeseeable reversals of fortune, no flesh- and-blood characters. The supposed conflict is between good people who know no fear and bad people who have no qualms.

There are numerous scenes and devices borrowed from earlier pictures other than Notorious . For instance, the hero suspended from a great height to commit a robbery is a poor reprise of a well-handled scene in De Palma's Mission: Impossible, which was, in turn, borrowed from, or a homage to, the far superior Topkapi.

The notion of both the hero and the villain putting on rubber masks to imper sonate each other was more cleverly used in Woo's own Face/Off (and it goes back to the opening sequence of From Russia With Love ). The shoot-out in a laboratory where the hero flies through the air firing guns with both hands is something that Woo himself developed and refined in Hong Kong.

But as C.P. Snow said, when explaining why he'd used a familiar phrase of his own as the title for his novel Corridors of Power: 'If a man hasn't the right to his own clichés, who has?'

The picture's most obscure reference resides in the heroine's name, Nordhoff Hall. Charles Nordhoff and James Hall are the authors of the book Mutiny on the Bounty . There's some private joke here.

fields.headline: Up, up and away
fields.standfirst: Norman Foster's 'erotic gherkin' marks a new phase in  London's aspirations to reach for the sky
fields.trailText: Norman Foster's 'erotic gherkin' marks a new phase in London's aspirations to reach for the sky.
fields.body:
The city of London's planning committee vote last Tuesday to approve a new tower designed by Norman Foster on the site of the Baltic Exchange would have been inconceivable a decade ago. We used to believe that though skyscrapers might initially seem seductive in a flashy, obvious kind of way, like fast food or gas -guzzling Cadillacs, they were actually a thoroughly bad thing.

By dumbing down the skyline, they made for characterless cities that could be anywhere, a dim echo of a distant American original. They were about cultural imperialism, environmental profligacy and corporate sterility. Yet we loved them, just as we love burgers and the chrome-plated products of the golden age of Detroit.

But in the 1980s, we were too po-faced to admit it. The very same planning committee that has just said yes to Foster's tower was immovable in its opposition to Peter Palumbo's plans to build a very much more modestly scaled tower designed by Mies van der Rohe for Mansion House Square. It became a cause célèbre , a last chance to save the Square Mile from the relentless tide of new development.

Now the opposite attitude is emerging. After a quarter of a century in which high-rise architecture was completely off the agenda, we have embarked on an unprecedented bout of skyscraper building. Cities determined to make their mark have decided that a crop of new towers, preferably as exhibitionistic as possible, is the way to get noticed. In urban-renewal projects, a conspicuous high rise is now regarded as one of the most effective ways to make the middle of nowhere feel like somewhere. Liverpool, which is desperate to shake off its image as one of the great urban losers, has plans for a major clump of high rises designed by slick Americans Kohn Pedersen Fox that would transform the traditional views of its waterfront. Manchester and Birmingham have equally ambitious plans. But it is in London that the turnaround is most remarkable.

Foster's scheme at the Baltic Exchange is currently the biggest tower with a serious chance of being built in the City, though it still has to clear the Court of Common Council and get the go- ahead from John Prescott. But Foster is already building the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank's world headquarters at Canary Wharf, and has plans for something almost as big at the Elephant and Castle in south-east London.

Ken Yeang is planning another 50-storey tower for the same site while Nick Grimshaw is working on yet another big tower erupting from Paddington Station. Richard Rogers has designed a tower 40 stories high just across Paddington Basin from Grimshaw's.

London is not exactly suffering from a lack of confidence. It doesn't need to impress anymore, as the Reichmann brothers certainly felt they had to when they hit on the scheme of building the tallest building in Britain, as a giant bill- board advertising their office development at Canary Wharf.

And yet London seems bent on reinventing itself as a city of towers on the American model. The trouble until now has been that only the Americans have really known how to build proper skyscrapers. Not in a technical sense, it's just that very few non-American skyscrapers looked any more convincing than the Soviet Union's ham-fisted attempts at building stretch limos.

The picture has changed. London is on a roll and seems to have adopted a breezy transatlantic swagger which is beginning to affect its architecture. Perhaps it was Foster's tower, first mooted for the site of the old Baltic Exchange, that triggered the change. Though his scheme for a 90-storey building was withdrawn, London suddenly found that plans for 40-storey towers were becoming commonplace.

The new towers share an urge to break out of the straitjacket of the glass box that has dominated the type ever since van der Rohe perfected the original with the Seagram tower. They flaunt their structure, they develop flamboyant curves and project jagged spires.

One conspicuous tower planned for Shanghai would have included a Ferris wheel in a circular hole punched through its top 10 floors. Other architects have started to unpick the skyscraper's skin. Instead of sleek, anonymous glass, they cut back the perimeter walls to create high-level gardens and atria.

While they may individually end up as more 'interesting', it's hard to see that a crowd of them jostling for attention is going to make for skylines any more satisfactory than those left to us by the enthusiasm of developers in the 1960s for building concrete filing cabinets. But they do struggle to come to terms with the issues of identity and energy use.

Building high is not simply a question of cash. You can pack more office space into a 50-storey tower than you can into a eight-storey slab, but as a developer you won't necessarily make more money. With a very tall tower, you can't let any of the space until the whole building is finished. A more modest collection of low rises is quicker to build and can be let bit by bit.

Building high goes beyond making money. It taps into the the most primordial of architectural impulses - to impress. In the end, building is not necessarily a rational, calculating process. Nobody is immune. The new cities of the exploding Pacific Rim are all building high. The twin towers of Malaysia's Petronas building, a witness to Prime Minister Mahattir's edifice complex, are taller than anything else in the world, for the simple reason that they are regarded as a national virility symbol.

Mahattir deliberately set out to top the Sears tower in Chicago, the city that gave birth to the skyscraper in the first place. Chicago has been stung enough by Malaysia's presumption to build something even taller than their Sears tower, for two decades the tallest building in the world.

Under the innocent sounding name of Seven South Dearborn, the Skidmore Owings and Merrill practice has designed a needle-shaped structure that will retake the title of tallest tower.

webTitle: If you dislike the American Dream, try Godard's French polish

fields.headline: If you dislike the American Dream, try Godard's French polish
fields.trailText: American Movie | Jesus' Son | Love and Basketball | Flamenco | Breathless | Céline and Julie Go Boating
fields.body:
American Movie (104 mins, 15) Directed by Chris Smith; featuring Mark Borchardt, Mike Schank, Ken Keen

Jesus' Son (109 mins, 18) Directed by Alison Maclean; starring Billy Crudup, Samantha Morton, Dennis Hopper, Holly Hunter

Love and Basketball (124 mins, 12) Directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood; starring Omar Epps, Sanaa Lathan

Flamenco (100 mins, PG) Directed by Carlos Saura

Breathless (90 mins, 15) Directed by Jean-Luc Godard; starring Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg

Céline and Julie Go Boating (192 mins,15) Directed by Jacques Rivette; starring Juliet Berto, Bulle Ogier

There have been many books about the making of movies, but the ones that stick in the mind are accounts of chaos or catastrophe. Lillian Ross's Picture on the unmaking of John Huston's Red Badge of Courage, for instance, Micheál MacLiammóir's hilarious diary of working on Orson Welles's Othello, or, most recently, Julie Salamon's The Devil's Candy on the production of Brian De Palma's disastrous Bonfire of the Vanities.

In each case, we're seeing big men tottering on their pedestals and there's a touch of tragedy in the comic circumstances. It's rather different, however, when the subject is a cinematic no-hoper as is the case in Chris Smith's documentary American Movie, a touching, amusing and troubling excursion into independent cinema of a gothic kind.

Twenty years ago, the Edinburgh Film Festival screened an extraordinary film called Demon Lover Diary , in which two professional cinematographers from Boston recorded the experience of being engaged by neophyte filmmakers in Detroit to shoot a schlock-horror flick.

They ended up running for their lives when they discovered their employers were low-life psychopaths. American Movie is a benign treatment of a similar mid-western case history centring on the 30-year-old Mark Borchardt from Menomenee Falls, Wisconsin, a high-school drop-out, failed soldier, odd-job man (lavatory cleaner at a cemetery), father of three and moviemaker.

His favourite pictures are Night of the Living Dead and Texas Chainsaw Massacre and at the age of 14 he co-opted two schoolfriends, the future jailbird, Ken, and the future alcoholic, Mike, (a Michael J. Pollard lookalike) to help him make The More the Scarier and its two sequels. Over the next decade, he created a team of collaborators who make Ed Wood's informal family look as conventional as Tony Blair's Cabinet.

Smith's film picks up Mark in the mid 1990s and follows him around for a couple of years as he travels hopefully, trying to make the shoestring, black-and-white horror movie Coven (arguing the while with his friends as to whether it rhymes with 'oven' or 'co-van') as a way of raising the $50,000 budget for his semi-autobiographical epic, Northwestern.

We see him rallying his flagging team, worrying over child-maintenance payments to his estranged wife, trying to get money out of his 82-year-old Uncle Bill. Bill lives in a trailer, has $250,000 in the bank. Though he may look gaga, he can recognise a dubious pitch when he hears one. Eventually, Coven does get made, is screened for a local audience and looks like out-takes from The Blair Witch Project.

Mark thinks he's the next Steven Spielberg. In fact, he's Ed Wood without the charisma. His ambitions are vast and vague, he has the symptoms of the artist, but not the disease. His triumph is becoming the star of Smith's American Movie just as the ultimate vindication of Wood's life resides in becoming egregiously bad and the subject of a Tim Burton film.

Mark realises the American Dream by attaining a weird sort of fame as a charming idiot. Though we have laughed at him and his circle, he has the last laugh. However, his sensible elder brother tells Smith that he always thought Mark would become a serial killer and one reflects that a camera is a less lethal weapon than a gun or a knives.

Jesus' Son is the long-awaited second movie by the gifted New Zealand director Alison Maclean, whose intriguing first feature, the psycho-drama Crush, was shown in competition at Cannes eight years ago. Set throughout the 1970s, though not in chronological order and broken up into pawkily titled chapters, the film is based on a collection of stories by Denis Johnson which takes its title from a Lou Reed song about drugs and religion.

Billy Crudup is impressive as a kindly, dim-witted heroin addict living off his wits in Iowa and earning the nickname 'fuckhead' the hard way. The movie traces the search for grace, enlightenment and redemption undertaken by this counter-cultural holy fool. He passes through a mutually destructive relationship with a fellow addict (the wonderful Samantha Morton), who dies of an overdose, and has various numinous encounters and epiphanies (some drug-induced) on his way to finding salvation as an orderly in an Arizona mental hospital.

Holly Hunter, Dennis Hopper, Denis Leary and Will Patton make brief appearances and the movie is directed with immense confidence, even if at times one isn't sure what Maclean is being confident about.

Gina Prince-Bythewood's Love and Basketball takes in the next American decade, starting in 1981, ending in 1994 and as befits the sport its hero, Quincey (Omar Epps) and heroine, Monica (Sanaa Lathan) pursue, the movie's divided into four quarters. Quincey and Monica are middle-class African-Americans who meet as sporting rivals at 13 and both become basketball stars at high school, the University of Southern California and, finally, as professionals. The movie is about fathers and sons, mothers and daughters, love versus ambition and the peculiar pressures on blacks in America.

Like last week's The Best Man , it's the directorial debut of an African-American filmmaker produced by the generous Spike Lee, and though overlong and too schematic, it's a likeable, attractively played picture.

Made five years ago, Flamenco differs from Carlos Saura's other dance films in having no plot. We just see a succession of singers, dancers and musicians performing in a hall in Seville, elegantly lit by Vittorio Storaro.

There are no subtitles and because my Spanish scarcely extends beyond 'no passarán' and 'cojones', I couldn't follow the scene-setting introduction or understand the lyrics. There are five minutes of Flamenco in Seville in M:i-2 and that was just about enough for me.

Two movies by leading figures of the French new wave are reissued this week in new prints. In an article on Jean-Luc Godard's Une Femme Marié 36 years ago, I wrote about engaging 'directly and centrally with one of the most remarkable minds in the history of the cinema, and the work of a true sociologist (in John Simon's definition: "A student of society, not merely someone with an advanced degree in sociology")'.

I stand by that view, even though I find his work of the past quarter century almost intolerable. Godard's first feature, the seminal Breathless (1960), is a film to see and see again.

Jacques Rivette's whimsical Céline and Julie Go Boating (1974), which lasts twice as long, is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, ie, few people would wish to see it more than once.
