webTitle: Sorry seems to be the hardest word

fields.headline: Sorry seems to be the hardest word
fields.trailText: Stolen
fields.body:
Stolen Tricycle Theatre, London NW6 until Saturday

For three years, an Aboriginal cast has been performing Stolen, a play written by Jane Harrison for the Ilbijerri Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Theatre Cooperative. They have humped the play round Australia, like one of the bashed suitcases they all possess. And they have unpacked its shocking contents with fresh emotion, as if each performance were their first.

The actors - in London as part of an Australian Arts festival - seem visibly moved by this play. Their involvement is more than sympathetic. For some of these Koori Aboriginal actors, the story is their own. They have a cause, a polemic to pass on. Between 1910 and the mid-Seventies, thousands of Aboriginal children in Australia were abducted by the 'Welfare' (heavily ironic word) and put into homes in the name of assimilation. Many were adopted by white families.

The play opens in the dorm of one such home, in which there are five iron beds and a filing cabinet, centrally placed like a replacement parent. The ceiling is split down the middle like forked lightning, and the design is a kind of portent, for this play is written to cut to the quick. (In Australia, according to director Wesley Enoch, three people have had heart attacks in response to it and thousands of white Australians have signed a 'sorry' book.)

The Aboriginal children follow different paths but their initial plight is the same. They are consumed by collective grief: they all wonder why their mothers never come. And their story unfolds in a deliberately childlike way. When one of the children is adopted, the white parents are conveyed by shadows behind a screen image of a suburban house. The dialogue is unsophisticated, like children playing Mummies and Daddies.

It is an engaging style but has drawbacks: innocence is not necessarily the same as truth. It would have been interesting to know something of what the white Australians thought they were up to. And Aboriginal culture could have been better served by the piece. There are one or two indigenous cautionary tales but they are heavy-handed. (The writing is full of leaden reiteration.) The play is in exile from Aboriginal material, just as the children themselves are. I suspect that Harrison did not want to presume a knowledge of the culture - for though her grandmother was Aboriginal, she does not boast of coming from the same world herself.

The subject is so strong that Harrison did not need to pull out the emotional stops so relentlessly. The play asks for tears - and never stops asking. But at the end it works. No one could fail to be moved by the testimony of the actors as they spill out of their roles and into their lives. It seems extraordinary that Australia's prime minister John Howard has so far felt unable to add his name to the 'sorry' book.

webTitle: Moderation in all things (but not here)

fields.headline: Moderation in all things (but not here)
fields.trailText: L'Allegro | White Nights Gala
fields.body:
L'Allegro Coliseum, London WC2

White Nights Gala Royal Opera House, London WC2

Dancing voices and singing bodies exulted at the Coliseum, as Mark Morris's American company and English National Opera's singers and musicians came together in Handel's L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato. Jane Glover conducted, as she had for L'Allegro 's previous performances in 1997. By last Thursday, she and the dancers were soaring on the same wavelength, after a spaced-out opening night.

Dancers en masse need a pulse, whether linked in a unison line or passing motifs from one cluster to another. Morris's group dynamics are so powerful that soloists seem vulnerable on their own - though no one is alone for long. As if in sympathy, the four solo singers are protected in the pit, while the chorus flanks the proscenium in tiered boxes. When they join in, celebrating the 'busy hum of men', the auditorium buzzes like a gigantic hive.

Handel's oratorio contrasts the man-made pleasures of the city with those of rural life. Morris populates the stage with scenes from town and country, his dancers metamorphosing from trees and bushes into hounds and hunters, lords and ladies, alfresco lovers and drowsy children. A nar rative thread meanders through ever-changing landscapes which dissolve and reform like passing clouds.

As melancholy finally gives way to mirth, the voice of the reasonable man, il Moderato, has a go at 'restoring intellectual day'. But ecstasy triumphs over order and moderation. A kaleidoscope of dancers in Adrianne Lobel's silken costumes merges with the music, skirts and trumpets flaring. Their swirling geometry, all the colours of the firmament, is how the Hubble telescope sees the dance of the spheres.

Singers and dancers alternated in last Wednesday's White Nights Gala for the Maryinsky and Royal Opera House companies. The combined forces of the Kirov and Royal choruses in extracts from Otello and Prince Igor almost lifted the newly gilded ceiling. The swoosh of cymbals raised Faroukh Ruzimatov off the ground in Le Corsaire pas de deux. He doesn't really jump any more but he gives good gala.

Royal Ballet dancers appropriated Vaganova's 'Diana and Actaeon' duet. Marianela Nunez fulfilled all the promise she has only hinted at, stuck in the company's lower ranks; Carlos Acosta blazed like a comet. Neither, of course, is British. The charmers of the evening were a Dane, Johan Kobborg, and a Canadian, Jaimie Tapper, who flirted with each other in the 'Flower Festival at Genzano' pas de deux. Suddenly, real people were dancing for the pleasure of it - just as Mark Morris's band of revellers do.

webTitle: What did you do in the war, Dad?

fields.headline: What did you do in the war, Dad?
fields.standfirst: This wonderful revival of Arthur Miller's poignant tale of wartime profiteering cuts straight to the heart of the American Dream with the question, who comes first - family or country?
fields.trailText: All My Sons | Romeo and Juliet | On Raftery's Hill
fields.body:
All My Sons Cottesloe, London SE1

Romeo and Juliet Stratford

On Raftery's Hill Royal Court SW1

Howard Davies's revival of All My Sons is a triumphant reminder of important theatrical truths. It shows that realism on the stage doesn't have to be stolid; it shows that an argumentative play needn't be tendentious, and that its characters needn't be ciphers. And it proves that the question 'what's going to happen?' can be as penetrating and productive as the more familiar theatrical query: 'What's it all about?'

Arthur Miller's play was first staged in 1947: later that year a performance for US troops in Germany was cancelled on the grounds that it was 'a Party Line play'. That accusation now sounds daft, but the play is still provoking: in pitting family loyalty against social conscience, it goes to the heart of the American Dream, and savages it.

An affectionate father and meticulous businessman has indirectly caused the death of one of his sons by supplying faulty parts to the American airforce. This is the nub of the play, approached through action which uncoils slowly, revealing delusions, memories and conflicting responses. Uncomfortable questions about the legacy of the Second World War are raised: questions about profiteering and about the guilt of the survivor. This is a play which is as detailed as a novel, but which never loses its dramatic pulse.

And it is beautifully realised in a production that has only good performances. Julie Walters, returning to the stage after an absence of nine years, is by turns shrewd and crumpled as the mother who can't believe in the death of her son, but who can credit the guilt of her husband. Under a dowager's hump, she is shaken by tiny quivers; in repose, her face settles into perplexity. Catherine McCormack, who is best known for her appearances in Braveheart and Land Girls, declines with magical lightness from radiance to disconsolateness. And, in the part of the surviving son who is also the play's conscience, Ben Daniels, moving from hesitancy to ferocity, consolidates his growing reputation as an actor who can bring to life the most orthodox of parts.

This cast plays together wonderfully well. Listen to the terrible concerto of sighs, when at the breaking of news Julie Walters lets out a dry grinding groan, and Catherine McCormack whimpers. Watch six of the actors in a circle, clenched together, but each reacting differently to a piece of news. Watch the ripple down the stage as James Hazeldine's voice, that of the fallible father, breaks when he pronounces the words of the title - and surprises you with their meaning.

It is one of the rare instances where a completely naturalistic design is what is needed. And William Dudley has supplied it. He has made a suburban garden of Eden in the Cottesloe, with a white house, complete with Victorian glass, at one end of the stage, and paper lanterns at the other. The voices of children at play ring out around the auditorium. It's an idyll waiting to be smashed.

Three years ago Michael Attenborough directed a Romeo and Juliet for the RSC which was suffused with dewy warmth and lusciousness. Michael Boyd's production at Stratford takes the opposite approach, creating a harsh arena in which Romeo and Juliet's feelings are alien.

Hostility reigns. Tom Piper's design is a grey S-shaped bunker, splattered with tomato sauce from an explosive fight in the opening moments, cheerlessly flashed with violet or scarlet neon. The dances are full of straddling and heaving: Lady Capulet looks as if she's copping off with Tybalt. A small band, led by an accordionist, supplies unconsoling music by Stephen Warbeck.

All this is sensible, but it stamps on intimacy and romantic intoxication. Forced to assert themselves against their overbearing surroundings, the lovers are neither fresh nor fervent. David Tennant loses his natural fluidity of movement and tongue: as if hell-bent on being non-lyrical, he ends up rasping and reedy. Alexandra Gilbreath, who is obliged to squirm on the top of the bunker in the balcony scene, and later to appear draped in ropes, plays full tilt the humour of Juliet's contra dictoriness, but at the risk of being pert. Too often she drowns the sense of the lines in the many layers of her remarkable voice. Too often she is commanding where she should be carried away: when she instructs the horses of the sun to gallop, she does so with the imperiousness of a riding-mistress. But in one moment - when she drops her voice and whispers the word 'banished' - she shows what she can be as an actress.

Double the dung-quota of Cold Comfort Farm , triple the slow-worm sensibilities and the dark mutterings of its rural family, and you have the basis of the new play by the Irish playwright Marina Carr.

On Raftery's Hill, co-produced by Druid Theatre and the Royal Court, features Daddy, who demands hare soup for breakfast, his son who lives in the cowshed playing his fiddle, and his posh-voiced mother who keeps running away in her nightie. His elder daughter sleeps with Daddy from time to time; the younger is raped by him on the kitchen table. A regular visitor is in love with his cat, and ends by planning to make this animal companion into a garment.

It's the cat that makes Carr's writing glow: she makes something unsettling out of the everyday. The poor creature is diseased; before long, its bones will surround its flesh and become its own cage. Elsewhere, preposterousness becomes predictable: given the troglodytic nature of the family, the incestuous rape, though ferociously well-staged, doesn't come as much of a surprise: you believe Daddy did it, all right. But it's hard to care.

Under Garry Hynes' direction the play is as tight as it could be. Tony Walton's design is a dark enmired space, striped with rays of light which sit on the surface without brightening it. The performances are distinguished, particularly that of Cara Kelly as the complaisant sister, stuck in wellingtons and cardigan and restrained gloom.

webTitle: My late wife's parents won't let me love again

fields.headline: My late wife's parents won't let me love again
fields.trailText: Moral muse
fields.body:
My wife died 13 months ago in a car accident. She was only 29; I am 31. We had been married for four happy years and were about to start trying for a baby. I loved her very much and was devastated.

To my surprise, I started to feel attracted to someone I met just seven months after her death. This other woman is very much like my wife in many respects - I know that is part of the attraction - and is helping me come to terms with my loss. So far, our relationship has been platonic, but I now feel ready to move on.

The problem is that my wife's parents, especially her mother, are very upset that I have met someone else so soon. My mother-in-law has called me callous and insensitive and accused me of not respecting her daughter's memory. She refuses to understand that I will never forget my wife, but she's no longer with me and I would like to rebuild my life.
T.G. of Hove

 I don't think you're rushing into things at all. A year is considered a decent interval, and your new relationship is only at the 'just good friends' stage.

The contrast between you and your in-laws is that you can find a replacement and they cannot. Their daughter was to them a uniquely precious individual, as children always are. Their pain is like a phantom limb, the ultimate aching void, and they will mourn her for all time. It is their particular grief that there is no grandchild to perpetuate their daughter's qualities.

Though parent-child love is remarkably stable as human attachments go, romantic love is very different and evolves through several stages, the first of which, courtship, is evolution's sop to fidelity. It is an attempt at imprinting and requires much togetherness in the early stages. Without reinforcing, the image fades, a necessary process in biological terms, to release you for your business in life, which is to reproduce. The fact that you have chosen someone who echoes your wife's attractive characterisitics shows the degree of persistence of this force.

Your most basic need as a young, healthy man is for a partner to love and with whom to make a family. Heaven knows, that's preferable to doing the bachelor thing and working through a series of uncommitted encounters. This need should be met and it is far too powerful to be demolished by such nebulous concepts as 'respect for memory'; that is your in-laws' way of rationalising their resentment that you can escape your sorrows, while they cannot. For them, I think, any new partner of yours would have come too soon.

You have shone in their daughter's reflected affection and been their semi-adopted son. Now their grief is compounded by seeing you destined to procreate with someone on whom they have no claim. You should try to understand the reason for their selfishness, and deal with it tactfully rather than rationally. You will never be the same to them again. Try if you can to mend the bridges and keep in touch. But if their affection is permanently alienated, it may be kinder just to withdraw from their life. Time will tell.

Readers' replies

 It sounds as though T.G. from Hove is approaching his new relationship in exactly the right way. He was cautious at first, but now feels ready to make a commitment. It's not as though he rushed out the minute his wife died and began desperately searching for a new partner. His parents-in-law should put themselves in his shoes. Love does not come into our lives very often and when it does we should grab it while we can.
Anon, Nottingham

 T.G. from Hove sounds as though he knows what he's doing. While I sympathise with his late wife's parents, they should back off and grow up.
N.A. of London

Next week's problem is from Y.L of Beckenham

When I was 17, I had a termination. I have never regretted my decision, as I was and still am sure it was the best solution to a very difficult situation.

However, at 33 I now find myself pregnant again. My boyfriend and I have been together for two years. From the outset of the relationship he expressed his dislike of children and, although we should have been more careful because of his strong feelings, a small miscalculation has put us in this predicament. I want to keep the baby. However, my boyfriend does not understand why I am so against a termination. His argument is that, if I was willing to have one in my teens, why am I so unwilling now.

I cannot make him understand that my feelings are completely different and I would probably regret it. He says he will do his best to bring up the child with me. But should I force him into fatherhood?

webTitle: New trainers or a theatre ticket? Expensive choice

fields.headline: New trainers or a theatre ticket? Expensive choice
fields.trailText: Sounding off
fields.body:
There are some things best left to the market, and theatre is not one of them. Standing in a queue for Tate Modern, 2,000 of us happy in the rain, I wondered why waiting to go into a theatre never felt like this: people of all ages and professions with only one thing in common - none of us paid to get in. Chris Smith's attempt to secure free entry for museums is a civilised and proper gesture, and £6 million of government money has turned Tate Modern into a true people's palace. No one seems to think the idea of modern art for free is ridiculous - should theatre be treated the same way?

In my experience, where people might consider a film or a gig as a good way to spend Friday night, most of them think theatre is shouting in the evenings for posh people. If your parents don't take you and your school doesn't organise visits to the theatre, it's very easy to grow up without ever setting foot inside one. When I can get into a club for a fiver, and buy an E for a tenner, and know I'll have a great time, no one should be surprised if I go to the club more often than a show. An entire generation has got out of the theatre habit: education, prejudice and attention span are all partly to blame, but the biggest barrier is expense. As an incentive to people who don't like theatre because they've never tried it, a proportion of seats should be free. There will always be those who save hard to afford the outrageous prices, but unless we make it easy and cheap for some of the others, those who grew up on cheap and easy visits will be dead and there will be no one to replace them.

Last year, about 11 million people watched a Premiership football match, and about 9 million went to the theatre. It's no coincidence that many ordinary fans are kept away from live football by the spiralling costs and 'executive club' feel at some grounds. Why can't cheap theatre be the new football, only putting on the 4-3 thrillers and avoiding the dull 0-0 draws on a windy November Tuesday?

Twenty years ago, this article would not have been written. To suggest that subsidised theatres should be funded well enough to make some of their seats free was not always naive. Subsidy of companies by the Arts Council and of venues by local councils was set at a level where theatre could often afford to cost its audience nothing. In the late Seventies the idea surfaced that art should try to break even or better; the vocabulary of mar ket forces shifted the debate, and it has never shifted back. A theatre is a place where every person's response is as valid as their neighbour's - why should that neighbour get a better seat just because they earn more?

No theatre now can afford to have a truly inclusive access policy. Seat prices are set at a level which the marketing department think the market can take. The irony is that the better an organisation uses its subsidy, and the more inclusive its access, the less it takes at the box office. Years of frozen grants have led to a £4million deficit in our regional theatres - one-sixth of the money provided to keep the Dome solvent for a month. There are excellent privately run audience development schemes which distribute unsold tickets free, but you can't build an audience by bringing them only to the shows you can't sell.

Last year the Hamlyn Foundation funded a week of performances at the National Theatre where all tickets across all three houses cost between £1 and £5. Twenty thousand people came who had never been to the National before. It clearly works - why can't these schemes be state-funded so there is a real possibility of continuity? The Treasury's Spending Review 2000 is a few weeks away - if more money were given to those theatres who try to provide free seats, many more would be encouraged to try.

Richard Eyre says that nowadays people ask: 'Why should I spend £50 going to the theatre when for £50 I can buy a nice pair of shoes?' Fair enough: buy the shoes. You can rely on shoes. You cannot rely on theatre. Great theatre, like all great art is, and should be, rare; it's up to us to try to make it as good as possible, but if we fail or you don't like it, and the experiment cost you £50, you won't come again in a hurry. Make it free, and you might be back next week.

 Sam West is Richard II at the Other Place, Stratford till October

Standing in a queue for Tate Modern, 2,000 of us happy in the rain, I wondered why waiting to go into a theatre never felt like this: people of all ages and professions with only one thing in common - none of us paid to get in. Chris Smith's attempt to secure free entry for museums is a civilised and proper gesture, and £6 million of government money has turned Tate Modern into a true people's palace. No one seems to think the idea of modern art for free is ridiculous - should theatre be treated the same way? fields.headline: The catchers in the pit
fields.standfirst: Security guards and rock fans are under attack in the wake of last week's tragedy at the Roskilde festival. But what do these two maligned, misunderstood groups think of each other?
fields.trailText: Security guards and rock fans are under attack in the wake of last week's tragedy at the Roskilde festival. But what do these two maligned, misunderstood groups think of each other?
fields.body:
They're known as 'the meat'. They guard the stage at rock gigs and festivals, a wall of muscle separating performers from feverish fans. It's part of rock lore that these inhabitants of the pit are humourless thugs who despise music and only smile when forcibly evacuating some poor sweaty kid from the stage. I go to gigs all the time, and I've often wondered, standing on the outer edge of the moshpit - the section of the crowd just in front of the stage where the most active fans gather to jump up and down and slam into each other - what these two groups of people think of each other. Are they really enemies, or is there some deeper symbiotic link between them?

Both groups - moshing fans and stage security - are under attack again at the moment, in the wake of the tragedy at the Roskilde festival in Denmark last weekend, when, during a set by US hard rock band Pearl Jam, nine young men were suffocated to death in a field of mud, accidentally trampled underfoot by the collective pressure of the 70,000-strong crowd.

Although the police inquiry will take months to reach its conclusion, the whispering has already started: that the fans were drunk, and made no effort to save the people who had fallen into the mud; that the security guards ignored warnings that people were being crushed, that one of them heartlessly told a fan, 'In a couple of years you'll forget all about it.'

Such horror stories are common in the aftermath of tragedies involving large numbers of people and confined spaces, and there is no way of proving or disproving them until much later. The same kinds of rumours circulated after Hillsborough, after the Kings Cross tube fire, the Paddington rail crash. The same stories were told last year, after 54 people died in a stampede to escape a lightning storm at a rock concert in Belarus.

Since the infamous Rolling Stones free concert at Altamont speedway in 1969, when the Hell's Angels hired to provide security attacked people with pool cues and knives, murdering one man, rock shows have been sporadi cally associated with carnage. (This country has one of the best safety records in the world: the worst such tragedy in Britain was the death of two fans during the Monsters of Rock festival in 1985.) In every case, recrimination has focused either on the stage security or on the fans, often both.

There are, routinely, calls to outlaw the practice of 'moshing' and 'bodysurfing', even to ban heavy rock bands (who tend to most inspire this behaviour) from certain festivals. Michael Eavis, the organiser of Glastonbury Festival, said last week: 'One of the most dangerous things is "moshing", where the crowd... start climbing over each other - we try very hard to avoid it, or halt it.'

Anyone who has been to gigs and festivals as a fan knows that this is both impossible and undesirable. The whole point of going to see a hard rock band is to abandon yourself physically. (In fact, moshing is a lot less dangerous than its Seventies and Eighties predecessor, headbanging, which destroyed about 1,000 braincells every second.) There are always a few nutters, but on the whole, moshing is good-natured and no more dangerous than walking down Oxford Street on a Saturday morning.

As for bodysurfing - where the protagonist is carried above his fellow fans on a sea of hands and deposited into the arms of a waiting security guard - well, the best person to ask about that is surely one of those doing the catching. How does it feel to be on the frontline facing a thousand screaming, writhing fans, and what do security guards really think of them?

Tom Clements is co-director of Specialised Security, a Scottish firm who provide stage security at most of the major rock festivals in Britain, including Glastonbury and Reading. Does he understand why the fans behave as they do? 'Oh aye,' he says. 'I'm rather a large lad now, but when I was thinner, I went to see bands all the time, as a fan. I've certainly experienced bodysurfing and crowd sways, as have all our staff - because we encourage them to do it.'

Is he aware of the negative perception many fans have of people in his profession? 'Absolutely, and it's something we're trying to change,' says Clements. 'We don't want to be perceived as hired thugs who just want to chat up women and bash people. So our staff sing along to the songs, talk to the people in front of them. We try to do everything we can to break down this barrier between us and the fans.'

In 16 years of going to gigs, I say, I have never seen a single security man singing along with a band. 'Well, not all security people are like us,' he admits.

Anyway, his firm, however progressive, does not employ people on the basis of a nice smile or a love of Smashing Pumpkins. 'Ultimately, they're there to work, not hand out flowers. We have a rigorous training course, where staff learn lifting techniques, how to recognise stress, how to deal with headrollers [bodysurfers]. People in the pit need stamina. You don't need to be built like a brick shithouse...' But it helps, of course.

There is more to saving lives, however, than brute force. Clements emphasises the amount of planning that goes into festivals. At Reading last year, the cost of stage security was more than £200,000. Up to 250 guards were employed at one time, helping bodysurfers who came over the barrier at a rate of more than one per second. Forty thousand paper cups of water were handed out. A medical team was always stationed by the side of the stage. And, a month before the first band took the stage, Clements was on site with Melvin Benn, festivals director for the promoter, Mean Fiddler, seeking out potential problems. 'You cannot take chances,' he says. 'You've got to look at every blade of grass.'

Though softly spoken and in his forties, Melvin Benn is an even bigger rock fan than Tom Clements. 'The first festival I ever went to was Reading in 1972. I hitch-hiked down from Yorkshire, and it was fantastic. The excitement in the crowd is phenomenal. I wholly understand it.' In contrast to Michael Eavis, he is '100 per cent opposed' to any legislation against moshing. 'It would take away all the excitement. And I don't accept that it's inherently dangerous. It can and does happen frequently in a very safe manner.'

Asked whether what happened at Roskilde could happen at Reading, he says: 'I don't know enough about the details to answer that question. What I do know is that we've had huge mudslides before at Reading, but we always prepare for that by having lots of hay and gravel and other drying agents. Preparation is the key.' Professionalism, too: ironically, the strongest criticism aimed at the stewards and security at Roskilde has been that it was a volunteer force: friendly, peaceable, but crucially inexperienced.

Benn, who worked with the Home Office to produce the current code of practice for concert promoters, is proud of the fact that Reading, despite a higher proportion of heavy rock bands than any other festival in Britain, has never been the scene of a death. 'At our festivals, where we've got very active performers, moshing is expected; crowd sways and crowd surges are expected. I know that's going to happen - it always has - and I plan on that basis. Touch wood, we've got a very good safety record.'

Not only does Benn defend the stagedivers and bodysurfers, but he is positively evangelistic about the virtues of the men in the pit. 'I've been in there with them, and it is a truly awe-inspiring spectacle, watching these men at work. They're so dedicated. They really help people and look after people.'

His eulogising brings to mind J.D. Salinger's most famous and tender passage: 'I keep picturing all these little kids playing some game in this big field of rye... if they're running and they don't look where they're going, I have to come out from somewhere and catch them. That's all I'd do all day. I'd just be the catcher in the rye.'

But if rock security guards really are the catchers in the rye, then why do they still have a reputation as heartless thugs? Benn puts it down to the 'daily experiences of music fans who go to clubs with rude doormen and bouncers'. Clements thinks the tide is turning. 'There's been a big change from 10 years ago,' he says. 'At the last Reading Festival, lots of the kids came up and thanked us for helping them have such a great time. That's really gratifying.'

webTitle: The double life of the screen's clown prince

fields.headline: The double life of the screen's clown prince
fields.standfirst: After a flirtation with serious acting, Jim Carrey returns to comedy in  Me, Myself & Irene. But can he reclaim his crown as Hollywood's funniest man, asks  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: After a flirtation with serious acting, Jim Carrey returns to comedy in Me, Myself & Irene. But can he reclaim his crown as Hollywood's funniest man, asks Mark Morris
fields.body:
Here's how Jim Carrey became Hollywood's most famous funny guy: a man walks into a police station, and starts talking to one of the detectives. Only, not quite in the normal way. In fact, he's turned right round, and moving his trousers in such way that it appears he's, well, talking out of his arse. The detective begs him to stop, because his boss is about to arrive. But of course, he keeps going...

'Until Ace Ventura, no actor had considered talking through his ass,' Carrey claims. He's disregarding the rather more extreme 'singing asshole' in John Waters's Pink Flamingoes, but original or not, it worked for Carrey. For a whirlwind two years from 1994, it was the stuff of his fortune. In the two Ace Ventura films, The Mask and most of all, Dumb And Dumber, he used silly walks, contorted faces, ever odder hair and just the right amount of offensiveness to make people laugh.Eleven years after his first film, his wage packet rocketed to $20 million. At the same time, he became the target for serious-minded cultural critics who found the title of Ace Ventura; When Nature Calls almost too much too bear, let alone the film itself.

And then two things happened: first, Carrey went too far. Then he had a go at serious acting. Now, having emerged bitterly empty handed from two Oscar ceremonies, he's back doing what made him a star.

'I don't want to get uppity,' he says. 'The danger now for me is to start choosing all my parts because they're good for an Oscar. I like to be funny. That's a great thing. I never decided at one point, "OK, I'm going to be serious actor". I just want to do everything I can! I love those kinds of movies. I like to get down and dirty and do comedy. It's a way of throwing the hounds off.'

Me, Myself & Irene certainly seems to have all the ingredients. It's made by Peter and Bobby Farrelly, who got their start with Carrey (Dumb And Dumber) but have prospered without him (There's Something About Mary). Carrey plays a highway patrolman with a split personality and a terrible haircut. There is a recurring dildo, an albino, a scene were Carrey suckles mother's milk, an obscene chicken gag, an enraged black midget and Carrey defecating on a lawn. But just as importantly, it it has an underlying sweetness. That's the rule of contemporary mainstream comedy, the reason why American Pie was a big success. You can have all the jokes you like about about sexual diseases, the disabled, and anal sex, as long as your central characters are essentially gentle and decent souls.

The question is whether Carrey has gone too far to come back. So far the US box office for Me, Myself & Irene has been disappointing by industry standards: ie a vast amount of people have seen it, but not nearly as many as saw There's Something About Mary. Maybe Carrey has just confused the audience a little too much. If Me, Myself & Irene lets Carrey's nice side and dark side do battle, then 1996's The Cable Guy was too much dark side.

Made right at the time Carrey seemed unassailable, he choose to play the deranged TV salesman who tries to take over Matthew Broderick's life. Most terrifying was the scene where he turns an OAP karaoke into a one-man recreation of Altamont, doing a violent rendition of the Jefferson Airplane's 'Somebody To Love'. It's a good film. But it breaks those rules: there's no softness there at all, just desperation, loneliness and revenge.

Then Carrey followed the path of reformed comedians Steve Martin and Robin Williams into serious acting. And surprised everyone. In truth, The Truman Show wasn't that much of a stretch. Peter Weir just harnessed the innocent side of Carrey, told him to cut down on the contorted faces, and used him in the service of a big idea or two (is it a film about the overwhelming power of the media or the death of God? Take your pick). Man On The Moon was a slightly different matter: his insistence on the most extreme kind of method acting, of insisting he was Andy Kaufman, might have been true to the spirit of the movie and the man, but it worried people.

'Yeah, I went to bed as him,' he admitted, 'Walked down my hall in the dark, turning off lights in the middle of night, completely gone in this thing. Woke up in the morning and jumped into his shoes.'

It all created a sense of something not quite right, especially as Carrey's interviews had grown pained and confessional, detailing the childhood poverty, the failed marriages. And there was an appearance at an awards programme as a Manson-Jim Morrison hybrid, a Kaufman-esque gag which was clever but not remotely funny. All of which makes it hard to believe him when he turns around and tries to reassure everyone that he's just that loveable, knockaround guy after all.

And while in his heyday he was unchallenged as the funny guy, things have changed. The obvious contenders for the crown are those who accept the modern dictum that stupid is funny (that's not meant negatively, by the way) - Mike Myers and Adam Sandler. Myers has the serious acting twitch, and has never had much success with anything that wasn't Austin Powers or Wayne's World . Sandler is more clearly Carrey's heir, fitting into the same tradition of idiocy that takes in Steve Martin and Jerry Lewis. So far, he seems to have the magic box-office touch that Carrey once had, plus total control over his films and a lack of distracting artistic ambitions.

A more surprising contender is the resurrected Eddie Murphy. There's a scene in The Nutty Professor where a young stand-up mercilessly mocks his audience, including the obese Sherman Klump (Murphy). It's almost impossible not to see it as an apology of sorts for the young, funny but deeply offensive (Aids gags, anyone?) Eighties Murphy. These days, the swagger is gone. He just wants to be loved. And it seems to work.

And occasionally - Bowfinger - he still makes you laugh. But these are the best paid comedy actors, not the funniest. That's a subjective title, although you would be hard-pressed to beat Jack Black or Chris Rock. Or, on his day, Bill Murray, who now has a sense of pathos missing at the height of his fame.

There might seem to be something missing here, the idea of subtle comedy, one that uses words rather than vomit or unlikely people cursing. Whatever happened to the comedy of Cary Grant or Woody Allen? Sure, there are still plenty of smart comedies, they just don't set the charts alight and they don't turn people into stars.

Then there is the sitcom factor. Woody Allen was a stand-up who used to write for TV, then moved into film. Jerry Seinfeld is a stand-up who made his way into TV, and didn't have to go any further. These days, you can top the TV ratings with high-speed witticisms and the comedy of character, and get paid as a movie star. If you're looking for the spirit of Howard Hawks, Frasier is a better bet than most movies.

There's a chance Carrey can reclaim his crown. He might have finally found the acceptable outlet for his dark side. His next film is How The Grinch Stole Christmas, a live action version of the Dr Seuss classic. There's no chance of confusing anyone there: every child in America (and most in the UK, probably) knows the story. And therefore knows that the Grinch is misanthropic and wonderfully nasty, before finally surprising himself - and gaining redemption - by giving back Christmas. Carrey's agent will be hoping that there is some kind of metaphor there.

Kings of comedy: the men behind Me, Myself & Irene

If Jim Carrey is the funniest guy in the movies, there's little doubt about who currently makes the funniest scenes in Hollywood. Like the freewheeling and episodic Woody Allen films of the Seventies, Peter and Bobby Farrelly trade on winning comedy moments. The comparison with Allen ends there. A compilation of their greatest clips would send Mary Whitehouse into apoplexy. They're the guys who gave Carrey his role in Dumb and Dumber, which helped define his sweet, dumb guy persona. Their slapstick allowed him to unleash his inimitable physical shtick as he does again in their new film Me, Myself & Irene . They are the masters of gross comedy and their previous films: Dumb and Dumber, Kingpin and There's Something About Mary have plumbed depths of taste yet soared at the box office.

Recent scatological comedies such as American Pie owe much to this pair of New England brothers who, when children, would boo at each other over the dinner table if someone said 'something that wasn't interesting'. No subject or joke is taboo, they delight in subverting PC orthodoxy and their audiences' prejudices. US mental health groups have attacked Me, Myself & Irene, in which Carrey plays a state trooper with a split personality 'from gentle to mental'. They'll have to wait in line though: African-Americans, albinos, lesbians, midgets and the disabled could take offence also. Ironically, the brothers are liberal sentimentalists.

There is more to them than toilet humour, too. There's Something About Mary was a cleverly crafted romantic comedy, which allied to their bankability makes them attractive to A-list stars. That's why Gywneth Paltrow is prepared to go through extensive prosthetic work to play the physically challenged heroine of their next film, Shallow Hal, the tale of a superficial young man who will only date beautiful women.

 Me, Myself & Irene opens on 22 September

In fact, he's turned right round, and moving his trousers in such way that it appears he's, well, talking out of his arse. The detective begs him to stop, because his boss is about to arrive. But of course, he keeps going... 'Until Ace Ventura, no actor had considered talking through his ass,' Carrey claims. He's disregarding the rather more extreme 'singing asshole' in John Waters's Pink Flamingoes, but original or not, it worked for Carrey. For a whirlwind two years from 1994, it was the stuff of his fortune. In the two Ace Ventura films, The Mask and most of all, Dumb And Dumber, he used silly walks, contorted faces, ever odder hair and just the right amount of offensiveness to make people laugh.Eleven years after his first film, his wage packet rocketed to $20 million. At the same time, he became the target for serious-minded cultural critics who found the title of Ace Ventura; When Nature Calls almost too much too bear, let alone the film itself. And then two things happened: first, Carrey went too far. Then he had a go at serious acting. Now, having emerged bitterly empty handed from two Oscar ceremonies, he's back doing what made him a star. 'I don't want to get uppity,' he says. 'The danger now for me is to start choosing all my parts because they're good for an Oscar. I like to be funny. That's a great thing. I never decided at one point, "OK, I'm going to be serious actor". I just want to do everything I can! I love those kinds of movies. I like to get down and dirty and do comedy. It's a way of throwing the hounds off.' Me, Myself & Irene certainly seems to have all the ingredients. It's made by Peter and Bobby Farrelly, who got their start with Carrey (Dumb And Dumber) but have prospered without him (There's Something About Mary). Carrey plays a highway patrolman with a split personality and a terrible haircut. There is a recurring dildo, an albino, a scene were Carrey suckles mother's milk, an obscene chicken gag, an enraged black midget and Carrey defecating on a lawn. But just as importantly, it it has an underlying sweetness. That's the rule of contemporary mainstream comedy, the reason why American Pie was a big success. You can have all the jokes you like about about sexual diseases, the disabled, and anal sex, as long as your central characters are essentially gentle and decent souls. The question is whether Carrey has gone too far to come back. So far the US box office for Me, Myself & Irene has been disappointing by industry standards: ie a vast amount of people have seen it, but not nearly as many as saw There's Something About Mary. Maybe Carrey has just confused the audience a little too much. If Me, Myself & Irene lets Carrey's nice side and dark side do battle, then 1996's The Cable Guy was too much dark side. Made right at the time Carrey seemed unassailable, he choose to play the deranged TV salesman who tries to take over Matthew Broderick's life. Most terrifying was the scene where he turns an OAP karaoke into a one-man recreation of Altamont, doing a violent rendition of the Jefferson Airplane's 'Somebody To Love'. It's a good film. But it breaks those rules: there's no softness there at all, just desperation, loneliness and revenge. Then Carrey followed the path of reformed comedians Steve Martin and Robin Williams into serious acting. And surprised everyone. In truth, The Truman Show wasn't that much of a stretch. Peter Weir just harnessed the innocent side of Carrey, told him to cut down on the contorted faces, and used him in the service of a big idea or two (is it a film about the overwhelming power of the media or the death of God? Take your pick). Man On The Moon was a slightly different matter: his insistence on the most extreme kind of method acting, of insisting he was Andy Kaufman, might have been true to the spirit of the movie and the man, but it worried people. 'Yeah, I went to bed as him,' he admitted, 'Walked down my hall in the dark, turning off lights in the middle of night, completely gone in this thing. Woke up in the morning and jumped into his shoes.' It all created a sense of something not quite right, especially as Carrey's interviews had grown pained and confessional, detailing the childhood poverty, the failed marriages. And there was an appearance at an awards programme as a Manson-Jim Morrison hybrid, a Kaufman-esque gag which was clever but not remotely funny. All of which makes it hard to believe him when he turns around and tries to reassure everyone that he's just that loveable, knockaround guy after all. And while in his heyday he was unchallenged as the funny guy, things have changed. The obvious contenders for the crown are those who accept the modern dictum that stupid is funny (that's not meant negatively, by the way) - Mike Myers and Adam Sandler. Myers has the serious acting twitch, and has never had much success with anything that wasn't Austin Powers or Wayne's World . Sandler is more clearly Carrey's heir, fitting into the same tradition of idiocy that takes in Steve Martin and Jerry Lewis. So far, he seems to have the magic box-office touch that Carrey once had, plus total control over his films and a lack of distracting artistic ambitions. A more surprising contender is the resurrected Eddie Murphy. There's a scene in The Nutty Professor where a young stand-up mercilessly mocks his audience, including the obese Sherman Klump (Murphy). It's almost impossible not to see it as an apology of sorts for the young, funny but deeply offensive (Aids gags, anyone?) Eighties Murphy. These days, the swagger is gone. He just wants to be loved. And it seems to work. And occasionally - Bowfinger - he still makes you laugh. But these are the best paid comedy actors, not the funniest. That's a subjective title, although you would be hard-pressed to beat Jack Black or Chris Rock. Or, on his day, Bill Murray, who now has a sense of pathos missing at the height of his fame. There might seem to be something missing here, the idea of subtle comedy, one that uses words rather than vomit or unlikely people cursing. Whatever happened to the comedy of Cary Grant or Woody Allen? Sure, there are still plenty of smart comedies, they just don't set the charts alight and they don't turn people into stars. Then there is the sitcom factor. Woody Allen was a stand-up who used to write for TV, then moved into film. Jerry Seinfeld is a stand-up who made his way into TV, and didn't have to go any further. These days, you can top the TV ratings with high-speed witticisms and the comedy of character, and get paid as a movie star. If you're looking for the spirit of Howard Hawks, Frasier is a better bet than most movies. There's a chance Carrey can reclaim his crown. He might have finally found the acceptable outlet for his dark side. His next film is How The Grinch Stole Christmas, a live action version of the Dr Seuss classic. There's no chance of confusing anyone there: every child in America (and most in the UK, probably) knows the story. And therefore knows that the Grinch is misanthropic and wonderfully nasty, before finally surprising himself - and gaining redemption - by giving back Christmas. Carrey's agent will be hoping that there is some kind of metaphor there. Kings of comedy: the men behind Me, Myself & Irene If Jim Carrey is the funniest guy in the movies, there's little doubt about who currently makes the funniest scenes in Hollywood. Like the freewheeling and episodic Woody Allen films of the Seventies, Peter and Bobby Farrelly trade on winning comedy moments. The comparison with Allen ends there. A compilation of their greatest clips would send Mary Whitehouse into apoplexy. They're the guys who gave Carrey his role in Dumb and Dumber, which helped define his sweet, dumb guy persona. Their slapstick allowed him to unleash his inimitable physical shtick as he does again in their new film Me, Myself & Irene . They are the masters of gross comedy and their previous films: Dumb and Dumber, Kingpin and There's Something About Mary have plumbed depths of taste yet soared at the box office. Recent scatological comedies such as American Pie owe much to this pair of New England brothers who, when children, would boo at each other over the dinner table if someone said 'something that wasn't interesting'. No subject or joke is taboo, they delight in subverting PC orthodoxy and their audiences' prejudices. US mental health groups have attacked Me, Myself & Irene, in which Carrey plays a state trooper with a split personality 'from gentle to mental'. They'll have to wait in line though: African-Americans, albinos, lesbians, midgets and the disabled could take offence also. Ironically, the brothers are liberal sentimentalists. There is more to them than toilet humour, too. There's Something About Mary was a cleverly crafted romantic comedy, which allied to their bankability makes them attractive to A-list stars. That's why Gywneth Paltrow is prepared to go through extensive prosthetic work to play the physically challenged heroine of their next film, Shallow Hal, the tale of a superficial young man who will only date beautiful women.  Me, Myself & Irene opens on 22 September

fields.headline: Jeffrey Wright
fields.standfirst: ...the classically trained actor who steals the show in the new Shaft movie
fields.trailText: ...the classically trained actor who steals the show in the new Shaft movie
fields.body:
If you've seen Woody Allen's documentary Wild Man Blues, you'll have etched in your mind the bit where Allen's elderly parents insist they still regret that their boy didn't grow up to be a pharmacist. His status as one of cinema's greats is a poor substitute.

Jeffrey Wright's mother would sympathise. Critics and audiences might think that Wright, playing Dominican drugs baron Peoples Hernandez, steals the new Shaft film from under Samuel L Jackson's nose. No mean feat, you might think. But Wright's mother wanted him be a lawyer. When he got into the distinguished Amherst College in Massachusetts to study political science, he seemed to be on the right path. Instead, he used his time at college to act. 'The first day, I knew this was going to be it,'he says.

Well, it was, but it didn't happen instantly. As he remarks: 'People in the industry are actively looking for new white actors. But they're not so actively looking for young black actors.' After graduating in 1987, and deciding not to go to law school, Wright spent the next few years working his way up in serious theatre in New York and in his hometown of Washington DC. It was his role as a gay nurse in Angels In America on Broadway that changed everything. He was bombarded with awards, including a Tony in 1994.

He had also done some bit parts in movies, but nothing of note until he was cast in the lead role in doomed artist biopic Basquiat. It was a great chance: the title role, on screen for virtually the whole film, and a chance to work with Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper, both in rare non-psycho mode. But although he got good reviews, it didn't bring true instant stardom. He kept doing theatre and films: he was good as the freed slave-turned-confederate soldier in Ride With The Devil last year. He got the part in Shaft only when Colombian-born actor John Leguizamo dropped out.

Controversially, nothing was changed about the part, so Wright plays it with slicked-down hair, white clothes and an extravagant 'Spanglish' diction. This has offended various Latino groups, but pleased the Shaft crew so much that his part became much bigger than originally intended, at the expense of the film's other bad guy, Christian Bale.

Maybe there's something sad about the fact that a highly regarded African-American classical actor still has to play a coke king to make his name in Hollywood. Then again, Wright's gleeful nastiness fits in the tradition of other distinguished Shakespeareans-turned-sniggering villains, established by the likes of Alan Rickman.

He's even appearing in Sylvester Stallone's next film, D-Tox. But like the classically trained trouper he is, he'll be spending summer playing Marc Anthony in a Central Park production of Julius Caesar. Going back onstage is a chance to control what I have,' he says.

Five things you should know about Jeffrey Wright

1 He defended Ride With The Devil against charges that it used the word 'nigger' too freely

2 He worked as a grip on Accidental Hero

3 Acting ruined his college lacrosse career: 'I became a real flake on the field. I'd go, "I can't get hurt - my director'll kill me if I show up with a broken leg".'

4 He played jazz legend Sydney Bechet in an episode of the Young Indiana Jones Chronicles

5 Basquiat director Julian Schnabel said: 'He is very much like Jean-Michel in a lot of ways.'

fields.headline: Hell is a weekend cottage
fields.standfirst: Only nostalgic dreamers with two of everything should contemplate a second home
fields.trailText: Only nostalgic dreamers with two of everything should contemplate a second home.
fields.body:
Perhaps you are reading this in your weekend cottage, curled up beside your inglenook with the scent of honeysuckle wafting through open, leaded windows. Perhaps herbs hang from the beams above your Aga and they are haymaking in the fields down the lane. If so, I feel sorry for you.

I had a country cottage once. Big mistake. But like Wordsworth, or for that matter, the Daily Mail, which is offering readers the chance to win the cottage of their dreams, I was in thrall to the fantasy that 'a wilderness is rich with liberty'. All I needed to make my life complete, to give me time and space to write novels, to work my way through Nigella Lawson's recipes and garden like Beth Chatto, was a period property in a field.

Of course, I knew even then that the national obsession with bricks and mortar is stupid and damaging. I knew that the houses advertised by posh estate agents at the front of Country Life wouldn't really solve all my problems. But it's hard to be rational when newspaper property pages constantly taunt you with the possibility of a stone house in Oxfordshire with stream and delphiniums, all for the cost of a large cupboard in London.

Nostalgia for the countryside is central to English sensibility. The Compleat Angler, published in 1653, has been through nearly 400 editions; The Natural History of Selborne and Lark Rise to Candleford are still selling. We all carry around in our heads images of stout yeomen harvesting with pitchforks and we are moved by the evocativeness of words like stooks and byres, threshing and winnowing.

Or we are if we haven't actually tried it. Like Fran Leibovitz, I have discovered that I am not, after all, the type who wants to go back to the land; I am the type who wants to go back to the hotel.

The first big difficulty is that the country is so far away. First, you have to queue through a bottleneck to get on to the motorway, then you have to queue through the bottleneck that is the motorway. Then, when it's finally possible to put your foot down, all the other motorists are so frustrated and steaming with pent-up aggression that getting there in one piece is only moderately likely. Life-insurance forms should include weekend cottages among their dangerous pastimes.

In my case, this horrible journey followed a day packing up all the possessions that the household might conceivably need for the weekend. Since I was meant to be working on Fridays, rather than running around the house thinking 'balloon whisk/teething ring/champagne flutes', I was already suffering stratospheric levels of stress before I set off. And then about halfway through the Blackwall Tunnel, with traffic backed up behind and solid ahead, I'd realise I'd forgotten my contact-lens solution.

So the first lesson I learnt is that there's no point in even contemplating a weekend cottage unless you can afford two food processors. Two of everything, in fact, because how are you supposed to learn to cook like Nigella when her book's 100 miles away in your other kitchen? But say you've got the second music system and widescreen television, RHS plant encyclopaedia and CD collection - because what's the point of spending your leisure time being less comfort able than you'd be at home? You still need to bring fresh parmesan. The whole point of a weekend cottage is to get away from it all,which is fine until you realise you're 10 miles away from the nearest lemon.

So you spend the whole of Saturday morning driving to a town in order to visit the supermarket on the ring-road. (There's no point bothering with the village shops because the vegetables are withered and they don't do organics.) The journey takes ages because there's more queuing - behind farm machinery this time - and you have to keep backing up to let the locals' Range-Rovers down the lanes.

By Saturday afternoon, I'd start noticing the dust on the surfaces and the grime on the kitchen floor. After that came the weary realisation that delphiniums don't appear in the cottage garden as a matter of course, as they do in the photographs. (Meanwhile, my London garden wasn't getting any attention at all, despite being the one I had to spend all week viewing from my desk.)

By Saturday night, I was exhausted by domestic maintenance and quite glad I didn't know anyone locally. (The protectionism of rural England, like the nostalgia for rural England, has a fine pedigree: in 1844, William Wordsworth fulminated that the railway would bring 'the whole of Lancashire and no small part of Yorkshire' into his Lake District.) Of course I didn't know any one anywhere else either, as I was never around for dinner parties.

And there's nowhere quite like a rural village for class distinctions. 'I always tell my WI ladies to iron their wrapping paper and reuse it,' the woman from the big house once advised me when she caught me throwing some away. So if you want interesting dinner companions who aren't going to start lecturing you about your domestic arrangements, you have to import them. That means either owning a castle or lots of sleeping bags. One gets too old for that.

You have to have their children as well, although there's only a couple of years when children and the country go together, and even then you have to take care to keep them indoors when the locals are crop-spraying. Too young and you're neurotic about them drowning in the stream; older and they don't want to come because there are no clubs in Gloucestershire and the pubs are full of old people.

I rapidly reached the conclusion that the countryside lobby is right and we townies don't understand them. We're not trained for it. I don't know which bits of the elderflower are poisonous, if any, so I can't make cordial. I don't like craft fairs or have anything to contribute to them. I don't either wear green wellies or sandals and flowing skirts. Outdoors, for me, is something you pass through on the way to DKNY.

The countryside is not full of winnowing and baling peasants, as it is in my head, but of concrete silos, mad cows, cruel chicken sheds, chemical-singed fields and motocross meets. And I fear that to want a weekend cottage is to reveal a deeply unattractive aspect of human nature: the desire for something mainly because most people can't have it.

Hazlitt thought that the nostalgia for all things rural was to do with our seeing natural objects as classes of things rather than individuals, so that a primrose seen in adulthood seems to us the same as a primrose seen in childhood. In other words, the cult of the countryside represents an attempt to return to our past; it's a kind of infantilism.

I sold my cottage - I couldn't afford it - and I decided I'd rather deal with my unease about the pace of modern life in town than try fruitlessly to hide from it behind a high hedge. At least my house in London which is, after all, where I really live, now occasionally gets tidied. And I don't spend Monday recovering from Sunday night swallowing carbon monoxide on the M40.

 Geraldine Bedell's novel, A Fabulous Fling, is published by HarperCollins, price £5.99. To order it for £3.99 plus 99p p&p call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

fields.headline: We're all in this together
fields.standfirst: Heard the one about the impressionist, the actor and the stand-up comic? Meet the latest stars to roll off the conveyor belt for Art, the West End hit with an ever-changing cast of three
fields.trailText: Heard the one about the impressionist, the actor and the stand-up comic? Meet the latest stars to roll off the conveyor belt for Art, the West End hit with an ever-changing cast of three.
fields.body:
In the RSC rehearsal rooms in Clapham, the fifteenth cast of Yasmina Reza's Art are being put through their paces, in between fags and sandwiches. Art, a three-hander about male friendship and its flipside, has become the West End's resident cash cow: every 14 weeks, the conveyor belt disgorges a new triumvirate of celebrities on to the Wyndham's stage, which has proved equally hospitable to established actors and comics wanting to stretch new muscles.

Albert Finney, Tom Courtenay, Art Malik, Nigel Havers, Frank Skinner, Anton Lesser, Jack Dee... One critic has commented that Art owes its longevity to 'the fact that the roles are as easily renewable as printer cartridges', which, though not particularly flattering, may also reassure the next incumbents: the impressionist Alistair McGowan, stand-up comic Sean Hughes, and Colin Buchanan, best known as the younger one in Dalziel and Pascoe . They are taking over from what are lazily termed 'the Americans': Patrick (Bobby in Dallas ) Duffy, Richard (John-Boy in The Waltons ) Thomas and the (British) RSC stalwart Paul Freeman. Whether you think it's a banal entertainment made palatable by the presence of telly stars, or a ticklish analysis of male relationships, you can't deny this show has legs.

Since opening in October 1996, Art has cunningly managed to reinvent itself with every cast change. To prove the point, there are several obsessives who have been back to see every version, finding that new actors bring an entirely new dynamic to the text. Some casts have pleased the critics more than others, but the play has weathered the bumpier patches and is about to coast into its fifth year. The team behind Art saw the potential of putting screen stars on stage long before Nicole Kidman flashed her bottom in The Blue Room . And Because a long line of household names is queueing up to appear (they appreciate the fact that contracts are relatively short, at three months, and that the play only runs for 80 minutes every evening), it's already part of the West End furniture: a production which draws in a new audience every three months. Even sniffy types like the fact that it's written by a French playwright.

Alistair McGowan the only member of the new cast who had previously seen the play. Twice, in fact. He bought tickets for the original version with Courtenay and Finney ('I was so wowed by it, it took me a good four days to get it out of my head'), and then, out of curiosity, caught a subsequent production with Jack Dee, Tim Healey and Larry Lamb. 'It creates a bit of a buzz. I wanted to see how the other production differed. If that gets people into the theatre - as well as the quality of the work - then that's fine. People go and see loads of different versions of A Midsummer Night's Dream over the years, just out of interest.'

McGowan (35, born in Worcestershire, lives in Hammersmith with his girlfriend, a stage manager) plays Serge, the dermatologist who buys an all-white canvas for 200,000 francs. Buchanan (33, raised in Dundee, lives in Birmingham with his girlfriend and two children) is Serge's old chum Marc, who sneers at it. Hughes (34, grew up in Dublin, lives alone in north London, and last night had an anxiety dream about being burgled by Paul Ince) is Yvan, the hapless piggy-in-the-middle. They're two weeks into rehearsal, under the supervision of Rupert Goold; in grand theatrical tradition, although Matthew Warchus is billed as director, he has yet to meet the cast.

For Buchanan, who is the only professional actor in the bunch, theatre has never held much appeal but, having already turned the producers down twice, he'd run out of excuses. 'I wouldn't really have entertained the thought of doing a longer run,' he explains. 'I like to ring the changes, which is another reason why I prefer to do filming rather than theatre. Okay, so you can work on it for weeks beforehand and then build on it while you're actually performing, but I like the idea of doing different things every day. Having said that, Art is a very rich play, and we're pretty much allowed to come to it fresh. I think every cast is encouraged to bring its own dynamic to it. It would probably be very easy for it just to be funny; Alastair and Sean know how to work an audience. But neither of them are doing that with Art . We're not playing it so that Alistair does his impressions and Sean plays it for laughs and I'm deeply serious. We're playing it for real.'

He knows McGowan from way back; the pair met while filming TV's Preston Front . 'No, he can't do me,' says Buchanan with small satisfaction. 'He tried, but I'm such a boring twat, he couldn't.'

'Some people come easily, some people don't. Colin doesn't,' admits McGowan. 'Maybe he will.' However, he finds Hughes - the startled eyebrows, the meandering delivery - a cinch.

'Once Frank [Skinner] and Jack [Dee] had been in it, I thought: "I'll wait for the call,"' explains the real Sean Hughes. 'I was really snobbish, I couldn't wait to turn them down. But it came at a certain time for me when I really saw the challenge. I'm interested in doing something that I could fuck up, but doing it well.'

The thing that's really worrying Hughes, who runs parallel careers in comedy, novel-writing and broadcasting, but has never tackled straight theatre before, is doing the same thing every night for three months, 'which is not what I'm used to. There is a fair chance that you'll see me in the West End shooting people, shouting: "I can't say these words anymore! I've squeezed every nuance out of them! I'm no Patrick Duffy!"'

When he accepted the part, he was banking on the fact that McGowan - whom he'd met a few times before - hadn't been to drama school either. Then it emerged that McGowan had in fact trained at the Guildhall, and Hughes's heart sank to his boots. But having done a couple of two-handers at Edinburgh last year, he knew he enjoyed the feeling of sharing the responsibility of performing. 'It's a real joy to be on stage with other people. I'm sick of that weight on my shoulders, and I love the idea of being able to rely on other people. I know Art is perceived as a comedy, but I don't have to prove myself in the funny stakes and I'm going to try my hardest not to mug for laughs.'

He pauses, then comes clean: 'Well, I say this, but I probably won't be able to resist it. I've been there all my life, and it's a lovely feeling, milking the laughs. But the joy for me will be... it's like, sometimes in a stand-up show, in the middle of a performance, if you know the audience is totally with you, you can hear the silence.'

Buchanan says that Hughes 'completely understands the nature of performing'. But Hughes can't help fretting about what will happen if the audience doesn't react as expected. When things went wrong one night in Edinburgh last summer, he and his co-star adlibbed themselves some therapy, and took the audience apart. 'But,' says Hughes, a little sadly, 'you can't do that in a play.'

McGowan always intended to act. After the Guildhall, a friend pointed out that there were fewer good impressionists than good actors, so he made a pragmatic decision to target the comedy circuit, which in turn led to Spitting Image (where he inherited John Major's voice from Steve Coogan). Even people who don't like impressions were charmed by his recent show, where he made mild but insistent mischief with David Beckham and Laurence Llewellyn-Bowen. It might not seem like the obvious point in his career for McGowan to go back to acting, but, he says: 'I've always been a little bit aware of not becoming too pigeonholed. I don't want to shut off any avenues. I've always wanted to do something like this: a play, a good, popular play, in the West End.'

Doing impressions, he says, is all about assuming things - wigs, tics, mannerisms - whereas theatre is about the opposite. 'It's a bit scary at first. When you're doing an impression, somehow it's easier and harder at the same time because there's something that you're working towards. It's easy for people to say, "Actually, that's not right." When you do get it right, you know. But with acting, it's more nebulous.'

Whereas Hughes finds the stage agreeably crowded, McGowan finds it oddly empty. He's used to playing four people a day. 'Doing that last series, I did something like 55 different characters over a period of three months - and then you leave them all behind. It doesn't necessarily screw you up but it is a bizarre experience when it's all over. "What do I do? How do I move? How do I speak?" And although Serge is a character, he's more like me, so you do feel a bit exposed.'

Two years ago, McGowan did Endgame and Kafka's Dick at the Nottingham Playhouse. Playing Kafka in the Bennett play was a vaguely alarming experience at first. 'The laughs happen around him, he's fairly straight, and I found it really strange not getting laughs. If you do stand-up, like me and Sean, if you're not getting your laughs, you're doing something wrong. That was a big shock. It's very daunting, just to trust that you're doing something right. Philip Franks, who directed Kafka , said to me, "If you get your p-part right [of course, McGowan has Franks's breathy, hesitant delivery to a T], then the laughs will happen around you. Don't think that if you're not getting laughs, it's not working." It was an invaluable lesson, really.'

Next week, they're going to watch 'the Americans' winding down at the Wyndham's. 'We're all going to go and heckle,' says Buchanan. 'By then we'll be in the last week of rehearsals, so hopefully we'll have done it for ourselves quite a few times by then.'

Sean Hughes can't wait. 'We don't want to leave it too late, in case there's a lot of stuff they're really good at, and we haven't got time to borrow it.'

webTitle: He'd got white robes, a drum to bang. I was history

fields.headline: He'd got white robes, a drum to bang. I was history
fields.trailText: True confessions
fields.body:
After being married for 15 years, my husband left me to join the Hare Krishnas.

A few months before, we had gone with some friends to a Krishna festival. It was a sunny day and the drums were hypnotic and the food delicious. We both had a good time and I thought nothing of my husband's enthusiasm at joining the noisy procession.

However, he started going to meetings. I assumed he would get bored, as he generally did with any new fad or hobby that he latched on to. But when he arrived home in white clothes, with his head shaved save for a small pony tail, I realised his dalliance with the Hare Krishnas had reached a higher plane.

'We need to talk' he said. 'I think we do,' I replied.

We sat on our chintzy three-piece suite in our three-bedroom semi in Surrey. Over his white robes he was wearing an anorak. He had a hippy bag across his shoulder and was wearing sandals. He looked as though he had spent the afternoon parading up and down Tottenham Court Road. From his bag he pulled out a crumpled piece of paper.

'This is a list of all the changes I will be making in my life,' he told me.

At this point, I have to make it clear that joining a religious sect was not the first unusual thing my husband had wanted to do. He had joined the merchant navy after leaving a boys' boarding school, and even after we had married and his job took him abroad, he wanted to make the trips on his own. It was an opportunity for him to relinquish responsibility and spend some time in, yes, an all-male environment.

After he left the merchant navy, we did some travelling, stayed in a kibbutz, dabbled in Buddhism and spent some time in India.

I knew in my heart that he could not face responsibility, but I persevered with our marriage. I went along with his whims because I loved him.

But now I drew the line. At the bottom of the list that included such things as not washing with soap or eating meat or sleeping on a proper bed was the final command. 'We cannot indulge in gratuitous sex any more,' he told me. Well, I thought, I can live with that. We've never been madly adventurous in the bedroom. I told him that it was all fine with me.

'You don't understand,' he said calmly. 'Krishna deems that only sex for reproduction is allowed.'

Now, we hadn't planned on having a child, but even if we were to have one, or even two, then that amounted to sex only once or twice more in my lifetime. I had had enough. My husband moved into the temple. We sold our house.

To this day, he owns not a single thing. He can be seen banging a drum and chanting in a high street near you and, I have to admit, he seems happy.

 The writer's name has been changed

webTitle: Greens' fury at BA's KLM takeover plan

fields.headline: Greens' fury at BA's KLM takeover plan
fields.trailText: British Airways' plans to take over KLM could be seriously disrupted by 'green' campaigners determined to limit the airlines' expansion.
fields.body:
British Airways' plans to take over KLM could be seriously disrupted by 'green' campaigners determined to limit the airlines' expansion.

Dutch environmentalists are furious at the idea that a deal would see British Airways channelling millions of extra passengers through Amsterdam, in order to relieve pressure on London.

They will try to block the building of a fifth runway at the city's Schiphol Airport if a combined BA-KLM try to use it for vigorous expansion.

UK City observers believe that one of the reasons Dutch national airline KLM is so attractive to BA is the expansion potential at Schiphol, where there are already four runways, compared with two at Heathrow and one at Gatwick.

While campaigners have stressed that the issue is more about the environment than the politics of ownership, UK City sources said the Dutch green lobby reluctantly tolerated restricted growth by the Netherlands' 'national champion' KLM. However, if the airline became British-owned, it could lose the greens' support.

Groups such as Stichting Natuur en Milieu (SNM) and Friends of the Earth have a powerful influence on public opinion and in the Dutch parliament.

Heathrow is straining at the seams, and even if a fifth terminal is approved, it will not be completed until at least 2007.

As revealed by The Observer in May, BA wants to complete 'preliminary' talks with KLM by early next month before deciding whether to enter detailed negotiations. The two airlines have signalled to the European Commission that they are considering a four-way tie up with Northwest and American Airlines of the US.

Jan Fransen, policy director of SNM, said: 'Schiphol should be a quality airport with only the air transport that is for the benefit of the national economy of Holland coming through it.

'We are very scared about a merger of KLM and BA in case the stress on London airports means a lot of low-value traffic coming from Heathrow to Schiphol, and we think there should be concrete assurances that that will not happen.'

A BA spokesman denied that the airline had plans to develop Schiphol as a second hub. It said green campaigners' worries would be 'unfounded'.

webTitle: Sales growth on the slide at Asda

fields.headline: Sales growth on the slide at Asda
fields.trailText: Sales growth is slipping at Asda, the supermarket chain acquired by the US giant Wal-Mart last year, industry sources say. By their estimate like-for-like increases have shrunk to little or nothing.
fields.body:
Sales growth is slipping at Asda, the supermarket chain acquired by the US giant Wal-Mart last year, industry sources say. By their estimate like-for-like increases have shrunk to little or nothing.

Asda began the year as one of the leading UK food retailers, with like-for-like sales rising by close to 10 per cent. Now, one analyst said: 'Sales growth looks horrible. That is bad for a sales-led retailer.'

These comments are supported by the launch of Asda's Ad Match campaign last week, which will match prices advertised by any rival. This is widely seen as a swipe at the Safeway Best Deals Ever drive, which cuts the prices of a different range of products every week by up to 50 per cent. Safeway claims the campaign has already helped its like-for-like sales to grow by 6 per cent.

But an Asda spokesman denied that Ad Match was a reaction to concern about sales. He said a new industry survey by Taylor Nelson Sofres put its market share at 14.1 per cent - its highest ever, almost matching Sainsbury's.

However, industry sources say such surveys are not based on actual sales figures.

Since Wal-Mart acquired Asda last July, the UK chain's Rollback campaigns have seen price cuts on more than 10,000 products. But reports suggest Wal-Mart is finding it hard to adjust to the British market and Asda's reporting methods. Allan Leighton, former chief executive and the force behind Asda's previous sales pushes, now has a wider, European role.
