webTitle: Centrica in bid to double US business

fields.headline: Centrica in bid to double US business
fields.trailText: Roy Gardner, head of gas-to-AA motor services group Centrica, is talking to two further US energy suppliers about deals he hopes will more than double the UK company's North American customer base within a year.
fields.body:
Roy Gardner, head of gas-to-AA motor services group Centrica, is talking to two further US energy suppliers about deals he hopes will more than double the UK company's North American customer base within a year.

Gardner told The Observer that he was discussing deals with two 'serious' energy companies in the US following Centrica's £406 million acquisition last week of Canadian-based Direct Energy, North America's largest unregulated gas retailer.

The Direct Energy deal gives Centrica 820,000 gas customers, mainly in Ontario, along with a further 450,000 in the US states of Ohio, Michigan, Georgia, Maryland, Pennsylvania and New Jersey through a joint venture called Energy America. Gardner is looking to add to this - focusing on the eastern Seaboard and Midwest, where energy markets are deregulating, giving Centrica the chance to sell both gas and electricity to some 44 million households.

Gardner said: 'We are in discussion with two serious energy players in the US. Within the next 12 months we will have increased our penetration in terms of customers. That would mean more than doubling the 1.2 million we acquired last week through Energy Direct.' He said his eventual target was more than 5 million customers - an increase on what has been stated before.

Gardner said his favoured strategy was to talk to companies that were separating gas production assets from their customer supply businesses, allowing Centrica to take over supply operations.

He said he was planning to spend the next two years consolidating the company's position in energy, offering dual fuel packages as it has done in the UK, before rolling out other services.

Eventually he plans to mirror Centrica's UK business, which offers financial and 'household' services as well as AA motor services. 'We aim to start with energy, but who knows, in a couple of years we may be into financial services.'

He added: 'US energy companies are also already talking about getting into telecoms - fixed, mobile and internet - and there is no reason why that should not work for us.'

The Direct Energy deal was received positively by the market, which saw it as proof that Centrica was focusing on growth markets.

The shares rose 6.75p to 227p on Thursday but lost some momentum on Friday, closing at 224p.
fields.bodyText: Roy Gardner, head of gas-to-AA motor services group Centrica, is talking to two further US energy suppliers about deals he hopes will more than double the UK company's North American customer base within a year. Gardner told The Observer that he was discussing deals with two 'serious' energy companies in the US following Centrica's £406 million acquisition last week of Canadian-based Direct Energy, North America's largest unregulated gas retailer. The Direct Energy deal gives Centrica 820,000 gas customers, mainly in Ontario, along with a further 450,000 in the US states of Ohio, Michigan, Georgia, Maryland, Pennsylvania and New Jersey through a joint venture called Energy America. Gardner is looking to add to this - focusing on the eastern Seaboard and Midwest, where energy markets are deregulating, giving Centrica the chance to sell both gas and electricity to some 44 million households. Gardner said: 'We are in discussion with two serious energy players in the US. Within the next 12 months we will have increased our penetration in terms of customers. That would mean more than doubling the 1.2 million we acquired last week through Energy Direct.' He said his eventual target was more than 5 million customers - an increase on what has been stated before. Gardner said his favoured strategy was to talk to companies that were separating gas production assets from their customer supply businesses, allowing Centrica to take over supply operations. He said he was planning to spend the next two years consolidating the company's position in energy, offering dual fuel packages as it has done in the UK, before rolling out other services. Eventually he plans to mirror Centrica's UK business, which offers financial and 'household' services as well as AA motor services. 'We aim to start with energy, but who knows, in a couple of years we may be into financial services.' He added: 'US energy companies are also already talking about getting into telecoms - fixed, mobile and internet - and there is no reason why that should not work for us.' The Direct Energy deal was received positively by the market, which saw it as proof that Centrica was focusing on growth markets. The shares rose 6.75p to 227p on Thursday but lost some momentum on Friday, closing at 224p.

webTitle: Time Computers to sue giant IBM

fields.headline: Time Computers to sue giant IBM
fields.trailText: Time Computers, Britain's biggest computer seller, is set to sue giant US rival IBM in a David-and-Goliath contest in the High Court.
fields.body:
Time Computers, Britain's biggest computer seller, is set to sue giant US rival IBM in a David-and-Goliath contest in the High Court.

Time is claiming £13 million compensation from IBM UK for allegedly supplying it with faulty computer components.

The case is due to start in the High Court tomorrow, and unless talks between both firms' lawyers conclude satisfactorily this weekend, a lengthy hearing could seriously harm IBM's reputation.

'There has been no outcome. We are still going through the legal process,' IBM UK spokesman Andrew Goldman said late on Friday.

Time Computers was set up in 1987 by 29-year-old self-made multi-millionaire Tahir Mohsan. From the humblest of starts, selling personal computers by mail order from above a corner shop in Blackburn, the company now runs more than 180 stores around the UK.

Now based near Burnley, it employs over 2,000 staff and has expected sales of over £300m this year. Through showrooms and mail order, Time sells around 400,000 personal computers a year, which it assembles from components supplied by manufacturers such as IBM.

Mohsan, who has always shunned personal publicity, is now worth an estimated £175m. This weekend a spokesman for Time Computers declined to comment on the writ while legal negotiations to settle the dispute were still taking place.

webTitle: Homes are where the hurt is

fields.headline: Homes are where the hurt is
fields.standfirst: We should care for damaged children; instead care is where we put them. But now children's homes are changing. Six young people talk about life without love, but with new hope...
fields.trailText: We should care for damaged children; instead care is where we put them. But now children's homes are changing. Six young people talk about life without love, but with new hope...
fields.body:
'I don't think I ever had a childhood. I'm going to give my own children a childhood. I'm going to love them so much. I'm going to give them everything I can. They'll always have a home. It will be different for them.'

'I'm older than I am. I know more than I should. Nobody should know the things that I know; nobody should go to the places I've been.'

'I got so low I couldn't say anything about what was happening to me. I was too scared, too lonely.'

'When I leave, I'm going to be a chef and cook macaroni cheese and nice things like that. And I'm going to be a foster parent, because I know how it feels to be someone like me.'

'And I'm going to be a foster parent too. I want to help children. And if I had foster children I'd treat them equal with my real children.'

'Me too. I want to care for children. Love them. I would love them and they would be safe with me and I wouldn't give them back.'

'People think that because you're in a home there's something wrong with you...'

'...And you feel there is something wrong with you. You think that if nobody loves you, then you're not lovable.'

'I don't think I've ever been loved.'

'I wouldn't trust anyone any more. Except my cats. My cats love me.'

Six young people talking about their lives at home and in a home - talking without any self-pity, very little anger, no sense that the stories they have to tell are strange and sad and terrible and terribly wrong. This is just what life has been for them. They haven't known anything else. Children are heartbreakingly accepting. They take what's given to them. They go on loving the parents who, for whatever painful reasons of their own, are hurting or neglecting them. In many of their experiences, all those things that most of us hold so dear are given grim inverse meanings. What is a home? A home is where you get put when there's nowhere else to go and no one else who'll have you. What is a childhood? Childhood is powerlessness and pain and loneliness - homesickness, if you like, for the home they've not got. What is a family? A family is where you were in danger, a family is what you have lost. What is care? Care is untender, institutionalised duty and bureaucratic management of you, done by people who sometimes don't care much at all; it's not a warm and fluid verb but a cold noun; you are in care, like being in a room with a high window and a stone floor. What is love? Love is a very dirty word indeed.

Where is hope?

The Waterhouse Report into the widescale abuse that took place in residential homes in Wales was released 10 days ago. It spoke of systematic abuse, a climate of violence and a culture of secrecy that existed for more than two decades. And it made sensible but unambitious recommendations - such as the appointment of a children's commissioner, and protection for whistleblowers. But for most people involved in the welfare of the young, the report did not go nearly far enough. It confined itself to what went on in particular children's homes in Wales over a confined period. It did not look at the plight of children in residential homes and in foster families all over the UK. It did not question the whole structure of care. The Welsh scandal, like the Cleveland child abuse scandal, came at us in a series of lurid headlines and stories so distressing that most of us didn't really want to hear them. Didn't want to hear how professional carers were paedophiles; how young boys and girls had been sexually abused over years and nobody had listened and nothing had been done. At least 12 of the victims had gone on to kill themselves; one had become a convicted murderer; many others had had their lives wrecked.

There will always be children who cannot live with their families. Maybe they have been abused, physically or sexually. Maybe their mother simply cannot cope - because of drugs, alcoholism, illness, severe depression, extreme poverty. And how do we treat these children, the unlucky and the damaged ones? Do our hearts go out to them so that we do everything that we can? Give them a safe structure, professional help, every advantage possible to go a small way towards compensating them for all they've irrevocably lost? Or do we put them in a bleak institution, hire carers who earn as little as £12,000 a year, turn them into 'problems', feed them right back into the vicious circle which produced them?

More than 75 per cent of young people leaving care have no formal qualifications at all; high levels of non-attendance and exclusion from school are very common. Between 50-80 per cent are unemployed (the Who Cares? Trust found that many employers mistrust care leavers). An astonishing 23 per cent of adult prisoners and 38 per cent of young offenders have been in care. At least one in seven young women leave care pregnant or as mothers. Sixty per cent use drugs. Many are homeless. Man hands on misery to man; we know this well enough. So what do we do?

Twenty years ago, when I left college, I worked for a year-and-a-half in a residential home for disturbed children in the North of England. About 18 children lived there, from toddlers through to teenagers. Some had severe learning difficulties; others were emotionally disturbed. There was a girl there whose parents were brother and sister. She had a flaring temper and tempestuous affections; she'd punch you in the face; land a violent wet kiss on your mouth; sob every night, her red clumsy face screwed up tight with anguish, for her mother who never came to visit.

There was a boy who used to paint his bedroom walls with excrement; another who could hold his breath until the blood vessels on his neck popped and he'd pass out; a sexually charged 15-year-old girl who wanted a baby of her own to cuddle. There was a tiny fellow, who'd been severely malnourished as a baby and had arrived at social services curled up naked in a bucket, his distraught mother wailing that she thought her beloved baby was dead. There was a boy I fell in love with, who had a chipped tooth and thick glasses and who never spoke, although everyone knew he could. Every month his mother would come to visit him, and for days after that he would stand at the front door, hour upon hour, waiting for her to come back again. I was young and foolish, and I thought I could love them all better (or even one of them), and, of course, I was wrong. And yet now - two decades and four children later - I look back on my time there and think I was also right. It was a respectable home, no scandals, no children beaten or buggered, but there wasn't much love around.

The children lived in a unit. Their rooms all looked alike, same wallpaper on the wall, bobbly chenille bedspreads on narrow beds, fake pine wardrobes in the corner. Maybe a teddy, but precious little else that they could call their own. No photographs pinned up - of their families or of themselves. They all got up at the same time in the morning, and went to bed at the same time at night. They all had breakfast, lunch, dinner, sitting round a long table, and had to eat up no matter what it was. There was a rota for the bathrooms. At weekends, they had supervised activities - jigsaw time, painting time, football-on-the-patch-of-green-lawn time.

Sometimes we went on outings, piling into a minibus with identical packed lunches. Everything was planned. Time was parcelled out. They didn't hang around with you, learning how to cook, or go shopping, or sit on your lap in front of the telly, or hang on to your legs while you chat with a friend, or have midnight feasts, or do any of the unplanned things that most children get to do. They didn't spend time one-to-one with an adult. They didn't have much opportunity to tell their own stories. Their lives were so threadbare and so dull.

At bedtime, those of us on nights would tuck them in, like parents do with their own children, and kiss them goodnight and maybe sing them a song or read them a book. But we didn't hug them tight and tell them we loved them to bits, and we didn't notice that something was maybe troubling them and sit down to listen to what it was. Later, we didn't creep back to watch them as they slept; tuck the teddy back under their arm or pull the cover back under their chin. And the next night another substitute mother would be there instead, singing 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' and looking at her watch, thinking of going back to her real home.

Things have changed a lot since those days. Fewer children are in resi dential homes, and often they are there for short periods of time, to give their parents respite. Almost none of them are orphans. More energy is put into keeping children, if not with their mothers or fathers, then at least with supported relatives. More children are sent to foster families (which have had their share of scandals). By far the greater proportion of those in residential care are teenagers. Often they chose to be in homes rather than stay with foster parents - after all, they already have a family; they don't want another. The homes are much smaller than they used to be: the average number of children in each one is now seven. Many of the buildings no longer look like units. But, like most jobs that involve touching bodies, getting close to people, the staff are still paid disgraceful wages - a derisory £12,080 a year is the salary on which someone in a home starts. Childcare should be a profession, esteemed and rewarded, like being a solicitor or a doctor. They are men and women who are picking up the pieces of lost childhoods.

I visited a residential home in Walton on the Naze - one of the homes Essex Council is clearly most proud of. Down a lane on the edges of the seaside town, a handsome redbrick house with a large lawn, washing on the line, a radio playing loudly in one of the rooms upstairs, that overlooks the sea. It does not smell like an institution, that cabbage and polish and old sweat odour. No keys jangle off belts. The staff - almost all women - are friendly and welcoming. It is term-time, nearly the end of the school day. As I talk to the manager of the home, Sue, the young people who live here - six at the moment, though it can take up to nine - drift back. They squabble, throw their arms around Sue, demand to go shopping at once. It doesn't feel bureaucratic at all, though there are a number of strictly enforced rules ('boundaries'), like no sex within the home. 'Without clear boundaries and without consistency,' says Sue, 'their life is much scarier. They need to know where they are.'

One of the girls takes me on a guided tour. In the sitting-room, she goes down on her bony knees and puts her hands, with their bitten fingernails, together and says: 'Don't take me away from here, don't let them close this place down. I'm safer here.' Then she shows me her room, where the clothes she has just bought are laid out on the bed. They are all allowed to decorate their rooms however they want. Some are neat, precise, everything in its right place. Others are in chaos, torn football posters on the wall and clothes everywhere. Each has a bathroom next to their room; a key so they can be alone and private. Each has an allowance, which they spend as they choose. They are encouraged to bring friends back from school. 'We try to make it absolutely as normal as we can,' says Sue. But of course it isn't normal. The teenagers here have been through terrible times; they feel a great deal of anger and grief. Some miss their parents a great deal; some are lonely, disturbed.

'We are not their parents, nor should we ever pretend to be.' One of Sue's staff, a young man who grew up in the residential home his parents ran, adds that: 'They want home, of course they do, they rarely stop loving their parents no matter what - but they also know that the safe place and the best place for the time being is here. They know that to be back at home would be painful and maybe damaging to them.'

Respect is the key word here. 'We work on respect,' says Sue. 'We respect the kids - or why should they respect us? When a young person arrives,' she continues, 'we draw up a 24-hour programme, with their help. For instance, we find out how they like to be woken up in the morning. The time that they are in their beds is a nightmare time for many of the children. You can shake them gently and they'll sit up and scream and punch you in the eye. So one of the boys, for instance, we decided with him that the best way was to tweak his toe. Then we find out how to open their bedroom door; what they like to drink in the morning, coffee or tea; sugar or not. What they like for breakfast. You have to give them choice and dignity. If a Martian landed and came here, he could read our files and know exactly how to treat each child.'

'There's always a pattern to abuse,' says David. 'We have to find out what that pattern was so that we don't inadvertently repeat it. If I say to one of the guys, "I'll run you a bath, do you want bubbles?", that could be exactly what the abuser used to do. You've got to ask the young people. What do they want? What don't they want?'

Sue adds: 'If you have a 6ft 6in teenager kicking the door in, you've got to be able to see that he's also a three-year-old who's feeling enormous pain and fear. He's become a child again, begging for attention and you have to see that and deal with it intelligently. When they call me an old fat cow, I know they don't mean it, they mean I'm hurting like hell here. Inside, they're little - there's a damaged little person in need of help. I remember every single child I've ever looked after, and I worry about all of them, and, of course, not all of them are all right. But you can change things,' she says. 'You can chip away. It can take months and months to move a fraction. We never give up here. And the children are heroes - my little heroes.'

Sue believes that every child should have an advocate, which is also what many children's groups want, as they made clear after the Waterhouse Report was released. 'The best protection for children,' said the chief executive of Child in Care, 'is to empower them to speak up.'

One of the most nightmarish aspects of what happened in Welsh homes is that victims did go to staff, but they were not listened to. Guy Cave is an NSPCC-managed child advocate in Croydon. His job, he says, is not to speak up for the young people, but to help them find their own voices. The Croydon Children and Young People's Rights Service that he runs has been named, by the young people themselves, Respect. It has made up 10 commandments for social workers, which include obvious rules, such as 'social workers should keep their promises'. Guy Cave says that he has heard social workers saying things to a young person like: 'I have got other cases, you know.'

'Part of my job is a kind of assertiveness training and not just over things like abuse,' says Cave. 'For instance, one young person went from a foster home to a residential home, and he wasn't allowed back to collect his photographs. That may seem a little thing, but photographs can be powerful possessions for them. I'm not like a social worker. I am not doing what I think is best for them. I don't make that judgment. I am helping them to say what they think is best for themselves. I am helping them to find a voice. Often, young people in care are silent. We never hear from them, only occasionally about them. They have stories to tell and their stories aren't listened to.'

A few days later, I met up with a group of young people who live, or have lived, in residential homes in London. They decided they wanted to go to an American-style restaurant in Soho. When I told them that they could eat whatever they wanted, they looked at me as if I came from another world. 'More than one course? Two courses?' 'Three!' I said. 'As much as you want.'

They ordered platters of spicy chicken wings, giant steaks, baskets of chips, great goblets of ice-cream sundaes with chocolate fudge sauce. They smoked like chimneys and giggled. They told me stories - fragments of their own stories...

Eileen's story

My mum and dad divorced when I was six or seven. Then it was just me and my mum. She was always an aggressive drinker, an aggressive person. I felt safer with my dad. But I did love her. I thought one day she'd stop and everything would be all right. I was very scared as a child. I knew other people had it better, but I sort of didn't realise it fully. It was just normal, to be scared all the time. I guess I had no real childhood. She was beating me all the time, knocking me round the room, saying she was going to kill me, kill herself, there'd be foam coming out of her mouth. When I was 12 , I had a kind of wake-up call. I realised it wasn't going to stop. I started running away. I'd sleep in parks and things. Then I went and put myself voluntarily in care. It was weird, but when I arrived in the home, I felt free for the first time. But then they sent me back to her, to try again. She tried to kill herself. So I went back into care. I was 14 when I got pregnant, 15 when I became a mother. People think that's terrible. It was the best thing that ever happened to me. My daughter saved me, brought me back from the edge. God knows what would have happened to me without her. She's my angel and my saviour. Now I have two daughters. I am not going to be like my mother. I'm going to protect my kids, be their friend. And I want to work with kids like me, because no one should be a kid like me. And I will do it.

Will's story

I'm the oldest of seven; most of us have different fathers. My mum was ill a lot when I was a child; in hospital a lot. She did care. But she couldn't cope, not when we were all there. She did her best. We were always moving around council estates. I had asthma badly. And I had trouble with my stepfathers - I used to be badly beaten up by one and locked in my room. If I ever see him again I'm going to kill him and get my own back for what he did.

Then a friend of the family abused me sexually. He abused all of us kids. That's when I first went into care, and it was so dreadful, I was so lonely. I was very young - and I have to live with the fact that it was because of me that we all went, because I snitched, and if it wasn't for me they'd still be with Mum. I never really had a childhood; I was too busy looking after the others. The best time was living for three years with my foster family - that was the longest stretch of time I've ever stayed anywhere and they were good to me.

I've not really had any education; I didn't used to care but now I do. I've been to 30 primary schools, a couple of secondary schools, more than 30 homes, hostels, foster families - you name it, I've lived in it. You name it, it's been done to me. That's the way life was. Now I feel sorry because sometimes I hear about what life is meant to be like for kids and I had none of that. But I love my mother. I don't blame her. One day I will get married and have kids of my own.

Clinton's story (Will's brother)

We were all abused. There are things I can't say - did Will say? I can't really speak about that. Well, I went into long-term care when I was eight. Before that, I was in and out. I started off with foster parents with Will and my sister. But they moved and couldn't take us with them. I liked them. Then we went to other foster parents and I hated it. I got the blame for everything. Their daughter's boyfriend kept hitting me. I used to get tied up in my room. I kept running away. It was awful. So I was sent to a home. It's better. Not good, though. There's a lot of bullying. People threaten to stab you if you don't give them cigarettes. I get bullied at school too, so I don't go there any more. Most of the time, I stay away. I go to the library. I get lonely a lot of the time, and think about other people's lives. I'd like someone to foster me again. I'm waiting for that.

Nizia's story

I can't really say about me. I'm not good at talking. I usually stay silent and other people talk about me. My mother died when I was five. I think she used to love me. I lived with my father in France. He didn't love me. He's never loved me. He sent me back here, to be taken into care.

I didn't want foster-parents. I prefer to be in a home. I've got used to it. There have been people who have cared about me in their own way, but I don't think I've ever been loved.

There must be something wrong with me. That's all.

Peter's story

My mum and dad didn't get on. When I was nine, my mum left. I didn't know where she was. I was really miserable because I loved her. My dad - he didn't beat me up, but he never liked me. I begged and begged and at 12 I went to my mum's. That was the best bit - the journey to be with her, thinking everything would be good again. But my stepdad didn't like me at all. He beat me up a lot and my mum didn't intervene. She said she didn't want to take sides. But I thought she was taking his side by not protecting me from him. Parents are supposed to protect you, aren't they? It was frightening and lonely and I got so low I couldn't say anything. I felt betrayed. I had been so happy to think that I'd be with her again. There was a day, a Thursday, when I was 14, when he beat me up again and I had bruises all over and I thought, right, that's it, I'm off. I wrote a letter saying: don't try to find me. Then I went to a friend's house and her mum got in touch with the social services. They sent me to my nan, but that didn't work out at all. They found me a foster-parent. I was supposed to stay for a weekend, while they sorted something out; then it turned into two more weeks; then another month. I ended up there on a permanent basis. I was really, really, really happy. They were kind to me. I liked my foster brother. Do you know what - I am lucky, aren't I? Lucky. It turned out perfect.

Tina's story

I was 12 when I went into care. Everything was a mess. My mum left when I was two; my dad beat her and she couldn't take us any more, but he beat us too, me and my brother.

There wasn't sexual abuse. My dad beat us with his belt. I was covered in bruises. I sorted it out by running away when I was 11.

I went to mum's - she used to send me a birthday card every year, so I knew her address. After all these years, nine years of never seeing her, I didn't know her. I had this photo of her, but she didn't look like that any more.

I couldn't call her mum. She'd left me. She was a stranger. I couldn't tell her anything. And she was an alcoholic, like my dad.

Well, we didn't get on and one day we had a big fight and she phoned the social workers and told them to take me away; she didn't want me.

I went to a foster family, but I wanted to be allowed to go out and things and my foster mother was strict, and she sent me back.

So I ended up in a children's home, a short stay unit. Then another home, with my sister. But me and my sister started arguing and they split us up. I was so upset. She was all I had left. Then I went to another home.

In the end, they found a foster family for me and I stayed there until I was 16. We had our ups and downs, but we sorted them out. I was glad to be independent, though.

I couldn't wait. I had a boyfriend, but he started beating me up, trying to strangle me. He's in a mental hospital now. I've left all that now - I work in the kitchens of a YMCA.

Sometimes I think how my life seems to have gone like my parents' life - I always said if anyone hits me just once, I'd be gone. But I stayed and I stayed.

Now I have to learn to be me, myself. I'll never live with anyone again. I'll never trust anyone. I'm on my own.

Maybe their mother simply cannot cope - because of drugs, alcoholism, illness, severe depression, extreme poverty. And how do we treat these children, the unlucky and the damaged ones? Do our hearts go out to them so that we do everything that we can? Give them a safe structure, professional help, every advantage possible to go a small way towards compensating them for all they've irrevocably lost? Or do we put them in a bleak institution, hire carers who earn as little as £12,000 a year, turn them into 'problems', feed them right back into the vicious circle which produced them? More than 75 per cent of young people leaving care have no formal qualifications at all; high levels of non-attendance and exclusion from school are very common. Between 50-80 per cent are unemployed (the Who Cares? Trust found that many employers mistrust care leavers). An astonishing 23 per cent of adult prisoners and 38 per cent of young offenders have been in care. At least one in seven young women leave care pregnant or as mothers. Sixty per cent use drugs. Many are homeless. Man hands on misery to man; we know this well enough. So what do we do? Twenty years ago, when I left college, I worked for a year-and-a-half in a residential home for disturbed children in the North of England. About 18 children lived there, from toddlers through to teenagers. Some had severe learning difficulties; others were emotionally disturbed. There was a girl there whose parents were brother and sister. She had a flaring temper and tempestuous affections; she'd punch you in the face; land a violent wet kiss on your mouth; sob every night, her red clumsy face screwed up tight with anguish, for her mother who never came to visit. There was a boy who used to paint his bedroom walls with excrement; another who could hold his breath until the blood vessels on his neck popped and he'd pass out; a sexually charged 15-year-old girl who wanted a baby of her own to cuddle. There was a tiny fellow, who'd been severely malnourished as a baby and had arrived at social services curled up naked in a bucket, his distraught mother wailing that she thought her beloved baby was dead. There was a boy I fell in love with, who had a chipped tooth and thick glasses and who never spoke, although everyone knew he could. Every month his mother would come to visit him, and for days after that he would stand at the front door, hour upon hour, waiting for her to come back again. I was young and foolish, and I thought I could love them all better (or even one of them), and, of course, I was wrong. And yet now - two decades and four children later - I look back on my time there and think I was also right. It was a respectable home, no scandals, no children beaten or buggered, but there wasn't much love around. The children lived in a unit. Their rooms all looked alike, same wallpaper on the wall, bobbly chenille bedspreads on narrow beds, fake pine wardrobes in the corner. Maybe a teddy, but precious little else that they could call their own. No photographs pinned up - of their families or of themselves. They all got up at the same time in the morning, and went to bed at the same time at night. They all had breakfast, lunch, dinner, sitting round a long table, and had to eat up no matter what it was. There was a rota for the bathrooms. At weekends, they had supervised activities - jigsaw time, painting time, football-on-the-patch-of-green-lawn time. Sometimes we went on outings, piling into a minibus with identical packed lunches. Everything was planned. Time was parcelled out. They didn't hang around with you, learning how to cook, or go shopping, or sit on your lap in front of the telly, or hang on to your legs while you chat with a friend, or have midnight feasts, or do any of the unplanned things that most children get to do. They didn't spend time one-to-one with an adult. They didn't have much opportunity to tell their own stories. Their lives were so threadbare and so dull. At bedtime, those of us on nights would tuck them in, like parents do with their own children, and kiss them goodnight and maybe sing them a song or read them a book. But we didn't hug them tight and tell them we loved them to bits, and we didn't notice that something was maybe troubling them and sit down to listen to what it was. Later, we didn't creep back to watch them as they slept; tuck the teddy back under their arm or pull the cover back under their chin. And the next night another substitute mother would be there instead, singing 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' and looking at her watch, thinking of going back to her real home. Things have changed a lot since those days. Fewer children are in resi dential homes, and often they are there for short periods of time, to give their parents respite. Almost none of them are orphans. More energy is put into keeping children, if not with their mothers or fathers, then at least with supported relatives. More children are sent to foster families (which have had their share of scandals). By far the greater proportion of those in residential care are teenagers. Often they chose to be in homes rather than stay with foster parents - after all, they already have a family; they don't want another. The homes are much smaller than they used to be: the average number of children in each one is now seven. Many of the buildings no longer look like units. But, like most jobs that involve touching bodies, getting close to people, the staff are still paid disgraceful wages - a derisory £12,080 a year is the salary on which someone in a home starts. Childcare should be a profession, esteemed and rewarded, like being a solicitor or a doctor. They are men and women who are picking up the pieces of lost childhoods. I visited a residential home in Walton on the Naze - one of the homes Essex Council is clearly most proud of. Down a lane on the edges of the seaside town, a handsome redbrick house with a large lawn, washing on the line, a radio playing loudly in one of the rooms upstairs, that overlooks the sea. It does not smell like an institution, that cabbage and polish and old sweat odour. No keys jangle off belts. The staff - almost all women - are friendly and welcoming. It is term-time, nearly the end of the school day. As I talk to the manager of the home, Sue, the young people who live here - six at the moment, though it can take up to nine - drift back. They squabble, throw their arms around Sue, demand to go shopping at once. It doesn't feel bureaucratic at all, though there are a number of strictly enforced rules ('boundaries'), like no sex within the home. 'Without clear boundaries and without consistency,' says Sue, 'their life is much scarier. They need to know where they are.' One of the girls takes me on a guided tour. In the sitting-room, she goes down on her bony knees and puts her hands, with their bitten fingernails, together and says: 'Don't take me away from here, don't let them close this place down. I'm safer here.' Then she shows me her room, where the clothes she has just bought are laid out on the bed. They are all allowed to decorate their rooms however they want. Some are neat, precise, everything in its right place. Others are in chaos, torn football posters on the wall and clothes everywhere. Each has a bathroom next to their room; a key so they can be alone and private. Each has an allowance, which they spend as they choose. They are encouraged to bring friends back from school. 'We try to make it absolutely as normal as we can,' says Sue. But of course it isn't normal. The teenagers here have been through terrible times; they feel a great deal of anger and grief. Some miss their parents a great deal; some are lonely, disturbed. 'We are not their parents, nor should we ever pretend to be.' One of Sue's staff, a young man who grew up in the residential home his parents ran, adds that: 'They want home, of course they do, they rarely stop loving their parents no matter what - but they also know that the safe place and the best place for the time being is here. They know that to be back at home would be painful and maybe damaging to them.' Respect is the key word here. 'We work on respect,' says Sue. 'We respect the kids - or why should they respect us? When a young person arrives,' she continues, 'we draw up a 24-hour programme, with their help. For instance, we find out how they like to be woken up in the morning. The time that they are in their beds is a nightmare time for many of the children. You can shake them gently and they'll sit up and scream and punch you in the eye. So one of the boys, for instance, we decided with him that the best way was to tweak his toe. Then we find out how to open their bedroom door; what they like to drink in the morning, coffee or tea; sugar or not. What they like for breakfast. You have to give them choice and dignity. If a Martian landed and came here, he could read our files and know exactly how to treat each child.' 'There's always a pattern to abuse,' says David. 'We have to find out what that pattern was so that we don't inadvertently repeat it. If I say to one of the guys, "I'll run you a bath, do you want bubbles?", that could be exactly what the abuser used to do. You've got to ask the young people. What do they want? What don't they want?' Sue adds: 'If you have a 6ft 6in teenager kicking the door in, you've got to be able to see that he's also a three-year-old who's feeling enormous pain and fear. He's become a child again, begging for attention and you have to see that and deal with it intelligently. When they call me an old fat cow, I know they don't mean it, they mean I'm hurting like hell here. Inside, they're little - there's a damaged little person in need of help. I remember every single child I've ever looked after, and I worry about all of them, and, of course, not all of them are all right. But you can change things,' she says. 'You can chip away. It can take months and months to move a fraction. We never give up here. And the children are heroes - my little heroes.' Sue believes that every child should have an advocate, which is also what many children's groups want, as they made clear after the Waterhouse Report was released. 'The best protection for children,' said the chief executive of Child in Care, 'is to empower them to speak up.' One of the most nightmarish aspects of what happened in Welsh homes is that victims did go to staff, but they were not listened to. Guy Cave is an NSPCC-managed child advocate in Croydon. His job, he says, is not to speak up for the young people, but to help them find their own voices. The Croydon Children and Young People's Rights Service that he runs has been named, by the young people themselves, Respect. It has made up 10 commandments for social workers, which include obvious rules, such as 'social workers should keep their promises'. Guy Cave says that he has heard social workers saying things to a young person like: 'I have got other cases, you know.' 'Part of my job is a kind of assertiveness training and not just over things like abuse,' says Cave. 'For instance, one young person went from a foster home to a residential home, and he wasn't allowed back to collect his photographs. That may seem a little thing, but photographs can be powerful possessions for them. I'm not like a social worker. I am not doing what I think is best for them. I don't make that judgment. I am helping them to say what they think is best for themselves. I am helping them to find a voice. Often, young people in care are silent. We never hear from them, only occasionally about them. They have stories to tell and their stories aren't listened to.' A few days later, I met up with a group of young people who live, or have lived, in residential homes in London. They decided they wanted to go to an American-style restaurant in Soho. When I told them that they could eat whatever they wanted, they looked at me as if I came from another world. 'More than one course? Two courses?' 'Three!' I said. 'As much as you want.' They ordered platters of spicy chicken wings, giant steaks, baskets of chips, great goblets of ice-cream sundaes with chocolate fudge sauce. They smoked like chimneys and giggled. They told me stories - fragments of their own stories... Eileen's story My mum and dad divorced when I was six or seven. Then it was just me and my mum. She was always an aggressive drinker, an aggressive person. I felt safer with my dad. But I did love her. I thought one day she'd stop and everything would be all right. I was very scared as a child. I knew other people had it better, but I sort of didn't realise it fully. It was just normal, to be scared all the time. I guess I had no real childhood. She was beating me all the time, knocking me round the room, saying she was going to kill me, kill herself, there'd be foam coming out of her mouth. When I was 12 , I had a kind of wake-up call. I realised it wasn't going to stop. I started running away. I'd sleep in parks and things. Then I went and put myself voluntarily in care. It was weird, but when I arrived in the home, I felt free for the first time. But then they sent me back to her, to try again. She tried to kill herself. So I went back into care. I was 14 when I got pregnant, 15 when I became a mother. People think that's terrible. It was the best thing that ever happened to me. My daughter saved me, brought me back from the edge. God knows what would have happened to me without her. She's my angel and my saviour. Now I have two daughters. I am not going to be like my mother. I'm going to protect my kids, be their friend. And I want to work with kids like me, because no one should be a kid like me. And I will do it. Will's story I'm the oldest of seven; most of us have different fathers. My mum was ill a lot when I was a child; in hospital a lot. She did care. But she couldn't cope, not when we were all there. She did her best. We were always moving around council estates. I had asthma badly. And I had trouble with my stepfathers - I used to be badly beaten up by one and locked in my room. If I ever see him again I'm going to kill him and get my own back for what he did. Then a friend of the family abused me sexually. He abused all of us kids. That's when I first went into care, and it was so dreadful, I was so lonely. I was very young - and I have to live with the fact that it was because of me that we all went, because I snitched, and if it wasn't for me they'd still be with Mum. I never really had a childhood; I was too busy looking after the others. The best time was living for three years with my foster family - that was the longest stretch of time I've ever stayed anywhere and they were good to me. I've not really had any education; I didn't used to care but now I do. I've been to 30 primary schools, a couple of secondary schools, more than 30 homes, hostels, foster families - you name it, I've lived in it. You name it, it's been done to me. That's the way life was. Now I feel sorry because sometimes I hear about what life is meant to be like for kids and I had none of that. But I love my mother. I don't blame her. One day I will get married and have kids of my own. Clinton's story (Will's brother) We were all abused. There are things I can't say - did Will say? I can't really speak about that. Well, I went into long-term care when I was eight. Before that, I was in and out. I started off with foster parents with Will and my sister. But they moved and couldn't take us with them. I liked them. Then we went to other foster parents and I hated it. I got the blame for everything. Their daughter's boyfriend kept hitting me. I used to get tied up in my room. I kept running away. It was awful. So I was sent to a home. It's better. Not good, though. There's a lot of bullying. People threaten to stab you if you don't give them cigarettes. I get bullied at school too, so I don't go there any more. Most of the time, I stay away. I go to the library. I get lonely a lot of the time, and think about other people's lives. I'd like someone to foster me again. I'm waiting for that. Nizia's story I can't really say about me. I'm not good at talking. I usually stay silent and other people talk about me. My mother died when I was five. I think she used to love me. I lived with my father in France. He didn't love me. He's never loved me. He sent me back here, to be taken into care. I didn't want foster-parents. I prefer to be in a home. I've got used to it. There have been people who have cared about me in their own way, but I don't think I've ever been loved. There must be something wrong with me. That's all. Peter's story My mum and dad didn't get on. When I was nine, my mum left. I didn't know where she was. I was really miserable because I loved her. My dad - he didn't beat me up, but he never liked me. I begged and begged and at 12 I went to my mum's. That was the best bit - the journey to be with her, thinking everything would be good again. But my stepdad didn't like me at all. He beat me up a lot and my mum didn't intervene. She said she didn't want to take sides. But I thought she was taking his side by not protecting me from him. Parents are supposed to protect you, aren't they? It was frightening and lonely and I got so low I couldn't say anything. I felt betrayed. I had been so happy to think that I'd be with her again. There was a day, a Thursday, when I was 14, when he beat me up again and I had bruises all over and I thought, right, that's it, I'm off. I wrote a letter saying: don't try to find me. Then I went to a friend's house and her mum got in touch with the social services. They sent me to my nan, but that didn't work out at all. They found me a foster-parent. I was supposed to stay for a weekend, while they sorted something out; then it turned into two more weeks; then another month. I ended up there on a permanent basis. I was really, really, really happy. They were kind to me. I liked my foster brother. Do you know what - I am lucky, aren't I? Lucky. It turned out perfect. Tina's story I was 12 when I went into care. Everything was a mess. My mum left when I was two; my dad beat her and she couldn't take us any more, but he beat us too, me and my brother. There wasn't sexual abuse. My dad beat us with his belt. I was covered in bruises. I sorted it out by running away when I was 11. I went to mum's - she used to send me a birthday card every year, so I knew her address. After all these years, nine years of never seeing her, I didn't know her. I had this photo of her, but she didn't look like that any more. I couldn't call her mum. She'd left me. She was a stranger. I couldn't tell her anything. And she was an alcoholic, like my dad. Well, we didn't get on and one day we had a big fight and she phoned the social workers and told them to take me away; she didn't want me. I went to a foster family, but I wanted to be allowed to go out and things and my foster mother was strict, and she sent me back. So I ended up in a children's home, a short stay unit. Then another home, with my sister. But me and my sister started arguing and they split us up. I was so upset. She was all I had left. Then I went to another home. In the end, they found a foster family for me and I stayed there until I was 16. We had our ups and downs, but we sorted them out. I was glad to be independent, though. I couldn't wait. I had a boyfriend, but he started beating me up, trying to strangle me. He's in a mental hospital now. I've left all that now - I work in the kitchens of a YMCA. Sometimes I think how my life seems to have gone like my parents' life - I always said if anyone hits me just once, I'd be gone. But I stayed and I stayed. Now I have to learn to be me, myself. I'll never live with anyone again. I'll never trust anyone. I'm on my own.

webTitle: I'm leaving on a jet plane... again

fields.headline: I'm leaving on a jet plane... again
fields.standfirst: Pico Iyer meditates on the life of the modern nomad in The Global Soul
fields.trailText: Pico Iyer meditates on the life of the modern nomad in The Global Soul
fields.body:
The Global Soul: Jet Lag, Shopping Malls and the Search for Home
Pico Iyer
Bloomsbury £15.99, pp303
Buy it at BOL

If our newly borderless, transistorised globe has a face, it probably belongs to Pico Iyer, creased with jet lag, blinking in consternation as the mind struggles to catch up with the ballistic body, deracinated and unplaceable, able to fit in anywhere but at home, happiest when 30,000 feet above the anchoring earth. I recognise myself in him, and many others will find he has mirrored the blurred and mutable sense of self which comes with a life spent in transit between cultures.

Iyer is a hybrid being or rather, to use his wry term, a mongrel. Despite being a homeless stray, he has an impeccable pedigree. His parents were Indian intellectuals who migrated first to England and later to California. Votaries of the Raj, they sent their son to Eton. Jumbo jets were his school bus, though he always felt more welcome in the jostling anonymity of Heathrow than at the school a few miles from the airport, where his surrogate parents were a frosty matron and a one-eyed clergyman.

Iyer is technically a Hindu, but he speaks no Hindi, and cannot even pronounce his polysyllabic Indian name. Luckily, his family prepared him for an expatriate existence: they also called him Pico, after the Renaissance mystic Pico della Mirandola. This name carried a destiny with it, and when not on a plane, Iyer can sometimes be found in a monastery, where he goes to reflect on the absurdity of his other, airborne life.

He quit England after graduating from Oxford, and now has an address in Santa Barbara. Nevertheless, the United States classifies him as a resident alien, which is little better than an extraterrestrial. Actually, he lives in a mock-Californian suburb across the Pacific outside Osaka. His partner is a Japanese woman, with whom he shares no language - they converse in a post-modern pidgin. His employer, Time magazine, has its headquarters half a world away.

Iyer's working life is jet-propelled. Time sends him to the Olympic Games, making him responsible for every sport on offer, so he races 'from cycling to three-day eventing to badminton arenas every day from dawn till after midnight for 16 days'. He then retreats for a while to his hermitage above the ocean - not to meditate, I suspect, but to sleep.

Iyer's first collection of essays, Video Night in Kathmandu, took delight in the incongruity of a new, garishly Westernised Asia. Recently, his tone has become more sober and philosophical. Falling Off the Map included an account of Cuba as an 'elegiac carnival' and a haunting commentary on the loneliness of Australia, with its high, smiling, empty skies.

The Global Soul retains the dizzy elation of his first book, but also stays true to the worried conscience, which first appeared in his memoir, The Lady and the Monk. Iyer rejoices in the gibberish of our international 'multiculture' - on display, for instance, in his Japanese neighbourhood, where you can get your hair cut at the 'Louvre Miason de Coiffure', the 'Musée Hair and Make' or the 'Jollier Cut and Parm' (whose name pays garbled homage to that hirsute goddess Julia Roberts).

Yet he wonders whether the human soul can dilate to comprehend a world which lacks localities and the native affections they inspire. Despite Time's urgent orders to chase events, Iyer wants to be 'free, a little of the moment' and to 'get such news as I need from the falling of the leaves'. The frequent flyer yearns to be grounded.

He takes his mixed motives to a variety of symbolic settings, theme-parks of contemporary placelessness: the airport in Los Angeles, the chaotic marketplace of Hong Kong or the global village hurriedly constructed in Atlanta to house Olympic athletes. He touches down for an extended stay in Toronto, a 'global city' where diversity creates 'not dissonance but a higher symphony'. Here, for once, he loses me. Toronto, flinching from the nearby US border, has always seemed to me too doughtily British for its own good.

The book concludes in Kyoto, where Iyer falls into a 'deep, deep sleep' and dreams, to his surprise, of England with its 'green, green hills'. The repetitive incantation reveals the poetic homesickness, which underlies all this hectic toing and froing. Jet lag deepens into a mystical reverie; like all travellers, Iyer is in search of a lost, fictional paradise.

Supposedly about our shared future, The Global Soul ends by retreating into his personal past. Iyer several times quotes Jan Morris approvingly, his predecessor as a memorialist of Empire. More than travel writers, both are analysts of the unstable, fluctuant human state. But Morris has managed to combine a career of exhausting itineracy with a reverence for home, identified by her with the green, green hills of Wales.

Iyer's remembered hills, by contrast, are no more than a mirage. She comes back to Mother Nature, while he has only the more abstract solace of the monastery. Commuting between Time and eternity, Iyer helps us to understand the disoriented, directionless contemporary condition.

fields.headline: The intelligent consumer
fields.standfirst: What to eat for lunch to stop you feeling drowsy in the afternoon, how to get off to sleep better at night, and do you really need a proper breakfast? The answers to these questions and more can be found in our two-part serialisation of Life columnist Jane Clarke's new Bodyfoods Cookbook. This week, she whips up delicious energising treats for breakfast and lunch, as well as suggesting what to eat when you're feeling down or suffering from swinging energy levels. Here, she explains how her love for food and cooking became her life
fields.trailText: What to eat for lunch to stop you feeling drowsy in the afternoon, how to get off to sleep better at night, and do you really need a proper breakfast? The answers to these questions and more can be found in our two-part serialisation of Life columnist Jane Clarke's new Bodyfoods Cookbook. This week, she whips up delicious energising treats for breakfast and lunch, as well as suggesting what to eat when you're feeling down or suffering from swinging energy levels. Here, she explains how her love for food and cooking became her life
fields.body:
When I was little, we used to go and stay with my great-auntie May and her husband Tom and I was struck by how much they enjoyed food. Breakfast toast was cooked on the fire in winter, and there would always be napkins, but not in a pretentious way. My mother was a good cook, too, but Auntie May gave me my burning desire to make food an enjoyable and loving thing. We always ate together as a family, and even if there's just the two of you, it's good to take even 10 minutes to eat together, rather than grabbing something from the fridge and eating it in front of the TV.

One of the very first things I remember making was cheesecake at primary school - the gelatine went all into strands. But I was always in the kitchen with Mum, and I'd just cook instinctively, make things up. Even then I cared about food - laying a tray, not just plonking fruit and cheese on a board but adding grapes and walnuts - because that's what Auntie May used to do. The way food looks is very important - when I first went into private practice, I used to keep recipe books in my rooms to stimulate patients. I still don't really use them myself, although I love Claudia Roden - it's all so simple and her love of food shines through in her writing.

As a teenager, I was interested in studying medicine, but I wanted to use food instead of drugs. I see a lot of people with cancer, some of whom have tried every other avenue and think I can make everything all right, but I can't. My mission is to encourage you to make the connection between what you put into your stomach and the way in which your life unfolds as a result. Having previously written two books - Bodyfoods for Women and Bodyfoods for Life - I thought it was time to explore eating habits more widely, to see how simple dishes and the way we put them together can help us tune into what our body needs. I hope that the following extracts from my new Bodyfoods Cookbook will inspire you to adopt delicious and nutritious eating habits that are both easy and achievable. I've kept things simple because you shouldn't have to hunt hard to find ingredients - you can hopefully find the ingredients to make everything from simple snacks to more exotic dinner party 'hits' in your local supermarket or delicatessen. The ingredients contained in every recipe have been included with the sole purpose of combining flavour with health-giving properties, but each recipe also features a 'magic ingredient', an ingredient that has a specific health-giving quality.

Breakfast-time boosts

Despite the saying 'Breakfast like a king, lunch like a knave and dine like a pauper', there is no hard-and-fast rule about when, or how much, you should eat. Instead, it's a question of understanding how your body responds to food and how you can maximise your wellbeing through eating. Breakfast provides an invaluable opportunity to enable you to do the latter. A bowl of fresh fruit salad eaten shortly after getting up, for example, will provide a slow release of energy to help you to get through the morning, as well as a good dose of vitamins and minerals. Scrambled eggs on toast, on the other hand, supply a dose of protein that goes towards building up your muscles, which is particularly necessary if you expend a lot of physical energy throughout the day.

Everyone responds differently to food in the morning: some people feel sleepy and unable to function after eating a large breakfast, whereas others need a hearty breakfast before they embark upon the day's activities. Although there is a lot of confusion about the necessity of having breakfast as a result of these differing reactions, it is important to consider the scientific evidence. It has been proven that the body performs and feels better if you eat something (however little) between waking up and having lunch. Because you have had to rely on your body's nutrient reserves to keep you going overnight, the morning is the best time to start topping them up again. Scientific studies have furthermore shown that children who either skip breakfast or eat very little at the start of the day are at a disadvantage when compared with those who eat a healthy breakfast. This is because the brains of children who have empty stomachs tend to receive less than the ideal level of blood sugar. Although this doesn't mean that they're likely to keel over at any moment, certain parts of their memories may not work as well as they should, which may cause problems at school. Children who've breakfasted properly generally have better reaction times and are also more proficient at such problem-solving exercises as mental arithmetic (this is most apparent in children with lower IQs).

A well-nourished brain can improve adults' ability to recall information, too, because it has received sufficient fuel (that is, sugar) to enable it to perform effectively. Before you start reaching for a sugar lump, however, you should understand that the sugar = brain-fuel formula is not that simple. For example, if you eat a sugar lump or gulp down a can of sweetened 'sports drink' first thing in the morning when you have an empty stomach, your blood-sugar level will shoot up, consequently stimulating your body to secrete a large amount of insulin (the hormone that transfers sugar from the blood to the body's cells). This insulin reaction will in turn cause your blood-sugar level to plummet, thus leaving your brain with very little sugar to work with.

Instead, the best way in which to deliver sugar to your brain is to package it within a high-fibre, carbohydrate-rich food, such as wholemeal bread, wholegrain cereal, oats or fresh fruit. The fibre in such foods helps to slow down the rate at which sugar is released into the blood and carried to the brain, thereby enabling you to remain focused.

The wide range of high-fibre, carbohydrate-rich foods offers you flexibility and choice at breakfast time. If time is short in the morning, how about a puréed fruit drink, such as a banana and pineapple smoothie? Smoothies (puréed fruit drinks) are ideal breakfasts, being both quick to make and containing energising properties. They are also a good way in which to give children a vitamin boost at the beginning of the day. Refreshing and revitalising drinks, they can be made with various combinations of fruits, such as oranges, grapefruits, apricots, peaches and other seasonal fruits, with or without added yogurt. Try adding a few baked fruits or a spoonful of puréed fruit to smoothies, as these give a slightly different texture. This breakfast can be eaten at home, as well as at the gym after a work-out, or after you've arrived at the office.

If your early mornings are not so rushed, relaxing over a wild-mushroom omelette with fresh herbs is a highly effective way in which to prepare yourself for some productive hours. However, pregnant women and people who have compromised immune systems should avoid eating undercooked and soft-boiled eggs. Although children under the age of eight or nine months can eat cooked egg yolks, egg whites are more challenging to a young gut, so you should wait until your children are a year old before feeding them eggs. Remember that breakfast doesn't have to be eaten at a set time each day, although you should try to have something within a couple of hours of getting up. Another good reason why you should eat a little something in the morning is because your digestive system performs much more efficiently if it is allowed to work on a small amount of food every few hours.

Long and short lunches

Lunches have changed over the past 50 years. Gone are the days when we stopped work for a couple of hours and went home to tuck into the substantial main meal of the day. By contrast, today it's more often a question of making a quick dash to the sandwich shop and then hastily consuming our purchase while working, or perhaps worse still, having a couple of mouthfuls of the children's left-overs, followed by a quick cup of coffee and a chocolate biscuit. For many of us, taking the time to have lunch seems like too much of an indulgence, one that we save for the weekend, when we can afford the time and can also cope better with the sleepy feelings that we frequently experience when our stomachs are full.

If we choose the foods that suit our bodies, lunch should provide the perfect opportunity to supply ourselves with nutritional, energising fuel. Yet many people don't like to take a food break in the middle of the day because they end up feeling far from energised, wanting instead to crawl into bed for a catnap. Because we lead demanding, highly stressed lives, we want and need to feel alert, not sleepy, during the afternoon.

What many of us don't realise, however, is that the type of food that we eat, as well as the manner in which we eat it, influences how we feel. For instance, pasta, bread and other starchy foods encourage the brain to produce sleep-inducing hormones. This happens because these foods need to be digested slowly, which means that the stomach and digestive system (which is, after all, a muscle) require oxygen to perform their duties efficiently. The brain therefore secretes hormones that encourage us to sleep in order to diminish both our desire and physiological ability to divert oxygen from our stomach to our limbs to enable us to rush around. If we ignore the effect of these hormones, however, and instead command our limbs to move energetically, oxygen is diverted from the stomach, which frequently leads to indigestion, stomach cramps and bloating.

In short, the brain's response to these starchy foods is one that is conditioned by physiological efficiency. If you have time to take a siesta after lunch, perhaps at the weekend, then by all means go ahead and make a dish like my pasta with courgettes and lemon or baby potatoes topped with guacamole and roasted peppers; eating these foods and then having a little snooze is the best way to allow your body to enjoy and digest them. If you don't have the time, however, choose a protein, fruit and vegetable-based lunch in which the proportion of vegetables, fruits and/or protein is high, such as my asparagus and lemon salad, a bowl of courgette and pea soup or a chunk of cheese with some figs, grapes and crisp, green celery. By opting for such foods, your body's hormonal response will encourage, not hinder, your desire to be energetic in the afternoon.

There is a further benefit of having a protein-rich lunch, too. Proteins are made up of amino acids, two of which, L-phenylalanine and tryptophan, encourage the body to produce endorphins (mood-enhancing hormones). Eating a protein-rich lunch, like my sea bass with crab, chicken Caesar salad or some lean charcuterie with cherry tomatoes, therefore not only helps to prevent the mood swings that may occur mid-afternoon, but also enables your body's blood-sugar levels to remain more constant (which means that you shouldn't experience 'sugar dips' at 4pm). If eating protein-rich foods doesn't appeal to you, having a fruit- or vegetable-based lunch, like a bowl of soup followed by some fruit, can similarly energise your body.

If you are organised and a little eclectic in your thinking, you can turn lunch into an interesting affair, rather than settling for the which-sandwich-bores-me-least? option. Practicality is usually a big issue, which is why sandwich bars may initially appear to be your only resort as a convenient source of lunch, but why not make a large cauldron of soup or a tray of grilled vegetables at home at the weekend to take to work in small plastic containers and then heat them up in the microwave at work (if your office has one)? Alternatively, if for reasons of practicality or preference, bread is your staple food for lunch, remember that you don't have to stick to the traditional sandwich made up of two slices of sliced bread with something in the middle.

Many different, mouth-watering types of breads are readily available today, such as ciabatta, focaccia or flat bread, which you can either make into wraps or warm up and eat with dips and crudités; muffins, too, can be topped or filled with lean, protein-rich foods and salads. In order to vary its texture and taste, you could also toast some bread to serve with a bowl of hearty soup, while an open focaccia sandwich like my focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham will show off its topping in a gloriously sensory-stimulating manner.

Turn lunch into a delightful, energising interlude in the middle of what would otherwise be a hectic, draining day. Half an hour or so is plenty of time in which to eat something nutritious and delicious, and taking a break will also allow you to step back from your busy routine for a while and refresh both your body and mind.

The brain therefore secretes hormones that encourage us to sleep in order to diminish both our desire and physiological ability to divert oxygen from our stomach to our limbs to enable us to rush around. If we ignore the effect of these hormones, however, and instead command our limbs to move energetically, oxygen is diverted from the stomach, which frequently leads to indigestion, stomach cramps and bloating. In short, the brain's response to these starchy foods is one that is conditioned by physiological efficiency. If you have time to take a siesta after lunch, perhaps at the weekend, then by all means go ahead and make a dish like my pasta with courgettes and lemon or baby potatoes topped with guacamole and roasted peppers; eating these foods and then having a little snooze is the best way to allow your body to enjoy and digest them. If you don't have the time, however, choose a protein, fruit and vegetable-based lunch in which the proportion of vegetables, fruits and/or protein is high, such as my asparagus and lemon salad, a bowl of courgette and pea soup or a chunk of cheese with some figs, grapes and crisp, green celery. By opting for such foods, your body's hormonal response will encourage, not hinder, your desire to be energetic in the afternoon. There is a further benefit of having a protein-rich lunch, too. Proteins are made up of amino acids, two of which, L-phenylalanine and tryptophan, encourage the body to produce endorphins (mood-enhancing hormones). Eating a protein-rich lunch, like my sea bass with crab, chicken Caesar salad or some lean charcuterie with cherry tomatoes, therefore not only helps to prevent the mood swings that may occur mid-afternoon, but also enables your body's blood-sugar levels to remain more constant (which means that you shouldn't experience 'sugar dips' at 4pm). If eating protein-rich foods doesn't appeal to you, having a fruit- or vegetable-based lunch, like a bowl of soup followed by some fruit, can similarly energise your body. If you are organised and a little eclectic in your thinking, you can turn lunch into an interesting affair, rather than settling for the which-sandwich-bores-me-least? option. Practicality is usually a big issue, which is why sandwich bars may initially appear to be your only resort as a convenient source of lunch, but why not make a large cauldron of soup or a tray of grilled vegetables at home at the weekend to take to work in small plastic containers and then heat them up in the microwave at work (if your office has one)? Alternatively, if for reasons of practicality or preference, bread is your staple food for lunch, remember that you don't have to stick to the traditional sandwich made up of two slices of sliced bread with something in the middle. Many different, mouth-watering types of breads are readily available today, such as ciabatta, focaccia or flat bread, which you can either make into wraps or warm up and eat with dips and crudités; muffins, too, can be topped or filled with lean, protein-rich foods and salads. In order to vary its texture and taste, you could also toast some bread to serve with a bowl of hearty soup, while an open focaccia sandwich like my focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham will show off its topping in a gloriously sensory-stimulating manner. Turn lunch into a delightful, energising interlude in the middle of what would otherwise be a hectic, draining day. Half an hour or so is plenty of time in which to eat something nutritious and delicious, and taking a break will also allow you to step back from your busy routine for a while and refresh both your body and mind.
