fields.headline: Every last morsel of Marcel
fields.standfirst: Erudite but not pedantic, scholarly but not obscure - Edmund White is impressed with Jean Yves Tadié's biography of Marcel Proust
fields.trailText: Erudite but not pedantic, scholarly but not obscure - Edmund White is impressed with Jean Yves Tadié's biography of Marcel Proust
fields.body:
Marcel Proust: a Biography
Jean Yves Tadié
Viking £30, pp986
Buy it at BOL

This is the best biography I've ever read. Its closest recent rivals in my mind are Hermione Lee's life of Virginia Woolf and Judith Thurman's Colette. In all three instances, the biographer is in close sympathy with his or her quirky subject, has mastered the extremely complex social and literary surround and takes an intuitive, writerly interest in the subject's fiction. These are biographers who are imposingly erudite but never pedantic. They plunge us into the richly detailed world of their subjects.

None of the three is the first biographer, just the best. If Tadié is my favourite, it is because he corrects misleading impressions about Proust that have accumulated over the years and achieves an extraordinarily balanced account of his elusive genius.

I don't like 'creative' biographies in which the biographer appears as a chatty character in a story that he never witnessed. Nor do I like Freudian reckonings (psychobiography seems to be the last refuge of psychoanalytic theory), books in which the subject's entire life is reduced to a single childhood wound. I'm horrified by biographies that present pure speculations about motives as certainties in sentences that begin with the word 'doubtless' or even 'indisputably'.

Jean Yves Tadié is refreshingly sensible in this regard. For instance, in a discussion of Proust's celebrated asthma, which reduced him to an invalid's life and played a determining role in his vocation as a writer, Tadié remarks:

"People put too much emphasis on the unconscious, but what is an unconscious that does not make itself felt? One is reduced to speculations based on mere probability: 'He can't fail to have had...' People have gone so far as to have attributed Marcel's first asthma attack at age nine to the fact that his brother had stopped wearing childhood dresses, thereby going from the state of 'little girl' to that of a boy, 'a serious rival for the conquest of their mother's affection'. These childhood dresses, the customary clothes of the period, no more suggested that their wearer was a girl than a Scotsman's kilt means that he is a woman.' [I've retranslated parts of this passage for the sake of emphasis and clarity.]"

Tadié's life of Proust gives us all the truth and nothing but the truth, as well as a wealth of ancillary information about the impressive cast of characters around the great writer, who turns out to be the reigning (if least typical) artist of last century. Tadié - the foremost living expert on Proust's manuscripts - foregoes a sweeping, integrated narrative and contents himself with short sections, each just a few pages long and under a separate heading, although all are arranged in roughly chronological order (thus for the first decade of the twentieth century there are headings such as 'Daily Life', 'Social Gatherings' and 'Literary Work').

The modesty of this arrangement is a frank admission that this biography will not read like a popular romance - which I, for one, find reassuring, since I'm convinced real life lacks narrative drive. Although I can be forced against my inclinations to admit that all biographical accounts are artificial and selective and nothing but versions of the truth, nevertheless I'd still insist that some versions are much truer than others.

Tadié's Way is the straightest, truest path I know of. It's also remarkably efficient. Even though the biography is about half as long as Proust's masterpiece itself, it still manages to pack in facts, judgments and interpretations on every aspect of Proust's life and talent in a condensed but never obscure prose. Scholars will be battening on the footnotes for years to come.

Proust's life was peculiarly uneventful in the worldly sense - no long, unusual voyages, no historically significant meetings, no recorded heart-wrenching amorous scenes. Proust himself was dismissive of the world's way of measuring significance. He found more profit and pleasure in his trips outside Paris to see various Gothic cathedrals than most travellers would experience in the Himalayas. He did meet James Joyce but was unable to communicate with him, and in any event accorded no importance to evenings spent with distinguished colleagues.

Of course, he did have heart-wrenching homosexual love affairs, but he was too closeted to acknowledge them in his fiction or correspondence. As Tadié puts it, Proust had discovered that 'the truth of art lies not in the object but in the mind; yet it is only certain things, the privileged subjects, that compel the mind to create, and which inspire a spiritual joy'.

Tadié makes neither too much nor too little of Proust's homosexuality. Reactionaries such as the US Proustian Roger Shattuck fear that dwelling on Proust's sexuality at all might reduce the 'universality' of his message. Tadié, by contrast, deals quietly with each sexual and emotional involvement in Proust's life. He doesn't lump them together but takes them up individually, just as one would treat comparable heterosexual affairs in writing another life. Nor does he inflate the importance of a Platonic heterosexual dalliance, as George Painter did with Proust or as Steegmuller did with Cocteau (Steegmuller pretends that the great love of Cocteau's life was the Princess Paley).

Whereas Painter's amusing two-volume biography of the 1960s, the standard life of Proust until now, relied almost exclusively on memoirs by Proust's contemporaries, Tadié's book benefits from a whole library of subsequent scholarship, including the publication of twenty-some volumes of correspondence.

Tadié has made a thorough study of Proust's manuscripts as the editor of the four-volume Pléiade edition of A la Recherche du Temps Perdu and of six volumes of Etudes Proustiennes. This knowledge allows him to trace the development of Proustian themes and reconstruct how Proust wrote his book, step by step. Never was a life and its literary expression so interwoven as in Proust's case, and Tadié has had the patience and scholarship necessary for teasing out all the connections (though, unlike Painter, he never turns Proust's novel into a straightforward roman à clef). Again and again Tadié reveals how Proust transformed his material; for instance, he shows how the salon conversation of his day gained in depth by being analysed and parodied in Proust's fiction.

Tadié is a sophisticated writer with an international outlook; he taught at the University of Cairo for years and was at All Souls from 1988 to 1991. He demonstrates Proust's debt to George Eliot, Robert Louis Stevenson and Ruskin (whom he translated).Tadié also has a total grasp of the French artistic geography of the time. For instance, he indicates how Proust, by joining Anatole France's camp, earned the enmity of Mallarmé and his followers, Valéry, Gide and Claudel.

Tadié is crystal clear about the disappointing reception of Proust's first book, Les Plaisirs et les Jours, which sold just 329 copies in its first 22 years of publication. Tadié explains convincingly why Proust abandoned his first novel, Jean Santeuil, the reason being that he broke off his passionate involvement with Reynaldo Hahn, the young composer for whom he was writing it.

Tadié rejects the vulgar notion that Proust defended Dreyfus because he was half-Jewish and argues that Proust did not think of himself as a Jew (he and his brother were baptised Catholics, though his Christian-born father was an atheist in the best Positivist tradition of late nineteenth-century scientists). Moreover, if Proust had identified with other Jews, that would have been all the more reason at the time to stay silent on Dreyfus, whereas Proust was one of the most outspoken champions of the falsely accused soldier.

Every page produces a new trouvaille. Tadié distinguishes between the usual wise-cracking sense of humour in literature and Proust's brand, which discovers the comic essence in each circumstance in life. On the subject of humour, we learn that Proust and the poet Anna de Noailles were invited everywhere not because they were talented but because they were the funniest pair in Paris. We hear one of Proust's quips after another, and we are given one of the first and clearest formulations of Proust's Law: 'Everything comes about just as we desired, but only when we no longer desire it' (in a letter sent during the summer of 1903 and reprinted in Volume 3 of the complete correspondence).

Perhaps Tadié's biography assumes the reader has already read Proust's novel and is imbued with Proustian lore. Tadié's book does not have the journalistic skill to create an interest where none existed previously. But for dedicated Proustians this biography will become their bible.

fields.headline: It all began with a ukulele...
fields.standfirst: Peter Hall tells the story of his life and his love of the theatre
fields.trailText: Peter Hall tells the story of his life and his love of the theatre in Making an Exhibition of Myself, his diaries and Exposed by the Mask
fields.body:
Exposed by the Mask
Peter Hall
Oberon £9.99, pp136
Buy it at BOL

Making an Exhibition of Myself
Peter Hall
Oberon £12.99, pp464
Buy it at BOL

Peter Hall's Diaries
Oberon £15.99, pp496
Buy it at BOL

Peter Hall is one of the great enablers of the British stage. He is also one of its contradictions. Identified with large theatrical institutions, he speaks up for small companies and intimate spaces. Knighted for services to the theatre, he has been forthright in attacking the arts policies of successive governments.

New Labour comes in for a drubbing in Hall's new book. Exposed by the Mask, essays delivered at Trinity College, Cambridge, contains illuminating passages about theatre spaces ('practically every major theatre built in the last 50 years is too big'), the dead weight of naturalism, and a keen analysis of the speaking of Shakespearean verse. Hall falls back on a jargon - 'challenge, disturb, provoke' - which makes theatre-going sound like a moral duty. But when he flares up against his nightmare vision of the theatre of the future - 'a computer-driven populist miracle of lasers and acrobats' - he is completely persuasive.

As with his productions, so with the man: Hall moves from the conventional to the bold. It is not easy to imagine what English theatrical life was like before he got going in the Fifties, when the great subsidised pillars of the dramatic establishment weren't in place. He founded the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford and London. He launched the National Theatre on London's South Bank when he took over from Laurence Olivier as director.

It is for these achievements that Hall will chiefly be celebrated. And he's had plenty of opportunity to demonstrate his flair in the choice of repertoires and colleagues. Within his first five years at the RSC, Vanessa Redgrave had created her Rosalind, Peter Brook had directed Paul Scofield as Lear, Hall himself had staged Pinter's The Homecoming and directed David Warner in Hamlet. And it was Hall who brought Beckett to Britain when he staged Waiting for Godot at the small Arts Theatre in 1955.

His professional life might be supposed to have been a glide from Cambridge to Stratford, Covent Garden and Glyndebourne. But Making An Exhibition of Myself, the autobiography first published seven years ago, tells the bumpy story behind the successes: an infancy as the precocious, ukulele-playing son of an East Anglian stationmaster; an ambitious youth (he decided he wanted to run Stratford at 16), suicidal thoughts and four wives.

The Diaries he kept in the Seventies are a detailed chronicle of other difficulties, to do with the National's early days: policy twists (the idea of amalgamating the RSC and the National recurs), financial worries, a rancorous press. There is Hall chewing over problems with Trevor (Nunn), listening to stories from Harold (Pinter) and watching productions by Richard (Eyre).

Hall has good stories to tell, both in the diaries and the autobiography. Princess Margaret says she can't understand why people are grumbling about the incomprehensible East Anglian accents in Hall's film of Akenfield: 'Though, of course, one did grow up there, in Norfolk at any rate.' Albert Finney discovers that while he was addressing the Ghost as Hamlet, his own father was dying. John Barton, future RSC associate of Hall's, is seen at Cambridge chewing a razor blade to damp down his enthusiasm for Shakespeare. Norman St John Stevas is said to have a harp in his bathroom.

Every time the late John Gielgud appears in these pages - refusing to wear a beard because it makes Prospero look even more boring than he already is, or explaining how he loves to rush around the stage swinging his cloak and dominating an audience - they are touched with charm. Every time Ralph Richardson appears, calling everyone 'cocky', having a parrot shot for biting his wife - a quaintness steals into Hall's normally stolid sentences.

Hall does not now have his own theatre but is currently working in Denver on a 10-play cycle about the Trojan Wars, and has also been collaborating with one of the country's most gifted young directors - Mick Gordon of the tiny Gate Theatre.

Hall says in his autobiography: 'Innovation continues to be the main characteristic of our two national theatres.' Maybe the RSC is getting the point. In their stirring History Cycle, a much-awaited Henry V is to be directed by a young man in his twenties. He is Edward Hall. Son of Peter.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Marika Cobbold toys with the conventions of romantic fiction to great effect in this tale of an architect and a journalist, plus Fortysomething, Nero's Heirs, A Rum Affair and Louis and the Prince
fields.body:
Frozen Music
Marika Cobbold
Phoenix £6.99, pp407
Buy it at BOL

Marika Cobbold's engaging, wry saga moves between England and Sweden following the lives of Linus, a dreamy child who matures into a visionary architect, and Esther, a serious girl who becomes a tabloid journalist.

Aware of each other's existence through their mothers' friendship, the two do not meet until Linus's proposed design for a 'people's Glyndebourne' threatens the home of two pensioners whose cause Esther fights through the pages of the half-baked journal she writes for.

A love affair develops, beset by obstacles, not least various skeletons in family closets and Esther's increasingly troubled conscience. Cobbold writes well, drawing her scenes with a delicate touch and her characters with credibility, toying with the conventions of romantic fiction to good effect.

Fortysomething
Nigel Williams
Penguin £6.99, pp403
Buy it at BOL

Paul Slippery, a 'boringly safe married man' and actor for 30 years in a Radio 4 serial, is approaching 50 via a midlife crisis narrated self-deprecatingly and very humorously in his diary. His wife's job in an all-female collective, 'making little dough men', arouses Paul's suspicion of her latent sapphic tendencies.

His three sons galumph about dealing in women and white goods. He, menawhile, is allegedly buying pornographic items through the post. His agent puts him up for voice-overs for natural history films ('Apparently my voice suggests insects') that he never actually gets.

In sum, Paul is the perfect example of the middle-class, white, British, ordinary, suburban male, the butt of every perfectly-pitched joke, no hero, yet somehow remarkable, and likeable, for his resolute conventionality.

Nero's Heirs
Allan Massie
Sceptre £6.99, pp248
Buy it at BOL

Allan Massie is a master author of dramatic historical fiction set in the classical world and his latest novel is no less impressive than its predecessors, though his desire to explore the complexities of Roman politics in detail does, at times, lend a dry flavour to his otherwise erudite, vivid prose.

In a series of letters to Tacitus, the noble Scaurus chronicles events anticipating and following Nero's death in a novel that is as much about how history itself is written as about how it is made.

A sometime lover to the Emperor Vespasian's son and daughter, Scaurus witnesses the intrigues and depravities - political, familial, social and sexual - of imperial Rome before circumstances conspire against him to devastating personal effect.

A Rum Affair
Karl Sabbagh
Penguin £7.99, pp224
Buy it at BOL

The case of Professor Heslop Harrison, a distinguished botanist during the 1940s, 'admired by many but loved by few', versus John Raven, an amateur in the field, where the latter accused the professor of defrauding the botanical establishment, is strangely fascinating.

Heslop Harrison claimed to have discovered plants indigenous to the Isle of Rum in the Inner Hebrides whose presence suggested survival through 1.7 million years of the Ice Age. John Raven refuted this claim with a vengeance.

Sabbagh, in his thorough and meticulous investigative work, gathers evidence (letters, anecdotes, papers), compares this case with other examples of alleged fraud in scientific fields and, having maintained an element of suspense and ambiguity throughout, ultimately leaves the reader to decide whether the professor was truly an accomplished fraudster or a distinguished scientist.

Geordie Greig
Coronet £7.99, pp332
Buy it at BOL

Geordie Greig's pacy account of his grandfather's friendship with Prince Albert, later King George VI, is an excellent book. Louis Greig of Glasgow, sailor-surgeon, first met Prince Albert in 1909 at the Royal Naval College, Isle of Wight.

Fifteen years Albert's senior, Louis became the hesitant prince's most loyal and trusted friend and quasi-mentor, his nickname, 'the Tonic', justly earned. His consequent constant proximity to the royal household left Louis unworried, even when Albert became king on his brother's abdication.

Away from court, Louis was just as spirited and philanthropic, whether on holiday with Johnny Weissmuller or debating the contentious issue of 'women players' frilly knickers' at Wimbledon. Greig's accomplished, sympathetic biography honours perfectly his grandfather's inspirational life.

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: This is a story to curdle the blood and capture the imagination.
fields.body:
Bloodtide
Melvin Burgess
Andersen Press £14.99, pp371
Buy it at BOL

This is a story to curdle the blood and capture the imagination. The setting is a ruined London sometime in the future. The land is in the hands of two warring gangster families. Signy, the 14-year-old daughter of one warlord, is about to be betrothed to her father's enemy, Conor, as part of a treaty. She is terrified and rebellious and her twin brother, Siggy, is horrified and repelled by the thought. The plot unfolds into a complex narrative of revenge and counter-revenge.

Burgess ventures where few children's authors would dare to go. He tackles the complex nature of sexuality - Signy finds herself falling in love with Conor against her will, and Conor himself is absorbed by her even though he tortures her.

It might seem like strong meat for youngsters, but it has the magnificent drama of the old myths and it is no surprise to learn that Burgess based the story on the first part of the Icelandic Volsunga Saga.

He has a fantastic imagination and draws out adolescent strong emotions very effectively.

fields.headline: Burney peculiar
fields.standfirst: She was the toast of literary London and an influence on Dickens, so what went wrong? Claire Harman charts Fanny Burney's decline
fields.trailText: She was the toast of literary London and an influence on Dickens, so what went wrong? Claire Harman charts Fanny Burney's decline
fields.body:
Fanny Burney: a Biography
Claire Harman
HarperCollins £19.99, pp394
Buy it at BOL

Who reads Fanny Burney now? The occasional lover of eighteenth-century novels who wants to go a little further; academic feminist enthusiasts of her late, rambling, political work The Wanderer, and precious few others. These days, she appears mostly on the edge of the photograph - the shy, watchful young woman with Dr Johnson at the Thraleses'; the journalistic observer of Napoleon; the unwilling courtier who was present throughout George III's 'mad business'.

Many readers know her best for a single, uncharacteristic and horribly vivid description of having a cancerous breast removed without anaesthetic, a piece of icy, yet clear writing infinitely more terrifying than anything written by the entire school of gothic horror novelists.

This relative obscurity would astound her contemporaries. Burney's first novel, Evelina, is a brilliant work still, a sharp, hard epistolary novel which is better than anything by Richardson and compares well with Fielding or Smollett. Her second and third, Cecilia and Camilla, are too long but still readable, while her comedies, which never found an audience at the time, are currently being rediscovered. Then, of course, there are her massive diaries and letters, an essential source for anyone interested in the turn from the eighteenth-century mind towards the age of Victoria.

She was a superstar of literary London who, in her heyday, enthralled the reading public, was admired by such formidable intelligences as Johnson and Burke and whose influence on Jane Austen, Thackeray and even Dickens is indisputable.

Beyond that, she lived an extraordinary life, growing up amid talented siblings (one sister was a musical child prodigy only outshone by a pint-sized Mozart and a brother sailed with Cook on his fatal voyage to Hawaii) before her literary glory, her incarceration at court, her late marriage to a refugee French soldier and her long exile in Paris, until she returned home, living until 1840, a curiosity for Sir Walter Scott to visit and Macaulay to revile.

Her story is gripping but it is melancholy. The slaughter of siblings, cousins, children, friends that was the lot of so many eighteenth-century families is part of it. The Burneys had their share of family humiliations and reverses, black sheep and missed opportunities. But the core problem for a biographer is that Fanny herself went off. She almost wilfully destroyed her early promise and emerges, in old age, as a pretty unattractive character.

This really, is the nub of the Burney problem and has a lot to do with her gender. Born into the coarse, robustly male world of the Enlightenment, into a family poor enough to struggle for its status, she was constantly and anxiously torn between feeding her genius and finding a place which would please her father and secure her position in 'society'.

This was too early for the heroic unconventionalism of a George Eliot; Burney had no female predecessors to refer to and lived in the anxious middle ground between wealth and poverty, a place many unattached male writers could inhabit happily enough, but a much harder terrain for a single woman of modest means.

Novel writing, she felt, was not quite respectable and she felt unable to turn down Queen Charlotte's offer to join the royal household at Windsor, a hideous life of exhausting routine idleness and gossip; there is a sad description of her last walk from outside life to the palace, almost unable to breathe. But after five years she did escape and before long, in one of the gayest passages in her life, unexpectedly married a penniless French émigré and officer, Alexandre d'Arblay, who emerges from this book as an engaging, kind, feckless man and a hilariously unbellicose soldier, like someone out of Tristram Shandy. He undoubtedly gave her her happiest years but when he died, Fanny's descent into a quavering mummifier of reputations and preserver of decency began.

This tough, observant and vastly talented woman decayed into a prudish, fluffy, prolix moralist, a censorious bore, an obsessive rewriter of her family's dubious history. The hard-edged observer of eighteenth-century life becomes a nineteenth-century prig.

Oh yes, and she lied. Claire Harman reviews the evidence on Burney's reshaping of the truth about her father, whose second marriage badly wounded his children and who never quite managed the literary status he craved, and incidents from her own life, including a semi-farcical near drowning (or not). Peeling back the layers of polite deceit is not easy, but has been done expertly and the result is not pretty. She was a comprehensive sanitiser, a Bowdler of her own life.

This particular problem of unpeeling and exposing has been well dealt with by Harman - quite quickly, the reader trusts her fairness and judgment on genuinely tricky questions - but it leads to a second problem. Fanny was admirable in many ways, tough and brave, resourceful and hugely intelligent... but by late middle age, at least, she was not likeable, certainly not if one has had to wade through her interminable late prose.

The sadness of her life, and this book, is that the young Fanny, cool and observant though she was, obsessed with her father's good opinion though she was, is nevertheless genuinely attractive in a Jane Austenish way, the miss who misses nothing, though without the greater writer's towering intelligence and merciless eye. In a sense, Jane Austen was Fanny Burney's final answer to her world. You wish not only that things had turned out better for her, after the fairy-tale success of Evelina, but also that she had turned out better, or at least more interesting, herself.

The biographer, from her increasingly cool tone, clearly does not much like her subject by the end and, inevitably, some energy drains away from the narrative as a result. Still, for the recovery of a life that ought to be as well known as that of any romantic poet or later novelist, this is a great achievement.

It is rare for a reviewer these days to complain that a biography is too short, but for once, I could have done with a couple of hundred pages more.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair is serious about holding a referendum on joining the single currency, he could do a lot worse than post a copy of 2066 and All That through every letterbox in the land.
fields.body:
2066 and All That
William Keegan
Iynx Publishing £6.99, pp87
Buy it at BOL

The Observer's William Keegan and the great cartoonist, Trog, have produced an indispensable guide to Britain's relationship with Europe in the twentieth century. Sounds a bit dry? Not a bit of it. In 50 chapters, Keegan takes us from 1918, where Sellar and Yeatman's 1066 and All That ends, to the present day debate on 'Europe'. This is deftly characterised by a short exam paper: 'Write on one side of the Channel only. Question one - tick the statement which in your opinion most captures the spirit of Britain's relationship with Europe: a) Well, yes and no. b) On the one hand... and on the other. c) Je ne sais pas.'

Other comical sections include a chapter on Marx, Lenin and Stalin, one on coal, steel and 'Bumps-a-Daisy' and one on Charles de Gaulle - the man, not the airport. Unlike Sellar and Yeatman, Keegan is doing more than just having fun. Beneath the wry style is a brilliant precis of a century of European politics. In the light of the current debate on Britain's role in Europe, the chapters on postwar Europe have a particular resonance - brief, witty and precise.

If Tony Blair is serious about holding a referendum on joining the single currency, he could do a lot worse than post a copy of 2066 and All That through every letterbox in the land. The text is complemented by the veteran cartoonist Trog's masterful caricatures. It is a real treat to see Trog deftly handle Keynes, Roosevelt, Churchill and Hitler with an assurance that matches the great David Low. All in all, a bargain at 2,220 escudos, 22,000 lira, 160 schillings or 90 markka.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Samantha Bond and Gareth Armstrong tell the tale of a confrontation between church and chocolate
fields.body:
Chocolat
Joanne Harris
Read by Samantha Bond and Gareth Armstrong
Running time 3 hrs approx
Hodder Headline £8.99
Buy it at BOL

We meet Vianne Rocher and her six-year-old daughter, Anouk, when they arrive as if from nowhere in the heart of the small French town of Lansquenet. Their arrival is a topic of much discussion among the residents of this small-minded rural community who, although suspicious of newcomers, soon become regular customers at the chocolaterie that Vianne opens.

But Vianne and Anouk harbour a shady past. They live by the tarot card and adhere to other ancient pagan traditions that instantly make Vianne an enemy of the local priest, Father Reynaud, who sees her pralines and chocolate mice as temptations of the devil.

Vianne's arrival also coincides with Lent, when self-denial is a requirement of the Catholic church. But instead of prayer and abstinence, Vianne plans to hold a Festival du Chocolat on Palm Sunday, as if in direct opposition to Reynaud.

Samantha Bond is perfectly cast as Vianne: her voice is smooth and luxurious. But Gareth Armstrong steals the show as the priest who turns increasingly to his faith and in so doing loses touch with reality (a far cry from The Archers, in which Armstrong plays gay Welsh barman Sean Myerson).

Writer Joanne Harris has created an intriguing and sensual story that builds to its climax as the festival approaches and the desperate priest preaches 'church not chocolate' to his congregation.

fields.headline: A haunting house
fields.standfirst: It's Pynchon meets Kafka. First novels are rarely better - or weirder - than Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves
fields.trailText: It's Pynchon meets Kafka. First novels are rarely better - or weirder - than Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves
fields.body:
House of Leaves
Mark Z. Danielewski
Doubleday £13, pp729
Buy it at BOL

There is a visual hallucination born of situations of extremity. It lurks just on the edge of vision. It has been described by exhausted mountaineers, soldiers and ultra-distance athletes. Most famously, members of Shackleton's exhausted Endurance expedition, trapped by the polar ice, described it, inspiring T.S. Eliot to write one of last century's most sinister stanzas in The Waste Land:

Who is the third who walks always beside you?

When I count, there are only you and I together

But when I look ahead up the white road

There is always another one walking beside you

Gliding wrapt in a brown mantle, hooded

The same hallucinatory experience is writ large in Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves, his genre-defying debut novel. It is a novel in which something is always just lurking out of sight: a spectral beast; the real identity and motivations of the alleged author (or authors); the key to understanding its labyrinthine and multi-layered stories, all of which dissolve under the scrutiny of closer observation.

Confused? You should be, for that is Danielewski's intention in an experimental novel that is at once a genuinely scary chiller, a satire on the business of criticism and a meditation on the way we read. His mission is to sow confusion, deliberately misleading the reader at almost every turn and undermining the credibility of his interlocutors.

As plots go, it is not the easiest to precis. A trainee tattooist who calls himself Johnny Truant, obscuring his real name to wrap himself in his delinquent reputation, is called to the LA apartment of his friend Lude - think Qualudes/lewd. There he discovers the corpse of an old man known only as Zampano. Retrieving Zampano's trunk, Johnny becomes the unwilling heir to his life work, a vast critique of all the available criticism of The Navidson Record, a film documentary of a haunted house.

All fine so far, except Zampano was blind and could not have seen the film. Even if he were not blind, as Johnny Truant tells us in a typical twist, he could not have seen it, as the film does not exist. Indeed, the critics quoted at such length by Zampano, as Johnny discovers, deny any knowledge of it.

But like the best stories, Zampano's book has a life of its own that insinuates its way into the life of the obsessive Johnny Truant as he attempts to edit Zampano's work. And in his own copious footnotes, added to those already supplied by Zampano, Johnny Truant tells his own story, of a disturbed and disaffected childhood and early adulthood.

But if Zampano is revealed as one of modern fiction's most unreliable narrators, Truant is worse, admitting early in his own account to a talent for lying, especially if it will get him laid, while only hinting at the reality of the demons that infest him. In this, Truant's is a novel within a novel, just as The Navidson Record is the creepy potboiler buried within Zampano's critical summation, both grippingly told behind the sliding screens of authorial detachment that Danielewski interposes.

It would be strange and difficult stuff were it not for Danielewski's skills as a storyteller: his book, for all its critical digressions and deliberate obscurity, sucks you in like a Stephen King novella. Johnny Truant's story too, as it develops out of his notes on Zampona's work, is equally gripping, full of echoes of The Navidson Record that Truant appropriates for his own difficult life. For as much as House of Leaves is full of hallucinatory trompe l'oeil, it is also full of echoes, reflecting the mysterious appearance in photojournalist Will Navidson's house of a door that opens into a snaking, echoing realm of tunnels and halls and endless flights of stairs.

And that would be enough for most aspiring novelists. But Danielewski has other things to say: about the way we read; about authorial authority and reliability; about the business of professional criticism revealed in Zampano's faux critique, stuffed, as it is, with quotes, footnotes and references from the alleged academic and journalistic devotees of his non-existent film.

While Truant supplies a kind of naive criticism of Zampano's book, the writers Zampano reviews in his critique of the criticism of The Navidson Record are wholly obscure as they apply their different brands of film, literary and structural theory, building their tottering intellectual conceits out of Navidson's unseen film.

In this, House of Leaves satirises the more unintelligible of the popular critical techniques, mocking feminist criticism, poststructuralism - practically any -ism that you like. The index is a case in point of Danielewski's droll sense of humour, nothing more or less than an index of words in the book and the pages where they appear.

All this - and the book's typographical oddities - leaves one wondering, however, exactly where to place Danielewski and his massive novel which was 10 years in the writing. In its typographical tricks, it is sometimes reminiscent of Sterne's Tristram Shandy; in its careful obscurity of John Fowles The Magus. At other times, one is reminded of Thomas Pynchon. And in the odd twists and turns of narrative perspective, it has echoes of Iain Banks's unsettling debut novel, The Wasp Factory.

There is a whiff too of Kafka in the novel's relentless claustrophobia. It also reminded me, in a curious way of Melville's Moby Dick, with which it shares its strange humanity and passion for digression. One thing is certain, however - like Don DeLillo's magnum opus, Underworld, this is a novel that could only have been written in America, and in this case only conceived west of the Mississippi.

Danielewski has located House of Leaves firmly on America's West Coast, suggesting that readers should look not to literary but cinematic precedents for its tone, content and structure, though it seems we have not been watching the same films. And in a book full of questions, there is one that will not go away: what can he do for an encore?
fields.bodyText: House of Leaves Mark Z. Danielewski Doubleday £13, pp729 Buy it at BOL There is a visual hallucination born of situations of extremity. It lurks just on the edge of vision. It has been described by exhausted mountaineers, soldiers and ultra-distance athletes. Most famously, members of Shackleton's exhausted Endurance expedition, trapped by the polar ice, described it, inspiring T.S. Eliot to write one of last century's most sinister stanzas in The Waste Land: Who is the third who walks always beside you? When I count, there are only you and I together But when I look ahead up the white road There is always another one walking beside you Gliding wrapt in a brown mantle, hooded The same hallucinatory experience is writ large in Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves, his genre-defying debut novel. It is a novel in which something is always just lurking out of sight: a spectral beast; the real identity and motivations of the alleged author (or authors); the key to understanding its labyrinthine and multi-layered stories, all of which dissolve under the scrutiny of closer observation. Confused? You should be, for that is Danielewski's intention in an experimental novel that is at once a genuinely scary chiller, a satire on the business of criticism and a meditation on the way we read. His mission is to sow confusion, deliberately misleading the reader at almost every turn and undermining the credibility of his interlocutors. As plots go, it is not the easiest to precis. A trainee tattooist who calls himself Johnny Truant, obscuring his real name to wrap himself in his delinquent reputation, is called to the LA apartment of his friend Lude - think Qualudes/lewd. There he discovers the corpse of an old man known only as Zampano. Retrieving Zampano's trunk, Johnny becomes the unwilling heir to his life work, a vast critique of all the available criticism of The Navidson Record, a film documentary of a haunted house. All fine so far, except Zampano was blind and could not have seen the film. Even if he were not blind, as Johnny Truant tells us in a typical twist, he could not have seen it, as the film does not exist. Indeed, the critics quoted at such length by Zampano, as Johnny discovers, deny any knowledge of it. But like the best stories, Zampano's book has a life of its own that insinuates its way into the life of the obsessive Johnny Truant as he attempts to edit Zampano's work. And in his own copious footnotes, added to those already supplied by Zampano, Johnny Truant tells his own story, of a disturbed and disaffected childhood and early adulthood. But if Zampano is revealed as one of modern fiction's most unreliable narrators, Truant is worse, admitting early in his own account to a talent for lying, especially if it will get him laid, while only hinting at the reality of the demons that infest him. In this, Truant's is a novel within a novel, just as The Navidson Record is the creepy potboiler buried within Zampano's critical summation, both grippingly told behind the sliding screens of authorial detachment that Danielewski interposes. It would be strange and difficult stuff were it not for Danielewski's skills as a storyteller: his book, for all its critical digressions and deliberate obscurity, sucks you in like a Stephen King novella. Johnny Truant's story too, as it develops out of his notes on Zampona's work, is equally gripping, full of echoes of The Navidson Record that Truant appropriates for his own difficult life. For as much as House of Leaves is full of hallucinatory trompe l'oeil, it is also full of echoes, reflecting the mysterious appearance in photojournalist Will Navidson's house of a door that opens into a snaking, echoing realm of tunnels and halls and endless flights of stairs. And that would be enough for most aspiring novelists. But Danielewski has other things to say: about the way we read; about authorial authority and reliability; about the business of professional criticism revealed in Zampano's faux critique, stuffed, as it is, with quotes, footnotes and references from the alleged academic and journalistic devotees of his non-existent film. While Truant supplies a kind of naive criticism of Zampano's book, the writers Zampano reviews in his critique of the criticism of The Navidson Record are wholly obscure as they apply their different brands of film, literary and structural theory, building their tottering intellectual conceits out of Navidson's unseen film. In this, House of Leaves satirises the more unintelligible of the popular critical techniques, mocking feminist criticism, poststructuralism - practically any -ism that you like. The index is a case in point of Danielewski's droll sense of humour, nothing more or less than an index of words in the book and the pages where they appear. All this - and the book's typographical oddities - leaves one wondering, however, exactly where to place Danielewski and his massive novel which was 10 years in the writing. In its typographical tricks, it is sometimes reminiscent of Sterne's Tristram Shandy; in its careful obscurity of John Fowles The Magus. At other times, one is reminded of Thomas Pynchon. And in the odd twists and turns of narrative perspective, it has echoes of Iain Banks's unsettling debut novel, The Wasp Factory. There is a whiff too of Kafka in the novel's relentless claustrophobia. It also reminded me, in a curious way of Melville's Moby Dick, with which it shares its strange humanity and passion for digression. One thing is certain, however - like Don DeLillo's magnum opus, Underworld, this is a novel that could only have been written in America, and in this case only conceived west of the Mississippi. Danielewski has located House of Leaves firmly on America's West Coast, suggesting that readers should look not to literary but cinematic precedents for its tone, content and structure, though it seems we have not been watching the same films. webTitle: Swastika plus cricket pad equals art

fields.headline: Swastika plus cricket pad equals art
fields.standfirst: David Sylvester takes a measured look at the legacy of a great artist in Looking Back at Francis Bacon
fields.trailText: David Sylvester takes a measured look at the legacy of a great artist in Looking Back at Francis Bacon
fields.body:
Looking Back at Francis Bacon
David Sylvester
Thames & Hudson, £29.95, pp272
Buy it at BOL

Great disservice is done to the work of Francis Bacon in the current display at Tate Modern, a claustrophobic hang of paintings in a corridor-like room. At Tate Britain he pops up in a large gallery devoted to portraiture, in a selection notorious for its eccentricity. His opulent and relatively relaxed Seated Man, with shiny shoes à la John Singer Sargent, is matched to a wall text mentioning his 'violent' portraits. This is the popular view, that Bacon is invariably horrific. Admittedly, some paintings do suggest that he could be sent down for GBH. But his pervasive characteristic is one of perfumed catastrophe, past or impending, of menace rather than horror.

One of the strengths of David Sylvester's new book is the way he cools Bacon down through formal analysis of the works. He is excellent on canvas-size, paint quality, the placing of the images, the geometry of the settings, the relation of the three parts of a triptych, that ecclesiastical format whose life Bacon extended into the twentieth century.

On the imagery itself, Sylvester is investigative rather than interpretative. In his discussion of Bacon's images - the tasselled window blind, a swastika armband, the minatory umbrellas - Sylvester walks like a cat along a crowded mantelpiece, taking notice of everything but disturbing nothing. He opens up the subject - why a hypodermic syringe or why cricket pads on naked legs - gives us what he knows and leaves us in command of the facts of Bacon's fetishistic regalia.

As the author of the celebrated Conversations with Francis Bacon and the selecter of many exhibitions, Sylvester is Bacon's representative on this earth, a Boswell to his talk, a cicerone to his paintings. But he is no unquestioning hagiographer. Looking back on the painter's career, he finds two periods of great achievement. There are the postwar years to about 1953, and the Seventies which saw the grand triptychs memorialising Bacon's lover George Dyer. I think Sylvester undervalues the work of the Eighties, but does justice to a handful of landscapes and the 1985-86 self-portrait triptych that was a revelation in the Paris exhibition at the Pompidou Centre in 1996.

New in this book are several early paintings that have only come to light since Bacon's death, and which take their place among the volume's generously illustrated pages with their double-sided pull-out colour plates. Some of Sylvester's earlier writings have been revised and there are some previously unpublished fragments of taped conversations full of the old authentic flavour of Bacon's decisive talk ('I never saw one of Picasso's [works] that ever looked erotic'). If the book isn't the full exploration we might have hoped for, it provides a distilled introduction to a painter who, fatal as an influence, narrow in range and on occasion absurd, is one of the two or three modern British artists likely to last beyond these shores.

webTitle: Literary life, but not as we know it

fields.headline: Literary life, but not as we know it
fields.trailText: Oscar Wilde's crack about Britain and America is often illustrated by the fascinating variations in critical judgment between London and New York.
fields.body:
Oscar Wilde's crack about Britain and America ('divided by a common language') is often illustrated by the fascinating variations in critical judgment between London and New York. Here, for instance, John Fowles is treated as a middlebrow novelist, but in America he is spoken of in hushed tones. Likewise, John le Carré. These strange divergences tell us much about our respective cultures. So, consider, then, the strange case of Zoe Heller, first-time author of Everything You Know (Penguin £6.99).

Before her novel came out last year, Heller was already a name. During the early Nineties she wrote a column in the Sunday Times that purported to tell rather more about the ins and outs of her life as a single woman in New York than most people needed to know. It was compulsive stuff, and it won her a following in Britain at about the time that a number of young women writers were experimenting with what has come to be known as 'Bridget Jones' fiction. Eventually, Heller wearied of 'After this terrible row with my boyfriend last night etc', moved away from the Sunday Times and went off to write a novel.

In the world of books we were all agog. Occasionally, word would filter back about its progress. Knopf (or was it Viking?) was bidding for world rights. So-and-so had been spied entertaining Ms Heller at the Four Seasons. Top agents were competing for her favours. The Jackal was prowling. Hollywood beckoned. When this book was eventually launched last year, it's fair to say that it arrived with an impossible burden of great expectations.

Heller herself did her level best to confound these. The hero of Everything You Know turned out to be a fat, depressed, fiftysomething man recovering from a heart attack. And did the joyous fraternity of British fiction reviewers greet this with the deference and approbation to which Zoe Heller had become accustomed during her palmy days as a journalist? Did they, hell! It was painful to watch the zestful delight with which reviewers tore Ms Heller's firstborn to shreds.

She is, sneered the Evening Standard, 'a highly intelligent journalist, but she has yet to find a convincing fictional voice'. To the Sunday Times, the novel was 'a feat of ventriloquy rather than a memorable debut'. Across the corridor, the Times dismissed it as 'rather slight, barely more than a novella'.

There was far worse to come. The Sunday broadsheets were lethal. To the Telegraph the book was 'dismal', exhibiting little more than 'a fine talent for impersonation'. The Independent on Sunday magisterially interred the corpse: 'Everything You Know cannot pass the test as a novel... it swings between the bagel and the banal.' The Observer, alas, did not even review the novel.

If you imagine that no book could survive such a critical mauling, you are reckoning without the magically restorative powers of the American literary scene. For those who dismissed Everything You Know as a 'cloth-eared' debut recycling 'the old clichés', I have bad news. The American edition has been greeted with the kind of reviews first novelists dream of: a 'smashing success' (Newsday), 'a novel that's as affecting as it is amusing' (New York Times) and 'scathingly clever' (New York Post).

Which only goes to show that (a) there's no accounting for taste and (b) London and New York have one thing in common: we hunt in packs.

robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: So farewell, Harry Potter
fields.standfirst: Anthony Holden on American bestsellers
fields.trailText: Anthony Holden on American bestsellers
fields.body:
In three weeks' time, the New York Times is launching a separate bestseller list for children's books, primarily to clear the three (soon to be four) slots permanently annexed by Harry Potter. Had this welcome innovation come sooner, there might have been room for the three titans of American fiction who have published new novels this year. But only Saul Bellow made it into the charts, for just one week, while Philip Roth and John Updike have, for once, failed to put in an appearance.

Which is no reflection on the quality of Roth's work, as powerful, original and angry as ever in The Human Stain, the third volume of the postwar US trilogy that began with the majestic American Pastoral and sagged somewhat with the bitterly postmaritaI I Married a Communist.

His tale of an academic hounded from his job by an absurd case of political correctness takes place in the summer of Clinton and Monica, enabling Roth to mount a ferocious tirade at his countrymen's capacity for sanctimonious hypocrisy.

Similar themes in a parallel setting propel Bellow's Ravelstein, an autumnal portrait of his late friend and colleague Allan Bloom, author of The Closing of the American Mind, so thinly fictionalised as to read more like a memoir. Updike, to my mind, slipped up for once with Gertrude and Claudius, his over-elaborate fantasia on the events leading up to the action of Shakespeare's Hamlet. But a new book by any of this trio is always a master-class; all three at once is an embarrassment of riches.

Also exploring the recent corruption of academic life is Blue Angel, hailed as the 'breakthrough' novel of the stylish, always thoughtful and thought-provoking Francine Prose, who is curiously underrated in Britain. She should be up there with the likes of Michael Ondaatje, whose Anil's Ghost has been competing just below the bestseller list with Jane Smiley's Horse Heaven and Kent Haruf's haunting Plainsong.

Thanks to the selling power of Oprah Winfrey's TV book club, Toni Morrison's Bluest Eye and Isabel Allende's Daughters of Fortune have found an unexpectedly wide audience. Otherwise, apart from the indestructible Frank McCourt, it is the usual diet of how-to books, thrillers, rites-of-passage memoirs and movie tie-ins. The film of The Perfect Storm, after all, is about to burst upon us.

In an unsettling class of its own is a fundamentalist Christian potboiler entitled The Indwelling: the Beast Takes Possession, the seventh in a literally apocalyptic series which has sold 17 million copies for its co-authors, a retired evangelical minister named Tim LaHaye and writer Jerry B. Jenkins. In the words of the New York Times, the book combines 'traditional elements of science fiction with the authors' unorthodox interpretation of the Book of Revelation to create a Rambo-style potboiler with a strong conservative ethos and noticeably contemporary characters who drive Range Rovers, use the internet and have everyday worries'.

Number one with Amazon.com even before it was published, The Indwelling abruptly replaced John Sandford's detective novel Easy Prey in the Times's top spot. Other surprise bestsellers this summer are From Dawn to Decadence, Jacques Barzun's survey of Western civilisation since 1500, and In the Heart of the Sea, Nathaniel Philbrick's reconstruction of the fate of the whaleship Essex, which inspired Herman Melville to write Moby-Dick.

Television anchorman Tom Brokaw has scored a huge success with two volumes of recent history, chronicling those Americans who 'came of age' during the Depression and the Second World War, the second consisting of letters he received about the first. Millennial interest lives on in two chunky tomes about the American century from another TV anchor, Peter Jennings, and Britain's own Harold Evans. America's morbid fascination with its health ensures a huge audience for the stories of cancer survivors Hamilton Jordan, Jimmy Carter's White House chief of staff, and Tour de France champion Lance Armstrong.

Prolific Harold Bloom has followed his surprise bestseller about Shakespeare with a literary miscellany, How to Read and Why. Brevity is rarely his forte; in this instance, after an inspiriting preface, it is his undoing, as he revisits his marathon The Western Canon in an unlikely 100-yard dash. The buzz-book among discriminating literati is Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language, just published to reviews as ecstatic as those in Britain.

Finally, for those who prefer their literature lite, Bill Bryson is back in the charts with his ramble round Australia, In a Sunburned Country.

fields.headline: Get the Boers in
fields.trailText: Kevin Mitchell steps into the ring with books on cricket, football and boxing
fields.body:
In ascending order of cover price, as well as the subliminal aspirations of the titles, these books reflect as much about the authors as do their words within.

Take Yakking Around the World: A Cricketer's Quest for Love and Utopia (Simon & Schuster £12.99, pp256), by Simon Hughes, an underpaid professional cricketer with Middlesex in the Eighties, who discusses the predicament of the jobbing sportsman stumbling through life after an extended adolescence. Whether it's bowling fast(ish) for £11,000 in the dullness of the county championship, scuffling about journalism in Australia and New Zealand, or luxuriating in the mystical hardship of Udumalaipettai, beyond the Nilgiri mountains in India, Hughes is a man whose price is negotiable.

One hopes the award-winning author had a healthy advance for this second collection of memories on the road. It is worth every penny - especially for the following observation: 'It's the Afrikaaners who should have been consigned to the gutter of life. There were dense, arrogant, hostile and often obese. Otherwise delightful.'

Brilliant Orange: The Neurotic Genius of Dutch Football (Bloomsbury £14.99, pp246) is by David Winner, a Londoner with a slightly different perspective on the breed. 'Ever since I was a small child,' he says, 'I've had the feeling there was something special and great about the Dutch.' No glibness here, only affection and understanding of the people and their love of the game. Anyone who watched Euro 2000 will have been struck by the almost Van Goghian beauty of the massed shirts of the Dutch fans, stippled and shimmering beyond the pitch. Winner paints a suitably glowing picture to accompany that image, more ambitious than Hughes's effort, and no less impressive.

Nick Tosches, author of Night Train: The Sonny Liston Story (Hamish Hamilton £17.99, pp272) is American - and that's not meant as a criticism.Where Hughes and Winner tread self-deprecatingly about their subjects Tosches gets in the ring and slugs it out from the first bell as if he were the twin reincarnation of John L. Sullivan and Jack Dempsey. He is happy, for instance, to quote the ex-fighter Chuck Wepner: 'This guy writes like Sonny Liston hits.'

Yet it's wholly appropriate. A brash book for a brash subject. Tosches, better known in the pages of Vanity Fair and Rolling Stone, comes to boxing on heat. He picks the dirtiest, ugliest, saddest man the fight game has thrown up in a hundred years and rides the story all the way to the grave, with some astute re-examination of boxing history. But I still prefer Hughes's observation that he'd 'been in and out of love more times than Miss Piggy'.

Buy Yakking Around the World at BOL
Buy Brilliant Orange at BOL
Buy Night Train at BOL

Tosches, better known in the pages of Vanity Fair and Rolling Stone, comes to boxing on heat. He picks the dirtiest, ugliest, saddest man the fight game has thrown up in a hundred years and rides the story all the way to the grave, with some astute re-examination of boxing history. But I still prefer Hughes's observation that he'd 'been in and out of love more times than Miss Piggy'. Buy Yakking Around the World at BOL Buy Brilliant Orange at BOL Buy Night Train at BOL

fields.headline: Economy 'growing at above target rate'
fields.trailText: Interest rates in the UK may not yet have peaked, despite last week's 'no change' decision by the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee.
fields.body:
Interest rates in the UK may not yet have peaked, despite last week's 'no change' decision by the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee.

This is the implication of new calculations by the independent National Institute for Economic and Social Research, which suggest the economy may still be expanding at above its long-term sustainable growth rate of about 2.5 per cent.

The NIESR calculates that, after growing at a mere 2 per cent in the first quarter of this year, the economy may have expanded at 3.2 per cent a year in April-June.

NIESR economists believe the seasonal adjustments for the first quarter did not take sufficient account of the mild weather in February and March, which cut demand from the energy sector.

Industrial output recovered substantially in April and May.

NIESR director Martin Weale told The Observer: 'With industrial output running 5.5 per cent above the first quarter in April and May, GDP [gross domestic product] growth is likely to have accelerated in the current quarter, even if industrial output is flat in June.'

fields.headline: Sterling value of hi-tech
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan looks at why companies in the 'new economy' are not single-minded
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan looks at why companies in the 'new economy' are not single-minded
fields.body:
Anyone looking for clarification on British attitudes to the single currency should be none the wiser after the events of last week. On almost all the key issues - the Government's position on entry timing, whether it is in British industry's interest to join and, crucially, what inward investors think - the picture appears more muddled than ever.

At the centre of the confusion are the figures produced by Invest UK, formerly the Invest in Britain Bureau, last Wednesday. These show record levels of new inward investment, creating 52,783 jobs and 757 projects and bringing £47.4 billion foreign investment into the UK.

As Eurosceptics speedily pointed out, these do not tally with statements from ministers such as Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook claiming inward investors are increasingly nervous of Britain's wait-and-see attitude to the single currency.

Adding to the confusion were the two high-level leaks - a memo to Byers from the head of Invest UK, Andrew Fraser, and a diplomatic telegram from the UK's ambassador to Japan, Sir Stephen Gomersall, pointing out that investors might pull out of the UK if a pro-euro agenda was not pushed.

Arch sceptics such as Lord Hanson leapt forward to claim these leaks sprang from pro-euro ministers attempting to get their spin on Invest UK figures in first. Senior government officials swiftly replied there was no evidence to back the Jeremiahs. But on Thursday Robin Cook waded in, stating that joining the euro was 'inevitable'. And on Friday European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg said in a newspaper interview that Britain was 'suffering greatly' from being outside the euro and that 'the United Kingdom satisfies all the conditions for entry, except that of the exchange rate.'

All of which left a profound muddle for those not firmly in one camp or the other, still seeking answers to such questions as: does remaining outside the euro really concern all inward investors?

Some of the companies mentioned in the Gomersall telegram - Nissan, Honda and bearing manufacturer NSK - are under the same exchange rate pressures as the UK manufacturers that have so publicly expressed pain in the past three years.

Gomersall and Fraser also indicated that companies further up the 'value chain' were vulnerable, too.

In sectors such as electronics, companies such as Matsushita, Sony and Aiwa are making investment decisions on where to make new generations of high-value products. Nurturing these companies and 'new economy' knowledge-based businesses is seen both by ministers and Invest UK officials as the future of inward investment policy.

Invest UK states in its report that it 'has focused on attracting high quality knowledge-driven projects into the UK' and trumpets its success in attracting computer software, internet, telecoms and e-business investment to the UK.

The Invest UK figures - which show that 48 per cent of investment comes from the US - were accompanied by a statement from Byers, who stressed once again the importance inward investors attached to the euro issue.

The impression from all of this appears to be that although current investment levels are strong, decisions being taken now may cause downturns in future, and, like manufacturers in traditional sectors, investment by electronics and 'new economy' companies could be at risk from volatility.

Is this the case?

At one level manufacturers in higher technology sectors do have similar concerns to more traditional companies.

Stephen Radley chief economist at the Engineering Employers Federation says: 'Some bigger electronics companies are looking to move production away from the UK into the euro zone or eastern Europe to avoid the currency issue.'

EEF's Scottish head Peter Hughes says: 'IBM in Greenock is a good example. Our members are concerned that they are switching supply of components away from the UK to Eastern Europe, even India. Then they can lower costs and match them to revenues.'

Alan Wood, chief executive of electronics manufacturer Siemens UK, with 16,000 employees, says that no major investment decisions have been reversed because of the euro, but admits that senior German figures are concerned about the UK's reluctance to join.

The picture is more complicated than these examples suggest. Inward investment is not simply about building plants. Only 40 per cent of the total last year involved manufacturing - more went to the services, particularly the financial, sector, where there is less concern about currency swings.

Also, much inward investment involves company takeovers, which may not add jobs, but may increase productivity. It is more difficult to assess the impact of the euro on these factors.

So if Gomersall, Fraser and Byers are expressing concern about high-value, knowledge-based businesses, they are likely to be ones that make high value things such as electronics, mobile phones and software packages.

Here, analysts point to three key factors in the euro argument. The first is the value of a company's products. The second is its geographical structure - are its costs and revenues in the same currency areas? And the third - how will currency swings affect productivity?

Nick Matthews of the Warwick Manufacturing Group at Warwick University says: 'If you are exporting high volume goods and selling them on their competitive price, you are going to be affected by exchange rates.

'Higher value products -- electronics or aerospace - are not sold simply on price. Quality and design issues make companies more resilient.'

In 1998 Siemens closed a £1.2bn chip plant in Tyneside with the loss of 1,000 jobs. There was concern that the sterling/euro exchange rate was pushing hi-tech inward investment away.

Wood says a slump in world prices caused the closure. Although the jobs were skilled and the plant expensive (£1.2bn) the product - basic Dram memory chips - is a commodity exposed to vicious demand and price cycles, rather than a high value item.

Some companies making the products highlighted in last week's report do not see the euro as significant at all.

Telecoms manufacturer Motorola has been in the UK for 31 years and now employs 10,000 people in six major plants. Earlier this year it took over a semiconductor plant from Hyundai in Dunfermline.

Instead of making Dram chips, it will produce hi-tech products for mobile phones and auto electronics, which are more specialised, valuable and capable of sustaining demand than those that Siemens made.

Motorola's Mark Durrant says: 'We take a wide variety of factors into account. But the euro is not one of them.'

The same is true of software companies. Software industry analyst Richard Holway says that investment decisions are entirely unaffected by currency.

This leads on to the second point - the location and structure of companies and the type of investment in the UK. As officials are keen to point out, companies pay dearly for manufacturing in the relatively high cost 'sterling zone' and selling into the lower-revenue 'euro zone'.

Some companies avoid this trap. Holway's example is Microsoft, which has invested heavily in software development in Cambridge.

'The software products designed here will be sold in Europe, but they will be manufactured and distributed in Microsoft plants in France, Germany and Italy, where costs and revenues can be matched.'

This, he says, is what distinguishes UK investment from that in Ireland - where euro enthusiasts point to a burgeoning hi-tech sector, nurtured by protection from currency volatility - but where jobs tend to be 'lower value', such as call centre operatives.

The third key factor is productivity. Car industry executives, for example, are concerned that productivity improvements of 7 per cent a year are swamped by 12 per cent currency fluctuations. But, as Radley points out, productivity improvements in newer, higher technology companies are far greater, and allow them to ride the currency swings to a greater degree.

Official figures show that the electrical and electronics sectors saw productivity increase by 5.4 per cent in 1998 and 12.3 per cent in 1999. This compares with 0.9 per cent and 1.0 per cent for the economy as a whole, and -0.6 per cent and 3.5 per cent for manufacturing.

'We find that the euro is less of an issue for some of these companies. It is easier for them to make productivity gains, which help offset currency problems,' says Radley.

None of these factors on its own may explain why higher technology investment has been pouring into the UK. It is clear that many manufacturers will watch the euro issue closely. But it is also likely that those 'new economy' companies lauded by ministers and Invest UK will have it at the back, not the front, of their minds.

Some we won, some we lost

Arrivals

1999
Component maker Toyota Gosei spends £32 million on a seals plant in Rotherham, creating 400 jobs.
Canadian telecoms equipment maker Nortel Networks creates 1,800 jobs, increasing capacity at sites in Paignton, Devon, and Monkstown in Northern Ireland.
Grundig expands Llantrisant plant; creates 120 jobs making set-top boxes.

2000
US TV and internet shopping operator QVC doubles size of distribution centre on Merseyside, creating 1,000 jobs.
US Motorola invests £1.3 billion in former Hyundai semiconductor plant in Dunfermline to make mobile phone chips.

Departures

1998
German electronics giant Siemens closes semiconductor plant on Tyneside with loss of 1,100 jobs.
Fujitsu closes semiconductor plant in North East with loss of 500 jobs.

1999
Levi Strauss ends jeans production at Whitburn in Scotland; 700 jobs go.
Goodyear closes Dunlop tyre factory in Birmingham with loss of 650 jobs.

2000
BMW announces it is to sell Rover.
Sumitomo Electric Wiring Systems, a Japanese electronics company, closes factory in Sunderland, Tyne and Wear.

webTitle: Browne surprises City with BP Amoco plans

fields.headline: Browne surprises City with BP Amoco plans
fields.trailText: Oil giant BP Amoco is set to raise its growth targets 'significantly' when it sets out corporate strategy at its eagerly awaited annual briefing to the City on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Oil giant BP Amoco is set to raise its growth targets 'significantly' when it sets out corporate strategy at its eagerly awaited annual briefing to the City on Tuesday.

Last year chairman Sir John Browne said the company aimed to increase revenues at an annual rate of 5 per cent from 2002, following the aquisitions of US oil giants Amoco, Arco and the Burmah Castrol marketing business.

But Browne is expected to raise the growth figure, and outline a substantial increase in the company's capital spending on exploration and production assets to fuel it.

In July last year, BP Amoco set out plans to boost its spending to $26 billion over the three years to 2001, along with a $4bn cost-cutting drive and $10bn of asset sales.

The spending figure - averaging $8.6bn a year - is likely to be revised upwards by at least 10 per cent.

Analysts indicated that most expenditure would be focused on oil fields in the gulf of Mexico - particularly the Crazy Horse field - and in Angola. BP has previously stated that it expects Crazy Horse to yield about a billion barrels.

But analysts believe that as news comes of further exploration in the field, this figure will be raised. They are also expecting news of new wells in Angola.

Browne's presentation is likely to come as a surprise to some analysts who have not been expecting radical changes to previous statements and expected him to outline a period of consolidation following three frenetic years of merger and aquisition activity.

However, others believe that Browne is determined to drive the business forward and prove wrong the sceptics who say that even 5 per cent growth figures are optimistic.

He also said he expected news on disposals - particularly in the North Sea, Pakistan and Venezuela - although he did not think specifics would be detailed.

fields.headline: Besieged banks branch out
fields.standfirst: The giants are opening up in stores, bringing in coffee shops and trying to awaken staff entrepreneurship. But their high street presence is still in danger, says Heather Connon
fields.trailText: The giants are opening up in stores, bringing in coffee shops and trying to awaken staff entrepreneurship. But their high street presence is still in danger, says Heather Connon
fields.body:
Would you pay your employer to let you carry on doing your job - and take a 20 per cent cut in salary for the privilege of doing so? Would you be more tempted if the arrangement also gave you the chance to increase your salary by up to 2.5 times?

That is what Abbey National plans to ask its 160 local market managers, who each run between three and six branches. It hopes the initiative, inaccurately called internal franchising, will unleash the entrepreneurial spirit deep inside its managers, inspiring them to sell more of the bank's products.

At the heart of the experiment, however, is the familiar problem that dogs all banks: how do they make their branches pay when most of their customers prefer use cash machines, telephones and, now, the internet to do their banking?

Abbey is in a better position than clearing bank rivals such as Barclays or NatWest. A former building society, it has only 760 branches, less than half that of HSBC. But, with fewer than 10 per cent of transactions carried out in the branches and the high cost of a high street presence, it is still under pressure to make them pay.

Rivals have addressed the issue in different ways but, generally, the focus has been on cutting costs. They have cut the size of their branches, moved them to busier areas, switched back-office functions to cheaper, central locations. And they have closed branches - more than 2,700 in the past five years alone - although the furore over Barclays' closures earlier this year means rivals are likely to think hard before contemplating more.

The banks claim redesigning branches will make them more attractive places for customers to linger, thus increasing sales. But it takes more than a few coffee tables and some attractive carpeting to persuade us to invest with our banks: the average number of products each of us has with our bank has stayed stubbornly at 2.1 for years.

Abbey's initiative is based on the premise that income is as important to branch profitability as costs. If it can generate more sales through the high street, its branches will look a bit less like expensive luxuries. And how better to give staff an incentive than paying them by results?

The scheme involves giving the local market managers control over a limited range of functions: marketing; the choice of which products to promote; human resources; and branch design. That does not amount to a great deal of freedom. Interest rates will still be determined centrally, as will decisions on who can get a mortgage. The branch will still sell only Abbey National products, although it is possible they will be able to sell non-competing goods, such as pizzas.

The branch design will have to comply with Abbey's chosen formats, so Ikea beech and primary colours will be out. To get those limited freedoms, the managers have to give up between £8,000 and £12,000 a year from their pay, which ranges between £40,000 and £60,000. If they meet the bank's most optimistic targets, however, they could get as much as £150,000.

Not that they will necessarily keep all the increase themselves: how the managers incentivise their staff will be up to them. 'Our view is that rewarding people will be critical to the success of the scheme,' said Abbey spokesman Tim Harrison.

The limited freedom makes it all the more surprising that the scheme has attracted so much interest from staff. The bank has invited bids from 24 local managers and will select three for a six-month trial, starting in the autumn.

The spokesman said the bids received had exceeded expectations, both in the amount the bidders were willing to pay and in the higher sales they thought they could get. 'They are saying they feel as if they have been underperforming in the past, and this will give them the push they need to improve,' Harrison said.

If the trial is successful, it will be extended to the whole country. The focus on selling more may make some a little nervous. Past attempts at aggressively pushing endowment policies and personal pensions were good for financial services companies only in the short-term. They were not good for the consumer, nor for the long-term health of the industry, which is still paying for its old mistakes.

And Barclays' lending surge in the late Eighties, which led it to large losses and slashed dividends in the Nineties, was partly caused by moves to give branch managers greater freedom to approve loans.

That experience may explain why Abbey is keeping tight control of credit checking.

Richard Coleman, banking analyst with ABN Amro Hoare Govett and a former Barclays employee, said: 'In a branch, the psychology is of high loyalty at branch level - it is very team-oriented - and an equal and opposite loathing of head office. Devolving decision-making can be a powerful tool.'

Abbey is trying other ways of selling more products. It has branches in Safeway stores and is experimenting with kiosk-type outlets in busy shopping malls. But these efforts still cost money, and there is no guarantee that any business they bring in is new. It may simply be transferring clients from one format to another. Such gimmicks are commonly used to win new customers but HSBC is extending the deal to all its borrowers, though existing ones have to wait for it until September.

HSBC admits this is aimed as much at keeping existing borrowers as attracting new ones. Remortgages account for about a quarter of all lending, as borrowers shop around for the latest cashback or discount. But as John Massey, head of mortgages at HSBC, acknowledges, keeping a client costs far less than winning a new one.

This industry offers fertile ground for the doom-mongers and their predictions of Armageddon through price wars and customer-hopping. The truth is likely to be less dramatic. Margins will gradually fall; costs will inexorably rise; and profits will become harder and harder to achieve. This already afflicts much of British industry: the banks cannot expect to be left out.

fields.headline: Is my car insured abroad?
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: You are taking your car with you abroad on holiday and wondering what you should do about motor insurance. You may remember needing in the past something called a green card - but you do not know what the rules are now.
fields.body:
You are taking your car with you abroad on holiday and wondering what you should do about motor insurance. You may remember needing in the past something called a green card - but you do not know what the rules are now.

Actually, it is all fairly easy. For the very minimum, third-party cover, you do not have to do anything if you are staying within the EU. As the Association of British Insurers explains in its (free) leaflet, Holiday Insurance and Motoring Abroad: 'All UK insurance policies automatically provide, at no extra cost, the minimum cover required by law in all EU countries or the minimum cover required in the UK if that is greater. The minimum requirement is cover for your liability to third parties.' You no longer even need to take a green card with you as proof of your minimum cover if driving within the EU - although insurers will provide you with one for free if you ask.

However, if you want more than this basic cover, you should check with your insurer. Norwich Union, for instance, will upgrade your foreign cover to match your domestic cover for £20. But it urges drivers to check their policies first. If you bought direct, you will have been offered modules of cover and you may have taken a minimalist approach. If you bought through an intermediary, you may have a broader policy which already covers the EU.

For a handful of non-EU countries - including Norway, Switzerland and Hungary - you do not need a green card either. But if you are going outside the EU you should check. You will need a green card in Bulgaria, Cyprus and Turkey, for example; and your insurer may charge you for it. About one in 20 UK cars break down when taken abroad, according to Norwich Union, and costs can be hefty - an average of £175 for a tow. So breakdown cover can be well worth the cost. This is a rather specialist type of insurance and you can be charged more on older cars. Rates at Saga (specialising in the over-50s market) start at £36 for a year.

 Write to Public Affairs, The Association of British Insurers, 51 Gresham Street, London EC2V 7HQ for a free copy of the ABI leaflet.
