fields.headline: Little boy blue (part two)
fields.standfirst: William Hague first came to attention as a perky 16-year-old addressing a Tory party conference, and heÕs been singing much the same tune ever since. Are people at last beginning to listen? Kevin Toolis joins him on the road to find out.
fields.trailText: William Hague first came to attention as a perky 16-year-old addressing a Tory party conference, and heÕs been singing much the same tune ever since. Are people at last beginning to listen? Kevin Toolis joins him on the road to find out.
fields.body:
Back at the hotel, there are more interviews. The Police Federation speech has led the One OÕClock News, and run big in the London Evening Standard. But there is trouble brewing. Straight away, the political editor of the Scottish Sun wants a line on the Mike Tyson row that has exploded into a constitutional battle between the Scottish Parliament, which wants to ban the convicted rapist from boxing in Scotland, and Jack Straw, who wonÕt exclude Tyson from the United Kingdom. The Tyson story is in danger of wiping out HagueÕs visit to Scotland as a news item. There is a brief discussion about what line to take. There is no line, and Hague refuses to comment. Within a few minutes, the Scottish Sun man closes his notebook. Later, Amanda Platell explains the decision: if they comment on Tyson, theyÕll just become part of the Tyson story. As it turns out, the Tyson row does kill media interest in HagueÕs visit Ñ even the Scottish broadsheets relegate the story to page nine; the Scottish Sun carries nothing.

Soon, we are back on the road again, to the Eastwood constituency dinner for Spanish melon, roast sirloin of beef and a rousing campaign speech by William for the 225 £25-a-head members and guests at the concrete 60s Normandy Hotel, in the suburbs of Glasgow. ItÕs another stage for Hague, glad-handing, greeting, frozen smiles and pictures with a whole queue of Tory council candidates. Later, after his speech, as part of some other ritual, he will walk around alone and introduce himself to each table of seated diners. The road to Downing Street, it seems, is paved with social excruciation.

Hague is an accomplished public speaker. His delivery is good, the comic timing spot on, and the cadences of rhetoric just right. He is a master of the big set-piece conference platform speech; his hands wave, he declaims, he cajoles. Tonight is a walk-over. Like all good after-dinner speakers, he starts off warming up the audience with a few jokes from old newspaper headlines Ñ "Home Secretary to act on Porn Video" Ñ and then hits with his big theme: Tony Blair is a fraud and the fortunes of the Tory Party can be revived.

He is scathing: "I know our chief opponent very well, because I have to ask him those questions every Wednesday afternoon.

I have to get into the way he thinks, think the way he thinks, and how he will answer those questions. I know that he does not believe in anything at all. At the last election, that gave him an advantage; at the next election, it gives us an advantage."

It was my first Conservative dinner, and it was a shock. The Party is old; most of the dinner guests were in their 70s. It was hard to believe that this Britain Ñ bouffant hair-dos, portly, uniformed chauffeurs, crinoline ball-gowns and floral prints Ñ still existed; Planet Tory. It was like stepping back into the 50s. One thing was sure, these people would not be knocking door to door at election time. At one table at the back was a small clique of young men from Glasgow UniversityÕs Conservative Society. They are strangely awkward, arrogant, odd-looking, dressed in clothes borrowed from their grandparents; young Williams revisited 20 years later.

Hague is not a fretter. He sleeps soundly. He is genuinely confident and relentlessly optimistic about both the ToriesÕ and his own prospects. He runs the Tory party like a company. Meetings are short, brisk and decisive. He does not like endless argument, and when he reaches a position, he sticks with it. "I like to hear the argument and then decide Ñ just sleep on it and know. ItÕs the same asking questions of the Prime Minister. Sometimes you can sit for hours thinking about the issues you could ask him about and working it all out Ñ the moves on the chessboard, as it were. But, actually, usually when IÕve really pinned him to the wall, itÕs when IÕve woken up that morning and thought of something Ñ that is going to be the thing I nail him on today."

In the morning, he does more radio and then drives to the outskirts of Edinburgh for a press conference on todayÕs theme: keeping the pound. ItÕs been raining, the hotel is cold, miserable. ItÕs a poor turnout from the press: Tyson 1, Hague 0. Clustered in a corner are another batch of the men who characteristically make up the political class of Britain. They stand around and smile, but their eyes are full of hunger for the glitter of attention as they watch the Leader being interviewed, again and again, by the few reporters who do turn up. The dominant emotion is not awe but envy. Among them stands Malcolm Rifkind, shorn of his former grandeur of power. He reminds me for all the world of my old Edinburgh dentist. ItÕs hard to believe he was once the British Foreign Secretary, and these the remnants of a political party that once ruled Britain.

Hague is at home in this world, as much a creature of the Conservative Party as he is his fatherÕs son. He inherited his politics from his father, Nigel, an instinctive Yorkshire Tory who ran a small soft-drinks company, Charles Hague & Sons, manufacturing lemonade. Ironically, Hague is the first Tory leader ever to have gone to a state school. He was educated at Wath-on-Dearne Comprehensive in Rotherham, Yorkshire, whose social mix included the sons of miners and steelworkers, after rejecting a scholarship to a state boarding school, Ripon Grammar, 30 miles from home. Hague got four As at A-Level and went on to Magdalen College, Oxford, where he obtained a first-class degree in, predictably, Politics, Philosophy and Economics, as well as being president of the Oxford Union. He has a further diploma from the prestigious INSEAD French institute.

For five years, Hague was a management consultant with McKinsey, but that was just his day job. According to his CV, even as he worked at McKinsey, he was already political adviser to Geoffrey Howe and Leon Brittan in the Thatcher Government. His line about his life outside politics sounds just like that, a line. "I have seen life from many different angles. I have not had a privileged upbringing.

I learned more delivering beer round the working men clubÕs in Rotherham when I was a teenager than I learned at Oxford."

Bill Clinton, Gordon Brown and Tony Blair also spent their entire lives training for political office, but HagueÕs resum is narrower: he started out as a political altar boy and he has single-mindedly devoted his entire life to the Conservative party from the age of 15. His family nickname was "Tory boy", and he was chairman of the Rother Valley Young Conservatives at the grand old age of 16. His infamous speech was delivered to the 1977 Blackpool Tory conference two years before Thatcher entered Downing Street.

In many ways, Hague has been giving the same speech ever since. "As a 16-year-old, I represent what may well seem to be the last generation for the Conservative Party. That lack of support stems largely from the fact that the party is seen, rightly or wrongly, as standing for the maintenance of the existing political and economic order. The young people who voted so overwhelmingly against our party last time are people who believe in change Ñ not change for changeÕs sake, but because they are dissatisfied with the existing state of affairs in Great Britain.They want a society where effort and initiative are rewarded instead of being stamped on Ñ most of all they want to be free from the government, the government that they think should get out of their lives . . . if we rise to the challenge and if we determine to roll back the frontier for the state, we will not only capture the imagination of younger people, we will save free enterprise and Great Britain and create a capital-owning, home-owning democracy."

Part of his strength, and his weakness, is this monumental belief in the Conservative cause. His fundamental political position is simple: the Tories should be in power always. From time to time, most of us wonder what it would be like to be a politician, but few of us, I think, could bear the price, the mind-numbing repetition of policy and belief, the wasted hours in wasted argument in dead committee rooms, the incremental advantage of this alliance instead of that alliance, the hanging around in the company of the warped, the fanatic, the politically ambitious. It requires extraordinary self-discipline and a sectarian passion for self-promotion. There is no doubt that Hague qualifies on both counts. "It helps if you enjoy being the centre of attention, being at the centre of events, and you donÕt mind everything being public in your life. I have always enjoyed that, or not minded it. It helps if you enjoy giving speeches, and setting out positions. There is an element of being an actor in there, without being completely taken over by being an actor. I think there is a bit of all that in me."

William Hague, I am pretty sure, was never much of an ordinary human being. His unadulterated devotion to his political cause raises uncomfortable questions about his very suitability for the office to which he aspires. Is there a real William Hague underneath the latest policy positions? Is there a warm human being behind the grin of the accomplished debater?

His passion for politics seems to leave space for little else. He has the air of a man not overly concerned with money or luxurious living. His clothes look inexpensive, even if theyÕre not. His London base is a flat in Dolphin Square and he has another flat in a stately home in his Yorkshire constituency.

In a belated bid to humanise his trainspotter image, Hague has taken up judo, revealed his passion for cross-country skiing and, most famously, got married to Ffion Jenkins, in December 1997. For years he has been dogged by rumours in the Westminster village that he is gay (despite the fact that he had a girlfriend when, in 1987, he first set his sights on the Richmond constituency, some 70 miles north of his home town) Ñ rumours that he has denied on the record. But, with a beautiful wife by his side, he is now, in the textbook Tory leader script, a happily married, firmly-founded, individual. "I do not intend to lose. But when you have the home, family, wife, interests that I have, there is no need to fear losing," he says.

But, despite the image make-over, Hague remains an enigma. FfionÕs presence, 300 public engagements later, has not softened his monastic, geeky image. Close observers say their relationship is joshy, schoolboy/ schoolgirl flirtatious, but their marriage remains a rigidly private matter, as closed off as the inner recesses of HagueÕs own self. In this respect, the contrast with the Ford Galaxy-driving First Family Blair, and the patter of LeoÕs little feet, could not be more pointed.

We move on to the local Currie High School. Aides, camera crews, Hague, other politicians, teachers Ñ a party of around 20 Ñ squeezing our way into a couple of classrooms in search of the elusive photo opportunity. The kids seem more frightened than curious, worried that the wrong remark might spell trouble. We end up downstairs in the library for a question-and-answer session with the sixth form.

The kids are 16 to 18 and show a healthy disrespect for the politician in front of them. Hague launches straight into a sectarian defence of the Conservative position. ItÕs just another hustings. The kidsÕ questions are predictable: crime, asylum, the battle over the repeal of Section 28, the clause that supposedly bans local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools.

In Scotland, LabourÕs plans to repeal the clause have proved to be a political disaster. The actual meaning of the Section 28 clause has long ceased to have any direct relevance to the storm of accusation and counter-accusation unleashed by the privately-funded "referendum" and Scottish Cardinal Thomas WinningÕs denunciation of "perverts". The Scottish Tory Party is strongly opposed to the clauseÕs repeal, despite well-founded media whispers that a number of prominent Scots Tories are themselves closet gays. HagueÕs answer is another little masterpiece, coating a reactionary stance in an outer layer of seeming tolerance. "I am not saying that everyone should live in a particular way.

I think we should be tolerant of people having different sexual orientations. We have got past all the attitudes that everyone has to live in a particular way. But that does not mean taxpayersÕ money should be used to promote a particular lifestyle. That is a separate issue. In our party, you will find people of a different sexual orientation who will agree about Section 28. The great majority of the public also agree about Section 28. Politicians have to respect issues like that."

He repeated a few jokes and the kids laughed, once or twice, but there was not any sense of connection. William did not enthuse, he did not inspire, he does not even pretend to give the standard political argument about politics, democracy and why, in an era of democratic apathy, the kids should bother voting for anyone. It was a telling moment. It is an argument that Hague is constitutionally incapable of enunciating; the blood in his veins runs so Tory blue that he would rather the sixth-formers of Currie High School stayed at home on polling day than vote Labour. To the private consternation of some of his staff, Hague does not even recognise his omission. The instincts of the Conservative battling debater can take you only so far. You also have to have the "vision thing".

We head off towards a Keep the Pound Rally in Princes Street gardens, and serious opposition. The rally has attracted about 200 people, including a large contingent of Socialist WorkerÕs Party hecklers. Their posters are festooned with images of Hague under the banner: "Stop this man playing the race card!"

Hague takes the platform mike and sticks it to Blair. "All the opinion polls show that the vast majority of British people agree with us that we should be in Europe, but keep the pound. That is why, as part of our Common Sense Revolution, we have issued a Sterling Guarantee that means that people can be sure that a vote for the Conservative Party at the next election is a vote to keep the pound."

As his aides crowd in on the SWP banner-holders, Hague takes questions. He is again a man at ease, enjoying the rollicking argument, the cut and thrust of hostile questions, and the soap-box politics. It is a genuine democratic moment. ItÕs not every day the citizens of Edinburgh get the chance in person to ask the Leader of the Opposition questions.

At the end, we all get ready to slip away, but then the SWP contingent starts running after us in a pincer movement to block our exit up the steep embankment that leads to Princes Street. "Stuff the racists, end the fear. Refugees are welcome here," they shout. What starts out as a brisk walk soon becomes a hurried trot. We make it through the narrow metal exit to Princes Street, once again a hurtling, 30-strong phalanx of human bodies. We dash over the road in front of hooting buses, but our pursuers follow. "Hague, you are a disgrace!" shouts one persistent Sinn Fein advocate of the Good Friday Agreement. We are chased along half the length of Princess Street to the refuge of Scottish Conservative Office, being spat at and abused. Once inside, everyone cracks jokes about jogging and trades heckler stories. There is a real air of relief as the Leader and his followers sit down for beer and lunch.

Soon Hague will be off for another appointment in his constituency, another stage on what will, or will not, be his road to No10. Will William Hague become Prime Minister? Two months ago, the answer would have been easy Ñ no. He did not have a chance. Now that answer is less certain, and the battle lines are clearer. But I am still not really sure who William Hague is. The hours I spent in his company revealed not the substance of a man but rather the internal working of a political machine. The person inside that machine remained as remote and untouchable as that flickering image in our memories of the Tory Boy Wonder. There is only one certainty. William Hague is going to fight the next election in the only way he knows how, as a real Tory, not one of the fake, soppy, compassionate ones, and he is fighting to win.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Dorset & Isle of Wight | Munich | Rome | Russia | Goa | Venice & Greece | Oman | Safari
fields.body:
Europe

Dorset & Isle of Wight: Summer Camp holidays running from July 22-September 2. One week from £304-£344, depending on age and activities, which include abseiling, canoeing, quad-biking and night hikes. Accommodation and meals all in. 3D (0800 1692606).

Munich: Three-night weekend breaks to the Oktoberfest (Munich Beer Festival) from £320pp, based on two sharing. The price includes return flights from Stansted to Munich and accommodation on a B&B basis. Departures to the Beer Festival on September 15, 22 and 29. German Travel Centre (020-8429 2900).

Rome: Two-night break to Rome from £159pp (based on two sharing) until the end of August. Includes scheduled flights from Heathrow, accommodation and Continental breakfast. Citalia (020-8686 5533).

Russia: Eight-day traditional arts and crafts tour of Russia from September 9-16. Takes in Moscow, Nizhni Novgorod and Suzdal among others. The £1,585pp price includes return BA flights, accommodation, transfers, transport, guide, entrance fees, most meals and visa. Steppes East (01285 810267).

Asia

Goa: Fourteen nights at the Holiday Inn cost £699pp this autumn. An all-inclusive option is available for an extra £10pp a night. The offer applies to holidays taken between October 7 and 28 and includes flights from Manchester or Gatwick, transfers and B&B accommodation. The Holiday Inn faces Mobor Beach. Somak Holidays (020-8423 3000).

Cruise

Venice & Greece: Seven nights from £499pp, taking in Venice, Dubrovnik, Santorini, Mykonos, Athens, Paxos, Corfu and the Corinth Canal. Based on standard cabin, full board, return flights from London and taxes. Departures on August 19, 26; September 2, 9, 16, 23 and 30. Seafarer Cruising & Sailing Holidays (01202 685500).

Middle East

Oman: Desert and marine safari from October 6-20, from £2,195pp. Includes whale and dolphin watching, snorkelling and camel riding. Price includes flights, accommodation, transport, most meals guides and park fees. Discovery Initiatives (020-7924 5696).

Australia

webTitle: Central contracts: nice idea, badly executed

fields.headline: Central contracts: nice idea, badly executed
fields.trailText: My name is David, I am 28-years-old, and I am an England cricket supporter. There I've said it, I have confessed. Actually I jest: I'm really quite proud of it. After all, what other team has claimed a victory as magnificent as Headingley 1981? Who can forget Gatting's team sweeping the board Down Under in 1986-87? And what other batsman has played an innings as good as Gooch's 154* against West Indies in 1991?
fields.body:
My name is David, I am 28-years-old, and I am an England cricket supporter. There I've said it, I have confessed. Actually I jest: I'm really quite proud of it. After all, what other team has claimed a victory as magnificent as Headingley 1981? Who can forget Gatting's team sweeping the board Down Under in 1986-87? And what other batsman has played an innings as good as Gooch's 154* against West Indies in 1991?

But we have to remember all the batting collapses, the inability to regain the Ashes for over a decade, the farcical reign of Chairman Illingworth. Throughout all this time, I've remained hopelessly optimistic, stupidly loyal, but sometimes, just sometimes, I feel as though my love has been unrequited.

Nevertheless, there is one aspect of English cricket in recent years I feel as though I have a right to grumble about. This has been the constant malaise that seems to affect every selection meeting, the apparent favouritism when choosing a tour party, the constant chopping and changing just when we feel as though this is a settled team.

England have just pulled off a magnificent two-wicket win over West Indies, a team whose confidence was growing by the game. Now this may seem harsh after such a great win, but England's recent wins have been with a team that is only half-performing. They are carrying a few passengers, a direct result of some shockingly poor England teams in the 1980s which can be blamed on a selection policy befuddled by rebel tours, misguided decisions and blatant stupidity.

How come the average England supporter can make better decisions and judgements than the selection panel? Recent history is littered with examples: the non-selection of David Gower, the premature dropping of Robin Smith, the fickle treatment of players like Andy Caddick, Phil Tufnell, Dominic Cork and Nasser Hussain himself. This group of players were not picked at various times as they were believed to be disruptive influences.

Surely the only common factor between these men are that they are proven matchwinners with a huge desire to win. After all, would the Australians drop Warne or McGrath, who have helped their team become the best in the world? Allan Border rarely cracked a smile on the field yet he is the most capped player and highest runscorer in Test history, so proving you can be a good player and look a bit sullen at the same time.

When England lost to New Zealand last year, and suddenly became the Worst Team in the World, the ever-optimistic, ever-hopeful England supporter found his confidence and belief wavering a little. Then after yet another mediocre winter tour, England bravely entered the 21st century with the announcement of a central-contract system, an idea successfully pioneered elsewhere, but one which the ECB finally cottoned onto as being a good thing. Surely this would protect our young pace bowlers from the rigours of the county system, Athers wouldn't have to risk his fragile back, Alec Stewart could rest his weary bones, Craig White could take a deserved rest.

Hang on, Craig White? Graeme Hick? Mark Ramprakash? Well, at least they didn't choose a rookie legspinner who had only played 11 first-class games. Oops, they did. As admirable as the contract system is, surely the wrong players were chosen. What exactly did Craig White do to justify selection? What was the point of awarding year-long contracts to the likes of Hick and Ramprakash, who have never been regular fixtures in the team and are in and out more times than a fiddler's elbow.

Surely the contracts should have been awarded to those cricketers who actually deserve the luxury of picking and choosing the games they play in. Players who have performed when it mattered most. Not injury-prone bowlers who break down at the start of the season or allrounders who are yet to prove themselves at Test level.

True, the selectors have just swallowed their pride and brought back Dominic Cork, and it is only a matter of time before Graham Thorpe returns to the fold. And England have just won a Test match. These are good enough grounds for believing England will win the series, stuff the Pakistanis on their home turf and finally wrestle the Ashes off those Aussies.

Well I can dream, can't I?

David Reavill lives in St Albans. To read last week's Punter's Point, on the match-fixing scandal, click here

fields.headline: Here they go again
fields.standfirst: Every year, perennials bring joy to the border. But if you are tempted to cram the flowerbeds with them, you'll need to plan carefully. Many happy returns, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Every year, perennials bring joy to the border. But if you are tempted to cram the flowerbeds with them, you'll need to plan carefully. Many happy returns, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
Perennials, I remarked last week, are not, on the whole, strongly designed. Many tend to be hazy and structureless. Gypsophilas, for instance, linums, most lychnis, cranesbills, asters, day lilies, spiderworts, phloxes... I could run on.

But some are helpful in this respect, and they will be especially valuable in perennial borders where you don't want shrubs. It would be better if you would keep an open mind on this question and grow a shrub among perennials if it seemed to you to look right in the context, but I shall here suppose that perennials, and perennials only, are your aim.

Anything spiky with an upright thrust will look purposeful. Eremurus, the foxtail lilies, for instance. Their colours range from white through pale pink and yellow to soft orangey shades; their heights from 1m to 3m, and their season covers, between them, all of May and June. No one of them flowers for very long. They have fleshy roots and need good drainage. They like alkaline soils and are exciting to look at. Dying away completely from view in late summer, you need from the start to think of replacements in their vicinity.

Verbascum chaixii (1.5m) seeded itself among mine, which was a good idea. It has more or less unbranched spikes of yellow or white flowers with purple stamens at the centre, flowering in July. All verbascums have a strong presence but some of the best are biennial. These self-sow.

Kniphofias, the red-hot-pokers, are strongly spiky and always make an impression, although not one that everybody likes. Their strap leaves can be rather messy, as are those of day lilies and tradescantias, but are a distinct asset in Kniphofia caulescens, where they are glaucous and borne in rosettes. This is quite a variable species, some strains flowering in June, others not till September, in a soft orange-red. In 'Little Maid' (1m or less), the pokers are creamy white and prolific over quite a long, late-summer season, especially if you replant fairly frequently.

I like the September-flowering 'Torchbearer' (2m), because there is quite a lot of green in its yellow colouring. Among the fieriest and most aggressive, but a fine landscape feature, is the August- flowering K. uvaria 'Nobilis' (3m). That is orange-coloured.

I count Phormium as evergreen perennials, and their fans of tough leaves are generally the principal asset. But some flower regularly in early summer, spiky at first, rather like a heron's neck and beak; then branching as the muted, greenish-yellow flowers develop. Hardiest and most reliable, in my estimation, is P. cookianum 'Tricolor' (2m in flower, half as high in leaf). The strap leaves are curved and combine strips of purple (at the margins), green and cream. The flowering stems in June are generously borne.

When flowers or leaves are borne in whorled tiers, they always agreeably draw attention to themselves. Thus, in Veronicastrum virginicum (1.5m), whose spiky flowers are a rather dusty purple, and the more popular white album, there is a great build-up beneath the flowers of whorled lance-leaves. In Phlomis russeliana (1.2m), the tiered whorls are of dusky-yellow labiate flowers, which show up at a distance as strong shapes.

On the other hand, the flat, cow parsley-style corymbs of many umbellifers draw our attention in a different way, and they often have a branching inflorescence that is strong on presentation. Among the handsomest are any species in the genus Ferula of the giant fennels. They have wonderfully dissect foliage but rise, on flowering, way above this, often to 3m, the domed flower heads themselves being greeny-yellow. Any Ferula will give pleasure in the first half of the year and flowering will be most generous if the plants are well fed, although in nature they may grow on arid, hungry slopes. In this respect, ecology is not the best guide.

Alliums, with their domed heads above naked scapes, make themselves noticed, especially the larger-headed kinds, such as Allium giganteum (1.5m), which is lilac-mauve, and A. cristophii (1m), whose globes of spiky stars start a light shade of purple. That seeds itself right through my borders, and it is the best way to see these alliums. On a recent visit to Germany, I was impressed by the strong clumps of A. multibulbosum (1m), with flowers in white domes. Multibulbosum does sound a bit threatening, however, as though it might take one over, as some alliums do.

A panicle of blossom can make a good impression from a distance. Red valerian, Centranthus ruber, does this, whether red or white, but I would avoid the rather dirty pink-red strain. It is a great self-seeder, but it is best to cut back the first flush of blossom now, before it has sown itself everywhere. In our southern counties, there will be a second flush in September.

The moisture-loving rodgersias are grown mainly, I suppose, for their bold foliage, but some of them flower most handsomely, with large panicles, if grown in good soil. Rodgersia podophylla (1m) is a shy flowerer but most of the others are pretty free, generally white but sometimes pink, as in certain strains of R. pinnata. The inflorescence dies tastefully over a long period.

Last mention shall go to the wonderfully structured cardoons, Cynara cardunculus (2m), with their widely branching candelabrums of mauve thistle-heads. Grey, divided leaves are handsomer still, early in their long season

 Christopher Lloyd's Garden Flowers (Perennials, Bulbs, Grasses and Ferns) is published by Cassell & Co, priced £30.

webTitle: Rebuff to Cook as Blair holds line on euro

fields.headline: Rebuff to Cook as Blair holds line on euro
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street insists entry not inevitable as banker fuels debate
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street yesterday slapped down Robin Cook after the foreign secretary came close to breaching the cabinet compromise on the euro by declaring that Britain would inevitably join the single currency.
fields.body:
Downing Street yesterday slapped down Robin Cook after the foreign secretary came close to breaching the cabinet compromise on the euro by declaring that Britain would inevitably join the single currency.

In a clear rebuke to Mr Cook, Downing Street insisted that Tony Blair did not believe it was inevitable that Britain would join.

The prime minister's spokesman said: "It's our objective to join a successful single currency, providing the economic conditions are met. It is not inevitable but it's our objective."

The intervention by Downing Street came as the European central bank president, Wim Duisenberg, fuelled cabinet divisions over the euro by declaring that Britain had met all but one of the conditions for entry.

Mr Duisenberg, who said recently that "psycho-political" worries were blocking entry, said that the British economy was "suffering greatly" by remaining outside euroland.

His remarks will be welcomed by the cabinet's pro-euro wing, led by Mr Cook, whose members believe that the government must step up its "prepare and decide" policy.

The foreign secretary attempted to widen the boundaries of the cabinet's euro policy on Thursday when he said that Britain would eventually join the single currency. Asked about recent opinion polls on the euro, Mr Cook said he welcomed figures which showed that most people believe that membership of the single currency was inevitable. "I think they are right," he said.

His remarks came close to defying the cabinet's agreed policy on the euro, which says that the government will hold a referendum on membership only if a series of economic tests have been met.

Gordon Brown, who is the foreign secretary's main foe over the issue, believes that the government should not allow the general election campaign to be distracted by the euro.

The position of the pro-euro ministers was strengthened yesterday when Mr Duisenberg said that Britain had met the criteria for membership set out in the Maastricht treaty on inflation, public sector debt and long term interest rates. The only exception was the exchange rate.

"The performance of the British economy is admirable, but it is suffering greatly because it is not participating in the euro - that said, the decision is for the British people," Mr Duisenberg told the Italian newspaper Il Sole. He made it clear he was speaking only from an economic and technical point of view.

The chancellor's cabinet faction will dismiss Mr Duisenberg's remarks, saying that he was referring to the Maastricht criteria, rather than the five economic tests set out by the chancellor. These include the impact of the euro on jobs.

The Tories were quick to exploit the Downing Street response to Mr Cook. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, claimed that the government was in a "state of disarray" over the single currency.

"Downing Street spin doctors have launched a panic rearguard action to try to cover up Robin Cook's remarks when he confirmed that the Labour government want to scrap the pound," he said. "Ministers are not only committed to the euro in principle, but believe membership is inevitable. Their outlook for Britain is defeatist. They ignore the evidence that Britain can survive and thrive outside the euro."

 Cheap mortgages promised by Mr Blair last week if Britain joins the euro could be a mirage, a Guardian survey reveals.

fields.bodyText: Downing Street yesterday slapped down Robin Cook after the foreign secretary came close to breaching the cabinet compromise on the euro by declaring that Britain would inevitably join the single currency. In a clear rebuke to Mr Cook, Downing Street insisted that Tony Blair did not believe it was inevitable that Britain would join. The prime minister's spokesman said: "It's our objective to join a successful single currency, providing the economic conditions are met. It is not inevitable but it's our objective." The intervention by Downing Street came as the European central bank president, Wim Duisenberg, fuelled cabinet divisions over the euro by declaring that Britain had met all but one of the conditions for entry. Mr Duisenberg, who said recently that "psycho-political" worries were blocking entry, said that the British economy was "suffering greatly" by remaining outside euroland. His remarks will be welcomed by the cabinet's pro-euro wing, led by Mr Cook, whose members believe that the government must step up its "prepare and decide" policy. The foreign secretary attempted to widen the boundaries of the cabinet's euro policy on Thursday when he said that Britain would eventually join the single currency. Asked about recent opinion polls on the euro, Mr Cook said he welcomed figures which showed that most people believe that membership of the single currency was inevitable. "I think they are right," he said. His remarks came close to defying the cabinet's agreed policy on the euro, which says that the government will hold a referendum on membership only if a series of economic tests have been met. webTitle: Three-finger exercise no breeze for Ramps

fields.headline: Three-finger exercise no breeze for Ramps
fields.trailText: Apparently we won a test match. So what? Nobody died. You'll have to forgive me if Pod doesn't join in all the celebrations and general euphoria about the Windies going belly-up and how England are poised to leapfrog Pitcairn Island in the coveted Wisden world rankings.
fields.body:
Apparently we won a test match. So what? Nobody died. You'll have to forgive me if Pod doesn't join in all the celebrations and general euphoria about the Windies going belly-up and how England are poised to leapfrog Pitcairn Island in the coveted Wisden world rankings.

Not everybody was at Lord's last Saturday afternoon. Some of us had a job of work to do. New betting shops don't just open themselves, you know. Somebody has to drive a long distance to cut that ribbon, without always having sorted out the business of petrol expenses beforehand. It's often an act of blind faith.

Actually this is one of the celebrity-circuit duties Dave Podmore takes very much in his stride these days. Call it an ill wind but many more opportunities opened up in the betting shop arena after Red Rum popped his clogs and since Mr High-and-Mighty Desert Orchid decided he was too grand to perform at anything less than the State Opening of Parliament.

I thought I was going to have a fight on my hands to get the latest gig, a state-of-the-art branch of Geo Salmon (Turf Accountant), Jesmond Ltd. Especially when I heard Keith Chegwin was also sniffing around. But then Cheggers dropped out, I gather because he didn't like the no-nudity clause in the contract, and so it was Dave Podmore who hit the A1(M) at dawn.

Though I say it myself, it isn't feasible for a personality betting-shop opening to have gone any smoother. The giant scissors worked a treat, 300 notes found their way into the Podmore back pocket and the local kiddies' hospital benefited to the tune of a £1.50 each-way bet (plus I paid the tax) at Newcastle races later that afternoon.

Word had got out I was in the area, so naturally Channel 4 wanted Pod to do an interview during their racing coverage. I was more than happy to indulge in a little banter with Derek Thompson in my special Geordie accent. More important, it gave me an opportunity to parade my wares on national television.

That is what I intended: the new Dave Podmore range of National League trousers ("cool in daytime, warm at night") has a Capri-length leg with generous cargo pockets, to accommodate high-protein nutritional supplements - trail mix, kebabs, etc - for those 45-over stretches between meal breaks.

Unfortunately the viewing millions were never to know about this exciting new product. No sooner had I said how great it was to be back in the north-west than the TV bosses pulled the plug on us and it was "And now back to Lord's for the cricket".

Watching England take seven hours to score less than 200 runs might be someone's idea of sporting entertainment but there's a time and a place for everything and I'm afraid that showing uninterrupted wall-to-wall cricket is just going to put people off the game. The sooner the BBC gets the coverage back, the better.

Fair play to Corky, though. I've got on well enough with him. I was only too pleased to be there for him during a messy marriage break-up and Corky couldn't have been kinder to Pod during my messy speeding and tax evasion problems, my messier shoplifting case and my very messy indeed indecent exposure allegations.

But there's no denying that on occasion D Cork hasn't done the game or his fellow professionals any favours, Saturday's attention-grabbing outburst being the latest example. The cocky so-and-so even had the nerve to hold up three fingers to the players' balcony, signalling to Mark Ramprakash to do something useful for once and put three Bacardi Breezers on ice for when he came in. The way I heard it, Ramps didn't manage to stick one of them away successfully.

Sure, that 30-odd of Corky's at the death and seven wickets might have won the match for England. But the knock-on effects are already being felt, whereby every bits-and-pieces player on the county circuit is now expected to go out and score a million every time he puts his helmet on and slides his box in. Cheers, mate.

Five years ago I might have been envious of the guy, with his no doubt impending bloody contract. But now, with my new-found maturity, I can shrug my shoulders and laugh - all the way to the bank actually, thanks to a little bird not unadjacent to Geo Salmon (Turf Accountant), Jesmond Ltd, who advised me to put my entire appearance fee on the remote possibility of South Africa somehow contriving to lose their bid for the 2006 World Cup.

Sorry, Corky. Didn't get that result, did you? Good luck in the rest of the series.

fields.headline: Master Brown delivers a caning
fields.standfirst: Surrey 334-8 v Leicestershire
fields.trailText: County cricket's outgrounds, with their geographical whims, diverse charms and impracticalities, have almost gone forever. They are among the game's anachronisms, rejected by the cold eyes of the accountants. But Rutland, of all places, is discounting the trend with picturesque defiance.
fields.body:
County cricket's outgrounds, with their geographical whims, diverse charms and impracticalities, have almost gone forever. They are among the game's anachronisms, rejected by the cold eyes of the accountants. But Rutland, of all places, is discounting the trend with picturesque defiance.

The last time a championship match was played here was in 1938. That was when Les Berry, the Bristol Rovers goalkeeper, and Leicestershire's New Zealand test player CS Dempster scored 180 for the first wicket.

It was there, three years earlier, that Tich Freeman tossed the twirling ball up into the clouds to take eight for 123. It was also where a callow 16-year-old George Dawkes made his unexpected debut and where yesterday, just short of his 80th birthday, he returned as a guest of the county club.

The pavilion now lacks its thatched roof but the outfield, tended lovingly by the groundsman Keith Exton, remains a table of billiards-baize perfection, even though the boys play rugby on part of it. And the strip itself, immaculate and loftily praised, is an argument Leicestershire have decided they cannot ignore.

When Surrey, after winning the toss, lost their first three wickets for 25 - all to James Ormond - this argument seemed momentarily suspect. Mark Butcher went in the opening over; Ian Ward soon followed and Adam Hollioake was well held, just off the ground at second slip, by Chris Lewis. Did that handsome run-rich pitch carry a deceptive facade? Or was Ormond bowling beyond himself?

After that, of course, Alistair Brown redressed matters and with considerable aplomb; an innings of punchy, controlled strokeplay, always good to look at and especially rewarding for the watching boys of the school.

This was Brown's first hundred of the season and in every sense worth waiting for. He might have gone once to mid-wicket but his approach was never reckless; it was always fluent, eager when there were runs to be taken or pilfered. He is a small player who gets into position quickly and strokes with merciless and expansive intent, and he grows in resolve as his total multiplies.

By late evening he had passed 200 in 5 hours, with 24 fours and a six, when he calmly leaned back to pull Darren Maddy. At the close Surrey were 334 for eight, with Brown on 211. Alex Tudor was his less spectacular partner in a stand of 141.

Earlier Nadeem Shahid had steadied Surrey until he was dismissed immediately after lunch. He and Ben Hollioake fell to Phil DeFreitas, Lewis held a sharp gully catch to send back Jon Batty and then, off his enforced short run, had Martin Bicknell caught behind the wicket.

It was never going to be, despite Ormond's successes, a day for the bowlers. Anil Kumble was a disappointment, bowling short too often, and did not pose his customary problems for batsmen. It was, however, a fulfiling end-of-term occasion.

fields.headline: Ramprakash enigma turns on style
fields.standfirst: Middlesex 288-8 v Worcestershire
fields.trailText: The footwork was pure Baryshnikov, the ball speeding to the long-off boundary for the second time in the over as if guided by radar. "Awesome," exulted Justin Langer, one of the world's finest batsmen beside himself in admiration for the prince of under-achievers.
fields.body:
The footwork was pure Baryshnikov, the ball speeding to the long-off boundary for the second time in the over as if guided by radar. "Awesome," exulted Justin Langer, one of the world's finest batsmen beside himself in admiration for the prince of under-achievers.

Mark Ramprakash's test career may be on the line for the umpteenth time but to watch him yesterday was to wonder for the umpteenth time how he ever got himself into such a jam.

It was a toss-up which was the more improbable: Glenn McGrath waiting until his 18th over for a wicket or a batsman, albeit the eminently sporting Langer, walking on a bat-pad appeal. By the same token nothing was so predictable than that Ramprakash, relieved of the pressures of opening after cutting such a forlorn figure against Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, should tackle the game's most lethal bowler with something akin to a smile, reminding us of a talent that infuriates as often as it intoxicates.

Thursday's thumping of Somerset in the NatWest Trophy may well signify a corner turned but, according to Langer, their thoughtful, feisty and above all realistic captain, the Middlesex revival has taken the best part of three seasons to reach second gear.

For a club boasting four proven internationals, and any amount of could-bes and would-bes, excuses have been as thin on the ground as clutchable straws, though the suspicion persists that plying their trade at Lord's, with its capacity to intimidate, has become more hindrance than help. That their most significant wins this year have come here and at Chelmsford may not be coincidental.

The ills stem from the top, as they have done from the day Desmond Haynes departed in 1994, since when the number of opening pairs has only narrowly been outstripped by the grey hairs sprouting from Mike Gatting's chin.

Langer's decision to restore Ramprakash to his natural habitat gave Andrew Strauss his fifth partner of term and David Nash's technique and pluck against McGrath augured well for a lasting alliance.

Strauss is rather partial to the visitors' attack. Last season he and Ben Hutton posted cen tury opening stands in each innings and that straight, unhurried bat served the economics graduate admirably again here. Driving fluently square of the wicket, he was within 10 runs of his second century of both season and career when his first false shot, a top-edged sweep off Matthew Rawnsley, proved his last.

"'E's got a longer run than me," exclaimed Phil Tufnell, but the lanky Rawnsley's flight and loop were more pertinent assets. He snared five men in all, his first such haul in the championship, but on a sluggish pitch offering no little turn, and with four spinners in the home ranks, Middlesex will not be displeased. Nor will it dismay them to see Ramprakash walking off unbeaten, one short of his first hundred of the century.

webTitle: Durham crack as pitch holds firm

fields.headline: Durham crack as pitch holds firm
fields.standfirst: Durham 253-8 v Yorkshire
fields.trailText: The cricket groundsman is easy to identify. He has a ruddy complexion, windswept hair, sloppy clothes and the distant gaze of a mystic.
fields.body:
The cricket groundsman is easy to identify. He has a ruddy complexion, windswept hair, sloppy clothes and the distant gaze of a mystic.

In all this he resembles the street corner down-and-out with a fistful of meths or Special Brew lager. Perhaps the two are one and the same. Being a groundsman these days is certainly enough to drive you to drink. As the good book said, he that toucheth pitch shall be defiled.

The trouble is that poor pitches are now such an established norm that you have to produce a real stinker, one so bad that a captain might turn his ankle on it as he walks out for the toss and then lose his coin down a crack, before anyone bothers to do anything about it.

The groundsman, fighting against awful weather, ancient earth, directives from the England and Wales Cricket Board and some arm-twisting from his own captain, is not always to blame. Turf wars rage far beyond Drumcree.

The Yorkshire groundsman, Andy Fogarty, is a particularly beleaguered man of the soil. Bowlers roll up their sleeves at Headingley while batsmen whimper and sniffle as their averages come down faster than store prices in January.

Yorkshire know they were lucky to avoid a points penalty when they beat Kent in just two days and 214 overs last month. AC Smith, the ECB's pitches liaison officer, turned in a performance of such indecision that his followers were damp-eyed with nostalgia.

Yesterday, under the stern gaze of another PLO, the former Lancashire captain David Hughes, Fogarty played safe. He picked the blandest strip on his entire square, the one on which Yorkshire piled up 508 for five against Derbyshire earlier this season. This pitch is the party bore, surrounded by those that jump and scurry, dive and dance.

It is a crazy-paving offering, like all the others, but somehow the small cracks do not widen. Yorkshire's captain David Byas must have been influenced by the dampness of the surface when he chose to bowl. Either that or he wanted to give Fogarty a pat on the back in front of Hughes.

Byas had soil on his face when Durham sauntered to 75 for one at lunch and 192 for three at tea. But in the final session Fogarty's countenance might have lost some of its healthy hue as Durham lost five wickets for 27 runs to close on 253 for eight.

When PLO Hughes left his post, Durham were looking serene at 214 for three. If he had his radio on, the clatter of wickets might have tempted him to do a panic u-turn on the M62 but in truth the pitch behaved reasonably well.

After losing four of their last five matches in all cricket, the championship leaders Yorkshire are anxious to do well here against one of the relegation favourites.

But they had to wait for their success. Before yesterday Jonathan Lewis had scored just one first-class fifty this season, also against Yorkshire.

Here he batted for 4 hours for a dogged 66 against some spirited bowling, particularly from Chris Silverwood, who took three wickets and bowled with real pace on a slow surface, and Ryan Sidebottom, who had four. Yorkshire were without England's Darren Gough and Craig White and then they lost Gavin Hamilton with a rib muscle injury halfway through an over.

Lewis and Michael Gough, playing his first championship match of the season, put on 60, Durham's best start of the summer. Then Simon Katich struck some fine blows before he pulled Silverwood to midwicket. Then came the collapse. But, with all respect to Kenneth Williams, the answer could not be found in the soil.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: There are those who feel Dominic Cork should be at the Oval today and back at Lord's tomorrow to renew his acquaintance with West Indies. But England's decision to overlook him for the triangular one-day series is Derbyshire's gain.
fields.body:
There are those who feel Dominic Cork should be at the Oval today and back at Lord's tomorrow to renew his acquaintance with West Indies. But England's decision to overlook him for the triangular one-day series is Derbyshire's gain.

With nearly half the season played, they are bottom of the First Division and likely to be without Cork for most of August so they need to get the most out of him. His first half-century of the season helped them to three useful batting points against title hopefuls Lancashire at Derby. Coming in at 143 for five, Cork struck eight boundaries in his 52.

At Taunton Hampshire gave another woeful batting performance. Put in by Jamie Cox, they were dismissed for 142 inside 42 overs.

With Marcus Trescothick away on international duty, Mark Lathwell played his first championship match for Somerset since 1998. fields.headline: Selvey
fields.standfirst: As I was saying, it could be England's summer
fields.trailText: Without wishing this to become known as the Eddie Calvert column, the number of people who predicted that England would resurrect the series by winning the second test at Lord's could hold their reunion parties in a telephone box and still have room for a dancefloor. And the Guardian will be there, propping up the bar and reminiscing long into the night.
fields.body:
Without wishing this to become known as the Eddie Calvert column, the number of people who predicted that England would resurrect the series by winning the second test at Lord's could hold their reunion parties in a telephone box and still have room for a dancefloor. And the Guardian will be there, propping up the bar and reminiscing long into the night.

It bodes well for the game, though, and they are still talking about the final day so much in the White Hart that I have started issuing invoices for consultancy fees on my days off: talk of Dominic Cork's manic eyes, and of the sheer phlegmaticness of the two Mikes, Atherton and Vaughan, as they kept out one of the finest ever sustained displays of skilled pace bowling from Curtly Ambrose.

They are also speculating on what precisely Duncan Fletcher may have said to Andy Caddick (no doubt among the smelly socks and sweaty jocks in the dark, windowless privacy of the drying room, the traditional location for a bollocking) that transformed him from first-innings mouse into second-innings monster.

What a game it was. No one in the crowd bit through an umbrella handle this time but there were some nails down to the quick, you can be sure. In the dressing room, superstition would have taken over from reason as the target got ever closer. Atherton apparently sat wedged in on his balcony seat, dying for a pee but unable or unwilling to move until the final run had been scored lest it break the spell.

In the Test Match Special box much the same was happening, with Graham Gooch destined to summarise to the close no matter how long it took, while Viv Richards tried desperately to wrest the seat from him.

It is not easy finding parallels. Things were pretty tense in the second of the Trinidad tests two years ago when, chasing 225, Mark Butcher and the tail saw England home by three wickets. But there was an overnight break mid-innings, leaving poor Butcher to ruminate on his fate, so that the atmosphere at Queen's Park Oval on the final day lacked its usual conch- blowing vibrancy.

The nearest my own watching experience takes me was eight years ago on the fourth day of the fourth test between Australia and West Indies in Adelaide. That game needs to be placed in context. Three matches into the series Australia were one up, with a win in either of the last two clinching the first series defeat for West Indies in 12 years. Ambrose, six for 74, ensured Australia had a first-innings deficit of 39, which West Indies extended to 153 before the last six second-innings wickets fell in an orgy of irresponsibility for only 22 more, Tim May's offspin taking five for nine.

Australia had two days to score 186, two fewer than England's requirement a week ago, and at 102 for eight were dead and buried. Then gradually a revival took place. Justin Langer, in his first test, added 42 with May before Ian Bishop had him caught at the wicket, leaving May with the notoriously fragile batsman Craig McDermott to score 42 more.

By now word had reached the city and the crowds streamed to the ground to witness what proved to be a heartstopping climax to the game as the pair gradually chipped away at their target until two were needed. McDermott then clipped Courtney Walsh firmly off his legs for what would have been the winning runs had not Richie Richardson, intuitively, just moved Desmond Haynes back from short leg. The fielder dived, stopped the runs and fended off defeat.

Then it happened. From deep in his resolve, Walsh dredged up a bouncer to McDermott who jerked his head back and tried to withdraw his bat. The ball clipped something, went through to Junior Murray and Walsh, without waiting for a decision, began his aeroplaning celebrations, banking sharply to the left and running straight to the dressing room.

If Darrell Hair had given McDermott not out they would never have got Walsh back on the field. In fact replays showed that the umpire had been unsighted and could not have made a reasonable judgment but that nonetheless the ball had deflected from the underside of the peak of McDermott's helmet and then just kissed the upward-pointing face of the bat: the right decision made for the wrong reason.

West Indies went on to pulverise Australia in the final match in Perth inside seven sessions of play, the equivalent of saving three match points on the opponent's serve and then taking the final set 6-0.

I like omens but are they that good? Will this be a famous summer for England?

Call it gut feeling but the Guardian thinks it will. Attendance at the reunion is strictly by invitation, though. The bandwagon carries only so many.

webTitle: Banger on the point of explosion

fields.headline: Banger on the point of explosion
fields.standfirst: Marcus Trescothick is that rarity, a man selected for an England debut when in form, writes  Rob Steen
fields.trailText: Even if Marcus Trescothick ignores his own prolonged hiccups, he needs no reminding that fate's fickle finger can be as indiscriminate as Bernard Manning's rib-tickling technique. It hits him every time he enters the Taunton dressing-room and glances over to the corner once occupied by Mark Lathwell.
fields.body:
Even if Marcus Trescothick ignores his own prolonged hiccups, he needs no reminding that fate's fickle finger can be as indiscriminate as Bernard Manning's rib-tickling technique. It hits him every time he enters the Taunton dressing-room and glances over to the corner once occupied by Mark Lathwell.

Lathwell, the snub-nosed ingénue who was going to help Trescothick forge England's first all-Somerset opening alliance, his elder by four years less a day, was first to graduate. Chucked into the deep end at 21 against Allan Border's rampant 1993 Australians, he confessed, somewhat sheepishly, that he did not really think he was up to it. Predictably it proved a self-fulfilling prophecy. Two Tests and he was history, confined to the fringe as form, fitness and heart took turns to desert. That once dashing blade is now more frequently flashed on behalf of the second XI.

"You can't help but be reminded and my heart goes out to Lathers, though I'm sure he'll bounce back," sympathises Trescothick, full of positivism as he looks forward to his first one-day international against Zimbabwe today. "But we're not made the same way."

Only this season, though, has this far from tentative left-hander looked to have the mental fibre to avoid a similar swoon. For once the selectors' timing has been impeccable.

"Look at me, I'm wonderful," caroused the inimitably sardonic Bonzo Dog Doo Dah Band on Keynsham, the album they named after Trescothick's birthplace. As England's Under-19 captain he could have been forgiven for chanting the refrain in earnest.

Terrifying his contemporaries, he was the first to amass 1,000 runs for that Eng land age group. It is a reflection of county cricket's inadequacies as a finishing school, however, that this earthy, ruddy-cheeked lad, the same budding colossus who once made 322 for Somerset Seconds before being last out seven shy of a target of 612, has taken half a decade to flower.

Last season typified his refusal to do things by halves: 19 championship knocks yielded 472 runs, the other two 357. More by chance than self-seeking guile - "it didn't even register he was there" - he saved his best for Duncan Fletcher, then seeing out his coaching contract with Glamorgan.

On a Taunton pitch that defied anyone else to pass 50, the artist known as Banger - his penchant for sausages is the stuff of legend - walloped 167 off 187 balls. One six landed in the St James's Church graveyard, a feat beyond Ian Botham, let alone Viv Richards.

Dermot Reeve, the Somerset coach, hailed it. "As good an innings as I've ever seen," he said, and the competition includes Brian Lara's 501. Fletcher popped into the home dressing-room and demanded to know: "Who is this bloke?"

"Maybe it was one of those quirks of fate that Fletcher was there," concedes Graham Rose, Somerset's senior pro. "But just as being appointed vice-captain here was a boost for him last year, getting on an A tour as a result of that innings was just what he needed - a show of faith."

If the tour did not prove fruitful, team-mates, significantly, praised his spirit and infectious bonhomie, a recurrent theme. The same goes for the tingling anticipation he inspires whenever he lugs that deceptively cumbersome frame to the crease.

"He has to be more consistent, concentrate harder, get that front foot further forward," Reeve charged in April, sentiments Trescothick was quick to echo. The statistics mirror the strides, not so much that 45.30 championship average this season - he began term with a mean of under 30 - as the sedate progress: 44.49 runs per 100 balls, less than half his National League rate. Rugged run-a-ball roust-abouts now mingle with stoic six-hour sojourns. Slowly but surely the value of alternative approaches has dawned.

Nor should his bowling be sniffed at. An unprepossessing seamer fond of a wickedly teasing variation that emerges from the back of a meaty right hand, he has claimed 13 one-day victims in 55 overs this season. Lara and co could be right up his street.

To describe Trescothick as a lover of all things flanneled and foolish would do his passion a disservice. Having spent winters honing his skills with vice and plane, he quite fancies becoming a batmaker. "He's also a bit of a kit freak," says Rose. "As soon as he sees somebody has something new he's over there, feeling a bat, smelling a fresh pair of gloves." Small wonder his girlfriend plays for Somerset Ladies.

Transferring such zeal to the loftiest stage has been beyond far too many Englishmen of late to be confident that Trescothick will buck the trend over the coming fortnight. But of one thing there can be no doubt: balls will be bruised.

webTitle: Stewart takes record in his stride

fields.headline: Stewart takes record in his stride
fields.trailText: If England supporters want evidence of why the team's achievements in limited-overs cricket down the years have been substandard, they need look no further than a table which lists appearances in one-day internationals.
fields.body:
If England supporters want evidence of why the team's achievements in limited-overs cricket down the years have been substandard, they need look no further than a table which lists appearances in one-day internationals.

Top of the heap comes the former captain of India, Mohammad Azharuddin, who has played 334 games (11 months of his life taken up with this: imagine). Below him come 66 further cricketers, including three Zimbabweans - Andy Flower, who will make his 140th appearance at the Oval today, Alistair Campbell (129) and Grant Flower (127).

Then comes a group of four on 126: Chris Cairns of New Zealand, Robin Singh of India, Pramodya Wickramasinghe of Sri Lanka and Alec Stewart assuming he takes the field against Zimbabwe. The significance is that today's game will see Stewart, at 37, pass Graham Gooch as the most capped Englishman. There is nothing like experience.

Stewart, who much to his chagrin was omitted from the side that played South Africa and Zimbabwe last winter, not only returns to keep wicket but will be leading the team in Nasser Hussain's absence and opening the batting while Nick Knight recovers from the finger injury he sustained during the last test.

Stewart, while proud of his new record, is not blind to its global insignificance. "Mark Waugh, who started at the same time as me, has played well over 200 [217 to be precise]," he said yesterday. "So it is not a significant milestone for me, to be honest. It's just nice to be back playing again."

For the next few weeks England will be looking to maintain the momentum gained by their remarkable win in the second test at Lord's, and they will start today against a Zimbabwe side buoyed by their six-wicket win over West Indies on Thursday.

This is always a tough nut as, since England and Zimbabwe first encountered each other in 1992, the sides have met a dozen times in all with the spoils equally shared, although England have won five of the last six encounters.

Stewart realises the danger. "Zimbabwe are a good one-day side," he says, "and I think I've only beaten them once, personally, during the World Cup last summer." That was when England cruised to a cocksure win and later regretted not upping their run-rate as Zimbabwe qualified for the next round and England did not.

In returning to the opening spot Stewart will find himself alongside Marcus Trescothick, the muscular young Somerset left-hander who will be his ninth partner in 74 innings at the top of the order. There is no doubt that, should Trescothick perform well in the time before Knight returns to the side, he will place increased pressure on Mark Ramprakash's test position.

There will also be a return to the fold today for Graham Thorpe, who has not played a one-day international since the World Cup. The left-hander was in danger of missing out again because of a calf strain picked up last week but he came through an intensive fitness test yesterday and - provided there is no adverse reaction - will play today.

England (probable) : Stewart (Surrey, capt & wkt), Trescothick (Somerset), Hick (Worcestershire), Thorpe (Surrey), Maynard (Glamorgan), Flintoff (Lancashire), Ealham (Kent), Croft (Glamorgan), Caddick (Somerset), Gough (Yorkshire), Mullally (Hampshire).

Zimbabwe (from) : Johnson, Wishart, Goodwin, Campbell, A Flower (capt and wkt), G Flower, Whittall, Viljoen, Strang, Brent, Mbangwa, Carlisle, Streak, Strang.

webTitle: No end to influx of foreign players

fields.headline: No end to influx of foreign players
fields.standfirst: As the FA picks over England's latest failure, the clubs continue to look overseas, writes  Martin Thorpe :   the summer's Premiership dealings so far.
fields.trailText: The potential for Kevin Keegan to throw his toys out of the pram will be tested further today when he is due to face more criticism of his England record from within the Football Association.
fields.body:
The potential for Kevin Keegan to throw his toys out of the pram will be tested further today when he is due to face more criticism of his England record from within the Football Association.

Today's summer meeting of English football's governing body will hear a number of worried FA councillors voicing their concerns over Keegan's failure in Euro 2000, and in particular his perceived lack of tactical nous.

However, Keegan can take some comfort from the fact that FA members do recognise that deeper, underlying factors have contributed to England's embarrassing recent record, and high on their list of suspects is the thorny issue of foreign players.

Keegan articulated his worries on this issue when he forecast soon after taking over the national reins that the day may soon come when he has to pick the bulk of his squad from the First Division.

So, while recent reports of record foreign investment into Britain pleased the Chancellor of the Exchequer, in football circles great horror greeted the posting of last season's record import figures - a record which, judging by events in the transfer market so far , will not stand for long.

At the end of last season there were 170 European Union and 39 non-EU players on the books of the 20 Premiership clubs - that is an average of 10 per club. "It was the most there's ever been and the number seems to be increasing," said a Premier League spokeswoman yes- terday.

Chelsea even famously fielded the first all-foreign XI and, though Gianluca Vialli suggested he would buy British this summer - and despite attempts by Fifa and Uefa to get the Bosman ruling modified - Chelsea's outlook, like those of other Premiership clubs, has remained distinctly unpatriotic.

Although the summer clearout at relegated Wimbledon has seen Neil Sullivan and, possibly, Ben Thatcher join Spurs and the £7m Carl Cort move to Newcastle, few other home-grown players have needed to trouble their agents about a transfer to the Premiership.

The main movers have been foreign: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to Chelsea for £15m, Sergei Rebrov to Spurs for £11m, Olivier Dacourt to Leeds for £7m, Robert Pires and Lauren Mayer to Arsenal for £6m and £7m respectively, Sylvain Wiltord possibly going to Highbury for £15m. And on and on.

The victims here are well known: young English talent. On Thursday Manchester United's promising home-grown defender Danny Higginbotham became the latest player to be pushed out of the nest. Aged 21, and fed up with waiting for his chance in the United first team, he has left Old Trafford in search of top- level football and the fulfilment of a potential recognised even by Sir Alex Ferguson.

As his new manager Jim Smith of Derby explained: "Danny wants to get on and play for England, which Alex believes he has a chance of doing."

The players themselves recognise the problem. Higginbotham's former team-mate Ryan Giggs said recently: "I think something's got to be done. If you ask any player, they'll say the same thing. There's no problem when you're bringing in quality players. But then you've got mediocre players coming in while there are plenty of 18- and 19-year-olds who could do the job."

However, the idea of foreign quotas is unpopular with those who count: the clubs. They like the fact that, in general, foreign players are cheaper. And, as for the managers, the demands on them are for instant success, so they have no time to wait for home-grown youngsters to mature. Scared to chance them in first- team football, managers collude in hindering their development even further. And so the next generation soon becomes the ex-generation.

From an England point of view, who knows what damage has been done to young Higginbotham's international development by being stuck in United's reserves for so long. What now for Alan Smith, the 19-year-old striker at Leeds following the recent signing of Mark Viduka from Celtic? And how, for instance, can England hope to nurture a decent midfield playmaker when the bulk of the creative work in the Premiership is done by foreigners?

Of course there have long been problems getting England to perform, going back years before the foreign invasion hit these shores. To that extent, the enigma that is the England team can be explained only partly by the large number of non-English players in the Premiership.

But, as Keegan earlier acknowledged, the warning signs are there. If the country thinks the England team is bad now, wait until the centre-half comes from Stockport County and the midfield playmaker from Grimsby Town.

fields.bodyText: The potential for Kevin Keegan to throw his toys out of the pram will be tested further today when he is due to face more criticism of his England record from within the Football Association. Today's summer meeting of English football's governing body will hear a number of worried FA councillors voicing their concerns over Keegan's failure in Euro 2000, and in particular his perceived lack of tactical nous. However, Keegan can take some comfort from the fact that FA members do recognise that deeper, underlying factors have contributed to England's embarrassing recent record, and high on their list of suspects is the thorny issue of foreign players. Keegan articulated his worries on this issue when he forecast soon after taking over the national reins that the day may soon come when he has to pick the bulk of his squad from the First Division. So, while recent reports of record foreign investment into Britain pleased the Chancellor of the Exchequer, in football circles great horror greeted the posting of last season's record import figures - a record which, judging by events in the transfer market so far , will not stand for long. At the end of last season there were 170 European Union and 39 non-EU players on the books of the 20 Premiership clubs - that is an average of 10 per club. "It was the most there's ever been and the number seems to be increasing," said a Premier League spokeswoman yes- terday. Chelsea even famously fielded the first all-foreign XI and, though Gianluca Vialli suggested he would buy British this summer - and despite attempts by Fifa and Uefa to get the Bosman ruling modified - Chelsea's outlook, like those of other Premiership clubs, has remained distinctly unpatriotic. Although the summer clearout at relegated Wimbledon has seen Neil Sullivan and, possibly, Ben Thatcher join Spurs and the £7m Carl Cort move to Newcastle, few other home-grown players have needed to trouble their agents about a transfer to the Premiership. The main movers have been foreign: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to Chelsea for £15m, Sergei Rebrov to Spurs for £11m, Olivier Dacourt to Leeds for £7m, Robert Pires and Lauren Mayer to Arsenal for £6m and £7m respectively, Sylvain Wiltord possibly going to Highbury for £15m. And on and on. The victims here are well known: young English talent. On Thursday Manchester United's promising home-grown defender Danny Higginbotham became the latest player to be pushed out of the nest. Aged 21, and fed up with waiting for his chance in the United first team, he has left Old Trafford in search of top- level football and the fulfilment of a potential recognised even by Sir Alex Ferguson. As his new manager Jim Smith of Derby explained: "Danny wants to get on and play for England, which Alex believes he has a chance of doing." The players themselves recognise the problem. Higginbotham's former team-mate Ryan Giggs said recently: "I think something's got to be done. If you ask any player, they'll say the same thing. There's no problem when you're bringing in quality players. But then you've got mediocre players coming in while there are plenty of 18- and 19-year-olds who could do the job." However, the idea of foreign quotas is unpopular with those who count: the clubs. They like the fact that, in general, foreign players are cheaper. And, as for the managers, the demands on them are for instant success, so they have no time to wait for home-grown youngsters to mature. Scared to chance them in first- team football, managers collude in hindering their development even further. And so the next generation soon becomes the ex-generation. From an England point of view, who knows what damage has been done to young Higginbotham's international development by being stuck in United's reserves for so long. What now for Alan Smith, the 19-year-old striker at Leeds following the recent signing of Mark Viduka from Celtic? And how, for instance, can England hope to nurture a decent midfield playmaker when the bulk of the creative work in the Premiership is done by foreigners? Of course there have long been problems getting England to perform, going back years before the foreign invasion hit these shores. To that extent, the enigma that is the England team can be explained only partly by the large number of non-English players in the Premiership. But, as Keegan earlier acknowledged, the warning signs are there. If the country thinks the England team is bad now, wait until the centre-half comes from Stockport County and the midfield playmaker from Grimsby Town. fields.headline: England put success on hold
fields.trailText: English football yesterday virtually gave up all expectation of winning a major international tournament for six years.
fields.body:
English football yesterday virtually gave up all expectation of winning a major international tournament for six years.

After the embarrassment of an early return from Euro 2000, the Football Association appears to be taking the long-term view with a vengeance on curing England's present inadequacies by suggesting that winning the 2002 World Cup and the 2004 European Championship is not a viable option.

Instead the FA chief executive Adam Crozier admitted that England's first realistic target for success was the 2006 World Cup in Germany, ironically the tournament it had hoped to be staging itself.

As Crozier reaffirmed his his backing for Kevin Keegan amid criticism of the coach's tactical naivety, he admitted that England had much to learn from countries such as France, and also stressed the importance of the role that the FA's technical director Howard Wilkinson had to play in any future success.

"There's a lot of hard work to do. On the playing side, we know there is no quick-fix. We have got to look at long-term improvement of our kids' technique, the way they behave and their attitude," he said.

"A bit of realism wouldn't do anyone any harm. Infrastructure sounds like a really boring thing but that is what France have done, they have got their infrastucture in place. France have gone back to basics.

"You have to go and see them, talk to them, learn why they are doing things that way. Howard Wilkinson has done an awful lot of that. He's visited a number of countries, looking at everything they do. He has always said that he felt the time when everything comes absolutely together would be the 2006 World Cup."

Crozier also explained that there was no question of Keegan having offered his resignation. "There wasn't any meeting with Kevin. Kevin did not offer to resign and therefore he did not need to be talked out of it. He was very down but he is getting back up now and beginning to look forward to the challenge ahead.

"Immediately after the tournament he has to protect the people around him but that doesn't mean he hasn't been watching, listening and that he hasn't been thinking about what we can do to get it right."

Keegan's next opportunity is a friendly against France in September which should at least serve to establish a fresh baseline for England's learning curve as they take on the world and European champions.

Meanwhile the FA are to reassess launching a bid to host the second World Club Championship after losing out on the 2006 World Cup. The tournament, in which Manchester United controvsersially took part in January in Brazil, is presently being revamped by Fifa, which now anticipates staging the event every two years in the northern summer, with the next due in June or July 2001.
