webTitle: Arsenal land third boy from Brazil

fields.headline: Arsenal land third boy from Brazil
fields.trailText: Arsenal brought their tally of Brazilians to three yesterday when Sao Paulo announced that their defender Edmilson would be a Highbury player next season. He joins Edu, the 22-year-old midfielder due to arrive in London on Monday, and the full-back Silvinho, who both came from Sao Paulo's neighbours Corinthians.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Arsenal brought their tally of Brazilians to three yesterday when Sao Paulo announced that their defender Edmilson would be a Highbury player next season. He joins Edu, the 22-year-old midfielder due to arrive in London on Monday, and the full-back Silvinho, who both came from Sao Paulo's neighbours Corinthians.

A Sao Paulo spokesman, Jose Dias, said Arsène Wenger had agreed a fee with the club and Edmilson would be travelling to Highbury for a medical and to sign a contract.

"Edmilson is virtually already an Arsenal player," he said. "All he needs to do is sign on the dotted line."

Edmilson, who is 24 on Monday, started his career as a midfielder and as such is a versatile defender who can also play as a right wing-back. The Brazilian press have quoted a fee of $7m (£4.6m).

Edmilson is due to fly to London tomorrow from Sao Paulo but wants to delay his trip because he has received his first call-up for the Brazil squad. He told a local newspaper: "What I'd like to do is to show up for duty on Monday. Arsenal can wait a little." Brazil have two World Cup qualifying games this month.

Meanwhile, the Leicester manager Peter Taylor yesterday snapped up the defender Callum Davidson from Blackburn Rovers for £1.7m. The Scotland international moved south of the border from St Johnstone two years ago but his progress has been hampered by a series of injuries.

"It's a step up coming here and obviously it will help my international career as well," said the 24-year-old full-back.

Manchester City are set to sign the Nigerian international Daniel Amokachi if he impresses in pre-season training with the club. The 27-year-old former Everton striker is available on a Bosman free transfer from the Turkish club Besiktas and is due to join the rest of the City players when they resume training on Monday.

City's Joe Royle managed Amokachi at Everton during his previous spell in England, when he played a leading role in the Merseysiders' successful 1995 FA Cup campaign, but admits he may not have given the Nigerian the opportunity to display his talents to the full.

"I have spoken to him and he assures me of his fitness, though he has had a couple of minor operations recently," said Royle. "He is very keen on the move and we are keen."

Massimo Taibi yesterday ended his troubled tenure at Old Trafford after agreeing a £2.5m deal to join Italy's Reggina. Taibi moved to Manchester United in a £4.5m deal last season but failed to hold down a regular place and was shipped back to Serie A on loan to Reggina.

The Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle has completed the signing of the teenage French striker Patrice Tano from Monaco on a free transfer. Tano, 18 and originally from Ivory Coast, signed a four-year contract after he impressed the former England coach during the Saints' summer training camp in La Manga last month.

The Sheffield Wednesday goalkeeper Pavel Srnicek yesterday turned his back on a move to Napoli in favour of a switch to the Italian side Brescia.

The former Barcelona coach Louis van Gaal was yesterday named the new Dutch national coach, succeeding Frank Rijkaard who resigned last week. "You see before you a very happy person," Van Gaal, who has signed a six-year contract, told reporters. "My ambition is to make this team world champions."

webTitle: Why not put £10m on a clothes horse?

fields.headline: Why not put £10m on a clothes horse?
fields.trailText: The Sun yesterday was in no doubt why England lost out in the bid to host the 2006 World Cup.
fields.body:
The Sun yesterday was in no doubt why England lost out in the bid to host the 2006 World Cup.

It was nothing to do with Tony Banks's gob, nothing to do with allegedly reneging on a gentleman's agreement to back Germany, nothing even to do with Bobby Charlton spinning round the globe accruing enough air miles for a free trip to Pluto while shrewder political wheelers and dealers were cementing deals on the telephone.

No, apparently it was the supermodel Claudia Schiffer wot won it for the Germans. Or more particularly the dress she wore during the final voting session. Cramming more double entendres into one report than could be found in the script for Julian Clary's new stage show, the paper concludes that the "breast bid won".

As a piece of satire, the Sun's report has a point. The voting was conducted with all the rationale of a beauty contest. And given the effectiveness of their approach, the England bid committee might as well have spent their cash hiring Kate Moss to front their presentation wearing the latest England kit.

Quite how £10m could be spent without ever figuring out the best way to manipulate the system is perhaps the biggest joke of the whole bid. At the last, Banks, Charlton and the rest were so far off the pace they might as well have spent £10. They have emerged from over three years of lobbying with the possibility of being the continent's choice the next time the tournament takes place in Europe, an outcome that frankly would have happened had they not even entered the race.

Oh, and they achieved something else. By constantly carping on about security problems in South Africa, they significantly undermined the bid that all right minds believe should have won it.

If the FA is really committed to its new slogan about using football as a force for good in society, that is the most shameful outcome of the whole business.

webTitle: The man who killed an African dream

fields.headline: The man who killed an African dream
fields.standfirst: Oceania delegate defied his own confederation by not voting, writes  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: Charles Dempsey had always been a difficult customer as far as the South Africans were concerned during their three and a half years of campaigning to try to land the World Cup.
fields.body:
Charles Dempsey had always been a difficult customer as far as the South Africans were concerned during their three and a half years of campaigning to try to land the World Cup.

Little did they realise, however, that in doing nothing during the final round of voting in Zurich on Thursday afternoon Dempsey had done so much to damage the progress of African football.

A day before Thursday's executive committee election it became apparent to the South Africans that one vote could prove crucial. Most analysts had predicted a close competition which would probably be decided by the casting vote of Fifa's president, Sepp Blatter, and so Dempsey's vote was more important than ever. In the event the Oceania representative's vote would have ensured a 12-12 tie; Blatter, meanwhile, had already announced his support for South Africa.

South African delegates were aware that, despite instructions from his confederation to vote for them, Dempsey was not keen on seeing the World Cup being staged there. During intense lobbying in the years leading up to the election, Dempsey had proved the most distant and awkward of the 24 Fifa executive committee members.

Before Thursday's vote officials from Oceania were contacted by South African campaigners in an attempt to apply some last-minute pressure on the wavering Dempsey. Oceania officials in Zurich for the vote were also contacted and urged to call Dempsey to reiterate the importance of casting his vote.

Up until 5am on Thursday Dempsey received numerous calls from New Zealand and from fellow Oceania delegates in Zurich. There is not believed to have been any direct contact between South African campaigners and Dempsey in the hours leading up to the vote. Most of the calls he received came from Oceania representatives in New Zealand who kept him up most of the night repeating instructions that he had to vote for South Africa once England were knocked out.

The Oceania decision to back South Africa after England was taken at a meeting in Samoa in May, but doubts continued to linger over whether Dempsey would carry out his duty. Privately, some felt that he was going to back Germany even before the abstention.

Danny Jordaan, the head of South Africa's bid, does not deny that last-minute pressure was applied to Dempsey and concedes that the South Africans were in constant contact with New Zealand, from where most of the telephone lobbying took place. Ironically, Dempsey cited the constant late-night calls and the intense pressure he was under as one of the reasons for his abstention.

But Jordaan said: "To be a Fifa member logically demands that you are able to take pressure at the national level. Pressure is part of the job. We were in touch with the Oceania federation, not just before the election but throughout the campaign."

Relations between Dempsey and the South African campaign deteriorated sometime last year. It is not exactly known why Dempsey was so unenthusiastic about the African bid but he turned down several invitations to visit the country and view first hands its plans for the World Cup. At one stage, Nelson Mandela personally telephoned Dempsey in an attempt to win him over and invite him to the country but this was also rejected.

Dempsey, aged 78, cited his age and failing health as reasons for not being able to visit South Africa. But, as president of Fifa's most far-flung federation, Dempsey is one of the organisation's most travelled members. Over the last three years he has clocked up almost 1m miles on football-related work, but he never made it to South Africa.

Born in Glasgow in 1922, Dempsey emigrated to New Zealand in 1952 where he established a successful construction business. During the second world war he served as a petty officer in the navy.

In Scotland Dempsey played for Milnegavie Amateurs, just outside Glasgow, and he also represented the Royal Navy team in England and West Africa during the war. Prior to emigrating he played briefly for Gillingham.

Dempsey has played a crucial role in the development of football in New Zealand and in the establishment of Oceania, formally recognised by Fifa in 1966. New Zealand's qualification for the 1982 World Cup was seen as Dempsey's ultimate achievement after dedicating years to the game in a country dominated by rugby.

But, despite his impressive track record as an administrator, he will ultimately be remembered as the man who killed the African dream.

During intense lobbying in the years leading up to the election, Dempsey had proved the most distant and awkward of the 24 Fifa executive committee members. Before Thursday's vote officials from Oceania were contacted by South African campaigners in an attempt to apply some last-minute pressure on the wavering Dempsey. Oceania officials in Zurich for the vote were also contacted and urged to call Dempsey to reiterate the importance of casting his vote. Up until 5am on Thursday Dempsey received numerous calls from New Zealand and from fellow Oceania delegates in Zurich. There is not believed to have been any direct contact between South African campaigners and Dempsey in the hours leading up to the vote. Most of the calls he received came from Oceania representatives in New Zealand who kept him up most of the night repeating instructions that he had to vote for South Africa once England were knocked out. The Oceania decision to back South Africa after England was taken at a meeting in Samoa in May, but doubts continued to linger over whether Dempsey would carry out his duty. Privately, some felt that he was going to back Germany even before the abstention. Danny Jordaan, the head of South Africa's bid, does not deny that last-minute pressure was applied to Dempsey and concedes that the South Africans were in constant contact with New Zealand, from where most of the telephone lobbying took place. Ironically, Dempsey cited the constant late-night calls and the intense pressure he was under as one of the reasons for his abstention. But Jordaan said: "To be a Fifa member logically demands that you are able to take pressure at the national level. Pressure is part of the job. We were in touch with the Oceania federation, not just before the election but throughout the campaign." Relations between Dempsey and the South African campaign deteriorated sometime last year. It is not exactly known why Dempsey was so unenthusiastic about the African bid but he turned down several invitations to visit the country and view first hands its plans for the World Cup. At one stage, Nelson Mandela personally telephoned Dempsey in an attempt to win him over and invite him to the country but this was also rejected. Dempsey, aged 78, cited his age and failing health as reasons for not being able to visit South Africa. But, as president of Fifa's most far-flung federation, Dempsey is one of the organisation's most travelled members. Over the last three years he has clocked up almost 1m miles on football-related work, but he never made it to South Africa. Born in Glasgow in 1922, Dempsey emigrated to New Zealand in 1952 where he established a successful construction business. During the second world war he served as a petty officer in the navy. In Scotland Dempsey played for Milnegavie Amateurs, just outside Glasgow, and he also represented the Royal Navy team in England and West Africa during the war. Prior to emigrating he played briefly for Gillingham. Dempsey has played a crucial role in the development of football in New Zealand and in the establishment of Oceania, formally recognised by Fifa in 1966. New Zealand's qualification for the 1982 World Cup was seen as Dempsey's ultimate achievement after dedicating years to the game in a country dominated by rugby. But, despite his impressive track record as an administrator, he will ultimately be remembered as the man who killed the African dream.

fields.headline: Mulberry Tree, Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort applauds the less-is-more philosophy of Lancashire's Mulberry Tree
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort applauds the less-is-more philosophy of Lancashire's Mulberry Tree
fields.body:
Address: Mulberry Tree, Lancashire
There used to be a very useful section in, I think, the old Egon Ronay Guide (it may have even been a complete guide to itself) devoted to good-value eateries within 10 minutes or so of any motorway. Given the total failure of service-station catering facilities to produce stuff (the word food is too precise to use in this context) that is anything other than utterly disgusting and outrageously priced, the need for such a guide remains as imperative as ever. But would we make use of it?

There's something about driving along motorways that saps the intelligence and drains away all energy. It took a colossal effort of will to turn off the M6 at exit 27, turn right at the first roundabout, continue for another three miles, keeping an eye peeled for the sign of the Mulberry Tree. Should you do so, too, however, you will find the minimal effort amply rewarded - with the emphasis both on the amplitude as well as on the reward.

There is something so instantly, utterly, distinctively Lancastrian about the whole enterprise. It breathes a jolly generosity mixed with confident commercial instinct. Refined it is not. Designer-driven it is not. A little bit brash it may be. But warm, and well-run, well-priced and well-aimed it undoubtedly is. The large ground-floor area is sort of open-plan, with cream-and-white walls, fake beams, the odd strip of anaglypta and mulberry-tree motif carpet. During the week, it has a bar menu, with proper dishes as well as sandwiches ranging from £3.50 to £8.95, and on Sunday it does the full lunch and dinner effort, with one course for £9, two for £12 and three for £15. I don't suppose that I have to tell you that I had three courses.

One of the reasons that I was keen to give the Mulberry Tree a go was the fact that it is the latest port of call of Mark Prescott, who once graced the kitchens of Le Gavroche, and then took the White Hart at Nayland, Suffolk, to culinary heights as one of the early gastro-pubs. He is a cook with pedigree and gravitas, who has opted for the relaxed and informal cheer of the pub over the demands of fine dining. Aside from that, he is a Lancastrian to boot.

I must admit that I find the combination of classically-trained skills applied to the simpler, more immediate demands of pub food tremendously appealing. It is interesting how many of our best and brightest chefs are finding the rewards of upgrading the standards of pub food preferable to hacking it in the torture chambers that are aiming for the stars. The general eating public is the beneficiary of this culinary vision.

The Sunday menu at the Mulberry Tree runs through a good many standards of modern cookery. There are Thai fishcakes and chicken-liver parfaits, confits of duck and rib-eye steaks. More interestingly, there was a white-onion soup with tarragon cream, a breast of chicken tikka massala, steak-and-kidney pudding, and a boneless saddle of lamb stuffed with spinach.

Dining alone, and scarcely recovered from lunch with some too, too hospitable friends, I made one of my rare sallies into the world of soups, but followed this up with slow-roasted belly-pork with spiced apple from the day's specials, and settled down to nougat glacé with raspberry coulis at the end. This is where the superior skills pay off in the pub context. The white-onion soup was faultless, smooth as velvet, delicate and mild, with a froth of tarragon cream pointing up the haunting sweetness of white onion. The belly-pork had been slow-roasted to unctuous, fibrous softness (which, unfortunately, extended to the crackling). The apple, lodged as a layer under the crackling, was suitably tart and breathily spicy. The potent, mahogany-brown gravy and mixed veg gave the whole plate a bit of the Sunday-lunch-at-home feel, and there was no need for seconds. The nougat glacé was marvellously nutty, if a little sweet for my taste.

There is tolerable beer, but I was drawn to a bottle of one of the nouvelle vague Viogniers at an undemonstrative £14.50 (I drank only two glasses - some readers take a kindly interest in my health, not to mention my postprandial driving abilities) from a very interesting and amiably-priced list. My notes at the time summarised the Mulberry Tree as follows: "You can eat lots for little. Tasty, too. A good place; and only 5 mins from the Mway." On reflection, that's just about bang on.

webTitle: Film director Lee spikes Patriot's guns

fields.headline: Film director Lee spikes Patriot's guns
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Spike Lee, America's best-known and most outspoken black film director, has accused the makers of The Patriot, a film about the fight for American independence, of producing a criminally distorted view of history. He has attacked the film for ignoring the issues of slavery and mocked its finale as "laughable".
fields.body:
Spike Lee, America's best-known and most outspoken black film director, has accused the makers of The Patriot, a film about the fight for American independence, of producing a criminally distorted view of history. He has attacked the film for ignoring the issues of slavery and mocked its finale as "laughable".

Lee's broadside against the film which stars Mel Gibson and opened in the United States for the July 4 weekend came in the form of an angry letter to the Hollywood Reporter, the entertainment industry's daily. He said that he and his wife had gone to see the film and that he had come out of the cinema "fuming" after having to hold himself back from shouting at the screen.

He wrote that the founding fathers George Washington and Thomas Jefferson owned numerous slaves yet Mel Gibson's character apparently was not a slaveholder. He called the film "pure, blatant American Hollywood propaganda".

Lee, the director of Malcolm X, Do the Right Thing and Jungle Fever among many others, has often attacked the Hollywood ethos of film-making but rarely in such a specific way. Some feel he has suffered for his plain-speaking by being overlooked for film honours despite high praise for Malcolm X.

"When talking about the history of this great country," he wrote, "one can never forget that America was built upon the genocide of the Native Americans and the enslavement of African people. To say otherwise is criminal.

"DW Griffith was a racist and Leni Riefenstahl a 'so-called reformed Nazi' but the Birth of a Nation and Triumph of the Will were made by great film-makers. To have Gibson's character doing a one-man Iwo Jima broken-field run through the 'Nazi'-like British with the 13-star American flag held high is laughable." (Earlier this year, the prestigious director's prize named after DW Griffith had its name changed because of his racist views and the fact that the Birth of A Nation had acted as a recruiting agent for the Ku Klux Klan.)

Lee said that he kept wondering where the slaves were and who was picking the cotton. "Where were the Native Americans? Did the two Johns - Ford and Wayne - wipe them out already? Why have the film critics ignored this in their reviews?"

While the film has attracted some criticism for the way in which most of the Britons are portrayed as sadistic child-killers while the American militiamen are largely saintly, as well as for the violence which involves children using guns on the British troops, Lee's attack is the first from a leading figure in the industry. It follows attacks from the United Kingdom about the way the history of the second world war is gradually being rewritten to give Americans a more prominent role in key events.

The Patriot, which has won many critical plaudits for the British actor Jason Isaacs as a magnificently amoral British commander, has done reasonably well in its first week although it was somewhat swamped by the opening over the same weekend of The Perfect Storm, which realistically recreates a true story of fishermen caught at sea.

fields.headline: Titanic costume suppliers found murdered
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The mother and daughter team who provided the costumes for the film Titanic have been found murdered at their homes in Virginia. The daughter's estranged husband has been arrested.
fields.body:
The mother and daughter team who provided the costumes for the film Titanic have been found murdered at their homes in Virginia. The daughter's estranged husband has been arrested.

Suzanne Arena, 79, and her daughter, Susan Varner, 50, were both found apparently bludgeoned to death in their respective homes in Cumberland county and Prince Edward county.

Police later arrested Reginald Varner, 53, after his car was stopped for speeding. A police officer noted that Mr Varner was covered in blood and had an axe in the car beside him. He was divorced from Susan in 1998 after 20 years of marriage. Mr Varner was held without bail and will appear in court on Monday.

The mother and daughter team supplied the black-beaded dress that Kate Winslet wore in the film. Titanic won an Oscar in 1998 for best costumes. The pair also supplied costumes to the country music stars Johnny Cash and his wife June Carter.

webTitle: Prep head's case goes to appeal

fields.headline: Prep head's case goes to appeal
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The case of the former prep school headmaster Robin Peverett, who last month admitted a series of indecent assaults on former pupils, is to be referred to the court of appeal following widespread concern that his sentence was too light, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The case of the former prep school headmaster Robin Peverett, who last month admitted a series of indecent assaults on former pupils, is to be referred to the court of appeal following widespread concern that his sentence was too light, it emerged yesterday.

Peverett, 66, of Battle, East Sussex, was given an 18-month suspended sentence after pleading guilty to nine counts of indecent assault on seven pupils aged 11 to 13 between 1969 and 1978, while he was headmaster at Dulwich college preparatory school in Cranbrook, Kent. A further seven charges remain on the file.

A spokesman for the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn QC, confirmed that he had referred the case, first heard at Maidstone crown court, to the appeal court for review as "an unduly lenient sentence".

The maximum sentence for indecent assault is 10 years.

Peverett, who received an OBE for his services to education, was an adviser to the Thatcher government.

fields.headline: Students at a premium
fields.standfirst:
The Greenaway report's logic looks shaky

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leader: No wonder the Committee of Vice Chancellors (CVCP) was back-pedalling energetically yesterday away from a report advocating market freedom for universities. The so-called Russell group which commissioned it threatens the existence of the single voice for higher education the CVCP aspires to be.
fields.body:
No wonder the Committee of Vice Chancellors (CVCP) was back-pedalling energetically yesterday away from a report advocating market freedom for universities. The so-called Russell group which commissioned it threatens the existence of the single voice for higher education the CVCP aspires to be. The report's ideas - fees set by universities ad lib, to be repaid out of unsubsidised loans - are far from new. Their radicalism (what the CVCP and government fear most) lies in throwing open the question of what the modern university exists to do. Is it a social service organisation, needed to generate and transmit knowledge in a society which makes an ever larger share of its living from the selfsame knowledge? If so, the university must in some measure be a public body, paid for directly or indirectly by government under state supervision. If, alternatively, university purposes are private and less functional, then the flag of independence raised by the Greenaway report deserves saluting.

The university debate is, unfortunately, clouded by false analogies with the US. Harvard is far from representative of higher education in that country. The portrayal of the Ivy League as "socially inclusive" is hard to accept. Recent studies of allegedly meritocratic scholastic assessment procedures are evidence for the prosecution. Greenaway mixes a naive faith that Nottingham could be turned into a Midlands Yale with some odd English logic. Somehow, it is suggested, full-cost university education need not exclude poorer students. A sudden outbreak of campus philanthropy will see us through.

The Blair government, like its predecessor, wants to maximise access at minimum cost. Unless more money is found from business, students or their parents, there will be casualties. One is the comfort and spaciousness English undergraduates used to enjoy. Other, different arguments apply to paying for postgraduates and research. On the latter, dubious arguments are often trotted out. American university research, buoyed by business and Big Defense, is scarcely "freer" than in the UK. Meanwhile, academics have a strong case for pay improvements, to which Gordon Brown would be wise to attend. The balance of investment between the UK's "international" universities and the rest needs constant attention. But a persuasive case for the market to set student fees has not yet been made.

webTitle: Harry Potter's secrets finally revealed at the witching hour

fields.headline: Harry Potter's secrets finally revealed at the witching hour
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter website
fields.trailText: As the clock struck midnight, the overexcited "muggles" smiled with glee. They had it. The new Harry Potter. Hyped as the publishing event of the century, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire was snapped up by children and adults as soon as it hit the shops.
fields.body:
As the clock struck midnight, the overexcited "muggles" smiled with glee. They had it. The new Harry Potter. Hyped as the publishing event of the century, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire was snapped up by children and adults as soon as it hit the shops.

The muggles - Potter language for a normal mortal, as opposed to someone with magic powers - queued at bookshops or attended special sleepover parties to get their hands on the fourth book in the phenomenally successful series about a boy wizard.

Others lingered near the letterbox waiting for the arrival of the 640-page book by mail after preordering it on the web. Amazon, the internet bookseller, sold 400,000 copies of the book. Staff at the company's distribution centre in Milton Keynes worked through the night to ensure that copies were posted out yesterday. The company estimates that it will be supplying a copy of the book to one in every 150 children between five and 14 in the UK and says it will send 53 tonnes, or 41.6m pages, of the book to British readers.

Some stores did not open at midnight, arguing that this was not a time for children to be up. A spokesperson for WH Smith said its shops would not open in the middle of the night but the opening hour this morning was at the individual store manager's discretion. She said: "We have got an ethical issue with children being up at that time of night."

The stores would, like most others, be holding events throughout today - wizards, magicians and face painters are in big demand. This morning at 11.27am a steam train will leave Kings Cross station bound for the Hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry. The train, decked out as the Hogwarts Express, will actually take the book's author, JK Rowling, on a book tour which will end up in Scotland.

Ms Rowling, who earned £14.5m last year in royalties, advances and film rights, plans to write seven books in the series and plotted each of the stories before writing the first book. In an interview in today's Guardian, she said she really would make the seventh the last Harry book but she would most likely go on writing. She said: "Yes, I'll still write. But I really mean this. I think it's quite possible that I'll finish Harry and go to the filing cabinet where the notes are and think it's rubbish."

The plot of the new book has remained a closely guarded secret, with Ms Rowling only revealing that someone very close to Harry dies.

It was not all good news for the Edinburgh-based author yesterday. Shortlisted for the Library Association's Carnegie Medal, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban was not even commended by the judges. The prize went to Postcards From No Man's Land by Aidan Chambers, a book which deals with real-life issues such as adultery, euthanasia and homosexuality.

The book weaves together the story of 17-year-old Jacob's experiences in modern day Amsterdam and the experiences of a dying Dutch woman, Geertrui, who recalls her love for a married English soldier during the second world war, examining the values of the two eras.

The prize went to Postcards From No Man's Land by Aidan Chambers, a book which deals with real-life issues such as adultery, euthanasia and homosexuality. The book weaves together the story of 17-year-old Jacob's experiences in modern day Amsterdam and the experiences of a dying Dutch woman, Geertrui, who recalls her love for a married English soldier during the second world war, examining the values of the two eras.

fields.headline: Farewell to Alain de Botton
fields.trailText: • So, we bid a fond farewell to Alain de Botton, who has vowed to forsake the dirty world of journalism to spend more time with his books. Not to mention, of course, taking walks with his "long-suffering girlfriend" and putting up the odd shelf. His moving adieu to Grub Street came in last week's Independent on Sunday, although eager browsers would have found him on fine form both in the Sunday Telegraph (reviewing a biography of Proust) and in the Sunday Times (recommending books for your summer hols). Turn to the Spectator, and A de B gives us his thoughts on Richard Holmes's new book. We must assume that retirement began this Monday - but the Loafer will award anyone spotting him in print henceforth with a bottle of bubbly.

 So, we bid a fond farewell to Alain de Botton, who has vowed to forsake the dirty world of journalism to spend more time with his books. Not to mention, of course, taking walks with his "long-suffering girlfriend" and putting up the odd shelf. His moving adieu to Grub Street came in last week's Independent on Sunday, although eager browsers would have found him on fine form both in the Sunday Telegraph (reviewing a biography of Proust) and in the Sunday Times (recommending books for your summer hols). Turn to the Spectator, and A de B gives us his thoughts on Richard Holmes's new book. We must assume that retirement began this Monday - but the Loafer will award anyone spotting him in print henceforth with a bottle of bubbly.

 At least if de Botton gets lonely in his brown study, he can comfort himself with his appearance, also in the Spectator, on Paul Johnson's list of the "cleverest mind-performers in Britain today", alongside Richard Dawkins, Roger Scruton, Germaine Greer and Noel Malcolm. No, honestly. It's a question of being damned with faint praise, however, as Johnson's weighty pronouncement is that clever is not what it used to be. All told, our man gets off quite lightly beside David Starkey ("intellectual pygmy" compared to AJP Taylor), Martin Amis and Jeanette Winterson. This decline in intellectual prowess is, apparently, something to do with not knowing poetry off by heart. Johnson, whom the Loafer recently spotted at the Times Literary Supplement annual bash unable to remember where he put his cloakroom ticket, omits himself from the great reckoning.

 Not content with firing one of their most popular managers and keeping publishers' reps firmly at bay, Waterstone's are finding ever more ingenious ways to make themselves unpopular. Their Worcester branch is currently attempting to put the mockers on a new Hammicks opening in the town by accepting their rival's specially produced quid-off vouchers in their own store. Hammicks, however, have decided to see the manoeuvre as welcome free advertising. Waterstone's maintain they are just being "cheeky". Neither shop appears, at first glance, on the mammoth Bloomsbury itinerary that kicks off today - publication day, as if you needed reminding, of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.

fields.headline: Prophet at the margins
fields.standfirst: He was born in Jamaica to a family whose aspirations to white Englishness contributed to his sister's                                                 breakdown. Maya Jaggi reports on the black icon who predicted the rise of Thatcher and now warns of hard                                                 times ahead
fields.trailText: He was born in Jamaica to a family whose aspirations to white Englishness contributed to his sister's breakdown. After Oxford he became a renowned leftist thinker on race, culture and Britain's postcolonial traumas. Maya Jaggi reports on the black icon who predicted the rise of Thatcher and now warns of hard times ahead
fields.body:
A decade ago, while Stuart Hall was teaching at the Open University, he began to be inundated with tempting offers of lucrative chairs at US universities. But the professor, a beacon of inspirational mentoring on TV in the small hours, chose to stay in Britain.

"From the Caribbean to England is one huge cultural gulf; did I really feel like crossing another?" he says. "America is an imperial culture now; it's what Rome must have felt like, or England in the 19th century. But I feel better taking a sighting on the world from the periphery than the centre."

Hall's sightings from the peripheries of colonial Jamaica, which he left almost 50 years ago, nascent black Britain and an England in post-imperial decline have not only helped to redefine the relationship of culture to power but to rewrite what he calls "the margins into the centre, the outside into the inside", in a "more global version of our island story".

He challenges others, as he did the culture secretary, Chris Smith, at an Arts Council discussion of "heritage" last November, to re-imagine Britishness or Englishness itself "in a more profoundly inclusive manner".

Harvard's head of African-American studies, Henry Louis Gates, named Hall in the New Yorker as "black Britain's leading theorist of black Britain". But Hall, an icon for black British artists and intellectuals over 35 years, not only traces Britain's transformation by post-war migrants, but tilts at myths about the society into which they came.

Questioning both the idea of a single way of being black, and of a fixed, white "majority culture", he holds up a different mirror to that envisioned by many Britons, black and white.

"Britain is not homogeneous; it never was a society without conflict," he says. "The English fought tooth and nail over everything we know of as the English political virtues - rule of law, free speech, the franchise. The very notion of Great Britain's 'greatness' is bound up with empire. Euroscepticism and Little Englander nationalism could hardly survive if people understood whose sugar has flowed through English blood and rotted English teeth. They are us and we are them. This never was a tiny, self-sufficient island."

Retired from the Open University in 1997, and now an emeritus professor, Hall sits on the Runnymede Trust's commission on the future of multi-ethnic Britain, which reports this autumn. "One of the most important debates over the last 20 years has been what does it mean to be English, and the relationship to declining imperial power: what it is to have been master of the world, and now second-rate, underpins so many social events - from the Falklands to football hooliganism."

At 68, arthritis doesn't seem to have diminished Hall's energy, whether "conversing" with his grandson Noah, who is nearly two, or leading the way to his attic study in West Hampstead with the aid of a stick. His agile mental leaps and easy laughter reveal a love of conversation.

He receives a tribute later this month in a book of essays, Without Guarantees, edited by Paul Gilroy, Angela McRobbie - both former students - and Lawrence Grossberg. It is a mark of his influence that its contributors span the globe, from Australia and Italy to Mexico and Taiwan. While his own writings are diffuse - collaborative or found in copiously reprinted nuggets - Hall relishes his role as an "enabler" of others' work.

His interests in cultural identity, race and ethnicity have come increasingly to the fore, but he was a pioneer of both Britain's new left in the 50s and the pathbreaking academic field of cultural studies that grew from it and is now burgeoning yet beleaguered, mocked for its meld of high theory and "low" culture - "Gramsci meets Coronation Street", as one cynic put it.

Yet, today's "commonsense" recognition of the power of television and tabloids owes much to Hall. His lifelong insistence that institutions have their own cultures is enshrined in the notion of institutional racism in the Macpherson report, which came out of the inquiry into the killing of Stephen Lawrence.

Hall was born in 1932 in Kingston, Jamaica, the youngest of three children. His father, Herman, was a scholarship boy who joined the United Fruit Company and became chief accountant. Hall says, "His family were respectable 'brown Jamaicans' from a lower-middle-class village, and he was upwardly mobile."

In what Hall sees as "pre-independence recruitment of the cleverest local boys", Herman was the first "coloured" Jamaican to be promoted to every post he held. Hall's mother, Jessie, "was from a completely different class fraction; only two generations from some white forebears". Her family lacked "the money to go with their status" so she was adopted by a lawyer uncle and moved to a big house in Port Antonio (now owned by Eartha Kitt) with a "palm-fringed drive by the sea".

"This gave her peculiar airs and graces as the adopted daughter of a landowner, whereas my father was more an aspiring local boy. It was a continuous source of tension in our family. He could never earn enough to guarantee her the status she thought she deserved."

Hall remembers being a "depressed adolescent": "The family aspirations were oriented towards England; my mother felt she was all but white. We were to aspire upwards, and have little to do with brown - or certainly black - Jamaicans." But Hall was formed by a Jamaica already moving into independence.

He squirmed as his father was patronised by white people, and by brown people earning more than him, "and he didn't know it". He chose his own friends. "My mother was an extraordinarily powerful person; she devoured us. But she said she had most respect for me because I fought her."

Hall, the rebel, was also the "blackest member" of his family, greeted by his sister, Patricia, at birth as a "coolie baby".

"I would never have named colour but I was aware of it all my life; Jamaican society was finely graded by colour. I was different, an interloper, and I must have internalised this. I felt as if I were a kind of stranger in my own family."

When he was 17 his sister had a nervous breakdown after the family barred her incipient relationship with a medical student from Barbados who was "middle-class but black".

She was given electric shock treatment, from which Hall says she never recovered. It left him with a sense of helplessness and guilt. "My sister kept washing her hands; she's still like that in her 70s. The psychic guilt was transposed into a physical sensation. I pieced the story together: it's what the family's done to her, but I couldn't make her angry about it. She looked after our father and mother till they died, then my brother George, who went blind, till he died. She never left home, and never had another relationship."

Hall sees the trauma of witnessing colonial aspirations "break" his sister as seminal in his belief that social structures are lived through the psyche, through emotions and cultural identifications.

"Later, when I read RD Laing about psychological disorder as a cultural system - one person takes on the dysfunction of a whole society - it all fell into place. It crystallised my feelings about not fitting in. At that point I left home. I said, if you get drawn back into the family, you'll be eaten alive." In 1951 Hall voyaged with his mother to Bristol, clad in a "brown felt hat and overcoat", and thence to Oxford, "the motor that creates Englishness".

His first impression of the landscape he knew from literature was that "I'd seen it before in some other life". But it was three years after the Empire Windrush had disgorged its cargo of West Indian immigrants, and in the streets of Paddington that first "terribly grey and gloomy" August day, he remembers "groups of black men in hats, who weren't students but working people, and women in their finery, dressed up to travel".

A Rhodes scholar in English, he survived the shock of Oxford's medieval gloom by befriending Americans and other West Indians, "huddled together to make sense of England".

He played jazz piano with a group including two Jamaican bus drivers, and, as the Bajan writer George Lamming put it, "became West Indian" in Britain, saturating himself in anti-colonial politics with diverse islanders - though he recalls one aloof Trinidadian contemporary, VS Naipaul, who "wasn't interested in affirming a West Indian consciousness; he was on different tracks".

As a postgraduate scholar Hall became involved with an anti-Stalinist, independent left. He argued with orthodox Marxists for reducing culture to "a decorative addendum to the 'hard world' of production and things".

He says: "I was never attracted to join the Communist party. I had a debate with [the late historian] Raphael Samuel about class which we had for the rest of his life; the old class system no longer explained a time of modern, consumer-oriented capitalism."

In 1956, when Britain invaded Suez and Soviet tanks rolled into Hungary, "it crystallised what we were saying about imperialism not being finished, and the Soviet Union being a totalitarian power. We were against both." The pro-Soviet communists crumbled, and Hall became a founding editor of what would be New Left Review.

"It was the beginning of the new left, which was interested in rising consumerism, Britain looking more like the US, the coming of mass culture and television - and whether it was changing the working class. People identified it with classically English figures: Edward Thompson, Raymond Williams - though he was Welsh. But looking back, our orientation was driven by voices that didn't quite fit in: foreigners from Sudan, Syria, west Africa, the West Indies, Jewish or provincial, Scottish, Irish."

Hall had abandoned his thesis on Henry James, and worked as a supply teacher in Brixton, south London. Michael Rustin, who became his brother-in-law and co-edits Soundings magazine with him, recalls "an air of excitement with the coming together of the old left and a younger generation where everything was being connected up: there was cinema, with Lindsay Anderson and Karel Reisz, and radical theatre, with Arnold Wesker".

Hall says: "I'd always gone to the movies as a child; I saw every 40s melodrama, every Bogart and Bette Davis. I became interested in the impact of television, new mass magazines, teenage culture."

After editing New Left Review for two years, he left in 1961 to teach film and allied media ("no one would dare put television in the title") at Chelsea College, and remembers lecturing on westerns in Wandsworth prison ("It was a riot, I loved it"). He did research for the British Film Institute on how to teach popular culture, co-writing the innovative book The Popular Arts (1964).

When Richard Hoggart founded the Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies at Birmingham University in 1964, he invited Hall to be its research fellow. Hoggart describes Hall as one of the best lecturers in England and an extraordinarily charismatic personality - "he has a brilliant theoretic mind".

After Hoggart went to Unesco in 1968, Hall took over as director, staying till 1979, when he left to be sociology professor of the Open University. They were "heady days", Hall recalls. "We made the curriculum up. It was the inauguration of, not a discipline, but a field of inquiry that, unlike fine art, is interested in how culture organises everyday life.

It was a very creative moment." Noting the backlash from older disciplines, he concedes with a laugh: "There is a ferocious amount of crap written in any field." But he adds: "The way in which culture organises social practice has come to be seen as crucial."

Hoggart's Uses Of Literacy (1957) was a pillar, along with the work of Raymond Williams and EP Thompson. Yet relatively ignored by the founding triumvirate was mass migration - which Hall has called "the world historical event of late modernity".

Paul Gilroy, professor of African-American studies and sociology at Yale, says: "Stuart was the fourth figure; his postcolonial formation and experience of migrancy, and his attention to race, gave the critical understanding of the workings of England a very different slant."

Hall had met his wife-to-be, Catherine Barrett - now a social historian - on a CND march at Aldermaston: 13 years his junior, she was beginning a degree at Sussex. They married in 1964, and she transferred to Birmingham, where they went on to have two children: Rebecca, now doing a PhD on the "mulatto" in English fiction, and Jess, a cameraman. But the newly-weds arrived in the midst of the Smethwick by- election, when the Tory candidate unseated a minister with the slogan: "If you want a nigger neighbour vote Labour."

Hall says: "Catherine and I, a mixed-race couple, were looking for cheap accommodation; it was a very unpleasant experience. I was aware of the bubbling up of race into politics. There were problems of housing, racial discrimination, policing, the 'sus' laws; a second generation feeling they neither belonged in England nor anywhere else; the influence of reggae and Rastafarianism. It was impossible to be active and alive in Birmingham without being drawn into all that."

One seminal study arose from the "moral panic" over street crime, when three teenagers - one of whom was black - were given 10-year sentences for robbery. "It triggered and was fed by wider fears - the youth revolution of the 60s and that Britain was being fundamentally changed by the presence of black people. It tapped into a long-term sense of decline. That's where we discover the question of Englishness as the central problem underlying British politics.

I thought if some politician decided to speak to these unspoken fantasies and fears in a popular language, you'd have a major swing." It took until the late 70s for that politician to emerge. Policing The Crisis, co-written by Hall, was published in 1978, the year before Margaret Thatcher came to power. The book is widely seen as prescient about the drift into a "law and order society" and the advent of Thatcherism - what Hall came to call "authoritarian populism" - and its promise to put the "great" back into Britain.

He wrote: "Blacks become the bearers, the signifiers of the crisis of British society in the 1970s... the means by which the crisis is to be resolved - send it away." He feels the threat remains. "That's what Hague is searching for - the remaining shoots of that feeling, which feeds Euroscepticism and the fear of asylum-seekers."

Hall was accused of overplaying the ideological nature of Thatcherism. He responds: "Look at politics now. The left was restructured from below by a cultural shift; it wasn't just economics. I feel real aggression about political commentators who poured scorn on the notion of a cultural shift governing politics, who said Thatcherism was a blip. Most would accept now that Thatcherism, and its embrace of neo-liberalism, was a watershed."

New Times, the political movement Hall espoused with Martin Jacques and others in Marxism Today in the late 80s and early 90s, was attacked for learning too much from its opponents, not least in its embrace of consumerism. One of Hall's most per sistent critics, A Sivanandan of the Institute of Race Relations, called it "Thatcherism in drag".

Hall says: "It came out of impatience with the old left thinking it could take a stand on traditional working-class values when the right was making the running in its 'heartlands'. But it was a call to match the depth of ambition of change Thatcher tried to bring about, but from a different direction."

Hall, who sees the Blair government as "a historic opportunity lost", criticised New Labour on the eve of its election in 1997. "Tony Blair swallowed the message but forgot the tune," he says. Describing himself as an "egalitarian moderniser", he adds: "I've been a kind of socialist all my life, but not what people would call a revolutionary. I've always been suspicious of the dream of remaking society in an instant.

I'm interested in deep change, but I don't think intellectual work should be short-changed to prove a political point. To point towards complexity, ambiguity, unexpected consequences - that's intellectual vocation."

At Birmingham, teachers and postgraduates worked together in a "hothouse atmosphere", radically rethinking the field by taking into account feminism or race politics. Angela McRobbie, now professor of communications at Goldsmith's College, London, says: "Stuart was a figurehead who let you get on with it.

He challenged the relations of power in academic life." Hall, though, has cited successive "crises" with each intake of students, and feminists' "dawn raids", as among his reasons for leaving in 1979.

"I lived with a feminist," he says. "Catherine became involved in the new feminist movement, especially moving from active academic life to isolation at home with two children. We were anxious that feminist work be done at the centre, but that's different from rethinking cultural studies from a feminist viewpoint. We were three men - 'the bosses'.

It drove me wild to be placed in that false position." McRobbie says: "I was surprised Stuart seemed as hurt as he was. My memories were that everybody was in the firing line, but he felt he was being set up as a patriarch." The Open University seemed a natural home.

"My instincts were towards widening access to adult education. Birmingham was an intellectual elite, whereas the average age at the OU was 40, people who'd not been in a classroom since 16. It was an intellectual challenge."

A colleague, David Held, now politics professor at the LSE, says: "Stuart's an engaged public intellectual of a kind celebrated in Europe but of which the English are wrongly sceptical; a great communicator who shines on television and radio." Hall has not only taught media, but made astute use of it - from his BBC series on the Caribbean, Redemption Song, in the early 90s, to his relaxed eloquence on Radio 4's Desert Island Discs in February.

He dissected how black people are represented on TV in It Ain't Half Racist, Mum - shown as a BBC 2 Open Door programme in 1979 - and Black And White In Colour, and his influence has grown on both sides of the Atlantic. Hall told a gathering of the Caribbean Artists Movement in 1968:

"The task of any intellectual and any writer in relation to [the next generations of West Indians in Britain] is to help them see, clarify, speak, understand and name the process that they're going through."

He believes that "cultural identity is not fixed, it's always hybrid [but] it comes out of a very specific historical formation", and he was possibly the first to appreciate the emerging hybrid identities of postwar Britain. He found a model in Caribbean culture: "Was it true West Indians had an identity crisis - neither European nor African in a 'pure' sense? I've written about the syncretism and creolisation of Caribbean culture all my life." For him, black communities are not some "ethnic minority culture" apart, but "in touch with their differences without being saturated by tradition; they are actively involved with every aspect of life around them, without the illusion of assimilation".

Gilane Tawadros, director of London's International Institute of Visual Arts (InIVA), which Hall chairs, says: "Stuart has an extraordinary ability to articulate the experiences of first, second and third-generation black Britons, their complexities and dynamism. He understood early on that you can't look at them as isolated in the 'margins' but part of a global diaspora, and that their presence was not just a challenge to Britain but created a new kind of Britishness that's internationally celebrated."

His ideas threw a lifeline to young artists. Tawadros adds: "At a time when art institutions were trying to bottle up what it meant to be black British or Asian British, when artists were frustrated at having to describe their work in terms of its 'Africanness' or 'Asianness', Stuart said that that experience, and its artistic expression, are more ambivalent; they draw on many things. He paved the way for the confidence of a new generation of artists, including Chris Ofili and Steve McQueen."

Hall took an early interest in diasporic artists in London, such as Ronald Moody, Aubrey Williams and Francis Souza, who he says have been "quietly written out of the record; not British enough for the Tate, not interna tional enough for Bankside". But he found growing affinities, and collaborated, with a younger generation, including the film makers Isaac Julien, John Akomfrah and Martina Attille; the visual artists Keith Piper and Sonia Boyce; and the photographers Mark Sealy, David A Bailey, Sunil Gupta and Ingrid Pollard.

"In the 80s black artists became preoccupied with identity, self-portraits, putting their own body in the frame," says Hall. "I was writing about identity and they were practising it. Racism is not just in the streets, it's written into how people recognise themselves. It made me more alert to the way artistic work is exploratory space in which ideas work themselves out. It brought me in touch with a huge creative explosion in literature, art, film."

In an influential talk at London's ICA in 1989, Hall insisted "blackness", far from being fixed in nature, was "politically and culturally constructed" - partly through unconscious desire, fantasy and memory. The same went for "whiteness": "We are all ethnically located." He was criticised for accepting the fracturing of a politically united black front. He says: "There is a danger of locking into ethnic enclaves, but also the possibility of making common cause. I'm interested in a politics that makes links without ignoring difference."

His stand is credited with freeing artists to speak from, but not for, black experiences, and giving crucial impetus to developing art criticism. Kobena Mercer, of New York University, says: "Stuart said films weren't good just because black people made them. It contributed to a culture of debate, not just celebration."

Hall is a voice cautioning against an "easy, celebratory spirit", warning instead of "hard, perhaps iron times to come". In his view, Britain is at a crossroads, marked by the 1998 Windrush celebrations and the pathologies exposed by the 1999 Macpherson report. What he calls multicultural drift - "the explosion of cultural diversity and difference which is our lived daily reality" - is no guarantee of peace or justice without the political will to see it through.

"Is Britain going to accept its diversity and become more humane? We don't yet know," he says. "Yes, things are better in some ways, but a lot of people feel left out. The five boys in the Stephen Lawrence case didn't have an O-level between them. People like them are not in the dot.com revolution. The only time they feel English is when they can kick shit out of the Dutch or the Belgians.

If you're serious about a multicultural society, you would address the sense of alienation of white working-class people, who have to be won to a new conception of themselves where Britain's not lording it from a gunboat." "I don't think identity's fixed, the real, true self," he reflects. "It's constructed from historical processes: I'm the sum of that boy called a 'coolie', the Rhodes scholar, the socialist from Jamaica. Every identity that feels so solid is the result of excluding things you could have been. I go back to Jamaica and adore it, but I couldn't be a Jamaican. I ache for a parallel life I could have lived. I also couldn't disappear into Englishness. I understand Britain; but I'm only British in a hyphenated way."

Hall feels a sense of homecoming - but never a settled one. "I never called myself black because no one in the Caribbean did then. I've come home to an identity I was never allowed to settle for; discovering I've become something I was all the time: a black intellectual, a migrant... People who are 68 should feel the ground solid under their feet. But I'm not surprised it feels shifting; it's the diasporic fate. More and more people feel life in this way."
