In what Hall sees as "pre-independence recruitment of the cleverest local boys", Herman was the first "coloured" Jamaican to be promoted to every post he held. Hall's mother, Jessie, "was from a completely different class fraction; only two generations from some white forebears". Her family lacked "the money to go with their status" so she was adopted by a lawyer uncle and moved to a big house in Port Antonio (now owned by Eartha Kitt) with a "palm-fringed drive by the sea". "This gave her peculiar airs and graces as the adopted daughter of a landowner, whereas my father was more an aspiring local boy. It was a continuous source of tension in our family. He could never earn enough to guarantee her the status she thought she deserved." Hall remembers being a "depressed adolescent": "The family aspirations were oriented towards England; my mother felt she was all but white. We were to aspire upwards, and have little to do with brown - or certainly black - Jamaicans." But Hall was formed by a Jamaica already moving into independence. He squirmed as his father was patronised by white people, and by brown people earning more than him, "and he didn't know it". He chose his own friends. "My mother was an extraordinarily powerful person; she devoured us. But she said she had most respect for me because I fought her." Hall, the rebel, was also the "blackest member" of his family, greeted by his sister, Patricia, at birth as a "coolie baby". "I would never have named colour but I was aware of it all my life; Jamaican society was finely graded by colour. I was different, an interloper, and I must have internalised this. I felt as if I were a kind of stranger in my own family." When he was 17 his sister had a nervous breakdown after the family barred her incipient relationship with a medical student from Barbados who was "middle-class but black". She was given electric shock treatment, from which Hall says she never recovered. It left him with a sense of helplessness and guilt. "My sister kept washing her hands; she's still like that in her 70s. The psychic guilt was transposed into a physical sensation. I pieced the story together: it's what the family's done to her, but I couldn't make her angry about it. She looked after our father and mother till they died, then my brother George, who went blind, till he died. She never left home, and never had another relationship." Hall sees the trauma of witnessing colonial aspirations "break" his sister as seminal in his belief that social structures are lived through the psyche, through emotions and cultural identifications. "Later, when I read RD Laing about psychological disorder as a cultural system - one person takes on the dysfunction of a whole society - it all fell into place. It crystallised my feelings about not fitting in. At that point I left home. I said, if you get drawn back into the family, you'll be eaten alive." In 1951 Hall voyaged with his mother to Bristol, clad in a "brown felt hat and overcoat", and thence to Oxford, "the motor that creates Englishness". His first impression of the landscape he knew from literature was that "I'd seen it before in some other life". But it was three years after the Empire Windrush had disgorged its cargo of West Indian immigrants, and in the streets of Paddington that first "terribly grey and gloomy" August day, he remembers "groups of black men in hats, who weren't students but working people, and women in their finery, dressed up to travel". A Rhodes scholar in English, he survived the shock of Oxford's medieval gloom by befriending Americans and other West Indians, "huddled together to make sense of England". He played jazz piano with a group including two Jamaican bus drivers, and, as the Bajan writer George Lamming put it, "became West Indian" in Britain, saturating himself in anti-colonial politics with diverse islanders - though he recalls one aloof Trinidadian contemporary, VS Naipaul, who "wasn't interested in affirming a West Indian consciousness; he was on different tracks". As a postgraduate scholar Hall became involved with an anti-Stalinist, independent left. He argued with orthodox Marxists for reducing culture to "a decorative addendum to the 'hard world' of production and things". He says: "I was never attracted to join the Communist party. I had a debate with [the late historian] Raphael Samuel about class which we had for the rest of his life; the old class system no longer explained a time of modern, consumer-oriented capitalism." In 1956, when Britain invaded Suez and Soviet tanks rolled into Hungary, "it crystallised what we were saying about imperialism not being finished, and the Soviet Union being a totalitarian power. We were against both." The pro-Soviet communists crumbled, and Hall became a founding editor of what would be New Left Review. "It was the beginning of the new left, which was interested in rising consumerism, Britain looking more like the US, the coming of mass culture and television - and whether it was changing the working class. People identified it with classically English figures: Edward Thompson, Raymond Williams - though he was Welsh. But looking back, our orientation was driven by voices that didn't quite fit in: foreigners from Sudan, Syria, west Africa, the West Indies, Jewish or provincial, Scottish, Irish." Hall had abandoned his thesis on Henry James, and worked as a supply teacher in Brixton, south London. Michael Rustin, who became his brother-in-law and co-edits Soundings magazine with him, recalls "an air of excitement with the coming together of the old left and a younger generation where everything was being connected up: there was cinema, with Lindsay Anderson and Karel Reisz, and radical theatre, with Arnold Wesker". Hall says: "I'd always gone to the movies as a child; I saw every 40s melodrama, every Bogart and Bette Davis. I became interested in the impact of television, new mass magazines, teenage culture." After editing New Left Review for two years, he left in 1961 to teach film and allied media ("no one would dare put television in the title") at Chelsea College, and remembers lecturing on westerns in Wandsworth prison ("It was a riot, I loved it"). He did research for the British Film Institute on how to teach popular culture, co-writing the innovative book The Popular Arts (1964). When Richard Hoggart founded the Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies at Birmingham University in 1964, he invited Hall to be its research fellow. Hoggart describes Hall as one of the best lecturers in England and an extraordinarily charismatic personality - "he has a brilliant theoretic mind". After Hoggart went to Unesco in 1968, Hall took over as director, staying till 1979, when he left to be sociology professor of the Open University. They were "heady days", Hall recalls. "We made the curriculum up. It was the inauguration of, not a discipline, but a field of inquiry that, unlike fine art, is interested in how culture organises everyday life. It was a very creative moment." Noting the backlash from older disciplines, he concedes with a laugh: "There is a ferocious amount of crap written in any field." But he adds: "The way in which culture organises social practice has come to be seen as crucial." Hoggart's Uses Of Literacy (1957) was a pillar, along with the work of Raymond Williams and EP Thompson. Yet relatively ignored by the founding triumvirate was mass migration - which Hall has called "the world historical event of late modernity". Paul Gilroy, professor of African-American studies and sociology at Yale, says: "Stuart was the fourth figure; his postcolonial formation and experience of migrancy, and his attention to race, gave the critical understanding of the workings of England a very different slant." Hall had met his wife-to-be, Catherine Barrett - now a social historian - on a CND march at Aldermaston: 13 years his junior, she was beginning a degree at Sussex. They married in 1964, and she transferred to Birmingham, where they went on to have two children: Rebecca, now doing a PhD on the "mulatto" in English fiction, and Jess, a cameraman. But the newly-weds arrived in the midst of the Smethwick by- election, when the Tory candidate unseated a minister with the slogan: "If you want a nigger neighbour vote Labour." Hall says: "Catherine and I, a mixed-race couple, were looking for cheap accommodation; it was a very unpleasant experience. I was aware of the bubbling up of race into politics. There were problems of housing, racial discrimination, policing, the 'sus' laws; a second generation feeling they neither belonged in England nor anywhere else; the influence of reggae and Rastafarianism. It was impossible to be active and alive in Birmingham without being drawn into all that." One seminal study arose from the "moral panic" over street crime, when three teenagers - one of whom was black - were given 10-year sentences for robbery. "It triggered and was fed by wider fears - the youth revolution of the 60s and that Britain was being fundamentally changed by the presence of black people. It tapped into a long-term sense of decline. That's where we discover the question of Englishness as the central problem underlying British politics. I thought if some politician decided to speak to these unspoken fantasies and fears in a popular language, you'd have a major swing." It took until the late 70s for that politician to emerge. Policing The Crisis, co-written by Hall, was published in 1978, the year before Margaret Thatcher came to power. The book is widely seen as prescient about the drift into a "law and order society" and the advent of Thatcherism - what Hall came to call "authoritarian populism" - and its promise to put the "great" back into Britain. He wrote: "Blacks become the bearers, the signifiers of the crisis of British society in the 1970s... the means by which the crisis is to be resolved - send it away." He feels the threat remains. "That's what Hague is searching for - the remaining shoots of that feeling, which feeds Euroscepticism and the fear of asylum-seekers." Hall was accused of overplaying the ideological nature of Thatcherism. He responds: "Look at politics now. The left was restructured from below by a cultural shift; it wasn't just economics. I feel real aggression about political commentators who poured scorn on the notion of a cultural shift governing politics, who said Thatcherism was a blip. Most would accept now that Thatcherism, and its embrace of neo-liberalism, was a watershed." New Times, the political movement Hall espoused with Martin Jacques and others in Marxism Today in the late 80s and early 90s, was attacked for learning too much from its opponents, not least in its embrace of consumerism. One of Hall's most per sistent critics, A Sivanandan of the Institute of Race Relations, called it "Thatcherism in drag". Hall says: "It came out of impatience with the old left thinking it could take a stand on traditional working-class values when the right was making the running in its 'heartlands'. But it was a call to match the depth of ambition of change Thatcher tried to bring about, but from a different direction." Hall, who sees the Blair government as "a historic opportunity lost", criticised New Labour on the eve of its election in 1997. "Tony Blair swallowed the message but forgot the tune," he says. Describing himself as an "egalitarian moderniser", he adds: "I've been a kind of socialist all my life, but not what people would call a revolutionary. I've always been suspicious of the dream of remaking society in an instant. I'm interested in deep change, but I don't think intellectual work should be short-changed to prove a political point. To point towards complexity, ambiguity, unexpected consequences - that's intellectual vocation." At Birmingham, teachers and postgraduates worked together in a "hothouse atmosphere", radically rethinking the field by taking into account feminism or race politics. Angela McRobbie, now professor of communications at Goldsmith's College, London, says: "Stuart was a figurehead who let you get on with it. He challenged the relations of power in academic life." Hall, though, has cited successive "crises" with each intake of students, and feminists' "dawn raids", as among his reasons for leaving in 1979. "I lived with a feminist," he says. "Catherine became involved in the new feminist movement, especially moving from active academic life to isolation at home with two children. We were anxious that feminist work be done at the centre, but that's different from rethinking cultural studies from a feminist viewpoint. We were three men - 'the bosses'. It drove me wild to be placed in that false position." McRobbie says: "I was surprised Stuart seemed as hurt as he was. My memories were that everybody was in the firing line, but he felt he was being set up as a patriarch." The Open University seemed a natural home. "My instincts were towards widening access to adult education. Birmingham was an intellectual elite, whereas the average age at the OU was 40, people who'd not been in a classroom since 16. It was an intellectual challenge." A colleague, David Held, now politics professor at the LSE, says: "Stuart's an engaged public intellectual of a kind celebrated in Europe but of which the English are wrongly sceptical; a great communicator who shines on television and radio." Hall has not only taught media, but made astute use of it - from his BBC series on the Caribbean, Redemption Song, in the early 90s, to his relaxed eloquence on Radio 4's Desert Island Discs in February. He dissected how black people are represented on TV in It Ain't Half Racist, Mum - shown as a BBC 2 Open Door programme in 1979 - and Black And White In Colour, and his influence has grown on both sides of the Atlantic. Hall told a gathering of the Caribbean Artists Movement in 1968: "The task of any intellectual and any writer in relation to [the next generations of West Indians in Britain] is to help them see, clarify, speak, understand and name the process that they're going through." He believes that "cultural identity is not fixed, it's always hybrid [but] it comes out of a very specific historical formation", and he was possibly the first to appreciate the emerging hybrid identities of postwar Britain. He found a model in Caribbean culture: "Was it true West Indians had an identity crisis - neither European nor African in a 'pure' sense? I've written about the syncretism and creolisation of Caribbean culture all my life." For him, black communities are not some "ethnic minority culture" apart, but "in touch with their differences without being saturated by tradition; they are actively involved with every aspect of life around them, without the illusion of assimilation". Gilane Tawadros, director of London's International Institute of Visual Arts (InIVA), which Hall chairs, says: "Stuart has an extraordinary ability to articulate the experiences of first, second and third-generation black Britons, their complexities and dynamism. He understood early on that you can't look at them as isolated in the 'margins' but part of a global diaspora, and that their presence was not just a challenge to Britain but created a new kind of Britishness that's internationally celebrated." His ideas threw a lifeline to young artists. Tawadros adds: "At a time when art institutions were trying to bottle up what it meant to be black British or Asian British, when artists were frustrated at having to describe their work in terms of its 'Africanness' or 'Asianness', Stuart said that that experience, and its artistic expression, are more ambivalent; they draw on many things. He paved the way for the confidence of a new generation of artists, including Chris Ofili and Steve McQueen." Hall took an early interest in diasporic artists in London, such as Ronald Moody, Aubrey Williams and Francis Souza, who he says have been "quietly written out of the record; not British enough for the Tate, not interna tional enough for Bankside". But he found growing affinities, and collaborated, with a younger generation, including the film makers Isaac Julien, John Akomfrah and Martina Attille; the visual artists Keith Piper and Sonia Boyce; and the photographers Mark Sealy, David A Bailey, Sunil Gupta and Ingrid Pollard. "In the 80s black artists became preoccupied with identity, self-portraits, putting their own body in the frame," says Hall. "I was writing about identity and they were practising it. Racism is not just in the streets, it's written into how people recognise themselves. It made me more alert to the way artistic work is exploratory space in which ideas work themselves out. It brought me in touch with a huge creative explosion in literature, art, film." In an influential talk at London's ICA in 1989, Hall insisted "blackness", far from being fixed in nature, was "politically and culturally constructed" - partly through unconscious desire, fantasy and memory. The same went for "whiteness": "We are all ethnically located." He was criticised for accepting the fracturing of a politically united black front. He says: "There is a danger of locking into ethnic enclaves, but also the possibility of making common cause. I'm interested in a politics that makes links without ignoring difference." His stand is credited with freeing artists to speak from, but not for, black experiences, and giving crucial impetus to developing art criticism. Kobena Mercer, of New York University, says: "Stuart said films weren't good just because black people made them. It contributed to a culture of debate, not just celebration." Hall is a voice cautioning against an "easy, celebratory spirit", warning instead of "hard, perhaps iron times to come". In his view, Britain is at a crossroads, marked by the 1998 Windrush celebrations and the pathologies exposed by the 1999 Macpherson report. What he calls multicultural drift - "the explosion of cultural diversity and difference which is our lived daily reality" - is no guarantee of peace or justice without the political will to see it through. "Is Britain going to accept its diversity and become more humane? We don't yet know," he says. "Yes, things are better in some ways, but a lot of people feel left out. The five boys in the Stephen Lawrence case didn't have an O-level between them. People like them are not in the dot.com revolution. The only time they feel English is when they can kick shit out of the Dutch or the Belgians. If you're serious about a multicultural society, you would address the sense of alienation of white working-class people, who have to be won to a new conception of themselves where Britain's not lording it from a gunboat." "I don't think identity's fixed, the real, true self," he reflects. "It's constructed from historical processes: I'm the sum of that boy called a 'coolie', the Rhodes scholar, the socialist from Jamaica. Every identity that feels so solid is the result of excluding things you could have been. I go back to Jamaica and adore it, but I couldn't be a Jamaican. I ache for a parallel life I could have lived. I also couldn't disappear into Englishness. I understand Britain; but I'm only British in a hyphenated way." Hall feels a sense of homecoming - but never a settled one. "I never called myself black because no one in the Caribbean did then. I've come home to an identity I was never allowed to settle for; discovering I've become something I was all the time: a black intellectual, a migrant... People who are 68 should feel the ground solid under their feet. But I'm not surprised it feels shifting; it's the diasporic fate. More and more people feel life in this way."

fields.headline: Phallic cymbals
fields.standfirst: There's more to rock than myth and masturbation. Though Ruth Padel covers the rampant sexual imagery associated with rock'n'roll in I'm a Man: Sex, Gods and Rock'n'Roll, she only touches on the whole story
fields.trailText: There's more to rock than myth and masturbation. Though Ruth Padel covers the rampant sexual imagery associated with rock'n'roll in I'm a Man: Sex, Gods and Rock'n'Roll, she only touches on the whole story
fields.body:
I'm a Man: Sex, Gods and Rock'n'Roll
Ruth Padel
Faber, £12.99, 409pp

Buy it at BOL

When is a guitar not a guitar? Why, when it's a cock. Throughout this extraordinary book, Ruth Padel suffers from a kind of metaphoric mania: nothing is allowed simply to be what it is. We are told many times that "performing on guitar, the core act of rock, is whipping out your cock". What Padel doesn't try to explain is why so many musicians beat themselves up trying to learn guitar in the first place, if they could just be whipping out their cocks to the same effect.

Padel's avowed project is to examine how the sexuality and theatricality of rock music owes its structural roots to Greek myth. Unfortunately the case of such a link is never argued, merely gestured at. Either we are to take on faith the assumption that Greek myth "underpins our own imagination", or the claimed connection is so banal as to be meaningless. "Like myth, [rock music] is amazingly transformative"; "Like Greek myth, pop song is about relationships". The whole book is written in a spatchcocked, febrile prose, a nauseous fusion of the overheated and the blankly demotic. Music "is brilliant at making things feel natural", Padel chirrups; Greek tragedy is "like a Lloyd-Webber musical".

Early on, Padel's claim that she is raiding the myth-kitty for its "patterns of feeling" alerts the reader to the fact that her approach is blissfully anachronistic: a Greek would have had no idea what "patterns of feeling" could possibly be, and would certainly have been baffled to be told that, for example, his society was "mercilessly racist". Padel's readings of the myths of Aphrodite, Narcissus, Eros, Hephaestus and so on (weirdly, she mostly prefers their Roman names) are filtered through a Vaseline-smeared lens of pseudo-Freudianism, the better to rope them in to her ready-made theories of sex'n'violence.

Such panting Graecocentrism causes two major problems. The first is that Padel cannot acknowledge the wide variety of non-Greek influences on rock music. From the ludic occultism of late-1960s heavy rock to the Norse myth, medievalism and cod-Wagnerianism of prog rock and heavy metal (as parodied in Spinal Tap's wonderful "druids" spiel), popular music has enjoyed many more narrative forebears than those from ancient Athenian religion. Also absent is discussion of any popular-music tradition outside Anglo-American rock: the French tradition of chanson, for instance, typified by a rumpled, crooning Serge Gainsbourg. And if rock music really does grow out of Greek myth, it is perhaps surprising that the only pop star modern Greece has given to the world is Nana Mouskouri, a folky, bespectacled woman who, as far as I know, never once got her cock out on stage.

Secondly, the attempt to force absolutely anything into one Greek template or another leads to gross simplifications. One of Padel's favourite explanatory myths is that of Hephaestus, the blacksmith, and Prometheus, the renegade Titan. Just as Prometheus stole a spark of fire from the blind god's forge, Padel trills, so the white man stole the creativity of black blues music in order to make rock'n'roll.

It's a nice image, but it depends on a slew of lazy clichés that Padel never attempts to unpack. When Padel cites "black music", it is uncertain whether she means jazz and blues specifically by African-Americans, or one of many thoroughly different traditions of the African continent: the musics of Zaire, Mali and so on. Yet she happily repeats the old musicological canards. One is that African Americans "challenged western harmony" by inventing the "blue note", yet such fractional intervals had already been around for centuries in northern European folk music. White rock musicians were apparently "plundering the alien sophistication of Afro-American rhythm", yet the meat-and-potatoes rock backbeat is worlds away from, say, the polyrhythms of folk music from western Sudan.

Padel supplies a couple of well-researched chapters about racism in rock and its orientalist substructure, whereby the black man is patronised as the fount of sexual and musical creativity. When Muddy Waters sang "I'm a man", she notes perceptively, it was a political statement, in a context of southern racism, as well as a claim to sexual and musical prowess. But Padel's own approach is itself fundamentally orientalist. "Soul music," she writes, "could only have been black. Its voice is feeling, with the physicality as intense as possible: both coming from the sacredness endemic to black music and the community it expresses."

This is a profoundly patronising sentence, implying that black musicians are mere automata of "feeling" and "physicality". They do it by instinct rather than design, don't you know? - which is exactly the sort of response that Padel herself deplores when she writes about white audiences thrilling to Duke Ellington's "jungle" jazz shows. And in what way might "sacredness" be more "endemic" to "black music" than it is, say, to Western polyphonic church music?

The history of 20th-century popular music is a far more complex web of borrowings and creative thefts than Padel's Prometheus envy allows her to admit. Of course Jagger and Richard rewrote blues classics, while Paul Simon and David Byrne have shamelessly raided African musics, yet contemporary black hip-hop and garage, for example, would never have existed without the electronic template laid down by the white German band Kraftwerk: a fact that Padel acknowledges, but does not allow to spoil her argument.

Padel's totemisation of "black music" also infects her discussion of misogyny in rock, in which she concentrates almost exclusively on smutty white heavy-metal bands. Yet if the adolescent yelps of dumb desire in the music of Led Zeppelin or Van Halen are to be decried as misogynistic, what does one say of the explicit narrations of sexual degradation and physical violence towards women that characterise gangsta rap, the stars of which are mostly black men? If you are Padel, you cling to the interesting but hardly extenuating circumstance that the audience for such music is mainly white. David Lee Roth, ex-frontman with Van Halen, is excoriated for consorting voraciously with female groupies, yet Jimi Hendrix, just as sexually insatiable, was merely displaying "an innocently baroque gusto". Innocently baroque? Best not go there.

I'm a Man is a book about rock music that, in common with many less spurtily bizarre examples of its genre, has almost nothing to say about music. When Padel riffs on "violence" in rock (Eros and Mars, natch), she fails to distinguish precisely between actual violence that happens around music (Altamont), violent lyrical content, and some vague way in which the music itself might be enacting violence. But is heavy metal really more "violent" than, say, The Rite of Spring? Is rock music in general really more heavily laden with "fierce ideology" than the use of Wagner during the Third Reich, or Beethoven's soaring paean to the French Revolution? Padel doesn't address such questions, and she lacks the musical apparatus to notice that, for instance, 1980s heavy metal, with its gleeful tinsel of arpeggios and grandiose diminished-chord progressions, is just as indebted to baroque and early classical music as it is to African-American blues.

Heavy metal, Padel thinks, sounds like "menacing metallic destruction, evoking machine-like killing". Actually, I'd suggest quite the opposite. Heavy or "nu" metal, a mainly working-class genre today, is often - as with the epically amplified protest group Rage Against the Machine, the true heirs of Dylan - a radical appropriation of machinic noise with which its musicians forge something lithe, rebellious and passionately humanist, something overtly political to which its alienated fans can cleave. Such artists really might be said to be the sons of Prometheus. Sadly, Padel's book is so cock-obsessed that she cannot see beyond her favoured image of men playing only with themselves.

Yet if the adolescent yelps of dumb desire in the music of Led Zeppelin or Van Halen are to be decried as misogynistic, what does one say of the explicit narrations of sexual degradation and physical violence towards women that characterise gangsta rap, the stars of which are mostly black men? If you are Padel, you cling to the interesting but hardly extenuating circumstance that the audience for such music is mainly white. David Lee Roth, ex-frontman with Van Halen, is excoriated for consorting voraciously with female groupies, yet Jimi Hendrix, just as sexually insatiable, was merely displaying "an innocently baroque gusto". Innocently baroque? Best not go there. I'm a Man is a book about rock music that, in common with many less spurtily bizarre examples of its genre, has almost nothing to say about music. When Padel riffs on "violence" in rock (Eros and Mars, natch), she fails to distinguish precisely between actual violence that happens around music (Altamont), violent lyrical content, and some vague way in which the music itself might be enacting violence. But is heavy metal really more "violent" than, say, The Rite of Spring? Is rock music in general really more heavily laden with "fierce ideology" than the use of Wagner during the Third Reich, or Beethoven's soaring paean to the French Revolution? Padel doesn't address such questions, and she lacks the musical apparatus to notice that, for instance, 1980s heavy metal, with its gleeful tinsel of arpeggios and grandiose diminished-chord progressions, is just as indebted to baroque and early classical music as it is to African-American blues. Heavy metal, Padel thinks, sounds like "menacing metallic destruction, evoking machine-like killing". Actually, I'd suggest quite the opposite. Heavy or "nu" metal, a mainly working-class genre today, is often - as with the epically amplified protest group Rage Against the Machine, the true heirs of Dylan - a radical appropriation of machinic noise with which its musicians forge something lithe, rebellious and passionately humanist, something overtly political to which its alienated fans can cleave. Such artists really might be said to be the sons of Prometheus. Sadly, Padel's book is so cock-obsessed that she cannot see beyond her favoured image of men playing only with themselves.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: If I were an Irish comedian looking for a television break, I would buy up the rights to be Bateman's trio of Dan Starkey novels pronto. Newly released is his third, Turbulent Priests plus All Quiet On The Orient Express, Beloved Stranger, Deep Blue Almost Black
fields.body:
Turbulent Priests
Colin Bateman
HarperCollins, £6.99

Buy it at BOL

If I were an Irish comedian looking for a television break, I would buy up the rights to be Bateman's trio of Dan Starkey novels pronto. Turbulent Priests, the third, sees the heavy-drinking journo with a line in corny jokes sent to Wraithlin Island on an assignment for the Primate of all Ireland. The Catholic Church fears that the islanders are being led into heresy by their priest, and when Starkey, his wife and the baby get ashore they discover that the congregation believes that the daughter of God is among them -and, more worryingly, they have closed down Wraithlin's only pub. Bateman is an engaging comic writer who has created another snappy adventure for Starkey.

All Quiet On The Orient Express
Magnus Mills
Flamingo, £5.99

Buy it at BOL

Mills has a nose for the uneasiness of English rural life. The countryside he describes is innocuously idyllic, but hides menacing rocks towards which strangers are guided. The nameless narrator of Mills's second novel has pitched his tent in a Lake District field. Staying on after the other holiday-makers have left, he is offered bits of work. Soon he is in the pub darts team and doing homework for the landlord's daughter. An outsider's desire to please means his planned trip to India gets endlessly postponed until it becomes clear that something sinister keeps him from leaving. Mills's engrossing portrait of this community is both comically and disturbingly distorted.

Beloved Stranger
Clare Boylan
Abacus, £6.99

Buy it at BOL

When Dick sees intruders under the bed and starts opening all the windows in the house, his wife Lilly, conditioned by years of married forbearance, carries on papering over the cracks. Their daughter, Ruth, naturally becomes anxious and irritated at her parents' decline and their obstinate refusal to let her manage their declining years. It takes only a chapter or two before you think you have fastened on to Boylan's narrative - a marriage unravelled by old age and Alzheimer's. But then she surprises you by not giving Dick the expected diagnosis and by apportioning sympathy and blame sparingly in sensitive prose.

Deep Blue Almost Black
Thanassis Valtinos
Hydra, £10.99

The title novella in this collection is a dramatic monologue that has become a favourite performance piece in Greece and elsewhere. Its narrator, a middle-aged woman, sweeps up the pieces of her life and complains of her losses both trivial and profound until her real sorrows emerge. It is a stunning, beautifully crafted introduction to Valtinos's sparse style. Read it first, then turn back to the other stories chosen from 40 years of his work. There is the blunt, political allegory of "The Plaster Cast", stories from the Greek Civil War, and timeless tales of lovers and ghosts that together make poetic sense of modern Greece.

fields.headline: Knight in shining armour
fields.standfirst: My Life on a Plate by India Knight rescues Alex Clark from distressing single-girl fiction
fields.trailText: My Life on a Plate by India Knight rescues Alex Clark from distressing single-girl fiction
fields.body:
My Life on a Plate
India Knight
Penguin, £5.99, 247pp

Buy it at BOL

You spend all those lonely nights fretting about the continuing non-appearance of Mr Right, plucking and tweezing and slimming yourself into virtual oblivion, listening patiently as boorish men drone on about their boring, self-satisfied lives and attempting to ignore the thunderous ticking of that infamous biological clock. Meanwhile, in the great race to the altar, all your pals are sprinting past while you are still lowering yourself creakily onto the starting blocks. What you need, patently, is a big dose of Bridget Jones to make you feel that You Are Not Alone.

Actually, what you really need is the evidence of your own eyes, plus a liberal helping of India Knight, to reassure you that married life sucks too. My Life on a Plate is the ideal gift for any friend caught mooning over Bride magazine, drawing up a seating plan or forcing sugared almonds into tiny netted bags. Knight, the Sunday-supplement columnist who has made a virtue out of plundering her life for material - and has pulled it off largely through a conspiratorial wit that suggests she's perfectly aware that it's trivial froth - has come up with that rare thing: the lightweight comic novel that is well-written, neatly constructed and actually funny.

Clara Hutt, Knight's alter/altar ego, is 33, the mother of two sweet but annoying little boys, the daughter of an overbearing drama queen and the step-sibling of a collection of immaculately groomed freaks. She is married to prissy Robert, whose exhausting job editing a women's magazine renders him capable only of lying on their ecru sofa reading Vogue, and useless when it comes to feeding and watering their children or performing acts of hot connubial sex.

Clara, apart from hoovering, tidying away the kids' toys and ballsing up the odd magazine feature (on one occasion by getting drunk "accidentally", insulting her interview subject and giving him the children's nits), is free to do whatever she likes, which largely involves eating doughnuts, bacon sandwiches, pumpkin ravioli and cream, and taking the piss out of herself and anyone else around.

Like her creator, Clara has a talent for seeing the farcically tragic in all that surrounds her. "Her pelvic floor!" she cries, when she hears that a friend's husband is busy cuckolding her with his acne-ridden secretary. "Who will notice its marvellous resilient elasticity now?" Of her own marriage, in which she plays tracksuit-bottomed, giant-sweatered Big Pig (a jovial, gritted-teeth nickname) to nauseatingly fastidious Robert in his Comme des Garçons suit, she knows not whether to laugh or cry. But the more she determines to count her blessings, casting her eyes over her neurotic single friends, the more she wonders about a world without headlice, PlayStations or school runs. Things, we sense, are coming to a head.

Grass-is-greener girlpower novels are where it's at these days in terms of publishers' advances and blanket media coverage. Most of them are illiterate, poorly imagined drivel, exploiting their readers' insecurities with an easy self-pity, a smattering of designer labels and a low-grade, cynical complicity. Many are by journalists, who ought to know how to string a few sentences together. Knight's book, on the other hand, is exemplary middle-brow fiction. Neither unfunnily comic nor unconvincingly tragic, it somehow conveys the idea that she's had a laugh writing it, and a big belly laugh at that. For once, as the reader, it's pleasant to feel that the joke's not on you.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText:
Windows on the Sixties
ed Anthony Aldgate et al
I B Tauris, £14.95

Much Arthur Marwickian posturing (academiaspeak plus lusting after minis) in these cultural studies - the Sgt Pepper album analysis must be a parody. But shrewd on the movie A Hard Day's Night (the fab four were already "hard as iron"); acute on Billy Wilder's The Apartment and its recognition of the new acceptability of New York Jewishness. Perhaps unintentionally funny on Lindsay Anderson's encounters with the priggish censors over This Sporting Life (they negotiated over "bloodies" and visible bollocks so as not to incite the lower orders); and the best essay I've read on The Avengers, with a sense of high style matching its subject.

Star Style
Patty Fox
Angel City Press, £12.99

Buy it at BOL

We love a total no-brainer with great pix, and this one has two key movie-fashion shots of the 1960s (among Vaseline-greased eyelids from vampier eras). Doris Day completely wrong as a mock-mod in boots and mini-shift, posing for wardrobe for the movie Caprice 1967 - there's no promise of the Left Bank about her, nothing reticent or even wild, just an American broad doing Par-ee. Plus Audrey Hepburn, utterly right, in the red coat Givenchy made for her in Charade (1964), which she wore off-screen until it was shiny at the edges: serious tailoring that helped make Stan Donen's thriller dead cool when it was really only pastiche Hitchcock.

fields.headline: Postcards (for Christine Wells) and Post-op
fields.trailText:
The walkabout postman studies his handful
Before he slots them home. What do they say?...
fields.body:
Postcards (for Christine Wells)
The walkabout postman studies his handful
Before he slots them home. What do they say?

Public as T-shirts, coded like
A mole's correspondence, designed to be enigmatic.

Having a wonderful they say. Oh boy,
This is the life! or Cooler now. Had to put

Our cardies on, they say, or Natives friendly,
Or just Wish you were here. He knows, the postman,

They don't say what they mean, mean what they say.
Extraordinary too, he thinks, the cards they send:

Of opera houses: owls; folk being ethnic;
Fish; teapots: eucryphia milleganii

(What'll she make of that? he thinks, popping it in.)
Each picture sends a message - proud, witty, wise -

But not enough for him to understand.
( Super day yesterday sorry I missed the post. )

O postman, postman, endlessly chivvied by cliché,
This freakish correspondence that teases you so
Is a minor rehearsal for the final take-off.

Look in the graveyard, as you make your round;
There are the ultimate postcards, trite as ever,
Stylised as runes, with a subtext intricate As a crossword puzzle clue, or house-agent's blurb,

Delivering the last message of stay-at-homes
To those who have left on a journey beyond deliveries:

Gone, not forgotten; Sadly missed; Wish you were here.


Post-op

Artists are wrong about light. They strew it
Tastefully across landscapes, let it focus
Thoughtfully on a forehead or a cabbage,
Self-consciously walk down a reach of water.

Artists are wrong.

Light comes storming out of its corner
Dealing dazzling uppercuts to the eyes.

See, says Light, It's like this and like this,
Injecting the whole national grid into one lens;

This is what you were missing, says Light,
Grinning like a mouthful of American teeth;

Fizzing and raucous, like the mixture
In Dr Jekyll's retort; importunate, like the tune

A child has just acquired for one finger.
That's good, says Light, I knew you'd like it,

And demonstrates
The unexpected awfulness of the tiles on the kitchen floor.

webTitle: The definitive unmasking of Bill Clinton

fields.headline: The definitive unmasking of Bill Clinton
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas Lezard relishes the dark dealings in the White House in Christopher Hitchens's No One Left to Lie To
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard relishes the dark dealings in the White House in Christopher Hitchens's No One Left to Lie To
fields.body:
No One Left To Lie To: The Values of the Worst Family
Christopher Hitchens
Verso, £7

It is interesting, if depressing, to note the different timbres of silence between two influential American groups: those on the right who affected not to notice claims that Reagan presided over the most corrupt American administration in history; and those on the "left" who affect not to notice claims that Bill Clinton is a liar and - according to testimony that deserves a hearing in court - more of a sexual predator than the Lewinsky affair would indicate.

The common reactions to that ultimate accusation is really depressing, for in the rapid succession of rebuttal, bafflement, and then flat-out denial, you can watch liberals out-perform the most barking mad misogynist, proving that such concepts as ethics or political principle can be surprisingly mutable. One woman, very dear and close to me, taught me, as the Nixon presidency imploded, about such concepts in the first place: she is now reduced to the nastiest, most Clintonian trick of all: discrediting the messenger.

As the most prominent, articulate and plausible of Clinton's detractors, Hitchens has come in for a lot of discredit lately, particularly when he broke the press corps code of silence on the Oval Office's off-the-record slandering of women the President had slept with. So the 'on dit' about No One Left was that old Hitch had shot his bolt, this was something of a rant, what's his problem with old Bill?

Well, that was dead wrong. This is, very easily indeed, the most important book to have emerged on the Clinton presidency to date; and, as we labour under a Prime Minister said to have modelled his style on the former governor of Arkansas, it might be instructive (or at least amusing) to imagine which parts of his mind he closes off when he hears about Clinton's pork-barrelling, smearing, canting, double-crossing activities.

In this book you will find chapter and verse on Clinton's record. The charges against him can all be boiled down to this essence: that he has soft-soaped the Left with windy, patronizing rhetoric, and provided the Right with deeds. He is, in effect, an audaciously right-wing President, presiding (which I suppose must be the right word) over an expansion of the underclass that even Dubya Bush will be hard-pressed to match; as Hitchens puts it, "he has never voluntarily spent any time in the company of anyone who earns money rather than makes it".

There are, in this book, enough practical examples of what this does to people to make your hair stand on end. Or, if you are that way inclined, to make you weep with rage. That Hitchens writes with a wit, power, and grace unrivalled by any of his colleagues should go without saying. What he describes may be appalling, but it is often read-bits-out-loud funny. The kickings he delivers to Arthurs Miller and Schlesinger, Jr - "this polka-dotted popinjay" - virtually justify the cover price by themselves.

Of course, if you don't mind that there is a back-stabbing, unprincipled predator on women in the White House, then you might not see the reason for a book such as this. Such people come and go, after all. But let's assume that as a reader of this paper you take a dim view of these matters.

fields.headline: The reluctant storyteller
fields.standfirst: Jim Crace talks about why he used to feel that fiction was a cop-out
fields.trailText: Jim Crace talks about why he used to feel that fiction was a cop-out
fields.body:
The novelist Jim Crace has never been particularly interested in other people's fiction. "My deep reading experiences have always been more likely to come from books on natural history or landscape," he explains. In this, as in much else, Crace follows his father, whose death was the starting point for his last novel, Being Dead. He was a working-class socialist, as well as a keen birder, groundsman and gardener.

"That combination of urban politics and country walks has always been with me. The flat where we grew up was on the very edge of north London. Out of the front windows it was houses all the way to Croydon. But out of the back it was fields all the way to Cambridge."

Although Crace did read English Literature at university, he says if he had his time over again he would do something different. "When, aged 18 or 19, you have a romantic notion of what being a writer is, you see doing English literature as the obvious route to becoming a writer. I used to walk around with a notebook, but I never wrote anything in it. I was just in love with the notion of being Jack Kerouac. Now I am a writer I never go anywhere with a notebook."

After university he had a spell as a VSO working for Sudanese educational television. He presented, acted in, directed and wrote the programmes. "I had the arrogance only a white Englishman on an overseas aid programme could get away with." When he returned home he was offered a contract to write educational plays for the BBC, but his real interest was in journalism.

"I spent half of my working life, up to the age of 40, as a journalist because I thought fiction was a bourgeois indulgence. If you wanted to be involved in politics and writing it had to be through journalism. Of course it turned out to be slightly difficult to raise the clarion call to the barricades because most of the time I worked for the Sunday Telegraph."

Even when he did write a widely praised short story, "Annie's, California Plates", in 1974, he still made no attempt to capitalise on its success.

"I got loads of phone calls from editors and agents wanting to work with me. Most of my friends were walking around with finished fiction but no publisher or agents. I had publishers and agents but no fiction. It wasn't until 1986 that I could be arsed to actually write a novel."

The linked cycle of stories that comprise his first novel, Continent, won three major literary prizes in a fortnight; the Whitbread, Guardian and David Higham. But Crace was still reluctant to become a full-time author.

"Then I had an article about Broadwater Farm estate spiked by the editor of the Sunday Times," he explains. "It was for quasi-political reasons and I felt so disenchanted that I didn't want to write journalism any more. But by that time Continent had been sold for a lot of money in America, and so in fact my principled stand was bankrolled by American dollars."

"But you can only play the hand that you've been dealt. I haven't got the skills of an Orwell or Steinbeck. "They didn't really look me in the eye when I told them that on the first page of Being Dead the two leading characters were lying dead on a beach."

But don't hold your breath for a Crace laugh-fest just yet. "While the concept is playful," he acknowledges, "there is something about me that is so bloody cussed. I'm not yet convinced it won't end up a lot more subversive and darker than is currently anticipated."

fields.headline: In search of Marcel
fields.standfirst: Lover or loner? An exploration of the many lives of Proust. Stuart Jeffries begins with Roger Shattuck's Proust's Way as he wades through a litany of Proust biographies
fields.trailText: Lover or loner? An exploration of the many lives of Proust. Stuart Jeffries begins with Roger Shattuck's Proust's Way as he wades through a litany of Proust biographies
fields.body:
Proust's Way: A Field Guide to In Search of Lost Time
Roger Shattuck
Penguin, £20, 304pp

Marcel Proust: A Life
William C Carter
Yale, £22.50, 946pp

Buy it at BOL

Marcel Proust: A Biography
Jean-Yves Tadié, translated by Euan Cameron
Viking, £30, 986pp

Buy it at BOL

It is a terrible thing to be imaginative. When Marcel kisses Albertine in A la Recherche du Temps Perdu, it takes 15 pages and about an hour's reading before he finally makes his moue. Even then he can't resist collapsing into Proustian digression: "To begin with, as my mouth began gradually to approach the cheeks which my eyes had tempted it to kiss, my eyes, in changing position saw a different pair of cheeks; the throat, studied at closer range as though through a magnifying glass, showed a coarser grain and a robustness which modified the character of the face."

A few lines later - during which the irresolute reader will be shouting "Kiss her! Just kiss her, damn you!" - the object of his affection changes again: "Just as at Balbec Albertine had often appeared different to me, so now . . . during this brief passage of my lips toward her cheek, it was ten Albertines that I saw; she was like a goddess with several heads, and whenever I sought to approach one of them, it was replaced by another." Finally, he closes in: "next, my nose, crushed by the collision, no longer perceived any fragrance, and, without thereby gaining any clearer idea of the taste of the rose of my desire, I learned from these unpleasant signs, that at last I was in the act of kissing Albertine's cheek." It's as though Frasier's fey Niles Crane is ineptly kissing baffled Daphne.

But, as Roger Shattuck writes in his wonderful new study of Proust's great novel, beyond the comedy of this passage, beyond the self-conscious self-parody of Proustian deferral, something more serious is afoot. There is an infirmity in Marcel's nature to which the best are prone. "The most reflective of us are endowed with this antithesis of the Midas touch," writes Shattuck. "It turns the things we want, or want to know, into dross."

Proust knew this as well as anybody, and wrote about it better than anyone else. Elsewhere in the novel, Swann's obsession with Odette results in a lustreless marriage, for "in physical possession . . . the possessor possesses nothing". In A la Recherche, Proust could not envisage love as anything but such possession, an object upon which his characters are nonetheless self-defeatingly bent.

Admittedly, this is hardly new territory for French literature. Montaigne felt oppressed by une erreur d'me: "I attach too little value to things I possess, just because I possess them; and overvalue anything strange, absent, and not mine." This "soul error" was also used by Stendhal to account for a man's sexual failings: sexual possession causes the libido to wane. And such was the unbearable truth of soul error for Rousseau that he suggested the only world worth living in was the realm of fiction.

Both Proust and Shattuck, his cunning celebrant, seem undecided as to whether soul error is the curse of the imaginative or a condition of being human. The latter is surely a more interesting position, since it suggests that the otherness of people is insurmountable. Proust was perhaps overwhelmed by his own experiences and nature into constructing a desperately unconsoling psychological law: "Man is the being who cannot get out of himself, who knows others only in himself, and, if he denies it, lies." Shattuck, too, is no slouch at building putative psychological laws, such as his "paradox of consciousness": "It is impossible to be present at the coronation of one's own happiness."

Turning to William Carter's new biography, I found this: "[Proust] apparently never had a sexually fulfilling relationship with a companion whom he loved. If he did, there are no traces of it in his letters and writings." Carter, professor of French at the University of Alabama, is in a perfect position to find such traces: this scrupulously detailed life betrays a great deal of time spent nose-deep in archives.

A page earlier, we are given the only insight into Proust's sexual fulfilment. A young man would go to a room in a brothel where Proust would be under the covers with a sheet drawn up to his chin. He was required to undress and "satisfy himself" while Proust attempted the same. If Proust failed, two cages would be brought in, each containing a famished rat. The rats would be released and attack each other with piercing squeaks. This spectacle, we are told, enabled him to achieve orgasm. This is the only point in his nearly 1,000-page biography at which Carter pushes the reader's head into Proust's dirty linen; for the rest of the book we are in the Olympian heights of creative growth, with Proust cast as dedicated literary hero.

André Gide saw in Proust's rodent-induced climaxes a "psychological inadequacy" and linked them to the depictions of gay men in A la Recherche that he found so objectionable. Gide contended that Proust contributed to the confusion between the homosexual and the invert. The former had noble associations dating from the ancient Greeks; the latter (as personified in A la Recherche by the Baron de Charlus) was a modern, decadent variety by means of which a man would become a woman for another man.

Edmund White's more approachable (not just because briefer) queer reconstruction of the life of Proust, published last year, portrayed the writer as more or less openly gay, and, more happily yet, having several lovers during his life. Jean-Yves Tadié, perhaps the world's greatest authority on Proust, whose magisterial biography of the writer has just been published, doubts this: "Not a single love letter has been unearthed." What drives both Carter and Tadié is Proust's life as it helps us understand the evolution of the artist. In this, both are writing biography in the way recommended by their subject: "Everything in an artist's life is connected according to the implacable logic of inner evolutions." But while Carter's book is ponderous, Tadié's is a thrilling journey through the development of intellect and sensibility. It is his biography that at last eclipses George Painter's two-volume life, for more than 40 years the last word on its subject. Unlike Painter, Tadié does not draw on the novel to explain the life, but realises that the life of an artist is important only insofar as it helps us understand the work. He implicitly accepts Shattuck's advice: "Forget the cork-lined room and the dallying aesthete. Proust lived in the world and wrote about it with fervour."

The newly thriving Proust industry is an extraordinary thing. Popular books in recent years have included How Proust Can Change Your Life, The Year of Reading Proust and four volumes of selected letters, as well as such fine works as Malcolm Bowie's Proust Among the Stars and White's biography. There's even a poem by Craig Raine called A la Recherche du Temps Perdu. But all this is as nothing compared with the French wing of the operation. The real Proust industry is commanded by Tadié (professor of French at the Sorbonne), who has also edited the vast Pléiade edition that includes sketches, drafts and variants in tiny print. For those intimidated by fat Proust, this is even more forbidding: now you can read a Pléiade Proust that is eight inches thick rather than the earlier three.

Shattuck lambasts Tadié for this edition. Unlike Montaigne, he argues, Proust worked towards a final version and that must form the basis of the authoritative edition. He has no truck with those French critics who maintain "Le texte n'existe pas" and who, he claims, have seduced Tadié into their sick world. The poor reader, though for more practical reasons, must surely agree: 7,500 pages of Proust is too much of a good thing.

But Shattuck, a retired former lecturer at Harvard and Boston universities who has spent 30 years teaching and writing on Proust, may have unwittingly contributed to this industry. One of the appendices to his book is an analysis of the first sentence of A la Recherche, "Longtemps, je me suis couché de bonne heure." Why did Proust use this tense, he wonders? Why not the characteristic imperfect tense that gives the novel its pervading tone of sadness and illusion? Interesting questions. But why stop one's exegesis there? After all, the second sentence is pretty fascinating. And the third - well, it's clearly worth a PhD of its own. The fourth, too . . . It is, to be sure, a terrible thing to be imaginative.

fields.headline: Culs de sac
fields.standfirst: Richard Holmes is a biographer thrusting himself into the limelight in Sidetracks: Explorations of a Romantic Biographer
fields.trailText: Richard Holmes is a biographer thrusting himself into the limelight in Sidetracks: Explorations of a Romantic Biographer
fields.body:
Sidetracks: Explorations of a Romantic Biographer
Richard Holmes
HarperCollins, £19.99, 416pp

Buy it at BOL

Is the biographer an artist who can and should exist on equal terms with the dramatist, fiction writer and poet? The short and robust answer is "certainly not", and however much we may revere, say, Richard Ellmann's great biography of James Joyce, we have to recognise that it does not break the boundaries of that genre to become the equivalent of an important novel. Richard Holmes thinks differently about his profession - thinks, in fact, is too strong a word; he believes differently and, in his latest gathering of superficial, self-regarding essays in biography, he attempts to charm his way into what he fondly regards as the Palace of Art.

Here is his Jamesian beginning: "We were at a cafe table, under the plane trees, far in the south, with the evening light flowing away down the river. I was asking the beloved novelist that old, fascinating question: how do you find your stories? Where do your ideas come from? When she said, with that sudden challenging smile of hers: 'But how do you find your subjects; where do they come from?' And I answered almost without thinking, between two mouthfuls of the cold white wine: 'Down many sidetracks.' She laughed and looked into the gathering dark. 'I think you'd better explain that,' she said. So I have tried."

This is a slack version of the Jamesian donnée, and is really an example of middle-class comfort journalism - travel, white wine, cultural backdrop, all ideas safely inert. And there's something gauche and clunking in that phrase "the cold white wine" - the unnecessary definite article gives it the displaced air of translationese. Though, on the other hand, it might be an example of a style Holmes elsewhere terms "profoundly and timelessly Irish".

Holmes likes to be seen in France, especially in Paris, city of carefree or decadent artists, which figures largely in Sidetracks. He even has the gall to admire the "white cupolas" of that obscene building the Sacré Coeur, and when he remarks that Fouquet's is "one of the ultra chique old cafes in Paris" he mistakes "chique" - a plug of tobacco - for "chic". Or perhaps he's thinking of "chiqué", meaning "sham"? Somehow elegance always deserts him as he allows us access to what he terms his "personal casebook". Here he asserts that Chatterton didn't commit suicide, but died from an accidental overdose of the arsenic with which he was treating his venereal disease. There is nothing to be gained from abandoning the legend of the poet whom Wordsworth called "the marvellous boy"; it merely diminishes Chatterton, whose account of thunder's "rattling clymmynge sound" Holmes in compensation absurdly over-praises as "one of the finest pieces of onomatopoeic poetry in the whole of English verse".

In "Monsieur Nadar", a self- referential study of the biographer as photographer, we're somewhere between a sloppy horror story and a bad film: "As night fell, and the street lamps swaying from their iron gibbets filled the thoroughfare with a garish, orange gaslight, and the cab lamps jerked down the uncertain asphalting of the boulevard, a great arc of clear white light, the output of 50 Bunsen Static Batteries linked in series, flooded down from the windows of number 35."

As well as offering this type of kitschy moment, Holmes's style manages to be chirpy, pushy, heartless and romantically self-involved. It's like watching a dogged, plodding narcissist who relishes telling us that Eton is the "sister college" to King's College, Cambridge. Of the don and ghost writer MR James, he says that James presided at the end "of the golden age of assured continuity between Eton and Cambridge". And he concludes with this finely judged heritage moment: "For myself, I shall call to mind only the view from the College Library, as the dark finally settles into the courts and the sound of Evensong drifts on the chill airs in the sweet, harmonious voices of the King's choristers and here and there a scholar twitches his curtains, sports his oak, and draws up his chair to the pool of light beneath his solitary, gazing lamp." The emphasis is on a vanished social harmony, the evocation of which will please the Times readers for whom most of these cooing pieces were designed.

Even so, when in "Poor Pierrot" Holmes turns to the tortured comic genius of mime artist Jean-Gaspard Deburau, he evokes his White Faced Fool or enfariné with an intelligent sympathy that made me realise the link with Chaplin, though he doesn't point to it. However, he fails to offer any detailed analysis of the trial that followed the killing of a young apprentice, Nicholas Vielin, whom Deburau struck with a walking stick after he had insulted his wife.

The fact that Deburau was holding his walking stick by the middle Holmes describes as "crucial evidence" which was "not pursued", but why it was crucial he fails to state (the blow would have been heavier if he'd held the stick by the handle). Time and again, Holmes fails to quote - he remarks that the Lisle letters written in the reign of Henry VIII "show the living language that Shakespeare was heir to", but manages only one quotation from them. Piling on more clichés, he declares that Voltaire soared to "increasingly dizzy heights in France" and notes his "brilliance as a private investor", but fails to give any details of his dealings on the stock market.

As he tries to make us rank him with biographers such as Ellmann and George Painter, Holmes's Pooterish self-regard can be felt in every hollow, preening sentence: "One enters these great biographies, as into entire worlds of historical recreation, having the human density of large novels peopled by many characters, and yet focused upon the single, minutely documented experience of an actual life. They contain extraordinary richness and conviction; they shimmer with innumerable points of living light."

That worn poeticism "innumerable points of living light" is typical of Holmes's tweeness. He even has the temerity to include two examples of that unprintable genre, the radio play. Holmes is a waffler who begins one paragraph "Writing as an experimental biographer myself". That use of "myself" is redundant, otiose, self-promoting and entirely vulgar. If you want to be soothed by complacent, low-level chattiness, read Sidetracks.
fields.bodyText: Sidetracks: Explorations of a Romantic Biographer Richard Holmes HarperCollins, £19.99, 416pp Buy it at BOL Is the biographer an artist who can and should exist on equal terms with the dramatist, fiction writer and poet? The short and robust answer is "certainly not", and however much we may revere, say, Richard Ellmann's great biography of James Joyce, we have to recognise that it does not break the boundaries of that genre to become the equivalent of an important novel. Richard Holmes thinks differently about his profession - thinks, in fact, is too strong a word; he believes differently and, in his latest gathering of superficial, self-regarding essays in biography, he attempts to charm his way into what he fondly regards as the Palace of Art. Here is his Jamesian beginning: "We were at a cafe table, under the plane trees, far in the south, with the evening light flowing away down the river. I was asking the beloved novelist that old, fascinating question: how do you find your stories? Where do your ideas come from? When she said, with that sudden challenging smile of hers: 'But how do you find your subjects; where do they come from?' And I answered almost without thinking, between two mouthfuls of the cold white wine: 'Down many sidetracks.' She laughed and looked into the gathering dark. 'I think you'd better explain that,' she said. So I have tried." This is a slack version of the Jamesian donnée, and is really an example of middle-class comfort journalism - travel, white wine, cultural backdrop, all ideas safely inert. And there's something gauche and clunking in that phrase "the cold white wine" - the unnecessary definite article gives it the displaced air of translationese. Though, on the other hand, it might be an example of a style Holmes elsewhere terms "profoundly and timelessly Irish". Holmes likes to be seen in France, especially in Paris, city of carefree or decadent artists, which figures largely in Sidetracks. He even has the gall to admire the "white cupolas" of that obscene building the Sacré Coeur, and when he remarks that Fouquet's is "one of the ultra chique old cafes in Paris" he mistakes "chique" - a plug of tobacco - for "chic". Or perhaps he's thinking of "chiqué", meaning "sham"? Somehow elegance always deserts him as he allows us access to what he terms his "personal casebook". Here he asserts that Chatterton didn't commit suicide, but died from an accidental overdose of the arsenic with which he was treating his venereal disease. There is nothing to be gained from abandoning the legend of the poet whom Wordsworth called "the marvellous boy"; it merely diminishes Chatterton, whose account of thunder's "rattling clymmynge sound" Holmes in compensation absurdly over-praises as "one of the finest pieces of onomatopoeic poetry in the whole of English verse". In "Monsieur Nadar", a self- referential study of the biographer as photographer, we're somewhere between a sloppy horror story and a bad film: "As night fell, and the street lamps swaying from their iron gibbets filled the thoroughfare with a garish, orange gaslight, and the cab lamps jerked down the uncertain asphalting of the boulevard, a great arc of clear white light, the output of 50 Bunsen Static Batteries linked in series, flooded down from the windows of number 35." As well as offering this type of kitschy moment, Holmes's style manages to be chirpy, pushy, heartless and romantically self-involved. It's like watching a dogged, plodding narcissist who relishes telling us that Eton is the "sister college" to King's College, Cambridge. Of the don and ghost writer MR James, he says that James presided at the end "of the golden age of assured continuity between Eton and Cambridge". And he concludes with this finely judged heritage moment: "For myself, I shall call to mind only the view from the College Library, as the dark finally settles into the courts and the sound of Evensong drifts on the chill airs in the sweet, harmonious voices of the King's choristers and here and there a scholar twitches his curtains, sports his oak, and draws up his chair to the pool of light beneath his solitary, gazing lamp." The emphasis is on a vanished social harmony, the evocation of which will please the Times readers for whom most of these cooing pieces were designed. Even so, when in "Poor Pierrot" Holmes turns to the tortured comic genius of mime artist Jean-Gaspard Deburau, he evokes his White Faced Fool or enfariné with an intelligent sympathy that made me realise the link with Chaplin, though he doesn't point to it. However, he fails to offer any detailed analysis of the trial that followed the killing of a young apprentice, Nicholas Vielin, whom Deburau struck with a walking stick after he had insulted his wife. The fact that Deburau was holding his walking stick by the middle Holmes describes as "crucial evidence" which was "not pursued", but why it was crucial he fails to state (the blow would have been heavier if he'd held the stick by the handle). Time and again, Holmes fails to quote - he remarks that the Lisle letters written in the reign of Henry VIII "show the living language that Shakespeare was heir to", but manages only one quotation from them. Piling on more clichés, he declares that Voltaire soared to "increasingly dizzy heights in France" and notes his "brilliance as a private investor", but fails to give any details of his dealings on the stock market. As he tries to make us rank him with biographers such as Ellmann and George Painter, Holmes's Pooterish self-regard can be felt in every hollow, preening sentence: "One enters these great biographies, as into entire worlds of historical recreation, having the human density of large novels peopled by many characters, and yet focused upon the single, minutely documented experience of an actual life. They contain extraordinary richness and conviction; they shimmer with innumerable points of living light." That worn poeticism "innumerable points of living light" is typical of Holmes's tweeness. He even has the temerity to include two examples of that unprintable genre, the radio play. Holmes is a waffler who begins one paragraph "Writing as an experimental biographer myself". That use of "myself" is redundant, otiose, self-promoting and entirely vulgar. If you want to be soothed by complacent, low-level chattiness, read Sidetracks.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.standfirst: What's new in thrillers? Chris Petit takes a peek at Antonio Tabbuchi's The Missing Head of Damasceno Monteiro plus  Karakan, Burnt Sienna, Fatal Climate, Painkillers and Andrew Pyper's first novel, Lost Girls
fields.trailText: What's new in thrillers? Chris Petit takes a peek at Antonio Tabbuchi's The Missing Head of Damasceno Monteiro plus Karakan, Burnt Sienna, Fatal Climate, Painkillers and Andrew Pyper's first novel, Lost Girls
fields.body:
The Missing Head of Damasceno Monteiro
Antonio Tabbuchi
Harvill, £8.99

Buy it at BOL

This book is that potentially awkward hybrid, the translated literary thriller. A journalist is dispatched to Porto to cover the story of a headless corpse, which leads to drug smuggling, strange secret boudoirs and police cover-ups. Despite the publisher's claim of unflagging suspense, the book defies most of the rules of genre to meander with artful and leisurely grace around its plot, preferring diverting excursions into the beguiling city of Porto and - thanks to an eccentric lawyer with a taste for Hölderin - a philosophical inquiry into the nature of jurisprudence. The result emerges somewhere between Dürrenmatt's more rigid meditations on the nature of evil and Michael Dibdin's Zen novels.

Karakan
Keith Michel
Minerva, £12.99

Buy it at BOL

It comes with a promising enough synopsis - "shipping deals, slick lawyers and merchant bankers, Islamic opportunists and their women, desperadoes and suited gangsters" - and a cod-Forsyth formula which here boils down to stodge. Love conquers all as an ex-Test cricketer reduced by scandal to prep-school teaching reclaims his lost sweetheart in the shape of the trophy wife of a Pakistani arms dealer.

Burnt Sienna
David Morrell
Headline, £17.99

Buy it at BOL

Another arms dealer in Burnt Sienna - a rather silly sinister one, who kills his wives after having their portraits done. However, the latest artist for the newest wife is a fight-back ex-vet; give over. Morrell wrote the memorable post-Vietnam manhunt/survival thriller First Blood, but here the prose is stuck on autopilot: "Sienna struck him as being more beautiful than ever. How do I hide one of the most striking women in the world? he thought."

Fatal Climate
David Hood
Gollancz, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Twenty years ago this book would have been a routine cold-war thriller. Now it's all Alvin Toffler with a plot, and the doomsday scenario has shifted from the nuclear to the climatic as a dull hero battles a White House cover-up regarding a likely catastrophe in the bottom half of the globe. Big storm climax, too much nick-of-time stuff and an over-egged eco-message.

Lost Girls
Andrew Pyper
Macmillan, £12

Buy it at BOL

This first novel was a number-one seller in Canada and has been compared to Stephen King. Pyper does lots well, but he lacks King's narrative drive, opting instead for a fussy over-simplicity that leaves one unpersuaded by the story's supernatural element. A bad-boy, coke-fuelled Toronto lawyer is sent up-country to defend a teacher accused of murdering the two lost girls of the title. Sentence by sentence there's little to fault: the moody unease of small-town Canada is maintained and a creeping horror revealed via a local skeleton lurking in the troubled lawyer's cupboard. In the end, however, the glancing, semi-hokey plot belongs more in a short story than a novel.

Painkillers
Simon Ings
Bloomsbury, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Again, this novel suffers some of the same problems. Smart writing and the laconic insolence of early Deighton take precedence over a plot that's more interesting at the edges than the centre, dominated by a mysterious Bakelite box and a grail of bizarre sexual perversions and strange cures. Painkillers is more enamoured of its own supercharged decadence than narrative application; it works best as journalism on, among other things, Hong Kong corruption, money laundering, autism, sandwich bars and London's South Bank, with a lot of names dropped along the way.

fields.headline: White heat
fields.standfirst: The Forger by Paul Watkins is a 'delicately written' Resistance adventure
fields.trailText: The Forger by Paul Watkins is a 'delicately written' Resistance adventure
fields.body:
The Forger
Paul Watkins
Faber, 240pp, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Searching for a tag to describe Paul Watkins's tense, delicately written novels, I came up with "highbrow yarns". Watkins, a thirtysomething Anglo-American, specialises in fast-moving tales of adventure, set on New England trawlerboats or under Saharan skies, their tone rendered all the sharper by the sense of something more cerebral uncoiling in the background. The Forger, a dense thriller set in the German-occupied Paris of the early 1940s, is a pattern example of his ability to combine the best kind of "literary" skills with a narrative pull worthy of George Macdonald Fraser's Flashman stories.

His early work - this is the seventh novel in a career begun in his early twenties - was occasionally criticised for its faux-Hemingway prose style ("Carefully he pulled the trigger. The blood ran out over the floor", etc). The new one jettisons some of these stylistic flourishes in favour of a Hemingwayesque situation. David Halifax, its American hero, is shipped to Paris at the fag-end of the 1930s courtesy of something called the "Levasseur Committee". Installed in the atelier of a Russian émigré named Pankratov, along with the latter's wonderfully farouche model Valya, he swiftly falls in with Fleury, a modish young art dealer.

Already several mysteries are jostling for the reader's attention. One of them concerns the Levasseur Committee, eventually revealed as a bright idea hatched by Pankratov and his café-owning chum Ivan, who served with Halifax's uncle in the Foreign Legion. Enigmatic Valya, for whom Fleury fruitlessly yearns, turns out to be Pankratov's adopted daughter. Then there is the conundrum of the art master's pictures, none of which have survived. Fleury, meanwhile, has given a hint of the novel's future course by passing off a sheaf of Halifax's museum "studies" as Old Master try-outs to an impressionable collector.

Everything, from the simmering personal relationships to Halifax's monastic commitment to his painting, moves up a gear with the outbreak of war and the Nazi occupation. Defying instructions to go home, Halifax finds himself caught up in a Resistance-sponsored scam to foil German attempts to expropriate the hastily concealed contents of the Paris galleries; in the guise of art thieves, they trade facsimiles for gargantuan stashes of Impressionism that the Degas-hating invaders would otherwise burn.

Dark horse Pankratov is suddenly revealed as a master forger. Posing as collaborators (Valya, by this time, is dating the SS man in charge of the Nazi art mission), Halifax and Fleury weave their way into the heart of the new Paris establishment. They survive the inevitable close shaves (Fleury narrowly escapes a cattle truck east to the camps) and - as the city awaits the arrival of the allies - secure a final commission to "find" a rare Vermeer that Goering wants as a present to propitiate Hitler for the fall of Stalingrad.

Thus framed, The Forger allows plenty of scope for the brain/brawn stand-offs at which Watkins excels. The precise forensic touch previously brought to trawlerboat routines or chainsaw husbandry is now transferred to the techniques of Old Master forgery, while the psychological portraits include a brilliant sketch of Goering - who, when lunching with the team, takes an inexplicable shine to Pankratov and monopolises him for the course of the meal. One of the best scenes comes when Halifax, wandering around Paris on the eve of the invasion, watches a reconnaissance plane land in the Place de la Concorde. After staring at him for a moment the German officer it conveys flies off again, leaving a single cigarette on the ledge of a nearby statue. Maintaining its suspense until the final denouement of the liberation, the novel is full of these odd, incidental effects, and in an already distinguished career is a definite contender for the best thing Watkins has yet written.
