fields.headline: Harry, Jessie and me
fields.standfirst: Joanne Kathleen Rowling is a down-to-earth kind of woman - considering she's a multi-millionaire writer. Her own daughter comes first, of course, even if they do have a boy-wizard in the family. By Simon Hattenstone
fields.trailText: Joanne Kathleen Rowling is a down-to-earth kind of woman - considering she's a multi-millionaire writer. Her own daughter comes first, of course, even if they do have a boy-wizard in the family. By Simon Hattenstone.
fields.body:
I've just been mobbed in the playground, buried in a froth of 10-year-old girls. I'd barely whispered that I was going to see JK Rowling, and that was enough. Can you get me her autograph? Will you find out the name of the new book? Ask her who dies? Who gets to snog Harry?

No one asks what the JK stands for, how old she is, whether she's married, got children. They know - Joanne Kathleen, 34, married, separated, single mum, six-year-old daughter Jessica, Jessie to us.

I walk away shellshocked. One of the dads rushes after me. "You're very lucky," he says. "She doesn't often give interviews, a bit of a recluse. It all got to her, I hear, went a bit Harry potty."

The grown-ups are almost as excitable as the children. A friend tells me that the books are really adult fare masquerading as kiddy lit. Look out for the leitmotif, he says - estrangement and loss. His wife calls him in for tea, and says he has always had a thing about boarding schools.

Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone was published in 1997. There were news stories about it at the time because Rowling had received an advance of more than $100,000 in the US. The first three in the series of seven have now sold more than 35 million copies. The fourth book has achieved advanced sales of two million. Last year, Rowling earned £14.5 million, making her Britain's third-best-paid woman, well ahead of the Spice Girls. And so the figures and hyperbole roll on.

We've arranged to meet in a hotel in Edinburgh. She doesn't allow journalists into her house; her daughter has always been kept away from the press. The hotel is camouflaged as a town house. No name on the outside, just a number. It's musty and forbidding, and reminds me of the invisible entry to Platform 9 3/4, from where Harry and his fellow student wizards take the train to the magic school of Hogwarts. The Harry Potter books are well-crafted slices of nostalgia. Nostalgia for a world that few contemporary children would know about. Boarding school, house points, a girlie swot, an insipid hero, a slightly naughty best friend: this could be the Famous Five or Billy Bunter or Just William. Her publicist leads me to the JK Rowling suite. She is sitting there ablaze - all strawberry-blonde hair, red velvet jacket and cigarette smoke. She'd make an attractive, down-to-earth witch in this grandiose setting.

She used to teach French in a Scottish comprehensive. She says that what attracted her to planet Potter was its "controlled anarchy", and she takes me back to her classroom experience. She doesn't think she was a bad teacher, but she does think she had bad thoughts. Sometimes, she'd face the children so aware of their strength and her vulnerability. "I remember standing in front of the most difficult class I taught, and things were going fine. I don't know why - maybe it's my personality - but I was standing, leaning against the desk, waiting for the next person to say, 'What am I supposed to do?' and I thought, 'They can have me. What's this invisible thing stopping them?' "

They used to take the mickey out of her, mock her English accent. But they were never sure whether to do her as a cockney or a Hooray Henry, so she taught them how to do Forest-of-Dean.

I tell her how, at my school, we drove our French teacher to a breakdown by sticking pins on her chair. She laughs, loudly, and I begin to feel guilty 25 years too late. "That's nice of you- hahaha!" She laughs like a Gatling gun - it's the loudest laugh I've ever heard. Suddenly it stops and she's speaking in a hush. "Did she cry in class?" I nod. "See, that's bad. I never cried, I felt like it, but I never did." Rowling is one of life's copers.

Her heroine is the writer Jessica Mitford. She remembers going to visit her great aunt Ivy in Somerset when she was 14, and being told about this amazing woman. "And she said, 'You know what she did, Jo, she bought a camera on her father's account and then went travelling.'" Young Joanne thought that was wonderful. Later, she discovered that Mitford was also a civil-rights activist who had suffered more than her share of tragedy. "She had a total lack of self-pity. And she lost three children through war, which is the worst thing that could happen."

After university, Rowling worked for the human-rights organisation Amnesty International. She still knew she wanted to write, but this was the next best option - "a day job that I cared about". She chews heavily on a cigarette before telling me how she loused up her life. Like Mitford, she left England to travel. She ended up teaching English as a foreign language in Portugal, where she fell in love with Jorge Arantes, married him, had a child, began writing Harry Potter, and fell out of love. When she told Jorge how she felt, he threw her out. She returned the next day with the police, collected Jessica, and headed back to Britain and the most dismal phase of her life. She had no money, no job, nowhere to live. "Pretty much everything was gone." She also feared being dragged back to Portugal to fight a custody case.

She considered moving to London, where many of her friends lived. But they were single, childless and carefree. London wasn't the right place for a woman with worries. So the girl, born in Chepstow, raised in the Forest of Dean, headed for Edinburgh, where her sister lived. "I knew two or three people, and I was incredibly lonely. I was really angry." Did she resent having Jessica? "No, never. I was very angry at myself." Why? "I don't know. I never expected to find myself in that situation, and I was furious with myself. But I certainly never regretted leaving, and I never ever for a second regretted Jessica. She kept me going."

It's not that she was particularly ambitious for herself, or that she had mapped out her life. "I just never expected to mess up so badly that I would find myself in an unheated, mouse-infested flat, looking after my daughter. And I was angry because I felt I was letting her down."

One day she visited her sister's friend and realised she'd hit rock bottom. "She'd had a baby just a couple of months before me, and I saw Thomas's bedroom full of toys, and at that point, when I packed Jessica's toys away, they fitted into a shoe box, literally. I came home and cried my eyes out." But within six months, Rowling had found herself a typing job. She then took a postgraduate certificate in education. A year later, she was teaching French, and Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone had a publisher. Her first royalty check was for £600. Another year on, she was a millionaire and had given up teaching. It all sounds terribly neat, but of course it wasn't.

When she left her teaching job, it was not because fame beckoned, it was because her contract had run out. "The senior teacher in the department was very worried about me. I said I'd do supply teaching, and she said, 'Are you going to be all right?' And I said, 'Well, it's not all doom and gloom - I'm having a book published!' She said, 'No way! ' It wasn't that we both then thought this will set you up; it was just something you've done that's good."

For years, Joanne Rowling was a closet writer. Her sister knew she was writing, her estranged husband knew, her oldest friend (to whom the second book is dedicated, and the template for Harry's friend Ron) knew. But that was about it. She once told another friend she was writing a novel, and the friend blanked her. "I think she thought I was deluding myself, that I was in a nasty situation and had sat down one day and thought, I know, I'll write a novel . She probably thought it was a get-rich-quick scheme."

For two hours every week, she'd leave Jessica with a friend and sneak off to a cafe to write. She has never had much time for fantasy, certainly isn't a buff. "I've read The Hobbitt, and I read CS Lewis when I was about eight. But I don't like fantasy as a genre. Today, people seem to think if there's a unicorn in a book I will love it, and they give me the books..." Invariably, they are wrong. She would much rather sit down with a good Roddy Doyle. She may have studied classics, but her frame of reference tends to be populist - Q Magazine, Father Ted, The Royle Family. What she seems to enjoy about Harry's universe is that it is her creation, ruled by her own logic. Whereas many of us may not have a clue whether Harry is exceeding his powers, she knows exactly what he can and can't do. She gets quite exercised if people tell her they think Harry's dead parents are going to come back to life at the end of book seven. "We've had petrified people, and we've had what would have been fatal injuries, but once you're dead you're dead. No magic power can resurrect a truly dead person."

One of her pupils eventually discovered she was writing a book. The girl had turned up without pen or paper; Rowling gave her the obligatory telling off and sent her to get some from the notepad on her desk. "She was ages at the desk, and I turned round and said, 'Maggie will you come back and sit down,' and she went (putting on a Jean Brodie voice) 'Miss, are you a writer?'" Rowling felt embarrassed, exposed. "I think I said, 'No it's just a hobby.'"

Rowling is stridently unpretentious. She admits hers is a remarkable story, but not nearly as remarkable as the newspapers would have you believe. Always simplify, always exaggerate, she says - the golden rules. So the two-bedroom flat became a bedsit; the papers conveniently fail to mention that she was from a middle-class family, that she had a degree in French and classics. They much preferred to caricature her as the penniless single mother/divorcee.

"I detected a tone of 'Ah, lone parent', as if by definition, if you found yourself in that situation, you must be a real under-achiever, which is so the reverse of the case, because I know lone parents and, without exception, they are people doing paid work, and the work of two parents, and really working so damned hard." She says she needed more help, but her health visitor told her it wasn't available because she was coping too well. "I know it's right that it would be kids at risk who get priority, but it does mean a lot of people, the majority, are in my situation where they are coping, but just a tiny bit of help would mean that life was so much better for the child."

But then I've occasionally detected a 'Well, they can do it if they have to', which is equally unfair." She says she was able to succeed because all she needed was pen and paper, and then some way down the line a typewriter. If she'd wanted to be a fashioner designer or fine artist, she reckons she would have been stuffed.

"Penniless single mother," she repeats. "The doleful tone of those words." At least, she says, when they call her a penniless divorcee it has attitude. "The blowsy woman up at a bar, 'and then when Charlie left me...' " Rowling's a cracking mimic.

She enjoyed the second stage of success most. This was just before the release of the third book, Harry Potter And The Prisoner Of Azkaban. At this point, she was allowed to merge into the background as writers began to analyse the appeal of Potter. "I never wanted the focus to be me. It's a good question. Rowling may not be in it for the publicity, but her publisher, Bloomsbury, certainly is. The more the books have sold, the more the media has wanted of Rowling. And when she declined their interest, they decided she had become a recluse. A while ago, her ex sold his story. Rowling didn't react, though it obviously upset her. "It is never a nice feeling." But he was nice about her, said how much he wanted her back and sod the money? "Nice isn't really the word. Nice or horrible isn't the issue. It's just his version of our marriage," she says. Then there was the time that Raymond Briggs criticised the books, and the papers were banging on her door demanding a defence. Then she didn't win the Whitbread, and they were back for another comment. Now another controversy looms- Rowling has just failed to win the Carnegie prize for children's literature.

"Phase three has been, 'She's cracking up, she's become reclusive.' If I'd not given an interview for longer than a month, they wanted to know why." In many ways, Harry Potter has enabled her to take control of her life; but he has also brought intrusions. She says it's funny how strangers feel confident that they know exactly why she wrote the books. "I'm often informed that I wrote the first book as escapism, because my life was so horrible. Well, that's just not true. When I started writing the books, I was working, in a very happy relationship, life was fine, no one had died. Everything was okay."

I ask her what is the most extravagant thing she has done with all her millions. She says it came at a time when she was struggling with the plot to book four, just after Jorge's story of their marriage was published. She was sitting in her favourite writing cafe, had been there two hours, and the paper was blank with self-pity. "I was just feeling very down, and really worried about the book, and then I thought there is an upside to this situation and I walked into this jeweller's and I dropped a lot of money on a very expensive ring that I'd seen the previous week. And you know when you spend more money than you plan to, everything else looks cheap by comparison - so then I bought presents for my two best female friends as well. And I have to say it helped."

Rowling considers the ring such an extravagance because there was no justification for it. She says she is possessive of him. What's the worst thing anyone could do to him? She mishears me. "I can do to him whatever I like. I'm allowed to torture him as much as I want. He's mine."

Does Jessica get jealous of Harry? "Oh no, she knows, and she's right, that she's top dog. She's got a healthy ego, in the best way." Initially, Rowling told Jessica she wouldn't read her the books until she was seven. But when she started school, the older kids would quiz her about Harry and she was in no position to answer. "It happened so often that, in the end, words had to be dropped - would they please leave her alone so she could play with her friends." When Jessica began to go behind her mother's back, asking other people what happened in Harry Potter, she decided it was unfair to keep her away from the books any longer. "I was more nervous reading to her than anybody." Why? "What if she'd turned round and said this is rubbish, I want to go and play with everyone - hahahaha! I would have been okay with it, but it would have been difficult because if her tea was half-an-hour late, and I'm going, 'In a minute, in a minute, I've just got to finish this.' No, she says, the first time she met anyone who'd been to boarding school was at university. "I thought it sounded horrible. She has become edgy. "I do get kind of frustrated with this conservative world thing because..." She explains at length, and somewhat defensively, that the school had to be a boarding school because most of the magic happens in the middle of the night, and if it was a day school you wouldn't get the same sense of community. She also argues that, in a way, Harry does reflect the modern world because he is mixed race - his dad being a wizard, his mum being a muggle (human) witch - which seems to be pushing it a bit.

This is about the only claim Rowling does make for her Potter books. She never suggests they stand up as modern classics. She's a pragmatist: she knows bestsellers are rarely great literature. When I say they are well-written, she seems delighted and tells me how at times she rewrites obsessively.

What limits the books for me is their lack of emotional and psychological depth. One of the few moving, and surprising, moments occurs in the first book, when Harry stares into a magic mirror... and sees his dead parents. He later learns that the mirror offers a reflection of what he most wants in life. Rowling says this is a rare autobiographical element in the novels. "The mirror is almost painfully from my own feelings about my mother's death. She died when I was 25, so I was six months into writing the book when she died. And she was 45." She says if she were looking in the mirror she would see exactly what Harry saw. People search pointlessly for other aspects of her life in the books. As she says, they are works of imagination.

At times when Rowling is talking about her success, she seems shaky, suspicious of it. Of course, she loves having money, she says, but maybe she wishes she'd been just a little less successful. She worries about the amount of money, and she also worries about talking about the fact that it worries her. "Yes, I'm riddled with guilt. It's a very weird situation. Then again, there is a solution... you can give it away. You can't sit there and say, 'Ah, it's tragic, I've got a lot of money', because nobody's stopping you spreading it about a bit." And is she doing so? "A bit," she says tersely. At least, she says, it doesn't feel like dirty money.

I ask Rowling if something such as this can happen without it changing you. She takes an age to answer. You sense she'd love to say, no, of course it doesn't alter a thing, but it wouldn't be true. "No, I don't think it is possible, honestly." She admits that it has become harder to trust the motives of people, and at the same time others are wary of her. She mentions a good friend she made in the schoolyard. The woman didn't know she'd written the Harry Potter books. "She said to me if I'd known who you were I'd never have spoken to you. I said, 'Oh, cheers!' She then said, 'I would have thought that you would have thought that I only wanted to speak to you because...' I laughed. She was very funny about it. So when we met in a normal, bog-standard situation we became very friendly. It's perfectly possible..." Suddenly, she seems a little self-conscious. "You know there are a lot of people who don't know about Harry Potter, millions of people who don't have a clue. I'm not Mick Jagger!"

Rowling still insists that the seventh Harry Potter will be the last. Will she miss Harry? She says she's not looking forward to finishing, but there will be some comforts in it. Less demand for photographs, for one. "If I can honestly say to myself that, at the end of book seven, I wrote the story that I set out to write, and didn't change one tiny thing because some reviewer had said, 'Let's have more feisty female footballers '; if I can look myself in the mirror and say I did it the way I wanted, then I'm okay with it."

She would like to try her hand at adult fiction, and has a filing cabinet full of notes. "Yes, I'll still write. But I really mean this, I think it's quite possible that I'll finish Harry and go to the filing cabinet where the notes are and think they're rubbish."

I follow her downstairs to where she's having her picture taken. The photographer asks if she minds having a picture taken with a broom that he's bought. She winces, and obliges. "Let's be honest, I feel a twat about this, let's be straight," she says through another Gatling gun laugh - before, true to form, she turns herself into a resolute misery for the pictures.

Did she call herself JK because she fancies being a modern-day Tolkien? "No, it was the publisher's idea," she says. "They were wary of me being a woman." Bloomsbury thought it might put off the boys, so they made her androgynous. "I was so grateful to be published, it didn't matter to me." We talk some more about life after Harry Potter, and she's getting increasingly enthusiastic. "You know, one day, I'd like to experience life as a woman," she says.

fields.bodyText: I've just been mobbed in the playground, buried in a froth of 10-year-old girls. I'd barely whispered that I was going to see JK Rowling, and that was enough. Can you get me her autograph? Will you find out the name of the new book? Ask her who dies? Who gets to snog Harry? No one asks what the JK stands for, how old she is, whether she's married, got children. They know - Joanne Kathleen, 34, married, separated, single mum, six-year-old daughter Jessica, Jessie to us. I walk away shellshocked. One of the dads rushes after me. "You're very lucky," he says. "She doesn't often give interviews, a bit of a recluse. It all got to her, I hear, went a bit Harry potty." The grown-ups are almost as excitable as the children. A friend tells me that the books are really adult fare masquerading as kiddy lit. Look out for the leitmotif, he says - estrangement and loss. His wife calls him in for tea, and says he has always had a thing about boarding schools. Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone was published in 1997. There were news stories about it at the time because Rowling had received an advance of more than $100,000 in the US. The first three in the series of seven have now sold more than 35 million copies. The fourth book has achieved advanced sales of two million. Last year, Rowling earned £14.5 million, making her Britain's third-best-paid woman, well ahead of the Spice Girls. And so the figures and hyperbole roll on. We've arranged to meet in a hotel in Edinburgh. She doesn't allow journalists into her house; her daughter has always been kept away from the press. The hotel is camouflaged as a town house. No name on the outside, just a number. It's musty and forbidding, and reminds me of the invisible entry to Platform 9 3/4, from where Harry and his fellow student wizards take the train to the magic school of Hogwarts. The Harry Potter books are well-crafted slices of nostalgia. Nostalgia for a world that few contemporary children would know about. Boarding school, house points, a girlie swot, an insipid hero, a slightly naughty best friend: this could be the Famous Five or Billy Bunter or Just William. Her publicist leads me to the JK Rowling suite. She is sitting there ablaze - all strawberry-blonde hair, red velvet jacket and cigarette smoke. She doesn't think she was a bad teacher, but she does think she had bad thoughts. Sometimes, she'd face the children so aware of their strength and her vulnerability. "I remember standing in front of the most difficult class I taught, and things were going fine. I don't know why - maybe it's my personality - but I was standing, leaning against the desk, waiting for the next person to say, 'What am I supposed to do?' and I thought, 'They can have me. What's this invisible thing stopping them?' " They used to take the mickey out of her, mock her English accent. But they were never sure whether to do her as a cockney or a Hooray Henry, so she taught them how to do Forest-of-Dean. I tell her how, at my school, we drove our French teacher to a breakdown by sticking pins on her chair. She laughs, loudly, and I begin to feel guilty 25 years too late. "That's nice of you- hahaha!" She laughs like a Gatling gun - it's the loudest laugh I've ever heard. Suddenly it stops and she's speaking in a hush. "Did she cry in class?" I nod. "See, that's bad. I never cried, I felt like it, but I never did." Rowling is one of life's copers. Her heroine is the writer Jessica Mitford. She remembers going to visit her great aunt Ivy in Somerset when she was 14, and being told about this amazing woman. "And she said, 'You know what she did, Jo, she bought a camera on her father's account and then went travelling.'" Young Joanne thought that was wonderful. Later, she discovered that Mitford was also a civil-rights activist who had suffered more than her share of tragedy. "She had a total lack of self-pity. And she lost three children through war, which is the worst thing that could happen." After university, Rowling worked for the human-rights organisation Amnesty International. She still knew she wanted to write, but this was the next best option - "a day job that I cared about". She chews heavily on a cigarette before telling me how she loused up her life. Like Mitford, she left England to travel. She ended up teaching English as a foreign language in Portugal, where she fell in love with Jorge Arantes, married him, had a child, began writing Harry Potter, and fell out of love. When she told Jorge how she felt, he threw her out. She returned the next day with the police, collected Jessica, and headed back to Britain and the most dismal phase of her life. She had no money, no job, nowhere to live. "Pretty much everything was gone." She also feared being dragged back to Portugal to fight a custody case. "If I can honestly say to myself that, at the end of book seven, I wrote the story that I set out to write, and didn't change one tiny thing because some reviewer had said, 'Let's have more feisty female footballers '; if I can look myself in the mirror and say I did it the way I wanted, then I'm okay with it." She would like to try her hand at adult fiction, and has a filing cabinet full of notes. "Yes, I'll still write. But I really mean this, I think it's quite possible that I'll finish Harry and go to the filing cabinet where the notes are and think they're rubbish." I follow her downstairs to where she's having her picture taken. The photographer asks if she minds having a picture taken with a broom that he's bought. She winces, and obliges. "Let's be honest, I feel a twat about this, let's be straight," she says through another Gatling gun laugh - before, true to form, she turns herself into a resolute misery for the pictures. Did she call herself JK because she fancies being a modern-day Tolkien? "No, it was the publisher's idea," she says. "They were wary of me being a woman." Bloomsbury thought it might put off the boys, so they made her androgynous. "I was so grateful to be published, it didn't matter to me." We talk some more about life after Harry Potter, and she's getting increasingly enthusiastic. "You know, one day, I'd like to experience life as a woman," she says.  Harry Potter And the Goblet Of Fire is published by Bloomsbury on July 8, priced £14.99.

fields.headline: Just for laughs
fields.standfirst: Should comedians write novels? Phil Daoust takes a stab at Night of the Toxic Ostrich by Nick Revell and Never Trust a Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson
fields.trailText: Should comedians write novels? Phil Daoust takes a stab at Night of the Toxic Ostrich by Nick Revell and Never Trust a Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson
fields.body:
Night of the Toxic Ostrich
Nick Revell
Headline, 277pp, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Never Trust a Rabbit
Jeremy Dyson
Duck Editions, 231pp, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

The intersection between TV comedy and fiction is piled high with damaged vehicles. Ben Elton, Sean Hughes et al may dream of rivalling Jeffrey Archer or the late Dame Babs, but they also seem to share those authors' approach to quality control. Someone - it won't be their agents or publishers - ought to tell them that even comic novels need decent plots and halfway credible characters, and that to write a serious book you also need something to say.

In a perfect world, those who have helped make British TV comedy what it is (almost unmitigated rubbish) would be banned from flytipping in the layby of literature. Failing that, their work would carry big red warning stickers, and bookshop staff would hand out extra-long bargepoles with which not to touch the product. There would be a few innocent casualties, such as Robert Newman, whose novel about a policeman, Manners , was almost enough to redeem the whole genre. But at least readers would have some protection against the day when French and Saunders get it into their heads that what the world really needs is 850 pages of flatulence masquerading as a good read.

In the meantime, you pays your money and you takes your choice, preferably in a shop with a cast-iron returns policy. Which brings us to Night of the Toxic Ostrich , a comic novel by Nick Revell, a former stand-up who has written for Drop the Dead Donkey and a number of radio shows. This book is a lot better than most of its rivals. But that's not saying much.

Ostrich revolves around an obnoxious London-based comedian called James, straight but pretending to be gay for the sake of his career, who rashly makes an on-air offer to bugger the Taliban, "even though I don't normally go for blokes with beards". A hitman travels from Afghanistan to take revenge, but instead falls in love with the woman the comedian is chasing. The comic and his would-be nemesis become entangled with a homicidal maniac with metal hands, a dangerously constipated fat man, a sleazebag promoter, the sweet but hippy-dippy love interest and James's mustachioed female agent, plus a radioactive ostrich with a bad attitude and a mastery of the martial arts, who ends up giving James the treatment he had proposed for the Taliban.

Revell is the author of the well-received House of the Spirit Levels, and he has a better than average grasp of structure, skilfully juggling characters and advancing his convoluted plot. But it can't have taken him long to come up with James and the entertainment-biz scumbags who surround him. Revell comes across as an artisan rather than an artist, a would-be Tom Sharpe who can't quite take us beyond mild amusement. And he certainly can't match him when it comes to having fun with flightless birds: in his 1973 novel Indecent Exposure, Sharpe fed his ostriches explosives-filled condoms then used them to blow up bits of South Africa, which at the time was no more than it deserved.

Fortunately, if you did get a money-back guarantee, the £9.99 you paid for Ostrich will also cover Never Trust a Rabbit. This collection of short stories comes from Jeremy Dyson, the non-acting member of the League of Gentlemen comedy team. It's a rougher read - downright ropey in parts - yet much more satisfying.

The title comes from a Hungarian proverb - "Never trust a rabbit. They may look like a children's toy, but they eat your crops" - and the book could be subtitled "Tales of the Fairly Unexpected". In "Love in the Time of Molyneux", the Messiah returns to earth, only to be betrayed by a "friend" who hates him for his perfection; in "We Who Walk Through Walls", a man recruited to help a phony magician in one of his tricks turns out to be a supernatural policeman sent to punish him for cheapening wonder.

The tales' starting points are often well-worn - Dyson is hardly the first writer to find horror on the tube or enchantment at the bottom of the sea - but he normally manages to work in a satisfying twist. On the downside, he is often pompous: one character "refrains from expressing the thought". He can also be clunky: another "appears relatively small in the flesh". He's over-fond of paradoxes: "Molyneux was not conventionally handsome but he was remarkably attractive." He speaks in too many voices, often not his own: some tales remind you of Roald Dahl, others of Ray Bradbury. And at times his training as a screenwriter makes itself felt in details that might help dress a set, but do nothing for the imagination.

These aren't insuperable problems, but it's significant that they haven't been ironed out. Book editors are too often loath to get to grips with writers with a reputation in another field. (Ben Elton's first novel, Stark, is a case in point, although putting that right would have employed more people than his arch-enemy Thatcher put on the dole.)

Yet for all Rabbit 's flaws, there's something admirable about it. It reflects a boldness that's rarely seen among Dyson's confreres - a willingness to dream and a refusal to fall back on humour when the ideas run thin. If the man gets some proper direction and resists complacency, he just might live up to his reputation. That's more than you can say for most of his peers.

fields.headline: Strangers under siege
fields.standfirst: Susan McKay examines the troubled Northern Irish Protestant mind-set in Northern Protestants: An Unsettled People
fields.trailText: Susan McKay examines the troubled Northern Irish Protestant mind-set in Northern Protestants: An Unsettled People
fields.body:
Northern Protestants: An Unsettled People
Susan McKay
Blackstaff, £12.99, 288pp

Buy it at BOL

The million and a half people who live in the north of Ireland who are collectively known as Protestants have been in the world's media spotlight for more than 30 years. They assert their Britishness with greater passion than the English, their political leaders appear regularly on television and radio; they have had ample opportunity to tell us what they are all about.

Yet, for the vast majority of Britons, not to mention the rest of the globe, they remain an enigma. In an increasingly secular world, what they stand for (Protestantism) and what they struggle against (Roman Catholicism) appear equally absurd. Just as nonsensical is their ambition to recreate a sort of Calvinist theocracy. They remain in limbo, honing their siege mentality, barking at the British state that doesn't care whether they go or stay, and braying at the notion of joining an Irish state which (nominally at least) does want them.

The political, economic and religious desires of this belligerent and brash people appear utterly untenable, an anachronism. But they have shed blood - tankersful of it - for their beliefs. There must be some kind of explanation which will help us to make sense of their fears and their ferocity, a key that unlocks the mysterious mind-set of a people outsiders just cannot fathom.

I fear, having read Susan McKay's book with a growing sense of sadness and, at points, repulsion, that there is no key because there is not only no lock, there isn't even a door. In structure, the book is both simple and subtle. It is the straightforward recording of more than 60 interviews with Protestants of all classes from across what they call "the province". But cleverly woven into these personal accounts are the potted histories of disturbing events, ancient and modern.

There was a moment, about halfway through, when I felt I couldn't go on. I had survived the genteel bigotry of the residents of North Down. I had gritted my teeth during the tales of murder and mayhem committed by drunken hoodlums from north Belfast. I had managed to turn the pages of mythologising about Drumcree, even getting beyond the woman who lamented the death of the paramilitary assassin Billy Wright: "Some people say he was a psychopath but at least he was our psychopath."

But then I came to the chapter on Ballymoney, the Antrim housing estate where three children, the Quinns, were burned to death in July 1998 after loyalists threw a petrol bomb into their home. A middle-class woman said of this horrific incident "There is no way it was sectarian", and went on to talk darkly of "other factors" which may have been involved. Most of the community was in a state of denial about the murders, deluding themselves with a more-to-it-than-meets-the-eye explanation that has turned a scandalous rumour into fact. In the wake of the deaths there was an attempt at creating cross-community meetings in a public hall until a woman who said she was speaking for everyone thundered: "There's no way Catholics are getting into this building. This has always been a building for Protestants."

When anyone dares to question this tunnel vision they are quickly whipped into line. Donna, a 15-year-old who had arrived in the village after growing up in a mixed area, failed to attend the annual bonfire on the Twelfth. Next day, a girl of eight asked her if she was a Fenian. When she dared to say she would have voted in favour of the peace agreement, her new schoolfriends called her "traitor".

McKay returns to Derry, the city in which she was born and raised a Protestant. When she mentions her "misnamed Londonderry High School for Young Ladies", I suddenly realised what a brave act this had been for McKay, and how she had been able to obtain such terrifyingly truthful statements from a people notorious for their loathing of the media and, especially, for those who don't hold fast to the creed. She catalogues a whole range of insults used by Protestants against their own: the "guilties", those ashamed of their background; "rotten Prods", those who stopped the expulsion of Catholics from their homes in the 1930s; "Prods who've got above themselves", such as prison officers; and, worst of all, "a Lundy", or traitor. This reference to a soldier who fled Derry city during a 17th-century siege is hurled indiscriminately at all those deemed to have compromised with Catholics. McKay, doubtless, will qualify for the epithet too.

Like so many of the more liberal voices in this book, and there are some, she had to escape to the hated Republic to realise the true horror of her upbringing. She guides us through an Orange maze, where opinions based on hearsay are held for a lifetime. There is no logic to much of what people think and say, no coherence to the views they hold so passionately.

Here are men who have committed foul murders in the name of religion and then, in jail, undergone religious conversions. But from what to what? There are glimpses along the way, odd insights into a changing perspective. Certainly, there are people who realise that religious differences were accentuated in the past to cloak class divisions. But what can one say to a woman who believes that the 13 victims of Bloody Sunday were IRA men killed in previous gun battles whose bodies were recovered from a deep freeze?

webTitle: Met faces inquiry into harassment allegations

fields.headline: Met faces inquiry into harassment allegations
fields.trailText: An inquiry is to be launched into allegations of a police vendetta against a black man, the authority set up to oversee policing in London promised last night.
fields.body:
An inquiry is to be launched into allegations of a police vendetta against a black man, the authority set up to oversee policing in London promised last night.

Delroy Lindo, 40, from Hornsey, north London, has been charged with 18 offences in the past four years, from driving with a dirty number plate to threatening to kill, and in each case the prosecution has collapsed.

Lord Harris of Haringey, Ken Livingstone's appointment as chairman of the new Metropolitan police authority, yesterday sought to reassure the Lindo family and the wider black community that the investigation would be thorough.

"Where police action may appear inappropriate or heavy handed, and the action is brought to my attention ... I will take every step to ensure that the Met investigate the case thoroughly," he said.

Mr Lindo, a father of three, claims that one of the reasons police have allegedly targeted him is because of his support for Winston Silcott. Mr Lindo was a childhood friend of Mr Silcott, who was jailed for the murder of PC Keith Blakelock during the 1985 Broadwater Farm riots in Tottenham, north London, but was later cleared on appeal.

Mr Lindo said the most recent alleged harassment happened on Sunday when he was arrested in front of his seven-year-old daughter. A police officer approached him in his street and told him he was being held for "sucking my teeth", Mr Lindo said. Mr Lindo said that in a police car on the way to the station an officer had said: "You lot need to be taught a lesson." He was later released without charge.

He said his arrests are upsetting for his family and he is suing for harassment and malicious prosecution.

Mr Lindo said he welcomed the inquiry into his allegations, but he expressed concern that the investigation was to be carried out by the police themselves.

"I have dealt for so long with the local police and nothing has been resolved," he said. "Maybe if there is intervention from Scotland Yard something may develop from it - but I wait, since it is police investigating police."

Lord Harris, the former leader of Haringey council, said the MPA - which assumed responsibility for the Met five days ago - had been set up, in part, to deal with this kind of problem.

"I have raised this matter with the [Met] commissioner and his senior officials and believe it is essential that a full internal inquiry is carried out into the handling of Delroy Lindo's case.

"The MPA has a central role in holding the Met to account, and we will expect them to respond fully and openly to the concerns expressed."

In a statement last night, the Met, which is responsible for a third of stop and searches in Britain, said that it had been gathering information about Mr Lindo's allegations and would carry out an inquiry.

webTitle: Kickboxer jailed in US for killing British professor

fields.headline: Kickboxer jailed in US for killing British professor
fields.trailText: A martial arts expert was yesterday jailed for murdering a British professor who was visiting the United States.
fields.body:
A martial arts expert was yesterday jailed for murdering a British professor who was visiting the United States.

Stanley Runcorn, 73, was beaten and strangled by Paul Cain, 28, a competitive kickboxer and black belt in karate.

A former head of physics at Newcastle University, the geophysicist served as an adviser to the Pope and was in San Diego to organise an academic conference for the Vatican when he was killed in December 1995.

Cain, who was convicted of second degree murder in May, never denied the killing. But he claimed he had been provoked when Prof Runcorn made an aggressive sexual advance by pushing him on to a hotel room bed, reminding him of being molested as a child.

A San Diego court ordered that Cain be jailed for between 15 years and life. Cain's lawyer, Robert Howell, said the judge had refused a new trial, but that he intended to appeal against the conviction.

Prof Runcorn, who was internationally recognised for his research on the magnetic fields of the earth and the moon, was born in 1922 in Southport, Lancashire. He earned his doctorate in Manchester in 1949 and became a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1965. He was honoured by such groups as the American Geophysical Union and the Royal Astronomical Society, from which he received the gold medal in 1984.

A visiting professor at the University of Alaska at the time of his death, Prof Runcorn was one of the world's leading experts on plate tectonics, the study of how the continents formed.

Press Association

fields.headline: Levy hoaxer may be prosecuted
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, has been asked by the inland revenue chairman, Nick Montagu, to decide whether a prosecution should be mounted against an impostor who contacted the inland revenue claiming to be Labour fund-raiser Lord Levy, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, has been asked by the inland revenue chairman, Nick Montagu, to decide whether a prosecution should be mounted against an impostor who contacted the inland revenue claiming to be Labour fund-raiser Lord Levy, it was announced yesterday.

Lord Levy - the prime minister's envoy to the Middle East - has featured in several media reports detailing his tax payments.

The two hoax calls came to light during an inquiry at the inland revenue into the leaking of Lord Levy's tax returns to the Sunday Times, which revealed that he had paid just £5,000 income tax last year.

An inland revenue spokesman said: "On June 9 and 23, calls were made to an inland revenue office by someone falsely claiming to be Lord Levy."

He said that the inland revenue had ascertained that the caller was not Lord Levy, but declined to say whether the documents passed to the DPP included the identity of the impostor. Press Association

Lord Levy - the prime minister's envoy to the Middle East - has featured in several media reports detailing his tax payments. The two hoax calls came to light during an inquiry at the inland revenue into the leaking of Lord Levy's tax returns to the Sunday Times, which revealed that he had paid just £5,000 income tax last year. An inland revenue spokesman said: "On June 9 and 23, calls were made to an inland revenue office by someone falsely claiming to be Lord Levy." He said that the inland revenue had ascertained that the caller was not Lord Levy, but declined to say whether the documents passed to the DPP included the identity of the impostor. fields.headline: BBC man moves to Telegraph
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC legal correspondent Joshua Rozenberg is to leave the corporation after 25 years to become a newspaper journalist for the first time at the age of 50.
fields.body:
The BBC legal correspondent Joshua Rozenberg is to leave the corporation after 25 years to become a newspaper journalist for the first time at the age of 50.

In a surprise move, Mr Rozenberg is joining the Daily Telegraph as legal editor in the autumn, after 15 years covering legal news for BBC radio and television.

He graduated with a law degree from Wadham College, Oxford, and was an articled clerk with a firm of solicitors when he decided to apply for a job as a BBC news trainee.

He finished his remaining exams and qualified as a solicitor after joining the BBC, but never practised as a lawyer.

In 1984 he launched the BBC Radio 4 series Law in Action, now presented by the Guardian columnist Marcel Berlins, and was appointed legal correspondent in 1985. Married to the Sunday Times columnist and former Guardian journalist Melanie Phillips, he is the author of several books about the legal system, including The Case for the Crown, a study of the role of the director of public prosecutions; The Search for Justice, a critical guide to the English legal system; and Trial of Strength---subtitled "the battle between ministers and judges over who makes the laws"

Mr Rozenberg is to replace Terence Shaw, who is retiring as legal correspondent after more than 30 years.

The new legal editor said it would be "a wrench and a challenge" to leave the corporation after such a long career in broadcasting but he felt he would always wonder what he had missed if he turned down the chance to work for a daily paper. "There are fewer than half-a-dozen jobs in daily legal journalism and they don't come up very often."

He said that he hoped to continue broadcasting for the BBC from time to time. A message to BBC staff from the head of newsgathering said: "We hope he will continue to be a regular contributor to our programmes."

webTitle: DNA to identify Chinese lorry victims

fields.headline: DNA to identify Chinese lorry victims
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
UN report
fields.trailText: Detectives trying to identify the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry in Dover are to fly to China to take DNA samples from those who fear they have lost their loved ones.
fields.body:
Detectives trying to identify the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry in Dover are to fly to China to take DNA samples from those who fear they have lost their loved ones.

Four police officers and a forensic specialist have received permission from Beijing to travel in the next fortnight to the Fujian region where the dead are believed to have come from.

Kent police said yesterday they had provisional identities for 42 of the young victims. Only after taking mouth swabs from parents or next of kin and matching it to the DNA of the victims will a final identification be made.

Days after the grim discovery in Dover docks last month, Chinese police officers arrived to assist Kent police in identifying the dead, who had tried to enter Britain illegally.

Kent police confirmed yesterday that they had provided pictures of the dead to Chinese authorities, but said they had no knowledge of reports that these had been displayed on posters in villages in Fujian province.

Kent officers were helped in the identifications by the only two survivors.

Their lives are believed to be in danger from leaders of the smuggling ring, and they are being housed under police guard.

Members of Britain's Chinese community said the insistence on checking the immigration status of anyone coming forward to identify the victims was scaring people off.

In a letter to Wah-Piow Tan, a London based lawyer contacted by eight people who fear their relatives were among the dead, Kent police stated that anyone coming forward would have to have their immigration status checked.

Mr Tan said many of those were themselves in Britain illegally, facing removal or seeking asylum, and feared deportation to China if they came forward.

Mr Tan said: "I believe the British authorities are not taking into account the characteristics of the Fujian community which are either underground or are living in fear of officialdom."

Three people are facing charges in connection with the deaths. Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, is facing manslaughter and smuggling charges.

You Yi, 38, a chef, and Ying Guo, 29, an interpreter, of South Woodford, Essex, are jointly accused of conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK.

fields.headline: Japan to return nuclear fuel
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Britain has agreed to take back the plutonium fuel from Japan which was the subject of a document falsification scandal.
fields.body:
Britain has agreed to take back the plutonium fuel from Japan which was the subject of a document falsification scandal.

The Japanese trade and in dustry ministry announced in Tokyo that Britain would take back the strings of plutonium fuel made at the British Nuclear Fuels plant in Sellafield last year.

Details of the deal have yet to be released, but BNFL's chairman, Hugh Collum, told the MPs earlier this year that if it helped to restore the confidence of Japanese customers, the company would be prepared to accept the fuel back.

The company has a £300m plant to make similar mixed oxide fuel lying idle at Sellafield. Its main customer was supposed to be Japan and the company had to prove to ministers that it had enough orders to justify opening the plant.

The scandal, followed by a scathing report from nuclear inspectors about the safety culture at the plant, caused the government to abandon plans to part privatise the company and a management restructuring to win back confidence in its operations. Yesterday the government and BNFL would not comment except to confirm a deal was near.

webTitle: Acute mental hospitals in dire state, says consultant

fields.headline: Acute mental hospitals in dire state, says consultant
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Wards in acute mental hospitals were overcrowded and run by staff who felt ashamed to work in them, a consultant psychiatrist said yesterday.
fields.body:
Wards in acute mental hospitals were overcrowded and run by staff who felt ashamed to work in them, a consultant psychiatrist said yesterday.

Peter Kennedy, NHS chief executive for York and co-director of the Northern Centre for Mental Health in Durham, described patients as "lonely, bored and sometimes frightened" and said they were being failed by the system designed to help them.

Dr Kennedy said that, although 70% of mental health spending was devoted to acute care, the state of acute wards across the country was "dire".

On the final day of the Royal College of Psychiatrists annual meeting in Edinburgh, he told delegates that apart from overcrowding, access was often delayed, nurses were leaving and "hot bedding" - moving a new patient into a temporarily vacant bed - was increasingly common.

Dr Kennedy, who monitored conditions in acute wards in 20 NHS trusts in the north of England between last October and January, said patients often felt disorientated while nurses said they felt "fraught and understaffed", without the skills for the job thrust upon them; those deciding to admit someone to an acute ward were often those least equipped to do so, such as the family doctor or a junior doctor with a few months' experience.

Dr Kennedy said efficient mental health care in the community should be backed up by good in-patient care and added: "Hospital care is a victim of the success of community care. The best and most ambitious nurses work in the community and in-patient care is often ignored."

webTitle: Oasis star's wife says marriage is over

fields.headline: Oasis star's wife says marriage is over
fields.trailText: At one time they were Britain's most fashionable couple - splashed across the front of Vanity Fair under a union flag duvet - but now the ambassadors of 1990s Cool Britannia have split.
fields.body:
At one time they were Britain's most fashionable couple - splashed across the front of Vanity Fair under a union flag duvet - but now the ambassadors of 1990s Cool Britannia have split.

The actor Patsy Kensit last night announced her separation from husband, Oasis singer Liam Gallagher, bringing to an end their fiery three-year marriage.

As the band once heralded as the next Beatles watch their fortunes fade, Kensit - who was previously married to Jim Kerr, the lead singer of 1980s band of the moment Simple Minds - has finally decided the troubled relationship has run its course. She was yesterday seen loading items from the couple's £1.25m home in St John's Wood, north London, which is thought to have been put up for sale.

Gallagher, as famous for his rows as for his singing, has been through numerous temporary splits from Kensit. Last year she left home for a time and was reportedly in tears most days during filming of Janice Beard: 45 WPM.

The couple also separated 17 months into their marriage when Gallagher allegedly threw his wife and her son by Kerr out of their home. Gallagher himself was then turfed out last November after he disappeared for two days.

Kensit was also photographed kicking the door of her BMW after newspaper reports linked Gallagher to supermodel Kate Moss.

There were hopes the couple would settle down when Kensit gave birth to Lennon - named after Gallagher's Beatle hero - in September 1999. But a spokesman for Kensit last night said the split was final.

It is the third marriage breakdown for Kensit, who was also previously married to Dan Donovan of the band Big Audio Dynamite.

The strain between Gallagher and Kensit came to light in May when Kensit reportedly checked into hospital suffering from depression and anxiety attacks.

At the time she was said to be "emotionally drained" and, at times, too weak to leave the house.

More recently she has been seen without her wedding ring.

Earlier this year she pulled out of a film project because of a stomach bug.

Gallagher has recently been touring in Europe with Oasis and has spent much of the year out of the country on band commitments.

webTitle: Synod to ponder christenings as church-going falls

fields.headline: Synod to ponder christenings as church-going falls
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England general synod meets in York this weekend to consider how to attract young people to the pews, as statistics show attendances at a record low and christenings on the slide.
fields.body:
The Church of England general synod meets in York this weekend to consider how to attract young people to the pews, as statistics show attendances at a record low and christenings on the slide. Members of the Church's democratic body, which consists of lay as well as ordained members and bishops, attending the last biannual synod of their five-year term, will be confronted with statistical evidence of the established church's continuing decline - a matter of acute sensitivity.

Hence the urgency of this weekend's debate on a report calling for young people to be encouraged to participate more, and proposals to revise the currently unclear rules on christenings, including whether the children of parents who do not attend church should be allowed to be baptised.

With a fall of 1.5% between 1997 and 1998, the latest figures available, Sunday attendances appear to be down to 803,700 - fewer than 2% of the population. Attendances for all the major Christian faiths are in decline, though more Catholics attend Mass than Anglicans.

Although the number of people attending Easter services in the Church of England rose by 1.8% to 1,193,000 in 1998, the numbers attending Christmas services fell by 2.6% to 1,308,000.

Infant baptisms dropped by 6% during the same period, from 139,000 to 129,000, around one in five of the number of live births, although the number of teenagers and adults being baptised rose slightly. That trend is likely to continue, especially as the government is proposing to allow registrars to supervise baby naming ceremonies. The number of confirmations was also down.

The Church plans to alter the way it collects statistics, from a snapshot Sunday picture to averaging weekly attendances over the month of October, to take account of changing patterns of worship. The survey says that the current statistics "do not adequately reflect the whole ministry of the Church".

Church officials draw comfort from the fact that the number of students coming forward for ordination is rising, and that those attending services donate more, up 7% to an average £6.37 a week each.

Synod members also have to debate whether the Church should eventually allow women priests, first ordained six years ago, to become bishops, and whether appointing so-called flying bishops to oversee parishes where women priests are not accepted is working.

There are also proposals to reform the way the Church deals with errant vicars, moving from consistory courts to something more like employment tribunals. Although only three courts have been called in 30 years, in Kidderminster an evangelical vicar is defying the authority of the Bishop of Worcester over the latter's liberal stand on homosexuality.

webTitle: BBC's dome plan could be too late

fields.headline: BBC's dome plan could be too late
fields.standfirst:
The Millennium Dome: special report
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC and the firm that runs the London Eye appeared yesterday to have acted too late to save the troubled millennium dome with a theme park based on programmes such as Walking With Dinosaurs and EastEnders.
fields.body:
The BBC and the firm that runs the London Eye appeared yesterday to have acted too late to save the troubled millennium dome with a theme park based on programmes such as Walking With Dinosaurs and EastEnders.

The plan, led by the Tussaud's group and backed with £150m from a venture capital firm, envisages turning most of the dome into a visitor attraction based on the BBC's most popular shows. It would be expected to draw up to 2.5m visitors a year.

But as support grew behind the proposals, it seemed more likely that the dome would be handed to one of the two bids already shortlisted: government sources said both were "extremely robust". For the Tussaud's/BBC plan to go ahead ministers would have to reject the bid from the Japanese-backed Dome Europe group, which wants to improve the Dome's present attractions, and the plan by Legacy plc to turn the site into a centre for new business.

The Tussaud's plan, backed by the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, envisages turning 70% of the dome into a theme park called BBC@dome. Visitors could have a pint at the Vic on the EastEnders set, before moving into a life-size recreation of the Walking With Dinosaurs series. Sir David Attenborough's wildlife programmes could be recreated, and visitors could watch a news programme being put together.

The other 30% of the dome would be an urban entertainment centre called DomeTown Greenwich, featuring entertainment, bars, restaurants and shops. Entrance to this section would be free, while the BBC section would cost around £10 in off-season times and more than £20 at peak periods.

Michael Jolly, chairman and chief executive of Tussaud's group, which runs the Madame Tussaud's waxworks museum, the London Eye and Alton Towers, said its dome plans were the most imaginative. "What you need is an attraction with a clear vision and an identity. The wonder of television is that it's informative and entertaining, and it is something Britain does best. We thought that a very appealing thing to centre this on."

The group wants to be given the 48-acre dome site free, but the government could expect to receive up to £50m of the profits over five years.

The BBC would not invest any money in the venture, but could expect a share in the profits. Tussaud's envisages paying the BBC at least a six-figure annual royalties fee. The cash would help the BBC meet its commitment to finding £1.1bn either from savings or new ventures.

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, said the Tussaud's-BBC bid was imaginative, but he did not want to see any delay. It was a "bizarre twist," he said. "The last thing we want to see is the dome lying empty next year while the government and others squabble about what happens next."

fields.headline: Prescott given key party role
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to give John Prescott an enhanced role at the centre of the Labour party in an attempt to reassure party activists and core voters about the true direction of his government. Mr Prescott will be asked to act as the link between party and government
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to give John Prescott an enhanced role at the centre of the Labour party in an attempt to reassure party activists and core voters about the true direction of his government. Mr Prescott will be asked to act as the link between party and government, and as a first step will be placed on all key strategy committees chaired by Tony Blair.

The move will involve Mr Prescott downgrading his departmental responsibilities, even though he will remain in overall charge of the Department of Environment, Transport and Regions.

The switch will take place as soon as Mr Prescott's 10-year plan for transport is published later this month.

Mr Blair will announce the appointment today at a meeting of the Labour national policy forum in Exeter, where he will also emphasise the flow of investment set to pour into key public services through the spending review.

Mr Prescott will be placed on a range of government and party committees with the same status as the main party strategists, Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell.

His presence at the heart of strategy is clearly designed as a signal to party activists and core voters that their interests will not be forgotten in the run-up to the election.

Downing Street believes Mr Prescott has the political credibility to cut through the current cynicism and deliver effective messages on the government's record.

With the government being branded by Tory leader William Hague as "all spin and no substance", Mr Prescott is clearly seen as the antidote. He has never disguised his contempt for spin doctors and what he has called "the Clintonisation of British politics".

Downing Street is increasingly frustrated that its "narrative" has been lost in what it describes as "media hostility, obsession with soap operas and trivia masquerading as political coverage".

Mr Blair will tell the policy forum: "Government is tough but nothing worth doing is ever easy. But the reason for this government is economic stability, jobs, investment and reform in schools and hospitals.

"John is a party man through and through and he will be out there day in and day out, getting our message across, motivating the party to do the same as well as bringing in new members."

Mr Prescott will also be given an enhanced role co-ordinating the work of ministers and MPs. It is known that Millbank, party headquarters, believes too many ministers have gone native in Whitehall, neglecting their role as campaigning ambassadors for Labour in the regions. Mr Prescott, working alongside his close political colleague, Ian McCartney, will also have the authority to sort out any rivalries within Millbank.

The deputy prime minister who has recently complained that excessive New Labour sloganising annoys voters will also be making more radio and TV appearances speaking across the policy board.

Although government sources insisted the appointment did not represent the starting signal for a spring 2001 general election, others will see Mr Prescott's new role as a move in that direction. Mr Prescott will tell the policy forum tomorrow that it needs to remind itself that it has a government of which it can be proud, citing "a million jobs, massive investment in schools and hospitals, the minimum wage and the working family tax credit to make work pay.

"Now is the time to direct our attention and energy into ensuring that we retain the trust and confidence of the electorate so that they return Labour for a second term on the basis of our record of delivery."

Mr Blair will announce the appointment today at a meeting of the Labour national policy forum in Exeter, where he will also emphasise the flow of investment set to pour into key public services through the spending review. Mr Prescott will be placed on a range of government and party committees with the same status as the main party strategists, Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell. His presence at the heart of strategy is clearly designed as a signal to party activists and core voters that their interests will not be forgotten in the run-up to the election. Downing Street believes Mr Prescott has the political credibility to cut through the current cynicism and deliver effective messages on the government's record. With the government being branded by Tory leader William Hague as "all spin and no substance", Mr Prescott is clearly seen as the antidote. He has never disguised his contempt for spin doctors and what he has called "the Clintonisation of British politics". Downing Street is increasingly frustrated that its "narrative" has been lost in what it describes as "media hostility, obsession with soap operas and trivia masquerading as political coverage". Mr Blair will tell the policy forum: "Government is tough but nothing worth doing is ever easy. But the reason for this government is economic stability, jobs, investment and reform in schools and hospitals. "John is a party man through and through and he will be out there day in and day out, getting our message across, motivating the party to do the same as well as bringing in new members." Mr Prescott will also be given an enhanced role co-ordinating the work of ministers and MPs. It is known that Millbank, party headquarters, believes too many ministers have gone native in Whitehall, neglecting their role as campaigning ambassadors for Labour in the regions. Mr Prescott, working alongside his close political colleague, Ian McCartney, will also have the authority to sort out any rivalries within Millbank. The deputy prime minister who has recently complained that excessive New Labour sloganising annoys voters will also be making more radio and TV appearances speaking across the policy board. Although government sources insisted the appointment did not represent the starting signal for a spring 2001 general election, others will see Mr Prescott's new role as a move in that direction. Mr Prescott will tell the policy forum tomorrow that it needs to remind itself that it has a government of which it can be proud, citing "a million jobs, massive investment in schools and hospitals, the minimum wage and the working family tax credit to make work pay. "Now is the time to direct our attention and energy into ensuring that we retain the trust and confidence of the electorate so that they return Labour for a second term on the basis of our record of delivery."

fields.headline: Euan Blair receives police reprimand
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister's son Euan Blair was yesterday reprimanded by police for being drunk and incapable in London's Leicester Square.
fields.body:
The prime minister's son Euan Blair was yesterday reprimanded by police for being drunk and incapable in London's Leicester Square.

A Downing Street spokes-man said the 16-year-old had been accompanied by his father and mother to Kennington police station in south London.

Downing Street denied that Cherie Blair, known to be a disciplinarian, had cut short her holiday on hearing her son had been arrested on Wednesday night following an evening with friends to celebrate the end of GCSE examinations.

She returned home from a short break in Portugal with her baby Leo and her mother "at exactly the time she had always planned to come back", according to the spokesman. Asked whether Euan had been grounded, the spokesman said: "The prime minister and Mrs Blair are dealing with this in their own way."

The Blairs had been expected to accompany Euan to Charing Cross police station, where Euan was held on Wednesday night and at first gave a false name, age and address. The change was made to avoid reporters and cameras gathered at Charing Cross.

Downing Street stressed that the family had intended to go to Charing Cross until it became impossible for what they regarded as a private matter, that it was perfectly appropriate to use another station, and that they had received no special treatment at Kennington.

The spokesman would not confirm whether the boy had had to admit to the offence before being given the reprimand. However, the warning means he has escaped the more serious sanctions of a caution or prosecution.

According to reports, the reprimand will mean that Euan's case will be referred to the local youth offending team, which will consider whether he should take part in a programme designed to prevent him reoffending.

Mr Blair had looked strained and emotional on Thursday, before he was joined by his wife late that evening. His spokesman said yesterday that he was "perfectly fine", adding: "He has got a job to do; he has a family to bring up; and he will continue to do both to the best of his ability."

It was revealed, however, that Mr Blair followed his son's example on Thursday after one of the toughest days of his premiership. He stopped off for a pint of Harvey's bitter at the Duke of York in the village of Sayers Common, Sussex, on his way back to Downing Street after appearing before a Question Time audience in Brighton.

Landlord Martin Daly said: "He seemed just to want to unwind, which is understandable. He was a normal guy, really friendly and willing to chat.

"He didn't mention his son at all. I expect he just had a tough day and wanted a break."

webTitle: In the bag: Thatcher icons draw big money

fields.headline: In the bag: Thatcher icons draw big money
fields.standfirst: Sotheby's Spitting Image sale
fields.trailText: If internet auctions are a measure of popularity then Margaret Thatcher is enjoying something of a renaissance.
fields.body:
If internet auctions are a measure of popularity then Margaret Thatcher is enjoying something of a renaissance.

A potential buyer has bid more than £1,400 for a Spitting Image puppet of Lady Thatcher which is being auctioned over the world wide web.

In a separate internet auction, her black Ferragamo handbag has drawn an offer of £200,100 from an American nightclub owner. The handbag includes a signed note from the former prime minister.

More than 200 puppets and 100 sketches from the ITV show Spitting Image are being sold by Sotheby's on behalf of Roger Law, one of the show's creators. The auction house hopes the sale will raise at least £100,000.

Puppets of John and Norma Major have attracted a bid of £1,600, compared with £1,000 for Tony and Cherie Blair.

Other puppets attracting large bids included £1,330 for the Queen.

Mr Law said he hoped the sale would raise enough money to buy a surfboard and to make the down payment on his house on Bondi beach, Sydney. He was glad to be getting rid of the puppets. "There isn't a sentimental bone in my body," he said.

He also hoped to interest several museums in housing some of his puppets, which need to be stored at a constant temperature.

Handbags are being auctioned by the website handbag.com to raise money for a breast cancer charity. Lady Thatcher's is exciting by far the most interest in the auction. A tinsel bag once owned by the GMTV presenter Lorraine Kelly had yesterday attracted only £82, while a pink suede shopper owned by the fashion journalist Trinny Woodall had reached only £60.

The puppet auction at the Sotheby's Spitting Image sale on Amazon.com runs for another two weeks. The handbag auction finishes on July 13.

webTitle: Straw offers five choices over future of fox hunting

fields.headline: Straw offers five choices over future of fox hunting
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw announced yesterday that MPs and peers are to be given five options to decide the future of fox hunting, ranging from an outright ban to maintaining the status quo, when a parliamentary bill is introduced later this year.
fields.body:
Jack Straw announced yesterday that MPs and peers are to be given five options to decide the future of fox hunting, ranging from an outright ban to maintaining the status quo, when a parliamentary bill is introduced later this year.

In a commons debate on the Burns report on hunting the home secretary confirmed that the bill would be introduced in November's Queen's speech and that MPs and peers would be given a free vote.

The options in the government bill will include:

 A wide ranging ban on fox hunting;

 Retaining the status quo;

 A more limited ban to restrict the hunting of particular species or to take account of geographical differences between, for example, lowland and upland areas;

 Tighter regulation of hunting through a new licensing authority;

 Holding a series of local referendums on a ban.

Mr Straw said the government had not decided the options because ministers wanted to hear the views of MPs. "But for [the bill] to be manageable it should contain no more than a handful, reflecting the broad proposals on all sides of the debate," he said.

MPs were on lively form for yesterday's debate, with pro and anti-hunting MPs trading insults. The former Tory minister Nicholas Soames claimed that the Burns inquiry had concluded there were no good policy grounds to ban hunting with dogs.

Coining one of his Soamisms, Churchill's grandson rounded on "polytechnic-bred louts" who wanted to "spit on a piece of Olde England". He said their behaviour contrasted with the tolerance and "generally civilised" manner of British democracy envied the world over.

"There still remains in this land in many places a richness and colour that is truly and wholly unique - hunting is a part of that," he said. "All those, from wherever they come in the UK, who believe that to be the case will fight to the end to see that it is not cast aside."

His eulogy to "Olde England" prompted the former sports minister Tony Banks to cry out: "Gawd bless you squire."

Gordon Prentice, the Labour MP for Pendle, insisted that the Burns inquiry had confirmed his view that hunting was repellent. "The key conclusion of the Burns report is that hunting with dogs compromises the welfare of the hunted animal. It is cruel," he said.

 The second Severn crossing linking England and Wales was closed yesterday by police due to a demonstration by pro-hunting activists.

An Avon and Somerset police spokeswoman said members of the Rural Action Group attempted to close both bridges but officers managed to control the protest, leaving the old bridge open.
