fields.headline: Scotland laments 11pc fall in visitors
fields.standfirst: Tourism is bigger than oil, gas or whisky for the Scots, but the number of overseas holidaymakers continues to decline
fields.trailText: They play bagpipes on Scottish street corners for small change and smiles from the summer visitors. It is a fixture of the season, like festivals, caravans and midges. Only these days there are fewer people to perform to.
fields.body:
They play bagpipes on Scottish street corners for small change and smiles from the summer visitors. It is a fixture of the season, like festivals, caravans and midges. Only these days there are fewer people to perform to.

Figures out yesterday show an 11% drop in the number of overseas visitors to Scotland over the last year and an overall 1% drop in tourism over the year, despite a rise in the number of Scots holidaying at home. It is the fourth year in a row that business is down.

And holiday money counts for Scotland. Tourism brings in £2.5bn a year and is one of the country's biggest industries, employing one in 12 of the workforce; more than the oil, gas and whisky industries combined.

The trade, however, has been in decline for a number of years and is now officially in crisis. Despite a recent re-launch by the Scottish executive, and the loyalty shown last year by homegrown holidaymakers, industry operators and analysts say the country's future as a global tourism contender has never looked bleaker. Beyond its borders, Scotland is just not selling.

Tourism officials are quick to blame the strong pound, the cost of petrol in rural areas, and emerging overseas markets. Anything but the product, says George Kerevan, an economics consultant and a former tourist authority head.

"The problem is not currency volatility," he said. "It always comes back to the quality of the experience. People will come if you are selling something worthwhile. And we still don't have the quality, whether it be food or accommodation. If you go to a small town in Burgundy you might find the best restaurant in France. If you go to a small town in Scotland you will not get the best."

A year ago, a group of MPs produced a withering report on the Fawlty Towers standards of some Scottish tourist businesses, examples of which included a hotel with sticky lino in the bathroom, unhelpful staff and a lack of disabled access.

George Kerevan says there is little sign of widespread improvement since then, a problem compounded by the structure of the trade.

"There is a fog of organisations, but no great clarity on what we want to do," he said. "The competition increases every year. It is quite clear we have been trounced by the Irish and every year that goes past Eastern Europe is becoming a bigger threat. The answer is not more plans or more administration or strategies, but the industry waking up to itself."

At the Herrislea House Hotel near Lerwick in the Shetland islands, Gordon Williamson says he has no option but to drum up trade himself. He pays thousands of pounds a year to the local tourist authority, but gets less than 1% of his business through their efforts.

"An awful lot can still be done to promote tourism. We need much more aggressive marketing, better direct marketing," he said. "Some of the wildlife tour operators here have had huge successes in the last couple of years. We need more specific targeting."

This week, the Herrislea was full, but business travellers outnumbered tourists two to one.

"The tourist numbers are down terribly," said Mr Williamson. "There's the strong pound and people have plenty of money to go abroad. It's good value for money for them, but the same can't be said for here."

The Scottish Tourist Board, meanwhile, admits Scotland is not a cheap holiday option, but claims the industry is making great strides to improve and adapt to a changing and challenging market.

"I don't think the industry is in crisis," said a spokeswoman, Barbara Clark. "It is an industry that needs support and needs to be marketed as much as possible."

A 20% rise in the number of Scots holidaying at home marks a recovery in the domestic market. She credits the shift to an aggressive marketing campaign urging Scots to take short breaks on home soil. "Maybe it also reflects a new pride in Scotland, with its new parliament," she said. "People want to learn about and visit their own country."

The slump in overseas trade, she says, is not unexpected and can be blamed partly on weakened European currencies. "People don't get as much for their Deutschmark here as they used to get."

Other industry analysts, however, say Scotland is badly served overseas. Only around half of its 15,000 tourist businesses are online. The rest rely on campaigns by the STB, which operates with a £7.5m budget, and the British Tourist Authority.

"E-commerce and IT is crucial to the future success of the industry and there is a real awakening to that," said Riddell Graham, of the Scottish Borders Tourist Board. "Our message to the operators is competition has never been greater. If you sit still you will get left behind."

George Kerevan, however, says the trade has done little to try to catch up.

"There is a self-satisfaction in the industry. They sell a Scotland they feel comfortable with rather than trying to create a product that suits the market.

"We still sell the twee B&B image; idea that folk are going to come here and look at the views and be satisfied. But people want quality, they want to be comfortable and if you don't give them that, then they'll go elsewhere."

Hits and Misses

What works

The scenery: Mountains, lochs, moorland, coast.

The family tree: Trace ancestors and wear your tartan.
Top attractions:
Edinburgh Castle attracts 1.2m visitors during Hogmanay celebrations.
Gretna Green is second with 700,000.

Golf: Invented here. Annual hordes come to worship at St Andrews.

What doesn't

The cost: The strong pound, price of rural petrol and crippling internal air fares give you less for your buck.

The food: For every choice venison steak there's a lumpy scone and a pot of weak tea.

The accommodation: Substandard hotels and guesthouses are still commonplace.

The practice: Complacency and a confused administrative structure prevents the message getting through.

webTitle: Police to get powers to keep soccer thugs in Britain

fields.headline: Police to get powers to keep soccer thugs in Britain
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: A V-sign, an offensive tattoo and a drunken chant while waiting for a plane or a train could be sufficient for a police officer to stop a football fan leaving the country under the details of the home secretary's legislation to clamp down on hooliganism published yesterday.
fields.body:
A V-sign, an offensive tattoo and a drunken chant while waiting for a plane or a train could be sufficient for a police officer to stop a football fan leaving the country under the details of the home secretary's legislation to clamp down on hooliganism published yesterday.

But the draft football (disorder) bill makes clear that the police officer will have to justify to a magistrates court within 24 hours his decision to stop the football fan leaving the country by providing evidence that "the person involved had caused or contributed to any violence or disorder".

Lord Bassam, the Home Office minister, said yesterday that he believed the emergency legislation to be rushed through Parliament this month would bring about a change "in culture, attitude and atmosphere" that surrounds some of England's football games abroad..

Lord Bassam said most football fans travelled abroad a couple of days before international games and so would not miss the match if they were wrongly detained. Officials later confirmed that compensation would be available for those who were wrongfully detained. The police will be able to present evidence of the violent or rowdy past of those they stop. The evidence can include video footage, deporta tion orders or a record of being thrown out of football grounds in England and Wales.

As the details of the legislation were published, the Football Supporters' Association warned that innocent supporters could find themselves banned under the new laws. "These proposals give us very considerable cause for concern," said the FSA's chairman, Malcolm Clarke. "The determined, clever troublemakers will don a suit and briefcase and go through alone, while groups of genuine supporters with replica shirts and tattoos could be stopped travelling wrongly."

He said supporters had to be given time to properly challenge a ban.

The chances of the legislation reaching the statute book in time for England's next international game in Paris on September 2 depend upon the co-operation of the Conservatives.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday sat on the fence about the extent of her party's support for the bill, saying that its proposals would have to be examined carefully. "We share the government's desire to see an end to the menace of football hooliganism and will support sensible measures brought forward to curb this problem," she said.

The draft bill gives police a new summary power to issue a notice preventing a British citizen from travelling abroad to attend a football match if there "are grounds for believing that the person has previously caused or contributed to any violence or disorder, or if the person's behaviour suggests that enquiries should be made to check whether or not there is evidence to that effect".

Banning Orders

The bill abolishes the distinction between domestic and international banning orders. A football banning order can be issued if it is shown that "the person has previously caused or contributed to any violence or disorder in the UK or elsewhere". The violence and disorder does not necessarily have to be football-related and can involve conduct which falls short of constituting a crime under British law. The order can also be issued if "there are reasonable grounds for believing that a banning order would help prevent football related violence or disorder", ie if there is police intelligence against an unconvicted person.

The bill makes clear that the definition of disorder is quite widely drawn and includes stirring up racial hatred, using threatening or abusive words, and "displaying any writing, sign or other visible representation which is threatening, abusive or insulting", which could even include a tattoo. Evidence that would be taken into account includes being deported from another country or being thrown out of a football ground in England or Wales. There will be an appeal to the crown court.

Banning orders will also be made when hooligans are convicted of a relevant offence. Those who are sent to prison for football-related offences can be banned for between six and 10 years. For those convicted of such offences but not sent to prison, the ban will last from three to five years, and for those convicted of other violent or disorder crimes it will last between two and three years.

"The determined, clever troublemakers will don a suit and briefcase and go through alone, while groups of genuine supporters with replica shirts and tattoos could be stopped travelling wrongly." He said supporters had to be given time to properly challenge a ban. The chances of the legislation reaching the statute book in time for England's next international game in Paris on September 2 depend upon the co-operation of the Conservatives. The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday sat on the fence about the extent of her party's support for the bill, saying that its proposals would have to be examined carefully. "We share the government's desire to see an end to the menace of football hooliganism and will support sensible measures brought forward to curb this problem," she said. The draft bill gives police a new summary power to issue a notice preventing a British citizen from travelling abroad to attend a football match if there "are grounds for believing that the person has previously caused or contributed to any violence or disorder, or if the person's behaviour suggests that enquiries should be made to check whether or not there is evidence to that effect". Banning Orders The bill abolishes the distinction between domestic and international banning orders. A football banning order can be issued if it is shown that "the person has previously caused or contributed to any violence or disorder in the UK or elsewhere". The violence and disorder does not necessarily have to be football-related and can involve conduct which falls short of constituting a crime under British law. The order can also be issued if "there are reasonable grounds for believing that a banning order would help prevent football related violence or disorder", ie if there is police intelligence against an unconvicted person. The bill makes clear that the definition of disorder is quite widely drawn and includes stirring up racial hatred, using threatening or abusive words, and "displaying any writing, sign or other visible representation which is threatening, abusive or insulting", which could even include a tattoo. Evidence that would be taken into account includes being deported from another country or being thrown out of a football ground in England or Wales. There will be an appeal to the crown court. Banning orders will also be made when hooligans are convicted of a relevant offence. Those who are sent to prison for football-related offences can be banned for between six and 10 years. For those convicted of such offences but not sent to prison, the ban will last from three to five years, and for those convicted of other violent or disorder crimes it will last between two and three years.

webTitle: 50,000 join Joey Dunlop on last lap

fields.headline: 50,000 join Joey Dunlop on last lap
fields.standfirst:
Massive tribute to road-racer who stayed people's champion
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David McGee peeled back his leathers and rolled up his sleeve to reveal his tribute. There, tattoed on his forearm, was the motorcyling legend Joey Dunlop, in trademark yellow helmet with black stripe, riding his Honda No 3.
fields.body:
David McGee peeled back his leathers and rolled up his sleeve to reveal his tribute. There, tattoed on his forearm, was the motorcyling legend Joey Dunlop, in trademark yellow helmet with black stripe, riding his Honda No 3.

Mr McGee, 27, a well-built fisherman from Killybegs across the Irish border in Co Donegal, was hardly the type with whom anyone would choose to trifle. So it was strangely affecting to see him quickly turn away, embarrassed, to avert his brimming eyes.

He was in good company in Ballymoney, Co Antrim, yesterday. Hundreds of hard men cried, and most did so without shame.

Northern Ireland hosted its largest funeral in almost 20 years yesterday in a staggering tribute to a man scarely known outside his native land or the world of motorcycle racing. Police expected 50,000 to turn up, and think that was an underestimate.

Protests over the Drumcree stand-off even came to a halt yesterday as heads were bowed in tribute.

Motorcyclists began arriving at dawn, from as far afield as Australia, New Zealand, Japan and South Africa, and they rode in noisy formation, turning the air blue with exhaust fumes. So many stood in the tiny country lanes around Dunlop's modest bungalow that when the cortege finally moved off, it was impossible to move.

As Dunlop began his last lap to the tiny Garryduff Presbyterian church, the applause began, tentatively at first. It was to ripple every step of the way, as the undertakers took an hour to carry him through the suffocating crowds and complete the mile-long trip.

Alan Watts, 31, a builder from Sligo, tried to explain. "Joey Dunlop was extraordinary, yet still remained ordinary. He was the most brilliant of motorcycle road-racers ever - we all know that - but he remained the same down-to-earth guy.

"I saw him last at the Isle of Man TT races three weeks ago, when he was under real pressure, and he still had time for everyone. He was welcoming fans into the paddock and chatting happily with them.

Dunlop, 48, was the last of the so-called Armoy Armada to die. His friends Mervyn Robinson and Frank Kennedy, the other members of the trio named after the nearby village where they were brought up, died in races long ago, and many thought Dunlop indestructible. He died last Sunday at a road race in Tallin, Estonia, two weeks after he won a hat-trick of races at the Isle of Man TT, taking his tally to 26 victories since 1977.

Ballymoney civic leaders granted him a civic reception and crowds clapped him around the town as he toured in an open-topped bus. He was faintly embarrassed, and his eyes were glistening as he said nothing could get any better than this.

David Cretney, the Isle of Man's tourism minister, turned up then, all chuckles as he announced an honorary knighthood for Dunlop. He broke down yesterday as he delivered the funeral eulogy.

Dunlop's racing career began in 1969. He won five world championships and hundreds of races. Dunlop's final victory came in a 600cc race in Tallin a week ago, and he was out in front on his 125cc when he lost control the next day and smashed into a tree. He died instantly.

Northern Ireland loves road-racing, the only place it is allowed in the United Kingdom, but they adore a people's champion even more.

Dunlop's pub, Joey's Bar, was festooned with flowers yesterday. Bikers queued to lay tributes and read messages left by others as Linda Dunlop and her five children buried their husband and father.

His cortege had been delayed for six hours as it ran into road blocks throughout Northern Ireland on Tuesday night.

Mrs Dunlop, in the church where she and her childhood sweetheart had recently renewed their marital vows on their silver wedding anniversary, listened as John Kirkpatrick, honorary chaplain to the Motor Cycle Union of Ireland, paid handsome tribute to his friend. In victory, he was self-effacing, and in defeat, generous.

But mourners were instead recalling Dunlop's own words. He said in his understated way: "I never really wanted to be a superstar. I just wanted to be myself.

"I hope people remember me that way."

webTitle: 'You need a sense of humour to be the PM's child'

fields.headline: 'You need a sense of humour to be the PM's child'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The drunken antics of the prime minister's son may have come as a shock to Tony and Cherie Blair, but to the offspring of former premiers and cabinet ministers it was just typical teenage behaviour.
fields.body:
The drunken antics of the prime minister's son may have come as a shock to Tony and Cherie Blair, but to the offspring of former premiers and cabinet ministers it was just typical teenage behaviour.

Carole Thatcher and her twin brother, Mark, endured years in the media spotlight as the children of Margaret Thatcher.

"You need quite good shock absorbers and a good sense of humour to be the prime minister's child," she said. "Everyone's been going on about the pressures, but there are also some privileges and perks. Euan, after all, had his 16th birthday party bash at Chequers, which is a pretty nice place."

The Thatcher children were quick to learn that media intrusion "came with the territory", however. "When my mother was education secretary, I was a student and I got more digs about that than when she was at number 10," said Carole Thatcher.

Catherine Smith, the daughter of the late Labour leader John Smith, also first encountered problems as a student. She told Channel 4 news: "You did find yourself watching what you said and watching what you did in certain company and in certain situations.

"Children at the age of 15 or 16 aren't interested in politics and having a politician in some ways is actually quite uncool. I know that I have been drunk and without doubt disorderly from time to time and I think young Mr Blair hasn't done anything different from what any other politician's son or daughter has done in the past."

John Major's son James, then only 20, became the subject of tabloid scandal when his affair with a married woman 12 years his senior was exposed. And in 1997 William Straw, son of the home secretary, Jack Straw, agreed to supply cannabis to a tabloid newspaper reporter.

But politicians have faced far worse consequences of their children's over-indulgence. Last year, the son of the then Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney, High, was found dead from a heroin overdose at the age of 23. In 1986, Olivia Channon, the 22-year-old daughter of the then Tory minister Paul Channon, died from a cocktail of champagne and heroin - as did Piers Shore, the 21-year-old son of the then Labour cabinet minister Peter Shore in 1977.

Although Hilary Benn MP, the son of veteran Labour MP Tony Benn, has also spoken in the past of the "exasperation" of having as father a famous politician - he also appreciated the benefits. "One of my most vivid memories is being allowed to stay up and have supper with Prime Minister Harold Wilson. I was just nine."

Denis Healey's position as defence secretary certainly impinged on his son Tim's student drug-taking days. "I smoked some dope in my student days, but when I did so, I routinely fell prey to panic," he once recalled. "You know that painting by Munch, The Scream; that kind of panic. In its grip, I imagined my student companions to be Trotskyite provocateurs, CIA agents or KGB stooges out to get at my father through me."

But many children of politicians have emerged unscathed. Victoria Scott, the disability campaigning daughter of former Tory disability minister Nick Scott, hit the headlines in 1994, when she called for him to resign over his opposition to the Disability Bill.

Now 34, Victoria said: "When I was growing up, dad was just a junior minister and nobody was particularly interested in what I did. It was never ever suggested that I should behave in a certain way because of what my dad did. There were moments when I thought 'I shouldn't do that, because it might reflect badly on my dad', but because he was my father, not because he was a politician. I think children will always embarrass their parents. If they don't, you're doing something wrong."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Why is it that, among fields, scattered trees, remnant hedgerows and field drain ditches, the best wildlife site is a square of land trapped between two housing estates and scheduled for more building? We stood in the middle of a wetland, wellingtons stirring rolling clouds of mud silt across the submerged ground, and surveyed the array of sedges, rushes and flag iris in this hidden corner of the borough.
fields.body:
Why is it that, among fields, scattered trees, remnant hedgerows and field drain ditches, the best wildlife site is a square of land trapped between two housing estates and scheduled for more building? We stood in the middle of a wetland, wellingtons stirring rolling clouds of mud silt across the submerged ground, and surveyed the array of sedges, rushes and flag iris in this hidden corner of the borough.

Hidden that is, from the prying eyes of naturalists and conservationists, but not from the local youngsters. They ride their mountain bikes through the mud, across the humps and hollows around the wetland and amongst the stands of ox-eye daisy, bird's-foot trefoil and clover.

They also come each spring with their buckets and collect newts, protected great-crested ones and the more common smooth newts. Nobody has told them you need a licence from English Nature to fondle the ugly, warty newt that has caused so much stir in conservation versus development battles. Why should they care? It is a piece of waste land as far as they can see, belonging to nobody, but is a great place to play. Actually, it belongs to the local council and the prospect of housing is real.

Kevin, who lives close by, cares enough to telephone me and ask how we should protect the site. That is why I am standing there now, scratching my head, watching whirlygig beetles careering around in the dizzy dance below the spike-rush stems. A tiny water cricket, just two millimetres long, scuttles across the water's surface tension.

Homes have to be built somewhere and if not here, where? No doubt there will be plans to move the newts to another pond. Cramming all our wildlife into a handful of sites is not conservation; it is creating concentration camps. They may suggest a small pond in the centre of the development. That would be nice, a feature. It may put £5,000 on the value of each house, maybe more. It won't be a wetland, though. That would be too untidy, too messy.

fields.headline: Ban on Orange march upheld
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The parades commission, the independent body which rules on contentious marches in Northern Ireland, yesterday rebuffed a late initiative from Portadown Orangemen and stuck to its decision to ban them from walking the nationalist Garvaghy Road tomorrow.
fields.body:
The parades commission, the independent body which rules on contentious marches in Northern Ireland, yesterday rebuffed a late initiative from Portadown Orangemen and stuck to its decision to ban them from walking the nationalist Garvaghy Road tomorrow.

Security forces are preparing for the worst, despite a reduction in the intensity of violence across Northern Ireland since Wednesday. The RUC said yesterday that there had been 145 attacks on police and army over five nights, including 12 guns attacks.

The Orangemen's legal representative told the parades commission that they were prepared to agree to the conditions it had laid down on Monday as the price for a march within eight months. But they were only prepared to do so if tomorrow's parade from Drumcree church into Portadown got the go ahead first.

The parades commission had stipulated the Portadown Orangemen had to call an immediate halt to protests at Drumcree and elsewhere. They also had to engage with the nationalist residents through South African lawyer Brian Currin's mediation efforts and in any civic forum.

While the commission last night rejected the move, the offer appeared to break new ground, with it clear now that the Portadown Orangemen are prepared to negotiate with the commission, against Orange Order policy. It also suggested they were moving towards talks involving the Garvaghy Road residents' coalition.

The commission said it was encouraged at the Orangemen's offer, and it also said after meeting residents that there was a genuine desire to find a solution. But yesterday's developments are too late to prevent conflict tomorrow.

Amid some signs of optimism, Harold Gracey, Portadown district master, sounded a hardline note. He refused to condemn the violence which has afflicted Northern Ireland this week and said he had no regrets over calling for province-wide protests.

Mr Gracey said: "I am not going to condemn violence because Gerry Adams never condemns it. I am not saying I am happy with violence. I never have been and anyone who knows me knows that.

"But the Protestant people of this country and the loyalist community are sick of what is happening to this country. They have been for 30 years."

Breandan MacCionnaith, spokesman for the Garvaghy Road residents, decried the Portadown Orangemen's initiative, calling it tired old rhetoric from tired old men.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson said the commission had set out a road map towards for an Orange march later this year. He pleaded with both sides to keep talking.

The RUC said 37 of its officers and two soldiers had been injured in this week's street violence. There had been 140 petrol bomb incidents, with 268 primed petrol bombs seized by security forces.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Andrew Lowe, Commercial director, Fleming Premier Banking
fields.trailText: Andrew Lowe, Commercial director, Fleming Premier Banking
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

When I joined TSB Commercial Banking in 1992 at the age of 26.

What has been your best moment in management?

Firstly, selling the Flemings/Save & Prosper credit card book to MBNA in 1998. Secondly, firmly positioning Fleming Premier Banking as a "value added" telephone bank for both the personal and business needs of professionals.

What was your greatest mistake?

Waiting until the end of the recession in the early 90s before taking a full-time MBA at Cranfield School of Management.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Persuading a large, traditional financial services company to invest tens of millions in marketing something that would lose hundreds of millions and calling it egg.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

When they don't challenge me as much as I challenge them.

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?

No - whether you're male or female makes no difference - it's talent that counts.

What management wisdom do you find most overrated?

Biggest is best.

What is the big business issue of the next decade?

Management, in both mind and body, keeping pace with IT developments.

What one lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?

Set yourself goals then plan and act to reach them.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Michael Porter, who said: "Only the lowest cost provider can compete on price." Many businesses - both large and small - would do well to remember this.

Who is your management hero?

Alex Ferguson, although I support Bolton Wanderers.

Who is your favourite politician?

Ken Livingstone, but I'd never vote for him.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

"That's BOLLOCKS!"

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Walking on a mountain in the Lake District with my friends.

What annoys you most?

Lack of purpose.

How do you relax?

I lie on my settee and watch TV with a cup of coffee.

What was your last cultural experience?

The Graduate - the play starring Kathleen Turner.

What is your favourite city?

Prague.

Do you have a favourite website?

No - they're all too busy.

What is your greatest regret?

Not knowing my late grandfathers.

What would you really like to have been?

I told my headmaster at 11 years of age that I wanted to be a banker ...

webTitle: Aids: Welcome to the land of the dying

fields.headline: Aids: Welcome to the land of the dying
fields.standfirst: With rampant Aids and without western drugs, Africa has lost all hope: South Africa hosts a summit this weekend.
fields.trailText: With rampant Aids and without western drugs, Africa has lost all hope: South Africa hosts a summit this weekend.
fields.body:
Malita Maxwell has Aids. But so does just about everybody else in the women's ward of Chiradzulu hospital, with its busted air conditioner, smell of old, sweet urine and greasy mattresses covered in bright green plastic.

In the administrator's office, Margaret Kalanda is discussing her staffing difficulties. Two nurses have died of Aids and haven't been replaced. She has also lost a laboratory technician, an electrician and two hospital attendants in the last year. Mrs Kalanda is a graduate of Chancellor college at the University of Malawi. Of her class of 20, three are dead and two are ill with aids.

James Morris, the morgue attendant, knows what is happening in this town in south Malawi. But it could be any town in southern Africa where an entire generation are going to their death. After the first sickness from Aids the average Malawian is dead within five years. The women are dying in their 20s, weakened to the virus by childbirth. The men are lasting until their 30s.

They all die without any chance of treatment with expensive Aids drugs that could give them another 10 years of life.

Mr Morris keeps his morgue well, washing it out every morning with a green garden hose he leaves hanging on the white-washed wall smelling of bleach. The bodies are stacked up until they have two ambulance loads - one going north and one going south. They wait for a job-lot to save on petrol. "I had two teachers last month. Seems to be more ladies these days. Six ladies to every four men I'd say. They have a baby and then they seem to die."

Surrounded by the silent, swollen and festering faces of the dying, you cannot help feeling for Malita Maxwell. She is 25 years old and walks stiff as a puppet through the ward, trying to keep the running infection in her legs and groin from rubbing against each other. She was recovering from the death of her son, who lived for a year before her virus killed him. Then her immune system, crushed by Aids, fell to a wild angry thrush that invaded her body.

Nurses say they cannot treat her raw, infected sores until she has washed herself with saltwater. She has no money to buy salt. "I sent a message home that I was in hospital so they could come and see me but no one has come." Here patients don't survive without relatives to feed them - the hospital cannot. The government is broke. On the radio at lunchtime the news in English includes an announcement that a Japanese delegation is donating a printing press to the National Bank and a message of congratulations to the Malawian government for its excellent record in paying off its debts to the World Bank and the IMF.

Malita Maxwell stands in the middle of the hospital ward with two Panadols in her hand, the only treatment there is. "Someone has taken the bed," she says.

When she dies - and it will be soon - she will leave behind three orphaned children. By the end of this year, Africa will have 12.1m orphans.

In Durban, South Africa, tomorrow, 9,000 delegates will meet for a UN Aids conference. The primary call for change will be an appeal to drug companies, such as Glaxo Wellcome, which have sold more than £2bn of anti-Aids drugs in the last two years to the first world.

"The thing about the big pharmaceutical companies is that there are no competitors to encourage them to reduce the price. They know that the people are dying here but they don't care. They can charge what the want, so they can charge £100 a month for treatment in the UK and just forget about countries like these," says Elisabeth Poulet of Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), the aid agency leading the campaign in Durban for pharmaceutical companies to bring down prices.

Masida Davila, a 40-year-old accoun tant, is also dying of Aids. His wife died five years ago and he has sent his only child, an 11-year-old girl, to boarding school. It is a Catholic convent and he hopes they will protect her when he dies. Even though he has not long to live he sees her only once every three months so she will not miss him so much. "She is on my mind all the time. How do I look after my daughter?"

Mr Davila earns £60 a month and cannot pay for the Aids drugs that could give him another 10 years. He is in a race against Aids and for time to provide for her. "I'm buying shares for her. This month I bought a thousand shares," he says.

Mr Davila, in his smart green linen suit, buys shares, while Malita Maxwell cannot afford salt, but both are excluded from the world of treatment. By the year 2010 the average person in Malawi will live only to the age of 30, according to the latest report from the UN.

"The emphasis is on saving the children, the next generation, but saving them from what - unless we keep the parents alive there will be nobody to bring them up," says Dr Poulet.

At 6.30am, as the town bell rings for the healthy to rise, the women are already drying the tobacco leaves under rusting corrugated iron roofs. The smell of bougainvillea, which produces flowers all year round and supplies the wreaths, is in the air. The Rev Hesbesa is attending two to three funerals a days. He is in a good mood today: "Not a single funeral." But late in the evening he gets a call.

Gracie Awafie died last Sunday night on a mat made of cardboard laid out under a tree. She slowly choked to death, a combination of tuberculosis and laryngitis - two of the diseases that infect Aids patients. In the last hours her face puffed up like an adder in a last battle against the infections. Cheap drugs were available to treat the infections but her grandmother, an old woman who cannot walk, could not get her to hospital. "The whole support structure has collapsed," she says.

"I'm glad to have visitors," she said a couple of hours before Gracie died. "It's hard being with her all day on my own - in and out. One minute she wants to be inside, one minute she wants to be out."

Hard words but then Arume Awafie had already nursed her daughter to death from Aids and buried her great-granddaughter. "We are going to run out of grandmothers soon," says Monique van de Kar, who also works for MSF.

With powerful anti-Aids drugs such as AZT out of reach in Africa, the country must rely on the condom. But sex and reproduction are part of a culture that encourages promiscuity. Africa is about survival. Breeding to ensure your own survival. It is a culture where marriage parties, harvest festivals, graduations all come with sex. And the introduction of the condom has not been easy. There has been little help from the churches.

The Catholics, Pentecostalists, Presbyterians and Seventh Day Adventists are all saving souls, building churches and water systems and running literacy classes but they refuse to endorse condoms.

Gods flock on earth has so far been reduced by some 31m by Aids. The Rev Howard Mbeza of the Presbyterian church next door to where Malita Maxwell is dying says: "We don't discourage them. Let's just say we keep silent. But we tell the people they must abstain from sex before marriage and they shouldn't commit adultery."

In Malawi 10 years ago, when the Aids virus was rampant and ignored by a stern Presbyterian president, young girls were taken out into the bush and prepared for married life. The ritual involved sex with a single man elected by the vil lage elders, a man of experience who could prepare them for marriage and infect the next generation of women. The practice still goes on in some parts of the country.

The name of the elected man, the Faesis , means hyena. The tradition that allowed an entire village of 14-year-old girls to be initiated by one man also dictated that: a widow should be cleansed by sex by an outsider to clear her home of spirits; in the last months of a pregnancy and for the first six of a new born's life a woman should allow her husband to seek other partners; and a young woman who was still a virgin could not sprinkle salt on a salad. In such a culture of sexual dictates, multiple partners and women without power, Aids has triumphed.

The Aids counsellors' door is painted sky blue but is smeared with the dust of years of African summer and no money for new paint. Outside room 13 Malita Maxwell waits for her counsellor, Angela Makata - a luxury provided by MSF, which also keeps the hospital running.

"She accepted that she was positive she just wanted to know what I could do to help her with her pain. Her weeping raw sores. I couldn't get anything stronger than Panadol for her. The doctor has gone to America and has n't been replaced and the clinical officer in on a course," she says.

Malita Maxwell, her mattress still missing, has wandered outside to lie on the concrete, wrapping herself in a thin cotton cloth of buttercup yellow.

"I really feel angry. The western world is making a mockery of us. They do have the drugs but they sell them to Africa for exorbitant prices so nobody can afford them. People are in fected and they are waiting to die. They are living in a world of hopelessness," says her counsellor.

For some, the only hope lies in denial. In a private room off the women's ward is Mary. Her mother is a teacher and she is a computer programmer who designed CD covers as a hobby. Her boyfriend was a presidential bodyguard. "He was small like me but handsome," she says. Now he has disappeared, gone to Botswana without her.

All the signs are that she is HIV positive - but she doesn't want a test. "My blood sugar level is low. I think it is TB. They want me to stay here for two months but I'll give it a month. It's a bit depressing here. I want to go on to do advanced computer studies."

The covers she designs are for country and Western CDs. Her favourite song is called Making Plans. "It's Dolly Parton and it's called Making Plans to Live," she says.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The career management mantra of the 90s was You plc. If organisations could no longer offer certainties, then individuals should remove their commitment. The career intelligent viewed themselves as assets whose investment value was in creased by careful choice of employer.
fields.body:
The career management mantra of the 90s was You plc. If organisations could no longer offer certainties, then individuals should remove their commitment. The career intelligent viewed themselves as assets whose investment value was in creased by careful choice of employer.

A decade on, the language of careers is moving into another area of business activity - marketing. Career management will be increasingly about managing one's individual brand.

Asking a group of managers to consider the brand qualities of products as diverse as Coca-Cola and Irn Bru shows that few products have a universal audience. The global impact of Coca-Cola is aimed at youth; the fierce loyalty of Scots to Irn Bru leaves most English drinkers perplexed.

Managing a brand well is about defining the audience and ensuring that its loyalty is maintained by anticipating its needs, staying relevant and positioning it appropriately.

The audience grew nostalgic as they ate their KitKats and Smarties. As they renewed childhood associations the emotional power of brands was realised, as was the limitations of just focusing on the functional attributes of the product. When functional attributes are replicated so rapidly, the power of emotion is enormously powerful. Put the two together and a brand is unbeatable. Lose the emotional connection with the customer and, as Marks & Spencer is discovering, it's a tough road back.

With careers, the attention given to competences in recent years has been a means for the organisation to control performance outcomes, but it is an insufficient predictor of personal outcomes. The emotions generated by an individual's interpersonal style can overshadow or enhance abilities in the same way as products with similar qualities can have different customer perceptions.

Lucozade was once a tonic for ill-health in childhood, but has been repositioned as a source of replacement energy for the physically active. Staying in tune with the labour market is less about acquiring new skills than assessing the market value of those skills and identifying new markets where they will have higher currency.

As the e-commerce job market explodes, with demand far outstripping supply, those who can leverage the value of their existing skills for a new market make more rapid career advances than their previous employment would have allowed.

The trick is to know which attributes are really valued. People need to understand what are the perceived strengths and limits of their personal brand. That means developing skills in asking for feedback, which have often not been well developed in a culture which prefers inference to straight talk.

Asked to choose between a range of high street suppliers of electrical goods the managers struggled. The lack of differentiation on customer service and product knowledge means that the only factor driving their choice is price. The price boards at store entrances inviting comparison with competitors suggest they accept that, to customers, they are just commodities. As such, they have an air of vulnerability.

People who cannot identify a differentiator between their offering and those of colleagues are in the same position as the car insurance market, where little loyalty is expected and renewal is price dependent. The challenge is to develop a personal brand so that it has the invulnerability of Heinz baked beans: many competitors, but still an enduring presence on the supermarket shelf.

Carole Pemberton is managing consultant at Career Matters

webTitle: Learning to work in corporate colleges

fields.headline: Learning to work in corporate colleges
fields.standfirst: Professor Colin Carnall of Henley Management College looks to a future where companies' own education programmes achieve true excellence
fields.trailText: Professor Colin Carnall of Henley Management College looks to a future where companies' own education programmes achieve true excellence
fields.body:
Everyone in higher education, and human resources directors in major plcs, has heard of corporate universities and that 1,600 or more have been established globally.

The US has taken the lead, and hundreds of such universities have been set up there by companies including Disney, Motorola and Mcdonald's. In the UK we have had the Unipart University for some years and BAe Systems' Corporate University and the Ernst & Young Virtual Business School. Companies like Ford have long had education programmes.

But the phrase "corporate university" is just a label. A much more fundamental change is under way: should we focus on providing knowledge irrespective of its usefulness? Should we be concerned about applying knowledge through professional practice?

There are long-established models, like medical schools, where education and work are integrated. The key is the greatly enhanced focus upon value, as well as professional development, personal effectiveness, and management development. The corporate university seeks to integrate the concern to educate, develop new knowledge and "give people qualifications" with a desire to gain individual and corporate value from the investment. This includes a real shift from a corporate body (business or university) deciding what education is to be provided, towards putting learners in the driving seat.

Universities and business schools are right to see these changes as important parts of an emerging competitive landscape. One observer has noted that while the average cost of classroom tuition in the USA is $60 per hour, the average cost of delivering the same material by modern technology is as little as 6 cents per hour. A survey of deans of corporate universities in the US suggests that by 2003 up to 75% of their education will be delivered by intranets, satellites and video-conferencing.

Will UK universities be able to rise to the challenge? Are they big enough? More fundamentally, can they lead their faculty towards a vision of education that is life-long and delivered "virtually" or "just-in-time" anywhere in the world to high standards of delivery and value?

There are contradictory pressures. The drive towards accreditation, quality assurance and so on, while right for the medium term, creates a short-term focus on meeting criteria not always consistent with long-term goals. Any director of an executive education centre will tell you that the needs are very different from the needs of a university business school delivering MBA programmes. Some can do well in both worlds, but they are few.

These are big questions. They need to be viewed in a rather uncomfortable setting. The reputation of university business schools is patchy. While some schools are perceived as excellent, the reputation of the sector is not generally high. There has been and continues to be substantial growth of in-company education to meet specific needs.

While the MBA market remains strong, distance learning provision represents a considerable proportion of the market. There is a negative attitude toward the traditional approach of "classroom-based teaching". Decision-making for corporate sponsorship of any education is increasingly decentralised. Major corporates seek to work in enduring partnerships. They can see real advantage in working with a small number of universities and business schools over time such that in-depth knowledge and experience of a firm and its development can be woven into the education delivered to their people. More and more there are cost pressures from companies as they seek to show the value added by education to others in the business.

So it seems likely that the next 20 years will see a shift from a plethora of universities toward the emergence of knowledge delivery systems which cut across traditional boundaries. There will be rapid emergence of new technologies which will lead to changes from classroom to technology, the workplace and action learning. Tutors will be coaches and participants more active learners.

But there will still be substantial demand for the gurus providing leading-edge knowledge. Technology will not replace all face-to-face work; a new integration will emerge. And here is the opportunity for some schools to achieve world-class status.

The challenge faces both employers and universities. Here is the opportunity for collaboration; less emphasis on government funding and more on collaborative working will help UK universities face the challenges with confidence.

Henley Management College's report: Corporate Universities - Learning Partnerships for the Future -costs £25 and can be ordered from Julie Terney on 01491-418811 (email Juliet@henleymc.ac.uk).

fields.headline: Keeping wolves from the door
fields.standfirst: Holiday time is here and thousands of empty homes make tempting targets for burglars. Elizabeth Langton lists defensive measures
fields.trailText: Holiday time is here and thousands of empty homes make tempting targets for burglars. Elizabeth Langton lists defensive measures
fields.body:
At this time of year thousands of holidaymakers prepare to make a break for the sun, leaving their homes empty and hence vulnerable to burglars.

For city-dwellers, switching on the alarm is as much part of their departure ritual as locking the front door. By contrast, homeowners living in the countryside have always felt safer than their city cousins.

But the days when rural residents could go out without locking the door are over. A rise in thefts from rural homes and businesses heralds a shift in rural crime trends, insurance company NFU Mutual warned this week.

Even homeowners who think their property is secure should be on guard, says the company. "The rise in domestic theft does lend weight to the theory that improved security in urban areas combined with the country's extensive motorway network, is leading thieves to believe there are easy pickings in rural areas" Sid Gibson, NFU Mutual underwriting manager told visitors to this year's Royal Show.

The cost of thefts from rural homes and businesses rose 6% last year to an estimated £168m. Crime is now top of rural dwellers list of worries, says the company. Rural life has got so bad that fear of crime has led to a siege mentality in some people.

But NFU Mutual acknowledged that the chances of being burgled in the countryside are still lower than in urban areas. However, certain types of households are at greater risk of burglary. Topping the victims list are single parents living with children, followed by young households and those living in the inner cities or poorly maintained areas.

Four out of five burglaries occur when the house or flat is empty, according to police statistics. Last year more than 460,000 households were burgled in England and Wales according to official figures. Burglary offences make up around a fifth of all property crimes.

Combating burglaries has been a priority for many police forces, particularly those covering urban areas with high levels of deprivation. A raft of anti-crime initiatives has helped cut domestic burglary by 20% since 1997. But there is no room for complacency. After steady falls in the number of burglaries taking place - they have fallen to their lowest rate in 10 years - figures out this week from the Home Office show the offence is on the rise again in London.

Across the country rates vary widely. Between April and September last year, Greater Manchester topped the table with 18.7 burglaries per 1,000 households, compared to 12.6 in the area covered by the Metropolitan Police. Residents covered by Cambridgeshire's force suffered 9.9 break-ins per 1,000 households compared to 5.2 in Surrey.

Most burglaries are not planned but carried out on the spur of the moment and two-thirds of intruders gain entry using a rear window or door. Those unlucky enough to have been victims once are still vulnerable. Research shows that once a home has been robbed it is likely to be targeted again, sometimes within a few days.

Insurance company Royal & Sun Alliance and the West Midlands police have joined forces to encourage homeowners to cut their chances of being burgled. They have published a booklet, Knowing Your Home, which advises householders to put themselves in a burglar's shoes and walk around their property looking for ways in which to break in. There is also detailed advice on security measures residents should consider.

Making a home secure may be common sense but it can be costly. This month's Which? magazine called in a security expert to estimate the cost of security improvements to one member's home. The recommendations included a new back door, five-lever mortice locks, window locks, a gate at the side passage, repairs to fence panels and a burglar alarm at a total cost of more than £1,300.

Installing a professionally fitted burglar alarm could add a further £1,000 to the bill plus an annual maintenance charge. A DIY version can be had for just under £200 although residents will need to possess electrical skills to fit the system.

There is plenty of advice available for the security conscious including a Home Office's website. The two associations that regulate companies installing alarms - the National Approval Council for Security Systems and the Security Systems and Alarms Inspection Board - will supply the names of approved companies.

But people of other nations living in both town and country can set off for their hols with greater peace of mind. England and Wales top the international league table for domestic burglaries, higher than the United States and four and a half times higher than Germany.

www.nacoss.org.uk Knowing Your Home, available via website.

fields.headline: Summer wine still fizzing
fields.trailText: West Yorkshire is just one of many areas in the UK that has seen dramatic variations in property prices on a town-by-town, even street-by-street basis.
fields.body:
West Yorkshire is just one of many areas in the UK that has seen dramatic variations in property prices on a town-by-town, even street-by-street basis.

While the average price of a terraced house in the county currently stands at £40,000, it rises to well over £60,000 in parts of Leeds, and plummets to just a fraction of this amount in other areas.

Terraced properties in Huddersfield, which are often bought to let to students, sell for as little as £15,000 and have seen little or no change in value over the past two or three years, says Alex McNeil of Halifax surveyors and estate agents Bramleys. Meanwhile, a three-bedroom semi-detached house in the town currently sells for around £58,000 compared with £55,000 a year ago.

And in the nearby village of Holmfirth - known to millions of television viewers as the setting for Last Of The Summer Wine - a three-bedroom cottage will typically go for around £80,000 against £72,000 last year.

Mr McNeil says that two years ago there was an extended boom in the south, and the north fell behind. Around six months ago the market in the south started to cool, although it has certainly not collapsed, while the northern market is still active. "The north-south gap has started to close but it is still wider than it has been since 1997," he adds.

In the Halifax area the market has slowed in the past few weeks - Mr McNeil thinks this may simply be due to the onset of summer.

It is very definitely a seller's market, with a shortage of quality properties in good areas. Houses are being snapped up within days, with few sales for significantly less than the market price.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Editor joins Tory shortlist
fields.body:
Editor joins Tory shortlist

The editor of the Spectator, Boris Johnson, has joined lawyers Jill Andrew and David Platt on the shortlist to succeed Michael Heseltine as Conservative candidate for Henley at the next election. Final selection will be on Thursday

Shed porn dealer jailed

A housewife guilty of running an international porn operation from her garden shed was yesterday jailed for three months at Swansea crown court. Sharon Thomas, 41, sent out catalogues advertising illegal CDs and videos from her home in St Clears, west Wales.

Police look for pimping mother

Police are looking for a woman charged with controlling a prostitute believed to be her 16-year-old daughter, since placed in care. The two were seen touting for business among Liverpool kerb crawlers.

BBC fears loss of Beatles film

A recording of the Beatles' sole live appearance on Top of the Pops has gone missing from the BBC archives. It is feared that Paperback Writer and Rain, filmed in 1966, might have been erased in a 70s clear-out.

Lutyens Pimple up for sale

South West Water is to sell a building by Sir Edwin Lutyens. The Pimple, 25ft long and 25ft high, a triangular structure full of pipes, was commissioned as an entrance to an underground reservoire on Whitchurch Down, Devon, in 1914.

fields.headline: Dimbleby bull is rescued
fields.trailText: A navy helicopter rescued a £600 Hereford bull belonging to BBC TV presenter Jonathan Dimbleby, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A navy helicopter rescued a £600 Hereford bull belonging to BBC TV presenter Jonathan Dimbleby, it was revealed yesterday.

The animal tumbled into a ditch near Dimbleby's farm near Bath, Somerset, and struggled to scramble free.

Firefighters were unable to get a winch to the 14-month-old pedigree, which was stranded more than half a mile from the nearest road.

Mr Dimbleby joined farm workers, RSPCA officials and two fire crews in an effort to haul the bull to safety. But when that failed an RAF Sea King helicopter was scrambled to winch the creature out of the tree-lined ravine.

The rescue, which lasted about four hours, involved 20 people and is estimated to have cost around £20,000.

Mr Dimbleby said yesterday: "I owe a huge debt of gratitude to the emergency services and the fantastic skill of the helicopter pilot. I would be happy to make an appropriate donation to the three key bodies involved. I would say that's the least I can do for the help we received."

webTitle: Lottery scheme directs more aid to deprived town

fields.headline: Lottery scheme directs more aid to deprived town
fields.trailText: An experiment in boosting lottery grants to deprived areas has hit its target two years early, scoring a huge rise in applications, grant awards and the success ratio of local bids.
fields.body:
An experiment in boosting lottery grants to deprived areas has hit its target two years early, scoring a huge rise in applications, grant awards and the success ratio of local bids.

The Brass for Barnsley pilot scheme run by the national lottery charities board has brought £3,400,000 to the South Yorkshire town in its first year, far exceeding the target of £3m in three years.

Intensive surgeries, promotion and a revival of the voluntary sector have also seen a 150% rise in local applications for lottery money, from a moribund rate which helped trigger the experiment last year. Over half (56%) were successful during the year, against a national success rate of 37%.

Janet Paraskeva, the board's director for England, said: "Perhaps the most important achievement is that community groups, helper agencies and local government are now working together in Barnsley to develop a better future for the voluntary sector."

Although difficulties with complex forms have been widely blamed for lottery grant shortfalls in deprived areas, the board found a weak voluntary sector to be more significant - particularly in coalfield areas, where local councils and British Coal had dominated grant-making and social welfare for decades.

The Barnsley pilot was prompted by concern at a mismatch in lottery funding, whereby a vicious circle operated in towns such as Barnsley while grants poured into areas with well organised voluntary sectors, including London and most of the large regional cities. Action was taken when Barnsley repeatedly came 17th or lower in Yorkshire's league table of grants, while ranking fifth in terms of social and economic deprivation.

fields.headline: Union pays £140,000 over expenses case
fields.trailText: Marcia Solomon, the whistleblower who alleged that union leader Roger Lyons was involved in thousands of pounds of expense fiddles and had used false bank accounts to obtain cash, won a £50,000 tax free payment in a £140,000 out of court settlement yesterday.
fields.body:
Marcia Solomon, the whistleblower who alleged that union leader Roger Lyons was involved in thousands of pounds of expense fiddles and had used false bank accounts to obtain cash, won a £50,000 tax free payment in a £140,000 out of court settlement yesterday.

The deal was made by the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union after the employment tribunal chairwoman, Enid Prevezer, halted the proceedings on Thursday.

Ms Solomon, who earned £19,500 in her former position as secretarial assistant to Nelson Mendes, the head of finance, was suing the union for wrongful and unfair dismissal. She claimed she had seen copies of cheques totalling nearly £35,000 from false union accounts payable to Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes and both had access to a £160,000 defunct account.

The deal involves the MSF union paying £50,000 plus VAT to cover the legal expenses of the GMB union, which defended its former shop steward. The MSF is also agreeing to take no action against any of its staff who acted as witnesses for Ms Solomon.

In a statement released yesterday the MSF said: "The par ties have agreed an out of court settlement. They each maintain their respective position but have agreed that it does not serve the interests of the members of both their unions to continue litigation."

Celebrating outside the tribunal, Ms Solomon said: "I regret having had to take the MSF to an employment tribunal as I always considered it to be an excellent organisation, not least in its campaign to provide protection for whistle blowers.

"However I maintain that I saw what I saw and acted in good faith when I brought my concerns to the attention of John Chowcat, the then assistant general secretary of the MSF. I therfore regard the settlement as a vindication of my position."

Richard O'Brien, the MSF spokesman, admitted the union could not continue because under the government's whistleblower legislation it had to prove that Ms Solomon had acted malicously. It is understood that it was over this key point that the chairman of the tribunal halted proceedings.

MSF maintains that Ms Solomon still had no evidence against Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes over the alleged £160,000 fraud and that the union's accountants, bankers and the independent trade union certification officer had cleared both men.

Mr O'Brien said yesterday that as a result of the hearing senior union officials were reconsidering their position on two former employees who are taking the union to tribunals. Howell John, a regional officer, is suing for unfair dismissal this month. Mr Lyons is also facing action from his former chauffeur, Bryan Keegan, for unfair dismissal after he won a £7,000 back claim for unpaid overtime.

The cost of the episode, including a £250,000 payment to Mr Chowcat and the commissioning of a report from the union's accountants, is thought to be around £500,000.

General secretary faces further tribunal allegations by chauffeur

When Tony and Cherie Blair entertained Roger Lyons at Chequers last month in their quest for trade union cash for New Labour, they could not have expected their dinner guest suddenly to become embroiled in allegations of fiddled expenses and false bank accounts.

Yet the climbdown in the Marcia Solomon whistleblower case by the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union has left unanswered questions about the way the union was run and how it spent its 400,000 members' subscriptions.

Allegations made during the hearing were in Ms Solomon's words " only the half of it". And Mr Lyons's former chauffeur, Bryan Keegan, made allegations in a document submitted to the tribunal, of how Mr Lyons and his family were driven about on private rather than union business.

Mr Keegan says he regularly took Mr Lyons's younger children to school, his daughter to work, and his boss and sons to Arsenal matches. He also disclosed that Mr Lyons has two vehicles paid for by the union: a Ford Mondeo for his wife, and an Vauxhall people carrier .

He says he once took Mr Lyons and his two sons to Hillsborough to watch Arsenal play Sheffield. After, he says, he drove Mr Lyons to a conference at Blackpool and his sons returned by train - using tickets the chauffeur had obtained the previous day using MSF rail warrants.

He alleges regularly chauffering Mr Lyons' Arsenal season ticket to friends' homes when the general secretary could not go, and twice taking Mr Lyons and his family to and from Heathrow and Luton airports on private holidays.

His most serious allegation contradicts Mr Lyons's evidence on the purchase of £831 worth of alcohol for a MSF national executive reception - which Mr Lyons told the union's accountants was spent entirely on union entertainment for the executive and the press. The chauffeur says he "carried four boxes of alcohol to his home, where I stacked them in his hallway".

A union spokesman confirmed Mr Lyons was regularly chauffeured to football matches, but said it was "a reciprocal agreement" with the chauffeur who could then go to his nearby home. He said he had no knowledge of the rail warrants or drink.

After the revelations in Ms Solomon's tribunal hearing, yesterday officially the union was maintaining that Mr Lyons had been totally cleared of breaking rules over the alleged use of thousands of pounds of expenses, and his actions were above board.

Yet an internal MSF memo submitted to the tribunal shows that two union figures believe the opposite. The memo by John Gardner and Bob Braddock, chair and vice chair of the MSF national executive's finance committee, said: "With regards to the general secretary, whilst we are disappointed to [sic] some of his actions he has taken, having taken legal and professional advice we reluctantly accept that the use of disciplinary procedure would not be appropriate in this instance. "

In a fortnight more allegations are expected when Howell John, a regional officer, goes to a tribunal. The chauffeur is also going to a tribunal and intends to make more allegations.

The union has spent large sums on other cases. Some £250,000 was paid to John Chowcat, former assistant general secretary, to prevent a hearing, and two weeks previously the union had paid £10,000 to its Northern Ireland officer, Joe Bowers to prevent another tribunal.

fields.headline: Politics made easy
fields.standfirst:
If you think of the parties as the Silly, the Sentimental and the Nasty it all makes sense
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: If you think of the parties as the Silly, the Sentimental and the Nasty it all makes sense
fields.body:
It's a man's life out there in the frontline of political commentary with its turf wars and thickets of verbiage. Insight's our game and analysis our trade as we read the runes, hunt the killer phrase and keep the show on the road. Suddenly the landscape looks strange. Isn't it a no man's land with one battalion looking shaky and another plain unworthy? There's competition but also consensus of view: a lower Labour majority next time and a Tory advance.

If views are similar it's because habits of thought are the same. Go to any West End first night and you'll see the critics in a huddle at the interval - terrified of getting it wrong. Political writing seeks the same consolation of the cartel - within an acceptable "margin of error". The pendulum theory dictates that if one party is in, the other must not be too far behind.

When a science gets to the end of the road it becomes too complicated for its own good. The subject matter may be as interesting as ever - but the conceptual tools can't do the job any more. Unreal distinctions come between the observer and the observed. The high priests of political observation today are rather like university teachers in the 17th century who still taught Aquinas and Aristotle although the world belonged to Galileo and Descartes: carry on scholasticism.

William of Ockham, that clever scholastic, proposed Ockham's Razor to avoid confusion. Don't multiply the categories of thought beyond the bare minimum necessary and you'll achieve clarity. I suggest an updated version. Williams's Blade offers new categories and discards old ones. British politics is simpler than we are made to think.

The British constitution has room for three effective parties. They are the Silly, the Sentimental and the Nasty. Their relationship to the officially recognised Liberal, Labour and Tory parties has been close - although political postmodernity has complicated matters somewhat. It is, however, always true that a governing party has to be considered respectable. These are not the shadows behind the reality. They are the reality.

The Liberal party's association with silliness is longstanding. It probably started when Sir Archibald Sinclair became its leader in the 30s. No party can be led by an Archibald and still be serious. The 70s saw the high point of Liberal silliness - a period when the beard ceased to denote gravitas. It was still powerful enough in the early 80s to annoy Dr David Owen and his SDP - an organisation whose respectability and lack of silliness anticipated the present condition of the Liberal Democrats.

It is possible to be silly and respectable. That is the habitual condition of members of the British establishment. But non-silly respectability is an important qualification for power. Mrs Thatcher's careful vowels exuded it in 1979. Losing respectability by 1990, the crazed termagant consequently lost power.

Sentimentality was the defining feature of old Labour's solipsism. It encouraged talk about "this great movement of ours" (TGMO) and involved a large number of anecdotes involving Aneurin Bevan. Respectability (Attlee, Gaitskell and Wilson, in his less-Artful Dodger moments) meant that TGMO could be a party of government. Silliness entered with the Bennery of the 80s - a development which also made nastiness possible.

Mr Blair is not thought to be nasty although he has said silly things about cashpoints and hooligans. His most important electoral card remains his respectability. He has also taught the Labour party not to be sentimental about itself. This may be why it has such an identity problem.

It is the point of the Tory party that it should be nasty. Tory nastiness has sometimes been necessary, but it is never a sufficient qualification for government. Toryism needs good enemies as well - sometimes, as "enemies within", it is happy to manufacture them. But the models on the present manufacturing line - gays, asylum seekers and dead Norfolk teenagers - aren't up to the job. They just can't excite the angry salivation needed to oil the battle-bus wheels. Bless.

Postwar Tories discovered that it was no longer respectable to be associated with 30s appeasement and mass unemployment. Macmillan's Edwardian facade and Heath's managerial modernity modified old nastiness while avoiding sentimentality about Conservatism. They were hardly TGMO men. Like most one-nation Tories they actively disliked their own party and put up with it as a pis aller.

Having elected Mrs Thatcher, the British electorate concluded she was nasty. Some thought that she was both nasty and doing dirty necessary work. The huge majorities of 1983 and 1987, however, were the result of a divided centre-left. Many Tories thought that nastiness was actually popular. This was a silly idea and Mr Blair is its beneficiary.

What happens next? Mr Hague has been through a phase of being regarded as silly. He has now embraced nastiness. Some forms of silliness and nastiness do indeed march hand in hand. Sentimentality about the sceptred isle's sovereignty - the John of Gaunt option - completes the Tory hat trick of a grand coalition of our three effective parties. But in 1997 the electorate wanted something that was neither silly nor sentimental nor nasty - and opinion polls hovering around upper 20s to low 30s at their height have not flattered the Hagueite alternative.

New Tory Lads court the unrespectable and, therefore, disaster. The shadow cabinet is a group of London-based middle class professionals. But they present themselves as brave strippers of imperial purple robes, Jacobins of the right standing up for the forgotten rights of a once deluded, but now disillusioned, petit peuple. This is a small way of business whose insincerity has yielded a modest profit. Mr Blair's bourgeois triumphalism cuts less ice. But the recrudescent Tory triumphalism will reawaken ancient and potent electoral hatred.

A shadow cabinet running scare campaigns is spoiling for a fight. But nastiness is only really relevant when there is a threat of social and economic meltdown. This is not the condition of Britain in 2000. Tory Trotskyism wants to create the revolutionary conditions which will justify its existence. Instead it just looks offensive - nasty as well as silly. There is more than enough material here to keep an anti-Tory coalition in place.

The Labour party did badly in May 1997 and can do better. Residual suspicion, now buried, that it was socialist meant that New Labour gained only 43.2% of the national vote. Its huge majority was the result of Labour/Lib Dem tactical voting against Tories. We remember the Labour-held marginals but forget the Tory ones. In 65 seats the Tory majority is less than 10% of the vote. In 59 seats the majority over Labour or Lib Dem is less than 5,000, Romsey showed Tories failing the respectability test.

Mr Hague can consolidate his core nastiness but little more. Mr Blair has to show that he is more than just not-nasty not-silly and unsentimental, that he is effective in policy as well as respectable in manner. Mr Kennedy's Lib Dems can take more seats from the Tories who, true to form, are cruising for a bruising. My blade rests.

Hywel Williams is a historian; his latest book is Guilty Men: Conservative Decline and Fall 92-97 (Aurum Press)
