webTitle: British banks set to freeze dictator's millions

fields.headline: British banks set to freeze dictator's millions
fields.standfirst: Nigeria asks for help to recover part of Abacha's stolen fortune
fields.trailText: The Nigerian government has formally asked Britain to freeze the bank accounts of the late military dictator General Sani Abacha who is alleged to have stolen $4.3bn during his five years in office from 1993.
fields.byline: David Pallister and Peter Capella, Geneva
fields.body:
The Nigerian government has formally asked Britain to freeze the bank accounts of the late military dictator General Sani Abacha who is alleged to have stolen $4.3bn during his five years in office from 1993.

In what is currently the world's largest case of known government corruption, the Nigerian authorities believe that up to $450m has been deposited by Abacha, his family and associates in some of London's leading banks.

The request, part of a world-wide hunt for the Abacha billions, is the latest in a series of disclosures which has exposed weaknesses in the international banking system's regulation of money laundering by corrupt politicians.

The size of the accounts identified so far dwarf those found by the Swiss authorities belonging to the former presidents Mobuto of Zaire and Marcos of the Phillipines.

Most of the British funds, in more than 20 accounts, are thought to be in branches of the HSBC, Barclays, Citibank, the French bank Credit Agricole-Indosuez, and subsidiaries of two Nigerian and four other European banks.

The sheer scale of the military junta's kleptomania only became apparent after Abacha's death from a heart attack in June 1998 while cavorting with three Indian prostitutes.

An investigations panel set up by the new government soon recovered nearly $1bn, much of it voluntarily handed over by his son, Mohammed, from accounts he held jointly with a London-based Nigerian businessman and former Abacha aide, Abubakar Atiku Bagudu. In confidential records of a prison interview conducted two months ago by British lawyers pursuing a separate civil litigation case against the Abacha family, Mohammed admitted that his fa ther had given him $700m in cash over a period of two years in bags and boxes. At times, he said, he had up to $100m in his house in the capital Abuja. A few weeks after Abacha's death, his widow was detained while trying to depart for Saudi Arabia with 38 suitcases full of foreign currency.

On Monday Liechtenstein's highest court froze accounts in three banks believed to be linked to Abacha and worth about $100m. This follows similar action in the past six months by the Swiss authorities who have frozen $750m lodged in 120 accounts in 11 banks. Some were held by Abacha's widow, Maryam, his brother, Abdulkadir, and the former national security adviser, Ismaila Gwarzo.

Swiss legal sources yesterday indicated that a first instalment of the frozen assets is about to be seized and returned to Nigeria within the next few days, marking the first time money has been recovered abroad.

Luxembourg has also frozen accounts worth $630m in the names of off-shore oil companies connected with two of Abacha's sons, Mohammed and Abba. Nigeria is also chasing assets held in Jersey, France, Germany, Austria and the United States.

Mohammed has been indicted in Switzerland with taking part in a criminal organisation, money laundering and fraud. He is being held in Kirikiri prison in Lagos charged with the murder in 1996 of one of the wives of Moshood Abiola, the winner of the 1993 presidential elections who died in prison. Swiss charges are also pending against Bagudu and Dharam Vir, an Indian businessman.

The Swiss investigating magistrate, Georges Zecchin, is expected to examine possible charges against Swiss financial intermediaries at a later stage of the investigation.

Abacha's sons - the eldest, Ibrahim, died in a plane crash in 1996 - and business associates were able to bank the money through British Virgin Island front companies or by failing to identify themselves as linked to the brutal dictator.

Officials at Citibank in London and New York, where the two brothers had deposited $107m, were criticised by a US Senate committee last November for failing in their checks on them. The New York branch was unaware of their true identity for three years.

In a reference for opening the New York account, a London Citibank official who had been dealing with the Abachas since 1988 when their father was army chief of staff, erroneously described Ibrahim and Mohammed as the sons of a "well-known and respected member of the northern Nigerian community ... I have found Ibrahim and Mohammed unfailingly charming, polite and, above all, reliable".

Nigeria estimates that of the $4.3bn, some $2.3bn was taken from the central bank, $1bn was awarded for contracts to front companies, and a further $1bn was extorted from foreign companies, some of them in Britain.

The OECD criticised British anti-corruption measures in a report published last month. The organisation's working group on bribery, which monitors an international convention which Britain signed in 1998, said it had "serious concerns on the applicability of UK law to bribery of foreign public officials", in the absence of explicit provisions to criminalise corruption abroad.

The British Bankers Association which chairs the joint money laundering steering group, said yesterday it was sometimes notoriously difficult to establish the beneficial owners of accounts.

webTitle: 'Have a go' minister nurses broken leg

fields.headline: 'Have a go' minister nurses broken leg
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair outlined his proposals to stamp out yobbism last week, a government colleague was taking a more practical approach on the streets of London.
fields.body:
As Tony Blair outlined his proposals to stamp out yobbism last week, a government colleague was taking a more practical approach on the streets of London.

Neither emerged from their noble endeavours unscathed, and in the case of Mike O'Brien, the junior home office minister and MP for North Warwickshire, he is nursing a broken leg. He became a hero for a day by intercepting an alleged shoplifter by sticking his leg out to trip him up as he ran past. He got back up and ran away pursued by a security guard and Mr O'Brien; but although the man escaped, he had dropped his car keys when he fell, and police were later able to trace and arrest him.

The MP, who went straight on to conduct a television interview, only realised later he had fractured his fibula. He has his right leg in plaster and will be on crutches for four to six weeks. He said of his exploit: "It is something anyone would have done, [the injury] is an inconvenience and nothing else; but they caught the man in the end, so I was able to have some small sense of satisfaction."

Mr O'Brien was following the example of his boss, home secretary Jack Straw, who once said citizens should take some responsibility for preventing crime, and has chased thieves he has come across.

webTitle: Brother may have seen kidnap van

fields.headline: Brother may have seen kidnap van
fields.standfirst: Local children take part in police reconstruction of last moments before schoolgirl Sarah Payne disappeared
fields.trailText: The brothers and sister of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne may have watched, oblivious to her plight, as their sister was driven past them in a white van in a country lane, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The brothers and sister of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne may have watched, oblivious to her plight, as their sister was driven past them in a white van in a country lane, it emerged yesterday.

Lee, 13, Sarah's eldest brother, noticed the van drive down the road towards their grandparents' home, in Kingston, West Sussex, as he struggled to catch up with Sarah, eight, who had run away from him through a cornfield after hurting herself in a game of "dinosaurs".

He turned back briefly to reassure his younger sister, Charlotte, six, who had also been hurt, and by the time they and Luke, 11, had reached the lane, just 250 yards from their grandparents' home, Sarah had vanished. Moments later, the van, which had turned around, drove back past them. The suspected scenario - which police stress does not eliminate other strands of inquiry - emerged as detectives staged a reconstruction of Sarah's last movements.

The mood was hushed as four local children, aged 10 to 13, trooped through the fields, alerting all, as one of their fathers put it, to the realisation that this could happen to anyone's child.

This was a girl who had been happily playing on ropes in a wooded area just minutes earlier - and whose brother was only two or three minutes behind her.

A week on from the day Sarah disappeared at 7.45pm, the official line is still that this is a "missing person's investigation", but there is little doubt in the minds of those on Operation Maple that they are dealing with an abduction by a paedophile. Moreover, while they profess the universal hope that Sarah is alive, many officers know their worst fears are likely to be realised.

Unprecedented case

The statistics are against them, and should Sarah be found alive and well, the case would be unprecedented. "In three quarters of abduction cases, the victims are killed within a few hours," said a senior detective.

"Having said that, we did have the scenario less than two years ago in Hastings, when two girls were found alive and well on the fourth day after being taken, but it would be unique if she was found alive after all this time."

The fear that the little girl had been abducted was in the minds of Sussex police officers from the time they received the call at 9.26pm last Saturday. Wary of leaping to the conclusions made in the Hastings case, when it was a day before police considered that the girls had been snatched, a detective superintendent was brought in two hours after Sarah vanished.

"They don't do that for a missing persons investigation," commented a senior officer. "Right from the start we were viewing this as a possible abduction."

By midnight Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley was ensconced in Littlehampton police station, poring over the details of the 300 people on the sex offenders register in Sussex, sifting the paedophiles from the rapists and flashers, and tapping into police records on other known paedophiles, convicted or released before October 1997 when the register came into force.

From the brief time-span, he knew that if Sarah had been taken, it was by a specific type of paedophile: a "predator", who snatches swiftly, rather than a "groomer", who acts after cultivating a relationship with a child. He concentrated on the immediate seven-mile division of Worthing and Littlehampton.

In the early hours of Sunday he came up with a list of potential suspects, and detectives began knocking on doors.

By Sunday evening one local man in his 40s had been arrested, and a second man, in his 30s, believed to be from Crawley, West Sussex, was arrested the next night. Both have since been released on bail, and police, who were last night still carrying out forensic tests on the first man's flat, are awaiting the results of DNA tests on his home and van.

With other forces directed to check high-risk offenders, and specialists from the National Crime Service monitoring paedophile bulletin boards on the internet, the searches of the fields around Sarah's grandparents' home continued.

By the end of Monday, specialist officers who had scoured the area within a 400- yard radius were confident she was not there and that her disappearance was unlikely to be accidental.

"As she's walking down the road towards her grandparents', on the left hand side she's faced with a very large hedge which has a very strong chain-link fence and on the other she's got a hedge carrying on to the end of the fields," said Superintendent Phil Clarke.

Fingertip search

"Every single inch has been fingertip searched and we haven't found a single piece of evidence she was there."

As officers continued knocking on the 150 nearest doors in the predominantly rural area, fields within a one-and-a-half mile radius were scanned by a helicopter using thermal imaging, to pick up the heat from the body of a child.

But the search teams, already distracted by hoax callers among the more than 2,500 people who have rung in, were also hampered by nature.

"One of the things we've found is that rapidly growing wheat fields also generate heat just like ourselves," said one officer. "But a dead person isn't considerably warmer than this. That's why we kept flying over and over to check that she wasn't there. I'd be foolish to say I was 100% sure, but a degree of certainty is very, very high."

As the question of where the youngster is hangs in the increasingly fraught atmosphere, police are trying not to think of their own children. "It hurts, of course it hurts, we are only human," said Detective Sergeant Sean Scott, one of two family liaison officers who are spending up to 19 hours a day with Sarah's family. He is himself a father.

"But, at the end of the day, we are trained police officers and it's only 3% of what they are going through."

They, of course, are Sarah's family, from Surrey, who, unable to eat or sleep, have described how every minute has seemed an hour.

"They are a remarkable couple, said DS Scott, shortly after Sarah's mother Sara, who throughout the week has appeared the rock of the family, broke down in public for the first time.

"But they, and everyone in the family, are united in the belief, which we all have to have, that Sarah is alive."

The fear that the little girl had been abducted was in the minds of Sussex police officers from the time they received the call at 9.26pm last Saturday. Wary of leaping to the conclusions made in the Hastings case, when it was a day before police considered that the girls had been snatched, a detective superintendent was brought in two hours after Sarah vanished. "They don't do that for a missing persons investigation," commented a senior officer. "Right from the start we were viewing this as a possible abduction." By midnight Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley was ensconced in Littlehampton police station, poring over the details of the 300 people on the sex offenders register in Sussex, sifting the paedophiles from the rapists and flashers, and tapping into police records on other known paedophiles, convicted or released before October 1997 when the register came into force. From the brief time-span, he knew that if Sarah had been taken, it was by a specific type of paedophile: a "predator", who snatches swiftly, rather than a "groomer", who acts after cultivating a relationship with a child. He concentrated on the immediate seven-mile division of Worthing and Littlehampton. In the early hours of Sunday he came up with a list of potential suspects, and detectives began knocking on doors. By Sunday evening one local man in his 40s had been arrested, and a second man, in his 30s, believed to be from Crawley, West Sussex, was arrested the next night. Both have since been released on bail, and police, who were last night still carrying out forensic tests on the first man's flat, are awaiting the results of DNA tests on his home and van. With other forces directed to check high-risk offenders, and specialists from the National Crime Service monitoring paedophile bulletin boards on the internet, the searches of the fields around Sarah's grandparents' home continued. By the end of Monday, specialist officers who had scoured the area within a 400- yard radius were confident she was not there and that her disappearance was unlikely to be accidental. "As she's walking down the road towards her grandparents', on the left hand side she's faced with a very large hedge which has a very strong chain-link fence and on the other she's got a hedge carrying on to the end of the fields," said Superintendent Phil Clarke. Fingertip search "Every single inch has been fingertip searched and we haven't found a single piece of evidence she was there." As officers continued knocking on the 150 nearest doors in the predominantly rural area, fields within a one-and-a-half mile radius were scanned by a helicopter using thermal imaging, to pick up the heat from the body of a child. But the search teams, already distracted by hoax callers among the more than 2,500 people who have rung in, were also hampered by nature. "One of the things we've found is that rapidly growing wheat fields also generate heat just like ourselves," said one officer. "But a dead person isn't considerably warmer than this. That's why we kept flying over and over to check that she wasn't there. I'd be foolish to say I was 100% sure, but a degree of certainty is very, very high." As the question of where the youngster is hangs in the increasingly fraught atmosphere, police are trying not to think of their own children. "It hurts, of course it hurts, we are only human," said Detective Sergeant Sean Scott, one of two family liaison officers who are spending up to 19 hours a day with Sarah's family. He is himself a father. "But, at the end of the day, we are trained police officers and it's only 3% of what they are going through." They, of course, are Sarah's family, from Surrey, who, unable to eat or sleep, have described how every minute has seemed an hour. "They are a remarkable couple, said DS Scott, shortly after Sarah's mother Sara, who throughout the week has appeared the rock of the family, broke down in public for the first time. "But they, and everyone in the family, are united in the belief, which we all have to have, that Sarah is alive."

fields.headline: Labour compromise on electoral system
fields.standfirst:
Deal would allow some proportional representation

Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's allies last night brokered a deal on electoral reform which will lead to a commitment in Labour's next manifesto to hold a referendum on modernising the system of elections to the House of Commons.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Nicholas Watt and  Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Tony Blair's allies last night brokered a deal on electoral reform which will lead to a commitment in Labour's next manifesto to hold a referendum on modernising the system of elections to the House of Commons.

The deal, which will lead to the party embracing the alternative vote (AV) system, will end an internal Labour row between supporters of proportional representation and traditionalists who want to maintain the first-past-the-post system.

However, the agreement, which was hammered out at Labour's national policy forum in Exeter, will come as a blow to the Liberal Democrats, who had been pinning their hopes on another system known as AV plus.

During yesterday's talks, which included the prime minister's close ally Lord Falconer, the Labour leadership agreed to continue to support the principle of a referendum on electoral reform. But the party refused to give its support to the more proportional AV plus system recommended by Lord Jenkins in his report on electoral reform.

The outcome will create tensions with Liberal Democrats who want voters to be given a choice between the Jenkins system and the existing first-past-the-post system in a referendum.

Supporters of AV say that it maintains the existing Westminster constituencies, while introducing an element of proportionality to elections. Under AV, voters register their support for candidates in order of preference. If no candidate receives more than 50% of votes, the last candidate is eliminated with his or her votes being redistributed.

The Lib Dems oppose this system because they say that it exaggerates swings at elections. If the last election had been held under AV, the Tories would have lost even more seats. Lib Dems believe that this would allow the Tories to mount a strong No campaign in a referendum, arguing that the reforms were designed to keep them out of Downing Street.

The Lib Dems support AV plus because it maintains the constituency link with Westminster, introduces a stronger element of PR and does not exaggerate swings. Under the Jenkins system, a smaller number of constituency MPs are elected under AV. There are then up to 100 other "county constituencies" which are elected on a top-up basis.

The motion agreed yesterday, for submission to a vote at the national policy forum tomorrow, states the party has "serious concerns about the acceptability of AV plus".

It adds: "It was strongly felt that the electoral system should retain the constituency link to ensure stable govern ment and take account of the proportionality of power. The final decision on the choice of electoral system for the Commons will rest with the British people in a referendum."

The motion will be tabled by the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, whose leader, Sir Ken Jackson, is a diehard supporter of first past the post. He claimed victory last night, saying: "This is good news for democracy. PR for Westminster is no longer a threat. Common sense has prevailed."

Tony Blair will use this weekend's policy forum to deliver a pep talk to party activists, warning them that they should not jeopardise the "great political prize" of the government's successful management of the economy.

In a speech to the forum in Exeter, he will say that the government can embark on the ambitious spending plans demanded by activists only if Gordon Brown maintains his strict handling of the economy.

webTitle: Israeli relief at spy's light sentence

fields.headline: Israeli relief at spy's light sentence
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Switzerland's supreme court has allowed a Mossad agent to return to Israel after it handed down a one-year suspended prison sentence on charges of espionage.
fields.byline: Peter Capella in Geneva and Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Switzerland's supreme court has allowed a Mossad agent to return to Israel after it handed down a one-year suspended prison sentence on charges of espionage.

The five judges found the Israeli, known as Issac Bental, guilty of acts committed illegally for a foreign state, of political espionage and of repeated use of false identity documents. A charge of illegal phone tapping was dropped at the end of the unprecedented week-long trial.

"The crimes were considerable. Switzerland's sovereignty was violated in a callous way," presiding judge Hans Wiprächtiger said. Bental was also barred from entering Swiss territory for five years.

The light sentence came as a relief to Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak. "The prime minister expresses his satisfaction with the sentence given to the Mossad man, which allows him to return to Israel immediately," a statement from Mr Barak's office said.

The bungled spying case was as much of a political embarrassment to Switzerland as it was damaging to Mossad. During summing up on Thursday, the Swiss deputy prosecutor, Felix Bänziger, said the aborted surveillance mission by Bental and four other Israelis in a suburb of Berne two years ago was unpardonable on behalf of a secret service with close ties to Switzerland. He said Israel should have asked for Swiss help, as it had done before.

Bental, who had admitted the charges, was arrested in February 1998 while he was installing a sophisticated bugging device in a block of flats used by the target of the surveillance operation, Abdallah El-Zein, a Swiss-Lebanese citizen suspected of having links with Hizbullah.

The other Israeli suspects escaped arrest because police did not realise at first that they were dealing with a spying mission. Bental was detained because he was carrying a diplomatic bag with technical equipment.

He was later released on $3m (£2m) bail, paid by Israel in return for a promise that the agent would return to Switzerland to face trial.

Defence lawyers had pleaded for an acquittal because Bental was only doing his job to stop terrorist attacks on Israel. "The danger of terror is omnipresent for Israel, its inhabitants and Jews," Ralph Zloczower, the defence lawyer, said.

Mr Zloczower described Bental as a "simple agent", a 45-year-old son of Jews who had fled Russia. He joined Mossad in 1990.

Mr Bänziger argued that the possible threat from El-Zein could not be regarded as an "immediate danger" to Israel. El Zein, a car salesman, apparently used the flat in the Swiss capital while he was taking care of the Ahl Al-Beit Islamic centre in Berne. He had denied any links with Hizbullah.

Mr Barak has attempted to reach out to other Mossad operatives, following rumblings of discontent during the last few days at the sight of their man on open view in a Swiss court. On Wednesday, Israel Radio reported that some Mossad agents had been prepared to refuse further missions if Bental were jailed.

Others are reportedly frustrated at a drop in further missions, and Mr Barak's rejection of some of their operations. Mr Barak's reputed caution - he has to approve all Mossad operations - has some basis. During recent years, Israeli agents abroad have been involved in a number of botched operations - including the notorious failed assassination attempt against the head of the Hamas Islamist movement in Jordan in 1997.

"The prime minister repeats his expression of appreciation for all of the people in the branches of security whose work exposes them to personal dangers for the sake of strengthening the security of Israel," Barak's statement said.

Despite some recent failures, experts on Israeli intelligence point out that the Mossad conducts some 500-600 operations every year similar to the one that went so badly wrong in Switzerland.

fields.headline: Ministers plan 50% increase in adoptions
fields.trailText: The government is planning an increase of up to 50% in adoptions to reduce the number of children living under local authority care, health ministers announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is planning an increase of up to 50% in adoptions to reduce the number of children living under local authority care, health ministers announced yesterday.

Their first step will be to set up an adoption register for England and Wales to improve the matching of children and potential parents. Local authorities with low adoption rates will be targeted for inspection and asked to explain why such a large proportion of their children stay in care.

This will be followed by a white paper later this year promising legislation to strengthen the rights of children during the adoption process and give prospective parents an opportunity of appeal if their attempt to adopt a child is refused.

Tony Blair launched the policy yesterday in the foreword to a report on adoption by the government's performance and innovation unit.

"Too often in the past adoption has been seen as a last resort," he said. "Too many local authorities have performed poorly in helping children out of care and into adoption. Too many prospective parents have been confused, or put off, by the process of applying to adopt, and the time the whole procedure takes."

The report said lack of transparency in the adoption process created "a climate of fear and distrust" which was deterring potential adoptive parents. Progress was hindered by restrictions on children from one local authority being adopted by a family in another.

John Hutton, the health minister, said the government would encourage single people as well as couples from all walks of life to come forward to adopt children.

There would be no weakening of safety standards in the selection of suitable adopters, but the government would set targets to increase the annual total of 2,500 children going forward into adoption by between 35% and 50%.

More than 55,000 children are in the care of local authorities, mostly with foster parents. The proportion placed for adoption varied from 1% in some areas to 15% in others.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said that she expected the government to back up its plans with an extra £100m in this month's comprehensive spending review. Half of that was needed to recruit and train potential adopters and half to support them in looking after children who often had painful backgrounds and special needs.

"Legislation must not be delayed until after the general election. It has to come in the next Queen's speech and it must impose a statutory duty on local authorities to provide post-adoption support to families and children," she said.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said that adoption plans should be drawn up for all children who have been in care for more than a year.

"We will not tolerate the prejudices of a handful of politically correct bigots standing in the way of perfectly decent people being able to adopt children who need a secure and loving home," he said.

Rob Hutchinson, chairman of the children and families committee of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said most prospective adopters wanted babies.

Most children waiting for adoption were over four, 40% had learning difficulties or physical disabilities, and 20% had been sexually abused.

"These are challenging children. Half the boys advertised for adoption between the ages of six and 10 had not had a single inquiry from prospective parents. That must be terrible for them."

fields.headline: Crash pilot cleared 50 years on
fields.trailText: A pilot has been cleared of an allegation of recklessness which has blackened his name for the 50 years since his aircraft crashed in the Andes, killing him and 10 others.
fields.body:
A pilot has been cleared of an allegation of recklessness which has blackened his name for the 50 years since his aircraft crashed in the Andes, killing him and 10 others.

There was no conclusive explanation why the converted bomber Star Dust plummeted into a 22,000ft mountain on August 2 1947, and the crash site went undiscovered for more than half a century. But in January climbers stumbled across it and the remains of several occupants preserved by sub-zero temperatures, high on Mount Tupungato on the Argentina-Chile border.

After examining wreckage, a senior Argentine air force officer has concluded the plane crashed because of severe weather and cleared the pilot, Reginald Cook, of any blame for the deaths of all five crew and six passengers.

Major Luis Estrella said a heavy snowstorm forced the decorated RAF veteran to veer off course. "They were unable to correct their positioning because they were flying in very cloudy weather," he said.

Heavy snow had been falling for three days when the British South American Airways flight from Buenos Aires to Santiago vanished, and aviation experts said the plane, which did not have de-icers, was unfit to travel in such weather.

A British investigation by Air Commodore Vernon Brown in 1948 concluded the cause of the accident was "obscure", but hinted that Capt Cook was guilty of recklessness. "As this was the pilot's first trans-Andean flight in command, and in view of the weather conditions, he should not have crossed by the direct route," it said.

- Press Association

webTitle: Life after Living Marxism: Fighting for freedom - to offend, outrage and question everything

fields.headline: Life after Living Marxism: Fighting for freedom - to offend, outrage and question everything
fields.trailText: Three months ago a high court libel jury forced the magazine LM, formerly Living Marxism, into closure and bankruptcy. But that did not mean its controversial views would go away. On the same day as the verdict was delivered, LM's co-publisher Claire Fox, a 40-year-old former social worker and teacher, and two colleagues formed a plan for a month of "thought provoking" conferences.
fields.byline: David Pallister, John Vidal and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Three months ago a high court libel jury forced the magazine LM, formerly Living Marxism, into closure and bankruptcy. But that did not mean its controversial views would go away. On the same day as the verdict was delivered, LM’s co-publisher Claire Fox, a 40-year-old former social worker and teacher, and two colleagues formed a plan for a month of “thought provoking” conferences in London, Oxford, Manchester, Edinburgh, Paris and Frankfurt.

As the Institute of Ideas, Fox and her team have drawn into their project many of the leading cultural institutions in the capital: the Tate Modern, the British Library, the British Museum, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the Royal Institution, the RSA, and the Art’s Council. An impressive array of academics, scientists, journalists, lawyers and writers have agreed to speak.

Related: Life after Living Marxism: Banning the bans

But critics, almost wholly from the left, argue that some of its more extreme laissez-faire positions are risible nonsense or simply promote an agenda pushed by big business. Should they be taken seriously?

“I believe,” writer Mick Hume told 50 people at a libel seminar, “in the right to be offensive.” He exercised that right in his magazine LM (formerly Living Marxism) three years ago by publishing an article which claimed that ITN deliberately misrepresented that haunting picture of Fikret Alic, an emaciated Bosnian Muslim at Trnopolje camp in 1992.

The result, this March, was a crushing and expensive libel case which forced the magazine’s closure. Hume and his co-publisher defendant, Helene Guldberg, are being personally pursued for £375,000 in damages.

But being offensive can have its own rewards as LM’s progeny, the Institute of Ideas, basks in the success of organising - this month and last - a series of conferences with the blessing and backing of some of Britain’s leading institutions. And there’s more: events in Oxford, Frankfurt, Paris, Dublin, Manchester and, in August, a raft of debates at the Edinburgh festival.

The institute’s director, Claire Fox, a former social worker and teacher, and her volunteers work out of a ground floor office formerly occupied by LM near Smithfield meat market.

Ms Fox proclaims her pride in the Institute of Ideas and maintains it has no political agenda other than to challenge the consensus agenda through the power of debate. “It’s the ideas that matter,” she insists. “Why would I be doing this? I could be earning a lot of money as a consultant, or gone higher in education.”

For the spruce young(ish) controversialists who formed the core of LM’s friends and contributors, it has been a long and curious ideological road. The institute now has a slogan: Ban nothing - question everything. Yet their origins lie in a small Trotskyist sect within the International Socialists (now the Socialist Workers’ Party), which used to spend most of its time in textual agonising over the third volume of Das Kapital.

After a monumentally unfathomable debate about the declining rate of profit and commodity fetishism, part of the faction split away from the International Socialists in 1974 and formed the Revolutionary Communist Group (RCG). Its central platform was to have no truck with political activism, reformist and united fronts. An infantile disorder, Lenin would have called it.

With a healthy respect for bourgeois ideology, it believed that the main task was to formulate the correct Marxist programme and then train a vanguard elite to storm the citadels of capitalism. The battle of ideas and the use of propaganda were all.

Horrified

The first law of Trotskyist sects is that, like amoebas, they have to split to survive. When the chief RCG theoretician, David Yaffe, decided that the time had come actively to engage with the Communist party and the anti-apartheid movement, the purists were horrified.

And so was born, in 1976, the even smaller Revolutionary Communist Tendency, later to become the Revolutionary Communist Party (RCP) with its organ, Living Marxism.

“They were skilful at organisation and publicity and had lots of energy,” says one of their critics from the left. “But they were basically a cult dealing in theoretical absolutes. They had no real ideas, just postures.” “Media pranksters and disco fascists,” snorted one old International Socialist hand.

To many observers there was a cultish flavour to the party. New recruits were collared in fashionable places like Covent Garden, Sloane Square and Oxford university. They were often approached with an invitation to take part in a bogus survey on political events of the day. Once recruited, they had to go through a programme of political education - learning the party line. It helped to look smart and good career moves in the media, academia and the professions were encouraged. Once in a job, they were expected to donate a percentage of their salaries to the party - and its publications.

Then the cold war ended, the party’s eight candidates lost their deposits at the fourth Tory election win of 1992 and Living Marxism began another transformation.

Conventional politics were declared exhausted and atrophied and in 1996 the RCP was disbanded and Living Marxism was reborn as the even glossier LM. The new scriptures decree that the old labour movements has collapsed for good. Apathy rules. The division of left and right has become irrelevant. A new crusade and new ideas for human emancipation are called for. The big buzz word, to be reclaimed from Thatcherism, was freedom.

Freedom to say whatever you like; the freedom to be offensive and contrary - just like in the old days.

LM articulated its new philosophy and found new friends from surprising places. “The RCP were always refreshingly different,” said one admirer in 1997 after a visit to an LM fringe meeting at the Edinburgh festival. “They took issue with the ‘no platform for fascists’ policy that most of the left slavishly and unthinkingly sought to enforce.” Thus Patrick Harrington, former student organiser of the National Front, whose presence at North London poly in the 1980s became a cause celebre for the SWP, now adopts many of the views of LM.

The institute’s programme does not say it, but this rightwing think tank/magazine, which has been promoting the corporate takeover of schools in the US, is pro-guns and pro-GM.

Both its founder and senior editor accepted invitations to talk at LM events - and will be paying their own way to come. Their leading writer, the syndicated columnist Sandra Postrel, is author of the libertarian book The Enemies of Freedom and frequently talks at the Hudson Institute. This body is mainly run by former Reaganite cold war warriors and initiates much of the “research” that attacks environmentalists and liberal governments.

In the past few years LM has effectively made five or more hours of prime time environmentalist-bashing TV. C4’s much discredited series Against Nature was directed by Martin Durkin, a keen LM fan. The producer of the Counterblast series told the Guardian that he had no idea that most of the contributors had LM or other links.

Another of its backers is cSscape, a US corporation whose British branch set up the full website for the Cabinet Office and has worked for Monsanto’s PR company, the giant Burson Marsteller. Other hi-tech companies supporting LM/IoI include Gap21 - which calls itself a “21st century dialogue on globalisation and power”, Internet Freedom, a radical free speech group, and Designagenda, an internet design operation set up by LM writer and academic Andrew Calcutt.

Mick Hume and his colleagues last month brought out Last Magazine, another expensively produced 124-page glossy using the LM initials. “So please, no flowers or memorial services for LM,” wrote Hume. “There is life after a libel trial. It starts here.”

webTitle: Life for nurse who raped and killed

fields.headline: Life for nurse who raped and killed
fields.trailText: A male nurse was given seven life sentences yesterday for manslaughter, rape and drugging women patients.
fields.body:
A male nurse was given seven life sentences yesterday for manslaughter, rape and drugging women patients.

Kevin Cobb, 38, abused his position of trust to prey on vulnerable women who went to the casualty department of St Peter's hospital in Chertsey, Surrey, for help, said Judge Martin Stephens at the Old Bailey. He drugged them with anaesthetic and assaulted them in the knowledge that they would not remember.

"It would be difficult to envisage a greater breach of trust," said the judge.

The attacks took place after Cobb had inadvertently killed a nursing sister, Susan Annis, 31, whom he had drugged so that he could rape her. The judge said this showed he was a danger to women, as well as someone who had brought the nursing profession into disrepute.

Cobb, from Yateley in Hampshire, was convicted on May 17 of seven offences following a four-week trial. He was remanded for reports after the jury found him guilty of the manslaughter of Miss Annis; guilty of four charges of drugging women with intent to rape; and guilty of two offences of rape at St Peter's casualty department.

The prosecution told the court that Miss Annis, from Crawley hospital in West Sussex, died at a nurses' home at the Royal Brompton hospital, west London, in November 1996, when her drink was spiked by Cobb. He was arrested in January 1999 after a patient, Janine Cuddington, complained she had blacked out on a hospital trolley and come round to find herself being raped; she has waived her right to anonymity.

During his trial Cobb denied using a fast-acting "date-rape" style drug, available for use in minor surgery in casualty departments, to stupefy his victims and create memory loss.

After the case Detective Superintendent Dave Cook of Surrey police said another woman patient had come forward after recognising Cobb's photograph in newspaper reports, but that would be a matter for the crown prosecution service. Police believed Cobb had also attacked other women, who remembered nothing about it.

Henry Grunwald QC, defending, said Cobb, who was married to a GP and had a young son, maintained his innocence. But Judge Stephens told Cobb that his offences had caused anguish to his victims and dismay to the public and his profession: "It is difficult to envisage what could constitute a greater breach of trust than what you did."

Worst of all, said the judge, after Susan Annis died at Cobb's hands he had continued to use the drug Midazolam on other women "in order to satisfy your perverted sexual demands".

- Press Association

webTitle: Life after Living Marxism: Banning the bans

fields.headline: Life after Living Marxism: Banning the bans
fields.standfirst: An agenda for radical change
fields.trailText: An agenda for radical change
fields.byline: David Pallister, John Vidal and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Society

LM/Institute of Ideas (IoI) says we live in an unfree world where people think society has reached a dead end. We mistrust ourselves to the point where we fear our own creations, from the motor car to the GM soya bean. We are preoccupied with risk, from the top down. The mood of the times is pessimistic, misanthropic and miserabalist - symptomatic of a society which has lost faith in itself. The great technological and social progress made this century must be defended and pushed further if we are to build a world fit for people. Restricting freedom leads to stagnation and holds back the potential to improve.

Free enterprise

LM believes in unfettered capitalism. But capitalists, they regret, have become insecure about their "mission" and have lost faith in the values of growth and profit. Capitalism should not be regulated. Planning should be deregulated. "Caring" has sadly replaced "ruthless" as the desirable label for businessmen. Liberal criticisms of greed are really attacks on human ambition for improvement.

Personal liberty

LM/IoI says we live in an age of new authoritarianism, in a "dark hour" of personal freedoms. People no longer have the freedom to argue with partners, let children play outside or smack them. Nor are they free to smoke, drink, own guns, adopt a child or walk down a street without negotiating a minefield of regulations, restrictions and surveillance measures. Gun laws in Britain should not be tightened, nor should paedophiles be put on a register. Campaigns by liberals against domestic violence are an increased intervention by the authorities into intimate relations.

Sex

Sex offenders, says LM/IoI, are ordinary people who err in a moment of depravity. Paedophiles are misunderstood. The government's Aids campaign to make people aware of the disease was not a response to a health problem faced by gay men but a moral crusade intended to terrify the entire population about the dangers of sex.

Free speech

LM/IoI argues that no speech should be constrained by bans, libel laws or well-meaning self-censorship. The internet should not be regulated at all from pornography. "Hate speech" by Nazis, anti-semites and racists which advocates violence or discrimination should not be censored. The only restriction should be when people advocate imminent harm to others. Holocaust denial is acceptable. Every social taboo should be busted, and people should blaspheme and outrage public opinion. The right to be offensive should be fought for.

Environment

LM/IoI argues that environmentalists practise the "socialism of fools" and are unaccountable, obsessed with risk and peril, anti-human, anti-science, a risk to "progress" and to people. It accuses them and consumer protection groups of doom-mongering and hollow compassion and of trying to regulate all human activity. Environmentalists' radical critiques of business and government are really arguments against creativity and innovation. The precautionary principle which environmentalists preach and governments are signed up to paralyses innovation. Global warming will be good, animal rights do not exist, pollution is overstated.

Science/internet

LM/IoI worships science and high technology. Scientific rationalism is a core belief and cyber-libertarianism is the great hope of the future. "New" human, animal and bio-genetic technologies are "progress" and therefore good for humanity. Science should be freed from all social constraints and scientists should be encouraged to experiment in every taboo area. No one should try to hold back experimentation on humans or animals.

Transport

LM/IoI is pro-car, pro-speed, pro-new roads and pro-raising speed limits. Cycling and walking are now at the top of the hierarchy of mobility and the car is in the dock. The problem of air pollution from vehicles is exaggerated.

Poor countries

LM/IoI opposes western interventions. Humanitarian aid is bogus. Western charities who work in poor countries undermine the rights of the third world. They make weaker nations more permeable to western domination. "Sustainable development" is based on an acceptance that economic and social development in the third world can only be limited. "Appropriate" technology means it is primitive and signals to poor countries that they have no alternative but to remain poor. Human rights groups are really crusading for a new colonialism.

Sources: LM articles 1996-2000, manifesto 1995, books by Frank Furedi et al

webTitle: Regrets but no repentance in middle England

fields.headline: Regrets but no repentance in middle England
fields.standfirst:
Stevenage focus Labour supporters in this key battleground are disenchanted, not least party donor Ken Follett, but are not about to desert
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Walking her three children to school and nursery, Sandra Barnes couldn't equate the rhetoric of Tony Blair with the reality of her daily life in Stevenage. A former Tory voter who opted for Labour three years ago, she was expecting great things from Tony Blair. "All these envelopes coming from school asking for money," she sighs. "We shouldn't have to do that - you know, having to beg for cash. It's a shame, it's wrong, isn't it? Things are no different than three years ago. There's never enough money. Hospitals are just as bad and schools are no better off. I thought they'd plough more money into services, but all they do is promise."
fields.body:
Walking her three children to school and nursery, Sandra Barnes couldn't equate the rhetoric of Tony Blair with the reality of her daily life in Stevenage. A former Tory voter who opted for Labour three years ago, she was expecting great things from Tony Blair. "All these envelopes coming from school asking for money," she sighs. "We shouldn't have to do that - you know, having to beg for cash. It's a shame, it's wrong, isn't it? Things are no different than three years ago. There's never enough money. Hospitals are just as bad and schools are no better off. I thought they'd plough more money into services, but all they do is promise."

A mile away, Andrew Paine - young, dapper, ambitious - is driving to his work as a sales manager with a hi-tech engineering company. A commentator on the radio is recounting the worst month of Tony Blair's premiership: heckled at the Women's Institute, ridiculed for attempting to dispense cashpoint justice, blasted by Ken Follett, bungling a Commons question time, then dealing with a wayward son.

It's all the predictable stuff of politics, thinks Mr Paine - a sideshow from the real issues and "a circus". On one level he feels sorry for Mr Blair. "To have your son plastered over the front pages isn't very nice. We've all been there. It's the learning process in life."

But Mr Paine, who also voted Labour for the first time in 1997, is similarly restless. "I became very disillusioned with the Tories over health and education," he says. "I wanted more money put in, but I am not convinced much has changed. I can live with the fact that I am paying a little bit more, but I am not sure they are siphoning money into the right things. I've got a lot of wealthy friends and they're now dividing 50-50 between pro- and anti-Labour."

Judging by the local newspaper placards, and the headlines about the local MP Barbara Follett "standing by her man" over "sneer and smear", New Labour should be feeling the heat in a seat gained from the Tories with a comfortable 11,500 majority in 1997. Ms Follett, wife of the novelist (and former Labour donor) Ken, seemed Blairite to the core.

Now she's similarly disillusioned, although slightly concerned about the publicity generated by her husband's outburst. "I broadly agree with him, although I probably wouldn't have gone public," she told the local paper before attending her granddaughter's birthday party.

Ken was unrepentant yesterday in the splendid manor house, a 19th century rectory on the edge of Lord Cobbold's Knebworth estate, which has been the couple's main home for two years. Finishing off another article on this week's events, he had few regrets about his outburst last weekend about the prime minister's perceived failings. "I have a faint hope it will do some good, although I'm not holding my breath," he said.

The prime minister, he smiled, had even mentioned him jokingly on the BBC's Question Time. "There's a slim chance Tony might listen to what I've said and take action ... a lot of people have phoned up and said 'well done, it's got to be said'. One or two people have said you shouldn't have done it [because] it's damaging to Labour ... but they've all been very amiable discussions. I've been here for five years in Stevenage and people know me. It's not like a stranger doing this - they're my friends and neighbours."

With near full employment, and a broad economic base, Stevenage should be showing few signs of rebellion against a government which has so assiduously courted middle England - arguably, at the expense of its heartlands. In the run-up to the last election it was selected by the Guardian as the ideal place to test voting attitudes with a series of carefully selected focus groups which regularly monitored public opinion.

Three years after that exercise, Mr Blair's problems are readily apparent. In a town largely populated by displaced east enders after the war, the loyalty of traditional Labour voters is clearly being strained to the limit.

Yet converts to Labour, like Sandra Barnes and Andrew Paine, while critical of the government's perceived failure to deliver improvements to key services, are still likely to give Mr Blair a second chance - in the hope that more money will be forthcoming to improve health and education. Even some long-standing Tories like Fiona Hunt, a buyer for a large supermarket chain, said they had been "pleasantly surprised" by Mr Blair's moderation. "I didn't vote Labour last time, but I'm more sitting on the fence now," she said. "I do admire Tony Blair more than I thought I would."

Admiration is a dirty word to Ernie West, a trained electrician who has been made redundant five times and now makes riot helmets for police. "I'm afraid I'm going away from Labour," he said. "I don't like the way things are going. Blair seems to have the attitude that no one can touch him. High and mighty. He needs to be given a short, sharp shock. I get the feeling over the past six months things haven't been going the way he'd like."

Richard Street, a former accounting officer with a string of companies, is similarly disenchanted. "I always voted Labour for what they stood for but it seems like we suffered 18 years under the Tories for nothing to change. We've now got a lot of second-hand Conservatives."

Nick Campbell, a customer services manager with a big insurance company, switched to Labour for the first time in 1997 "for a change". But so far he sees little difference between John Major and Tony Blair. "We've probably got to a standardised level of politics, with little to choose between the parties." But he might still vote Labour again. "I've met Barbara Follett a couple of times and she seems to be doing a good job."

The MP's neighbour, as it happens, is not your average Hertfordian, but David Cobbald, master of 2,000 rolling acres and a former Liberal Democrat candidate for the European parliament who sits as a crossbencher in the Lords. Although friendly with Barbara and Ken, he is also a fan of Mr Blair for killing off socialism. "He's done a fantastic job in converting the Labour party and getting the support of the middle ground. The country has always swung from right to left, and we've needed an alternative government looking after the country as a whole. I was always looking for a middle way."

Now he has one, Lord Cobbald rests much easier in his stately pile, "a Gothic extravaganza grafted on to a red brick Tudor manor house".

Others in Stevenage aren't so sure. While sometimes feeling let down by New Labour, floating voters - often instinctive Tories - just can't take to William Hague, or Michael Portillo. "Something funny about them, a bit wet, wimpish," said a middle aged respondent. Andrew Paine added: "I don't hear anyone saying the Tories are the great white hope."

That might make Mr Blair rest easier. But it probably won't keep Ken Follett quiet.

fields.headline: Council chief sacked
fields.trailText: David Foster, 53, was sacked as chief executive of the Vale of Glamorgan council in Barry, near Cardiff, following a closed session of the full council on Thursday night.
fields.body:
David Foster, 53, was sacked as chief executive of the Vale of Glamorgan council in Barry, near Cardiff, following a closed session of the full council on Thursday night.

He had been suspended on full pay since last year after allegations that he spent taxpayers' money recklessly. An inquiry by Michael Farmer QC on behalf of the Welsh Assembly looked at 60 allegations of misconduct.

The report has not been published, but it upheld 36 of the charges and was critical of, among other things, a trip to Geneva; it recommended Mr Foster's dismissal without notice.

The council's leader, Jeffrey James, said yesterday that the evidence against Mr Foster had been unequivocal, as had the recommendation.

fields.headline: Mother, 55, loses house to daughter
fields.trailText: A mother yesterday lost a battle with her daughter over the ownership of their £250,000 family home.
fields.body:
A mother yesterday lost a battle with her daughter over the ownership of their £250,000 family home.

A high court judge ruled that Bonnita Dobson did not use her influence to cut her natural mother out of a will and have the entire property, set in more than an acre of Surrey countryside, left to her.

Mrs Dobson, 35, known as Bonnie, is the daughter of Monica Davies, 55, but was adopted by her mother's parents, Annie and Frank Randall, when she was five years old.

They all lived at The Shack, Green Lane, Chertsey, which was built by Mr Randall's father in 1935 on the site of an old hut.

When Mr Randall died in 1991, he left it to his wife, who made a draft will dividing her estate equally between the children: Monica Davies, Bonnita and a son, John, now 56.

But in June 1992, Mrs Randall secretly conveyed the house to Mrs Dobson "in consideration of her natural love and affection" and left Mrs Davies' flat, where she had been staying, to return to live with her adopted daughter and her children aged 10 and 14 at The Shack until her death in November 1993.

Deputy judge Geoffrey Vos QC said Mrs Randall was found drowned in a pond near The Shack and Mrs Davies blamed Mrs Dobson for her mother's death "in some unspecific way".

Mrs Davies also began her legal action against Mrs Dobson, seeking a declaration that the conveyance should be set aside on the grounds that Mrs Dobson or her former husband unduly influenced Mrs Randall.

The judge, dismissing Mrs Davies's action, said of her: "She is understandably bitter about having been disinherited, but I am bound to say that I believe that, in these proceedings, she has unjustifiably set out to blacken Bonnie's character." Press Association

fields.headline: Okinawa attack enrages Japanese
fields.trailText: The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, yesterday condemned the alleged molesting of a young girl by a drunken US Marine on Okinawa, the site of this month's summit of President Clinton and other world leaders.
fields.body:
The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, yesterday condemned the alleged molesting of a young girl by a drunken US Marine on Okinawa, the site of this month's summit of President Clinton and other world leaders.

"Basically, this is outrageous," Mr Mori said. "It's no excuse to say that [the marine] was young. They need to be educated about this."

The incident, in which a 19-year-old marine allegedly entered the 14-year-old Japanese girl's apartment early on Monday morning and fondled her as she slept, has revived memories of the 1995 rape of a schoolgirl by three US servicemen.

It threatens to cast a cloud over Mr Clinton's trip to Okinawa during the July 21-23 Group of Eight summit, the first visit by a US president since 1972 when the island was returned to Japan.

The US forces on Okinawa said yesterday they would introduce a late night curfew from July 14 until July 24 and ban drinking both on and off the bases from July 20 to 24.

"While we demand and enforce a high level of conduct at all times, it is especially important during the summit - when the eyes of the world are upon us - that we put our best foot forward and make our corps and our country proud of who we are and what we do," Marine Corps Lieutenant General Earl Hailston said.

The step follows an apology on Thursday by Gen Hailston, the top US military official in Okinawa, to Governor Keiichi Inamine. "These Marines are my sons and daughters. That is why it hurts me deeply when any of my marines appear to fall short of the standard I have set and demand," he said.

The incident prompted the Okinawa prefectural assembly, the Okinawa city assembly and the assembly of Nago City, where the summit will be held, to pass resolutions protesting against the incident and urging steps to prevent recurrences, but anti-base activists said it proved the bases must go.

"Every time these incidents happen, the Americans apologise and the Japanese government apologises and the prefecture protests. They take steps and promise it won't happen again, but it just keeps happening," said Zenko Nakamura, of the Council for Opposing Offshore Base Construction.

webTitle: World holds breath as US tests son of Star Wars

fields.headline: World holds breath as US tests son of Star Wars
fields.trailText: Greenpeace activists yesterday broke into a US air force base in California and sent a vessel into an off-limits military zone in the Pacific in an attempt to thwart a key test of a new missile defence system scheduled for early this morning.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Washington and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Greenpeace activists yesterday broke into a US air force base in California and sent a vessel into an off-limits military zone in the Pacific in an attempt to thwart a key test of a new missile defence system scheduled for early this morning.

The environmental pressure group said the proposed $60bn national missile defence (NMD) scheme would undermine existing disarmament treaties and "provide additional justification to Russia and China to retain their existing nuclear arsenals, while developing new nuclear weapons that can penetrate any future missile shield".

Greenpeace said its team at the base was equipped with survival gear and supplies for several days.

The test was the third in a series, but its timing in the midst of a presidential election campaign was expected to have a significant bearing on President Clinton's decision on whether to go ahead with the system, which is intended to provide a shield against missiles fired from "rogue states".

A Greenpeace spokesman said a team of activists had entered Vandenberg air force base and reached the silo from which a Minuteman II missile was due to be fired as part of the test.

Meanwhile, a Greenpeace vessel, an icebreaker called Arctic Sunrise, entered one of five "hazard zones" off the coast from the Californian base under the missile's trajectory in an effort to stop the countdown.

John Sprange, a Greenpeace activist on board the ship, said the organisation "will continue to use every non-violent means to convince President Clinton to stop Star Wars".

The US air force was quoted as saying that the approaching vessel would be "dealt with". In 1989 a navy ship rammed another Greenpeace vessel challenging a Trident test.

The Minuteman was expected to release a mock warhead into space, which would then be targeted by a rocket fired 20 minutes later from the Marshall Islands in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. The rocket was supposed to launch an interceptor in space which would then track down and target the incoming warhead.

Criticism of the scheme has come from all corners. Russia and China have complained it would undermine the deterrent value of other nations' arsenals. America's allies in Europe have also expressed unease about the project, concerned that it would trigger global instability.

Meanwhile US scientists and intellectuals have criticised NMD as an expensive waste of time. In a letter to President Clinton, Theodore Postol, a professor of science and national security studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, accused Pentagon officials of covering up flaws in the scheme and making "numerous technologically illiterate and highly misleading statements" about the system.

A spokesman for the National Security Council said it had seen the letter and had asked the Pentagon to analyse the questions raised.

fields.headline: Chinese threaten nuclear arms race
fields.standfirst:
National missile defence programme
National committee on US-China relations
China foreign ministry
fields.trailText: China has warned that it is likely to increase the size of its nuclear missile force if Washington goes through with its controversial "son of Star Wars" defence programme.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Beijing and Amelia Gentleman in Moscow
fields.body:
China has warned that it is likely to increase the size of its nuclear missile force if Washington goes through with its controversial "son of Star Wars" defence programme.

"China cannot sit idly by and watch its means for self-defence being weakened and even deprived of in any form," Beijing's top arms control official, Sha Zukang, told the Guardian, in a reference to America's national missile defence (NMD) project, which was being tested early today.

The official People's Daily newspaper weighed in yesterday, denouncing the "hegemonic arrogance of the US".

The Chinese position was reinforced by the commander-in-chief of Russia's missile defence force, Vladimir Yakovlev, who declared that today's tests represented "the first step towards global nuclear instability" and reiterated that they were a "flagrant violation" of the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty.

He added that America's development of the missile defence system would encourage other countries to spend vast amounts of money on developing technology to overcome the US barrier.

Russia, like China, believes that the system is designed primarily to fend off its own weapons and has indicated that it may abandon all previously signed disarmament treaties if America goes ahead.

The spate of Chinese warnings comes ahead of next week's visit to Beijing by the US defence secretary, William Cohen, when the NMD project will be top of the agenda.

"If [NMD] is effective the US will have both huge offensive forces and reliable defensive forces," said Mr Sha, the director-general of China's department of arms control and disarmament. "At that time other nuclear countries like China may again be blackmailed."

He added: "China must have the legitimate means for self-defence. [US plans] must be taken into account when China decides the size of its nuclear forces."

President Jiang Zemin criticised NMD on Wednesday in a joint statement with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, from a central Asian security summit in Tajikistan. The two leaders said that the plan could trigger a new arms race.

Experts say that China possesses a land-based strategic force of only some 20 CSS-4 intercontinental ballistic missiles and a "very small" submarine-based missile force. The CSS-4s are capable of reaching the US mainland.

Mr Sha argued that China's nuclear forces have always been maintained "at the lowest necessary level for self-defence".

But the nuclear umbrella provided by NMD in US airspace would undermine the strategic rationale behind China's "minimum deterrent". China could no longer be sure that its own missiles would get through to hit targets on the American continent if it first sustained a US nuclear strike.

The NMD scheme would destroy China's theoretical "second strike capability", which was the basis for an effective deterrence, forcing Beijing to think again.

"The colossal efforts of the US to develop NMD and its attempt to deploy advanced Theatre Missile Defence [TMD] in north-east Asia will constitute a direct threat to the effectiveness of the limited nuclear forces China possesses now," Mr Sha concluded.

China is still anxious to avoid provoking anti-Beijing sentiment in the US. Mr Sha said that China preferred to give the US the benefit of the doubt and added: "Even if we deploy, it will take a long time." He also gave credit to US efforts for arms control so far.

But the US interest in NMD encourages a darker view of America's intentions which has been strengthened by the Kosovo war and the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade.

China is also deeply suspicious of the US agreement with Japan to study a TMD system ostensibly aimed at protecting against a possible North Korean nuclear threat.

Mr Sha said such an anti-missile system meant only to defend US forces stationed abroad would be acceptable. But he feared that TMD could be linked to the defence of the US heartland, particularly if it was extended to cover Taiwan.

Critics of Chinese policy towards Taiwan say Beijing's hints about the possible use of force against the island have been counter-productive and strengthen the argument for providing Taiwan with more effective anti-missile defence.

But Mr Sha said that China's policy on the use of force has been "greatly misunderstood". He went unusually far in claiming that its use was out of the question except in the most extreme circumstances.

There were only two scenarios where force could be contemplated: if Taiwan declared independence or in the case of "foreign aggression".

"It is unbelievable that the mainland should use force against our brothers and sisters [on Taiwan]," he insisted.
fields.bodyText: China has warned that it is likely to increase the size of its nuclear missile force if Washington goes through with its controversial "son of Star Wars" defence programme. "China cannot sit idly by and watch its means for self-defence being weakened and even deprived of in any form," Beijing's top arms control official, Sha Zukang, told the Guardian, in a reference to America's national missile defence (NMD) project, which was being tested early today. The official People's Daily newspaper weighed in yesterday, denouncing the "hegemonic arrogance of the US". The Chinese position was reinforced by the commander-in-chief of Russia's missile defence force, Vladimir Yakovlev, who declared that today's tests represented "the first step towards global nuclear instability" and reiterated that they were a "flagrant violation" of the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty. He added that America's development of the missile defence system would encourage other countries to spend vast amounts of money on developing technology to overcome the US barrier. Russia, like China, believes that the system is designed primarily to fend off its own weapons and has indicated that it may abandon all previously signed disarmament treaties if America goes ahead. The spate of Chinese warnings comes ahead of next week's visit to Beijing by the US defence secretary, William Cohen, when the NMD project will be top of the agenda. "If [NMD] is effective the US will have both huge offensive forces and reliable defensive forces," said Mr Sha, the director-general of China's department of arms control and disarmament. "At that time other nuclear countries like China may again be blackmailed." He added: "China must have the legitimate means for self-defence. [US plans] must be taken into account when China decides the size of its nuclear forces." President Jiang Zemin criticised NMD on Wednesday in a joint statement with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, from a central Asian security summit in Tajikistan. The two leaders said that the plan could trigger a new arms race. Experts say that China possesses a land-based strategic force of only some 20 CSS-4 intercontinental ballistic missiles and a "very small" submarine-based missile force. The CSS-4s are capable of reaching the US mainland. Mr Sha argued that China's nuclear forces have always been maintained "at the lowest necessary level for self-defence". But the nuclear umbrella provided by NMD in US airspace would undermine the strategic rationale behind China's "minimum deterrent". China could no longer be sure that its own missiles would get through to hit targets on the American continent if it first sustained a US nuclear strike. The NMD scheme would destroy China's theoretical "second strike capability", which was the basis for an effective deterrence, forcing Beijing to think again. "The colossal efforts of the US to develop NMD and its attempt to deploy advanced Theatre Missile Defence [TMD] in north-east Asia will constitute a direct threat to the effectiveness of the limited nuclear forces China possesses now," Mr Sha concluded. China is still anxious to avoid provoking anti-Beijing sentiment in the US. Mr Sha said that China preferred to give the US the benefit of the doubt and added: "Even if we deploy, it will take a long time." He also gave credit to US efforts for arms control so far. But the US interest in NMD encourages a darker view of America's intentions which has been strengthened by the Kosovo war and the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. China is also deeply suspicious of the US agreement with Japan to study a TMD system ostensibly aimed at protecting against a possible North Korean nuclear threat. Mr Sha said such an anti-missile system meant only to defend US forces stationed abroad would be acceptable. But he feared that TMD could be linked to the defence of the US heartland, particularly if it was extended to cover Taiwan. Critics of Chinese policy towards Taiwan say Beijing's hints about the possible use of force against the island have been counter-productive and strengthen the argument for providing Taiwan with more effective anti-missile defence. But Mr Sha said that China's policy on the use of force has been "greatly misunderstood". He went unusually far in claiming that its use was out of the question except in the most extreme circumstances. There were only two scenarios where force could be contemplated: if Taiwan declared independence or in the case of "foreign aggression". "It is unbelievable that the mainland should use force against our brothers and sisters [on Taiwan]," he insisted.

webTitle: Red faces over theft from EU's defence fortress

fields.headline: Red faces over theft from EU's defence fortress
fields.trailText: Europe's fledgling defence structures have been dealt a new blow by the wholesale theft of computers and furniture from the Brussels building used to plan the union's first military moves.
fields.body:
Europe's fledgling defence structures have been dealt a new blow by the wholesale theft of computers and furniture from the Brussels building used to plan the union's first military moves.

Embarrassed diplomats reported yesterday that 200 computers vanished last weekend from the Justus Lipsius building, the imposing pink marble structure which houses the EU council of ministers.

And even worse, it seems to have been an inside job.

Whoever took the computers had taste as well as nerve: they also removed three translucent stools by the renowned avant garde designer, Phillipe Starck, on loan from France, which has just begun its turn at the EU presidency.

Ominously, the furniture was on display in one of the upper levels of the building -and strictly off limits to journalists and other visitors, suggesting that the theft could only have been committed by civil servants or diplomats.

Javier Solana, the EU's defence and foreign policy supremo, has already complained bitterly that his headquarters had "more holes than a Swiss cheese" and demanded that it be moved to a more secure site.

Mr Solana has the delicate job of keeping the US and the western alliance happy - and persuading them to share their secrets - as the 15-member EU fumbles its way to organising its own modest military moves.

But the building's poor defences against spies and terrorists - to say nothing of ordinary thieves - have not inspired confidence.

At one stage, contract cleaning staff were discovered to have criminal records, while concealed microphones were found in booths used by the interpreters who are a standard feature of all EU life.

Diplomats say the problem is that there is no "culture of security" in a building which until this spring had hosted nothing more classified than discussions about agriculture or the environment.

Security staff are not even authorised to search cars leaving the underground garage. "The more brazen thieves don't even take the trouble to hide their booty in the trunk," complained one furious official. "They drive out with it right there on the passenger seat."
