webTitle: Aids: HIV surge among San Francisco gays

fields.headline: Aids: HIV surge among San Francisco gays
fields.trailText: No city in the US has more experience of Aids than San Francisco, where the epidemic reached its height among gay and bisexual men in the 1980s. New figures showing that the city is experiencing its first rise in HIV cases for more than a decade confirm fears that complacency and "battle fatigue" are leading to a surge.
fields.body:
No city in the US has more experience of Aids than San Francisco, where the epidemic reached its height among gay and bisexual men in the 1980s. New figures showing that the city is experiencing its first rise in HIV cases for more than a decade confirm fears that complacency and "battle fatigue" are leading to a surge.

"We speak to around 7,000 gay and bisexual men a year and this is what we have been fearing for some time," said James Nguyen of the organisation Stop Aids yesterday. "There has been a general feeling of complacency, not just among young men who have grown up with the warnings as a sort of background noise but also among middle-aged men. The figures have confirmed what we have been hearing."

Last weekend, the department of public health in San Francisco announced that the rate of new HIV cases in the city has tripled in the last two years. There were 900 new HIV cases reported in 1999, compared to 500 in 1998.

At the height of the epidemic in 1982, the figure reached 6,000 but after educational campaigns and extensive work with the gay community, the figure dropped dramatically.

The interpretation of the latest figures was contested by a leading gay group.

David Pasquarelli of ACT UP/San Francisco said that instead of giving out the raw figures, the researchers "have concocted an elaborate mathematical method using numerous 'indicators' and employing ... tests unapproved by the Food and Drug Administration to concoct HIV increases on paper".

San Francisco was held up as a pioneer of safe sex and there was optimism in a city with a population of 43,000 gay and bisexual men that the worst was long past. The new figures challenge that assumption.

The proportion of gay men who said they always used a condom has fallen from 70% in 1994 to 54% last year. The figures for gay men having unprotected anal sex with more than one partner rose from 23% to 43% in the same period.

"This should sound a warning bell for the rest of the country," said Dr Thomas Coates, director of the Aids research institute of the University of California San Francisco, which has been compiling the figures. "We saw the first Aids infection and now we're seeing the first rise in new infections."

A variety of factors are seen to be behind the rise. James Nguyen said many young men came to San Francisco from towns in the Midwest because of the city's liberal attitude and were unaware of the risks they were running. "In San Francisco, there is about a one in three chance of having sex with someone with the virus."

Mr Nguyen said not enough had been done to target those most at risk. "Only 8% of the money spent on Aids is spent on prevention," he said. "The government is definitely not doing enough."

Gustavo Suarez of the San Francisco Aids Foundation said the reasons for the increase were complex and included both complacency and what some of his colleagues have called "battle fatigue".

"After two decades of campaigning, complacency can set in and you see this in other health campaigns around smoking and heart disease," he said. "Also the new treatments have led to a false sense that the epidemic is not as serious as it once was. There are people who believe they are behaving in a safe way but basing it on mistaken assumptions."

He said that whereas San Francisco showed a big rise among gay men, in other US cities the increase was among heterosexuals.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Syria lifts ban on car imports
fields.body:
Syria lifts ban on car imports

Syria has lifted a 30-year ban on private car imports in a new sign of economic reform, officials said yesterday.

A decree from the prime minister, Mohammed Mustafa Mero, stipulated that imports only of petrol vehicles would be allowed. Cars should have been built no more than two years before being imported. Reuters, Damascus
Bulls injure 20 in Pamplona

Twenty people were hurt yesterday as hundreds of bullfighting fans risked their lives on the first day of Pamplona's running of the bulls festival.

Locals and tourists packed the streets for the first run of the San Fermin festival. Emergency workers said two men, both Spaniards, required hospital treatment. Reuters, Pamplona
Gang grabs gold at Brazil airport

An armed gang of 15 men stormed the tarmac at the international airport in the Brazilian capital, Brasilia, and stole about £300,000 in gold from a commercial airliner with 70 passengers on board, police said yesterday. The gang escaped after forcing open the cargo hold as the plane was ready to take off. Reuters, Brasilia
Vets try to save tigers in India

A team of vets sped to a zoo in Orissa in southeastern India yesterday after another Royal Bengal Tiger died of either sleeping sickness or its antidote.

Nandankanan Zoo had 56 of the rare cats, but since June 23, 12 have died, prompting the vets' search for a cause. AP, New Delhi

webTitle: Poverty opens Haiti to cocaine trade

fields.headline: Poverty opens Haiti to cocaine trade
fields.standfirst: Poorly paid officials and a convenient location make the Caribbean island an ideal staging post
fields.trailText: The fleet of ageing freighters anchored off the ramshackle waterfront suggests a threadbare trade. Ships registered in Panama, Honduras or Belize unload cargoes of outdated consumer goods fit for a charity shop.
fields.body:
The fleet of ageing freighters anchored off the ramshackle waterfront suggests a threadbare trade. Ships registered in Panama, Honduras or Belize unload cargoes of outdated consumer goods fit for a charity shop.

Piles of unfashionably large stereos, reject shoes, second-hand bicycles and worn clothes choke the port's narrow streets. These are the cast-offs of the richest economy in the world, imported into Haiti from the United States.

However, one lucrative commodity which thrives on Miragoane's seaborne traffic - cocaine powder - remains invisible from the quayside. Midway between the coca fields of Colombia and the docks of Miami, Haiti is becoming a crucial staging post in the international drugs trade.

"Ships come and go to Colombia and the US all the time," says Jean William Jenty, a candidate in Miragoane's mayoral election. "Even the police are involved in the [drugs] traffic.

"If you come to this region as an officer, you have to buy the post because it's worth so much. From time to time there are arrests of policemen but they never spend long in prison. They are friendly with people of consequence - and are released quickly."

In one incident, 150kg of cocaine seized from a truck was impounded in Miragoane's police station and shortly afterwards 10kg of the powder vanished. Seven officers were arrested, followed by three members of the judiciary.

The local MP alleged officers had even lent a police car to a drug courier.

René Préval, Haiti's president, admitted to the Guardian that there is a "big problem". But he added: "It's not a problem from Haiti. It's a problem for the drug-consuming countries. Because you have demands you have a market.

"The USA asks us what we are doing to fight drugs. I ask the Americans what they are doing to reduce the demand. We don't produce drugs, we don't consume drugs. We are just a transit point.

"We signed an agreement two years ago with the Americans so that they could enter our airspace and seize boats. But the Americans are more interested in catching boat-people than in catching drugs."

Even though mangoes, vegetable oils and herbs for perfume are shipped from Miragoane, vessels often set out with empty holds - a sign, according to US Customs, that a voyage involves smuggling.

At a waterside cafe,where a large black pig and her litter picked over the waste, Manuel Romero-Napa, an Ecuadorian chief steward from one of the freighters sat drinking with a local crew in dark sunglasses.

"The ships are often flagged to Honduras but owned by Haitians," Mr Romero-Napa explains. "Sometimes you go empty, sometimes carrying a little butter or Barbancourt rum. Returning, you bring all the rubbish from Miami: beds, rice, old fridges, cars - things that are necessary for life in Haiti.

"Some boats do the journey in two to three days. When you pass [the US naval base in Cuba at] Guantanamo Bay, the US coastguards come down close and look [for illegal immigrants]."

And drugs? "Here it's not safe to talk about that," he replied in English, glancing at his companions.

It is not only Miragoane, three hours' drive on a pot-holed road west of the capital Port-au-Prince, which is involved in trafficking. Small planes from South America land by night on private airstrips, while speedboats make the journey from the Colombian coast in just eight hours.

Around 14% of all cocaine entering the US comes through Haiti, according to a recent report to the US house of representatives. Last year, 75 tonnes of the drug was believed to have been routed through Haiti, an increase of nearly 25% over 1998.

The chief of the US drug enforcement agency (DEA) in the Caribbean, Michael Virgil, told a congressional committee in April: "Haiti's weak democratic institution and eroding infrastructure provide South American-based narcotics traffickers with a path of very little resistance."

The traditional routes for the Cali and Medellin drug cartels used to be through Mexico, but the DEA has been relatively successful in intercepting their deliveries. The Colombians have consequently switched their routes back through the Caribbean.

The trafficking through ports like Miragoane depends on Haiti's desperate poverty, which produces poorly paid officials who are easily corrupted. While the London-based pressure group Jubilee 2000 has pleaded for Haiti's debts to be cancelled to help development, Washington has considered withdrawing aid as a punishment for the country's failure to stem the drugs flow.

Profits from the smuggling are visible in the high-walled villas under construction in Petionville on the hills above Port-au-Prince.

"Every day you hear reports of drug shipments by boat or plane," said Suzy Castor, the leader of the opposition OPL party. "This is a country where there is not much money and it's surprising to see $600,000 [£400,000] houses going up with Mercedes cars in the driveway."

As many as 1,000 Colombians are also thought to live in the country.

Once controlled exclusively by the rich, the drug trade is now pulling in the poor. Earlier this month, a plane that landed at Leogane, south of the capital, was burnt by locals looking for cocaine to sell.

In March, villagers on the south coast attacked and sank a French cabin cruiser and a Cuban fishing boat in the hope of finding drugs. And although the vast majority of the cocaine is shipped to the US, there is evidence of small-scale dealing in the worst coastal slums of the capital.

Government critics warn that Haiti is in danger of degenerating into a "narco-state". But its degeneration may not be such a recent development; evidence of the country's vulnerability to the cartels due to its proximity to Columbia dates back to the 1980s.

At that time a senior police officer from Port-au-Prince was reportedly seen on the ranch of Pablo Escobar, the head of the Medellin cartel.

webTitle: Aids: The disease ten times as deadly as war

fields.headline: Aids: The disease ten times as deadly as war
fields.standfirst: South Africa hosts a summit this weekend aimed at countering the scourge killing 2m a year across the continent.
fields.trailText: South Africa hosts a summit this weekend aimed at countering the scourge killing 2m a year across the continent.
fields.body:
Half of all the 15-year-olds living in South Africa and Zimbabwe and two-thirds of 15-year-old boys in Botswana are facing early deaths unless the Aids pandemic sweeping sub-Saharan Africa can be stopped in its tracks.

In Africa as a whole, Aids now kills 2m people a year - 10 times more than war. But 4m were newly infected with HIV last year alone and, without treatment, are expected to die within 10 to 15 years.

Aids experts fear that what is happening in Africa may be only a rehearsal for what could follow in Asia. China and India between them account for 36% of the world's population. and large numbers of people there are already infected.

Western leaders fear the global implications of the pandemic. President Clinton is concerned about the threat to security posed by the destabilising impact on countries where Aids is a serious problem. And in the UK, where popular perception has it that there is no longer a problem thanks to drug treatments, HIV infection rates are rising again.

There is a new mood to take on HIV/Aids within the international community, but some confusion about the way to proceed. While UNAids, the agency responsible for the global effort against Aids, celebrates an agreement with drug companies to slash the prices of some drugs for the developing world from $16 to $2 a day, it is clear that the cost will still be prohibitive for governments and ordinary individuals in sub-Saharan Africa.

International agencies and governments are promoting different schemes to help, but without much obvious success, and the only vaccine to have reached phase III clinical trials - where it is tested on large numbers of people - is not relevant to the strains of HIV prevalent in Africa, where it is most urgently needed.

HIV/Aids in Africa, together with conflict, said Clare Short, development secretary, at the London launch last month of the South African government's Aids plan, is "reversing decades of gains made in development". Life expectancy has been cut by 20 years in some areas, down from the mid-60s to the mid-40s, and literacy rates are suffering as teachers fall ill and parents die.

Global inertia

Aids has created some 12.1 million orphans in Africa, many of whom are stigmatised, get no schooling and are at risk of illness and crime. South Africa has 4.2 million people infected with HIV - the largest number of any country in the world. One in four women aged 20-29 are HIV-positive .

Launching a new report on the impact of HIV/Aids, ahead of the international Aids conference which begins in Durban, South Africa, tomorrow, Peter Piot, executive director of UNAids, called for the rest of the world to respond to the crisis on a "massively different scale from what has been done so far".

"The Aids toll in hard-hit countries is altering the economic and social fabric of society," he said. "HIV will kill more than one-third of the young adults of countries where it has its firmest hold, yet the global response is still just a fraction of what it could be."

This year's international Aids conference - attended by thousands of scientists, development workers and campaigners - is of symbolic significance because for the first time it is being held in the developing world, in South Africa, at the heart of the pandemic.

The predominantly first-world, laboratory science focus of past conferences will shift to the practical realities of tackling disease, disability and death in impoverished communities. There is bound to be anger over Africa's plight, staggering under the burden of a disease which the US and Europe appear to have conquered.

The Durban conference theme is lifting the stigma of Aids. It is important, not just for the sake of women and children who are shunned if people know they are HIV-positive, but to encourage national governments to do more about a problem that some would rather ignore.

There will never be enough money, because the impact of Aids is worsened by the endemic problems of developing countries - poverty, poor education, the low status of women and inadequate health care systems.

"The health sector deficiencies in the developing world appear to be growing instead of shrinking," says the UNAids report. To make things worse, tuberculosis is now rife in countries with the worst HIV/Aids problems, and a leading cause of death among those with immune systems weakened by the virus.

High-risk focus

Yet progress should be possible, because we know how to prevent HIV infection and Aids, according to Martha Ainsworth of the Development Research Group of the World Bank, writing in the medical journal the Lancet with Waranya Teokul of Thailand's National Economic and Social Development Board. "Increased con dom use, treatment of sexually transmitted diseases, reduction in number of sexual partners, safe injecting behaviour and drugs to prevent mother-to-child transmission have all been shown effective in preventing HIV infection," they point out.

So why are those policies and practices not being implemented in every country where HIV/Aids is on the rise? Thailand is one of "remarkably few" success stories, increasing condom use among brothel workers to 90% through an intensive campaign. The numbers of army conscripts who are HIV-positive has dropped by half. Uganda has also had success in cutting HIV prevalence among pregnant women and young people.

They have done it, say Ms Ainsworth and Mr Teokul, by focusing efforts on the groups most at risk of HIV infection in society and not trying to fight the pandemic on all fronts at once. To do that, they have to overcome cultural prejudices, because the high-risk groups are often those at the margins of society - the poor, the prostitutes and the drug users.

Trials have shown that safe sex campaigns and condom promotion for those most at risk can cut HIV rates dramatically, "yet no government in Africa has systematically attempted to reduce high-risk behaviours on the scale achieved in Thailand", they say.

Then there are the relatively inexpensive drugs to treat infections like TB and pneumonia that could dramatically improve the quality of life of people with Aids. National governments could afford these, even though the anti-retroviral drugs that keep people well in the west are way beyond their means.

These and other focused, relatively low cost, interventions could make a real difference, they say, and deserve the backing of the international agencies and western governments who risk confusing the picture further and spreading scarce resources too thin.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A late buying spree and inflation-friendly economic data helped the FTSE 100 end the trading week on a bright note yesterday.
fields.body:
A late buying spree and inflation-friendly economic data helped the FTSE 100 end the trading week on a bright note yesterday.

With US interest rate fears soothed by the latest economic data (non-farm payrolls for June), the FTSE closed 77.9 points higher at 6,497.5. All the other indices were in positive territory.

The usual suspects were behind the strong performance. Vodafone AirTouch ended 8p up at 320p, BP Amoco added 12.5p to 617p and Shell rose 9p to 563p. Telecoms equipment group Marconi was also in favour, up 74.5p to 960p.

Yet Marks & Spencer had a tough session, declining 7p to 233p after analysts' lukewarm reaction to the autumn collection. City analysts were given a preview on Thursday night and were unimpressed by Marks's efforts to woo the younger end of the market.

BSkyB was also out of favour, falling 38p to £12.55, on fears that Vivendi might sell its 20% stake.

Outside of the FTSE 100, there was renewed interest in computer games company Eidos on talk that the creator of cyber heroine Lara Croft might have another stalker. Over the past month Eidos's shares have reacted strongly to reports of takeover discussions with French group Infogrames. But, according to City dealers, this speculation has attracted the attention of US group Electronic Arts, which is poised to pounce with a 620p per share offer. Eidos shares closed 15p higher at 495p.

Dealers also noted strong demand for QXL shares late in the session. Although they closed down 2.5p at 79p - a low for the year - volume topped 4m shares on talk that EBay might be running a slide-rule over the internet auction company.

British Energy spiked up 9.75p to 195p after the competition commission signalled it might take a sympathetic approach to the examination of alleged market abuse.

NXT rose 52.25.p to £10.76p as Matsushita became the latest licensee of its flat-speaker technology.

Trinity Mirror eased 25p to 575p after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney cut its 2001 profit forecasts and lowered its rating on the newspaper group to "underperform".

On AIM, Weatherly International added 1p to 8.5p on news that non-executive director Stephen Dean has increased his stake by 900,000 shares.

fields.headline: The power of the tower
fields.standfirst: Interview Paul Reichmann, executive chairman, Canary Wharf Group
fields.trailText: Canary Wharf rarely fails to evoke emotion; the Manhattan-style, skyscraper development on the eastern edge of the City of London is either loved or hated, more usually the latter. Yet, the man who has nurtured it through its excruciating birth fails to live up to the stereotype of a flash, brash, arrogant property tycoon.
fields.body:
Canary Wharf rarely fails to evoke emotion; the Manhattan-style, skyscraper development on the eastern edge of the City of London is either loved or hated, more usually the latter. Yet, the man who has nurtured it through its excruciating birth fails to live up to the stereotype of a flash, brash, arrogant property tycoon.

Softly spoken, slightly stooping and modestly but smartly dressed, Paul Reichmann would more easily pass for a slightly eccentric academic than a man who made a fortune - as much as £4bn according to some reports - lost some of it and made it back again through high-profile, controversial property deals, most notably the Canary Wharf complex.

Flashing more than 67,000 times a day, the light atop the Canary Wharf tower he has constructed distracts the Queen in Windsor Castle as well as commuters deep in Surrey. The 50-storey building it crowns - Britain's tallest - transforms London's skyline and has courted controversy for almost 20 years.

It has been bankrupt and rescued, faced long legal wrangles, been locked in disputes over tax incentives and received an estimated £2bn of government aid. (According to some calculations, taxes paid for 40 of the 50 floors of the tower). Legal issues are still continuing with an arm of the advertising group WPP, while the Treasury has investigated claims by the Corporation of London, the local council for the City, that it benefited unfairly from tax breaks.

Soulless and stranded

Above all, it is criticised for being the landmark tower of a development which is soulless and stranded, and difficult to get to despite being just three miles from the heart of the capital's financial centre.

Reichmann, who dislikes interviews only slightly less than having his photo taken, is now able to explain, however, that the project in which he has been involved in since 1987 is ahead of schedule. This week he announced that he is beginning what many of his detractors thought would never happen: the third phase of its development.

It must be a crucial moment in the career of a man who has spent almost 50 years in the cut-throat and volatile world of property, after a frantic journey in his early life across many continents during which he picked up seven languages.

His first job was in "educational work" in Morocco, the temporary residence of his family when they fled his Vienna birthplace at the outset of the second world war, before reaching Toronto, his home now for more than 40 years. His devotedly Jewish family, five children and grandchildren are all based in Canada.

It is in Toronto that the young Reichmann took his first steps into the world of construction and property development.

"Toronto was about a quarter of its present size. It was expanding rapidly. It was a logical thing for a young man to pursue," he says.

He went on to regenerate the Battery Park area of New York, building the World Financial Centre. Then, with much the same management team, he set his sights on the derelict dock on the Isle of Dogs which was earmarked by Margaret Thatcher for regeneration and became home to the famous tower.

Now, at the age of 69 he is the executive chairman of Canary Wharf Group, floated on the stock market just over a year ago. That share sale was the first sign that the Canary Wharf complex, after its bankruptcy in the early 1990s, was regaining life. At 370p, the shares are off their highs but above the 330p at which they made their stock market debut.

Another two towers are springing up alongside the famous original, whose official address is One Canada Square. The journalists and bankers, most notably those from Morgan Stanley who recently leased the top, long-vacant 50th floor, are soon to get new neighbours.

This week, the group announced that another tower, this one a mere 30 stories high, will start to take shape to the south - the third phase - as the new home of legal firm Clifford Chance.

Other new towers will be built in the south section, but with a new flexibility, according to George Iacobescu, Reichmann's long-standing lieuntenant and chief executive of Canary Wharf. The foundations have been set but the height of the towers will be determined by demand.

The move by a major professional firm such as Clifford Chance to the site is, to Reichmann, a sign that the development has matured. Until now it was the bankers, attracted by lower rents than those in the City and buildings more suited to their demands for vast, open dealing rooms, and journalists, who had been associated with the Wharf.

Now, it might be the turn of the lawyers to migrate to the east from the City. "We probably would not have announced the third phase without them," he says. To build their tower is likely to require £200m of fresh funding.

When the next phase of development is completed in five years, 160,000 people will be employed in the area, against the 70,000 who toiled there during its former heyday. And 75% of the people who work at the Wharf, will live within a mile of it.

The cynics might quip this is because getting on and off the Isle of the Dogs, where the development is located, is still a slow and erratic experience, despite the much-heralded opening of the extended Jubilee Line last year. Reichmann sees that transport link, funded by government money with a contribution from the Canary Wharf Group, as a big factor in encouraging companies to the area, however. As is the fact that Canary Wharf is now a town with a critical mass.

"The bigger it is, the more attractive it is," he says. Certainly, Canary Wharf can no longer be described as a ghost town. It is now the workplace of 28,000 people and where empty shop frontages were a familiar site brand names such as Gap, Monsoon and Mont Blanc tempt the investment bankers.

A man of conviction

Whether working there is a pleasant thing, preferable to the traditional City area, is another matter. The next phase of its development comes as the City undergoes a surge in construction activity, including the soon-to-approved, Norman Foster-designed "erotic gherkin" tower at the Baltic Exchange. Even Paddington station is being given a makeover, more competition for Canary Wharf just as rents are starting to rise in Docklands.

Reichmann, however, is convinced his vision is right, the idea being to create modern, spacious offices. The problem was that it started to come to fruition at a time when the country was diving into recession in the aftermath of the 1987 crash.

But it was this conviction that made him hold on to his dream during the difficult days in the early 90s when his Olympia & York business was bankrupted, the complex taken over by a syndicate of banks led by Lloyds bank before he bought it back again, with the help of some wealthy friends, for £800m.

It is these friends, the likes of Prince al-Waleed, and work colleagues to whom he feels a sense of "gratitude" rather than expressing pride as he surveys the view towards the City. "It would not have been possible without their support."

"London needs this district to compete with the City and West End," he says.Without Canary Wharf and its modern offices, there had been speculation that the big investment banks would relocate to Frankfurt where office space was cheaper than the over-crowded financial district in London. With such a threat still hanging over the City, this time because of the raging debate about whether Britain would be better in or out of the euro, Reichmann, with his bird's eye view of bankers' attitudes to the situation, refuses to be drawn into this row. Like the most experienced politician, he says: "I want to attract business from both sides of the fence."

webTitle: High priests cling to discredited faith

fields.headline: High priests cling to discredited faith
fields.trailText: People make mistakes. There - we've said it. It really wasn't so painful. Does it shock you? Probably not, most of us are humble enough to look at ourselves and know we make mistakes. But do you have any idea just how radical that simple statement is? To some finance academics it is pure heresy.
fields.body:
People make mistakes. There - we've said it. It really wasn't so painful. Does it shock you? Probably not, most of us are humble enough to look at ourselves and know we make mistakes. But do you have any idea just how radical that simple statement is? To some finance academics it is pure heresy.

Some still cling to the concept of efficient markets theory. This idea says that markets are just about always correctly priced. Any mistakes that are made are purely random and hence tend to cancel each other out. What is most worrying is that this style of thinking still dominates the way in which finance is taught in most universities.

However, those working in the real world of finance (if that isn't an oxymoron) have often expressed a healthy degree of scepticism over efficient markets theory. Now academia is catching up. Vast libraries of research by armies of academics have shown the efficient markets theory to be flawed. Investors' errors are not random, they follow largely predictable patterns.

Despite the overwhelming evidence, the high priests of market efficiency refuse to accept the invalidity of their cherished theories - desperately clinging to a discredited faith.

The alternative to the efficient market theory goes by the name behavioural finance. Essentially, the approach combines psychology and economics. It abandons the misleading assumptions that investors are rational and the arbitrage is costless.

Behavioural finance has a long and distinguished pedigree - John Maynard Keynes acknowledged the imperfection of financial markets opining "it is hard to see how any rational man can ever invest" and that there is nothing worse than a rational investment policy in an irrational world.

These are not the words of an ivory tower academic, but the voice of experience - Keynes made and lost several fortunes in the stock market.

Arbitrage is the key mechanism whereby prices are kept in line with fundamentals under the efficient markets theory. According to this view, identical assets cannot sell for different prices. If they did, someone would come in and make a risk-free profit by buying where the asset was cheap, and selling it where it was expensive.

This blind faith in markets has given rise to a believable (but hopefully apocryphal) story of two economists walking along the street. One sees a £50 note on the floor and points it out to the other economist (a true believer in efficient markets), who replies that he should not be so ridiculous: if there were a £50 note lying on the ground, someone would have already picked it up.

The behavioural finance approach accepts that there is an element within the market that makes mistakes. As an example, consider the example of Royal Dutch and Shell. These two firms are independently incorporated in the Netherlands and Britain respectively. In 1907 they both signed a charter, stating that the two companies would merge their interests on a 60:40 basis while remaining separate and distinct entities. Cash flow adjusted for corporate tax and control rights are effectively split in the agreed proportion.

Hence, if markets were efficient and set the market value of equities equal to the net present value of future cash flows, the market value of Royal Dutch should be 1.5 times the market value of Shell stock.

However, the reality is very much at odds with the efficient markets view: Royal Dutch market value -currency adjusted - = 1.5 x Shell market value.

The range of deviations is massive. Royal Dutch has fluctuated from a 35% undervalution to a 20% overvalaution in the past two decades. Anyone trying to profit from selling the relatively expensive Royal Dutch stock against the relatively cheap Shell stock in 1993 would only just be seeing the position in any kind of profit.

Remember hearing about a seriously large hedge fund needing to be rescued in 1998? It was called LTCM, and it specialised in these so-called "convergence" trades. Indeed, the Royal Dutch/Shell trade was one on which LTCM placed a bet which went bad. LTCM based many of its trades on the work of Nobel prizewinning economists (who were also partners in the firm) - even they make mistakes.

The interaction of mentality and markets is an area of vital importance. Market practitioners have long acknowledged the role of psychological factors in driving markets. So remember when you are deciding whether or not to invest, don't underestimate your own or indeed others' capacity to make mistakes.

James Montier is Global Strategist at Old Mutual Securities

These are not the words of an ivory tower academic, but the voice of experience - Keynes made and lost several fortunes in the stock market. Arbitrage is the key mechanism whereby prices are kept in line with fundamentals under the efficient markets theory. According to this view, identical assets cannot sell for different prices. If they did, someone would come in and make a risk-free profit by buying where the asset was cheap, and selling it where it was expensive. This blind faith in markets has given rise to a believable (but hopefully apocryphal) story of two economists walking along the street. One sees a £50 note on the floor and points it out to the other economist (a true believer in efficient markets), who replies that he should not be so ridiculous: if there were a £50 note lying on the ground, someone would have already picked it up. The behavioural finance approach accepts that there is an element within the market that makes mistakes. As an example, consider the example of Royal Dutch and Shell. These two firms are independently incorporated in the Netherlands and Britain respectively. In 1907 they both signed a charter, stating that the two companies would merge their interests on a 60:40 basis while remaining separate and distinct entities. Cash flow adjusted for corporate tax and control rights are effectively split in the agreed proportion. Hence, if markets were efficient and set the market value of equities equal to the net present value of future cash flows, the market value of Royal Dutch should be 1.5 times the market value of Shell stock. However, the reality is very much at odds with the efficient markets view: Royal Dutch market value -currency adjusted - = 1.5 x Shell market value. The range of deviations is massive. Royal Dutch has fluctuated from a 35% undervalution to a 20% overvalaution in the past two decades. Anyone trying to profit from selling the relatively expensive Royal Dutch stock against the relatively cheap Shell stock in 1993 would only just be seeing the position in any kind of profit. Remember hearing about a seriously large hedge fund needing to be rescued in 1998? It was called LTCM, and it specialised in these so-called "convergence" trades. Indeed, the Royal Dutch/Shell trade was one on which LTCM placed a bet which went bad. LTCM based many of its trades on the work of Nobel prizewinning economists (who were also partners in the firm) - even they make mistakes. The interaction of mentality and markets is an area of vital importance. Market practitioners have long acknowledged the role of psychological factors in driving markets. So remember when you are deciding whether or not to invest, don't underestimate your own or indeed others' capacity to make mistakes. James Montier is Global Strategist at Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Ceramics masters compete for gold
fields.standfirst: Stewart Dalby previews a sale of work by two of the most popular potters Britain has produced: Moorcroft and Cliff
fields.trailText: Stewart Dalby previews a sale of work by two of the most popular potters Britain has produced: Moorcroft and Cliff
fields.body:
In ceramics collecting, or in what might be termed factory ceramics collecting, William Moorcroft and Clarice Cliff are enjoying a tortoise and hare existence. There is a craze for the bright art deco and jazz-age figures of Clarice Cliff. Auctions of her work are packed. Prices seem to go sky-high (more than £18,000 in one instance).

But the more restful designs of Moorcroft art nouveau ceramics are also keenly sought and enjoy great popularity. There are 8,000-plus members of the Moorcroft Collectors Club who underpin the output of the Stoke factory, which is still operating and prices are strong.

Mark Wilkinson, a specialist at Christie's South Kensington, says: "They are two completely different markets. You need to be very considered with Clarice Cliff. You almost need to design a room around her wares. But the quieter floral designs of Moorcroft fit in anywhere."

Christie's has two dedicated auctions of Moorcroft each year and two of Cliff. Overall sales for each work out roughly the same, at around £1m annually.

Unusually, Phillip's auction house is holding an auction of both William Moorcroft and Clarice Cliff on Thursday July 13 in London's New Bond Street. Cynics may say that this is an attempt by the revived Phillip's under its new owner, French businessman Bernard Arnault, to break into markets dominated by the other big auction companies, Sotheby's, Christie's and Bonhams. Christie's, South Kensington, has established something of a corner in Clarice Cliff.

Johanna Freidwall, specialist at Phillips, says: "Clarice Cliff is new to us. We have only been doing this for a year." It shows. There are few outstanding Cliff pieces in the sale. There are 300 lots but the Moorcroft items are more interesting.

William Moorcroft started out 102 years ago, in the heyday of studio pottery, as the chief designer of the Macintyre factory. He was involved in creating what is known as florian ware, pottery drawing heavily on the stylised floral designs of William Morris. In 1913, Macintyre went off to make electrical goods and Moorcroft set up on his own in partnership with Liberty, the London department store.

Another difference between Cliff and Moorcroft is that she is dead while the Moorcroft line still exists. William Moorcroft's grandson John Moorcroft is managing director.

Ostensibly, little seems to have changed over the years. The designs have broadened out, their colours moving from the yellows and blues and greens with which they are traditionally associated to reds and yellows. But the motifs remain centred still on flowers, wildlife and landscapes. They are still hand coloured and some are characterised by "tube-lining", a ceramic equivalent of brocading.

The cognoscenti would tell you, however, that there is a difference. Johanna Freidwall says: "The pieces designed by William were extremely subtle and intricate in their colouring and design. The modern pieces reflect their time. They are bolder and brasher."

Recent pieces, often issued as limited editions, can fetch high prices. Items from the "carp decoration" brought out in the early 90s by Sally Tuffin, until recently chief designer at Moorcroft, have sold for £6,000. But pieces made by William Moorcroft in his heyday in the 1910s and 1920s can be very valuable. At a Christie's sale two bidders chased each other up to £12,550 for a 1928 "eventide" baluster vase.

At the Phillip's sale there are a number of Eventide pieces. One, a dish decorated with trees in ochre and green against an ochre/red sky, 18.5cm in diameter, is on offer at £800 to £1,000.

Another, a bowl decorated around the sides and to the interior in deep autumnal colours, 21.5in diameter with the signature in blue is priced at £150 to £200.

Moorcroft is a collectors' market rather than an investors' one. The company organises special weekends for collectors to visit the factory to buy the latest designs. But for those interested in older pieces there are a lot of good value pieces at the Phillip's sale. Those favouring particular designs such as the pomegranate or wisteria, early florian wares or later flambe ceramics, will find them, like the Eventide, starting at around £150.

Prices for old Moorcroft pieces might not be as acrobatic as Cliff, but enthusiasts who buy now will almost certainly find they have a steadily rising investment.

For further information: Phillips, tel: 020-7629-6602.

fields.headline: The sweet swoosh of success
fields.standfirst: Brand values Nike
fields.trailText: Phil Knight, a former long-distance runner, had been selling Japanese-made shoes out of the back of his car when he fell out with his Asian manufacturers in the early 1970s.
fields.body:
Phil Knight, a former long-distance runner, had been selling Japanese-made shoes out of the back of his car when he fell out with his Asian manufacturers in the early 1970s.

Keen to target local marathon runners with a new type of running shoe, he searched around for a name associated with the early days of the sport in ancient Greece. He picked the name of a goddess and paid a recent graduate $35 (£22) to design a logo which reflected the swoosh of speed.

Last year, Nike, the company and brand born out of these events in 1971, sold more sports shoes than any other in the world. Even after recent upsets, it has more than 45% of the US athletic shoe market.

The company, called Blue Ribbon Sports from 1962 until that swoosh of ancient inspiration, was started by Mr Knight and Bill Bowerman, a track coach, after they first met at the University of Oregon. Significantly, the two men left the car boot behind when they first harnessed the power of advertising.

After persuading several participants at the 1972 Olympic marathon trials in their home town of Oregon to wear their shoes, the pair quickly advertised the fact that their Nike shoes were worn by "four of the top seven finishers" of the race. By 1979 Nike controlled an estimated 50% of the US running shoe market.

Faced with increased competition from Reebok, which had spotted the growing market for aerobics in the early 1980s, Nike started to use high-profile sports stars to paint itself as the repository of youthful rebellion.

This positioning has resulted in the Nike brand being placed alongside Coca Cola and McDonald's as the very image of the American Dream. It now sells its products in 110 countries.

Although the company paid previously unheard of amounts to such stars as Andre Agassi and Charles Barkley, it was its association with Michael Jordan, the basketball player, that led to its greatest successes in the 1980s. After launching the Air Jordan shoe in 1985, the company started running its Just Do It ads in 1988. The "in-your-face" tone combined with the popularity of America's most successful player summed up the Nike brand.

According to Gareth Coombs, a co-founder of the Cambridge Strategy Centre and a brands expert, Nike also cashed in on a global trend towards healthier living and more casual dressing in the 1980s.

At the same time as the company became a business school case study for brand building, articles and books started to focus on the anti-establishment bravado of the corporate culture of its headquarters in Beavertown, Oregon. The culture exalted in turning down potential recruits with a doctorate and a law degree who did not know what Deion Sanders did.

The books have become more critical since 1993, commonly regarded as a turning point for the company and its brands. It was the year that Jordan retired and the year the company first cut jobs.

It was also in the mid-1990s when young people at college, part of Nike's target market, started to wage anti-sweatshop campaigns. Stung by reports of slave wages being paid to young children working in its third world factories, Nike had to raise wages at its plants in Vietnam and Indonesia as well as the minimum age of its workers to 16. But the most frightening development for the company was the backlash against branded clothing among the young. Students campaigned against greed masked as globalism and took to wearing non-branded grungey clothes.

Unsurprisingly for a company with its history, Nike has fought back by softening and diversifying its image as well as publicising its educational programmes . In 1995, it switched to the less aggressive "I can" slogan and signed up its first golfing figurehead.

The baby-faced Tiger Woods would show a calmer front to the world than the previously macho, sweat-streaked stars.

The strategy appeared to have failed in 1998 when falling sales in Asia led Nike to cut 1,200 jobs, or 5% of its workforce, and caused a quarterly loss. The company's fortunes began to show signs of recovery earlier this year with a 20% increase in orders from overseas.

Now Nike is using Marion Jones, a female athlete with a hard edge, and Lance Armstrong, the cyclist who battled cancer to win the 1999 Tour de France, to further burnish its image in this, an Olympic year vital for any sports brand.

The fax

Just say no Nike offered Ralph Nader, the consumer rights campaigner and presidential candidate, $25,000 to "take a light-hearted jab" at the company's poor human rights record in an ad. He said no

webTitle: Cambridge Discovery goes to US firm

fields.headline: Cambridge Discovery goes to US firm
fields.trailText: A long-running soap opera ended at Oxford Molecular yesterday, when the drug development software group sold its Cambridge Discovery Chemistry subsidiary for £35m to an American biotechnology firm.
fields.body:
A long-running soap opera ended at Oxford Molecular yesterday, when the drug development software group sold its Cambridge Discovery Chemistry subsidiary for £35m to an American biotechnology firm.

The sale, to Millennium Pharmaceuticals, is likely to trigger a full-scale break-up of Oxford Molecular, which made a £26m loss last year. The group once styled itself as "the next Misys" but an expected explosion in demand for hi-tech scientific software has failed to materialise.

Cambridge Discovery Chemistry is headed by Allan Marchington, the brother of Oxford Molecular's chief executive, Tony Marchington.

Allan Marchington said yesterday that he was sorry he would no longer be working with his brother: "Me and Tony have always got along pretty well."

Their relationship raised eyebrows in the City in 1998, when Oxford Molecular bought the Cambridge business for £13m. That deal meant a windfall of more than £4m for Allan Marchington and it was criticised by Oxford Molecular's then financial adviser, Nomura.

Mr Marchington said: "Joining Oxford Molecular gave us status and gave us access to some first-rate software. But in some respects I'm kicking myself." Oxford Molecular shares rose 3.5p to 29.5p.

fields.headline: Ministers keep Archer off target
fields.standfirst: Value for money note sole issue
fields.trailText: The government admits that Britain's armed forces are overstretched and, as US pressure for a greater European defence role rises in the run-up to November's presidential elections and the prospect of a new and probably more isolationist administration, the need to equip them with modern, effective kit will become ever more important.
fields.body:
But this week the national audit office reported that all but two of the Ministry of Defence's big projects are four years behind schedule. So much for the vaunted "smart" procurement initiative.

Take Bowman, the project to provide the army with 47,000 military mobile phones, including 3,500 high capacity data radios with access to the internet, in place of the clapped-out Clansman radios which in the Kosovo conflict proved so ineffective the Serbs could overhear every word said.

This scheme, eight years behind schedule, is crucial in providing the armed forces with digital battlefield communications; if ever there was a need for smart procurement this is it. But, after years of shilly-shallying, an agreement reached six months ago between industry and MoD now threatens to unravel - because ministers and officials keep moving the goalposts. The Archer consortium, composed of BAE Systems (30%), Racal (30%) and ITT (40%), agreed in December to scale back costs from £3.8bn to £2.1bn and has now trimmed that to a shade short of £1.7bn. But, under Treasury pressure and because of concern that the Bowman radios and network will not enter service until 2004-05, the MoD's equipment acquisitions committee has suggested the whole competition be reopened.

Now Archer is warning ministers that it can only keep the 400-strong team working until the end of this month on a project deemed crucial to the role of the pan-European rapid reaction forces; after that, it will walk away, leaving the MoD with little option but to order a lesser scheme.

This is not some arcane dispute about money but about a state-of-the-art project that would give British industry a proven lead in digitised military communication systems and the army a sophisticated network of secure data and voice transmission from command HQ to battlefield unit. Ministers' desire to get value for money is laudable but if the smart initiative is to prove not just a pie-in-the-sky mantra, they should approve the Archer bid swiftly and enhance, not compromise, Britain's and Europe's defence capability.

Strange Wim

Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, would never win prizes for diplomatic subtlety but yesterday's intervention in the debate about British membership of the euro looks frankly clumsy. To argue that Britain is suffering economically by not being in the euro at a time when UK unemployment is well below the average for the euro zone is a gift to critics of the bank and the defenders of the pound alike.

It may be that Britain is at a disadvantage by not being a member of the single currency club but recent events have shown that the evidence, such as it is, is scarcely compelling.

It is all very well for Mr Duisenberg to argue that he was speaking on technical and economic grounds and any decision on entry must be left to the voters. The British government has set its own economic tests which are additional to the Maastricht criteria. Gordon Brown in particular is unlikely to have been mollified by the qualifications the ECB president attached to his remarks.

One point is worth noting, however. While Britain now meets most of the Maastricht criteria, the exception, as Mr Duisenberg pointed out, is on the exchange rate. Strict interpretation of the treaty says single currency candidates must have at least two years in the exchange rate mechanism.

Some would argue Britain would do well to rejoin a system from which it was so ignominiously ejected in 1992 on the grounds it would allow time for the pound to settle at an appropriate euro entry level. It is not a view that finds favour in official quarters. No doubt that will provide Mr Duisenberg with the wherewithal for further undiplomatic interventions in Britain's euro debate.

Cash cowed

Meanwhile, back in the euro zone, the European commission reckons there is still plenty of work to be done getting the area's citizens and businesses up to speed.

According to a commission poll published yesterday, businesses are reluctant to use the euro, even though it has been available in virtual form since the beginning of last year.

Moreover, consumers are still confused about when and how notes and coins will be introduced, with just over half feeling they were insufficiently informed about the single currency.

webTitle: Opponents line up against German gay rights charter

fields.headline: Opponents line up against German gay rights charter
fields.trailText: A bill to extend the legal rights of gay couples began what is likely to be a stormy voyage through the German parliament yesterday.
fields.body:
A bill to extend the legal rights of gay couples began what is likely to be a stormy voyage through the German parliament yesterday.

Publication of the text of the proposed new law this week prompted a highly critical reaction from church leaders, rightwing opposition politicians and even a senior minister in Germany's centre-left coalition cabinet.

The issue is supremely delicate in a country where up to 15,000 homosexual men were put to death under the Third Reich. Homosexual acts were banned by law until 1969 and while Berlin has established itself as a "gay capital", attitudes in the rest of the country remain relatively conservative.

This is particularly so in staunchly Roman Catholic Bavaria, the stronghold of the Christian Social Union (SCU), which has promised implacable opposition to the bill. The party's general secretary, Thomas Goppel, called the measure "juridically superfluous and socially unacceptable".

The government's proposals are an attempt to make good on 1998 campaign promises.

As tabled, the bill would enable officially registered homosexual couples to file joint tax returns, claim social security benefits to which they are currently not entitled, and be treated in much the same way as married men and women for the purposes of inheritance and gift tax. It would not allow them to adopt children.

fields.headline: Policies 'punish genuine refugees'
fields.trailText: Measures adopted in Europe to combat the smuggling of immigrants are destroying the chances of genuine asylum-seekers fleeing persecution, a UN study said yesterday.
fields.body:
Measures adopted in Europe to combat the smuggling of immigrants are destroying the chances of genuine asylum-seekers fleeing persecution, a UN study said yesterday.

The study, commissioned by the UN's High Commissioner for Refugees called on EU countries to adopt common "legal and safe migration opportunities for all refugees", while bringing "the full weight of international justice" to bear on traffickers.

It said human trafficking has become virtually the only escape route for those entitled to protection in Europe and contradictory policies appear to harm the victims more than the traffickers.

The study found that trafficking involves between one-third and two-thirds of the main nationalities who go on to have their refugee claim accepted on the grounds of persecution, including Iraqis, Afghans, and Yugoslavs. Around 250,000 people seek asylum every year in Europe.

"The main nationalities that are being smuggled and trafficked to Europe to claim asylum are those same nationalities that are recognised as refugees by European countries themselves. Yet, these are the same nationalities that have been the main target of all European anti-trafficking and anti-smuggling activity," it says.

There has been a shift in the past decade from traditional deception - where migrants travel on invalid documents - to "clandestine methods" where they resort to traffickers or smuggling rings because of tighter obstacles to entry: 56% of illegal entries to Britain in 1998 were clandestine.

The study says politicians have created "public confusion and mistrust on issues of asylum policy", clouded by secrecy.

"Stop calling people illegal migrants or aliens if in fact you know these people are refugees legally entitled to asylum," its author, John Morrison, said.

webTitle: Short leads new move to help war torn Africa

fields.headline: Short leads new move to help war torn Africa
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, is to spearhead a cross-departmental initiative aimed at solving some of Africa's most intractable conflicts, the government announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, is to spearhead a cross-departmental initiative aimed at solving some of Africa's most intractable conflicts, the government announced yesterday.

In an attempt to use "joined-up government" to tackle the wars which scar many sub-Saharan countries, Britain's diplomatic, developmental and military operations aimed at resolving conflict will come under the same budget for the first time. Ms Short will chair a new ministerial group to include ministers from the Treasury, Ministry of Defence and Foreign Office.

Of 48 countries in sub-Saharan Africa, 22 are at war. In these countries 45% of the populations live on less than $1 a day.

"The consequence in injury and loss of life and the destruction of infrastructure are very great, but conflict also blocks development," said Ms Short. "While some African countries have begun to make economic and political progress in recent years, in many parts of the continent progress remains threatened and undermined by conflict."

A pooled budget for conflict resolution will be announced in the 2000 spending review, expected from the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, in mid-July.

At the moment, the three departments spend around £30m a year on conflict resolution - excluding contributions to international peacekeeping operations. Mr Brown said yesterday that the peacekeeping budget would receive a £7.5m top-up this year to cover efforts in Sierra Leone.

The Government hopes the new fund will help kickstart debt relief efforts for Africa, stalled as countries have diverted resources from povert reduction into war.

Mr Brown will use this weekend's meetingof the G7 finance ministers to spread the message that conflict resolution is a vital step for getting debt relief back on track.

"There are now 10 countries which cannot benefit from debt relief because they are in conflict," he said. "We want the international community to send a message to these countries: if by October, they can turn away from these conflicts we will make additional efforts to bring them forward in debt relief."

The 10 are Burundi, the Central African Republic, Congo Republic (Brazzaville), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Somalia, Sudan and Myanmar.

webTitle: Judgment day  Former GM executive fights extradition

fields.headline: Judgment day  Former GM executive fights extradition
fields.trailText: The former General Motors executive wanted in the US on charges of passing secret documents to Volkswagen, told a Spanish judge yesterday that he would fight extradition.
fields.body:
The former General Motors executive wanted in the US on charges of passing secret documents to Volkswagen, told a Spanish judge yesterday that he would fight extradition.

Spanish-born Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua who was forced to resign from Germany's VW in 1996, faces a six-count indictment, including charges of industrial espionage, handed down in May by a federal grand jury in Detroit, Michigan.

Lopez, nicknamed "Superlopez" for the revolutionary cost-cutting measures he introduced to the auto industry, rejected extradition in an appearance on Friday before a high court judge in Madrid.

"I don't want to be extradited," he told Judge Juan del Olmo at a closed-door hearing. "I want to live in my country."

Lopez rose to fame when he helped turn around US car maker General Motors in the early 1990s with controversial cost-cutting measures that involved squeezing suppliers' prices.

When he defected from the General Motors to Volkswagen in 1993, GM was quick to accuse him of stealing documents.

The case was settled out of court in 1997 with VW agreeing to pay $100m (£62m) in compensation and buying $1bn worth of GM parts. Lopez returned to Spain.

webTitle: IBT investors in key vote on board

fields.headline: IBT investors in key vote on board
fields.trailText: The fate of Rothschild's £270m International Biotechnology Trust was on a knife-edge last night, as shareholders voted on proposals to oust the board and carry out a wholesale reconstruction.
fields.body:
The fate of Rothschild's £270m International Biotechnology Trust was on a knife-edge last night, as shareholders voted on proposals to oust the board and carry out a wholesale reconstruction.

About 60 private and institutional investors turned up for an extraordinary general meeting. They spent more than an hour discussing the resolutions, put forward by the US arbitrage firm, Millennium Partners, which has a 10% stake.

Millennium has raised issues about corporate governance at the trust. IBT's principal, Jeremy Curnock Cook, resigned last week "on health grounds", saying his heart condition had been aggravated by criticism of his position. Millennium dislcosed that Mr Curnock Cook held share options worth more than $1m (£625,000) in some of the companies in which IBT has invested.

Millennium wants to give shareholders the option of realising their investments, or carrying forward their shares in a trust with new management. It wants to replace Rothschild as fund manager with either 3i or Merlin Ventures.

However, IBT may have persuaded enough shareholders to support the board by offering a large cash handout - initially £70m - then another £50m by September 2001.

Reaction to the offer from investors was mixed.

webTitle: Welsh plea over Hyder bid snubbed

fields.headline: Welsh plea over Hyder bid snubbed
fields.trailText: The government yesterday snubbed the national assembly for Wales by rejecting its campaign to "repatriate" from Brussels the £464m bid for multi-utility Hyder by Western Power Distribution of the United States.
fields.body:
The government yesterday snubbed the national assembly for Wales by rejecting its campaign to "repatriate" from Brussels the £464m bid for multi-utility Hyder by Western Power Distribution of the United States.

Its decision, announced by Kim Howells, the Welsh MP who is competition minister, is bound to trigger a new phase in the bid war for Wales's largest public corporation between WPD and its rival, Japanese bank Nomura.

Nomura, which has bid 260p a share or £401m against WPD's 300p, remains under pressure to raise its offer but last night welcomed Mr Howells's statement.

The Welsh assembly, backed by Rhodri Morgan, first secretary, urged the DTI to ask Brussels to hand the bid back to Britain because it believes the US offer involves the break-up of Hyder and the effective merger of its water business Dwr Cymru with United Utilities, leading to the loss of hundreds of Welsh jobs.

WPD's offer would leave ownership of Welsh Water's assets in its hands but transfer management to Warrington-based United which would also acquire Hyder's non-regulated services business. WPD would take on electricity distributor Swalec but assembly members feared it would be merged with its Bristol-based power business, South Western Electricity.

Mike German, Liberal Democrat leader in the assembly, accused WPD of secret "sale of shares" arrangements with United to hand over the employment contracts of thousands of Hyder staff to United.

WPD executives insisted that the arrangements had been disclosed to both the DTI and office of fair trading and denied any threat to jobs beyond 1,000 redundancies planned by Hyder.

"I think we will win and that will be the best outcome for the business and the people of Wales," one insider said. "We are an experienced utility and I don't think Nomura is in there for the long term. We genuinely want to own and improve Hyder as a Welsh-based business."

Mr Howells last night muddied the regulatory issues by declaring that WPD's offer could not be repatriated because it did not meet the criteria for doing so. But he said the arrangement for Welsh Water did fall within the powers of British competition authorities.

While his overall decision is a snub to the fledgling parliament, it does meet its wish for the future of Welsh Water to be decided in Britain. The OFT and the water regulator, Ofwat, have yet to decide whether to refer the WPD/UU arrangement to the competition commission.

Nomura said last night: "This decision had been anticipated. It is helpful that it has now been made so that the way is cleared for consideration of a reference to the UK competition commission."

But the Japanese bank, which last week claimed 18.8% acceptances for its lower offer, is considering raising its offer to deliver a knockout blow.

webTitle: Berlin's Love Parade marches to a techno beat

fields.headline: Berlin's Love Parade marches to a techno beat
fields.trailText: I shall not easily forget my first experience of Berlin. How could I? We had just cleared the baggage reclaim at Tegel airport when I ducked into the men's loo to find two teenage girls wearing next to nothing helping a teenage boy, who was wearing even less, apply metallic eye shadow.
fields.body:
I shall not easily forget my first experience of Berlin. How could I? We had just cleared the baggage reclaim at Tegel airport when I ducked into the men's loo to find two teenage girls wearing next to nothing helping a teenage boy, who was wearing even less, apply metallic eye shadow. If I remember correctly, he had on a pink tutu, tights and boots.

On our first reconnoitre of the city we had run into the Love Parade.

The event has only this year reached Britain - a simultaneous Love Parade clone is due to be held in Leeds today. The whole unlikely business started in 1989, the year of the fall of the Wall. A Berlin DJ, Mathias Röingh, aka "Dr Motte", drove up the Kurfürstendamm with a couple of ill-synchronised cassette recorders blasting out house music. About 150 of his friends and fans followed, turning the event into an impromptu rave.

Spool forward 10 years to 1999 and the turnout for the Love Parade has risen to a million and a half. It has outgrown its original venue and now takes place along the wide boulevard slicing through the Tiergarten park in the centre of Berlin. The two cars in the original parade have been replaced by giant floats loaded with solid walls of sound equipment. And Dr Motte has been joined by all of the city's, and a lot of the world's, best DJs.

The Love Parade is not just a vast street party, but the planet's biggest celebration of dance culture and techno music. The din it generates is such that when Berlin zoo published its annual results last month, it noted that an important reason for 1999's losses was that the noise had prompted a number of the animals to abort valuable offspring.

There are other down-sides. Two people died last year from drug abuse. The Tiergarten is being slowly poisoned by the vast quantities of urine peed out by the ravers each year. And, as the local papers never tire of emphasising, they also leave behind prodigious quantities of rubbish.

Yet almost no one in local politics is seriously advocating that the Love Parade move on. In fact, when the pressure on the organisers over the rubbish got too much a few years back, they trumped their critics with a threat to take the event out of Berlin.

The backing that the parade gets, from left and right alike, has something to do with tourist revenues. But what it has most to do with is giving Germany's new (yet old) capital a fresh image, allowing it to distance itself further from the terrible past.

There is nothing that the majority of Berliners would like better than for their city to be known in the 21st century more for a riotous annual carnival than as the former seat of the Third Reich. If that means putting up with open drug-taking, drunkenness, exhibitionism, an all-night sexfest in the Tiergarten, and mountains of rubbish the next day, then so be it.

Nowadays, the Love Parade consists of two processions which advance in opposite directions down the Strasse des 17 Juli. You may not know the name, but you would recognise this broad, tree-lined avenue from photographs of the 1930s showing Hitler's SA marching in pomp. In the middle of the Strasse des 17 Juni, where the two columns come together for the climactic evening rave, stands the Siegessäule (the Victory Column), an ugly, sombre and blatant monument to Prussian militarism. The symbolism of the Love Parade could scarcely be plainer.

When the Germans were pulling together their pavilion for the world fair, Expo 2000, in Hanover it was decided to create a hall of fame with giant busts of modern Germany's most distinguished figures. Among them is one of Dr Motte.

webTitle: Virgin Atlantic staff ballot rebuffs unions

fields.headline: Virgin Atlantic staff ballot rebuffs unions
fields.trailText: Staff at Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic have failed to get the majority that would force the company to recognise trade unions, the airline announced here today.
fields.body:
Staff at Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic have failed to get the majority that would force the company to recognise trade unions, the airline announced here today.

Of a total of 5,829 staff, only 1,949 voted in favour of union recognition in a ballot conducted by the Electoral Reform Society.

But Sir Richard acknowledged that the majority of Virgin's 650 pilots had asked for union recognition. The company is therefore meeting Balpa, the pilots' union, later this month.

The company decided to ballot its staff voluntarily after the government's trade union legislation came into force earlier this year. Under the legislation there has to be a 50% turnout of staff, with at least 40% of all staff voting in favour of union recognition.

In a letter to pilots Sir Richard said: "We have set up a meeting to have a discussion to explore the possibility of a mutually acceptable agreement for both Virgin and Balpa."

Sir Richard acknowledged that a large minority had voted for union recognition, but said most employees recognised that the company was continuing to make good progress with its system of consultation committees. "We would prefer it if the company works as one but we are ready to listen to what we are told."

Sir Richard spent most of yesterday in talks with Indian government officials on the possibility of opening up new routes into the country, after Virgin's inaugural flight to Delhi landed on Thursday. Sir Richard said that Bombay and Calcutta were next on the list, but this depended on an agreement with Air India.

Air India, which is due to be privatised, has signed a codesharing pact with Virgin under which the Indian airline has handed over to Virgin three of its weekly flight allocations and promised to give "favourable consideration" to offering Sir Richard its remaining three weekly route slots by next March.

Air India yesterday responded to heavy criticism in the Indian media of the alliance, which some commentators claimed would diminish the value of any sell-off of the company.

A lack of landing slot availability at Heathrow airport had prevented it from using more than 10 of its 16 weekly route allocations, Air India said.

The pact with Virgin would add 732 seats a week to the London-Delhi route, some of which would be sold by Air India.

 Virgin Blue, Sir Richard's internal airline in Australia, begins operations at the weekend with an inaugural flight between Brisbane and Sydney. Scheduled flights will not start for several weeks, but will be operating before the start of the Olympics.

The pact with Virgin would add 732 seats a week to the London-Delhi route, some of which would be sold by Air India.  Virgin Blue, Sir Richard's internal airline in Australia, begins operations at the weekend with an inaugural flight between Brisbane and Sydney. Scheduled flights will not start for several weeks, but will be operating before the start of the Olympics.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Unions fear up to 500 job losses after a Japanese electronics form announced the closure of a factory under restructuring plans.
fields.body:
Sumitomo job losses feared

Unions fear up to 500 job losses after a Japanese electronics form announced the closure of a factory under restructuring plans.

Sumitomo Electric Wiring Systems said its plant at Sunderland, Tyne and Wear will close in the first half of next year.

No details of job losses were given, but unions said they feared hundreds of jobs will be lost.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union said: "This is a shocking decision that will have a terrible impact on an area of already high unemployment. We urge the company to look at alternatives. It cannot just walk away from its responsibilities."

2,000 Merrill jobs at risk

Merrill Lynch, the American investment bank, could cut as many as 2,000 jobs as part of a significant cost-cutting exercise in its US private client business.

The move, designed to improve margins at the business, would be the first dramatic action taken by Stan O'Neal, the executive appointed to head the US brokerage business earlier this year.

A spokesman for Merrill in New York declined to comment yesterday.

Wall Street analysts and dealers had expected the measures to be announced shortly following the company's recent commitment to increase operating margins from 19% to 24% over the next three years.

Vivendi seeks role in Sky arm

Vivendi wants to have a proper role to play in Sky Global, News Corp's future digital platform, a spokesman said.

The spokesman declined to comment on an article in a French newspaper which quoted the Vivendi chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, as saying that he might sell his company's 20% stake in BSkyB if he did not get a leading role in Sky Global.

Management buys Christy

Christy, the towel maker that supplies the Wimbledon tennis championships has been bought from Courtaulds Textiles by its management team in a £15m deal.

Managing director Joel Rosenblatt is leading the team based at the Hyde, Cheshire, plant. The buyout followed the decision by Courtaulds Textiles to sell the companies in its furnishings division.

Woolwich to sell free shares

Woolwich, the former building society turned bank, yesterday said it planned to sell all its unclaimed free shares, worth an estimated £72m, which were offered at the time of its stock market flotation three years ago.

Woolwich believes nearly 40,000 shareholders have not yet claimed some 23m free shares and it wants to track them down before it sells the shares in three months time.

Once the three month deadline ends on October 10, Woolwich will sell any unclaimed shares but retain the proceeds, which can be claimed for a further nine years. After that the proceeds revert to the company.

Stars picked as shoppers

Ask shoppers who epitomises their favourite supermarket and you will get some enlightening answers, according to a poll by Supermarketing magazine.

Jo Brand symbolises Asda, Coronation Street's Vera Duckworth personifies Safeway, Zoe Ball stands for Tesco and Gary Lineker epitomises Sainsbury's, according to the poll which asked which celebrities would visit the country's leading four stores to buy their groceries.

webTitle: Walkout by 5,000 halts production at Shorts

fields.headline: Walkout by 5,000 halts production at Shorts
fields.trailText: Nearly 5,000 workers at Belfast aerospace company Shorts were on strike yesterday.
fields.body:
Nearly 5,000 workers at Belfast aerospace company Shorts were on strike yesterday.

Five of the six unions at the company have called regular Friday strikes in a dispute over pay. An overtime ban was introduced on Wednesday.

The company's "final" four-year offer of a 3% a year increase with a review in years three and four if inflation exceeds expectations has been rejected.

Workers are unhappy with the length of the deal and want a two-year agreement. They claim the review clause is not binding. Shorts - a subsidiary of Bombardier Aerospace of Canada - warned the strikers that they could be jeopardising their jobs.

Bombardier recently announced a £100m investment in Shorts and a large increase in its workload.

In a statement, management warned workers that if their action caused delivery delays, work would go elsewhere.

"If industrial action or strike action disrupts the bringing of additional work to Belfast then it will place that work and the jobs involved at risk," the statement said. "Some of that work may have to go to companies outside Northern Ireland.

"If we fail to provide stability for our customers, there are many international competitors lining up who would be only too glad to provide that stability and to take on this long term work.

- Press Association
