fields.headline: Peugeot workers vote to strike
fields.standfirst: Ballots in manufacturing sector blot Britain's industrial relations copybook
fields.trailText: Britain's recent record as the Europe's strike-free country lost a lot of its gloss yesterday when 5,000 aerospace workers at Shorts, Belfast, went on strike and 3,000 car workers at Peugeot's Ryton plant voted for an all-out stoppage from next month
fields.body:
Britain's recent record as the Europe's strike-free country lost a lot of its gloss yesterday when 5,000 aerospace workers at Shorts, Belfast, went on strike and 3,000 car workers at Peugeot's Ryton plant voted for an all-out stoppage from next month - the first break in production at both sites for 22 years.

Ryton's French owners expressed bafflement at the threat of a strike over their plans for the shortest working week in the British car industry.

But the growing militancy among manufacturing staff testified to the impact that skills shortages and low unemployment are having as unions grow more confident in pressing their demands and use Conservative legislation, enforcing secret ballots, to extract concessions.

The decision at Ryton, home of the best-selling Peugeot 206 and a model for industrial relations in union eyes, "shocked" management which had planned to introduce a French-style 35-hour week, or 36.75-hour week including breaks, under the plant's agreement on flexible working and had secured the official if wary backing of the two unions, the TGWU and AEEU.

Members of the AEEU, a proponent of strike-free deals which urged a no vote, were 339-270 in favour of a 24-hour stoppage on July 24 followed by an all-out strike from August 21. TGWU members voted 60-40 in favour of action.

"We're asking our employees to work fewer hours and they want to go on strike," bemused Peugeot officials said, urging the unions to reconsider. But the row centres on Peugeot's plan for a Friday night shift one week in two which would count as overtime and see assembly-line workers pocket £90 a night, a 17% pay increase.

Peugeot's French employees work their 35-hour week in five seven-hour shifts but at Ryton the firm wanted the staff to come in 3.8 days a week instead of 4. Weekend shifts, normally covering Friday, Saturday and Sunday, would spread over into Monday and entail 3.3 days instead of 3.

Tony Woodley, the TGWU's chief car negotiator, said union officials had warned a "greedy" Peugeot that the workers would object to compulsory overtime working on a Friday that was aimed at boosting output of the 206 from 168,000 units last year to nearer 200,000 this year. This would be on top of the agreed annualised hours.

Talks to resolve the dispute are likely next week, largely because union leaders believe the deal offers substantial benefits compared with the job-losses at Rover and Ford. These include the cut in the working week, the first at Ryton for 17 years, improved pay and conditions for 900 staff taken on two years ago and a commitment to introduce a new model, the 206 estate, to be built in Britain alone.

Mr Woodley said: "We have now given the company some time to review its position. If the company don't want to talk it will be an all-out strike; then they will want to talk."

A Peugeot spokesman said: "Obviously, we don't want to see this dispute coming off and we will do everything we can to find a way around it ... But it is very difficult to contemplate renegotiating something which has already been accepted by officials."

fields.trailText:
Thursday - MoD overspends by £3bn, half of page 4; Friday - PM's son gets drunk, front page, pages 6 and 7, Polly Toynbee article, letters and leader comment. Can't we have a sense of proportion, at least from the Guardian?
Vince McGlennan
Glasgow

Thursday - MoD overspends by £3bn, half of page 4; Friday - PM's son gets drunk, front page, pages 6 and 7, Polly Toynbee article, letters and leader comment. Can't we have a sense of proportion, at least from the Guardian?
Vince McGlennan
Glasgow

 Being a parent normally lasts longer than being a prime minister but to suggest, even in jest, that it is harder is sentimental nonsense (Emotional PM talks of faith and family, July 7). The 99.99% of young people who stand no chance of reaching No 10 should not be discouraged from making a stab at being good parents.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

 Where were Euan's friends as he lay there in Leicester Square?
Father Bryan Storey
Tintagel
bryan@storey150.freeserve. co.uk

 If Euan Blair was the son of a poor single mother, he'd have all the wrath of the government on his head. The Blair family should, for a start, stop trailing their religious piety around the country.
Bill Moore
Youlgrave, Derbyshire
billmore@freenetname.co.uk

 You report that after Euan Blair's arrest in Leicester Square, Scotland Yard officers went around the local businesses seizing videotape footage from security cameras, which presumably might have shown the young Blair's antics beforehand. Is it really the function of the police to confiscate other people's property in order to prevent political embarrassment to the Prime Minister?
Nick Wray
Derby
nickwray@globalnet.co.uk

 So it's a hearty slap on the back and congratulations all round as Blair Junior drinks his way into manhood. We can only speculate about what the reaction would be if it had been a 16-year-old Kathryn lying legless in the gutter.
Pat Spungin
London
spungin@raisingkids.co.uk

 I see that Euan Blair was found slumped in Leicester Square by a plaque honouring Richard E Grant. Perhaps the evening was a homage to Withnail And I ("I demand to have some booze") and a celebration of the British film industry rather than a post-GCSE bender. As long as he doen't go the same way as Oliver Reed...
Alastair Macaulay
London
alastairmacaulay@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Happy day: it's the HMIs
fields.trailText: Gary Younge's article (The day of reckoning, July 3) and the debate on Ofsted and local education authorities (Saturday Review, July 1) oblige me to write. I was a teacher for 50 years, from 1937 to 1987. I worked with local authorities - Kent, the London county council and Hertfordshire -who made distinguished contributions to the advances in education in that period.
fields.body:
Gary Younge's article (The day of reckoning, July 3) and the debate on Ofsted and local education authorities (Saturday Review, July 1) oblige me to write. I was a teacher for 50 years, from 1937 to 1987. I worked with local authorities - Kent, the London county council and Hertfordshire -who made distinguished contributions to the advances in education in that period.

Just a few miles south of the school Gary Younge visited in Letchworth, I enjoyed a full inspection from HMIs at Alleyne's grammar school, Stevenage, in 1953. My colleagues and I would consider the week the inspectors spent with us as the happiest and most professionally informative of the decade. Two or three of the teachers were in their first post, at least two had very serious weaknesses.

The contribution of the inspectors was to improve everything without any concern or reproach. Their understanding of how to show a teacher how to improve was most impressive.

For the Ofsted spokesman to say to Gary Younge that "nobody knew what happened in our schools" is an unbelievable absurdity.

Throughout my 50 years of teaching I was guided by men of genius who had a vision of what would help the growth of young men and women.

Central government cannot do it all and it is tragic for our children if teachers are being harassed and misunderstood. Every class of pupils is different and, depending on the weather, the time of day and the state of mind of the teachers, the good or the bad happen. How do you pay that by results?
Francis Cammaerts
Le Pouget, France

fields.headline: Virtual loyalism
fields.trailText:
Is it not possible for someone to develop a virtual reality march down the Garvaghy Road (Orangemen split on violence, July 7)? Then, not only would "loyalists" be able to take part every day of the year, if they wished, but we would also be spared observing their depressing antics.
Dave Hanson
Hull

 Will someone please explain how people getting drunk and shouting at each other in England are "yobs", but sober people throwing petrol bombs and fireworks at the police in Northern Ireland are "loyalists"?
Philip Parker
Leamington Spa

 I'm afraid Ivor Gaber is completely mistaken (Comment, July 6) in assuming the Mail on Sunday changed its front page following his representations on behalf of Lord Levy. As a professor of journalism, Mr Gaber should know that newspapers change their front pages to accommodate breaking stories. This is just what happened last Saturday night when the Ken Follett story broke. Our full story about Lord Levy's South American trip ran across two pages inside through all editions.
Russell Forgham Mail on Sunday

 Simon Hoggart's attacks on Conservative MP Michael Fabricant and his amazing unicolour haircut (Sketch, July 7) are becoming increasingly contemptuous and threatening to descend into gutter ridicule. Please keep up the good work.
Howard Rose
 Dublin
v-hrose@microsoft.com

Ed Lilley
Bristol

webTitle: Worried by the misappliance of science

fields.headline: Worried by the misappliance of science
fields.trailText: An investment programme into scientific research (Science gets £1bn to halt brain drain, July 5) is a welcome development. However, our well nurtured research students with further academic aspirations should be warned they may be heading for unemployment.
fields.body:
An investment programme into scientific research (Science gets £1bn to halt brain drain, July 5) is a welcome development. However, our well nurtured research students with further academic aspirations should be warned they may be heading for unemployment.

As a devoted mathematician with a first class degree and a good PhD I have been enjoying the scintillating conversation of the dole queue for the past six months. My bank balance is the negative of that of my non-academic friends. This is my reward for being passionate about mathematics since childhood.

In such circumstances any allegiance (if present) to British/European science evaporates and one takes the first job offered, regardless of geography. Indeed, there is a strong urge to escape from one's oppressor'. These are the simple mechanics of the brain drain.

Research students are important for the future livelihood of academic communities only when they have an academic future. I trust the financiers will create sufficient academic posts for the new PhDs they intend to encourage, otherwise the boosted grant will go towards their move to the US.
Dr B Sheppard
Reading, Berks

 George Monbiot (Science is selling out to business, July 6) is right in his suggestion that scientists are being transformed into prostitutes of big business. I see this first hand as a technician in the engineering department of a large university. More sharp-suited business people can be seen in my department than scientists in lab coats. This change is not healthy for society but at present inevitable. The rich, and big business, will keep control of universities as knowledge is power and power is control. Sadly there can be no change in our universities if the rest of society and all its cultural aims are subjugated to the need to make profit.
Martin Cobourne
St Helens

 In principle, the more money we spend on science, the better off we will be. But when public research is used for strictly private ends, it's hard to see why we should fund it. Only a small fraction of the money going into research is commercial, as distinct from charitable, and helps keep labs going. I am amazed at the hostility of your article: is it any wonder that so many of us are leaving?
Dr Martyn Sharpe
Institute of Neurology London msharpe@ion.ucl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Potteriana
fields.trailText: So Harry Potter takes over the world, but his illustrators lose the plot (the Editor, July 7). I was fascinated to see that the publishers feel the need to draw different images of Harry on the covers for different countries, to fit in with what they see as different national stereotypes. The Hungarian, Icelandic and French Harrys appear cheerful, bright, alert and friendly, like the English version.
fields.body:
So Harry Potter takes over the world, but his illustrators lose the plot (the Editor, July 7). I was fascinated to see that the publishers feel the need to draw different images of Harry on the covers for different countries, to fit in with what they see as different national stereotypes. The Hungarian, Icelandic and French Harrys appear cheerful, bright, alert and friendly, like the English version.

But I was horrified to see that the German Harry appears sad, pompous, complacent and withdrawn. I wonder whether this very disturbing role-model will really attract children in Germany. If such a thing as a national psyche really exists, could it really be so different in Germany from the rest of Europe, or have the publishers got it badly wrong?

Ray Booth
Leeds

But I was horrified to see that the German Harry appears sad, pompous, complacent and withdrawn. I wonder whether this very disturbing role-model will really attract children in Germany. If such a thing as a national psyche really exists, could it really be so different in Germany from the rest of Europe, or have the publishers got it badly wrong? Ray Booth Leeds

fields.headline: Death on an epic scale
fields.standfirst: Aids is one of the great world catastrophes
fields.trailText: Leader: By the time you finish reading this leader comment, another 10 people will have contracted HIV; if you're a slow reader, make that 20.
fields.body:
By the time you finish reading this leader comment, another 10 people will have contracted HIV; if you're a slow reader, make that 20. Twenty lives shattered. Every day 15,000 people contract the disease. Worldwide, 53m are now HIV positive and 19m have died of Aids. Tragically, the bulk of this catastrophe is happening in sub-Saharan Africa. If you have a teenage son in South Africa, he has a terrifying 50/50 chance of dying of Aids: in Botswana, that will be 66%. The number of deaths already dwarfs the genocide of Rwanda or the death toll of combatants of both of the last century's world wars.

And to make the scale of this crisis clear: these statistics will get worse and worse. Our children and children's children are likely to be dealing with the consequences for much of this century. Consequences such as 12m orphans in sub-Saharan Africa alone; a generation of economically active adults decimated; decades of painstaking advances in life expectancy and literacy going into reverse. The economic, political and social fabric of swathes of the African continent is unravelling in the heartwrenching suffering of millions of people. And there is fear that in time, parts of Asia - populous nations such as India and China - will be similarly afflicted.

Tomorrow's international Aids conference has rightly set up camp in the eye of the storm, in Durban: South Africa has the largest population of HIV affected people in the world: 42m. It opens up a debate which many of the governments in the region have been keen to repress. It also marks a shift of focus of the international effort to combat Aids, away from the west's preoccupation with the expensive science of vaccines, anti-Aids drugs and research into the origins of the disease, and towards deciding which tactics can penetrate the poverty and social taboos of Africa to reduce infection rates.The tragedy is that the very magnitude of this disaster seems to be paralysing the human race's capacity to respond. As the International Herald Tribune pointed out this week, information about the disease has been subjected to "demand management" as governments and international agencies (WHO and Unicef included) failed to give it priority for fear of their entire budgets being swallowed up. In 1991, the US administration was warned how destabilising Aids would prove, but it committed only $124.5m - just over half what the US spends on baldness treatments annually - and since then 18m have contracted HIV.

This fatalistic inertia has pervaded many governments in the developing world, as well as the west; they preferred to turn aside from the complicated questions of sexual mores, thus criminally exposing millions of children and young adults to infection. But as Durban will show, it does not have to be this way. There are also success stories. In Thailand, where intensive campaigns have increased condom use to 90%, the numbers of army conscripts who are HIV positive has dropped by half. An exception in Africa, Uganda has managed to reduce HIV rates among young people. But such programmes are rare because they involve tackling deep social prejudices around sexual behaviour and the most marginalised groups in society.

This is a grim picture, and there are no easy solutions. It will require huge amounts of money and political will, and it will probably be several generations before this catastrophe is curbed. In the meantime, as our reporter Maggie O'Kane describes today, a human tragedy is unfolding every minute.

fields.headline: Soccer's cup of sorrows
fields.trailText: I am disgusted that the right to host the 2006 football World Cup has been awarded to Germany (Inquest into £10m World Cup flop, July 7). I have followed the decision making process with great interest. Fifa admitted that the bids submitted by all the countries involved were of a high standard. Towards the end of the biding process, it became apparent that Germany and South Africa were the favourites, and that both countries displayed the ability to host an event of such magnitude.
fields.body:
I am disgusted that the right to host the 2006 football World Cup has been awarded to Germany (Inquest into £10m World Cup flop, July 7). I have followed the decision making process with great interest. Fifa admitted that the bids submitted by all the countries involved were of a high standard. Towards the end of the biding process, it became apparent that Germany and South Africa were the favourites, and that both countries displayed the ability to host an event of such magnitude.

It seemed to me that Fifa, by awarding the right to host this event to South Africa, had an excellent opportunity to contribute to the development of football in Africa and also to the socio-economic development of southern Africa. This event would have contributed more in terms of job creation and economic growth to this region than the combined development aid of the whole of the G8 could have provided.

South Africa's GDP per person is a mere 40% of that of Germany. One can only imagine what this event would have done to the development of this region. The alarming HIV-Aids statistics in southern Africa, and the clear link between poverty and HIV-Aids infection rates make this decision even more shameful.

It is a sad day when the narrow interest of the developed world triumphs over its ability to do genuine good. .
PR Smith
Newark, Notts p_asmith@yahoo.com

 I suspect that the reason for New Zealand abstaining from the final ballot was to protect the status of rugby union in South Africa. These two states are the strongest rugby-playing countries in the world and the game reigns supreme, with very little opposition from other sport. Would all this have changed if the soccer World Cup had been staged there?
Michael Murphy
Huddersfield

 As a means of avoiding the costly and escalating demands of Fifa delegates for beach parties, malibu drunk straight from the pineapple and blazer badge commemorative box sets, I suggest Fifa adopts the Eurovision system of deciding the next venue: if you win it, you hold it . That way Africa will eventually get to hold a World Cup, Europeans won't have to get up at 4am to watch group games (unless the Aussies fulfil their potential), and global domination by a single country would be avoided because successful teams would be so sick of holding the thing that they throw games, thus giving us all a chance of winning.

It would also introduce a degree of fairness and transparency to the overall process.
Neil Manley
Beckenham Kent

 Surely both the European and World football championships should always be held in England, to ensure our yobs don't inflict themselves on others?
Chris Maher
Caerphilly, Mid Glamorgan

 England will not be hosting the World Cup in 2006 - good! And presumably as it will not again be Europe's turn for a while, this precludes any danger of England hosting the competition in the foreseeable future - doubly good! In spite of the weather, summer 2006 seems that bit brighter.
Terry Peck
Roade, Northants

 Serves us right. If we'd thrown our weight behind the South African bid, as Nelson Mandela asked us to, we'd have made some friends instead of so many enemies, and probably avoided losing to Germany again.
Nick Martin-Clark
London
nndlmc28@netscapeonline. co.uk

fields.headline: They wuz robbed
fields.standfirst:
South Africa has a right to feel cheated

South Africa's 2006 World Cup bid
fields.trailText: Leader: The contest, it seemed, could have only one outcome. With England and Morocco out of the hunt, Germany and South Africa were destined to tie, 12 votes each. The president of Fifa would then use his casting vote and South Africa would win the right to stage the 2006 World Cup.
fields.body:
The contest, it seemed, could have only one outcome. With England and Morocco out of the hunt, Germany and South Africa were destined to tie, 12 votes each. The president of Fifa would then use his casting vote and South Africa would win the right to stage the 2006 World Cup. But then came a twist none had foreseen. When the final vote was taken, the 78-year-old representative of New Zealand, mandated to vote for South Africa once England was out of the chase, was inexplicably missing. So Germany, host nation as recently as 1974, won by a single vote, and hugely deserving South Africa was sent empty away.

Even if we were not in the backwash of disclosures of cricketing fraud, most people would scent something fishy here; all the more so because this decision, which had so much hanging on it in terms of national prestige and political and economic consequence, came out of a world thick with clandestine deals and inducements. Past deals helped determine the outcome here, while others we do not yet know about may already have written the script for the next round in four years time. England's bid cost some £10m - no more than Arsenal routinely spends on fresh French arrivals, maybe, but money which could have funded many worthwhile projects elsewhere. And yet it was doomed all along - judged by potential allies to have broken the terms of a deal made seven years ago to win us the right to stage Euro 96.

Fifa is now to investigate claims of bribery, corruption, even of death threats now ringing round Zurich. But what matters far more is to clean up this whole system and to introduce rules which would guarantee greater equity between continents: even if that means that England's hopes of a second triumph at Wembley are yet further deferred. "I still confidently expect to see England stage the World Cup in my lifetime" the prime minister's emissary, Tony Banks, declared yesterday. He is 57. He'll be lucky.

webTitle: Fear of race bias delays execution

fields.headline: Fear of race bias delays execution
fields.trailText: The first execution by US federal authorities in nearly four decades is likely to be delayed, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
The first execution by US federal authorities in nearly four decades is likely to be delayed, it was reported yesterday.

The expected stay of execution was prompted by concerns that the chances of being sentenced to death are often determined by the defendant's race and where the trial was held, and comes at time when capital punishment has become a presidential election issue.

Most Americans still support the death penalty, but the nation's certainty has been jolted recently by a series of high-profile cases in which death row inmates have been exonerated and their trials shown to have been flawed.

At the same time, the US press has been scrutinising the Republican contender, George W Bush, over the record number of executions he has overseen as Texas governor.

But the federal execution due on August 5 of a convicted triple murderer, Juan Raul Garza, would focus attention back on President Clinton and the Vice-President Al Gore, Mr Bush's Democratic opponent. They both support capital punishment, but have also voiced concern about the recent string of errors.

Garza's lawyers had filed an appeal claiming that the imposition of the death penalty was racially weighted. Of the 21 inmates now on federal death row, 17 are black or Hispanic.

President Clinton has ordered an investigation into the claims of bias. He has also asked the justice department to draw up a formal procedure that would make it easier for federal death row inmates to ask for clemency.

According to the New York Times, Garza's execution is likely to be put off at least until the justice department has completed its review.

If the sentence is carried out, Garza will be the first federal inmate to be executed since John F Kennedy's presidency. The death penalty was suspended by the supreme court in 1972 and only reinstated 12 years ago.

Most capital crimes are tried in the state courts, but in 1988, amid fears that drugs would fuel a rising tide of violent crime, Congress gave federal prosecutors the right to call for the death penalty for a list of aggravated crimes. The legislation has mostly been applied to drug-related murders.

Garza was sentenced to death under this "drug kingpin statute" in a federal court seven years ago. He ran a drug smuggling operation across the Texas-Mexican border and was convicted of murdering three people who got in his way.

There is no dispute that non-white prisoners are over-represented on death row, but proponents of capital punishment argue that those figures simply mirror the crime statistics. Opponents argue that black or Hispanic defendants are far more likely to be sentenced to death than white defendants who have committed the same crimes.

The justice department study is supposed to untangle the statistics to reveal any pattern of prejudice in federal courts.

It is also supposed to look into the fact that, of the 471 death penalty cases referred to the attorney general by federal prosecutors between 1995 and 1998, 200 came from five judicial districts: Puerto Rico, Eastern Virginia, Eastern New York, Southern New York and Maryland.

Defence lawyers argue that the figures show that death sentences are not evenly applied. Garza's lawyer, Gregory Wiercioch, said that his appeal for clemency would emphasise the discriminatory nature of death sentences in the US. He said its imposition was like a "rigged lottery" in which the outcome was determined by "the colour of your skin and where you purchased your ticket".

President Clinton last week also expressed concern over "the disturbing racial composition" of the inmate population on federal death row.

He added that the geographical disparities in sentencing "raises the question whether, even though there is a uniform law across the country, what your prosecution is may turn solely on where you committed the crime".

webTitle: Step to the right, step to the left, step on your partner's toe

fields.headline: Step to the right, step to the left, step on your partner's toe
fields.trailText: Why prams are getting bigger | New Labour's chicken run | Jack Straw's 'fuzzy logic'
fields.body:
I went to a barn dance last Saturday and great fun it was too. What I like about barn dances in this country is the manic disorder. The caller does his (or in this case, her) spiel, about step to the front, step to the left, doh-si-doh your partner now, and swing! For the first few minutes we get it right; couples promenade on cue, stars are formed, we all walk under the appropriate arches. We begin to imagine we can do it. A certain complacency creeps in. Glasses of cold chardonnay, the traditional accompaniment to these events, are generously swigged.

Then at a certain point, possibly related to the hour, more likely to the consumption of alcohol, things begin to fall apart. You look up from the promenade and find you're staring at a quite different woman from the one you started with. You form a circle, but someone isn't fast enough, gets left out, and can only return by smashing into a different part of the line to grab a random hand. By the last number, the place is in total chaos, with people frolicking around in no order at all, bouncing off each other, desperately gazing for someone they came with. It's great fun.

The point of barn dances in the old west, I assume, is that it not only brought together all the unmarried men and women from miles around, but it allowed them to have brief but real physical contact with all the others. Thus they were able to decide whether they actually fancied each other without breaking the rigid mores of the day.

 We had prams in the old days, prams, which were skips with suspension. Their main job was to permit the child to be admired from above. Being enormous, they couldn't be forced onto a car or a bus, so they were only used for walking to the shops and the park. Then came buggies, light and easy to fold. Now we have strollers, and they're getting bigger. They have bumpers like dodgem cars, gigantic parasols, running boards, eight chunky wheels like goods lorries. With a bit of carbon fibre cladding you could send your baby into battle. The other day I saw a mother failing to get the buggy through the end door of a tube. She had to retreat and missed the train. Is it guilt that we have to give our children the baby carriage version of the Range Rover?

 I've often said that the problem with that lot in 10 Downing Street isn't that they're evil, twisted, Machiavellian back-stabbers, but that they aren't very clever. They meld incompetence with arrogance in equal measure, and it's a lethal recipe. Take Tony Blair's wheeze about on-the-spot fines for drunken yobs, which seems pretty apposite this weekend. Everything about this crazed plan was naff. The fact that it was dreamed up in a panic because the focus groups say the government appears soft on crime. The way it was inserted into a speech to a body titled The Global Ethics Foundation, which is surely about grander issues than fat louts chanting "I'd rather be a Paki than a Turk" in the street. It's as if Mr Blair had been asked to deliver the Reith lectures and had devoted them to complaining about the Grundys in The Archers.

But most of all it was stupid because they hadn't asked the police. They hadn't consulted the very people who would have had to enforce the policy in the first place. It's unimaginable to us. No wonder the Tories have been enjoying every moment, conjuring up fantasies of lines of staggering hooligans trying to remember their Pin numbers. If we approached our work in the same careless, slapdash, headless-chicken manner, we'd be out on our ears. They're like accountants who can't add up, lifeguards who can't swim. They just can't hack it. Yet these idiots are at the very heart of our government.

 Thanks for your letters about Jack Straw's claim that some 31.5 % of all British males have a full criminal conviction - no cautions, no motoring offences included - by the age of 30. Like me, most statisticians seem to regard the figure as evidently ridiculous, and have devoted some time to guessing how the error might have arisen. One factor seems to be that once a statistic is accepted in an institution, it's very hard to winkle out - especially if it seems to imply that the problem is worse than everyone thought, and therefore makes it vital to keep everyone employed.

Graham Lee wonders if the Home Office had done all it might to list the names and check for duplicates. "Is the Government using a 'snapshot'? Have they used the figures from just one year?' - apparently this would make a huge difference. John Evans makes a similar point about duplicates. "Getting true 'person-based' counts out of 'event-based' records is a very difficult business... computers are very bad at 'fuzzy-matching'. I suspect a lot of fuzz in this study!"

Peter Moverley described his own career as a statistician. "I would often find absurd changes in the normal patterns which had been either wrongly plotted, or correctly plotted after uncritical acceptance of a very suspect figure. This sort of checking is very boring, so at different levels, all those meant to make the checks are inclined to skimp or skip... in this case I suspect a simple clerical error with pen or keyboard, possibly a misplaced decimal point. You may think this is far-fetched, but from my experience it is far from implausible."

And Mr Moverely agrees on the main point: "I find it inconceivable that in my unsheltered, working-class upbringing I could have been mixing with as large a number of criminals as is suggested, without my being aware of it."

But most of all it was stupid because they hadn't asked the police. They hadn't consulted the very people who would have had to enforce the policy in the first place. It's unimaginable to us. No wonder the Tories have been enjoying every moment, conjuring up fantasies of lines of staggering hooligans trying to remember their Pin numbers. If we approached our work in the same careless, slapdash, headless-chicken manner, we'd be out on our ears. They're like accountants who can't add up, lifeguards who can't swim. They just can't hack it. Yet these idiots are at the very heart of our government.  Thanks for your letters about Jack Straw's claim that some 31.5 % of all British males have a full criminal conviction - no cautions, no motoring offences included - by the age of 30. Like me, most statisticians seem to regard the figure as evidently ridiculous, and have devoted some time to guessing how the error might have arisen. One factor seems to be that once a statistic is accepted in an institution, it's very hard to winkle out - especially if it seems to imply that the problem is worse than everyone thought, and therefore makes it vital to keep everyone employed. Graham Lee wonders if the Home Office had done all it might to list the names and check for duplicates. "Is the Government using a 'snapshot'? Have they used the figures from just one year?' - apparently this would make a huge difference. John Evans makes a similar point about duplicates. "Getting true 'person-based' counts out of 'event-based' records is a very difficult business... computers are very bad at 'fuzzy-matching'. I suspect a lot of fuzz in this study!" Peter Moverley described his own career as a statistician. "I would often find absurd changes in the normal patterns which had been either wrongly plotted, or correctly plotted after uncritical acceptance of a very suspect figure. This sort of checking is very boring, so at different levels, all those meant to make the checks are inclined to skimp or skip... in this case I suspect a simple clerical error with pen or keyboard, possibly a misplaced decimal point. You may think this is far-fetched, but from my experience it is far from implausible." And Mr Moverely agrees on the main point: "I find it inconceivable that in my unsheltered, working-class upbringing I could have been mixing with as large a number of criminals as is suggested, without my being aware of it."

fields.headline: Harold Nicholas
fields.standfirst: Dancer who combined elegance with extraordinary acrobatics
fields.trailText: For most of Hollywood's existence, racial segregation and prejudice forced great black artists to play minor or subservient roles. In many musicals they were only acceptable in what were called "speciality numbers", detached from the plot, which could be easily cut from the film on release in the bigoted South. fields.body:
For most of Hollywood's existence, racial segregation and prejudice forced great black artists to play minor or subservient roles. In many musicals they were only acceptable in what were called "speciality numbers", detached from the plot, which could be easily cut from the film on release in the bigoted South. As a result, the dazzling dancing duo, the Nicholas Brothers, can only be a footnote (or feetnotes) to the history of the Hollywood musical.

Harold Nicholas, who has died aged 79, was seven years younger than his brother Fayard, and when they began in vaudeville aged seven and 14 respectively, lanky Fayard towered over his little brother. The better-looking Harold remained much shorter and slighter, but this did not disturb the perfect unity of their actions; any differences in their vertiginous dancing were revealed when they each did a solo spot during a number in an attempt to top one another in friendly sibling rivalry.

The sons of musicians, they and their sister began dancing at black vaudeville theatres billed as the Nicholas Kids. As a duo, they performed at the Lafayette Theater in Harlem in the early 1930s, moving on to the famed Cotton Club, and a short film called Pie, Pie, Blackbird (1932).

After Samuel Goldwyn saw the brothers at the Cotton Club, he cast them in the tiny roles of street urchins in the Eddie Cantor musical Kid Millions (1934). Back on stage, they appeared in Blackbirds of 1936, which came to London. The Times critic wrote that the audience did not know whether to admire more Harold's "twinkling feet or slow, baby smile."

The Nicholas Brothers' feet and smiles enlivened several Fox musicals during the 1940s. Among their show-stopping numbers was Chattanooga-Choo-Choo in Sun Valley Serenade (1941), which was sung by Dorothy Dandridge, whom Harold married the following year. They divorced soon after their daughter was born.

Harold and Fayard also had snazzy dance routines in Down Argentine Way (1940), Tin Pan Alley (1940), and Orchestra Wives (1942), combining elegance with extraordinary acrobatics. They called their dancing "classical tap", a blend of jazz, tap, acrobatics (with supple splits), angular eccentricmovement, black vernacular dance and ballet.

"People always asked did we study ballet," Harold remarked. "We never did." However, ballet choreographer George Balanchine cast them in The Ziegfeld Follies of 1936 and Babes in Arms (1937) on Broadway.

In the all-black musical Stormy Weather (1943), their Jumpin' Jive number provoked Fred Astaire to declare that it was the greatest movie musical moment he had ever seen. "We had a huge set made of big steps," Harold recalled. "My brother would jump over my head into a split on the step below me. I'd do the same thing over his head until we both got down on the floor." The brothers also dance on drums and leap over orchestra musicians.

In Vincente Minnelli's The Pirate (1948), their last feature together, Gene Kelly broke the colour bar by dancing with them in the rousing Be A Clown number. Dressed in the same blue-and-yellow motley, they formed a tumbling equilateral triangle in constant motion, a distinct change from the segregated specialities imposed upon the brothers during their screen career. Even though they are hardly distinguishable behind white clown's make-up, the routine was excised from the film in the South.

In recent years, Harold and Fayard were feted in the US, the subject of a tribute at Carnegie Hall in 1998, and recipients of honorary awards galore. They also charmed audiences in person at a season at the National Film Theatre in London a few years ago.

Before and after the Nicholas Brothers split up, Harold had a separate career. As a 12-year-old, he appeared in Eugene O'Neill's The Emperor Jones; he introduced the song, Come Rain or Come Shine in the 1946 production of St Louis Woman; and later had a role in Sidney Poitier's Uptown Saturday Night (1974), as well as starring in the Broadway Duke Ellington musical Sophisticated Ladies in 1982 and in the touring musical The Tap Dance Kid (1985).

There is a wonderful moment in the film Tap (1989), when a young hoofer unwisely suggests a group of legendary old dancers has lost their legs. One of them is 68-year-old Harold Nicholas, who accepts the challenge with enthusiasm, and does his stuff, bringing back memories of the glory days of tap dancing and movie musicals.

He is survived by his brother, his third wife, a daughter and a son.

 Harold Lloyd Nicholas, dancer, born March 21 1921; died July 3 2000

fields.headline: Nothing new under the sun
fields.trailText: My task this week is to compose a reading list for Ken Follett's hols
fields.body:
My task this week is to compose a reading list for Ken Follett's hols. I know he is a best-selling novelist and perhaps he uses his holidays to think up new plots, but in the light of his outburst against Tony Blair in last week's Observer, I think he should also find time to look at a little history.

Follett seems to suppose that spinning, manipulating, and the settling of scores between ministers through unattributable briefings were invented by Margaret Thatcher and Bernard Ingham. I suggest he starts with a history of the Attlee government - there are several - for there he will find inter-ministerial feuding and blackguarding far outreaching anything we have seen under Tony Blair.

Many senior ministers openly loathed and denounced each other. When someone remarked that Herbert Morrison, Attlee's deputy, was his own worst enemy, the former union leader Ernie Bevin, who was Attlee's foreign secretary, retorted: "Not while I'm alive he ain't." That story, significantly, is also told about Morrison and the left-wing firebrand Nye Bevan, and even about Bevin and Bevan (whom people now sometimes assume, even in serious newspapers, were one and the same person.) Great fountains of venom spurted up at the very mention of the mischievous Hugh Dalton or Attlee's calamitous minister for fuel and power, Emmanuel Shinwell. As for Attlee, there were several attempts to remove him, in some of which left-wingers like Stafford Cripps allied themselves with right-wingers like Morrison. No one is talking of dumping Tony - yet.

Next, Ken should get hold of Ben Pimlott's book on Wilson (large, but worth it) and the diaries of Richard Crossman and Barbara Castle, where he will find plots and mighty feuds and petty envies and spites and vicious briefings and counterbriefings which will make his expensive coiffure stand on end. I also recommend a book by the Sunday Times's political man of those days, James Margach, called The Abuse Of Power - subtitled The War Between Downing Street and the Media - which recounts Wilson's paranoid rage against those newspapers (most of them) which refused to see things as he did and which he took to be in the pocket of enemies like Roy Jenkins. There were cabinet meetings in Wilson's four terms as prime minister which, unlike today's, thrashed out the issues at length with commitment and passion; but the terms in which they were reported frequently owed more to surreptitious briefings than to what had really occurred.

As a veteran of the 1974-1979 governments said to Smallweed this week, the people whom the media made prime movers in those debates had often in fact said least, while those who said most, and to greatest effect, were barely mentioned at all. Afterwards Wilson would make frantic, doomed attempts to pin down the source of leaks, while telling proprietors and editors to get rid of those whose reporting upset him most. None of this is to say that Follett's disgust is unjustified - any more than it was unjustified when much the same case was made by others, like the party's former deputy leader and general secretary, who know rather more about these matters than he does.

One more book to complete Ken's holiday reading: a life of King Alfred. All he knows about this king, he wrote in the Observer, is that he burned some cakes. A good life of Alfred - there are several, starting with the king's contemporary Asser - would open Ken's eyes to rather more important aspects of Alfred than cake (that incident probably never happened) such as his success in repelling the Danes, his promotion of learning, his consolidation of the burgeoning English monarchy, and so on. Some also credit him with achievements like founding Oxford university or establishing trial by jury: but such claims were probably the work of spin doctors (or flamsters, as I prefer to call them).

But Ken should rely on historians more accomplished than Smallweed. The account in this column last week of the battle of the medieval schoolmen, in which the nominalists took on the realists, has been challenged this week in an erudite letter from The Queen's College, Oxford. "Realists," it explains, "were not insisting on the reality of tables. It was abstract concepts (eg whiteness) that they claimed had a reality of their own, whereas nominalists believed these concepts were just names, and that the only realities were individual white objects. Nominalists were thus, in modern terms, more realistic than realists." I hope this makes everything clear.

Next week in Smallweed: Anna Kournikova; nominalist or realist? (with amazingly yummy pictures of Elizabeth Hurley).

Smallweed was treated on Monday to a persuasive interpretation of the term "at sixes and sevens". This had to do, a representative of one of the London livery companies explained, with the trial of strength which took place in the 14th and 15th century between the Skinners and Merchant Taylors as to who should be sixth and who seventh in the companies' pecking order. This led to bumping and bruising. But in 1484 the Mayor of the City, as arbitrator, ruled that the two should alternate: one would be sixth this year and the other seventh; next year, the other way round.

Unfortunately, this is not necessarily true. Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable thinks the term comes from dicing. "There is," a book of 1542 explains, "a proverb omnem jacere aleam, to cast all dice by which is signified to set all on six and seven_ assaying the wild chance of fortune, be it good, be it bad." But since the mayor's ruling predated this reference by 58 years, who can be sure which came first? From now on I shall adopt the livery companies' explanation in odd-numbered years, and the book's in even-numbered years like this one.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report about the acquisition of Asprey & Garrard by the US clothing group of Tommy Hilfiger, page 5, July 7, we referred to Naim Attallah as the former managing director of Asprey's and said that he was "replaced" by Ian Dahl. Mr Attallah was, in fact, the group chief executive of Asprey's. He retired at the end of a tenure of 21 years and was "succeeded", not "replaced", by Mr Dahl. Asprey's made money every year of Mr Attallah's association with the company. Apologies if we seemed to suggest otherwise.
fields.body:
In a report about the acquisition of Asprey & Garrard by the US clothing group of Tommy Hilfiger, page 5, July 7, we referred to Naim Attallah as the former managing director of Asprey's and said that he was "replaced" by Ian Dahl. Mr Attallah was, in fact, the group chief executive of Asprey's. He retired at the end of a tenure of 21 years and was "succeeded", not "replaced", by Mr Dahl. Asprey's made money every year of Mr Attallah's association with the company. Apologies if we seemed to suggest otherwise.

In a report from Berlin, page 16, June 22, we said that the Konrad Adenauer foundation had awarded its annual prize to "the rightwing historian" Ernst Nolte. In fact it was the Deutschland Foundation that awarded its Konrad Adenauer prize to Nolte.

The paper, A study of eating disorders among female secondary students in Ghana, which formed the subject of a brief report on page 14, July 6, was presented at the annual meeting of the Royal College of Psychiatrists by Dr Dinah Bennett and not by Alan Carson as we suggested. The research was conducted by Dr Bennett in Ghana and Alan Carson was involved in the writing of the paper.

The readers' editor writes about apostrophes and autophoby, page 9, today's Saturday Review.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. fields.headline: Genevieve Cooper
fields.standfirst: From Cosmo secretary to Fleet Street editor
fields.trailText: Back in the 1970s when feminism was an exhilarating cocktail, Cosmopolitan was a new magazine that attracted the enthusiastic and often untried journalist and where special effort was rewarded with champagne rather than a salary increase.
fields.body:
Back in the 1970s when feminism was an exhilarating cocktail, Cosmopolitan was a new magazine that attracted the enthusiastic and often untried journalist and where special effort was rewarded with champagne rather than a salary increase.

Secretaries were thought to be an anachronism, but someone had to type contracts and readers' letters and Genevieve Cooper, a nice girl from Forum magazine, was recommended.

We prepared ourselves for bondage gear and a superior sexual air. Instead, there appeared a tall shepherdess, in Watteau mode, with blonde curls and shy smile, who swished her petticoats past the desks and flashed high-heel boots from which, I swear, she produced her CV.

Genevieve, who has died of cancer aged 55, could type. Better than me anyway. She read books. She lived the life. She ate out. She had many admirers. She could cope with the frightening talents of Anna Raeburn and Sally Vincent. As editor, I was delighted to have such good company facing me across our awful desks. Blowsy bouquets of flowers from Berwick Street market appeared on the desk and her perfume changed with the arrival of new product samples.

After several happy years with this jolly assistant, she asked for a long weekend to fly to Los Angeles to see her scriptwriting boyfriend. On her return Genevieve regaled us with what it's like fixing your mascara in the same bit of mirror as Elizabeth Taylor at the Oscars. Do write it down, Gen dear, I said. She did and I lost a PA and found a writer. Genevieve went on to become the first woman editor of the Sunday Times colour supplement.

Being Gen, she also brought back from Frederick's of Hollywood an edible bikini. Lacking an immediate partner, Genevieve and chum ate the red liquorice straps and chocolate body right there in the office.

Genevieve, with her discreet charm, eagle eye for social change, her blue stocking well concealed under that toile de jouy exterior, was in effect the spirit of the new age: liberated, opinionated, iconoclastic - watch how she changed the face of newspapers - funny and sometimes unbearably vulnerable. A pencil often held back those curls. Minus Doc Martens and dungarees, she cut the feminist mustard.

Genevieve was born in Nottingham: her mother a journalist on the Sunday Times, her father an executive at Marks & Spencer. She attended a succession of local schools due to the family's constant moving and at 16 was already working as a secretary.

It was at Cosmo that her career bloomed. Compiling a what's on, what's in column, she went to a boutique opening in Covent Garden where she met a man in a pink sweater, 13 years' younger and gorgeous. He must be gay, she told the office.

Craftily the young man, Peter Knight, used his advantage to entice the cautious Ms Cooper. A colleague said: "Genevieve is doing her best not to get married." At this point and well before Fleet Street, Cosmopolitan went into computers. Peter, now a computer expert, was in the building a lot and an office romance was launched. Reader, she married him.

Fleet Street also made Genevieve proposals and we watched as she applied her talent, charm and compassion to the flinty surface of newspapers in the 70s and 80s. In 1983 it was at the Mail On Sunday's You magazine, and a year later came the editorship of the Sunday Times colour supplement. There she wrote a piece explaining how no, she wasn't the features editor, or the woman's editor, she was the Editor, dammit.

She went on to become the London Evening Standard's deputy editor, before working for the newly launched London Daily News and then launching the Standard's ES magazine. In her turn Genevieve helped the careers of many new young writers including Nigella Lawson, Jaci Stephens, Lowri Turner and Annalena McAfee.

Last month I saw her for the last time. All those smart editorships behind her, a little stooped with cancer, but the same wonderful smile, the curly hair, the fluttering lashes, the jokes, the wicked stories of news-paper chicanery.

She was resting in the house and garden of her friend Pattie Barron, surrounded by flowers, cats, books and magazines. What shall we all be reading tomorrow? Such a good time. Thank you Genevieve.

She is survived by Peter and her 12-year-old son Max.

 Genevieve Hope St Clair Cooper, journalist, born December 10 1944; died June 26 2000

A pencil often held back those curls. Minus Doc Martens and dungarees, she cut the feminist mustard. Genevieve was born in Nottingham: her mother a journalist on the Sunday Times, her father an executive at Marks & Spencer. She attended a succession of local schools due to the family's constant moving and at 16 was already working as a secretary. It was at Cosmo that her career bloomed. Compiling a what's on, what's in column, she went to a boutique opening in Covent Garden where she met a man in a pink sweater, 13 years' younger and gorgeous. He must be gay, she told the office. Craftily the young man, Peter Knight, used his advantage to entice the cautious Ms Cooper. A colleague said: "Genevieve is doing her best not to get married." At this point and well before Fleet Street, Cosmopolitan went into computers. Peter, now a computer expert, was in the building a lot and an office romance was launched. Reader, she married him. Fleet Street also made Genevieve proposals and we watched as she applied her talent, charm and compassion to the flinty surface of newspapers in the 70s and 80s. In 1983 it was at the Mail On Sunday's You magazine, and a year later came the editorship of the Sunday Times colour supplement. There she wrote a piece explaining how no, she wasn't the features editor, or the woman's editor, she was the Editor, dammit. She went on to become the London Evening Standard's deputy editor, before working for the newly launched London Daily News and then launching the Standard's ES magazine. In her turn Genevieve helped the careers of many new young writers including Nigella Lawson, Jaci Stephens, Lowri Turner and Annalena McAfee. Last month I saw her for the last time. All those smart editorships behind her, a little stooped with cancer, but the same wonderful smile, the curly hair, the fluttering lashes, the jokes, the wicked stories of news-paper chicanery. She was resting in the house and garden of her friend Pattie Barron, surrounded by flowers, cats, books and magazines. What shall we all be reading tomorrow? Such a good time. Thank you Genevieve. She is survived by Peter and her 12-year-old son Max.  Genevieve Hope St Clair Cooper, journalist, born December 10 1944; died June 26 2000

fields.headline: Face to faith: Pass the word
fields.trailText: There is a moment in Henry James's novel Roderick Hudson when Christina, the beautiful socialite, asks the urbane and cultured Rowland a disarmingly direct question: "Please tell me about your faith." The normally unflappable Rowland is decidedly put out. "My faith?" he splutters; and rejects her request with vigour. "Never in the world!" Some things, apparently, are just too personal.
fields.body:
There is a moment in Henry James's novel Roderick Hudson when Christina, the beautiful socialite, asks the urbane and cultured Rowland a disarmingly direct question: "Please tell me about your faith." The normally unflappable Rowland is decidedly put out. "My faith?" he splutters; and rejects her request with vigour. "Never in the world!" Some things, apparently, are just too personal.

But Christina cannot accept this. She takes him to task. If "such things" can't be readily expressed, she insists, "then of what use are they? Deep convictions. . .should be eloquent and aggressive. They should wish to make converts, to persuade and illumine, to take possession!"

Seeking converts is what Christians call evangelism. Yet many British Christians epitomise the attitude of Rowland: to talk about one's faith is bad enough; to try and convert someone else to it is unthinkable. Rowland is the classic "nominal" Christian: "I'm very old-fashioned," he says. "I believe in the grand old English Bible." No doubt he is sincere in saying this, but it is manifestly not true.

There is no doubt that Christina's attitude is far closer to the New Testament than his. Try telling Paul or Peter that it is wrong to seek converts. The Christian church was born in a blaze of evangelism as the Book of Acts testifies. And, according to Matthew's gospel, one of the last commands the risen Christ gave to the 11 was - precisely - to "Go and make disciples". Apart from evangelism, there simply would be no Christian church.

How come, then, this coy and reluctant attitude towards sharing one's faith?

No doubt crass, insensitive and inappropriate forms of evangelism have discredited the whole notion. Think of the Crusades; the religious anorak on the doorstep; or those modern forms of mass evangelism which verge on the hysterical and manipulative. But the baby should not be thrown out with the bathwater. Evangelism is an integral part of the Christian faith, not an optional add-on for those so inclined. A non-evangelising church is a contradiction in terms; as, indeed, is a non-evangelising Christian.

The Bishop of Oxford recently suggested that people who find Christianity uncongenial - you know, all that esoteric stuff about the Trinity, the virgin birth, the crucifixion, the resurrection - might like to take a good look at Judaism as a possible alternative (Unitarianism being now a spent force.)

But such a suggestion of made-to-measure religion ("I'm sure we can meet your requirements, sir") is out of line with authentic Christianity. And just suppose God is a Trinity? Suppose that the incarnation, the crucifixion and the resurrection of Jesus really do offer the key to the meaning of life? Suppose (latching on to what has sadly been reduced to the great mega-cliché of evange lism) we really do need to die to the old life and be "born again" as the Jesus of John's Gospel is reported as saying? If this should be so, to direct people elsewhere can only be a breathtaking dereliction of duty - the desert-dweller pointing the dying man away from the oasis. If something is true, our business is to mould ourselves to it; not to find or fashion an alternative "'truth" which happens to suit our convenience, taste or temperament.

For the question of truth is what it ultimately boils down to. Religions, whether we like it or not, make truth claims; they purport to tell us the way things actually are with the world, and how we should face up to the great issues of right and wrong, life and death, suffering and pain. This is true of all religions, not just Christianity in general or evangelical Christianity in particular. By their claims they invite our allegiance. True, there can be no ultimate proof: it is by an act of faith that we commit ourselves to them. But it is also by an act of faith that we reject them. Nobody believes in nothing: to believe in nothing is itself a belief.

Certainly, the how of evangelism poses important questions. Let it always be sensitive, gracious, respectful, courteous. Of course. But Christina had it right: deep convictions should be "eloquent and aggressive." They should wish to "make converts, to persuade and illumine."

When all is said and done, a faith not worth sharing is a faith not worth having.

 Colin Sedgwick is pastor of Lindsay Park Baptist Church, Kenton, Middlesex

fields.headline: Trivial pursuit
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... apostrophes and autophoby
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... apostrophes and autophoby
fields.body:
One of the questions I am frequently asked as I plough my lonely furrow is, "Have they nothing better to do?" The question is asked by the journalist confronted with an error which he or she considers too trivial to bother about. The "they" is you, the readers of the paper who feel sufficiently involved, obsessive, proprietorial about the Guardian to believe that attention to detail might contribute something to a general improvement, particularly in the standard of English.

I have a good deal of sympathy with this kind of mind, the kind of mind which, in Britain anyway, makes it impossible for the possessor to eat in a restaurant, however good the food, that tells us it is "fully licenced". If we are given a c instead of an s who knows what liberties might have been taken with the food?

I cannot recommend too highly for readers blessed or cursed with this propensity a book, Ex Libris: Confessions of a Common Reader by Anne Fadiman (Penguin). Ms Fadiman, an American - where a licence is a license - will strike you as exactly the type who might impose a similar grammatical or linguistic boycott.

How many of us can identify with this from her book - an example of obedience, but not blind obedience? "It is hard for me to walk on a DONT WALK sign even if there are no cars for miles. However, while waiting, I get back at it by thinking, DON'T OMIT THE APOSTROPHE."

Ah, here it is again, cropping up, as it often does, when you least expect it. Objections to it are not always because it is misplaced or omitted or ungrammatical. Sometimes we are chastised because its use introduces an ingratiating note of informality into an inappropriate context, for example a leader on literacy in which we said, "... where teachers have needed guidance, it's provided".

An objecting reader complained, "It's is an informal, usually spoken form. An editorial which employs rhetorical repetition and ellipsis is both formal and written." I couldn't - excuse me - I could not agree more, and neither could the editor of the Guardian style guide. This is what the guide says, "The rash of abbreviations containing apostrophes such as aren't, can't, hasn't, don't, I'm, it's, there's and what's has reached epidemic proportions (even the horrific 'there've' has appeared in the paper). While they might make a piece more colloquial or easier to read, they can be an irritant and a distraction, and make a serious article sound frivolous..."

Before we leave the subject (but only for the time being, of course), let me make way for a brief word from one of your fellow readers (Donald Madgwick): "As to the apostrophe, its misuse is so widespread that I have written a play with an apostrophically foolproof title.

"Its plot, derived from the commedia dell'arte , concerns the return to Rome of Captain Spavento following a defined mission (The Captain's Return), and the coincidental return on the same day of his twin brother, the Stranger Captain (The Captains' Return). By changing the noun into a verb, it becomes The Captains Return. The title is therefore correct with the apostrophe either before or after the s or omitted altogether."

I reproduce this in the hope that, having suggested almost everything else, juggling may help. However, even writers whose use of language might qualify them, were it expressed in an equivalent skill, to perform in a Chinese circus, sometimes make mistakes.

One of our columnists wrote recently, "...he followed my husband and I home..." This brought cries of indignation. "I know the meaning is perfectly clear but it is rubbish grammar and [the writer] should know better." One reader offered a useful piece of advice. "As my English teacher dad used to tell us, when in doubt, separate out the pronoun. You wouldn't say 'He followed I' would you?"

The New Fowler's Modern English Usage, revised by RW Burchfield (Oxford) is unusually sharp on this point, putting the use of I "as the second member of an objective phrase, eg 'He drove Kirsten and I home'" in the same category as the dire, "Between you and I." "Anyone who uses it now," says Fowler, "lives in a grammarless cavern in which no distinction is recognised between a grammatical object and a subject."

Between you and me, I think we have some way to go before we have seen the back of that one. Perhaps what we need is an epidemic of autophoby, a word which the Oxford English Dictionary acknowledges as rare, as rare perhaps as the condition it describes, "fear of referring to oneself". Its first use is recorded in Guesses at Truth by Two Brothers, 1827. The brothers in question were Augustus and Julius Hare. Which one actually wrote, "This shrinking from the personal pronoun, this autophoby, as it may be called," we do not need to know. That would simply be splitting Hares.

 Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The last word on  loyalty
fields.standfirst: A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. -   Shakespeare
fields.trailText: A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. - Shakespeare
fields.body:
Loyalty was once the Conservative Party's secret weapon, its absence the Labour Party's public disease. In an effort to overcome the vitiating effects of the quarrels and rifts which so undermined voter confidence in Old Labour, leaders of New Labour sought to manage their party with the same discipline as once benefited Conservatism. But as Ken Follett's putatively disloyal attack on Mr Blair's alleged disloyalties to his Cabinet colleagues suggests, the endeavour is in difficulties.

The kind of loyalty once instinctive among Tories seems to be an inherent impossibility for Labourites, either because their instincts are those of opposition and therefore Opposition - which perhaps some of them secretly prefer, since it is so much easier to complain than to govern - or because their adherence is to ideals, not people, which means that loyalty to the former necessitates disloyalty to the latter when the latter are disloyal to the former.

Loyalty is only a virtue when it is principled. Unquestioning allegiance to a cause, a faith or an individual is bad because by its nature it is too easily made an instrument of wrongdoing - and indeed amplifies wrongdoing, for when instructions are blindly followed they are thereby potentiated. Even as an instrument of good its value is equivocal; a loyal servant is the mere vehicle of another's intentions, therefore little praise is due to him beyond the mere fact that he yields himself to his master.

The concepts most associated with loyalty are constancy, fidelity and trustworthiness. These can be virtues indeed, and the fact that they play a central role in loyalty explains why we think well of it. Generally, in praising loyalty we really mean to praise one or more of these virtues, and when we decry it - as when the Stalinist apparatchik carries out a purge, and the SS officer a gassing - we described it as misplaced, mistaken or blind. But if it can be these things, it only deserves its positive light when it represents a principled adherence to something independently defensible as good.

Loyalty to a verifiable good is not a requirement in politics, where, on the contrary, Elbert Hubbard's dictum that "an ounce of loyalty is worth a pound of cleverness" very much applies. An individual MP is seen by party whips as a pair of feet for the voting lobbies, and - if those same feet are not too often in it - another mouth for the propaganda war. To be loyal in party terms means being quiescent, obedient and obliging. Loyalty to principle, to constituents, or to a cause which happens not to be party policy is regarded as rank disloyalty.

This is what offends independent minds on both right and left, thinking of their forerunners: the former, of the bluff squires of Walpole's day, stubbornly forming their own views no matter what the Crown's ministers wanted; the latter, of their roots running deeply via dissent to Wat Tyler and beyond. It is a fact of history that independent-mindedness has more often been found in the latter camp than the former.

In personal life loyalty is a less equivocal virtue. In friendship it means standing by someone despite occasions of disagreement and disapproval, for friendship is first about fidelities and only afterwards about what tests them. The component virtues of constancy and trustworthiness are especially valuable in friendship when troubles come, because they are an infinitely greater comfort to anyone sleepless in the dark night of the soul than such impersonal helps as medications, counsellors or prayers.

"Men's minds are given to change in hate and friendship," said Sophocles, which explains some of the rifts and reconciliations seen in public life. If Follett's attack on Blair was prompted by a sense of personal rather than political disloyalty, it would explain its bitterness of tone: as it would if Blair felt the same in response, for every blow of disloyalty against one who stands naked to the public gaze is, by that very fact, trebled in the harm it does, thus making disloyalty a kind of assassination - sometimes needful, sometimes wanton.

fields.headline: The joy of Rex
fields.standfirst: A cavernous cinema proves the perfect place to stage Wayne McGregor's latest hyperactive dance, says  Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: A cavernous cinema proves the perfect place to stage Wayne McGregor's latest hyperactive dance, says Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
Two weeks ago, Wayne McGregor was hogging the applause in the Royal Ballet's New Works season with his glittering, grown-up duet Symbiont. This week, he's featured in the Greenwich and Docklands Festival with a work created for 32 amateur dancers along with his own company Random.

Two different worlds, yet it's a measure of how fast McGregor has matured that both fizz with equal invention and energy and that the dancers from east London look as stretched and flattered by his movement as those from Covent Garden. During the past few days, children and locals from Stratford have been made to feel as good about themselves as the Royal Ballet's Edward Watson and Deborah Bull.

As well as being a community project, Field was conceived as a showcase for the cavernous magnificence of Stratford's local cinema, the Rex. In the show's pre-publicity, we were promised that a team of digital artists would be transforming the huge "urban shell" of this art deco building into a kind of electronic dreamscape, through which the live dancers would move.

In fact, the technology featured in Field turns out to be far less spellbinding than that which we're used to in McGregor's work. The dancers perform on a conventional stage, which doubles as a 3-D screen on which footage of people and landscape is projected. But interestingly the modesty of the technology becomes a virtue rather than a disappointment. For in some ways Field is the most intimately human work McGregor has made.

One factor is his untypical use of live music, specially written by composer Tunde Jegende, whose breezy fusion of Baroque, South East Asian, jazz and minimalism generates a far more extrovert quality than the electronic scores McGregor generally favours. Jegende's restless sonorities and pulsing rhythmic structures stimulate McGregor's own musical invention, and give a physical warmth to the virtuosity of Random's dancers, who open the show in a series of solos and duets. These actually feature modern dance at its most technically powered, with extravagantly stretched lines of movement sliced into drastic angles or teased into edgily delicate ripples. Yet as the local dancers are gradually incorporated into the work, it is extraordinary how seamlessly the two teams blend and how the amateurs become assets to the dance rather than liabilities.

McGregor certainly exploits the latter's strengths, giving the younger ones moves based on hip-hop and gymnastics, the older ones more low-key social dance steps, which he then breaks down into tiny modules of movement and reactivates into his own distinctively hyperactive style. He also enjoys the varieties of body size, placing tiny tots in sculptural contrast with more chunky adults and he deliberately retains the colours of their personalities.

Within the kaleidoscopic, shifting patterns created by the 40 dancers, there are moments where the stage jitters with the anarchic energy of a playground, and moments too where it settles into the more orderly fun of a ballroom. In one unexpectedly poignant duet, one of Random's dancers is partnered by a middle-aged Asian man, whose courtliness and calm inspire you to picture him practicing t'ai chi on the banks of the River Lea.

Of course, McGregor relies on his own dancers to weave a thread of virtuosity through the main fabric of the dance, but it's often surprisingly hard to tell the two groups apart. The pace of the choreography changes so fast, its ideas come in such quick profusion that despite its length (an hour), it rarely flags. Nor do Stratford's dancers. Their discipline and focus are impressively unwavering and it's a tribute to them and to Random that Field is community dance with a genuinely professional edge.
