This week, he's featured in the Greenwich and Docklands Festival with a work created for 32 amateur dancers along with his own company Random. Two different worlds, yet it's a measure of how fast McGregor has matured that both fizz with equal invention and energy and that the dancers from east London look as stretched and flattered by his movement as those from Covent Garden. During the past few days, children and locals from Stratford have been made to feel as good about themselves as the Royal Ballet's Edward Watson and Deborah Bull. As well as being a community project, Field was conceived as a showcase for the cavernous magnificence of Stratford's local cinema, the Rex. In the show's pre-publicity, we were promised that a team of digital artists would be transforming the huge "urban shell" of this art deco building into a kind of electronic dreamscape, through which the live dancers would move. In fact, the technology featured in Field turns out to be far less spellbinding than that which we're used to in McGregor's work. The dancers perform on a conventional stage, which doubles as a 3-D screen on which footage of people and landscape is projected. But interestingly the modesty of the technology becomes a virtue rather than a disappointment. For in some ways Field is the most intimately human work McGregor has made. One factor is his untypical use of live music, specially written by composer Tunde Jegende, whose breezy fusion of Baroque, South East Asian, jazz and minimalism generates a far more extrovert quality than the electronic scores McGregor generally favours. Jegende's restless sonorities and pulsing rhythmic structures stimulate McGregor's own musical invention, and give a physical warmth to the virtuosity of Random's dancers, who open the show in a series of solos and duets. These actually feature modern dance at its most technically powered, with extravagantly stretched lines of movement sliced into drastic angles or teased into edgily delicate ripples. Yet as the local dancers are gradually incorporated into the work, it is extraordinary how seamlessly the two teams blend and how the amateurs become assets to the dance rather than liabilities. McGregor certainly exploits the latter's strengths, giving the younger ones moves based on hip-hop and gymnastics, the older ones more low-key social dance steps, which he then breaks down into tiny modules of movement and reactivates into his own distinctively hyperactive style. He also enjoys the varieties of body size, placing tiny tots in sculptural contrast with more chunky adults and he deliberately retains the colours of their personalities. Within the kaleidoscopic, shifting patterns created by the 40 dancers, there are moments where the stage jitters with the anarchic energy of a playground, and moments too where it settles into the more orderly fun of a ballroom. In one unexpectedly poignant duet, one of Random's dancers is partnered by a middle-aged Asian man, whose courtliness and calm inspire you to picture him practicing t'ai chi on the banks of the River Lea. Of course, McGregor relies on his own dancers to weave a thread of virtuosity through the main fabric of the dance, but it's often surprisingly hard to tell the two groups apart. The pace of the choreography changes so fast, its ideas come in such quick profusion that despite its length (an hour), it rarely flags. Nor do Stratford's dancers. Their discipline and focus are impressively unwavering and it's a tribute to them and to Random that Field is community dance with a genuinely professional edge.

fields.headline: Oceans of time
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney  is invigorated by Jet Lag
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney is invigorated by Jet Lag
fields.body:
In 1969 the round-the-world yachtsman Donald Crowhurst disappeared after 243 days at sea, largely spent circling in the mid-Atlantic. Two years later 74-year-old Sarah Krasnoff died after making 167 consecutive transatlantic plane journeys with her grandson, becoming the world's most spectacular fatality of jet lag.

Crowhurst went nowhere, but still managed to persuade the world that he was moving in a straight line; Krasnoff, endlessly in motion, was locked into a private loop of stasis.

Their stories inspired Jet Lag, part of the Barbican's Bite season. Written by Jessica Chalmers and directed by Marianne Weems, this play brings together two companies - the Builders Association, which specialises in media-based performance, and Diller + Scofidio, which works in architecture and installation art as well as theatre.

The show uses the disparities between live acting and on-screen effects to explore different kinds of time lags and lapses. The physical and mental dislocation suffered by its protagonists as they cross (or fail to cross) time zones corresponds to the gap between real-time acting and life filtered through the media.

In the first half, a yachtsman, played by Jeff Webster, videos himself for an image that is instantly visible on the screen behind him but won't reach the TV-watching world for some time. His audience is "whoever you are, or will be". But his viewers won't get the unadulterated story, as he rewinds and re-records his video log for public consumption.

The paradoxes of time and motion become more acute as an old woman and her grandson shuttle between airport lounges in America and Europe, becoming the subject of a delirious litany of statistics (most terrifying is the information that they watched 22 movies an average of seven times each). A four-screen closed-circuit television image turns Charles de Gaulle airport into a Piranesi labyrinth; computer imagery makes a plane slowly materialise around their seats; pastel-bland digital escalators and walkways roll by soporifically.

Sparingly designed, Jet Lag uses its rather flashy novelty factor to brilliant effect. A perplexing row of opaque screens at the front miraculously clears to reveal flight announcers, public relations people and the distraught relatives back home. There is something of the feel of Robert Lepage, but with a more focused journalistic drive, unfolding scientific and philosophical propositions about time, space and the human body.

Some observations about deferred experience and the media may seem over-familiar, but the concrete realisation is impressive: transmitting live, the yachtsman's voice is caught up in a sonic whirlwind of echoes and distortions.

The acting offsets satiric stereo types, such as a stiffly breezy newsreader, against the naturalistic ordinariness of Webster's briskly careworn sailor and Dale Soules's pathetically sensible, increasingly paranoid non-stop flyer.

For a production so much concerned with paradoxes, the ending - as the endless flights turn into an abstract computer game - is strangely poignant.

At 80 minutes, Jet Lag is not quite like buckling in for a transatlantic trip on a jet aircraft, but by the end you certainly feel the spacy dislocation of life lived between airport lounges. The in-flight entertainment, though, is a lot more stimulating.

fields.headline: Thick and thin
fields.standfirst: When you give an art show a title like Intelligence, you had better pick the right works.  Adrian Searle  isn't convinced Tate Britain has pulled it off
fields.trailText: When you give an art show a title like Intelligence, you had better pick the right works. Adrian Searle isn't convinced Tate Britain has pulled it off
fields.body:
Intelligence is supposedly the largest loan exhibition ever held in the Tate's Millbank gallery. Largest here means that it takes up more of Tate Britain's space than any show before it, filling all the top-lit cells of the 70s addition to the gallery. It is also the first Tate triennial of new British work.

It may be smaller and more coherent than the British Art Show, which has reached Southampton, but Intelligence has me dragging my knuckles.

Curated by Charles Esche, editor of Afterall magazine, and the Tate's Virginia Button, Intelligence presents the artist as deep-cover agent, a bottom feeder scavenging the detritus of modern life. Gillian Wearing presents an elegy to one of life's losers; Jeremy Deller and Alan Kane document the modern-day folkloric; Susan Hiller records people who believe in UFOs; Graham Gussin fills a factory with dry ice.

Intelligence is a redoubtable slog round the art world, but done with a bit of panache. The last time the Tate tried to do a groovy Brit show, with Abracadabra, it was a disaster. At least Intelligence looks elegant.

Yet I look at Julian Opie's work blankly, just as his outlined, generic portraits and cut-out figures look back at me, with their wan smiles, their brainless button eyes. The show has hardly begun and I feel like I'm on anti- depressants - life's complications haven't gone away, but the world has lost its spark. I'd like to see Opie's work as social critique, but I think he likes things this way.

It is a pity we go from this into Michael Craig-Martin's room, decorated with a mural of outlined objects, rather than straight into the mess of Deller and Kane's presentation of low-culture dreck, with its Jimmy Saville scarecrow, a sort of dragon costume from a morris-dancing parade, the tattoo-parlour gags and photos of funny local customs. At least there's a bit of life there.

In the middle of the show there's a metal structure by Liam Gillick, standing in the centre of the long corridor-like space running the length of the exhibition. All right angles, overlapped shiny metal planes and window-frame openings, Gillick's work is a pleasing sort of bus shelter-cum-unfinished double-glazing unit.

I stand in an aperture and do Marcel Marceau impressions. Innocent gallery-goers look alarmed. I file something scandalous in the complaints box pro vided by Bob and Roberta Smith. At the end of every week they'll be sign-writing the filed complaints on the wall in bright gloss.

This is the nearest thing you will find to painting here, discounting Alan Johnston. What labyrinthine thought processes have led to his inclusion? His work is thin stuff, austere black-and-white vanity decor with a work-ethic patina. I guess it looks intelligent, but this is not enough.

A list of everyone Douglas Gordon can ever remember meeting, printed all round the walls, is a kind of menacing roll of the war dead, or a name-and-shame list of poll-tax defaulters. Or it could be showing off. The intelligence is, however, that Gordon is a shy and lonely cove who never goes out, and this list is a plea for help.

Oladele Ajiboye Bamgboye's video, Spells for Beginners, in which the artist and his ex-girlfriend discuss, off-screen, why they split up, is too tersely edited to be mere confessional, too studied to be sentimental. On the screen snow falls, a boy walks down steps, a younger, dreadlocked Bamgboye takes a bath. The couple's downfall comes alive. The work is also a revisitation of the artist as a young man, as it reworks footage from 1994. There's a lot of feeling in the film, but it is tempered by rectitude and distance.

Wearing's slowed-down video of a drunken woman is, by contrast, alarmingly sentimental. Wearing filmed a damaged street drinker she'd befriended; the woman died. Over silent footage of the woman talking, drinking and leering, the woman's twin sister talks about the booze, the overdoses, the wrecked life, the funeral. I guess this work is a kind of eulogy, but it ends up sickly.

But there is only one major, lasting work in the exhibition. White egrets sit in a green tree. A tropical storm moves in, flattening the sea. The building, a hurricane-proof, utopian modernist egg in the Cayman Islands, is slowly falling apart. The owner is in jail. The camera watches, looking in and looking out. Rain falls through the shell of the echoing house. I cannot tell you how beautiful is Tacita Dean's film of this house she found by accident. Her film replays in my head, as an epitaph to someone else's dream.

Intelligence here is her noticing how loaded and metaphoric and condensed something seen can be. The house is a found object, someone else's lost hope. This work is so dense and rich and potent that everything else here looks struggled for, too formulaic, too clever by half.

 Intelligence is at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8000), till September 24.

fields.headline: Dirty tricks down under
fields.standfirst: Australia's shameful past is being raked up on the London stage.  Michael Billington  reports
fields.trailText: Australia's shameful past is being raked up on the London stage. Michael Billington reports
fields.body:
I see that John Howard, the Australian prime minister, was in Downing Street this week asking for Tony Blair's help in repatriating the remains of more than 2,000 aborigines. Before making a decision, Blair and the museum bosses could visit some of the shows in the Australian Heads Up season currently playing in London, in particular Jane Harrison's Stolen at the Tricycle, and a pair of one-woman shows at the Barbican.

At the very least, the shows would tell them something about the wrongs aborigines have historically endured and about their sacred relationship with the past. Stolen is extraordinary, as moving as any show in London. Its starting point is the Australian government's policy, which apparently lasted from 1910 to the mid-70s, of forced integration of aboriginal people: in practice, this meant wrenching children from their parents and placing them in special homes. Some were adopted by foster parents, some went into domestic slavery, others drifted into petty crime. But the social disruption was immense and the violation of the natural tie complete. And only now is the nation confronting its collective guilt and hungering for reconciliation.

Harrison's play has been part of that process. It started in 1992 as a research project funded by an aboriginal theatre group. It is now on its second national tour and is making its debut outside Australia here. But the reason for its success is instructive - it is not worthy, it is not preachy, it is not even violently angry. It simply recounts the aboriginal experience in fluid and entertaining form.

What it proves - not unlike the South African production of The Island - is that good theatre is the best way of recording social injus tice. Harrison's method is to focus on five characters. We meet Shirley, the classic earth mother, desperate to find her abducted kids and see her grandchildren. Then there are Ruby, a crazed solitary sold into domestic servitude, and the pale-skinned Anne torn between her suburban foster parents and her real family. The two males are Sandy, a vagrant with a mystic sense of the past, and Jimmy, an orphaned outsider driven to suicide.

All have one thing in common: they were stolen children. But a key point the play makes is the diversity of aboriginal experience.

What is impressive is the form, a restless, time-transcending mosaic dazzlingly realised in Wesley Enoch's production. One moment we see the five characters as institutionalised children playing rhyming games but always fearful of authority. The next they are adults either seeking or being sought.

Sometimes their plight is expressed visually, at others verbally. Ruby's lifelong slavery is embodied by a mop descending on her head from the ceiling. Sandy tells a Catch-22 tale about the arbitrariness of authority: welfare condemned his mother as unfit because her shelves contained an outdated can of peas which they themselves had supplied in the first place.

You are moved by the authenticity of the experience - these are true stories vividly told. And the effect is overwhelmingly reinforced by the closing moments when the actors abandon all pretence and recount their own experiences.

Pauline Whyman tells of her own mother who had 11 children stolen from her and of what it was like growing up as an aborigine categorised until 1967 under "flora and fauna". Kylie Belling describes the shock of meeting her natural parents when she was 24. Glenn Shea expresses the hope that one day all the stolen children may sit with their aboriginal gods.

But the overall effect is not pious. Rather, one is moved to tears by the way an unthinking white bureaucracy distorted and even destroyed so many individual lives. Apologists for the past might point to the way some of the stolen children prospered.

And there is a fascinating solo show at the Barbican, White Baptist Abba Fan (playing in tandem with Box the Pony), which I saw in Sydney and in which Deborah Cheetham recalls how she was brought up as an "adopted aboriginal", studied music and became an opera singer. But Cheetham also recalls the emotional cost of severance and the pain of reunion with her real family. Nothing can excuse an unfeeling official policy; and, as one of the actresses in Stolen points out, those who survived it amount to a freakish 1%.

While seeing these shows I've been reading Jonathan Bate's The Song of the Earth which offers an ecological reading of literature and makes a powerful plea for poetry as the place where we save the earth. Seeing Stolen and White Baptist Abba Fan suggests to me that drama may have a parallel function. It is the last place, in a hi-tech world, where we gather to hear stories and possibly redeem the past.

Poetry, Bate says, becomes the original admission of dwelling. Theatre, in the case of these exhilarating Australian shows, becomes a vehicle for reconciliation.

 Stolen is at the Tricycle Theatre, London NW6 (020-7328 1000),till July 15. White Baptist Abba Fan and Box the Pony are at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), till July 8.

fields.headline: Little boy blue
fields.standfirst: William Hague first came to attention as a perky 16-year-old addressing a Tory party conference, and he's been singing much the same tune ever since. Are people at last beginning to listen? Kevin Toolis joins him on the road to find out.
fields.trailText: William Hague first came to attention as a perky 16-year-old addressing a Tory party conference, and he's been singing much the same tune ever since. Are people at last beginning to listen? Kevin Toolis joins him on the road to find out.
fields.body:
Her Majesty's Leader of the Opposition and would-be First Minister William Hague is arriving at the Police Federation in Brighton for a speech. His car stops and the waiting camera crews scramble as he, accompanied by a single aide, sweeps in through the doors. "When are you going to have a baby," shouts a lone female camerawoman. Hague, his bald head gleaming like a beacon, strides past into the hall. The Police Federation welcoming party instantly becomes a swarming phalanx of jumping, swirling camera crews, burly police sergeants, burning television lights and scurrying photographers, snaking its way through the conference centre. We march forward deeper and deeper, a procession bathed in light, now of seeming power and destiny, and arrive at our destination, the elevators.

It's the end of the line for the media, but not for the Guardian, as we rise in the lift towards the VIP suite, where William, as he is universally known to his aides, will briefly prepare himself before his big speech of the day on crime, law and order, more bobbies on the beat, the heart of the Tory heartland. In the non-descript room, the walls lined with tables covered with plates of biscuits and bottles of mineral water, he stands in the centre, making awkward small-talk with the chairman of the Police Federation. He wears a blue suit and one of those big, silky politician's ties. Hague is enveloped by the aura and armour of leadership; in another life, this could be the first meeting of the take-over team who are going to sack everyone. Even in this inner sanctum, there are 20 people: party press officers, a documentary crew and his hosts. Every eye is upon him; this room is just another public stage. Hague asks for a private moment - to put on make-up for the television cameras - and we are all briefly expelled.

Later, ready to make his speech, he pauses in the darkness by the side of the stage, looking out over ranks of middle-aged policemen settling down for the show. Hague at last seems to relax. He stands there, self-contained, peering into the middle distance, confident that he is again in his element, assured of his audience. Soon, these beer-gutted coppers with their bad ties and shiny suits will be chortling in their seats at the Tory leader's gags, applauding his attacks on crime, relishing the verbal boot going into Labour Home Secretary Jack Straw.

It is a moment to ponder. Is this the next British Prime Minister? Can Hague win for the Tories this time, or even the next time? Will he be Prime Minister in 2001 or 2006? Or never? Can the Tory Boy Wonder destroy the might of New Labour? Or will the Great British nation always see him as that geeky man-child, prematurely old, 16 going on 45, dressed in an appalling adolescent tweed blazer giving that "famous speech" at the 1977 Tory party conference, an instantly retrievable icon in the national archive somewhere between the three-day week, power cuts and Mrs T in a polka-dot dress on the steps of 10 Downing Street.

At the back of the hall, staring down impassive and unrelenting, are the electoral gods, the TV cameras, beaming out their message to the great beyond of low, high and middle England. We say we have to put that right, and it's practical common sense to put it right."

The intention is to convince you that Hague is reflecting the concerns of Britain's Asian population, their anger at this unregulated flood of immigrants. No, no, it's nothing to do with the old unfashionable Powellite Tory race card; it's Britain's existing immigrants who are annoyed at these bogus asylum seekers.

It is an unabashed non-sequitur: the political crisis over asylum seekers has nothing to do with mythical protests by British Asians and everything to do with ugly racial attitudes by British whites. It is the reverse of the truth. But, as Hague and his advisers know, the message, the code hidden inside his sound-bite, will still connect to this racist constituency - you can only really trust the Tories to keep those foreigners out.

Like any politician, Hague's lines, however sincerely delivered, are carefully pre-scripted. At any one moment he can churn out 20 or maybe 30 little sound-bites on whatever issue the interviewer presses the button on. It is an essential tool of the politician's trade, and Hague has nearly mastered it to perfection. Each little line is important, not just for what it says, but for what it does not say. The best one, which we heard repeated, word perfect, half-a-dozen times over the following 24 hours, was on asylum seekers. "We have chaos in the asylum system. We believe we have to have firm but fair immigration controls. The people who should feel most offended, and often do feel most offended, by the abuse of the asylum procedures, are people who are immigrants to this country and have gone through all the proper procedures, filled in the forms, waited years and have gone through every rule and regulation and waited to bring their families into this country. And then they see that the system can be completely abused and circumvented by people claiming political asylum who are not political refugees at all. We say we have to put that right, and it's practical common sense to put it right." The intention is to convince you that Hague is reflecting the concerns of Britain's Asian population, their anger at this unregulated flood of immigrants. No, no, it's nothing to do with the old unfashionable Powellite Tory race card; it's Britain's existing immigrants who are annoyed at these bogus asylum seekers. It is an unabashed non-sequitur: the political crisis over asylum seekers has nothing to do with mythical protests by British Asians and everything to do with ugly racial attitudes by British whites. It is the reverse of the truth. But, as Hague and his advisers know, the message, the code hidden inside his sound-bite, will still connect to this racist constituency - you can only really trust the Tories to keep those foreigners out. Read the second part of Little boy blue here

fields.headline: Love among the lawn ornaments
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Must we subject our kids to this filth? No, not to the giant breasts and omnipresent penises of Eurotrash (of which more later), but to the nonsense that passed for debate in Love Bites Back (ITV). In a violently edited half-hour, Anna Richardson attempted to chair a discussion of Section 28. Katie Ivens, of the Campaign for Real Education, was convinced that schools are under siege from gay pornographers eager to thrust mucky pamphlets into the hands of children. She based this on once seeing some literature that equated homosexual relationships with heterosexual relationships, and included "contact numbers" that doubtless were hotlines to "sex rings". Tim Montgomerie, of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, topped that by saying: "It's because I believe in a tolerant society that I believe Section 28 should stay." The other two panellists, a former headmaster and a representative of the Institute of Education, argued sanely and quietly for the repeal of the clause.

A 16-year-old lesbian testified to her experiences of homophobic bullying, and a woman from Save the Children suggested that children have a right to decent sexual and health education, but they were swept aside. To its fans, Section 28 is all that stands between us and complete social collapse. Two facts were overlooked in the debate: firstly, that no prosecutions have ever been brought under the section, and secondly, that those of us who left school before 1988 all seemed to get on quite well without it.

Richardson remained cheerful to the very tips of her fingers-in-the-socket hairdo. "I'm afraid I'm going to have to stop you there," she told the panellists four or five times, with increasing desperation, fighting back the desire to wade into the argument with a few choice phrases of her own.

Thank heavens for the healthy outdoor pursuits of Charlie's Garden Army (BBC1), where the good people of Peckham, south London, got down to the mucky business of converting a council-owned dumping ground into a public open space. The results were typical of BBC gardening shows: too many features, not enough plants. Walls were painted lilac and orange, decking was laid, breezeblock carved and copper hammered, and there was even a sculpture of two fighting sheep as a focal point for the meadow area. "Maybe now they're in place, the locals will grow to love my rams," said Charlie Dimmock, in a way that invited smutty interpretation.

After only three months, the results were little short of spectacular. The community had clearly benefited from the experience and could even face the prospect of balloon artists and face painters descending in their midst. Given that any vertical space in London is usually covered in graffiti within five minutes, one could fear for the future of Dimmock's handiwork.

Had she been German, Dimmock might well have featured on Eurotrash (Channel 4) with a salacious commentary and a regional accent. Although, now we've reached the 13th series of the post-watershed warhorse, you have to do a bit more than not wear a bra to get noticed by Antoine de Caunes. Among this week's freaks were the Swiss artist Danny Calderon, who uses semen in the way that other painters use turps, and The Amazing Randy, a magician who did a trick with a guillotine (and can you guess what he used as his wand?). The voice-over artists had a bit of fun with Eros and Aldo, two incredibly gay Italians who design erotic lingerie.

Practically everyone got their genitals out at some point, which is a crude but effective way of maintaining an audience of some sort. Even the seemingly normal Olesen family from Denmark turned out to have a secret: George is a tattooed strong man and Karina (with her football-shaped breast enlargements) makes lesbian videos. But that's what you get for growing up in a country unprotected by Section 28.

fields.headline: Nagging doubts
fields.standfirst: 'The Daily Mail has created thousands more anorexics than Vogue: it links women's weight to their sexual orientation and career success'
fields.trailText: 'The Daily Mail has created thousands more anorexics than Vogue: it links women's weight to their sexual orientation and career success'.
fields.body:
I always think of myself as fairly shameless, so when someone surprises me with their shamelessness I'm quite taken aback. It doesn't happen very often. In particular, I don't expect to have my thunder stolen by English tennis players, yet a news item last week had me pop-eyed with awe. The speaker was one "Buster" Mottram; the paper carrying his gems didn't say how old he was - or, craftily, print a photograph of him - but I remember his silly name from my teens, so he's got to be in his fifties. It's hardly a stellar name, is it: "Mottram"? Like something embarrassing you'd do in a car. And as for being called "Buster" once you've lost your milk teeth...

Like most English tennis players over the past 30 years, his reputation is hardly glorious, either. In fact, all I remember him for is expressing support for the National Front and then attempting to cover his embarrassment by embarking on a song-writing career with the black entertainer, Kenny Lynch. I don't suppose you're currently tapping your toe to a snazzy little Mottram-Lynch number, or indeed have ever done, so I think it's fair to say that in this, as in his day job, "Buster" cut a less than Olympian figure. Never mind - he has now found a foolproof way to get into the papers: throughout Wimbledon, he has been available to the media to do exactly what you'd think a fifty-something man who still laboured under the name "Buster" would do best. Namely, tease the girls and make them cry.

That's right - "Buster" has announced that he doesn't fancy Lindsay Davenport, Monica Seles or Jennifer Capriati, because they're too fat. Furthermore, he warned from his throne on Mount Olympus, the women's game will soon start losing out financially (something he is an authority on, to be fair) if women players leave their femininity behind. "In the 70s, women earned massive sponsorship from cosmetic companies, attracted by their femininity," he said. "Today, sponsorship is drying up because women do not regard their femininity as an asset. I think Anna Kournikova is the best influence on the women's game in a long time."

You don't have to be a rad fem to consider it weird that a player who gets knocked out in the first few days of Wimbledon is held up as the example to whom other women players should aspire. And, somehow, I can't imagine Davenport, Seles or Capriati crying in the dressing room and refusing to come out on court because Mottram doesn't fancy them. Well, that settles it: they must be lesbians then. Davenport (6ft 2in, 12 stone), Capriati (um, nine and a half stone) and Seles (no vital statistics available, but reported as being definitely "chunky"), by putting devotion to their craft over their appeal to men (Capriati, we were reminded by the Daily Mail, was a "delicate figure in her early career" and a regular pin-up), have committed one of the most heinous modern crimes a woman can: they do not care whether or not they are physically attractive. Whereas a woman might once have been disapproved of merely as sloppy, today her appearance calls into question her sexual orientation, morals and even sanity. I'm thinking here of the way the exquisitely beautiful Patsy Kensit is accused of being on the verge of mental collapse if she so much as steps outside her house without full stage make-up and a Versace frock.

As Susan Faludi pointed out in Backlash, as women's assurance in the professional field has grown, so their confidence has been assaulted by a growing media obsession with their personal appearance. After all, as Simone de Beauvoir said, it takes an awful lot of time to become a "real" woman - time that must inevitably be snatched away from working, playing or relaxing. The hysterical over-use of the word "pampering" - which implies that this is a woman's "Me" time, whereas really it is simply more work on the raw material so as not to make it too repulsive to all-important men - is a symptom of this. So are famous and/or older women who neurotically strip off for inspection every chance they get; and the City bankers who waste their lunch-times having manicures (once the province of the kept woman and the idle housewife) when they could be having fun; and the idiot who brought the phrase "Does my bum look big in this?" into popular use. (Who would you rather sleep with/look like - Jennifer Lopez or Calista Flockhart?)

Look at poor old Sporty Spice, accused of being a lesbian partly because she went on holiday with a woman, Ying Yau, whose name sounded like an Oriental orgasm, but mostly because she put on loads of weight and didn't seem to care; seemed really happy, in fact. The castration of Sporty, who can now be heard mewing, "I'm going to have my hair long and blonde for the next video - it'll be magic!", is an example of how easily young, not-too-smart girls can be cowed into submission by what Anna Ford so memorably dubbed body fascism. The Daily Mail has created thousands more anorexics than Vogue, because Vogue simply shows thin women while the Daily Mail keeps up a non-stop commentary on the weight gain of famous women and links it directly to their sexual orientation and career success. For a newspaper so opposed to the Nanny State, it certainly does a good imitation of a prize nag.

And here is the heart of the matter. "Nagging" is popularly believed to be the province of women in our society - though, in my experience, the nagging, neurotically-houseproud husband is an ever-present danger as he strives to achieve in the domestic arena the order and dominance that he cannot achieve in the outside world. It is fair to say that, of the 72% of divorces that women petition for each year, a good number of them involve husbands who fussed, fretted and nagged themselves right out of a marriage.

On a far greater level, to be a woman today is to be subjected to a barrage of nagging from cradle to grave, much of it about morals, conduct and health, but mostly on the way one looks, and almost all of it from men such as Buster Mottram. How does this happen? Is there some sort of NHS scheme whereby kind nurses creep into the homes of the likes of David Baddiel and Frank Skinner at night and replace their real mirrors with trick mirrors that reflect them as resembling Josh Hartnett and Heath Ledger? If not, how would they dare nag at women for not being up to sexual scratch?

If a man is married to a nagging wife, he can kill her, get a pat on the head from the judge and be out on the streets in time for the next Rotary dinner. If a woman finds herself stuck in a nagging nation state, though, what is her option?

fields.headline: How to garden
fields.trailText: Once you've been out in the fresh air for a few hours, you begin to feel a deep inner peace, which fades only after you've driven a garden fork straight through your foot. The best thing about gardening is that it gets you away from everyone else.
fields.body:
You can tell what kind of gardener you are by your tools; trowel and trug mean you're a primrose and sweetpea sort; wheelbarrow and seed dibber mean you're a potato and marrow person; concrete mixer and socket set mean what you most like to grow in your garden is a second-hand Ford Sierra.

Once you've been out in the fresh air for a few hours, you begin to feel a deep inner peace, which fades only after you've driven a garden fork straight through your foot. The best thing about gardening is that it gets you away from everyone else, which is why it's a little bizarre that people who've spent years on their gardens suddenly decide to open them up to the general public.

What real gardeners like most of all is fooling around with the compost. This is where you throw all your waste food to rot and be turned into rich nutrients for your vegetables. Of course, if you didn't grow so many vegetables in the first place, you wouldn't have so much waste food and you wouldn't be producing all this stinking compost.

The joy of gardening is that it allows you to go outside in your favourite corduroys and cardigan and pretend they're just your gardening clothes. To turn normal clothes into gardening clothes, simply mix with compost.

One of the best rituals of gardening is the bonfire, where you burn all manner of garden waste and a couple of your wife's dresses that you don't like. Done properly, bonfires should be huge piles of damp greenery with great choking clouds of smoke heading directly for your neighbours' washing.

You don't need 40 acres of prime agricultural land to becomes a gardener. It's amazing what can be done with a couple of terracotta pots and some window boxes. With care, you can feed a family of eight entirely on organically-grown produce (once you've sold the marijuana from your pots).

Gardeners get pleasure out of growing things, but not when things grow without permission. Weeds can grow up to 4ft high overnight, which is why gardeners actually spend most of their time slashing, burning, spraying, pruning and generally beating the hell out of nature.

The sign of a real gardener is when they're away from home they think about their vegetables more than they think about their family and, when they finally return home, the first thing they do is rush down the garden and check their runner beans, totally oblivious to the charred embers of their home.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: London calling
fields.standfirst: 'Feel I am an enormous sow, with family of piglets sucking out my life energies'
fields.trailText: 'Feel I am an enormous sow, with family of piglets sucking out my life energies'
fields.body:
Must engineer escape from provincial treadmill involving Ex-Spouse, Great Aunt and two feckless teenagers. Have been invited to London for Saskia's exhibition, Digital-is, though not sure whether the angle is electronic, toxic or Sapphic.

However, anticipate objections all round. Sometimes, I feel I am an enormous sow with whole family like a row of piglets sucking out my life energies. To fortify myself, have bought a book called How To Say No Without Feeling Guilty. But will it change my life?

It changed Richard Carlson's. He wrote the foreword. He's the author of his own self-help book, Don't Sweat The Small Stuff. I wonder what that means? Have an uneasy feeling - call it guilt, if you like - that I probably sweat even medium-sized stuff without even realising I'm doing it.

I begin with "Saying No To A Mooch". Not sure what a "Mooch" is. A GM poodle with a great shaggy head, given to grazing the tundra and stampeding? "They never have the right change for the bus, and always need to bum it from you." Ah! I think I do perhaps recognise a Mooch after all.

"Dulcie?" Aunt approaches with hand on cheek. "I'm having a bit of trrrouble with a tooth." The aunt has not been to the dentist for decades. Some of her teeth are blue.

"Gordon will take you to our dentist's while I'm away, Auntie. She's very good, and never hurts."

"You'rrre going to London, dearrr?" Aunt's eyes flash with envy. "How wonderrrful! I would so like to see Nelson's column once morrre beforrre I die."

"Then let's go later in the summer. I'm afraid I can't take you this time, because I'm staying with my friends, Alice and Saskia."

"Ah, Alice! Such an intelligent gairrrl! Has she found herrrself a nice young man yet?"

Inhale deeply. Must say no also to mealy-mouthed evasions. "It's just not going to happen, Auntie. The fact is, they're lesbians. I envy them, in a way. Lesbian relationships are often a lot more stable and faithful."

Aunt goes pink. "Och , you mustn't think I'm auld-fashioned about that sorrrt of thing, dearrr, Why, I had quite a wee crrrush on Jeannie Macpherrrson when we werrre at school. In fact..."

"Mum!" Harriet arrives, thank God, to forestall aunt's coming out. "Let's go down the Mall and buy me loadsa cloves tomorra, right?"

"No! I'm sick of you being a mooch, bumming off me all the time! I'm going to London for a few days."

"Lunnon?!" Harriet bridles with outrage. "Tight!! I wanna come!"

"You can't! You have to go to school!"

"I'll just come for the weekend then!"

"No!" Race upstairs and hurl miscellaneous clothes into bag. Terrible way to pack. Bound to forget something. After another five "No"s, I am packed and rush downstairs again. Meet Ex-Spouse in hall. "I'm off to London in a minute!" I cry defiantly.

"You never mentioned London!" he snaps in fury.

"That's because I knew you'd be a Grouch about it. Mooching and bumming all the time. This is for me."

"Don't talk to me in that transatlantic twaddle!" he roars, as the phone rings. It is Alice.

"Dulcie? Look, I'm sorry, but Saskia and I are in the middle of a crisis."

"No!"

"Yes - we went to the theatre last night - Tennessee Williams, I should have known better. English actors just can't do Deep South. They kept veering off into Geoffrey Boycott or the Dalai Lama. Anyway, Saskia started flirting outrageously with the woman sitting next to us. She's such a shameless tart. When we got home, we had a huge row and she's sleeping in the spare room."

"Alice... are you saying you can't have me to stay?"

"I'm sorry, Dulcie, but... no."

Ring off determined to say no to this no. This is just small stuff, and I'm not going to sweat it. I'm going to London come what may. There are cheap hotels in Bloomsbury. Dive into my rucksack, blow treacherous kisses to incredulous family and walk off briskly towards the station. No guilt, no sweat and, as I discover on arrival at the booking office, no purse.

Not sure what a "Mooch" is. A GM poodle with a great shaggy head, given to grazing the tundra and stampeding? "They never have the right change for the bus, and always need to bum it from you." Ah! I think I do perhaps recognise a Mooch after all. "Dulcie?" Aunt approaches with hand on cheek. "I'm having a bit of trrrouble with a tooth." The aunt has not been to the dentist for decades. Some of her teeth are blue. "Gordon will take you to our dentist's while I'm away, Auntie. She's very good, and never hurts." "You'rrre going to London, dearrr?" Aunt's eyes flash with envy. "How wonderrrful! I would so like to see Nelson's column once morrre beforrre I die." "Then let's go later in the summer. I'm afraid I can't take you this time, because I'm staying with my friends, Alice and Saskia." "Ah, Alice! Such an intelligent gairrrl! Has she found herrrself a nice young man yet?" Inhale deeply. Must say no also to mealy-mouthed evasions. "It's just not going to happen, Auntie. The fact is, they're lesbians. I envy them, in a way. Lesbian relationships are often a lot more stable and faithful." Aunt goes pink. "Och , you mustn't think I'm auld-fashioned about that sorrrt of thing, dearrr, Why, I had quite a wee crrrush on Jeannie Macpherrrson when we werrre at school. In fact..." "Mum!" Harriet arrives, thank God, to forestall aunt's coming out. "Let's go down the Mall and buy me loadsa cloves tomorra, right?" "No! I'm sick of you being a mooch, bumming off me all the time! I'm going to London for a few days." "Lunnon?!" Harriet bridles with outrage. "Tight!! I wanna come!" "You can't! You have to go to school!" "I'll just come for the weekend then!" "No!" Race upstairs and hurl miscellaneous clothes into bag. Terrible way to pack. Bound to forget something. After another five "No"s, I am packed and rush downstairs again. Meet Ex-Spouse in hall. "I'm off to London in a minute!" I cry defiantly. "You never mentioned London!" he snaps in fury. "That's because I knew you'd be a Grouch about it. Mooching and bumming all the time. This is for me." "Don't talk to me in that transatlantic twaddle!" he roars, as the phone rings. It is Alice. "Dulcie? Look, I'm sorry, but Saskia and I are in the middle of a crisis." "No!" "Yes - we went to the theatre last night - Tennessee Williams, I should have known better. English actors just can't do Deep South. They kept veering off into Geoffrey Boycott or the Dalai Lama. Anyway, Saskia started flirting outrageously with the woman sitting next to us. She's such a shameless tart. When we got home, we had a huge row and she's sleeping in the spare room." "Alice... are you saying you can't have me to stay?" "I'm sorry, Dulcie, but... no." Ring off determined to say no to this no. This is just small stuff, and I'm not going to sweat it. I'm going to London come what may. There are cheap hotels in Bloomsbury. Dive into my rucksack, blow treacherous kisses to incredulous family and walk off briskly towards the station. No guilt, no sweat and, as I discover on arrival at the booking office, no purse.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Asexuality is not as easy as it sounds.
fields.body:
I don't think it's possible for me to be asexual - as my readers wish - and fashionably dressed. Last week, I was asked to a party; celibacy doesn't mean that I'll dress boringly, so I visited www.brownsfashion.com. I bought myself a lovely, wispy slip-dress. You may remember, I've joined The Asexual Coalition whose official greeting involves raising your arms triumphantly and shouting 'ASEXUAL!' At the party, a Mediterranean-looking hunk eyed me pretty thoroughly; needless to say I ignored him, but he headed my way prontissimo. I decided to use the Coalition salute to make clear he didn't have a chance.

One of the things about being asexual is that you're full of energy. I bought a terrifying bench-press from www.ironmaster.com, and I've been working out like mad in the evenings; nobody believes I haven't had silicone implants because my pecs are in such good shape. So, the hunk approached, flashing a 'Hey, babe' lazy smile; I glared at him icily, threw up my arms, and roared 'Asexual!' Disaster! The sudden thrust of my toned-up glories was too much for the delicate dress, and the flimsy straps came unstitched.

I admit that it's hard for a man to believe protestations of chastity when your dress drops to the floor as soon as you greet him. I made as discreet an exit as I could.

Still, my looks are my comfort, so I visited www.changeslive.com. The idea is great: you scan your photo and then you try different make-up styles, which you can order from them. There's advice for men as well (yes, they can be gorgeous, too, if they try). The problem is that you can read War And Peace while downloading the make-up studio. Anyway, what's the point of being all made up with nowhere to go?

 www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Clouded Yellow
fields.trailText: Clouded Yellow
fields.body: St Austell Brewery, in Cornwall, has come up trumps with the best new beer I've tasted in a long time. Chosen as the winner of the Tesco Spring/ Summer Challenge, Clouded Yellow, 5%, has an all-star cast: alongside the statutory barley malt, hops, yeast and water, there's a generous dose of malted wheat to provide the cloudy character of the beer when poured, plus spices, vanilla and organic maple syrup. Wheat is a difficult grain to brew with, but it's worth the effort, as it imparts to the beer rich and luscious flavours and aromas of citrus fruits and over-ripe bananas. The maple syrup is fermented out and gives a soft, creamy note to Clouded Yellow without being cloying. Any residual sweetness from the grains and syrup are offset by the hops, the spices and the vanilla, which all linger tantalisingly on the back of the palate. St Austell is proud of its pure spring water, which comes from its own aquifer in a Wagnerian blue cavern. Clouded Yellow costs £1.49 for 500ml and is in a Tesco near you.

fields.headline: Beauty within
fields.standfirst: Never trust your first impressions, says Lesley Gillilan - inside that ordinary-looking house, there might be lurking an extraordinary interior.
fields.trailText: Never trust your first impressions, says Lesley Gillilan - inside that ordinary-looking house, there might be lurking an extraordinary interior.
fields.body:
Charlotte Hindle and Simon Ritchie's south-London home is nothing much to look at from the outside. One of a row of family houses in a low-rise, inner-city estate, built in 1966 (the year of white PVC and World Cup euphoria), it's an unremarkable example of utilitarian, public-sector architecture. And, despite years of private ownership, it still has "council" written all over its dull, red-brick facade.

You get a similar, dull feeling from the exterior of the home of Chris Fletcher and his wife Susan Shaw - a mundane, purpose-built flat dating from Edwardian times. Inside, the comparisons do not stop, but for entirely different reasons. Both couples have transformed the dysfunctional parts of their interiors using ultra-modern design so, judging from the outside, you would not think you were in the same home.

But while Fletcher and Shaw wanted to change their hated, cramped kitchen and the "flimsy" trap-door that hid a staircase leading to the back yard, Hindle and Ritchie had more ambitious plans.

According to Hindle, the interior of their house used to be "very councilly", just like the outside. Now, behind the front door, is a clean, white, open-plan space, highlighted with bold slabs of bright paintwork; nice wooden floors; clever lighting; a groovy kitchen with lacquered units in strong colours (inspired by the lavender fields of Provence) and a collage of unusual linear tiles (after the London Underground).

An oblique travel theme reflects the occupants' jobs (Charlotte is a manager at publisher Lonely Planet; husband Simon is a travel writer). But this is no Changing Rooms make-over. More structural engineering than cosmetic surgery, it's been a case of changing the dynamics of the space, rather than dressing it up in new clothes. It's not a DIY job, either - in fact, the couple were terribly grown-up and hired an architect.

The architect, Robert Loader, wasn't cheap, of course. "We budgeted for £50,000 but ended up spending £60,000," says Hindle. But, for the majority of architects, that is cheap (as a rough guide, their fee works out at between 8% and 15% of the total contract value; any job worth less than £30,000 is small-practice chicken-feed). And, for Hindle and Ritchie, it was a great deal cheaper than the alternative - buying an "airier, spacier" house in the same area of inner London. "We considered that option, but couldn't find anything for much less than £300,000," says Charlotte.

Their ex-council house, in its raw, unlovely state, was not worth that kind of money. So, they decided to invest in what their architect describes as a process of "renewal". And the result is an inspiration for all those aspiring modernists who despair of ever affording a contemporary living space. If you don't have the wile or the wherewithal to buy, or build, something new and exciting, then here's the solution: buy something old and tired, and then remodel, extend and, indeed, renew.

Do you need to hire an architect? Absolutely, says Hindle. And the quality of the design is only part of that necessity. "We didn't have time to come up with plans, or to keep track of builders, or to do any of the project management, so we needed somebody to do all of that for us," she explains. "Plus, our architect came up with ideas we'd never have thought of, he sourced products we wouldn't know where to find, he even helped with the colour scheme."

This, in essence, is what architects do. In fact, the notion that they are all shoving up landmark schemes on the scale of the Lloyds building is a misunderstanding. More often than not, they are reconfigurating existing material rather than building from scratch (only one in four of the private housing projects that made it on to the RIBA awards list for this year are new-build schemes). Hence, the majority of architectural practice is simply a case of adding or subtracting walls - albeit in a manner that expresses their own distinctive style.

While Robert Loader has particular sympathy for 60s and 70s buildings ("much more interesting than poxy Victorian terraces," he says), the architect used by Chris Fletcher and Susan Shaw specialises in "introducing very modern insertions to listed buildings". Deborah Saunt is a partner at the London practice of DSDHA, which has just won a RIBA award for an Orangery extension in Norfolk. With its contract value of £30,000, this was one of the smallest winning projects. Fletcher's and Shaw's flat, in Dulwich, south London, was an even smaller job.

Fletcher, a museum curator, and Shaw, a doctor, were perfectly happy with the majority of their home (with its unusually large and splendidly original reception rooms), but the cramped kitchen was "dreadful". The cabinet doors hung off their hinges, the sink didn't work, the hole in the floor was blocked by a washing machine. And not only was it a "dark, pokey, unappealing space", but it was one of the first sights to greet guests when they walked in. "Neither of us had any ideas or solutions," says Fletcher. "And although we knew we needed proper advice, it was a revelation to discover that we could use an architect for such a small job."

The basis of Deborah Saunt's brief was to make one "simple clean space" out of two awkward ones (kitchen and dining room) and to rethink the trap-door exit. In general, her approach is, she says, a case of "finding a long-term solution that is flexible enough to accommodate change". And, in this one, she compensated for the limitations of a low budget - around £20,000 - by investing in rich, tactile materials (such as adding American oak surfaces to the MDF kitchen units) and small but clever touches in the detailing (like nifty door handles).

As well as opening up the space, she built a storage wall to hide kitchen utilities, designed an island kitchen unit (complete with a lift-up ledge to conceal the cooking mess that Chris likes to make and Susan hates to see); she hid a "stranded boiler" in the dining room behind a neat enclosure and, finally, created a new, more accessible door to the once-horrible rear exit in the form of lift-up flaps, which blend beautifully with the floor when not in use.

According to Fletcher, the trapdoor has since become semi-redundant ("I actually find it more convenient just to use the front door and walk round the back," he admits), but he and Shaw are delighted with the overall scheme. "I think we saved money in the long run," says Fletcher. And, since they are thinking of selling the flat, the improvements will almost certainly enhance its value.

This wouldn't apply, however, in areas of Britain where you can still buy a whole house for roughly the same price as Deborah Saunt's low-budget bill. Four years ago, the architect Doug Chadwick (of Chadwick & Bracewell) and his daughter Delphine (also an architect) bought such a place, in Blackburn for £14,500. True, it was a wreck (damp walls, dodgy roof, dismal interior), but that was all part of the masterplan - part of Doug's "30-year crusade to bring contemporary design to East Lancashire".

The two-up-two-down house was essentially for Delphine, who was still studying at the time and not only wanted a cheap home but, according to her father, also needed "a little bit of hands-on experience in the practicalities of construction". For Doug, meanwhile, the property provided his own little experiment in small-scale urban regeneration - a model that would, hopefully, inspire others to do extraordinary things with Lancashire's plentiful supply of ordinary houses ("people in this area are not very interested in modern design," he says).

They went for a south-facing property in a single-row terrace overlooking a playing field, in an area of Blackburn known as Cherry Tree. Between them, father and daughter gutted the place, removing walls, doors and a section of the first floor ceiling so that the old landing is now open-plan to a former bedroom (which became a study) and the stairwell is now open to the apex of the roof (which now features a line of Velux windows). They also created storage areas either side of what used to be the attic space, and suspended a bridge between the two.

According to Doug, the total cost was only £30,000, which covered the cost of the house, the refurbishment and every little detail, from the beech floors to the Venetian blinds. The figure, however, doesn't allow for much of the labour costs and design fees (supplied by the Chadwicks). But even though the house is now worth around £49,000, Doug insists that capital gain is less important than design objectives, or "enhancing the drama of the space".

The main objective, he says, was to bring sunshine into the property's dark, north-facing rear end - "to warm it up with daylight and give it more life," says Doug - and to increase its "accommodation capability" (getting rid of circulation space added 15% to living space). And although internally almost nothing original survives, the character of the building is unchanged. Thus, a modern, minimalist home has, once again, been slipped unobtrusively into an old shell.

Although the economics bear no comparison, the objectives are similar to those encountered during Robert Loader's 60s council-house renewal. There, too, the clients wanted to bring light into the back of a house, rid themselves of superfluous enclosures and free up unused space. "The rooms were small and claustrophobic, and the house felt very suburban and old-fashioned," says Charlotte. "The windows at the back didn't let in much light. And we didn't have a dining area. Having friends round for dinner is part of our lifestyle, so not having a dining area mattered to us."

Aside from the Provençal kitchen, the living space now has full-height windows overlooking the garden; the dining table sits in place of a redundant utility room; and air flows freely between one space and another.

The architect's bill included everything - design fees, builder's fees, kitchen units, tiles, flooring. "He took a very holistic approach," says Hindle. "He even helped us design the furniture. But I suppose, that's what good architects do. Instead of asking for a brief, they talk to you about your life and then they design the house around you."

So if the house you have no longer suits your life, then think about it: you might not even have to move

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Beacham
fields.trailText: Stephanie Beacham
fields.body:
Stephanie Beacham was born in 1949. After studying at Rada, she went on to have a successful career in film, TV and theatre on both sides of the Atlantic. She starred in the movie The Nightcomers with Marlon Brando, played Sable Colby in the TV series Dynasty, and is currently appearing in the comedy A Busy Day at the Lyric Theatre, London. She is divorced, with two daughters, and lives in Los Angeles.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Tea in hand, task completed, job well done.

What is your greatest fear?
Not caring.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Dithering.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Monstrous certainty.

What vehicles do you own?
A Mercedes in LA, a BMW in London

What is your greatest extravagance?
My imagination.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Hopefully the ones I'm going to need.

Where would you like to live?
When I finally make up my mind, I'll live there.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My hair is annoying me these days.

What is your most unappealing habit?
No one has dared tell me.

What is your favourite smell?
A baby's neck.

What is your favourite journey?
Going down the California incline to Pacific Coast Highway, and home.

What is your favourite fantasy?
I don't have fantasies - I make plans.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
They are scrapping already.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Not often.

For what cause would you die?
Good living.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Constantly.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Not today.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
'Sorry' and 'I'm not sure'.

What is your greatest regret?
Don't believe in them.

What would your motto be?
Good better best never let it rest till the good is better and the better best.

How would you like to be remembered?
In laughter.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Keep on truckin'.

She is divorced, with two daughters, and lives in Los Angeles. What is your idea of perfect happiness? Tea in hand, task completed, job well done. What is your greatest fear? Not caring. What is the trait you most deplore in yourself? Dithering. What is the trait you most deplore in others? Monstrous certainty. What vehicles do you own? A Mercedes in LA, a BMW in London What is your greatest extravagance? My imagination. What objects do you always carry with you? Hopefully the ones I'm going to need. Where would you like to live? When I finally make up my mind, I'll live there. What do you most dislike about your appearance? My hair is annoying me these days. What is your most unappealing habit? No one has dared tell me. What is your favourite smell? A baby's neck. What is your favourite journey? Going down the California incline to Pacific Coast Highway, and home. What is your favourite fantasy? I don't have fantasies - I make plans. Should the Royal Family be scrapped? They are scrapping already. Do you believe in capital punishment? Not often. For what cause would you die? Good living. Do you believe in monogamy? Constantly. Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it? Not today. Which words or phrases do you most overuse? 'Sorry' and 'I'm not sure'. What is your greatest regret? Don't believe in them. What would your motto be? Good better best never let it rest till the good is better and the better best. How would you like to be remembered? In laughter. What is the most important lesson life has taught you? Keep on truckin'.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck finds that Oddbins have come a long way since their inauspicious beginnings
fields.body:
On my first visit to an Oddbins shop, the year the England football team was managed by a bald man in a macintosh, I paid 24 shillings for three half-bottles of Château Smith-Haut-Lafite 1933. I wasted my money, and didn't get any of it back (one bottle oxidised, one bottle corked, one bottle boring). Oddbins has come on a lot since then, and so has the Languedoc, from where come the majority of the 14 Oddbins red wines that follow.

Château de Valcombe Costières de Nîmes 1998 (17 points out of 20, £5.49) has cheroots, hedgerows, leather, smoke, tannins, plus hints of old wood and les garrigues - enough of an assault course for anyone. Château de Valcombe Prestige Costières de Nîmes 1998 (16 points, £6.49) has a touch less drama than the cheaper wine from this property, and is slightly less gripping, though still a lovely wine. Château Grand Escalion Costières de Nîmes 1998 (17 points, £5.99) I found difficult to tell apart from the £5.49 Château de Valcombe. Perhaps the greatest differentiating subtlety is with the texture and the level of fumes.

Domaine Borie de Maurel Belle de Nuit Minervois 1999 (17.5 points, £7.49) is an extravagant mouthful, spreading itself lavishly on the tastebuds and refusing to budge. A bottle might last a week, so lingering is the richly complex, stunningly tannic fruit. Domaine Borie de Maurel Cuvée Sylla Minervois 1998 (18 points, £12.99) is even more grandiose, with its intensely savoury, deep, granite-jawed tannins and involved, swirling fruit of layered richness and texture. A truly exciting masterwork of such potency that it has to be compared with great claret costing four times more (a comparison odious in the extreme, but then this is an extreme wine).

Domaine Borie de Maurel Esprit d'Automne Minervois 1999 (17 points, £5.99) has a lush edge to its cigar-tangy fruit. It's very ripe and ready, and the tannins are the civilised side of intimidating.

Enclave des Papes Cuvée Spéciale Côtes du Rhône 1999 (16 points, £4.69) has wonderfully smooth and unruffled fruit with a hint of spiced plum and tobacco. More than a bit of a snip at this price, it's a great wine for back-garden get-togethers. James Herrick Millia Passum Syrah Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16.5 points, £6.99) has brilliant dark, dusky fruit of concentrated cassis and crunchy tannins. (This wine is possibly at Safeway, too, but no one could return my office's phone call to confirm this.)

Le Grand Verdier Minervois 1998 (17 points, £5.99) has tannins that grip, fruit that thrills, texture that excites - real class on show here. Pavillion de l'Escalion Costières de Nîmes 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99) has warmth and herby richness, allied to sensational tannins, which are soft yet insistent. And Plan Macassan Costières de Nîmes 1998 (16 points, £4.49) is a brilliant wine to take to the BYO restaurant because it can't be affected by cork taint and ruin your evening. The fruit under its plastic cork is all-action and feisty, and may prove seductive in the right candlelight.

From Portugal, Oddbins has dug up Quinta das Setencostas Alenquer 1998 (16.5 points, £5.49), which has warmth of disposition, weight of personality and panache of fruit. An exciting wine for the money. Scaranto Colli Euganei 1997 (16 points, £6.49), from Italy, is also warm and generous, with a hint of plum/raspberry jam to the rich fruit and a softish finish. And from Australia there is Wirra Wirra Church Block Cabernet Shiraz Merlot 1998 (17 points, £8.99), which is a benchmark blend, parading brisk tannins that elegantly coat the chocolate and cassis fruit. Waitrose has this wine, too, for the same money.

Last, we must pop into Somerfield for some barbecue bargains. This retailer has four cheapies currently on offer until July 18. They are a decently earthy and rustic Vin de Pays d'Ardeche Red (14 points, £2.29), a pleasant lemon/ melon Vin de Pays d'Ardeche White (14.5 points, £2.75), a blackberryish Bulgarian Country Red (14 points, £2.49), and a truly delicious Argentine, Santa Julia Syrah Rosé (15 points, £3.29). No hugely complex claims can be made for these wines, but with flambéed bangers or burnt mackerel they do more than merely drown your sorrows.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Hot stuff: barbecues, Part II
fields.trailText: Hot stuff: barbecues, Part II
fields.body:
The subject
Cooking outdoors over an open fire.

The basics
Because barbecuing is a simple but unpredictable operation, success depends on following the three holy precepts of Barbecue Knowledge. Precept 1: know thy heat. Precept 2: respect thy food. Precept 3: don't turn thy back.

The details
Precept 1 means attending minutely to the level of heat radiated by the coals once they've died down to white-and-glowing, the condition that indicates readiness for cooking. Use your hand to 'read' the temperature over every sector of the grill. Unless you're an obsessive, or a genius, or you have a gas grill, some sectors will be hotter than others. Note their location. Adjust your expected cooking times. Be prepared to move the food around with a pair of long-handled chef's tongs. Precept 2 means knowing what kind of heat can bring the food to barbecue ecstasy. Thin pieces of meat, fish, or veg need a high flame for a short period; thick pieces the exact opposite. Once you master the process, you can barbecue anything - even a whole duck or a shoulder of lamb, if your barbecue has a lid. Precept 3 has but one exception: you can nip inside for a few minutes if the lid is down. Apart from that, you must not leave the glowing coals for longer than it takes to have a glug of beer. Whenever The Knowledge asks his 'assistants' (they know who they are) to keep an eye on things while he tends to the salad, disaster strikes. Unless your assistants are trained to Cordon Bleu-becue standards, don't trust them. Do it yourself. Be a control freak.

Where to buy
Chef's tongs: most kitchen outlets.

The easy way out
Anything that can be barbecued can be grilled - but it won't taste the same.

fields.headline: The sauce of it
fields.standfirst: Those bottles sitting at the back of the store cupboard offer no end of tangy potential for your cooking. In fact, they can work wonders, says Jeremy Lee
fields.trailText: Those bottles sitting at the back of the store cupboard offer no end of tangy potential for your cooking. In fact, they can work wonders, says Jeremy Lee
fields.body:
Here is a tale of three sauces. None of them is made by fancy-pants chefs. None has much of a place in haute cuisine or any of that nonsense. But they are all classics in the best sense of the word. I've always loved going to the stores and seeing the ordered ranks of tins and bottles and bags and boxes of ingredients that are just as much the backbone of the professional kitchen as they are of the domestic. Here are the different oils and essences, vinegars and pulses, herbs and spices with quality and pedigree. And here, too, between the tins of anchovies and tubs of mustard on the shelf below, are the bottles that you almost don't notice because they blend so much into daily life.

They are the unmistakable bottles of Tabasco and Worcestershire sauce (not to mention Heinz tomato ketchup), stalwarts of the pantry and friends indeed when the soup has no ping, the sauce has no wow and a dish is as flat as a punctured tyre. Their unique abilities to quicken and enliven the foods upon which they are boldly splashed really are as brilliant as the legends that surround the origins of these potent kitchen comrades.

The seeds of the original peppers for Tabasco came, around 150 years ago, to Edmund McIlhenny through a friend who had been fighting in the Mexican civil war. On receiving them, he sowed the seeds on Avery Island, Louisiana, but before they could be harvested he and his family had to flee during the upheavals of the war. On their return, McIlhenny discovered that the peppers had grown apace, a credit, possibly, to the mountain of salt below the soil, the peak of which is Avery Island. The rest, as they say, is history, the peppers having a unique and splendid flavour that eventually became the sauce that graces eating and drinking establishments around the globe.

The story of Worcestershire sauce is less dramatic. In fact, it's all rather British. It seems that, back in the 1830s, a certain peer returned from India with a recipe involving vinegar, soy, molasses, anchovies, chilli, garlic, ginger, shallots and various fruits for a sauce, which he gave to two chemists by the name of Lea and Perrins to make up for him. So foul was the result - well, it would be, wouldn't it? - that the batch was left in the cellar, dismissed. A few years later, a big cleaning and sort-out was done to the cellar, and the barrel was heading for the bin when it was tasted - and, lo, one of the most famous sauces in the world came into creation.

There are the obvious modes of using these condiments (a word I am none too keen on): Tabasco and oysters, Worcestershire sauce and roes on toast, for example; while a bowl of crisp, golden chips - hand-made, naturally - served with a bottle of ketchup is a far superior eat-me to a drab bit of pastry wrapped around some dull shredded vegetables accompanied by a spineless dip.

But they play their part in many other dishes, too. Where, say, would the prawn cocktail be without a dash of Tabasco? I have little room in my heart for the prawn cocktail (I made so many of the damned things in my youth), but thinking about them again stirred my memory, and the recollection of avocado stuffed with prawns seemed measurably better. I shall lose no sleep over replacing mayonnaise with cream in a recipe that is as tasty as it is quaint.

Bottled sauces, catsups (or ketchups), relishes and chutneys have figured in cooking for so long that it's all too easy to dismiss them. But they serve the odd vital purpose - and that is to provide the buck-up that is the saviour of the cook in a dilemma over food. In fact, I find they are most effective when they join forces in that classic stimulant for the brain cells, the Bloody Mary. Now where did I put those bottles?

All recipes serve six.

Fried oysters with salsa

Although this recipe calls for oysters, prawns and little bits of fishes such as sole or mackerel are very good, too. These quantities will make an excellent companion to a Bloody Mary or Martini, or will double-up as a starter.

4 big ripe tomatoes

2 tsp sea salt

1 small handful fresh coriander

3 tbsp good red-wine vinegar

Juice of 1 lime

2 small red onions

Tabasco

1 small dish cornmeal (polenta)

18 oysters, or fish fillets cut into bite-size pieces

Vegetable oil, for frying

First, remove the eyes from the tomatoes, chop the flesh into small pieces, and tip into a bowl. Peel and finely chop the onions, and add to the bowl, along with the chopped coriander, lime juice, vinegar, salt and several bold dashes of Tabasco. Stir gently but thoroughly.

Shuck the oysters, removing any fragments of shell, and drain them in a sieve (the juice makes a welcome addition to a Bloody Mary). Heat a deep-fat fryer according to the maker's instructions, then press both sides of each oyster into the cornmeal. Drop the oysters, a few at a time, into the fryer and cook until crisp and nicely browned (three to five minutes, depending on their size). Drain the fritters on a kitchen towel and serve hot with the salsa.

Mince

Now here's a funny thing: in Scots cookery, it is unheard of to add tomato ketchup to mince when serving it up with skirlie and mash (although mushroom ketchup seems popular); we left that to those uncouth English. However, in making a shepherd's or cottage pie, it is unthinkable to omit it.

1.5kg best minced beef

2 onions

200ml stock

4 grates nutmeg

Tomato ketchup

Worcestershire sauce

Peel and finely chop the onions. Heat a large frying pan, and cook the onion in hot oil for a minute. Add the mince and brown the meat carefully, taking care to break it down to remove any lumps. Add the stock, nutmeg, salt and pepper, and leave to simmer for at least an hour. A few minutes before serving, add a spoonful of Worcestershire sauce.

Mince is nearly always eaten with mash; for a pie, it should be mixed with a spoonful or two of tomato ketchup, placed in a suitable oven-proof dish, covered with mashed potato, and baked at a moderate heat until a light, golden crust has formed.

Crab boulet

In the hands of Miss Eula Mae Dore of Louisiana, these crab cakes are just too good. She is a cook of the highest order, and makes a virtue of simplicity.

225g fresh crab meat

50g brown crab meat

1 slice white bread, crust removed

1 small onion

1 small handful flat-leaf parsley

Sea salt and freshly-milled pepper

Tabasco

1 dish well-seasoned flour

Oil, for frying

Pick through the white crab meat and remove any shell. Place it in a bowl along with the brown meat. Chop and whizz the bread into very fine breadcrumbs, and add these to the bowl, too. Peel and grate the onion, pick and chop the parsley, and put them in the bowl. Add a shake or two of Tabasco, sea salt and freshly-milled black pepper, then mix, taking care not to over-handle.

Shape the mixture into balls no larger than a cherry, and place on a tray in the fridge for at least half-an-hour. Heat a deep-fat fryer according to the maker's instructions, dip the boulets briefly in the seasoned flour, and fry until golden on the outside and hot within. Splendid served hot with a Bloody Mary.

A lively tomato soup

2.3kg fully ripened tomatoes

200ml olive oil

1 large onion

1 small carrot

2 sticks celery

6 cloves garlic

1 litre pale chicken stock

200ml passata (sieved tomatoes)

A fully-charged pepper mill

Sea salt

Tabasco

Worcestershire sauce

Tomato ketchup

Bring a large pan of water to the boil and plunge in the tomatoes for 10 seconds only. Remove, lay out out on a tray to cool, then peel off the skins and chop the flesh. Peel the carrot, onion, garlic and celery, and chop into very small pieces. Over a low heat in a large pan, soften the chopped vegetables in the olive oil, then add the tomatoes to the pot, along with the stock, passata and some salt and pepper.

Bring the soup to a boil, stirring from time to time, and leave to simmer for an hour or so. The tomatoes should be completely collapsed and the soup wholly blended. If there are any residual seeds, then by all means sieve the soup, but the texture is fine left as it is. Stir in two or three tablespoons of tomato ketchup, a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce and a cavalier amount of Tabasco. Crotons spread with horseradish cream make a fantastically good accompaniment to this soup.

Avocado and prawn marie rose

Very, very popular, once upon a time.

3 fully-ripened huss avocados

300-400g whole prawns in their shell (frozen or fresh)

280ml double cream

1 tsp Tabasco

2 tbsp tomato ketchup

1 tsp Worcestershire sauce

1 tbsp Cognac

Juice of 1/2 a lemon

Salt and milled white pepper

Make the sauce earlier in the day. Stir the ketchup, Tabasco, Worcestershire sauce, Cognac and lemon juice into the cream, then season with salt and pepper. Cover and chill. Prepare the prawns: if cooked and frozen, shell them; or, if fresh, cook them first then shell them.

This dish should be assembled just moments before serving, as the pears will discolour otherwise. Mix the prawns with the sauce, and adjust the seasoning as required. Halve the pears and remove the stones. Remove a few scoops of their flesh, add this to the prawn mixture then pile the lot back into the halved pears. Dust with a little paprika and strew with finely chopped parsley. There was a time when glassmakers of repute made avocado-shaped bowls, so have a look in the back of a cupboard, as this may reveal a lost treasure on which to serve the pears

 Jeremy Lee is the chef at the Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.
