A lively tomato soup 2.3kg fully ripened tomatoes 200ml olive oil 1 large onion 1 small carrot 2 sticks celery 6 cloves garlic 1 litre pale chicken stock 200ml passata (sieved tomatoes) A fully-charged pepper mill Sea salt Tabasco Worcestershire sauce Tomato ketchup Bring a large pan of water to the boil and plunge in the tomatoes for 10 seconds only. Remove, lay out out on a tray to cool, then peel off the skins and chop the flesh. Peel the carrot, onion, garlic and celery, and chop into very small pieces. Over a low heat in a large pan, soften the chopped vegetables in the olive oil, then add the tomatoes to the pot, along with the stock, passata and some salt and pepper. Bring the soup to a boil, stirring from time to time, and leave to simmer for an hour or so. The tomatoes should be completely collapsed and the soup wholly blended. If there are any residual seeds, then by all means sieve the soup, but the texture is fine left as it is. Stir in two or three tablespoons of tomato ketchup, a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce and a cavalier amount of Tabasco. Crotons spread with horseradish cream make a fantastically good accompaniment to this soup. Avocado and prawn marie rose Very, very popular, once upon a time. 3 fully-ripened huss avocados 300-400g whole prawns in their shell (frozen or fresh) 280ml double cream 1 tsp Tabasco 2 tbsp tomato ketchup 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce 1 tbsp Cognac Juice of 1/2 a lemon Salt and milled white pepper Make the sauce earlier in the day. Stir the ketchup, Tabasco, Worcestershire sauce, Cognac and lemon juice into the cream, then season with salt and pepper. Cover and chill. Prepare the prawns: if cooked and frozen, shell them; or, if fresh, cook them first then shell them. This dish should be assembled just moments before serving, as the pears will discolour otherwise. Mix the prawns with the sauce, and adjust the seasoning as required. Halve the pears and remove the stones. Remove a few scoops of their flesh, add this to the prawn mixture then pile the lot back into the halved pears. Dust with a little paprika and strew with finely chopped parsley. There was a time when glassmakers of repute made avocado-shaped bowls, so have a look in the back of a cupboard, as this may reveal a lost treasure on which to serve the pears  Jeremy Lee is the chef at the Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: The week after Sarah Kane's tragic death, I visited the Essex village where she had lived to lead a Lent Bible study and met a number of her friends. So I read with particular interest and sadness Sarah and Simon Kane's comments on Christianity (A Sad Hurrah, July 1).
fields.body:
The week after Sarah Kane's tragic death, I visited the Essex village where she had lived to lead a Lent Bible study and met a number of her friends. So I read with particular interest and sadness Sarah and Simon Kane's comments on Christianity (A Sad Hurrah, July 1).

The first conclusion that I drew from my visit was that a 'compassionate Christianity', which lacks the burning condemnation of injustice found in the prophets and the teaching of Jesus, will lead to many more Christian casualties in a world spoilt by economic injustice, ethnic cleansing and religious bigotry. The second was that her favourite Beckett quote, 'God, the bastard', and Jesus's cry on the cross, 'My God, my God why have you forsaken me', have much in common.

I will be eternally grateful to Sarah for challenging my own faith and, I hope, enabling me to minister more effectively to those people who feel like she did about 'Cruelties carried out in the name of God'.
Roger Barking
Bishop of Barking

Many thanks for the interview with John Cusack, a hero (and fantasy) of mine for a long time (Being John Cusack, July 1). It's nice to know there are other 'recovering Catholics' out there. I wasn't as lucky as him: I suffered until I was 18, and am still getting over it 15 years on. Thanks also to Chris Floyd, for the great photos, which now adorn my walls.
Sally Rickaby
mamser@bath.ac.uk

Could Julie Burchill interview the actors in future? I doubt she'd ponder over Cusack making Con Air for the money, being smart about drugs and thinking 'women are great'. Suzie Mackenzie's gummy flirting was so insipid, she could be a character by Nick Hornby. Or was that the point?
M Willis
London WC2

Reading Matthew Klam's column on violence in the US (Front, July 1) just after reading Julie Burchill's puerile outpourings of the soul, I wondered how many of the criminals Klam cited derived 'a mild sexual pleasure' from their actions, or how many had voiced paeans to King Coke.
Dorothy Soulsby
Stockport, Cheshire

Stupendous! Julie Burchill was on absolute top-form this week: as razor-sharp as any of her enemies' finely manicured nails. And to think I didn't used to like her column.
Emma Sutcliffe
emma@arehaus.com

While I can understand that Julie Burchill may have a burning desire to slag off her ex (although to still hate the guy after 16 years is a tad obsessive), who has committed the unforgivable crime of having considerably more talent and success than her, is it entirely appropriate to allow her to conduct her vendetta from within your pages?
Ron Graves,
Birkenhead

In response to the debate on food allergies (Dear Weekend, passim). We could take a wider view, namely that many degenerative illnesses such as allergies and asthma are on the increase because we are keeping alive more people who years ago would have succumbed. No longer do only the fittest survive, as nature intended - and that, over the years, dilutes the gene pool.
Gemma Thwaite (SRMN)
Brighton

fields.headline: Amazon addiction
fields.standfirst: 'The invisible glasses and tablets had cured me of 'author blindness': the inability to see right in front of your own eyes your own book'
fields.trailText: 'The invisible glasses and tablets had cured me of 'author blindness': the inability to see right in front of your own eyes your own book'
fields.body:
I ring my publisher from a phonebox outside a bookshop. I think it was Boots The Bookshop, or was it Books EG. Anyway, I was behaving with the crushed childishness of a newly-published writer and complaining that my book, out only a matter of days, was not stocked in this large bookshop. As far as I could tell, it seemed to stock every new release except mine. I admit that my book doesn't feature anyone called Harry - or Tom or Dick or, indeed, Jamie - but then, not all books do. Not yet, anyway.

Julian, the target of my frustration, managed somehow, with publisher's guile, to hold my hand down the phone and stroke my anguished brow. He suggested that I wear the special invisible pair of glasses he had supplied me with for such an occasion, and swallow the tablets he had given me. Go back into the shop, he gently said, massaging my shoulders and pouring me a Martini, and look again. With newly-published-author obedience, I looked again. Under "M" in the new-release section, possibly just where they should be, were copies of my book. The special invisible pair of glasses and the tablets had cured me of what I believe is called "author blindness". The immature inability to see right in front of your own eyes your own book.

A more modern author affliction is "Amazon addiction". The on-line bookseller features a sales rating for all the books it sells. Every book in print is rated, which means there is something like a top-million book chart, updated every hour. When you have your own book out, you get hooked on finding where it is rated, and soon come to the conclusion that anything in the top 5,000 is a kind of hit. You also realise that the difference between numbers 100 and 100,000 is probably only about half a dozen copies. As you bob up and down in the hundreds and the thousands, the whole thing becomes endlessly fascinating. You receive instant feedback, which can be both a blessing and a curse. Up into double figures because of a review in this paper, up so high near the Bryson's and Rowling's that I can smell Tony Parson's aftershave - blessed! A temporary slump into four figures - cursed! I also note, thanks to another great Amazon service, that people who bought my book also bought The Return Of The Naked Chef, and feel both blessed and cursed. I should point out that the only recipe in my book is for dry Weetabix spread with Stork margarine.

You begin to notice a direct relationship between reviews, interviews and radio appearances, and the number you find yourself at in the Amazon top million. An appearance on the Nicky Campbell Show (Round The Horne meets a young Jimmy Young) helps keep my rating healthy. Nicky in passing gives me a quote I hope we can use in the publicity for the book: my book, he says, is sort of about death (it's also about life and, in fact, the lot in between). This being Radio 5, the subject is summer holidays. One second Nicky is rattling on about Benidorm, and then he changes the subject with Zidane-like agility. He turns to me and suggests with the kind of disorienting abruptness that means he really is worthy of presenting Newsnight: "Not the kind of book you can read on the beach!" For a moment I suffer from author dumbness. It is only later that I think of the correct reply: "No, but it's a big help if it rains."

I record an appearance on the Sky Book Show. This means a drive out into the tangled wilds of west London. The route to BBC TV Centre from my house takes me past Kenneth Williams's old flat. The drive to Sky television centre takes me past a house that Sid James once lived in. This seems fitting - Auntie Kenneth as the BBC, ever so camp and anal, Uncle Sid as Sky, hearty and boisterous. I feel flattered to appear on the only regular books show on television; the two men responsible for it appearing 52 weeks a year, Chris Pearson and David Freedland, are rightly proud of it.

It's part of the continuing puzzle of what is actually happening to terrestrial television that you will not find any programmes dedicated to books on BBC2 or Channel 4. As Chris explains, a book show is not a mystery, and it is not about keeping up with the fluff of fashion and neurotically searching out the newest hip young thing. Books are about people, and feelings, and life, and conversation. Really, a book show on BBC 2 or Channel 4 - simple, smart, informative - should be as regular a fixture as the weather. But then, perhaps BBC2 thinks that The Naked Chef is a book show.

Driving home after the show, I notice that for all the New Labour, Terence Conran, Wallpaper* and dot.coms, we are still a nation of lace curtains. Behind the curtains, home world is as mysterious as the world of Harry Potter, or as ordinary as Jamie Oliver's. I head towards a Waterstones. I put on my special glasses and swallow my publisher's tablet. I walk into the shop and, hallelujah, I can see! I can see nothing.

 Paul Morley's book, Nothing, is published by Faber. Alexander Chancellor is away.

webTitle: How to... enjoy your time on secondment

fields.headline: How to... enjoy your time on secondment
fields.standfirst: The most important item to pack is a positive attitude
fields.trailText: The most important item to pack is a positive attitude
fields.body:
Bangor has never been on my wishlist of places to visit," admits systems programmer Richard Barker, "so when my boss told me that there was a project they needed me to work on for six months, and that's where it was, I was less than impressed. Although I was told that I was under no obligation to go, I really didn't feel that I had a choice - it was clear that the powers that be wanted me to take the secondment and that it would be extremely positive for my career progression. So I agreed."

Agreeing to a secondment is one thing, adopting a positive attitude to it - particularly if, like Barker, you're not keen in the first place - is something very different. All too often secondments are not a particularly enticing prospect - months spent staying in a hotel, working with people you don't know, away from friends and family, all so that you can come back after six months and feel totally out of place in your own company.

"If you view a secondment in those kind of terms you might as well not go," believes Averil Leimon, director of Plus Consulting. "It's fairly essential to adopt a positive attitude and look for the benefits that six months in a new company and a new area will give you. Although being away from your friends and your office might seem intimidating or an effort, it is a chance to meet different people, to observe different working practices and broaden your experience."

Three months after returning from Bangor, Barker admits that the secondment has had some benefits. "I can't honestly say that I enjoyed my time there, but it was positive in that I'm much more confident in myself," he says. "Suddenly I was with a group of people I didn't know, and they were the only people to spend time with in the evening.

"After a few weeks we all became quite close - and it meant we worked far more productively. It really taught me the importance of getting to know your colleagues - and how much better you can work as a team if you spend some time together away from your desks."

However, six months is a long time to be miserable - even if you are learning new workplace skills. "If you're going on a secondment that you're not terribly happy about the key thing to do is plan for it," says Leimon. "Think about what might make it difficult and how you can make it better.

"For example, hotel rooms are terribly impersonal - so take a few photographs and prop them up, and take a CD player or personal stereo and your favourite music. Check up the train times and see if you can leave slightly early on Friday afternoon - or if you can't travel home, make plans for friends to come and see you."

For assistant TV producer Serena Macintosh, it wasn't until three months into her secondment to Manchester from Southampton that she realised how unhappy she was. "I'd accepted a six month secondment - I wasn't overly keen to go, but I arranged to come home each weekend and tried to learn everything that I could. At first I got on quite well, but gradually I started to worry that people back at my old company were forgetting about me. I know it sounds stupid, but I really started to feel as if I wasn't going to have a job to come back to."

Things came to a head three months into the secondment, when Macintosh was told by her boss that they wanted to extend her time to nine months. "I simply burst into tears," she says. "I felt as if it was proof that they weren't interested in having me back. My boss was really understanding and took me for a drink and it all came out - how lonely I felt, how isolated, how I felt that instead of increasing my standing in the company I was just being forgotten about."

"It's incredibly important to maintain regular links with your own company whilst on secondment," says Imogen Daniels, adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development. "Attending a team meeting or briefing every couple of weeks means you can update people on what you are working on - and also catch up on what's been happening at their end. Its hugely important to feel confident about slotting back into the company at the end of a secondment - if you are feeling anxious then talk to the person who is running the secondment and explain your fears."

For Macintosh the secondment ended up being an extremely positive experience - two months after she returned, she was promoted. "Looking back I did get in a state," she admits, "when all I needed to do was talk to someone to straighten things out.

"From my experience I would say it's imperative to be honest about how it's going and make sure there is someone in your old office to talk things through with. Hotel rooms can be very lonely places if you've only got worries to keep you company."

If you don't remember anything else...

If you go on secondment with a negative attitude, you won't gain from the experience. Focus on the positive and see it as a finite amount of time in which to learn all you can.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Financial advice
fields.standfirst: Carlton Crabbe, an account associate with Chase De Vere Investments, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Carlton Crabbe, an account associate with Chase De Vere Investments, talks to Miles Brignallv
fields.body:
I know the industry used to have an image problem but I think that has changed over the last five years. Besides, I used to be in an even more unpopular profession - journalism - so at least I'm moving up the ladder!

Essentially my job is to advise clients face to face on how to place their investments and I deal with everything from Isas, mortgages, bonds, insurance policies and Peps right through to premium bonds. The only area I can't advise on is individual shares.

The process starts with a first appointment either in the client's home or here in our offices to establish what the client has in the way of existing investments, how much they are looking to invest and, most importantly, over what timescale they expect the return.

If we had a typical client - which we probably don't - they might be a couple looking to plan for school fees or take early retirement. Equally, it could be someone with a lump sum to invest.

From the initial meeting, I go away and prepare a recommendation based on what the client has told me. Because there are nearly 30,000 financial products available we have a research department whose sole purpose is to examine new products. Only once they are thoroughly checked for probity will the company allow us to use them and we are constantly updated on the best.

I then take the proposal back to the client and assuming they agree, the investments are then made on their behalf. Because things change, we track the markets closely and it's not unheard of for us to remove our client's money if things aren't performing as planned. On top of this, each client receives an annual review of their portfolio where we can make adjustments as required.

Although we do sometimes charge fees, most of our income is earned through commission on the investments we put our clients into. I'm aware of the perceived conflict that that might present, but ultimately we are there to give the best, impartial advice and our reputation is based on doing just that. Besides, many of the products we suggest such as a high interest deposit account don't pay us any commission.

In general I'm out of the office two days a week and on average I'll meet three new clients each week. I like meeting people and find helping them with what can be hugely important decisions very rewarding.

I started doing my Financial Planning Certificate while I was still producing personal finance bulletins for the BBC. The thing I like about this job is that at the BBC we always had to give general advice; today I'm advising real people and matching them to real investments.

On top of this, each client receives an annual review of their portfolio where we can make adjustments as required. Although we do sometimes charge fees, most of our income is earned through commission on the investments we put our clients into. I'm aware of the perceived conflict that that might present, but ultimately we are there to give the best, impartial advice and our reputation is based on doing just that. Besides, many of the products we suggest such as a high interest deposit account don't pay us any commission. In general I'm out of the office two days a week and on average I'll meet three new clients each week. I like meeting people and find helping them with what can be hugely important decisions very rewarding. I started doing my Financial Planning Certificate while I was still producing personal finance bulletins for the BBC. The thing I like about this job is that at the BBC we always had to give general advice; today I'm advising real people and matching them to real investments.

webTitle: Graduate recruiters rush to the internet

fields.headline: Graduate recruiters rush to the internet
fields.standfirst: Applying for a job online has never been easier: soon, you could find work in less than an hour
fields.trailText: Applying for a job online has never been easier: soon, you could find work in less than an hour
fields.body:
The great sci-fi dream was for everything to be done by computer. Data exchange is fast and efficient. The screen becomes the only means of communication, and the user interface performs life-like functions. Outside the IT industry itself, this dream has not yet come true. But over the next couple of years, graduate recruitment may become the first non-specialist area of human activity to be fully digitalised.

This coming revolution relies on three simple factors. Students are more e-literate than other adults; they're all looking for jobs; and the most successful companies have to attract and identify the best people in order to succeed in the future.

These three factors are combining to force graduate recruiters on to the web, and, once there, to push them towards exclusive use of online application (because PCs can interact where paper can't, making selection much more efficient).

The first part of this process is almost complete. Nearly two-thirds of companies recruiting graduates now accept online applications alongside paper forms.

For students, this initial transition has created a few minor problems, and some unforeseen benefits.

The few problems associated with e-applications lie in the nature of the medium. Email is fast and informal, qualities not normally associated with the filling out of application forms.

Recruiters report that students can easily slip into the sort of email habits which do not impress. These include rambling (because space is often not limited in the way it is on a conventional form) and frequent occurrences of the original bugs in the system: spelling and grammar.

Many online application forms do not have grammar or spell checks, and this is a calculated act of unhelpfulness. Employers want to know one of two things. Can you spell, and if you can't, are you professional enough to get it checked?

Printing off a copy before sending it is essential not only for proofreading purposes, but also because it lets applicants look back at what they have said if they are called for interview.

The unforeseen benefit of web-based recruitment lies in the fact that the newness of the medium encourages students to make new kinds of judgements about their potential employers. Brochures may have been highly branded, but there was little information to be gleaned from the way the information was accessed, presented and managed.

Websites, because they are interactive, tell you far more about how a company views itself and its potential employees. Judgements that can be made about websites include the technical (are you downloading forms and software or accessing it directly on the company server?), ease of use (does it take long to download and is the layout, structure and menu clear?), the communicative (can you follow the progress of your application?), convenience (can you save and return, and does it all take less than an hour?), as well as a whole range of branding judgements.

Good websites are not created by accident. As last week's briefing paper from the Association of Graduate Recruiters pointed out, "A striking feature of the more successful web-users was the extent to which managers from corporate communications or marketing, IT and graduate recruitment had worked together as a real team."

A poor website reveals far more about organisational fault lines than the ubiquitously well-produced brochure ever could. If websites are already encouraging students to think in a new way about which companies they apply to, the transition to receiving applications exclusively online is going to increase this tendency enormously. The first issue however is one of access. Some companies remain nervous of going all the way.

"We're not sure that internet usage is sufficiently well established to get rid of paper altogether," says Graham Philpott, graduate recruitment manager for Thames Water. "We have concerns that certain groups of people like those at less well-equipped universities or those on second jobs might have less opportunity to apply."

Other companies are pushing ahead. At BT, all applications have been online since the beginning of this recruitment year. "In terms of other access issues, we know that our gender and ethnicity profile is better, and that the general standard is higher compared to running paper and online systems in parallel," says Dave Wilson, employment policy manager.

This is the key benefit that online recruitment can offer and is the reason it will be irresistible: applications are better targeted and the selection process less prone to subjectivity. By going fully online, companies can put competency questionnaires, ability tests, personality profiles and cultural fit indicators at the beginning of the process rather than placing them, where for reasons of cost they have always been, in the middle.

This generates fewer, but better quality applications through a mixture of self-selection and gentle rejection.

If you don't fit the job specification you'll find out straight away - and on the best sites you will be given feedback which should help you find a job which suits you better.

"The Holy Grail of recruitment has always been self-selection," says Roy Davis of human resource consultants SHL. "Instead of firing off CVs in all directions, applicants will soon be able to make informed judgements about an organisation up front just from the way the selection process is carried out in the first instance. Assessment centres will no longer be a sifting event, they will be a hiring event."

Whether you want to join a company or they want you to join them is no longer a decision that takes many months of careful mutual consideration. In the next year or two, for many graduates, it could be something that happens within the hour in front of a PC.
